Judd"}],"pages":{"1745307":{"pageid":1745307,"ns":0,"title":"Cledus T. Judd","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country music artist (born 1964)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Cledus T. Judd\n| image_size      =\n| birth_name      = James Barry Poole\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1964|12|18}}\n| origin          = [[Cartersville, Georgia]], United States\n| instrument      = Vocals\n| genre           = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country music|Country]]\n* [[parody music|parody]]\n}}\n| occupation      = {{flatlist|\n* Singer-songwriter\n* [[parodist]]\n}}\n| years_active    = {{flatlist|\n* 1995\u20132015\n* 2018\u2013present\n}}\n| label           = {{flatlist|\n* Cross Three<ref name=\"countrymailbag.com\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.countrymailbag.com/bios/cledus_t_judd_bio.asp|title=Country Mailbag \u2013 Country Music's Top Interactive Radio Show|website=Countrymailbag.com}}</ref>\n* [[Razor & Tie]]\n* [[Monument Records|Monument Nashville]]\n* [[Audium Entertainment|Audium]]\n* [[Curb Records|Curb]]\n* E1\n* [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros. Nashville]]\n* RoseyMo\n* [[Average Joes Entertainment|Average Joes]]\n}}\n| spouse = [[Julie Reeves]]\n}}\n'''James Barry Poole''' (born December 18, 1964) is an American [[country music]] artist who records under the name '''Cledus T. Judd'''. Known primarily for his parodies of popular country songs, he has been called the [[\"Weird Al\" Yankovic]] of country music, and his albums are usually an equal mix of original comedy songs and parodies. Judd has released 11 studio albums and two EPs, and several singles have entered the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. His chart peak is the number-48 \"I Love NASCAR\", a parody of [[Toby Keith]]'s 2003 single \"[[I Love This Bar]]\".\n\n==Musical career==\nJudd moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], to pursue a career in country music. By 1993, he was living in a house with [[Daron Norwood]] and preparing to move back home until he wrote a parody of \"[[Indian Outlaw]]\" by [[Tim McGraw]], which made him decide to pursue a career as a parodist.<ref name=\"stark\">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/legal-and-management/6443453/cledus-t-judd-on-his-decision-to-bow-out-of-the-music|title=Cledus T. Judd on His Decision to Bow Out of the Music Business for a 'Higher Purpose'|last=Stark|first=Phyllis|date=January 15, 2015|work=Billboard.com|access-date=January 16, 2015}}</ref>\n\n===1995\u20131999===\nCledus T. Judd released his debut album, ''[[Cledus T. Judd (No Relation)]]'', on [[Razor & Tie Records]] in 1995, the \"(No Relation)\" part of the title being a reference to [[Wynonna Judd|Wynonna]] and [[Naomi Judd]].<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p144284/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Cledus T. Judd biography|last=Huey|first=Steve|work=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=January 9, 2009}}</ref> Two non-country parodies were also included on this album: one of the [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]]' \"[[Hotel California]]\", and one of \"[[We Are the World]]\", a 1980s charity single credited to [[USA for Africa]]. Judd's parody, entitled \"We Own the World\", satirized the marriage of [[Lisa Marie Presley]] and [[Michael Jackson]].\n\n''[[I Stoled This Record]]'' followed in 1996. This album, despite not producing a chart single, earned [[RIAA]] gold certification for shipping 500,000 copies. This album included parodies of two [[Shania Twain]] songs: \"[[(If You're Not in It for Love) I'm Outta Here!]]\" became \"(I'm Not in Here for Love) Just a Beer\" and \"[[Any Man of Mine]]\" became \"If Shania Was Mine\". [[John Michael Montgomery]]'s \"[[Sold (The Grundy County Auction Incident)]]\" was also parodied twice on this album.\n\nHis third album, ''[[Did I Shave My Back for This?]]'' (a take-off on [[Deana Carter]]'s ''[[Did I Shave My Legs for This?]]''), included his first duet, with [[Buck Owens]] on the original track \"First Redneck on the Internet\". The album also parodied [[Alan Jackson]], [[Joe Diffie]], [[Brooks & Dunn]], [[Mindy McCready]], and [[Trace Adkins]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\n1998's ''[[Juddmental]]'' was his final album for Razor & Tie. It included a duet, this time with [[Daryle Singletary]] on \"Ricky Tidwell's Momma's Gonna Play Football\", a non-parody song previously recorded by [[Tim Wilson (comedian)|Tim Wilson]]. This album once again parodied a Twain song, with her \"[[Honey, I'm Home]]\" becoming \"Shania, I'm Broke\". The [[Garth Brooks]]/[[Trisha Yearwood]] duet \"[[In Another's Eyes]]\" was also parodied on this compilation. It was originally to have been on Judd's previous album, but Brooks had initially expressed concern over a parody compromising the song's chances at winning a [[Grammy Award]].<ref name=\"countrymailbag.com\"/>\n\n===2000\u20132005===\nAfter leaving Razor & Tie Records, Judd signed to [[Monument Records]] Nashville in 2000 to release his fifth album, ''[[Just Another Day in Parodies]]''. This album produced his first chart single in \"My Cellmate Thinks I'm Sexy\", a parody of [[Kenny Chesney]]'s 1999 single \"[[She Thinks My Tractor's Sexy]]\" which referenced Chesney's and McGraw's 2000 arrest for stealing a Mounted Reserve officer's horse. The parody charted at No.&nbsp;61 on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]). Following this song was another chart single, \"How Do You Milk a Cow\" (based on [[Toby Keith]]'s \"[[How Do You Like Me Now?! (song)|How Do You Like Me Now?!]]\"), which peaked at No.&nbsp;67; the music video also features Toby Keith. In 2002, he released ''[[Cledus Envy]]'', followed later that year by a Christmas album entitled ''[[Cledus Navidad]]''. At the end of the year, Judd also made an appearance in the music video for Keith's \"[[Who's Your Daddy? (Toby Keith song)|Who's Your Daddy?]]\".\n\nHis last release for Monument was a six-song [[extended play|EP]] called ''[[A Six Pack of Judd]]'', released in 2003. After Monument closed its Nashville division, he signed to [[Koch Records]] Nashville to release a second EP, the four-song ''[[The Original Dixie Hick]]'', later in 2003. This release, which contained parodies pertaining to the [[Dixie Chicks]], also produced his third chart single in \"Martie, Natalie and Emily (The Continuing Saga Of)\", a parody of [[Brad Paisley]]'s \"[[Celebrity (Brad Paisley song)|Celebrity]]\".\n\nJudd's final release for Koch was 2004's ''[[Bipolar and Proud]]''. This album produced two more chart singles for him, including his highest-peaking, the No.&nbsp;48 \"I Love NASCAR\", which parodied Keith's \"[[I Love This Bar]]\" and included guest vocals from Keith himself. Following this song was the No.&nbsp;58 \"Bake Me A Country Ham\", based on [[Tracy Lawrence]]'s \"[[Paint Me a Birmingham]]\".\n\n===2006\u20132014 ===\nBy mid-2005, Judd had announced plans to release a tribute album to [[Ray Stevens]] entitled ''[[Boogity, Boogity - A Tribute to the Comedic Genius of Ray Stevens]]'', containing [[cover song|covers]] of Stevens's material with several guest vocalists. Due to the closure of Koch's Nashville division, however, this album was delayed until 2007, when Judd signed to [[Asylum-Curb Records]] and released it in August. Shortly before its release, he made his sixth chart appearance with the non-album song \"Illegals\".\n\nJudd re-signed to Koch in 2009, after the label was renamed E1 Music. In January of that year, he released the single \"Waitin' on Obama\" (a parody of Brad Paisley's \"[[Waitin' on a Woman]]\") referencing [[Barack Obama]]'s election as President of the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.cmt.com/2009-01-08/cledus-t-judd-counts-the-days-waitin-on-obama/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090116111904/http://blog.cmt.com/2009-01-08/cledus-t-judd-counts-the-days-waitin-on-obama/|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 16, 2009|title=Cledus T. Judd Counts the Days \"Waitin' on Obama\"|last=Bonaguro|first=Alison|date=January 9, 2008|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]|access-date=January 9, 2009}}</ref><ref>[http://www.tennessean.com/article/20090106/COLUMNIST0501/901060341 Cledus T. Judd unveils a new Obama parody] Tennessean.com</ref> This is the first single from Judd's latest album, ''[[Polyrically Uncorrect]]'', released on June 30. Its second single is \"Garth Must Be Busy\", a parody of [[Brooks & Dunn]]'s \"[[God Must Be Busy]]\" which features Brooks & Dunn as guest vocalists. Its third single is \"(If I Had) [[Kellie Pickler]]'s Boobs\".\n\nHe transferred to [[Warner Bros. Records]] in 2012 to release ''[[Parodyziac!!]]'' The album includes a parody of [[Little Big Town]]'s \"[[Pontoon (song)|Pontoon]]\" titled \"Honeymoon\", the video of which was directed by [[Laura Bell Bundy]].<ref name=\"billboard.com\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/474621/cledus-t-judd-parodies-miranda-lambert-little-big-town-on-parodyziac|title=Cledus T. Judd Parodies Miranda Lambert, Little Big Town on 'Parodyziac'|date=October 1, 2012|website=Billboard.com|access-date=July 9, 2019}}</ref>\n\nJudd moved again to RoseyMo, a division of [[Average Joes Entertainment]], in late 2014. On November 5, he released a new single titled \"Luke Bryan\", a parody of [[Robin Thicke]]'s \"[[Blurred Lines]]\", which features guest rapping from [[Colt Ford]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2014/11/cledus-t-judd-releases-new-parody-single-luke-bryan/|title=Cledus T. Judd Releases New Parody Single \"Luke Bryan\"|last=Stephenson|first=Troy|date=November 6, 2014|work=[[MusicRow]]|access-date=November 6, 2014}}</ref>\n\n===2015 retirement ===\nIn a January 2015 article in ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'', Judd announced that he would be retiring from the music industry, as he felt that he had lost the desire to continue, and wanted to focus on raising his daughter instead. He also revealed past struggles with a [[cocaine]] addiction and suicide attempts, and said that he made the decision to change his lifestyle after becoming baptized.<ref name=\"stark\" /> In 2016, he issued a three-CD memoir titled ''Things I Remember Before I Forget''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thecountrynote.com/in-the-news/cledus-t-judd-releases-things-i-remember-before-i-forget/|title=Cledus T. Judd Releases 'Things I Remember Before I Forget'|date=November 18, 2016|work=The Country Note|access-date=August 11, 2018}}</ref>\n\nJudd was one of the co-writers of the song \"Three Feet of Water\", the final track on [[Brantley Gilbert]]'s album ''[[The Devil Don't Sleep]]''.\n\n===2018 comeback ===\nIn mid-2018, Judd announced his return to the music industry by releasing a new parody song and music video titled, \"(Weight's Goin') Up Down, Up Down\", a parody of \"[[Up Down (Morgan Wallen song)|Up Down]]\" by [[Morgan Wallen]].<ref name=\"up down\">{{cite news|url=http://www.herald-dispatch.com/features_entertainment/dave-lavender-cledus-t-judd-releases-parody-single/article_773977fe-9351-11e8-b133-f3bf89affa0b.html|title=Cledus T. Judd releases parody single|date=July 27, 2018|newspaper=[[The Herald-Dispatch]]|access-date=July 30, 2018}}</ref> It was followed by a parody of [[Bebe Rexha]]'s and [[Florida Georgia Line]]'s \"[[Meant to Be (Bebe Rexha song)|Meant to Be]]\" called \"Gotta Pee\".<ref name=\"Country Music Television\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cmt.com/video-clips/r3ooge|title = Cledus T. Judd - \"Gotta Pee\" - Video Clips from CMT| date=November 27, 2018 }}</ref>\n\n==Radio and television work==\nJudd has toured as an emcee with such acts as [[Brooks and Dunn]], [[Brad Paisley]], [[Trace Adkins]], [[Toby Keith]], the [[Dixie Chicks]], [[Shania Twain]], and [[Montgomery Gentry]]. Judd's television work includes a stint as the co-host of ''CMT Most Wanted Live'' from 2002 to 2004 and as a \"special correspondent\" on the 2005 season of ''[[Nashville Star]]''. Additionally, he was one of the featured contestants on Season Five of [[VH1]]'s reality show ''[[Celebrity Fit Club (US TV series)|Celebrity Fit Club]]''.\n\nHe also hosted the ''Cledus T. Party Morning Show'' for [[WQYK-FM]] in [[Tampa, Florida]]. In January 2008, he returned to Atlanta as the morning host at 94.9/The Bull, [[WUBL-FM]]. In September 2010, he returned to WQYK-FM as co-host of the ''Cledus and Dave Morning Show''. On November 19, 2012, Judd became the co-host of ''The Cletus T. Judd Party with Clint & Judy'' morning show on [[iHeartMedia]]-owned [[WTCR-FM]] in [[Huntington, West Virginia]]. At WTCR, Judd joins longtime morning hosts [[Clint McElroy]] & Judy Eaton.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wsaz.com/news/headlines/Comedian-Cledus-T-Judd-Joining-WTCR-Morning-Show-178095971.html|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130209135909/http://www.wsaz.com/news/headlines/Comedian-Cledus-T-Judd-Joining-WTCR-Morning-Show-178095971.html|url-status=dead|title=Comedian Cledus T. Judd Joining WTCR Morning Show|archive-date=February 9, 2013}}</ref> Judd stated that moving to WTCR allows him to live closer to his daughter.\n\n==Musical style==\nJudd has been called the [[\"Weird\" Al Yankovic]] of country music.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1478117/20030911/brock_chad.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930034038/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1478117/20030911/brock_chad.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=September 30, 2007|website=CMT.com |title=Chad Brock : Cledus T. Judd Needles Chesney and McGraw<!-- Bot generated title -->}}</ref> Judd's albums typically contain a mix of parody songs and original songs. His parodies are often topical in nature, such as \"My Cellmate Thinks I'm Sexy\", a parody of [[Kenny Chesney]]'s \"[[She Thinks My Tractor's Sexy]]\" which addressed Chesney's and [[Tim McGraw]]'s 2000 arrest after stealing a Mounted Reserve deputy's horse;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=WE&s_site=Kansas&p_multi=WE&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EADB22C25D915EA&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=Yoakam headlines triple country threat|last=Rush|first=Diane Sams|date=September 1, 2000|work=Wichita Eagle|access-date=January 6, 2009}}</ref> or \"Waitin' on Obama\", which he released shortly before President [[Barack Obama]] took office in January 2009.\n\nInitially, Judd sang in an intentionally off-key, nasal voice with an affected [[Southern American English|Southern accent]], described by ''[[Country Standard Time]]'' critic Ken Burke as \"[[Junior Samples]] on [[helium]].\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=573|title=''A Six Pack of Judd''|last=Burke|first=Ken|work=[[Country Standard Time]]|access-date=March 27, 2009}}</ref> Judd stopped affecting his voice on ''A Six Pack of Judd'' and all subsequent albums.\n\n== Personal life ==\nJudd was formerly married to country music singer [[Julie Reeves]]. They have a daughter, Caitlyn. Judd married Amanda Fizer on October 5, 2017<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theboot.com/2008/07/15/cledus-t-judd-celebrates-wedding-no-4/|title=Judd Celebrates Wedding No. 4|last=Cameron|first=Amy|date=July 1, 2008|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]|access-date=July 15, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cledustjudd.net/bio.html\n|title=Cledus T. Judd's . 2009|last=Poole|first=C.J.|year=2009|website=Cledustjudd.net|access-date=July 15, 2009}}</ref> and has two stepchildren, Isabella and Jeremiah.<ref name=\"Herald-Dispatch\">{{Cite news|url=http://www.herald-dispatch.com/features_entertainment/cledus-t-judd-back-with-new-parody-video/article_c665340f-3014-5872-9766-78658a77ba7a.html|title=Cledus T. Judd back with new parody video|author=Dave Lavender|newspaper=[[The Herald-Dispatch]]|access-date=August 19, 2018|language=en}}</ref>\n\nAfter announcing his retirement in 2015, Judd focused on spending time with his family and doing a morning radio show. Once he was done with his radio show in the mornings, he had a lot of downtime and became bored. He then began working on buying and remodeling dilapidated houses.<ref name=\"The Country Note\">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecountrynote.com/in-the-news/cledus-t-judd-back-with-new-parody/|title=Cledus T. Judd Back With New Parody \u2013 The Country Note|date=July 2, 2018|work=The Country Note|access-date=August 19, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nAfter years of retirement, Judd was inspired to return to music by his idol, [[Ray Stevens]], who asked Judd to open for him at a show in Kentucky. Stevens asked Judd why he retired and Judd responded that he did not think he was relevant anymore. Stevens told him that the 1,500 audience members giving Judd a standing ovation said otherwise. With the encouragement of his daughter, Judd decided to make a comeback.<ref name=\"The Country Note\"/><ref name=\"Herald-Dispatch\"/>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"5\"| Peak chart positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| [[Music recording sales certification|Certifications]]<br><small>([[List of best selling music artists|sales threshold]])</small>\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"40\"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]<br><ref name=\"Country Albums\">{{cite web|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=cledus t. judd|chart=Country Albums C}}|title=Cledus T. Nashville]]\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| 14\n| \n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Things I Remember Before I Forget''\n| \n* Release date: 2016\n* Label: BFD\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014 \n| \n|-\n| colspan=\"8\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes the album failed to chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Compilation albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"60\"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]<br><ref name=\"Country Albums\" />\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Cledus Country''\n| \n* Release date: March 30, 1999\n* Label: BMG Special Products\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''The Essenshul Cledus T. Judd''\n| \n* Release date: February 10, 2004\n* Label: Razor & Tie\n| 61\n|-\n| colspan=\"3\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Extended plays===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"4\"| Peak chart positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"40\"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]<br><ref name=\"Country Albums\" />\n! width=\"40\"| [[Billboard 200|US]]<br><ref name=\"Billboard 200\" />\n! width=\"40\"| [[Top Heatseekers|US<br>Heat]]<br><ref>{{cite web|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=cledus t. judd|chart=Heatseekers Albums}}|title=Cledus T. Title\n|-\n| 2000\n| ''I Stoled This Video''\n* Release date: 2000\n* Label: Razor & Tie Home Video\n|-\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n{{Cledus T. Judd}}\n{{Nashville Star}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Judd, Cledus T.}}\n[[Category:1964 births]]\n[[Category:American parodists]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American novelty song performers]]\n[[Category:American radio personalities]]\n[[Category:Average Joes Entertainment artists]]\n[[Category:Curb Records artists]]\n[[Category:MNRK Music Group artists]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Monument Records artists]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Marietta, Georgia]]\n[[Category:Parody musicians]]\n[[Category:Participants in American reality television series]]\n[[Category:Razor & Tie artists]]\n[[Category:Warner Records artists]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Georgia (U.S. state)]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Georgia (U.S. state)]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Gretchen_Wilson","to":"Gretchen Wilson"}],"pages":{"802086":{"pageid":802086,"ns":0,"title":"Gretchen Wilson","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country singer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name = Gretchen Wilson\n| image = GretchenWilsonApr10.jpg\n| caption = Wilson in April 2010\n| background = solo_singer\n| birth_name = Gretchen Frances Wilson\n| birth_date = {{birth date and age|1973|06|26}}<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n| birth_place = [[Pocahontas, Illinois]], U.S.\n| origin = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| instrument = Vocals, guitar\n| genre = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[country rock]]}}\n| occupation = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active = 2003\u2013present\n| label = [[Epic Records|Epic Nashville]], [[Columbia Records|Columbia Nashville]], Redneck \n}}\n\n'''Gretchen Frances Wilson''' (born June 26, 1973, in Pocahontas, Illinois) is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. She made her debut in March 2004 with the [[Grammy Awards|Grammy Award]]-winning single \"[[Redneck Woman]]\", a number-one hit on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts. The song served as the lead-off single of her debut album, ''[[Here for the Party]]''. Wilson followed this album one year later with ''[[All Jacked Up]]'', the title track of which became the highest-debuting single for a female country artist upon its 2005 release. A third album, ''[[One of the Boys (Gretchen Wilson album)|One of the Boys]]'', was released in 2007.\n\nOverall, Wilson has charted 13 singles on the ''Billboard'' country charts, of which five have reached top ten: the number one \"Redneck Woman\", as well as \"[[Here for the Party (song)|Here for the Party]]\" (#3, 2004), \"When I Think About Cheatin'\" (#4, 2004), \"Homewrecker\" (#2, 2005), and \"[[All Jacked Up (song)|All Jacked Up]]\" (#8, 2005). The album ''Here for the Party'' was certified 5\u00d7 multi-platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]] for sales of five million copies, while ''All Jacked Up'' was certified platinum. She has sold over 8.2 million records worldwide.\n\n==Country music career==\n===''Here for the Party''===\n[[File:Gwnp.jpg|thumb|right|Wilson performing in a concert]]\nWilson signed with [[Epic Records]] in 2003 and recorded ''[[Here for the Party]]'' within the year. Her first single, \"[[Redneck Woman]]\", was released in early 2004 and reached the top of the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts and No.&nbsp;22 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. This song was also the first number one country hit by a female in two years.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p657188/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Gretchen Wilson biography|access-date=October 6, 2008|last=Ruhlmann|first=William|work=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> The success of \"Redneck Woman\" prompted an earlier-than-planned release for ''Here for the Party'', and it debuted at No.&nbsp;1 on the ''Billboard'' country chart. It reached No.&nbsp;2 on the ''Billboard'' 200 and ''Billboard'' Internet album sales charts. She performed as a support artist for [[Brooks & Dunn]] and [[Montgomery Gentry]].{{citation needed|date=January 2016}}\n\nShe released the title track to her debut album as the second single. It peaked at No.&nbsp;3 on the ''Billboard'' country chart. Two other songs were released as singles, and both reached the top 10. Released in markets outside the U.S., the album hit No.&nbsp;2 on the Australian country charts (behind [[Kasey Chambers]]) and the top 50 of the Australian charts. ''Here for the Party'' was certified 5\u00d7 multi-platinum by the RIAA.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}}\n\n===''All Jacked Up''===\nOn September 27, 2005, Wilson released her second album, ''[[All Jacked Up]]'',<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> which peaked at No.&nbsp;1 on both the Top 200 and Country album charts and sold 1 million copies. The title track debuted at No.&nbsp;21 on the Hot Country Songs charts, setting a record for the highest debut ever made by a female artist.\n\nThis record was broken in late 2007 by [[Carrie Underwood]]'s \"[[So Small]]\". Despite its high debut, however, \"All Jacked Up\" peaked at No.&nbsp;8 on Hot Country Songs after only eight chart weeks. It was also used, at one time, by [[ESPN]] as the opening theme for its baseball coverage.  Three more singles were released from ''All Jacked Up'': \"I Don't Feel Like Loving You Today\", \"Politically Uncorrect\" (a duet with [[Merle Haggard]]) and \"California Girls\", none of which reached Top 20 on the country charts. These latter two singles were issued on [[Columbia Records]], due to the closure of Epic Records's Nashville division.\n\nWilson's \"I Don't Feel Like Loving You Today\" was nominated for two Grammy Awards: Best Female Country Vocal Performance, and Best Country Song. In 2006, Wilson contributed a well-received cover of [[Kris Kristofferson]]'s \"Sunday Mornin' Coming Down\" on the tribute CD ''The Pilgrim: A Celebration of Kris Kristofferson''.\n\n===''One of the Boys''===\n{{BLP unreferenced section|date=January 2016}}\nOn May 15, 2007, Wilson released her third album, ''[[One of the Boys (Gretchen Wilson album)|One of the Boys]]''. The album debuted at No.&nbsp;5 on the Top 200 and at No.&nbsp;1 on the Country album chart. After 10 weeks, it exited the Billboard Top 200, having sold 178,220 copies at that point. \"Come to Bed\" (a duet with John Rich) and the title track, the first two singles released, both peaked in the 30s on the country charts, while the third and final single (\"You Don't Have to Go Home\") failed to reach the Top 40.\n\n===''I Got Your Country Right Here''===\nOn July 14, 2008, Wilson released a new single, \"Don't Do Me No Good\". This song was intended to be the lead-off single to a fourth studio album, but it failed to reach the Top 40 and the album was delayed. It was followed in 2009 by two more singles, \"The Earrings Song\" and \"If I Could Do It All Again,\" neither of which entered the charts. Wilson then issued a press release on July 28, 2009, stating that she would be parting with Sony Music Nashville.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1617125/gretchen-wilson-sony-music-part-ways.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090731231724/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1617125/gretchen-wilson-sony-music-part-ways.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=July 31, 2009|title=Gretchen Wilson, Sony Music part ways|date=July 28, 2009|work=CMT|access-date=July 28, 2009}}</ref> Wilson then launched Redneck Records, her own record label. \"[[Work Hard, Play Harder]]\" was released to radio on October 26, 2009, as the first single from the label and her fourth studio album, ''[[I Got Your Country Right Here]]'', was finally released on March 30, 2010. Her former label, Columbia Nashville, released her first ''[[Greatest Hits (Gretchen Wilson album)|Greatest Hits]]'' album on January 19, 2010, to finish off her recording contract.\n\nOn July 31, 2008, [[The Black Crowes]] filed a lawsuit against Wilson for copyright violation, alleging that her song \"Work Hard, Play Harder\" copied the Crowes song \"[[Jealous Again (The Black Crowes song)|Jealous Again]]\". Also included in the suit were her label [[Sony BMG]], her publishing company, and the cable network [[TNT (American TV network)|TNT]], which had been using the song in commercials.<ref name=crowes-caw>{{cite news | last=Serpe | first=Gina | title=Black Crowes Caw Out Gretchen Wilson for Alleged Song Stealing | url=http://www.eonline.com/uberblog/b148496_black_crowes_caw_gretchen_wilson.html | publisher=E! Online | date=July 30, 2008 | access-date=July 31, 2008}}</ref> The lawsuit was eventually settled out of court for an undisclosed sum<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ocregister.com/soundcheck/http-480854-strong-wilson.html |title=Gretchen Wilson battles (and gives) back |author=Kelli Skye Fadroski |website=Ocregister.com |date=March 4, 2010 |access-date=January 4, 2016}}</ref> and Black Crowes members [[Chris Robinson (singer)|Chris]] and [[Rich Robinson]] were given songwriting credits.<ref>{{cite web|last=Simbeck |first=Rob |url=http://www.nashvillescene.com/nashville/redneck-woman-gretchen-wilsons-search-for-radio-redemption/Content?oid=1227357 |title=Redneck Woman Gretchen Wilson's search for radio redemption {{pipe}} Cover Story |publisher=Nashville Scene |access-date=January 4, 2016}}</ref>\n\n===''Right on Time'', ''Under the Covers'' and ''Christmas in My Heart''===\nWilson released an album of original songs titled ''[[Right on Time (Gretchen Wilson album)|Right on Time]]'' on April 2, 2013. It was led by the single \"Still Rollin'\". A collection of rock covers titled ''Under the Covers'' was released on June 4, 2013. Wilson released her first Christmas album, ''Christmas in My Heart'', on October 8, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=''Christmas in My Heart'' \u2013 Gretchen Wilson|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/release/christmas-in-my-heart-mr0003998169|work=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=August 11, 2013}}</ref>\n\n==Other ventures==\n===Rock music===\nWhile a country singer first and foremost, Gretchen Wilson has also attracted favorable attention<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tdpri.com/forum/bad-dog-cafe/76557-wow-gretchen-wilson-does-cover-heart.html|title=Wow Gretchen Wilson does a cover of Heart!|publisher=Tdpri.com|access-date=December 10, 2011}}</ref> for her rendition of classic rock songs by [[Heart (band)|Heart]] \u2013 a group which she sees as \"one of the biggest influences on my musical career\".<ref name=\"youtube.com\">{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_KRzICeBXBE |title=Gretchen Wilson Heart's 'Straight On' Live w/John Rich |date=May 10, 2008 |publisher=YouTube |access-date=December 10, 2011 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/_KRzICeBXBE |archive-date=December 21, 2021 |url-status=live }}{{cbignore}}</ref>\n\nShe has appeared several times on the same stage as lead singer [[Ann Wilson]] and guitarist [[Nancy Wilson (rock musician)|Nancy Wilson]], once describing the experience as \"beyond a dream come true\".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://noted.blogs.com/westcoastmusic/2004/12/gretchen_wilson.html |title=Gretchen Wilson (Country Music female artist) Jams With Heart |author=Jean-Luc Raymond |date=December 12, 2004 |website=noted.blogs.com |access-date=December 10, 2011 }}</ref>\n\nShe has sung \"[[Straight On]]\",<ref name=\"youtube.com\"/> \"[[Crazy on You]]\", and \u2013 most notably \u2013 \"[[Barracuda (song)|Barracuda]]\",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BqQkECIn738#|title=Gretchen Wilson & Alice in Chains \u2013 Barracuda|date=October 24, 2008 |publisher=YouTube|access-date=December 10, 2011}}</ref> which she performed with [[Alice in Chains]] and Nancy Wilson on guitar at the [[VH1 Rock Honors|2007 VH1 Rock Honors]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BqQkECIn738|title=Gretchen Wilson & Alice in Chains \u2013 Barracuda|date=October 24, 2008 |publisher=YouTube|access-date=December 10, 2011}}</ref> She also performed, with [[Randy Bachman]], the classic [[The Who|Who]] track \"[[Who Are You (The Who song)|Who Are You]]\" on the album ''Who Are You \u2013 An All Star Tribute to the Who''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/who-are-you-an-all-star-tribute-to-the-who-mw0002417600|title=Who Are You \u2013 An All Star Tribute To The Who|publisher=AllMusic|access-date=January 10, 2015}}</ref> She performed on [[Buckcherry]]'s single \"The Feeling Never Dies\" (from the album ''[[Rock 'n' Roll (Buckcherry album)|Rock 'n' Roll]]''), which was released January 29, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oM-nWOsMEpE |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/oM-nWOsMEpE |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|title=Buckcherry \u2013 The Feeling Never Dies feat. Gretchen Wilson [Audio]|last=Buckcherry|date=January 27, 2016|access-date=March 19, 2018|via=YouTube}}{{cbignore}}</ref>\n\nShe has sung \"[[Even It Up]]\", \"[[Rock and Roll (Led Zeppelin song)|Rock and Roll]]\" and \"[[Barracuda (song)|Barracuda]]\" which she performed with [[Heart (band)|Heart]], [[Jerry Cantrell]], [[Dave Navarro]], [[Duff McKagan]], [[Rufus Wainwright]] and [[Carrie Underwood]] at the [[Decades Rock Live!]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2023}}\n\n==Activism==\n===Politics===\nGretchen Wilson sang the National Anthem (blended with a voice-over of the [[Pledge of Allegiance]]) to a national audience at the [[2008 Republican National Convention|Republican National Convention]] on September 3, 2008, later describing this as a \"once-in-a-lifetime\" experience at a \"historic moment.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.armytimes.com/entertainment/music/gns_gretchenwilson_091008|title=Gretchen Wilson describes 'surreal' convention performance \u2013 Entertainment, Music|publisher=Army Times|access-date=December 10, 2011}}</ref> Wilson and her band also performed during a rally for [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] presidential candidate [[John McCain]] and vice-presidential candidate [[Sarah Palin]] at [[Lunken Airport]] in [[Cincinnati]], Ohio, on October 22, 2008, to a crowd of approximately 12,000 supporters. Palin started the rally by exclaiming that she couldn't wait to get Wilson's autograph. Wilson played a version of the [[Heart (band)|Heart]] song [[Barracuda (song)|\"Barracuda\"]] for Palin.<ref>[https://content.usatoday.com/topics/article/People/Celebrities/Musicians,+Composers,+Singers,+Groups/Gretchen+Wilson/0gkn7ZR4VScEX/1 \"Palin, McCain Rally At Airport\"], ''USA Today'', October 23, 2008.</ref>\n\nIn September 2024 she appeared at a Wisconsin rally for presidential candidate Donald Trump, where she sang \"Redneck Woman\" and then addressed the crowd from the podium.<ref>https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/elections/2024/09/07/takeaways-from-donald-trumps-rally-in-mosinee-wisconsin/75057336007/</ref>  She said, \"the American dream that I have been fortunate enough to find will more most certainly be lost forever if we do not show up and vote for freedom in November. It is on us. Let's make sure we, the people, do all we can to save our country by voting for President Trump and JD Vance.\"\n\n===Charities and public service===\nWilson has been active in support for children's charities, adult education, and the fight against obesity. Initiatives to date include:\n* (1) Raising over $1.5 million through benefit performances for children's charities, such as [[St. Jude Children's Research Hospital]] and the [[Make-A-Wish Foundation]].\n* (2) Serving as national spokesperson for Country Bands Together, a national obesity education and counseling/support campaign sponsored by [[Allergan]].\n* (3) Advocacy for adult education, including testimony before Congress on the value and importance of support for adult learners. Wilson dropped out of high school while in 9th grade but gained her GED in 2008 through an adult education college.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/gretchen-wilsons-graduation-picture/ |title=Gretchen Wilson's Graduation Picture |website=Tasteofcountry.com |date=June 4, 2013 |access-date=April 15, 2020}}</ref>\n\n===Sports===\nIn {{wsy|2004}}, Wilson sang the national anthem before Game 4 of the [[2004 World Series|World Series]] between the [[Boston Red Sox]] and the [[St. Louis Cardinals]] at [[Busch Memorial Stadium]] as a long-time fan of the Cardinals. However, the Red Sox winning the game and sweeping the series made her the anthem singer when the [[Curse of the Bambino]] died.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.espn.com/blog/sportscenter/post/_/id/88820/this-day-in-sports-the-curse-of-the-bambino-is-lifted|title=This Day In Sports: The Curse Of The Bambino Is Lifted|date=October 27, 2010|accessdate=January 23, 2024|work=ESPN.com|quote=Country music singer and long-time Cards fan, Gretchen Wilson, sang 'The Star-Spangled Banner' in front of the 52,037 fans who gathered at Busch Stadium to watch Game 4 of the 2004 World Series between the Red Sox and Cardinals...Edgar Renteria...grounded the ball back to (Keith) Foulke, who flipped it to Doug Mientkiewicz to record the final out of the series and give the Sox their long awaited World Series title.}}</ref>\n\nIn April 2010, Wilson released a customized version of \"Work Hard, Play Harder\" in honor of the [[National Hockey League]]'s [[Nashville Predators]], with reworked lyrics mentioning the team and its fans.<ref>{{cite web|author=blakegrant |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bnMIWdCZ-4o |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/bnMIWdCZ-4o |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|title=Play Harder Predators Edit|publisher=YouTube|date=April 22, 2010|access-date=December 10, 2011}}{{cbignore}}</ref>\n\nShe also sponsors a women's softball team in [[Pierron, Illinois]].\n\n==Legal issues==\nOn July 31, 2008, The Black Crowes filed a lawsuit against Wilson for copyright violation, alleging that her song \"Work Hard, Play Harder\" copied the Crowes song \"Jealous Again\". Also included in the suit were her label Sony BMG, her publishing company, and the cable network TNT, which had been using the song in commercials.<ref>{{cite web|author=Daniel Kreps|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/black-crowes-sue-gretchen-wilson-over-saving-grace-commercial-2-254922/|title=Black Crowes Sue Gretchen Wilson Over \"Saving Grace\" Commercial|publisher=Rolling Stone|date=July 30, 2008|access-date=September 21, 2021}}</ref> The lawsuit was eventually settled out of court for an undisclosed sum<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ocregister.com/soundcheck/http-480854-strong-wilson.html|title = Gretchen Wilson battles (And gives) back|date = March 4, 2010}}</ref> and Black Crowes members Chris and Rich Robinson were given songwriting credits.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nashvillescene.com/news/redneck-woman-gretchen-wilsons-search-for-radio-redemption/article_256edd1c-9abe-5dd9-8cc3-c4e7f84a1b34.html|title=Redneck Woman Gretchen Wilson's search for radio redemption|date=February 25, 2010 }}</ref>\n\nOn August 21, 2018, Wilson was arrested at [[Bradley International Airport]] in [[Windsor Locks, Connecticut]]. [[Connecticut State Police]] arrived at the airport after reports of a minor disturbance. Police arrested Wilson after she reportedly became belligerent during their on-tarmac interview. Wilson was charged with breach of peace and her bond was set at $1,000.<ref>{{cite web|author=Chloe Melas and Kristina Sgueglia|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/08/22/entertainment/gretchen-wilson-arrested/index.html|title=Gretchen Wilson arrested at Connecticut airport|publisher=CNN|date=August 23, 2018|access-date=September 21, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=https://www.tmz.com/2018/08/22/gretchen-wilson-arrested-connecticut-airport-fight-bathroom-beef-feud-police/|title=GRETCHEN WILSON VIDEO SHOWS HER CUFFED AT AIRPORT After Rowdy Flight|publisher=TMZ|date=August 22, 2018|access-date=September 21, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/gretchen-wilson-arrested-at-connecticut-airport/|title=Gretchen Wilson arrested at Connecticut airport|publisher=CBS News|date=August 22, 2018|access-date=September 21, 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Awards==\n*[[2005 Country Music Association Awards|2005]] [[Country Music Association|CMA]] Female Vocalist of the Year\n*[[39th Academy of Country This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Wayne_Mills_(singer)","to":"Wayne Mills (singer)"}],"pages":{"41209643":{"pageid":41209643,"ns":0,"title":"Wayne Mills (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country singer (1969\u20132013)}}\n{{Primary sources|date=January 2017}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2014}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Wayne Mills\n| birth_name      = Jerald Wayne Mills\n| birth_date      = {{Birth date|1969|8|17}}\n| birth_place     = [[Arab, Alabama]], U.S.\n| death_date      = {{death date and age|2013|11|23|1969|8|16}}\n| death_place     = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| years_active    = 1999\u20132013\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[outlaw country]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cnn.com/2013/11/24/showbiz/wayne-mills-death/index.html |title= Outlaw country singer Wayne Mills dies in bar shooting|last= Duke|first=Alan |date=November 25, 2013 |work=CNN |access-date=2023-07-25}}</ref>}}\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| associated_acts = Wayne Mills Band, [[Taylor Hicks]], [[Jamey Johnson]], [[Blake Shelton]]\n| website         = {{URL|waynemillsband.com}}\n}}\n'''Jerald Wayne Mills''' (August 17, 1969 \u2013 November 23, 2013) was an American [[country music]]ian, known for touring with the '''Wayne Mills Band''' for over fifteen years and playing alongside [[Blake Shelton]], [[Jamey Johnson]] and 2006 ''[[American Idol]]'' winner [[Taylor Hicks]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Jerald Wayne Mills buried today|url=http://communities.washingtontimes.com/neighborhood/entertainment-news-and-reviews/2013/dec/8/jerald-wayne-mills-buried-today-live-stream-nashvi/|publisher=The Washington Times Communities|access-date=December 10, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Spike TV Apologizes for Airing 'Bar Rescue' Featuring Location of Wayne Mills Shooting|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/spike-tv-apologizes-airing-bar-659861|publisher=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=November 27, 2013|first=Ashley|last=Lee|date=November 25, 2013}}</ref> During his career, Mills released five studio albums (with a sixth unreleased) and two live albums. He had seven Top 20 singles in Europe from 2008 to 2010, including a chart-topper in Belgium in 2009.<ref name=\"gactv\">{{cite web|title=Wayne Mills Band|url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,gac_26071_6036940,00.html|publisher=Great American Country|access-date=December 10, 2013}}</ref>\n\nMills played baseball for Wallace State Junior College and football for the [[University of Alabama]], earning a bachelor of science degree in education.<ref name=\"gactv\" />\n\nIn the early hours of November 23, 2013, in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], Mills was shot in the head by bar owner Chris Ferrell, allegedly over an argument involving Mills lighting up a cigarette in a nonsmoking area. He was rushed to a hospital but later died.<ref>{{cite web|title=Wayne Mills: Country Singer Shot Dead|url=http://news.sky.com/story/1173434/wayne-mills-country-singer-shot-dead|publisher=Sky News|access-date=November 27, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Country singer shot dead in Nashville bar after owner catches him smoking|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/country-singer-shot-dead-nashville-bar-article-1.1528106|work=New York Daily News|access-date=November 27, 2013}}</ref> The incident occurred towards the end of an afterparty at the bar following a recent makeover it received for the television show ''[[Bar Rescue]]'', with its episode scheduled to air the following day. The episode featuring it was later pulled, and the bar closed shortly after.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hudak |first=Joseph |date=2015-03-09 |title=Bar Owner Found Guilty in Country Singer's Murder |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/bar-owner-found-guilty-in-murder-of-country-singer-wayne-mills-111973/ |access-date=2024-05-24 |website=Rolling Stone |language=en-US}}</ref> The building was demolished in 2016. On March 6, 2015, Ferrell was found guilty of [[second-degree murder]] in Mills' death and received a twenty-year sentence with no possibility of parole.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wkrn.com/2015/03/06/closing-arguments-underway-in-wayne-mills-murder-trial/|title=Jury finds bar owner guilty of second degree murder in Wayne Mills' death|work=WKRN.com}}</ref> The verdict and sentence were appealed<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/chris-ferrell-sentenced-wayne-mills-murder/|title=Man Sentenced for Murder of Singer Wayne Mills|first=Billy|last=Dukes|website=Taste of Country|date=April 28, 2015 }}</ref> but were upheld by the appeals court in 2019.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cullmantribune.com/2019/08/19/friends-ride-to-remember-wayne-mills-2/ |title=Friends Ride to Remember Wayne Mills |first=Christy |last=Perry |date=August 19, 2019 |newspaper=The Cullman Tribune |access-date=September 15, 2022}}</ref> Mills left behind wife Carol, whom he had married in 2000,<ref>{{cite web|title=Obituaries|date=December 11, 2013 |url=http://www.thearabtribune.com/articles/2013/12/11/obituaries/obits6.txt|publisher=The Arab Tribune|access-date=December 17, 2013}}</ref> seven-year-old son Jack, and six-year-old niece Cali.\n\n==In popular culture==\n\nMills is the subject of the song \"King of Alabama\" by [[Brent Cobb]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.al.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2018/03/brent_cobb_wayne_mills.html |title=New song honors murdered Alabama country singer Wayne Mills |website=al.com |date=March 9, 2018 |access-date=March 9, 2018}}</ref>\n\n==Discography (with Wayne Mills Band)==\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\" \n|-\n!style=\"width:20em;\"| Title\n!style=\"width:25em;\"| Album details\n!style=\"width:30em;\"|Notes\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''The Wayne Mills Band''\n| \n* Release date: June 13, 1999<ref>{{cite web|url=http://waynemillsband.com/audio/the-wayne-mills-band/ |title=The Wayne Mills Band Wayne Mills Band |website=Waynemillsband.com |date=1999-06-13 |access-date=2017-01-10}}</ref>\n* Label: self-released\n*Format: [[Compact Disc|CD]]\n|\n*Debut album.\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Under the Influence of Outlaws & Mama''\n| \n* Release date: August 17, 2007<ref>{{cite web|url=http://waynemillsband.com/audio/under-the-influence-of-outlaws-mama/ |title=Under The Influence of Outlaws & Mama Wayne Mills Band |website=Waynemillsband.com |date=2007-08-17 |access-date=2017-01-10}}</ref>\n* Label: self-released\n*Format: CD, Digital\n|\n*Reissued on August 17, 2008 with a new final track that replaced the one from the original release.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://waynemillsband.com/audio/under-the-influence-of-outlaws-mama-2/ |title=Under The Influence of Outlaws & Mama Wayne Mills Band |website=Waynemillsband.com |date=2008-08-17 |access-date=2017-01-10}}</ref>  The 2008 version is available digitally.\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''The Last Honky Tonk''\n| \n* Release date: June 7, 2010<ref>{{cite web|url=http://waynemillsband.com/product/last-honky-tonk/ |title=Last Honky Tonk Wayne Mills Band |website=Waynemillsband.com |date= |access-date=2017-01-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005HZV322?ie=UTF8&*Version*=1&*entries*=0 |title=The Last Honky Tonk: Wayne Mills Band: MP3 Downloads |website=Amazon.com |date=2010-06-07 |access-date=2017-01-10}}</ref>\n* Label: Diesel LLC\n*Format: CD, Digital\n|\n*The band's final album before Wayne Mills' death, and the only release that is available via mainstream digital retailers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/the-last-honky-tonk/id458349262 |title=The Last Honky Tonk by Wayne Mills Band on iTunes |website=Itunes.apple.com |date=2010-06-07 |access-date=2017-01-10}}</ref>\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist|30em}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Mills, Wayne}}\n[[Category:1969 births]]\n[[Category:2013 deaths]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Deaths by firearm in Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Outlaw country singers]]\n[[Category:People from Arab, Alabama]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Alabama]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Alabama]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Dylan_Marlowe","to":"Dylan Marlowe"}],"pages":{"77588263":{"pageid":77588263,"ns":0,"title":"Dylan Marlowe","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Dylan Marlowe\n| image           =\n| caption         =\n| birth_name      = \n| birth_date      = \n| birth_place     = [[Statesboro, Georgia]], United States\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar\n| years_active    = 2018\u2013present\n| label           = [[Sony Music Nashville]]\n| associated_acts = \n| website         = {{URL|https://www.dylanmarloweofficial.com/}}\n}}\n'''Dylan Marlowe''' is an American [[country music]] singer-songwriter from [[Statesboro, Georgia]] signed to [[Sony Music Nashville]].<ref name=\"Sony Signing\"/>\n\n==Background==\nMarlowe relocated to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] shortly before the start of the [[COVID-19 pandemic]] and signed a publishing and artist development deal with Play It Again Entertainment in 2020.<ref name=\"Sony Signing\"/> Following several self-released songs, a growing social media presence, and scoring his first Number One hit as a songwriter with [[Jon Pardi]]'s \"[[Last Night Lonely]]\",<ref name=\"Holler\">{{cite web|url=https://holler.country/news/breaking/exclusive-dylan-marlowe-on-authenticity-his-debut-album-boys-back-home-and-more/|title=Exclusive: Dylan Marlowe on Authenticity, His Debut Album, 'Boys Back Home' and More|author=Maxim Mower|date=January 10, 2024|website=Holler|access-date=August 9, 2024}}</ref> it was announced in January 2023, that Marlowe had signed a recording contract with [[Sony Music Nashville]].<ref name=\"Sony Signing\">{{cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2023/01/sony-music-nashville-signs-dylan-marlowe/|title=Sony Music Nashville Signs Dylan Marlowe|author=LB Cantrell|date=January 27, 2023|website=Music Row|access-date=August 9, 2024}}</ref> His debut EP with the label, ''Dirt Road When I Die'', was released on July 7, 2023.<ref name=\"EP\"/> Marlowe's debut single to country radio, \"Boys Back Home\" (a duet with [[Dylan Scott]]), was released on December 4, 2023.<ref name=\"Aircheck\">{{cite web|url=https://assets.countryaircheck.com/public/9a096aad-e54d-4456-8d6f260485724392/Issue-887-December-4-2023.pdf|title=Country Aircheck Weekly December 4, 2023, Issue 887|date=December 4, 2023|website=Country Aircheck|accessdate=August 9, 2024}}</ref> Originally recorded in 2021, its release was delayed due to Scott's ''[[Livin' My Best Life]]'', and Marlowe had to later re-record his vocals when the label decided to issue it as his debut single instead of \"Record High\".<ref name=\"Holler\"/> Marlowe's debut studio album, ''Mid-Twenties Crisis'', will be released on September 27, 2024.<ref name=\"Debut\">{{cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2024/07/dylan-marlowe-will-explore-mid-twenties-crisis-on-debut-album/|title=Dylan Marlowe Will Explore 'Mid-Twenties Crisis' On Debut Album|author=Madison Hahnen|date=July 26, 2024|website=Music Row|access-date=August 9, 2024}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" positions\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! scope=\"col\" width=\"45\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country Songs]]<br /><ref>{{cite 2023\n| 36\n| 25\n| ''Mid-Twenties Crisis''\n|}\n\n=== Music videos ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:14em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 2024\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Boys Back Home\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://countrynow.com/dylan-marlowe-and-dylan-scott-light-up-middle-tennessee-in-fun-filled-boys-back-home-music-video/|title=Dylan Marlowe And Dylan Scott Light Up Middle Tennessee In Fun-Filled 'Boys Back Home' Music Video|author=Madeleine O\u2019Connell|date=February 1, 2024|website=Country Now|access-date=August 9, 2024}}</ref><br />{{small|(with Dylan Scott)}}\n| Tristan Cusick\n|-\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Marlowe, Dylan}}\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Julie_Roberts","to":"Julie Roberts"}],"pages":{"2111952":{"pageid":2111952,"ns":0,"title":"Julie Roberts","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country music singer (born 1979)}}\n{{for-multi|the Welsh painter|Julie Roberts (artist)|the American actress|Julia Roberts|the British singer-songwriter|Juliet Roberts}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| image               = Julie_Roberts_2005.jpg\n| caption             = Roberts in 2005\n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_date          = {{birth date and age|1979|2|1}}\n| origin              = [[Lancaster, South Carolina]], U.S.\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = 2003\u2013present\n| label               = [[Mercury Nashville]], [[Sun Records|Sun]]\n| associated_acts     = [[Trace Adkins]], [[Saving Jane]]\n| website             = {{official website|http://www.julieroberts.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Julie Roberts''' (born February 1, 1979) is an American [[country music]] singer. Signed to [[Mercury Nashville]] in 2003, Roberts made her debut with the single \"Break Down Here\" in February 2004, a Top 20 hit on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts and the first track from her [[Julie Roberts (album)|self-titled debut album]]. A second album for Mercury, ''[[Men & Mascara]]'', followed in 2006. This album produced two non-charting singles in its title track and a cover of [[Saving Jane]]'s \"[[Girl Next Door (Saving Jane song)|Girl Next Door]]\".\n\nIn 2013, she took part in the Blind Auditions of [[The Voice (U.S. season 4)|fourth season]] of the reality television show ''[[The Voice (U.S.)|The Voice]]'' but failed to qualify. Her comeback album ''Good Wine & Bad Decision'' charted on both US Country Albums chart and the US [[Independent Albums|Indie Albums]] charts.\n\nRoberts has [[multiple sclerosis]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2014/05/28/health/julie-roberts-human-factor/index.html|title=Living with MS, 'I do not have to give up on my dreams'|author=Julie Roberts, Special to|website=CNN|date=May 28, 2014 }}</ref>\n\n==Biography==\nJulie Roberts was born in [[Lancaster, South Carolina]], United States, in 1979. The daughter of an engineer and accountant, she began her life performing in [[pre-school]] plays. She also was in school choirs and performed in a rendition of \"My Fair Lady\" at a singing summer camp. Roberts began performing country music as a child. When she was in junior high and high school, she toured with her family, playing at festivals in [[North Carolina]], [[South Carolina]] and [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. She also performed at area nursing homes (where she developed an appreciation for [[blues music]]); and worked at [[Carowinds]] (a theme park in [[Charlotte, North Carolina]]) and [[Dollywood]]. She also worked with 60- and 70-year-old men performing at nursing homes. Her influences include [[Dolly Parton]], [[Barbara Mandrell]] and [[Tanya Tucker]].\n\nShe first attended [[University of South Carolina Lancaster|USC Lancaster]] in her hometown from 1997 to 1999 before graduating from [[Belmont University]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], with a degree in business administration. Roberts performed in local clubs and restaurants until graduation, she began working for [[Mercury Nashville Records]], later becoming assistant to label head Luke Lewis. During her tenure there, she recorded a demo tape with producer Brent Rowan during her off-time. Rowan eventually played the tape for Lewis, who was favorably impressed by the recording.\n\n===Country music career===\nRoberts was signed to [[Universal Music Group Nashville]]'s Mercury Nashville division. Her debut single, \"[[Break Down Here]]\", was released on February 24, 2004. The song had previously been recorded by [[Trace Adkins]] under the title \"I'd Sure Hate to Break Down Here\". Roberts released her self-titled [[Julie Roberts (album)|debut album]] on May 25, 2004. It charted within the Top 10 of the ''Billboard'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart, peaking at No.&nbsp;9. \"Break Down Here\" became a Top 20 single on the [[Hot Country Songs]] chart, however, she never charted within the Top 40 after that. The two follow-up singles, \"The Chance\" and \"Wake Up Older\", peaked at No.&nbsp;47 and No.&nbsp;46 on the country charts, respectively. The album was then certified Gold by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] on December 13, 2004.\n\nIn 2006, she released her fourth single, \"Men & Mascara\", which would in-turn be the title track to her second album. ''[[Men & Mascara]]'' was released on June 27, 2006. Although not charting a single from this album, it managed to chart even higher than her debut album. It reached No.&nbsp;4 on the Top Country Albums and No.&nbsp;25 on the all-genre [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. Included on the album is a [[cover version]] of [[Saving Jane]]'s \"[[Girl Next Door (Saving Jane song)|Girl Next Door]]\", however, it failed to chart along with the album's title track.\n\nRoberts and Mercury Records parted ways at the beginning of May 2010. She released her third album \"Alive\" on June 7 as an independent artist, with the first single being \"NASCAR Party\".\n\nIn 2011, Roberts revealed that she was diagnosed with [[multiple sclerosis]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/julie-roberts-multiple-sclerosis/|title=Julie Roberts Combats M.S. With Health and Fitness|first=Stephen L.|last=Betts|website=The Boot|date=August 17, 2012 }}</ref>\n\n[[Sun Records]] signed Roberts to a recording contract in mid-2013. Her album ''Good Wine & Bad Decisions'' was the first full release for the label in 40 years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/julie-roberts-first-artist-to-sign-with-sun-records-in-40-years/ |title=Julie Roberts First Artist To Sign With Sun Records in 40 years |access-date=July 13, 2013 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429093311/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/julie-roberts-first-artist-to-sign-with-sun-records-in-40-years/ |archive-date=April 29, 2014 }}</ref>\n\nRoberts will release the album ''Ain\u2019t in No Hurry'' on  October 28, 2022.<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Nicholson|first=Jessica|title=Julie Roberts Returns With First Album in Nearly a Decade: 'Everything Has Happened at the Right Time'|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/julie-roberts-album-aint-in-no-hurry-1235162242/|date=October 27, 2022|access-date=October 27, 2022|magazine=Billboard}}</ref>\n\n===Charities===\nRoberts made a donation of $124,250 to [[St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital]] after she, along with contestant Peter Buccellato, won the $100,000 prize in the bonus round on the game show ''[[Wheel of Fortune (US game show)|Wheel of Fortune]]'' on an episode that aired in February 2007.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=CS&s_site=thestate&p_multi=CS&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=117506B6F7B830D0&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D|title=Fortunate \"Wheel\" Winner|date=February 1, 2007|work=The State|access-date=February 23, 2009}}</ref>\n\n==''The Voice'' (2013)==\nIn 2013, Julie Roberts took part in the Blind Auditions of [[The Voice (U.S. season 4)|fourth season]] of the reality television show ''[[The Voice (U.S.)|The Voice]]''. In the third Blind Audition episode broadcast on [[National Broadcasting Company|NBC]] on April 1, 2013, she sang a cover of [[Blake Shelton]]'s version of the [[Dave Barnes]] song \"[[God Gave Me You]]\". None of the four judges, [[Adam Levine]], [[Shakira]], [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]] or Blake Shelton pressed their \"I Want You\" buttons to turn their chairs and she did not qualify to the following rounds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gotcountryonline.com/|title=Got Country Online \u2013 Bringing you the latest country music news & reviews}}</ref> Shelton immediately recognized the contestant and introduced her by name to the other judges.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Couldn't Make You Love Me\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/entertainment/music/catching-up-with-julie-roberts-i-couldn-t-make-you-love-me/article/549560|title=Catching up with Julie Roberts: 'I Couldn't Make You Love Me'|author=Markos Papadatos|date=May 11, 2019|publisher=Digital Journal|access-date=June 16, 2019}}</ref>\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| TBD\n|-\n| colspan=\"6\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Director\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2004\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Break Down Here\"\n| [[Steven Goldmann]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Chance\"\n| Michael McNamara\n|-\n| 2005\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Wake Up Older\"\n| Steven Goldmann\n|-\n| 2006\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Men & Mascara\"\n| [[Peter Zavadil]]\n|-\n| 2011\n! scope=\"row\"| \"NASCAR Party\"\n| Camp Riley\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2012\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Whiskey and You\"\n| Zac Adams\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Sweet Carolina\"\n| Fabio Frey\n|-\n| 2013\n! scope=\"row\"| \"He Made A Woman Out Of Me\"\n|\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n{{Notable contestants of The Voice (U.S.)}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.julieroberts.com Julie Roberts Web site]\n*[http://www.umgnashville.com/artist.aspx?ob=ros&src=lb&aid=31 Official Julie Roberts UMG Nashville Artist Page]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Roberts, Julie}}\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:1979 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:People from Lancaster, South Carolina]]\n[[Category:Mercury Records artists]]\n[[Category:People with multiple sclerosis]]\n[[Category:Sun Records artists]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from South Carolina]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from South Carolina]]\n[[Category:University of South Carolina Lancaster alumni]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Perfect_Stranger_(band)","to":"Perfect Stranger (band)"}],"pages":{"10205735":{"pageid":10205735,"ns":0,"title":"Perfect Stranger (band)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name                = Perfect Stranger\n| image                 = \n| caption            = \n| image_size            = \n| background          = group_or_band\n| origin              = [[Carthage, Texas]], U.S.\n| genre               = [[country music|Country]]\n| years_active        = 1986-2010\n| label               = Pacific, [[Curb Records|Curb]], Smith Music Group\n| past_members        = Andy Ginn<br />Marty Arbter<br />Doug Martin<br />Shayne Morrison<br />Steve Murray<br />Richard Raines<br />Clint Williams<br />Marcus Eldridge<br />Chad Ware<br />Scott Zucknick\n| associated_acts     = [[Vince Gill]], [[Kostas Lazarides|Kostas]], Clyde Brooks\n}}\n\n'''Perfect Stranger''' was an American [[country music]] band founded in 1986 in the state of [[Texas]] by Steve Murray ([[lead vocals]]), Andy Ginn ([[Drum kit|drums]]), Shayne Morrison ([[bass guitar]]) and Richard Raines ([[guitar]]). After several years of performing throughout Texas, the quartet released an independent album in 1994; this album was later picked up by [[Curb Records]], who re-packaged and re-released it a year later. By 1995, its second single (entitled \"[[You Have the Right to Remain Silent (song)|You Have the Right to Remain Silent]]\") had become a Top 5 hit on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts.\n\nAlthough Perfect Stranger never entered Top 40 on the country charts again, the band continued to perform and record throughout the 1990s, charting several more singles before eventually exiting Curb in the late 1990s. In addition, Andy Ginn was replaced by Marty Arbter on drums. Perfect Stranger returned to Curb to release its second album, ''The Hits'', in 2001, and was dropped again afterward. As of 2009, the band is composed of co-lead singers/guitarists Marcus Eldridge and Clint Williams, bassist Shayne Morrison, lead guitarist Chad Ware, and drummer Doug Martin. A third album, ''Shake the World'', was released in 2009. Morrison briefly re-established the band in 2010 with Murray, Raines, and new drummer Scott Zucknick.\n\n==Biography==\nPerfect Stranger was founded in 1986 in [[Carthage, Texas]], by Steve Murray (lead vocals), Shayne Morrison (bass guitar), Richard Raines (lead guitar), and Andy Ginn (drums).<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p146793/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Perfect Stranger biography |accessdate=2008-01-07 |last=Loftus |first=Johnny |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> They originally performed as Midnight Express before assuming the name Perfect Stranger.<ref name=\"oldies\">{{cite web |url=http://www.oldies.com/artist-biography/Perfect-Stranger.html |title=Perfect Stranger biography |accessdate=2008-01-07 |work=Oldies.com}}</ref> The four artists played together throughout the state of Texas, mostly in clubs and at rodeos. In December 1994, they released an independent album on the Pacific label, entitled ''It's Up to You''. Featured on it was the single \"Ridin' the Rodeo\". Written by [[Vince Gill]] and [[Kostas Lazarides|Kostas]],<ref name=\"talent\"/> the song was considered the biggest independent country music hit in the United States at the time, although it never reached the ''Billboard'' charts.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nA second single, entitled \"[[You Have the Right to Remain Silent (song)|You Have the Right to Remain Silent]]\", followed soon afterward. By the time of its release, Perfect Stranger's success as an independent act had been noticed by [[Curb Records]], who acquired the band's debut album and its single. Curb continued promoting \"You Have the Right to Remain Silent\".<ref name=\"talent\">{{cite web |url=http://www.gatalent.com/Acts/Perfect_Stranger/perfect_stranger.html |title=Perfect Stranger |accessdate=2008-01-07 |work=GA Talent}}</ref> ''It's Up to You'' was then re-packaged and re-released in 1995 as ''You Have the Right to Remain Silent'', the band's major-label debut. By the middle of the year, its title track had reached No.&nbsp;4 on the country music charts, and No.&nbsp;61 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].\n\nThey were nominated in 1996 at the [[31st Academy of Country Music Awards]] for [[Academy of Country Music Award for New Vocal Duo or Group of the Year|Best New Vocal Duo or Group of the Year]], along with [[4 Runner]] and [[Lonestar]], losing to the latter group. \n\nThroughout the 1990s and into the 2000s, Perfect Stranger continued to chart singles on occasion, although none of their other singles entered Top 40 on the country music charts. By the end of the 1990s, Andy Ginn had departed,<ref name=\"oldies\"/> with Marty Arbter taking over on drums. They eventually left Curb in the late 1990s, but rejoined the label in the early 2000s.<ref name=\"dish\"/>\n\nThe band's second album, ''The Hits'', was issued in 2001, also on Curb.<ref name=\"oldies\"/> This album included a re-recording of \"You Have the Right to Remain Silent\",<ref name=\"dish\">{{cite web|url=http://www.musicdish.com/mag/index.php3?id=6439|title=Texas Country Act \"Perfect Stranger\" Gives Nashville Second Try|last=Freeman|first=Anne|date=2002-08-05|work=Music Dish|accessdate=2009-05-05}}</ref> as well as \"Fire When Ready\" and \"A Little Bit More of Your Love\", which had charted in 1997. The album also produced two more non-charting singles in its title track (co-written by former [[MCA Records]] artist [[Marty Brown (singer)|Marty Brown]]) and \"Miracle\". After these two, the band exited Curb again.\n\nAll of the original members except Morrison eventually left. They were replaced by co-lead vocalists Clint Williams and Marcus Eldridge,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marcuseldridge.com/news.html |title=News |work=Marcus Eldridge official website |accessdate=2009-05-05 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080819183440/http://www.marcuseldridge.com/news.html |archivedate=August 19, 2008 }}</ref> Chad Ware (guitar), and Doug Martin (drums). A third album, ''Shake the World'', was released on June 2, 2009, via Smith Music Group.<ref>{{cite web |last=Sudhalter |first=Michael |title=''Shake the World'' review |url=http://www.roughstock.com/reviews/perfect-stranger-shake-the-world |date=2009-08-28 |work=Roughstock |accessdate=30 August 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901185920/http://www.roughstock.com/reviews/perfect-stranger-shake-the-world |archive-date=1 September 2009 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nOriginal members Morrison, Raines and Murray briefly re-established in 2010 with new drummer Scott Zucknick.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.perfectstrangercountry.com/about#!__about/members|title=Perfect Stranger members|work=Perfect Stranger|accessdate=25 April 2011}}</ref>\n\nRichard Raines died on June 1, 2013, at his home in [[Mineola, Texas]], following a long battle with depression.  He was 48.<ref>[http://www.news-journal.com/panola/news/richard-raines-of-perfect-stranger-fame-dead-at/article_c10eec8b-0ab1-54a3-9795-b51f9e5d235d.html] {{dead link|date=May 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n;Albums\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"3\"| Peak chart positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[Billboard 200|US]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[RPM (magazine)|CAN Country]]\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| ''It's Up to You'' \n| \n* Release date: December 1994\n* Label: Pacific\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[You Have the Right to Remain Silent (Perfect Stranger album)|You Have the Right to Remain Silent]]''<br /><small>(re-issue of ''It's Up to You'')</small>\n| \n* Release date: June 13, 1995\n* Label: [[Curb Records]]\n| 7\n| 68\n| 13\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| ''The Hits''\n| \n* Release date: June 26, 2001\n* Label: Curb Records\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Shake the World''\n| \n* Release date: June 9, 2009\n* Label: Smith Music Group\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"5\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n;Singles\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"3\"| Peak chart positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[Billboard Hot 100|US]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[RPM (magazine)|CAN Country]]\n|- \n| 1994\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Ridin' the Rodeo\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| ''It's Up to You''\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1995\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[You Have the Right to Remain Silent (song)|You Have the Right to Remain Silent]]\"\n| 4\n| 61\n| 8\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"4\"| ''You Have the Right to Remain Silent''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Am a Stranger Here Myself\"\n| 52\n| \u2014\n| 41\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1996\n!
