scope=\"row\"| \"A Little Bit More of Your Love\"\n| 66\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2000\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Coming Up Short Again\"\n| 75\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| {{n/a}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2001\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Hits\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"2\"| ''The Hits''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Miracle\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2009\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Turn Around Point\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| ''Shake the World''\n|-\n| colspan=\"6\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n;Music videos\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Year\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 1994\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Ridin' the Rodeo\"\n| Chuck Price\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1995\n! scope=\"row\"| \"You Have the Right to Remain Silent\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Am a Stranger Here Myself\"\n|-\n| 2001\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Miracle\"\n|}\n\n== Awards and nominations ==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n!Year\n!Organization\n!Award\n!Nominee/Work\n!Result\n|-\n|1996\n|[[Academy of Country Music Awards]]\n|[[Academy of Country Music Award for New Vocal Duo or Group of the Year|Top New Vocal Group or Duet]]\n|Perfect Stranger\n|{{nom}}\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n[[Category:Country music groups from Texas]]\n[[Category:Curb Records artists]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 1986]]\n[[Category:1986 establishments in Texas]]\n[[Category:People from Carthage, Texas]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Eric_Heatherly","to":"Eric Heatherly"}],"pages":{"4735049":{"pageid":4735049,"ns":0,"title":"Eric Heatherly","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter (born 1970)}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name                = Eric Heatherly\n| image               = \n| caption             =\n| image_size          =\n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          = Eric Lafon Heatherly\n| alias               =\n| birth_date          = {{birth date and age|1970|2|21}}\n| origin              = [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]], United States\n| instrument          = Vocals, guitar\n| genre               = {{Flatlist|\n* [[Rockabilly]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/swimming-in-champagne-mw0000606937|title=Swimming in Champagne - Eric Heatherly &#124; Songs, Reviews, Credits &#124; AllMusic|via=www.allmusic.com}}</ref>\n* [[country rock]]<ref>{{cite news |last1=Printz |first1=Larry |title=ERIC HEATHERLY |work=The Morning Call |date=5 Aug 2000 |page=A38}}</ref>\n}}\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = 2000\u2013present\n| label               = [[Universal Music Group Nashville|Mercury Nashville]]<br />[[DreamWorks Records|DreamWorks Nashville]]<br />NashVegas/[[Koch Records|Koch]]\n| website                 = http://www.theericheatherly.com/\n}}\n'''Eric Lafon Heatherly''' (born February 21, 1970) is an American singer. In 2000, he debuted with a cover of [[The Statler Brothers]]' \"[[Flowers on the Wall]]\", the first of three singles from his debut album ''[[Swimming in Champagne]]'', which was issued in 2000 on [[Mercury Nashville Records]]. A second album for Mercury was planned in 2001 but not released, due to the label's restructuring.\n\nBy 2002, he had signed to [[DreamWorks Records|DreamWorks Nashville]], where he recorded a third studio album which was also unreleased. His fourth overall album, and second to be released, was 2005's ''The Lower East Side of Life'', issued on his own NashVegas Records label.\n\n==Biography==\nEric Heatherly was born February 21, 1970, in [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]]. Influenced at an early age by [[country rock]] acts such as [[Creedence Clearwater Revival]], Eric wrote his first song at 8.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Throughout his teenage years, Heatherly played guitar in several bands in the Chattanooga area.\n\nHe later moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], where he gained a following as a musician, as well as endorsements for guitar manufacturers [[Fender Musical Instruments Corporation]] and [[Takamine Guitars]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> At the 1997 [[Country Music Association]] awards show, Heatherly also played lead guitar in [[Shania Twain]]'s band.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p417055|pure_url=yes}} |title=allmusic ((( Eric Heatherly > Biography ))) |accessdate=2007-12-14 |last=Phares |first=Heather |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>\n\n==Musical career==\nIn 2000, Heatherly was signed to [[Mercury Nashville Records]] as a recording artist. His debut single was a [[cover version]] of [[The Statler Brothers]]' 1965 debut single \"[[Flowers on the Wall]]\".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1476343/20030808/heatherly_eric.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070706210304/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1476343/20030808/heatherly_eric.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=July 6, 2007 |title=\"Flowers on the Wall\" Blooms Again |accessdate=2007-12-14 |date=2000-02-03 |work=CMT.com}}</ref> Heatherly's rendition was a Top Ten hit on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] chart, peaking at #6 in mid-2000.\n\nThe song served as the first single from his debut album. Entitled ''[[Swimming in Champagne]]'', the album was co-produced by [[Keith Stegall]]. Due to a restructuring of Mercury Nashville's parent company, ''Swimming in Champagne'' received minimal promotion;<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> its second and third singles peaked at #46 and at #32 on the chart. Heatherly had also recorded a second album for Mercury, but it was not released, and Heatherly was dropped from the label by 2002.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1452243/20020211/heatherly_eric.jhtml |title=Heatherly Parts With Mercury |accessdate=2007-12-14 |date=2002-04-11 |work=CMT.com}}{{dead link|date=July 2024|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>\n\nA month after parting ways with Mercury, Heatherly signed to [[DreamWorks Records]]' Nashville division.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1452857/20020312/heatherly_eric.jhtml |title=Heatherly Signs With DreamWorks |accessdate=2007-12-14 |date=2002-03-12 |work=CMT.com}}{{dead link|date=July 2024|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> His third album, to be titled ''Sometimes It's Just Your Time'', was to have been released in late 2002. Its lead-off single (\"The Last Man Committed\") entered the country music chart; although promotional advance copies of the album, ''Sometimes It's Just Your Time'', had been issued, it was ultimately unreleased as well.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nThree years after his departure from DreamWorks's roster, he founded a personal label named NashVegas Records, with [[Koch Records]] serving as distributor.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> His fourth album overall (but only the second to be released), ''[[The Lower East Side of Life]]'', was issued in 2005, though no singles were released from it.<ref name=\"cw\">{{cite journal|last=Hollabaugh|first=Lorie|date=2009-05-11|title=In Bloom Once Again|journal=[[Country Weekly]]|volume=16|issue=13|pages=50}}</ref>\n\nAfter ''The Lower East Side of Life'', Heatherly continued to tour, in addition to manufacturing custom-made guitar straps. Through the help of songwriter and producer Carson Chamberlain, Heatherly recorded a song called \"Unforgettable\", which appeared in an episode of ''[[Grey's Anatomy]]''.<ref name=\"cw\"/> He has also recorded another album, ''2 High 2 Cry'', released in 2009.<ref name=\"cw\"/> A second self-released album, ''Painkillers'', followed in 2010.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:22em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"3\"| Peak chart positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[Billboard 200|US]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[Top Heatseekers|US Heat]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Swimming in Champagne]]''<sup><span id=\"ref_A\"></span>[[#endnote_A|'''[A]''']]</sup>\n| \n* Release date: April 18, 2000\n* Label: [[Universal Music Group Nashville|Mercury Nashville]]\n| 17\n| 157\n| 6\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[The Lower East Side of Life]]''\n| \n* Release date: April 26, 2005\n* Label: NashVegas/[[E1 Entertainment|Koch Entertainment]]\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''2 High 2 Cry''\n| \n* Release date: 2009\n* Label: Self-released\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Painkillers''\n| \n* Release date: 2010\n* Label: Self-released\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''The Goats of Kudzu''\n| \n* Release date: 2012\n* Label: Self-released\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"5\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n{{refbegin}}\n;Notes\n*A<span id=\"endnote_A\"></span>'''[[#ref_A|^]]''' ''Swimming in Champagne'' also peaked at number 6 on the ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Country Albums chart in Canada.\n{{refend}}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"2\"| Peak chart<br />positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[Billboard Hot 100|US]]\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2000\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Flowers on the Wall]]\"<sup><span id=\"ref_A\"></span>[[#endnote_A|'''[A]''']]</sup>\n| 6\n| 50\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"3\"| ''Swimming in Champagne''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Swimming in Champagne\"\n| 46\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2001\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Wrong Five O'Clock\"\n\n| 32\n| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2002\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Last Man Committed\"\n| 36\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"3\" |''Sometimes It's Just Your Time''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Sometimes It's Just Your Time\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2003\n! scope=\"row\"| \"When a Heart Begins to Drift\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"5\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|}\n\n{{refbegin}}\n;Notes\n*A<span id=\"endnote_A\"></span>'''[[#ref_A|^]]''' \"Flowers on the Wall\" also peaked at number 3 on the ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Country Tracks chart in Canada.\n{{refend}}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Year\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2000\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Flowers on the Wall\"\n| Gerry Wenner\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Swimming in Champagne\"\n|\n|-\n| 2002\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Last Man Committed\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/eric-heatherly/309978/last-man-committed.jhtml|title=CMT : Videos : Eric Heatherly : Last Man Committed|publisher=[[Country Music Television]]|accessdate=October 14, 2011}}{{dead link|date=July 2024|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>\n| [[Steven Goldmann]]\n|}\n\n== External links ==\n* [http://www.agr-music.com AGR Television Records] International Record Label of Eric Heatherly (multi-lingual)\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Heatherly, Eric}}\n[[Category:1970 births]]\n[[Category:American country guitarists]]\n[[Category:American country rock singers]]\n[[Category:American male guitarists]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Chattanooga, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Mercury Records artists]]\n[[Category:DreamWorks Records artists]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Guitarists from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American guitarists]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American rockabilly guitarists]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Rehab_(band)","to":"Rehab (band)"}],"pages":{"4767159":{"pageid":4767159,"ns":0,"title":"Rehab (band)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American band}}\n{{about|the American rap rock group|the Dutch-Moroccan DJ|R3hab}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name              = Rehab\n| image             = Buford_and_Boone_Playing_Live.jpg\n| image_size        = 200\n| caption           = The duo most known for being Rehab. Brooks Buford on the left and Danny Boone on the right\n| background        = group_or_band\n| alias             = \n| origin            = [[Warner Robins, Georgia]], U.S.\n| genre             = {{flatlist|\n*[[hip hop]]<ref name=\"Biography\"/>\n\n\n}}\n| years_active      = {{flatlist|\n*1998\u20132002\n*2005\u20132014\n*2017\u2013present\n}}\n| label             = {{flatlist|\n*[[Epic Records|Epic]]\n*Rehab/Atticasound\n*[[Universal Republic]]\n*[[Average Joe's Entertainment]] \n*BooneBox Records\n*ONErpm\n}}\n| associated_acts   = \n| website           = http://www.rehabtheband.com/\n| current_members   = {{plainlist}}\n*Danny \"Boone\" Alexander\n*Denny \u201cSteaknife\u201d Campbell\n*Austin \u201cDj Uh-Oh\u201d Sanderson\n*Brandon Dover\n*Ian Corabi\n*Joey Malik \n{{endplainlist}}\n| past_members      = {{plainlist}}\n*Jason Brooks 'Buford'\n*Jericho\n*Mike Hartnett\n*Hano Leathers\n*FOZ\n*Lamar Williams Jr.\n*Demun Jones\n*DJ Chris Crisis\n*Chris Hood\n{{endplainlist}}\n}}\n\n'''Rehab''' is an American [[hip hop]] group from [[Warner Robins, Georgia]].<ref name=\"Biography\"/> The band recorded seven albums, initially as the duo of Danny \"Boone\" Alexander and Jason \"Brooks\" Buford, before Buford left the group and Alexander continued with the band as a quintet.\n\n==History==\n===1998\u20131999: Formation and debut===\nRehab was originally formed by vocalists Danny \"Boone\" Alexander and Jason \"Brooks\" Buford, with producer Denny \"Steaknife\" Campbell.\n\nBoone and Campbell (both from Warner Robins, Georgia) were previously the rap group \"Prime Suspect\". Alexander and Buford were recovering alcoholics and drug addicts, and while it is a common misconception they met at a rehab facility, the trio did not meet within rehabilitation. Early on, they released their first album ''[[To Whom It May Consume]]'' produced by Campbell and Buford.\n\n===2000\u20132002: Departure of Steaknife, and ''Southern Discomfort''===\nSoon after ''To Whom It May Consume'', Campbell was incarcerated and Epic/Sony offered a record deal to Buford and Alexander as a duo. Mashing rap with rock, the duo released their major label debut album, ''[[Southern Discomfort (Rehab album)|Southern Discomfort]],'' in 2000 on the Sony label. Cee-Lo & Bigg Gipp of Goodie Mob, Mandy Lauderdale and Cody ChesnuTT were the guests on the album, which spawned the Top 15 modern rock hit \"It Don't Matter\", and \"Sittin' At A Bar\".\n\nTwo years were spent on the road supporting the album touring with Kottonmouth Kings and the Phunk Junkeez, including a stint on the Warped Tour.\n\n===2002\u20132004: ''Cuz We Can'', departure of Buford, and hiatus===\nFor reasons not publicly clarified, Buford left the band, and released 26 unreleased Rehab songs on his website towards the end of his tenure. This collection was later known to fans as ''Cuz We Can''. 22 of the 26 songs were produced by Denny \"Steaknife\" Campbell, and the album was later given out to on tours by Boone in 2007. Boone also modified the track list of the pressed version, removing certain songs and adding new ones, in light of Buford's departure.\n\nAfter two years on the road supporting the Vans Warped Tour and playing with bands such as Linkin Park, the group went on an indefinite hiatus. Buford did not return to the group, however, later appeared as host of 2005's ''[[List of programs broadcast by MTV|Trailer Fabulous]]'' on MTV and recorded a single for the show's theme, before joining the short-lived project The Audio Club with [[Tommy Henriksen|Tommy Hendriksen]].<ref name=\"Biography\">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/rehab-p416355/biography|title=Rehab > Biography|work=[[Allmusic]]|publisher=[[Rovi Corporation|Macrovision]]|access-date=2011-01-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Lang |first=Derrik J. |title=MTV show \\'Trailer Fabulous\\' tricks out mobile homes |url=https://www.heraldtimesonline.com/story/news/2005/08/05/mtv-show-trailer-fabulous-tricks-out-mobile-homes/48285067/ |access-date=2024-02-12 |website=The Herald-Times |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Writer |first=Derrik J. Lang, Associated Press |title=MTV makeover show helps out the mobile home set |url=https://www.seacoastonline.com/story/news/2005/08/02/mtv-makeover-show-helps-out/50236360007/ |access-date=2024-02-12 |website=Portsmouth Herald |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n===2004\u20132010: Reformation, ''Graffiti the World'', and ''Welcome Home''===\n[[File:Rehabband.JPG|thumb|Rehab in Exeter New Hampshire at the Ioka Theatre in 2008]]\nIn 2004, Boone connected with Atlanta producer Shannon Houchins. WIth Houchins, a new band was assembled consisting of guitarist Mike Hartnett, Hano Leathers, Chris Hood and [[Foz]]. Now a quintet with Alexander, Rehab signed with Arshid Entertainment and released ''[[Graffiti the World]]'' in 2005.\n\nSometime in 2008, the three original members decided to do a reunion [[Extended Play|EP]] and go by the name Southern Discomfort. Their label saw this and decided to halt most of the promotion, since the name of Southern Discomfort was essentially owned by Epic/Sony. As a result, the label released ''Sitting at a Bar,'' which was a [[Reissue|re-release]] of their debut album. All of this was done without the band's permission.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rehab Discography|date=14 October 2008|url=http://rehab-world.blogspot.com/2008/10/rehab-discography.html|publisher=Nate|access-date=23 March 2016}}</ref>\n\nTo fight this unauthorized reissue, the band re-recorded the single and renamed it \"Bartender Song.\" This version would end up on a 2008 version of ''[[Graffiti the World]]'' released by the major label, Universal. Rehab stuck with Universal for their 2010 album ''[[Welcome Home (Rehab Album)|Welcome Home]],'' which saw a handful of singles on the Top 30 video countdown for CMT through January 2011.\n\n===2011\u20132014: ''Gullible's Travels'' and breakup===\n''[[Gullible's Travels (Rehab Album)|Gullible's Travels]]'' was released on February 21, 2012 through AVJ Records (a subsidiary label of [[Average Joe's Entertainment]]) owned by former Rehab producer and manager Shannon Houchins and country music artist [[Colt Ford]]. Touring followed with the single \"Waho by the Hoti\" (\"the Waffle House by the hotel\"). The video for their single \"King of Tweakers\", which was released on their website in the summer of 2011, premiered on February 21, 2012 with the album release.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rehab About|url=http://www.rehabmusic.com/about|publisher=Rehab|access-date=26 March 2012}}</ref> A video for the next single \"Can't Catch Up To You\" was also recorded.\n\nOn July 3, 2013, a track by [[Twiztid]] was released off their first mixtape [[A New Nightmare]] entitled \"Unjust love\", featuring Danny Alexander.\n\nThe band released a 2013 single \"Whore\" which would be the last recorded content by the band. In 2014, the band released a statement to their fans that they would be going on a farewell tour and disband to form solo careers. Before the break, the band recorded a full album titled ''Million Dollar Mugshot,'' which [[Average Joes Entertainment]] did not release until 2017.\n\n===2015\u20132016: Possible reformation===\nSometime in June 2015, former founding member Denny Campbell posted on his Facebook page that said there was a possible Rehab reunion between Alexander and himself. He continued to post pictures of him and Boone in the studio as well. On March 19, 2016, a possible album cover was posted on Rehab's website. On September 1, 2017, ''Million Dollar Mug Shot'' was finally released.\n\n===2017\u2013present: Reformation===\nOn December 31, 2017, Alexander announced via video on the official Rehab Facebook page<ref>https://www.facebook.com/rehabmusic/videos/10159759494615076/ {{User-generated source|certain=yes|date=March 2022}}</ref> that Rehab had returned. In the video, he stated there would be new music and tour in 2018. He also stated that the band lineup is now Danny Boone and Jericho,<ref>https://www.facebook.com/jay.j.robinson.10 {{User-generated source|certain=yes|date=March 2022}}</ref> in addition to a full band.\n\nOn April 12, 2019, the studio album titled ''Galaga'' was released. This is the first album released independently with the help of ONErpm. Full tours in 2019 and 2020 followed. The tour included a band but with a different lineup as prior iteration as seen below.\n\n==Band members==\n[[Image:Chrishood.JPG|thumb|Chris Hood]]\n[[Image:Dannyboone.JPG|thumb|Danny Boone Alexander]]\n[[Image:Demonjonesrehab.JPG|thumb|Demun Jones on the left]]\n[[Image:Fozrehab.JPG|thumb|Foz]]\n[[Image:Hano Leathers.jpg|thumb|Hano Leathers]]\n[[Image:Mikehartnett.JPG|thumb|Mike Hartnett]]\n[[Image:Steakniferehab.JPG|thumb|Steaknife on the right]]\n\n'''Current lineup'''\n*Danny \"Boone\" Alexander (vocals)\n*Doyle Williams (lead guitar)\n*Nate Lee (bass)\n*Ian Corabi scope=\"row\" | \"Talk About\" (Country Mix)\n| 2011\n| David Poag<ref>{{cite web | title=Talk About Country Mix {{!}} Rehab {{!}} Music Video | url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/rehab/633437/talk-about-country-mix.jhtml | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111222083009/http://www.mtv.com/videos/rehab/633437/talk-about-country-mix.jhtml | url-status=dead | archive-date=December 22, 2011 | work=[[MTV|MTV Music]] | publisher=[[Viacom Media Networks]] | access-date=February 28, 2013}}</ref>\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Helen_Cornelius","to":"Helen Cornelius"}],"pages":{"15036540":{"pageid":15036540,"ns":0,"title":"Helen Cornelius","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Helen Cornelius\n| image           = Helen Cornelius.jpg\n| image_size      =\n| caption         = Cornelius in 2012\n| birth_name      = Helen Lorene Johnson\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1941|12|06}}\n| origin          = [[Monroe City, Missouri]]\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 1975\u2013present\n| label           = [[Dot Records|Dot]]<br />[[RCA Victor]]<br />[[MCA Records|MCA]]\n| associated_acts = [[Jim Ed Brown]]\n}}\n\n'''Helen Cornelius''' (born '''Helen Lorene Johnson'''; December 6, 1941)<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|pages=95/6}}</ref> is an American [[country music|country]] singer-songwriter, best remembered for a series of hit duets with [[Jim Ed Brown]], many of which reached the U.S. country singles top ten during the late 1970s and early 1980s.\n\n==Biography==\nHelen Cornelius was born in [[Monroe City, Missouri]],<ref name=\"AMG\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/helen-cornelius-mn0000954455|title=Helen Cornelius &#124; Biography & History|website=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=August 5, 2021}}</ref> and was raised on a farm nearby. Her older brothers played in country bands, and she formed a singing trio with sisters Judy and Sharon.<ref name=\"AMG\"/> Together they toured locally with the blessing of their father.<ref name=\"AMG\"/> Subsequently, Helen began touring on her own with a backup band called The Crossroads.<ref name=\"AMG\"/>\n\nAfter completing high school, Cornelius wed and became employed as a secretary.<ref name=\"AMG\"/> She began touring again at the end of the 1960s and signed with Screen Gems Music as a songwriter in 1970.<ref name=\"AMG\"/> When the company went under, she sent a [[demo tape]] to [[Jerry Crutchfield]], who offered her a contract with [[MCA Records]]; eventually she signed with [[Columbia Records]], with whom she released two singles. In 1975, she signed with [[RCA Records]]; two further singles followed with little recognition.<ref name=\"AMG\"/>\n\nIn 1976, she recorded a duet, \"[[I Don't Want to Have to Marry You]]\" with [[Jim Ed Brown]];<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> it was a major success in America.<ref name=\"AMG\"/> Further solo singles failed to take off, but her next duet with Brown, \"Saying Hello, Saying I Love You, Saying Goodbye\", was another smash, and the pair began playing on the TV show, ''Nashville on the Road''.<ref name=\"AMG\"/> She continued to record with Brown, releasing the hits \"[[I'll Never Be Free]]\", \"If the World Ran Out of Love Tonight\", \"Don't Bother to Knock\", \"Lying in Love with You\", and finally notching a solo hit with \"Whatcha Doin' After Midnight Baby\".<ref name=\"AMG\"/> In 1981, after topping the U.S. country charts one last time with Brown with \"Morning Comes too Early\", Cornelius separated with Brown, and enjoyed moderate success as a solo artist, touring with [[The Statler Brothers]] and performing in an ''[[Annie Get Your Gun (musical)|Annie Get Your Gun]]'' road show.<ref name=\"AMG\"/> In 1988, she and Brown reunited for a nationwide tour.<ref name=\"AMG\"/>\n\nCornelius opened Nashville South in [[Gatlinburg, Tennessee]], in the 1990s, where she performed with a house band nightly.<ref name=\"AMG\"/> Early in the 2000s, she took a regular gig at the Jim Stafford Theater in [[Branson, Missouri]].  Most recently, Cornelius has been an active participant in the ''Country's Family Reunion'' series, which airs on [[RFD-TV]].\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\" \n! Year\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Raybon_Brothers","to":"Raybon Brothers"}],"pages":{"4163257":{"pageid":4163257,"ns":0,"title":"Raybon Brothers","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name                = Raybon Brothers\n| image               =\n| caption             =\n| image_size          =\n| background          = group_or_band\n| origin              = [[Florida]], United States\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]]\n| years_active        = 1997\n| label               = [[MCA Nashville]]\n|spinoff_of = [[Shenandoah (band)|Shenandoah]]\n| past_members        = [[Marty Raybon]]<br />Tim Raybon\n}}\n'''Raybon Brothers''' were an American [[country music]] duo from [[Sanford, Florida]], consisting of brothers [[Marty Raybon]] and Tim Raybon. Prior to the duo's inception in 1997, Marty Raybon was the lead singer of the country music band [[Shenandoah (band)|Shenandoah]], having left in 1997, before rejoining in 2014.<ref name=\"gibson\">{{cite web |url=http://www.gibson.com/player/apr03/raybon.html |title=Marty Raybon scratches his bluegrass itch |accessdate=2008-07-28 |last=Nikolai |first=Michelle |work=Gibson Guitar Corporation |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719161854/http://www.gibson.com/player/apr03/Raybon.html |archivedate=2008-07-19}}</ref>\n\nThe Raybon Brothers charted in 1997 with a cover of [[Bob Carlisle]]'s pop hit \"[[Butterfly Kisses (song)|Butterfly Kisses]]\". Their version was a top 40 hit on both the ''Billboard'' country music charts and the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. A second single, \"The Way She's Lookin'\", reached the lower regions of the country charts. Marty recorded a number of solo projects before rejoining Shenandoah.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! Monroe\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Way She's Lookin\"\n|\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Falling\" <small>(featuring Olivia Newton-John)</small>\n|\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n{{Shenandoah}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n[[Category:Country music groups from Florida]]\n[[Category:American country music duos]]\n[[Category:Sibling musical duos]]\n[[Category:MCA Records artists]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 1997]]\n[[Category:Musical groups disestablished in 1997]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Marshall_Tucker_Band","to":"The Marshall Tucker Band"}],"pages":{"1583973":{"pageid":1583973,"ns":0,"title":"The Marshall Tucker Band","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American Southern rock band}}\n{{Infobox musical artist  <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name             = The Marshall Tucker Band\n| image            = Marshall Tucker Band on the 4th.jpg\n| caption          = The Marshall Tucker Band in 2006\n| image_upright    = 1.2\n| background       = group_or_band\n| origin           = [[Spartanburg, South Carolina]], U.S.\n| genre            = {{Hlist|[[Progressive country]]|[[Southern rock]]|[[blues rock]]|[[country rock]]|[[jazz fusion|jazz rock]]}}\n| years_active     = 1972\u2013present\n| label            = [[Capricorn Records|Capricorn]], [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]], Mercury, Cabin Fever, Ramblin'\n| associated_acts  = [[Charlie Daniels]], [[The Allman Brothers Band]], Eric Quincy Tate, [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]]\n| website          = {{URL|marshalltucker.com}}\n| current_members  = [[Doug Gray]]<br>Marcus James Henderson<br> Chris Hicks<br> Rick Willis<br>Ryan Ware<br>B.B. Borden\n| past_members     = [[Jerry Eubanks]]<br>[[Toy Caldwell]]<br>[[George McCorkle]]<br>Paul Riddle<br>[[Tommy Caldwell (musician)|Tommy Caldwell]]<br>Franklin Wilkie<br>Stuart Swanlund<br>Rusty Milner<br>Tim Lawter<br>Ronnie Godfrey<br>[[Bobby Ogdin]]<br>Bob Wray<br>[[James Stroud]]<br>Tom Robb<br>Ace Allen<br>Don Cameron<br>Frank Toler<br>Mark Pettey<br>Ronald Radford<br>Paul Thompson<br>Garry Guzzardo<br>David Muse<br>[[Clay Cook]]<br>Tony Heatherly<br>Pat Elwood<br>Tony Black\n}}\n\n'''The Marshall Tucker Band''' is an American [[rock music|rock]] band from [[Spartanburg, South Carolina]]. Noted for incorporating [[blues]], [[country music|country]] and [[jazz]] into an eclectic sound, the Marshall Tucker Band helped establish the [[Southern rock]] genre in the early 1970s.<ref name=larkin /> While the band had reached the height of its commercial success by the end of the decade, it has recorded and performed continuously under various line-ups for 50 years.<ref name=larkin>Colin Larkin (ed.), \"Marshall Tucker Band\". ''The Encyclopedia of Popular Music'', Vol. 5 (New York: Oxford University Press, 2006), pp. 521\u2013522.</ref> Lead vocalist [[Doug Gray]] remains the only original member still active with the band.\n\nThe original line-up of the Marshall Tucker Band, formed in 1972, included [[lead guitarist]], vocalist and primary songwriter [[Toy Caldwell]] (1947\u20131993), lead vocalist [[Doug Gray]] (born 1948), keyboard player, saxophone player and [[flautist]] [[Jerry Eubanks]] (born 1950), rhythm guitarist [[George McCorkle]] (1946\u20132007), drummer Paul Riddle (born 1953) and bassist [[Tommy Caldwell (musician)|Tommy Caldwell]] (1949\u20131980). They signed with [[Capricorn Records]] and released their first album in 1973, ''[[The Marshall Tucker Band (album)|The Marshall Tucker Band]]''.\n\nAfter Tommy Caldwell was killed in a car accident in 1980, he was replaced by bassist Franklin Wilkie. Most of the original band members had left by 1984.<ref name=olson>Ted Olson, \"Marshall Tucker Band.\" ''The Encyclopedia of Country Music: The Ultimate Guide to the Music'' (New York: Oxford University Press, 1998), pp. 325\u2013326.</ref> The band's current line-up consists of Gray on vocals; keyboard player, saxophonist and flautist Marcus James Henderson; guitarists Chris Hicks and Rick Willis, bassist Ryan Ware and drummer B.B. Borden.<ref>[http://marshalltucker.com/nt-30-the-marshall-tucker-band-is.html The Marshall Tucker Band \u2013 Current and former members page] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090529061538/http://marshalltucker.com/nt-30-the-marshall-tucker-band-is.html |date=2009-05-29 }}. 2009. Retrieved: 9 June 2009.</ref>\n\n==Origin of the name==\nThe \"Marshall Tucker\" in the band's name does not refer to a band member, rather to a blind piano tuner from Spartanburg.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Blind piano tuner turns talent into a key business|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1454&dat=19830215&id=8dZOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cRMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6972,3967212&hl=en|access-date = 2016-01-13|date = February 15, 1983|publisher = Associated Press|last = Herring|first = Melissa}}</ref>  While the band was discussing possible band names one evening in an old warehouse they had rented for rehearsal space, someone noticed that the warehouse's door key had the name \"Marshall Tucker\" inscribed on it, and suggested they call themselves \"The Marshall Tucker Band,\" not realizing it referred to an actual person. Later it came to light that Marshall Tucker, the piano tuner, had tuned a piano in that rented space before the band and his name was inscribed on the key.<ref name=bio>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090529001722/http://marshalltucker.com/nt-31-biography.html The Marshall Tucker Band \u2013 Biography]. 2009. Retrieved: 9 June 2009.</ref> Music historian [[Joel Whitburn]] erroneously attributes \"Marshall Tucker\" to the owner of the band's rehearsal hall in his book ''Top Pop Singles, 1955-2002''.<ref>{{cite book|first=Joel|last=Whitburn|year=2003|title=Top Pop Singles 1955-2002|publisher=Record Research, Inc.|location=Menomonee Falls, Wisconsin|isbn=0-89820-155-1|url-access=registration|url=https://archive.org/details/joelwhitburnstop00whitbur}}</ref> Marshall Tucker died on January 20, 2023, at the age of 99.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Obituaries in Spartanburg, SC {{!}} Spartanburg Herald-Journal |url=https://goupstate.com/obituaries/pspa0409094 |access-date=2023-01-22 |website=Goupstate.com |language=en}}</ref> At the time it was reported that he supported the band\u2019s use of his name and that he was \"proud of them as long as they were good boys and played good music\".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://obits.postandcourier.com/us/obituaries/charleston/name/marshall-tucker-obituary?id=38721737|title=Marshall Tucker Obituary (2023) - Charleston, SC - Charleston Post & Courier|website=Obits.postandcourier.com}}</ref>\n\n==History==\n===Early history===\nThe original members (and some later members) of the Marshall Tucker Band had been playing in various line-ups under different band names around the Spartanburg area since the early 1960s. In 1966 members of several such bands merged to form the Toy Factory, named after guitarist Toy Caldwell. The Toy Factory's constantly shifting line-up included, at various times, Caldwell, his younger brother Tommy, Doug Gray, Jerry Eubanks, George McCorkle and Franklin Wilkie. In the late 1960s, four of the band members served in the US military;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.georgemccorkle.com/Bio.htm|title=GEORGE MCCORKLE|publisher=georgemccorkle.com|access-date=3 June 2012|archive-date=14 August 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160814042449/http://www.georgemccorkle.com/Bio.htm|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://marshalltucker.com/articlesby-382|title=Marshall Tucker Band to Entertain Troops in Iraq & Kuwait|author=Ryan|date=May 4, 2011|publisher=marshalltucker.com|access-date=3 June 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120611130837/http://marshalltucker.com/articlesby-382|archive-date=11 June 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://marshalltucker.com/articlesby-382|title=Marines salute Hutchings, Caldwells|author=Dudley Brown|date=June 29, 2003|newspaper=[[Spartanburg Herald-Journal]]|access-date=3 June 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120611130837/http://marshalltucker.com/articlesby-382|archive-date=11 June 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref> Toy Caldwell served in the Marine Corps and received a Purple Heart after being wounded in [[Vietnam War|Vietnam]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/02/26/arts/toy-caldwell-jr-45-a-founder-of-the-marshall-tucker-band.html|title=Toy Caldwell Jr., 45, a Founder of the Marshall Tucker Band|date=February 26, 1993|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=3 June 2012}}</ref>\n\nBy the 1970s, Toy Caldwell and George McCorkle had returned to Spartanburg and the Toy Factory had resumed playing in area clubs.<ref name=smith>Michael B. Smith, [http://www.tuckerhead.com/toy_bio.htm Toy Caldwell's Carolina Dreams]. Tuckerhead.com.  Retrieved: 9 June 2009.</ref>\n\nIn 1972 Caldwell and McCorkle once again revamped the band's line-up, eventually settling on Tommy Caldwell on bass, George McCorkle rhythm guitar, vocalist Doug Gray and Jerry Eubanks, keyboards/flute/tenor sax, while adding Paul Riddle on drums; the new line-up adopted the name \"Marshall Tucker Band\". [[Wet Willie]] lead singer [[Jimmy Hall]] told Toy Caldwell to book the band at Grant's Lounge in [[Macon, Georgia]], which he did. After hearing the band play at Grant's Lounge, Buddy Thornton and [[Paul Hornsby]] recorded the band's [[demo (music)|demo]] at [[Capricorn Records|Capricorn Studios]]. [[Frank Fenter]] and [[Phil Walden]] signed the Marshall Tucker Band to [[Capricorn Records]] based on those demos.\n\n===1970s===\nThe Marshall Tucker Band's [[The Marshall Tucker Band (album)|self-titled debut]], produced by [[Paul Hornsby]], was released in 1973 and certified gold in 1975.<ref name=elliott>James Elliott, \"Marshall Tucker Band.\" ''Definitive Country: The Ultimate Encyclopedia of Country Music and its Performers'' (New York: Berkley Publishing Group, 1995), pp. 504-505.</ref> All of the tracks were written by Toy Caldwell, including \"[[Can't You See (The Marshall Tucker Band song)|Can't You See]]\" which was released as a popular single in 1973 and re-released in 1977, generating much FM airplay and becoming the group's best known song. After the album's release, the band began touring, playing upwards of 300 shows per year throughout the decade.<ref name=elliott /> Southern rock fiddler [[Charlie Daniels]] later recalled that the Marshall Tucker Band \"came onstage and just blew it out from start to finish.\"<ref name=alfonso>Barry Alfonso, Notes to ''The Marshall Tucker Band: Anthology'' [CD liner notes]. Ramblin' Records, 2005.</ref> \n\nDaniels' first of many collaborations with the Marshall Tucker Band came on the band's second album, ''[[A New Life (album)|A New Life]]'',<ref name=alfonso /> which was released in 1974, and certified gold in 1977.<ref name=elliott /> Daniels and blues guitarist [[Elvin Bishop]] were among several musicians that joined the band for ''[[Where We All Belong]]'',<ref name=alfonso /> a double-album (one studio album and one live album) released by the band in 1974 and certified gold that same year.\n\nThe following year the band's ''[[Searchin' for a Rainbow]]'' was also certified gold the year of its release, and contained the track \"[[Fire on the Mountain (The Marshall Tucker Band song)|Fire on the Mountain]],\" which peaked at No. 38 on the [[Billboard charts]]. ''[[Long Hard Ride]]'', the band's fifth consecutive gold album, was released in 1976,<ref name=alfonso /> and its instrumental title track (which again features Charlie Daniels on fiddle) was nominated for a [[Grammy Award|Grammy]].<ref name=cortner>Amy Cortner, \"Marshall Tucker Band.\" ''Encyclopedia of Appalachia'' (Knoxville, Tenn.: University of Tennessee Press, 2006). p. 1186.</ref>\n\n''[[Carolina Dreams]]'', released in 1977 and certified platinum that same year, proved to be the band's most commercially successful album, and included the track \"[[Heard It in a Love Song]]\", which reached No. 14 on the Billboard charts.<ref name=elliott />  And the band's final Capricorn release came with 1978's ''[[Together Forever (The Marshall Tucker Band album)|Together Forever]]'', which was produced by [[Stewart Levine]].<ref name=alfonso />\n\nFollowing the bankruptcy of Capricorn, the Marshall Tucker Band moved to [[Warner Bros. Records]] in 1979 for their ninth album, ''[[Running Like the Wind]]'' (the band's eighth release was a compilation album entitled ''Greatest Hits''), and they retained Levine as the album's producer.\n\nIn August 1979, the band played at [[Knebworth Festival 1979|Knebworth Festival]] in England. [[Led Zeppelin]] was the headline act at both of their festival appearances.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Led Zeppelin {{!}} Official Website Knebworth Festival - August 11, 1979|url=https://www.ledzeppelin.com/|access-date=2022-01-09|website=Led Zeppelin {{!}} Official Website - Official Website|language=en}}</ref>\n\n===1980s===\nOn April 22, 1980, following the completion of the band's tenth album ''[[Tenth (The Marshall Tucker Band album)|Tenth]]'', bassist and co-founder Tommy Caldwell suffered massive head trauma in a car wreck and died six days later. Former Toy Factory bassist Franklin Wilkie replaced Caldwell for their next album, [[Dedicated (The Marshall Tucker Band album)|''Dedicated'']] (1981), but the band was never able to recapture its commercial success of the 1970s.\n\nOn 1982's ''Tuckerized'', which featured Ronnie Godfrey, who joined them as an additional keyboardist, only two songs were written by band members; \"Sea, Dreams & Fairy Tales\" by Toy Caldwell and \"Sweet Elaine\" by George McCorkle. And main songwriter Toy Caldwell only contributed three songs to each of their next two albums, both released in 1983; ''Just Us'' and ''Greetings from South Carolina''. Afterwards, all the rest of the original band members split in June 1984, except for Doug Gray and Jerry Eubanks.<ref name=larkin />\n\nDuring the summer of 1984, MTB toured with a revamped lineup featuring Gray, Eubanks, Spartanburg guitarist Rusty Milner and new Nashville players: Bob Wray (bass), [[James Stroud]] (drums), Kenny Mims (guitar) and [[Bobby Ogdin]] (keyboards).  But in 1985, Wray, Stroud and Mims were replaced respectively by session veteran [[Tom Robb]] (from [[Leslie West]]'s Wild West Show), Stuart Swanlund (guitars, slide guitar, pedal steel guitar, vocals) and  David \"Ace\" Allen (drums).\n\nIn 1988 Gray and Eubanks released the album ''Still Holdin' On'', their one and only release on the Mercury Records label, which had been recorded mostly back in 1985 in Nashville with the 84/85 mostly Nashville players lineup. \n\nBassist Tim Lawter joined in 1987, and the newer members (including newly added, in 1989, keyboardist Don Cameron) had a much greater role on the band's 1990 album, ''Southern Spirit'', released on the Sisapa label. The album marked a return to the band's country and blues roots.<ref name=tuckerhead>Tuckerhead.com, [http://www.tuckerhead.com/still_holdin_on_review.htm ''Still Holdin' On'' Review]. 2002\u20132008. Retrieved: 9 June 2009.</ref>\n\n===1990s===\nIn 1992 the Marshall Tucker Band produced its first album for the Cabin Fever label, ''Still Smokin'''. Just after the album's recording, drummer David \"Frankie\" Toler (ex-[[Allman Brothers Band]]) replaced Allen on drums and Mark Pettey replaced Don Cameron later that same year on keyboards.\n\nThe band's 1993 release, ''Walk Outside the Lines'', marked a transition to a more country sound, relying less on long improvised jams that were the trademark of the band's early career.<ref>Craig Cumberland, [http://www.tuckerhead.com/walk_review.htm ''Walk Outside the Lines'' Review]. Tuckerhead.com,  Retrieved: 9 June 2009.</ref> The album's title track was co-written by country music star [[Garth Brooks]], a long-time fan of the band who considered writing a track for them a \"milestone\" in his career.<ref name=elliott />\n\nThe band added Spartanburg-area guitarist Ronald Radford in 1993 to 1995 after Swanlund suffered a hand injury, and Radford appeared on 1998's ''Face Down In the Blues'', along with [[Firefall]]'s multi-instrumentalist David Muse, the latter replacing Jerry Eubanks who had retired in 1996. But Swanlund was back in the band from 1995 till his death in 2012 and Muse was there from 1996-2000, then again in 2003-2009.\n\nGarry Guzzardo replaced drummer Toler in 1994-1996 and was succeeded by current drummer B.B. Borden (ex-[[Mother's Finest]]) in 1997, guitarist Chris Hicks joined in 1996, after a long stint in the [[Outlaws (band)|Outlaws]], and keyboardist Paul Thompson (who came in after Pettey left) was briefly a member in 1994, but was dropped pretty soon after and not replaced. He was killed in a motorcycle accident in 1999.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1998.html|title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 1998 - 1999|website=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com}}</ref>\n\n''Gospel'', the band's 1999 album, featured the band's rendition of traditional songs including [[The Wayfaring Stranger (song)|\"The Wayfaring Stranger\"]], [[Can the Circle Be Unbroken (By and By)|\"Will the Circle Be Unbroken\"]], and several original tracks.\n\n===21st century===\n[[Clay Cook]] (saxophone, flute, keyboards, vocals) was a member from 2000-2009 and Dave Muse returned in 2003-2009 before \nbeing succeeded by current man Marcus James Henderson in 2009. Longtime bassist Tim Lawter was succeeded by Tony Heatherly in 2001, who turned it over to Pat Elwood in 2004. Guitarist Rusty Milner left in 2003 and Stuart Swanland was there on and off (his health permitting) from 1985 until his death on August 5, 2012 at age 54. The current guitarists are Chris Hicks (since 1996) and Rick Willis (since 2009) and bassist Tony Black was there from 2017-2019. Ryan Ware has occupied the bass chair since the band returned to the road in 2021, after the [[COVID-19 pandemic]].   \n\nThe Marshall Tucker Band continued recording and performing into the 21st century, playing between 150 and 200 shows per year.<ref name=bio /> The band reissued many of its albums from the 1970s on its new Ramblin' Records label, as well as two two-disc compilations, the first (''Anthology'') being a 30-year retrospective and the second (''Where a Country Boy Belongs'') being a collection of the band's country songs. In 2004, they released another studio album, ''Beyond the Horizon'', and the following year released a Christmas album, ''Carolina Christmas''. In 2007 they released their newest studio album ''The Next Adventure''.\n\n\"Can't You See'\" was used for the opening and closing credits of the [[Kevin Costner]] 2008 motion picture ''[[Swing Vote (2008 film)|Swing Vote]]''. \"Take the Highway\" was also used in the movie.\n\n\"Can't You See\" is also used in the 2001 film ''[[Blow (film)|Blow]]'' and the 2017 film ''[[I, Tonya]]''.\n\n==Musical style==\n[[Tommy Caldwell (musician)|Tommy Caldwell]] described the Marshall Tucker Band's music as [[progressive country]], explaining that the band played [[country music]] structures and riffs combined with [[jazz]] improvisation upon which more complex structures were built from the country music foundation.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.loudersound.com/reviews/marshall-tucker-band-where-we-all-belong-album-of-the-week-club-review |title=Marshall Tucker Band: Where We All Belong - Album Of The Week Club review|author=Staff |date=January 24, 2022 |work=Classic Rock |access-date=2023-07-22}}</ref> In 1977, ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' identified the Marshall Tucker Band as major performers of the genre.<ref>{{cite magazine |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=p00EAAAAMBAJ&dq=marshall+tucker+band+%22progressive+country%22&pg=PT92 |title=Traditional Country + Modern Sound |last=Cech |first=Tom |date= October 15, 1977|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=2023-07-24}}</ref> Aside from progressive country, the band has also been categorized as [[Southern rock]],<ref name=longislander>{{Cite web|url=http://www.longislandernews.com/life-and-style/the-marshall-tucker-band-brings-southern-rock-to-the-paramount|title=The Marshall Tucker Band Brings Southern Rock To The Paramount|website=Long Islander News|date=6 December 2017 |access-date=Apr 28, 2019}}</ref><ref name=allmusic3/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.axs.com/the-marshall-tucker-band-southern-jam-kings-32507|title=The Marshall Tucker Band: Southern jam kings|website=Axs.com|access-date=Apr 28, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/entertainment/music/op-ed-marshall-tucker-band-puts-on-the-best-southern-rock-show-of-2017/article/510984|title=Op-Ed: Marshall Tucker Band puts on the best southern rock show of 2017|date=December 28, 2017|website=Digitaljournal.com|access-date=Apr 28, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://beneathadesertsky.com/2017/10/15/the-marshall-tucker-band-brings-its-southern-rock-to-talking-stick-resort-showroom/|title=The Marshall Tucker Band Brings its Southern Rock to Talking Stick Resort Showroom |website=Beneathadesertsky.com|first=Fred|last=Kuhlman|date=15 October 2017 |access-date=Apr 28, 2019}}</ref> [[blues rock]],<ref name=allmusic4>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/live-on-long-island-4-18-80-mw0000445891|title=Live on Long Island: 4-18-80 - The Marshall Tucker Band &#124; Songs, Reviews, Credits|website=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=Apr 28, 2019}}</ref> [[country rock]],<ref name=Faignant/> [[jazz rock]],<ref name=Faignant>{{cite web |url= https://www.rutlandherald.com/features/vermont_arts/the-marshall-tucker-band-southern-rock-n-roll-music-with-the-ability-to-stray/article_c0af42cc-74ac-5792-956d-1134f912c4d5.html |title=The Marshall Tucker Band: 'Southern rock 'n' roll music with the ability to stray' |last=Faignant |first=Janelle |date=February 18, 2023 |work=Rutland Herald |access-date=2023-07-22}}</ref> and as a \"proto-[[jam band]]\".<ref name=allmusic4/> ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' charts have categorized the band as country, blues and [[adult contemporary]].<ref name=allmusic3/>\n\nThe band has incorporated throughout its career elements of diverse genres into its sound, most frequently [[blues]],<ref name=southernrockbrasil/><ref name=longislander/><ref name=rollingstone>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country-lists/50-rock-albums-every-country-fan-should-own-150698/|title=50 Rock Albums Every Country Fan Should Own|first1=Jon Dolan, David Menconi, Linda Ryan, Rob Harvilla, Charles Aaron, Nick Murray, Kory Grow, Mike Powell, Marissa R. Moss, Reed Fischer, Richard Gehr, Chuck|last1=Eddy|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=Nov 12, 2014|access-date=Apr 28, 2019}}</ref><ref name=allmusic3>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-marshall-tucker-band-mn0000052382|title=The Marshall Tucker Band &#124; Biography, Albums, Streaming Links|website=AllMusic|access-date=Apr 28, 2019}}</ref> country<ref name=southernrockbrasil/><ref name=longislander/><ref name=allmusic3/> and jazz.<ref name=southernrockbrasil>{{Cite web|url=http://www.southernrockbrasil.com.br/2012/10/marshall-tucker-band-new-life-review.html?m=1|title=Marshall Tucker Band - A New Life (Review) - Southern Rock Brasil|date=19 January 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180119235115/http://www.southernrockbrasil.com.br/2012/10/marshall-tucker-band-new-life-review.html?m=1|access-date=28 September 2021|archive-date=2018-01-19}}</ref><ref name=allmusic3/> The band has also drawn from [[boogie]],<ref name=rollingstone/> [[psychedelic music|psychedelic]],<ref name=allmusic1/> [[R&B]],<ref name=allmusic1/> [[Gospel music|gospel]],<ref name=allmusic1/> [[folk music|folk]],<ref name=allmusic1>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/the-marshall-tucker-band-mw0000195566|title=The Marshall Tucker Band - The Marshall Tucker Band &#124; Songs, Reviews, Credits|website=AllMusic|access-date=Apr 28, 2019}}</ref> and [[rock and roll]].<ref name=longislander/> According to [[Allmusic]]'s Jeff Tamarkin, Toy Caldwell's guitar playing style was categorized by \"flashy, jazzy licks\"; the band has also been noted for extensive [[Jam session|jamming]].<ref name=allmusic4/>\n\nRemembering the early years in 2012,  Doug Gray describes the band as being like <nowiki>''a bowl of soup like your mom would cook. Whatever was in the refrigerator was all thrown in there, and however it tasted was what it was.'' As Grey remarks, the result was so eclectic that the press didn'</nowiki>t really know what to make of them as they failed to fit neatly in any pigeonhole.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Goldmine Staff|title=MTB's singer Doug Gray is still searchin' For a rainbow|url=https://www.goldminemag.com/articles/mtbs-singer-doug-gray-is-still-searchin-for-a-rainbow|access-date=2020-12-17|website=Goldmine Magazine: Record Collector & Music Memorabilia|date=15 July 2012 |language=en}}</ref>\n\n==Members==\n===Current===\n* [[Doug Gray]] - vocals <small>(1972-present)</small>\n* Chris Hicks - lead guitar <small>(1996-present)</small>\n* [[B.B. Borden]] - drums <small>(1997-present)</small>\n* Rick Willis - rhythm guitar <small>(2009-present)</small>\n* Marcus James Henderson - flute <small>(2009-present)</small>\n* Ryan Ware - bass <small>(2021-present)</small>\n\n===Former===\n* [[Toy Caldwell]] \u2013 lead guitar <small>(1972-1984; died 1993)</small>\n* [[Tommy Caldwell (musician)|Tommy Caldwell]] \u2013 bass <small>(1972-1980; his death)</small>\n* [[George McCorkle]] \u2013 rhythm guitar <small>(1972-1984; died 2007)</small>\n* Paul Riddle \u2013 drums <small>(1972-1984)</small>\n* [[Jerry Eubanks]] \u2013 flute <small>(1972-1996)</small>\n* Frankie Wilkie \u2013 bass <small>(1980-1984)</small>\n* Ronnie Godfrey \u2013 keyboards <small>(1982-1984)</small>\n* Kenny Mims \u2013 lead guitar <small>(1984-1985; died 2020)</small>\n* Bob Wray \u2013 bass <small>(1984-1985)</small>\n* Rusty Milner \u2013 rhythm guitar <small>(1984-2003)</small>\n* David Allen \u2013 drums <small>(1984-1992)</small>\n* [[Bobby Ogdin]] \u2013 keyboards <small>(1984-1989)</small>\n* Stuart Swanlund \u2013 lead guitar <small>(1985-1993, 1995-2009, died 2012)</small>\n* [[Tom Robb]] \u2013 bass <small>(1985-1987; died 2006)</small>\n* Tim Lawter \u2013 bass <small>(1987-2001)</small>\n* Don Cameron \u2013 keyboards <small>(1989-1992)</small>\n* Mark Pettey \u2013 keyboards <small>(1992-1994)</small>\n* [[Frankie Toler]] \u2013 drums <small>(1992-1994; died 2011)</small>\n* Ronald Radford \u2013 lead guitar <small>(1993-1995)</small>\n* Garry Guzzardo \u2013 drums <small>(1994-1996)</small>\n* Paul Thompson \u2013 keyboards <small>(1994)</small>\n* [[David Muse]] \u2013 flute <small>(1996-2000, 2003-2009; died 2022)</small>\n* [[Clay Cook]] \u2013 flute <small>(2000-2003)</small>\n* Tony Heatherly \u2013 bass <small>(2001-2004)</small>\n* Pat Elwood \u2013 bass <small>(2004-2017)</small>\n* Tony Black \u2013 bass <small>(2017-2020)</small>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n! colspan=\"3\"| Chart positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Factory\n|-\n| ''The Essential MTB 3.0''\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| 2011\n| ''Greatest Hits'' [Expanded This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jawga_Boyz","to":"Jawga Boyz"}],"pages":{"50535014":{"pageid":50535014,"ns":0,"title":"Jawga Boyz","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|We are professionals}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Jawga Boyz\n| image           = D. Thrash of Jawga Boyz wearing a white shirt with a blue tie.jpg\n| image_size      =\n| landscape       =\n| alt             =\n| caption         = D. Thrash of Jawga Boyz performing in 2012\n| alias           =\n| origin          = [[Athens, Georgia]]\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Country rap]]}}\n| years_active    = 2003\u2013present\n| label           = D. Thrash Productions\n| associated_acts = [[Joe Diffie]]\n| website         = \n| current_members = Derek \"D Thrash\" Thrasher<br/>A.J. \"BoonDock\" McIntyre<br/>Mark \"Cornbread\" Bryant<br/>Dez<br/>Chris Hood<br/>Rich \"Sloppy Jones\" Williamson<br/>Doyle \"Dreadneck\" Williams\n| past_members    = \n}}\n\n'''Jawga Boyz''' is an American [[country rap]] group formed in [[Athens, Georgia]] in 2003.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|last=Jeffries|first=David|title=Jawga Boyz {{!}} Biography & History|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=mn0002911507/biography|pure_url=yes}}|work=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=May 13, 2016}}</ref> The current lineup is  D Thrash, BoonDock, Cornbread, Dez, Chris Hood, Sloppy Jones, and Dreadneck.<ref name=\"allmusic\" /> They have released four studio albums including 2014's ''Tailgate Music'', which debuted at number 155 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], number 22 on the Country Albums chart and number 17 on the [[Rap Albums]] chart. Steve Leggett of [[AllMusic]] gave ''Tailgate Music'' a favorable review, writing that it \"keeps the fun and quality up, showing once again what this Dirty South hip-hop country rock thing is all about, and doing it all with engaging energy and intensity.The Group has Disbanded and hasn't released songs in a number of years\"<ref>{{cite web|last=Leggett|first=Steve|title=''Tailgate Music'' review|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=mw0002714946|pure_url=yes}}|work=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=May 13, 2016}}</ref>\n\nIn 2013, Thrasher wrote and recorded a song with [[Joe Diffie]], \"Girl Ridin' Shotgun\". In response to [[Jason Aldean]]s song \"[[1994 (song)|1994]]\" <ref>{{cite news|last1=Dukes|first1=Billy|title=The Real Joe Diffie Releases 'Girl Ridin' Shotgun' Video, a Response to '1994'|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/joe-diffie-girl-ridin-shotgun-video/|accessdate=May 13, 2016|work=Taste of Country|date=June 21, 2013}}</ref> Their song \"Chillin in the Backwoods\" feat. Young Gunner currently has over 80 million views on YouTube. It also features known country rap guitarist, Matt \"Manchild\" Marshall on guitar.\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:10em;\"| Title\n! Thrash Productions\n| 22\n| 17\n| 155\n| 4\n| 28\n|-\n| colspan=\"7\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{official|http://jawgaboyzz.com/}}\n\n[[Category:Country music groups from Georgia (U.S. state)]]\n[[Category:American hip hop groups]]\n[[Category:Country rap musicians]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 2003]]\n[[Category:Musical groups from Athens, Georgia]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Kid_Rock","to":"Kid Rock"}],"pages":{"17396":{"pageid":17396,"ns":0,"title":"Kid Rock","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American musician (born 1971)}}\n{{for|the 2003 self-titled album|Kid Rock (album)}}\n{{Use American English|date=August 2022}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2018}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| background       = solo_singer\n| name             = Kid Rock\n| image            = Kid Rock Dec 2013.jpg\n| caption          = Kid Rock performing in 2013\n| birth_name       = Robert James Ritchie\n| alias            = Bobby Shazam\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1971|1|17}}\n| birth_place      = [[Romeo, Michigan]], U.S.\n| death_date       =\n| genre            = {{flatlist|\n* [[Rock music|Rock]]\n* [[Country music|country]]\n* [[Hip hop music|hip hop]]\n* {{nowrap|[[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]]}}\n}}\n| occupations       = {{flatlist|\n* Musician\n* singer\n* rapper\n* songwriter\n}}\n|instruments       =\n {{flatlist|\n* Vocals\n* guitar \n}}\n| years_active     = 1988\u2013present\n| label            = {{flatlist|\n* Top Dog\n* [[Broken Bow Records|Broken Bow]]\n* [[Warner Records|Warner Bros.]]\n* [[Lava Records|Lava]]\n* [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]\n* [[Jive Records|Jive]]\n}}\n{{Infobox person\n| embed              = yes\n| spouse             = {{marriage|[[Pamela Anderson]]|2006|2007|end=div}}\n| relatives          = [[Jill Ritchie]] (sister)\n| children           = 1\n| website            = {{URL|kidrock.com}}\n}}\n}}\n'''Robert James Ritchie''' (born January 17, 1971), known professionally as '''Kid Rock''', is an American musician, singer, rapper, and songwriter. After establishing himself in the [[Music of Detroit#Hip hop|Detroit hip hop]] scene, he broke through into mainstream success with a [[rap rock]] sound before shifting his performance style to [[country rock]]. A self-taught musician, he has said he can play every instrument in his backing band and has overseen production on all but two of his albums.\n\nKid Rock started his music career as a rapper and DJ, releasing his debut album ''[[Grits Sandwiches for Breakfast]]'' (1990), on [[Jive Records]]. His subsequent independent releases ''[[The Polyfuze Method]]'' (1993) and ''[[Early Mornin' Stoned Pimp]]'' (1996) saw him developing a more distinctive style, which was fully realized on his breakthrough album ''[[Devil Without a Cause]]'' (1998), which sold 14 million copies. This album and its follow-up, ''[[Cocky (album)|Cocky]]'' (2001), were noted for blending elements of hip-hop, country and rock.\n\nHis most successful single from that time period, \"[[Cowboy (Kid Rock song)|Cowboy]]\" (1999), is considered a pioneering song in the [[country rap]] genre. His best-selling singles overall are \"[[Picture (song)|Picture]]\" (2002) and \"[[All Summer Long (Kid Rock song)|All Summer Long]]\" (2008). Starting with his 2007 album ''[[Rock n Roll Jesus]]'', his musical output has tended to be in the country rock style. Politically, Ritchie is a vocal supporter of the U.S. [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] and holds conservative views.\n\n==Early life==\nKid Rock was born Robert James Ritchie in [[Romeo, Michigan]], on January 17, 1971, the son of Susan and William \"Bill\" Ritchie (1941\u20132024),<ref>{{cite web |title=Bill Ritchie, former Sterling Heights auto dealer and father of Kid Rock, dies in Florida |url=https://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/music/brian-mccollum/2024/02/16/bill-ritchie-father-of-kid-rock-and-ex-sterling-heights-auto-dealer-dies/72633949007/ |website=www.freep.com}}</ref> who owned multiple car dealerships.<ref name=\"Biography\">{{cite web|url=https://www.biography.com/people/kid-rock-251986|title=Kid Rock|website=Biography.com|access-date=October 13, 2017|archive-date=October 13, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171013224846/https://www.biography.com/people/kid-rock-251986|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=\"Allmusic\"/><ref name=\"cowboysindians\"/> He was raised in his father's large home on extensive property,<ref name=\"Biography\"/><ref name=Freep2016>{{cite web|url=http://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/macomb/2016/11/04/kid-rock-macomb-county-house/93299716/|title=Kid Rock's posh childhood home listed in Macomb County for $1.3M|website=Freep.com|access-date=November 3, 2017|archive-date=November 7, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107142821/http://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/macomb/2016/11/04/kid-rock-macomb-county-house/93299716/|url-status=live}}</ref> which included an [[apple orchard]] and barnyard for their horses.<ref name=\"The Independent\">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/my-secret-life-kid-rock-musician-age-37-870596.html|title=My Secret Life: Kid Rock Musician (age 37)|last=Philby|first=Charlotte|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|access-date=November 30, 2010|location=London|date=July 19, 2008|archive-date=March 24, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324122407/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/my-secret-life-kid-rock-musician-age-37-870596.html|url-status=live}}</ref> He attended [[Romeo High School]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.dailytribune.com/2011/04/22/kid-rock-visits-romeo-high-school-donates-money/amp/ | title=Kid Rock visits Romeo High School, donates money | date=April 22, 2011 }}</ref> His younger sister, [[Jill Ritchie]], is an actress.<ref name=Heartbreak/> In the 1980s, Kid Rock became interested in [[hip hop]], began to [[breakdance]], and taught himself how to rap and DJ while performing in talent shows in and around [[Detroit]].<ref name=Biography/><ref name=\"Allmusic\">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist |id=kid-rock-p15074/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Kid Rock \u2013 Biography|last=Huey|first=Jeff |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=November 30, 2010}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\n===Early career, signing with Jive Records, and ''Grits Sandwiches for Breakfast'' (1988\u20131991)===\nKid Rock began his professional music career as a member of a [[hip hop music]] group called the Beast Crew in the late 1980s.<ref name=Biography/> During this time, he met rapper [[D-Nice]]. That relationship would eventually lead to him becoming the opening act at local shows for [[Boogie Down Productions]].<ref name=Biography/>\n\nDuring this time, Kid Rock began a professional association with producer [[Mike E. Clark]], who, after some initial skepticism with the idea of a white rapper, found himself impressed with Kid Rock's energetic and well-received performance where the artist, using his own turntables and equipment, actually prepared his own beats to demonstrate his skills for Clark.<ref name=\"freepearly\">{{cite web|url=https://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/music/brian-mccollum/2015/08/26/kid-rock-early-years-detroit/31193049/|title=Kid Rock before the fame: The definitive Detroit oral history|website=Freep.com|access-date=February 1, 2018|archive-date=January 27, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180127204237/https://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/music/brian-mccollum/2015/08/26/kid-rock-early-years-detroit/31193049/|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nIn 1988, Clark produced a series of demos with Kid Rock. These demos eventually led to offers from six major record labels, including [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]] and [[CBS Associated Records|CBS Records]].<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/><ref name=\"freepearly\"/>\n\nIn 1989, Kid Rock became a shareholder in an independent record label that was formed by Alvin Williams and Earl Blunt of EB-Bran Productions, called \"Top Dog\" Records. Later, that investment would become a 25% ownership stake.<ref name=\"mtv.com\">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1458341/kid-rocks-ex-partners-ask-judge-to-determine-whos-top-dog/|title=Kid Rock's Ex-Partners Ask Judge To Determine Who's Top Dog|website=MTV.com|access-date=February 1, 2018|archive-date=January 28, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180128132500/http://www.mtv.com/news/1458341/kid-rocks-ex-partners-ask-judge-to-determine-whos-top-dog/|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nWith the help of D-Nice, Kid Rock signed with [[Jive Records]] at the age of 17, releasing his debut studio album, ''[[Grits Sandwiches for Breakfast]]'' in 1990.<ref name=\"Biography\"/><ref name=\"cowboysindians\"/><ref name=\"freepearly\"/> According to Kid Rock, the contract with Jive resulted in animosity from fellow rapper [[Vanilla Ice]], who felt that he should have been signed with Jive instead of Kid Rock.<ref name=\"freepearly\"/>\n\nThe album made Kid Rock one of the two biggest rap stars in Detroit in 1990, along with local [[independent music|independent]] rapper [[Esham]].<ref name=\"BehindthePaint164\">{{cite book |last1=Bruce |first1=Joseph |author-link=Violent J|last2=Echlin |first2=Hobey |editor=Nathan Fostey |title=ICP: Behind the Paint |url=https://archive.org/details/icpbehindpaint00viol |url-access=registration |date=August 2003 |edition=second |publisher=Psychopathic Records |location=Royal Oak, Michigan |isbn=0-9741846-0-8 |pages=[https://archive.org/details/icpbehindpaint00viol/page/164 164\u2013167] |chapter=Paying Dues }}</ref><ref name=\"BehindthePaint174\">{{cite book |last1=Bruce |first1=Joseph |author-link=Violent J |last2=Echlin |first2=Hobey |editor=Nathan Fostey |title=ICP: Behind the Paint |url=https://archive.org/details/icpbehindpaint00viol |url-access=registration |edition=second |publisher=Psychopathic Records |location=Royal Oak, Michigan |isbn=0-9741846-0-8 |pages=[https://archive.org/details/icpbehindpaint00viol/page/174 174\u2013189] |chapter=The Dark Carnival|date=August 2003 }}</ref> To promote the album, Kid Rock toured nationally with [[Ice Cube]], D-Nice, [[Yo-Yo (rapper)|Yo-Yo]] and [[Too Short]]; Detroit artist James \"Blackman\" Harris served as Kid Rock's DJ on this tour.<ref name=\"freepearly\"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www2.metrotimes.com/editorial/story.asp?id=7099 |title=Metro Times - Music: Champ's town |access-date=January 28, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090102071445/http://www.metrotimes.com/editorial/story.asp?id=7099 |archive-date=January 2, 2009 |url-status=dead }}</ref> During instore promotions for the album, Kid Rock met and developed a friendship with local rapper [[Eminem]], who frequently challenged Kid Rock to rap battles.<ref name=\"freepearly\"/>\n\nUltimately, unfavorable comparisons to Vanilla Ice led to Jive dropping Kid Rock, according to Mike E. Clark.<ref name=\"freepearly\"/>\n\n===Signing with Continuum Records and ''The Polyfuze Method'' (1992\u20131995)===\nIn 1992, Kid Rock signed with local independent record label Continuum.<ref name=freepearly/> Around this time, Kid Rock met local hip hop duo [[Insane Clown Posse]] through Mike E. Clark, who was producing the duo.<ref name=\"BehindthePaint174\" /> While ICP member [[Joseph Bruce|Violent J]] disliked Kid Rock's music, he wanted the rapper to appear on ICP's debut album, ''[[Carnival of Carnage]]'', believing the appearance would gain ICP notice, since Kid Rock was a nationally successful artist.<ref name=\"BehindthePaint174\" /> Noting that local rapper Esham was paid $500 to appear on ICP's album, Violent J claims that Kid Rock demanded $600 ({{Inflation|US|600|1992|fmt=eq}}) to record his guest appearance, alleging that Esham and Kid Rock had a feud over who was the bigger rapper.<ref name=\"BehindthePaint174\" /> Kid Rock showed up to record the song \"Is That You?\" intoxicated, but re-recorded his vocals and record scratching the following day.<ref name=\"BehindthePaint174\" />\n\nIn 1993, Kid Rock recorded his second studio album, ''[[The Polyfuze Method]]'', with producer Mike E. Clark, who worked with Kid Rock to help give the album more of a rock-oriented sound than his debut.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/>\n\nKid Rock also began releasing his \"Bootleg\" cassette series to keep local interest in his music.<ref name=freepearly/>\n\nLater in the year, Kid Rock recorded the EP ''[[Fire It Up (EP)|Fire It Up]]'' at White Room Studios in downtown Detroit, run by brothers Michael and Andrew Nehra, who were forming the rock-soul band [[Robert Bradley's Blackwater Surprise]].<ref name=freepearly/> The EP featured the [[heavy metal music|heavy rock]] song \"[[I Am the Bullgod]]\" and a cover of [[Hank Williams Jr.]]'s [[country music|country]] song \"A Country Boy Can Survive\".<ref name=freepearly/>\n\nBy 1994, Kid Rock's live performances had mostly been backed by DJs Blackman and [[Uncle Kracker]], but Kid Rock soon began to utilize more and more live instrumentation into his performances, and formed the rock band [[Twisted Brown Trucker]].<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/><ref name=freepearly/>\n\nAfter breaking up with his girlfriend, Kid Rock moved engineer Bob Ebeling into his apartment.<ref name=freepearly/> During a recording session with Mike E. Clark, the producer discovered that Kid Rock could sing when he recorded a reworked cover of [[Billy Joel]]'s \"[[It's Still Rock and Roll to Me]]\", entitled \"It's Still East Detroit to Me\", which Clark claims led him to encourage Kid Rock to sing more.<ref name=freepearly/>\n\nDuring this time, Kid Rock developed animosity towards other Detroit artists, including Insane Clown Posse.{{citation needed|date=June 2023}}\n\nThrough extensive promoting, including distributing tapes on consignment to local stores and giving away free samplers of his music, Kid Rock developed a following among an audience which DJ Uncle Kracker described as \"white kids who dropped [[LSD|acid]] and liked listening to [[gangsta rap]]\"; this following included local rapper [[Joe C.]], who had been attending Kid Rock concerts as a fan, but upon meeting Kid Rock, was invited to perform on stage as Kid Rock's hype man.<ref name=freepearly/>\n\n===''Early Mornin' Stoned Pimp'' and local breakthrough (1996)===\n[[File:Kid Rock (3421137233).jpg|thumb|A display of pyrotechnics during one of Kid Rock's performances. His stage presence helped increase his local following in Detroit in the mid-1990s.]]\nKid Rock's stage presence became honed with the addition of a light show, pyrotechnics, dancers and a light-up backdrop bearing the name \"Kid Rock\", and 1996 saw the release of his most rock-oriented album to date, ''[[Early Mornin' Stoned Pimp]]''; the album's title came from Bob Eberling, who told a sleepless, alcoholic, drug-using Kid Rock, \"Dude, you are the early-morning, stoned pimp.\"<ref name=freepearly/> According to Kid Rock, who distributed the album himself, ''Early Mornin' Stoned Pimp'' sold 14,000 copies.<ref name=cowboysindians/>\n\nKid Rock developed his stage persona, performing dressed in 1970s pimp clothing with a real, possibly loaded, gun down the front of his pants.<ref name=freepearly/>\n\nThough Kid Rock became known for frequent partying, as well as his drug and alcohol use, he was primarily focused on increasing his success and fame, placing himself as a businessman first; the result of this drive led to increased success locally.<ref name=freepearly/>\n\n===Signing with Atlantic Records, ''Devil Without a Cause'', and national success (1997\u20132000)===\nKid Rock's attorney, Tommy Valentino, increased his stature by helping him get articles written about Kid Rock and Twisted Brown Trucker in major publications, including [[Beastie Boys]]' ''[[Grand Royal]]'' magazine. However, though his management tried to interest local record labels in his music, they told his management team that they were not interested in signing a white rapper, to which Valentino told them, \"He's not a white rapper. He's a rock star and everything in between.\"<ref name=freepearly/>\n\nIn 1997, Jason Flom, head of [[Lava Records]], attended one of Kid Rock's performances, and met with Kid Rock, who later gave him a demo containing the songs \"Somebody's Gotta Feel This\" and \"I Got One for Ya\", which led to Kid Rock signing with Atlantic Records.<ref name=freepearly/><ref name=\"Lava Record Deal\">{{cite web|title=Interview Andy Karp Vice President of A&R at Lava/Atlantic in New York |publisher=AtlanticRecordsContact.com |url=http://www.atlanticrecordscontact.com/ |access-date=July 22, 2008 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705133859/http://www.atlanticrecordscontact.com/ |archive-date=July 5, 2008 }}</ref> As part of his recording deal, Kid Rock received $150,000 from the label.<ref name=cowboysindians/>\n\nBy this time Kid Rock had fully developed his stage persona, and musical style and wanted to make a \"[[redneck]], shit-kicking [[rock and roll|rock 'n' roll]] rap\" album, resulting in his fourth studio album, ''[[Devil Without a Cause]]'', recorded at the White Room in Detroit and mixed at the Mix Room in Los Angeles.<ref name=freepearly/>\n\nThe album was a commercial smash hit as it would be certified Gold and Platinum several months after its release. In promotion of the record, Kid Rock would join [[Limp Bizkit]] on a national tour spanning 27 dates.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mtv.com/news/6dmipb/limp-bizkit-kid-rock-announce-joint-us-tour-dates|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230525061804/https://www.mtv.com/news/6dmipb/limp-bizkit-kid-rock-announce-joint-us-tour-dates|url-status=dead|archive-date=May 25, 2023|title=Limp Bizkit & Kid Rock announce joint US Tour Dates|website=[[MTV]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mtv.com/news/zhqigx/limp-bizkit-taps-kid-rock-for-summer-tour|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230525061935/https://www.mtv.com/news/zhqigx/limp-bizkit-taps-kid-rock-for-summer-tour|url-status=dead|archive-date=May 25, 2023|title=Limp Bizkit Taps Kid Rock For Summer Tour|website=[[MTV]] }}</ref> He made an appearance on the [[1999 MTV Video Music Awards|1999]] [[MTV]] VMA (including a performance alongside [[Aerosmith]] and [[Run-DMC]]) and also memorably performed [[Bawitdaba]] at [[Woodstock 1999]].
