the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Bucky_Covington","to":"Bucky Covington"}],"pages":{"4095922":{"pageid":4095922,"ns":0,"title":"Bucky Covington","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name         = Bucky Covington\n| image        = Bucky Covington.jpg\n| caption      = Bucky Covington in [[The American Idol Experience]] motorcade at [[Walt Disney World]].\n| image_size   = <!-- Only for images narrower than 220 pixels -->\n| birth_name   = William Joel Covington III\n| birth_date   = {{birth date and age|1977|11|8}}\n| origin       = [[Laurinburg, North Carolina|Rockingham]], [[North Carolina]], [[United States]]\n| instrument   = Vocals, guitar, bass guitar, drums\n| genre        = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation   = Singer\n| years_active = 2006\u2013present\n| label        = [[Lyric Street Records|Lyric Street]], [[eOne Music|E1 Music]]\n| website      = [http://www.buckycovington.com/ buckycovington.com]\n}}\n\n'''William Joel''' \"'''Bucky'''\" '''Covington III''' (born November 8, 1977) is an American [[country music]] singer. He placed eighth on the [[American Idol (season 5)|5th season]] of the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox Network's]] talent competition series ''[[American Idol]]''. In December 2006, he signed a recording contract with [[Lyric Street Records]]. His self-titled [[Bucky Covington (album)|debut album]], produced by Dale Oliver and Mark Miller of the band [[Sawyer Brown]], was released on April 17, 2007. The album debuted at number one on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart, and produced three hit singles on the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts: \"[[A Different World (song)|A Different World]]\" at number six, \"[[It's Good to Be Us]]\" at number eleven, and \"[[I'll Walk]]\" at number ten. Three more singles: \"[[I Want My Life Back]]\", \"[[Gotta Be Somebody]]\", and \"[[A Father's Love (The Only Way He Knew How)]]\", were released for an unreleased second album, titled ''I'm Alright'', and later included on his 2012 album, ''[[Good Guys (album)|Good Guys]].''\n\n==Biography==\n===Personal life===\nWilliam Joel \u201cBucky\u201d Covington was born in [[Rockingham, North Carolina]], to Gene Covington and Deborah Gates on November 8, 1977 - along with his identical [[twin]] brother, Robert David \"Rocky\" Covington.\nBucky is the nickname derived from his grandfather \"Buck\".<ref>[http://myidol.idolonfox.com/blogs/cheeselady/2006/03/11/Bucky_and_Rocky MyIDOL \u2013 American Idol<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927065803/http://myidol.idolonfox.com/blogs/cheeselady/2006/03/11/Bucky_and_Rocky |date=2007-09-27 }}</ref> He graduated in the class of 1996 from [[Scotland High School]] in [[Laurinburg, North Carolina]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Bucky Covington |url=https://northcarolinamusichalloffame.org/vtour/inductee-item/bucky-covington/#toggle-id-1 |website=North Carolina Music Hall Of Fame Virtual Tour |access-date=15 June 2020}}</ref> He worked at Covington's Body Shop in [[Rockingham, North Carolina]].<ref>[http://www.laurinburgexchange.com/pages/full_story/push?article-Local+idol-+Bucky+Covington-+returns%20&id=20576272&instance=top_stories]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>\n\nAt the age of 18, Covington taught himself how to play the guitar and began performing at clubs. He is also a [[bassist]], [[drummer]], and [[songwriter]]. Over the years, Covington has expanded his talents, both [[country music|country]] and [[rock music|rock]].  After some time, he elected to perform both original and cover material in a cross-genre vein. Rocky is also a musician and is the former lead singer of the North Carolina band ''Swamp Cat''.\n\nIn 1998, when the Covington twins were 20 years old, they were in a minor automobile mishap.  Bucky allegedly pretended to be Rocky. They were arrested for confusing the authorities. The plaintiff failed to identify which twin was driving, since the twins were identical.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1528396/20060411/index.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060420092904/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1528396/20060411/index.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 20, 2006|title=Report: 'Idol' Finalist Bucky Covington Duped Police To Help Twin|work=MTV News}}</ref>\n\nAfter ''Idol'', Bucky bought a house in [[Franklin, Tennessee]], near Nashville, which he shared with Rocky and his wife Terra. Rocky also joined Bucky's band as a drummer. On February 13, 2007, he and his wife Crystal [[legal separation|separated]] after more than seven years of marriage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/package/americanidol2007/article/0,,20007868_20011779,00.html|title=Bucky Covington & Wife Split - American Idol, Bucky Covington |website=People.com}}</ref> Covington became engaged to Katherine Cook in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/bucky-covington-theft-accusation/|title=Bucky Covington Accused of Theft|date=25 July 2011|work=Taste of Country}}</ref>\n\nOn October 10, 2014, Covington's fiancee, Katherine Cook, gave birth to their daughter, Kennedy Taylor Covington.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2014/10/10/bucky-covington-welcomes-daughter-kennedy-taylor/|title=Bucky Covington Welcomes Daughter Kennedy Taylor \u2013 Moms & Babies \u2013 Celebrity Babies and Kids - Moms & Babies |website=People.com}}</ref>\n\n===''American Idol''===\nIn the 2005-06 season, the Covington twins auditioned for ''American Idol'' in [[Greensboro, North Carolina]], individually. Of the two, Bucky advanced to the final twelve.  On March 22, Bucky remained in the bottom three, along with [[Lisa Tucker (singer)|Lisa Tucker]] and [[Kevin Covais]]. On April 12, when Covington was in the bottom three with [[Ace Young]] and [[Elliott Yamin]], the votes went to the latter two.  In the Top 8 results show of season six of American Idol, he appeared in one of the front rows.\n\n;Performances during ''Idol''\n;Semi-finals\n*February 22, 2006: \"Simple Man\" by [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]]\n*March 1, 2006: \"[[The Thunder Rolls]]\" by [[Garth Brooks]]\n*March 8, 2006: \"[[Wave on Wave (song)|Wave on Wave]]\" by [[Pat Green]]\n\n;Finals\n*March 14, 2006: \"[[Superstition (song)|Superstition]]\" by [[Stevie Wonder]]\n*March 21, 2006: \"[[Oh, Boy! (The Crickets song)|Oh Boy]]\" by [[Buddy Holly]] (Bottom 2)\n*March 28, 2006: \"[[Real Good Man]]\" by [[Tim McGraw]]\n*April 4, 2006: \"[[Best I Ever Had (Grey Sky Morning)|Best I Ever Had]]\" by [[Gary Allan]]\n*April 11, 2006: \"[[Fat Bottomed Girls]]\" by [[Queen (band)|Queen]] (Bottom 3, Eliminated)\n\n===Debut album: ''Bucky Covington''===\nIn November and December 2006, Bucky Covington performed on the GAC Country Music Christmas tour, making him the first Idol from the 5th season to be part of a major non-American Idol concert tour.<ref>[http://www.countrymusicchristmastour.com/ GAC Country Christmas<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070110170400/http://www.countrymusicchristmastour.com/ |date=2007-01-10 }}</ref>\n\nCovington negotiated with [[Disney Music Group|Buena Vista Music Group]]'s country label, [[Lyric Street Records]]. His debut single, \"[[A Different World (song)|A Different World]]\", was released to country radio on January 16, 2007, coinciding with the premiere of [[American Idol (season 6)]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.syracuse.com/idolthoughts/2007/01/the_numbers_are_in_and_theyre_1.html|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130816055752/http://blog.syracuse.com/idolthoughts/2007/01/the_numbers_are_in_and_theyre_1.html|url-status=dead|title=The Numbers are in and They're Not Pretty|first=Donna|last=Reynolds|date=January 4, 2007|website=Syracuse.com|archive-date=August 16, 2013|access-date=March 25, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1549185/20070103/rascal_flatts.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070107230504/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1549185/20070103/rascal_flatts.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 7, 2007|title=CMT}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_headlines/article/0,,GAC_26063_5256649,00.html |title=GAC |access-date=2007-01-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070105234103/http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_headlines/article/0,,GAC_26063_5256649,00.html |archive-date=2007-01-05 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Its initial debut on radio was on Sirius Satellite Radio's ''New Country'' channel in late December 2006.\n\nHis debut album, ''[[Bucky Covington (album)|Bucky Covington]]'', was released on April 17, 2007, to positive reviews. It debuted on the Billboard 200 at number four selling 61,000 copies. It also debuted at number one on the Top Country Albums chart, making the album the best opening week for a debut album by a male on the chart since [[Billy Ray Cyrus]]' 1992 debut with ''[[Some Gave All]]''.<ref>Katie Hasty, [http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1052570/lavignes-new-thing-debuts-atop-billboard-200 \"Lavigne's New 'Thing' Debuts Atop Billboard 200\"], Billboard.com, April 25, 2007.</ref> Covington's debut surpassed the previous record held by [[Jason Michael Carroll]]'s ''[[Waitin' in the Country]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jasonmichaelcarroll.com/site.php?em2253=116321_-1__0_~0_-1_2_2007_0_0&content=news|title=jmc|access-date=2007-07-21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927190040/http://www.jasonmichaelcarroll.com/site.php?em2253=116321_-1__0_~0_-1_2_2007_0_0&content=news|archive-date=2007-09-27|url-status=dead}}</ref> He performed selections from his album during a nationwide tour in 2007, and the track \"Empty Handed\" appeared in NASCAR 08 as part of the in-game soundtrack. Overall, ''Bucky Covington'' accounted for three singles. \"A Different World\" peaked at number six, followed by \"It's Good to Be Us\" at number eleven and \"I'll Walk\" at number ten.\n\n===Unreleased second album: ''I'm Alright'' and ''Good Guys''===\nIn January 2009, Lyric Street noted that Covington has been in the studio recording his second album, ''I'm Alright''. The lead-off single, \"[[I Want My Life Back]]\" was released to radio in April 2009 and it peaked at number 32. In early October 2009, Covington released a cover version of [[Nickelback]]'s hit single \"[[Gotta Be Somebody]]\" which peaked at number 51 in December 2009 after spending only three weeks on the chart. The album's third single, \"[[A Father's Love (The Only Way He Knew How)]]\", was released in March 2010, and peaked at number 23.\n\nThe album was expected for release on April 27, 2010. However, in April 2010, it was announced [[Lyric Street Records]] would be closing, but Covington would be transferred to another label owned by Disney Music Group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1637143/covington-fowler-dickerson-follow-rascal-flatts-to-disney-music-group.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100514093818/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1637143/covington-fowler-dickerson-follow-rascal-flatts-to-disney-music-group.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=May 14, 2010|title=Covington, Fowler, Dickerson Follow Rascal Flatts to Disney Music Group|work=CMT News}}</ref> However, Covington remained unsigned until October 2011 when it was announced that he had signed as the \"premier artist\" for [[eOne Music|E1 Music]]'s Entertainment One Nashville label.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nashville.com/music/2011/10/bucky-covington-signs-new-record-deal/ |title=Bucky Covington Signs New Record Deal |access-date=15 January 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303224444/http://www.nashville.com/music/2011/10/bucky-covington-signs-new-record-deal/ |archive-date=3 March 2016 }}</ref> Covington released his second studio album, ''[[Good Guys (album)|Good Guys]]'', on September 11, 2012. Two singles\u2014\"I Wanna Be That Feeling\" and \"Drinking Side of Country\"\u2014were released by E1 Music in promotion of the album.\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Marty_Raybon","to":"Marty Raybon"}],"pages":{"14789518":{"pageid":14789518,"ns":0,"title":"Marty Raybon","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{BLP sources|date=October 2010}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name                = Marty Raybon\n| image               = RayboBlue.jpg\n| caption             = Marty Raybon\n| image_size          =\n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          = Marlon Raybon\n| alias               = \n| birth_date          = {{birth date and age|1959|12|08}}\n| birth_place         = [[Sanford, Florida]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alabamamusicoffice.com/artists-a-z/r/1603-raybon-marty.html|title=Raybon, Marty|website=www.alabamamusicoffice.com}}</ref>\n| instrument          = Vocals, acoustic guitar\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]], [[Christian country music|Christian country]], [[bluegrass music|Bluegrass]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = 1985\u2013present\n| label               = [[Sparrow Records|Sparrow]], Tri Chord, Doobie Shea, Dakota Sky, [[Rural Rhythm Records|Rural Rhythm]]\n| current_member_of = [[Shenandoah (band)|Shenandoah]]\n| past_member_of = [[Raybon Brothers]]\n| website             = [http://www.martyraybon.com/ MartyRaybon.com]\n}}\n'''Marlon \"Marty\" Raybon''' (born December 8, 1959) is an American [[country music]] artist. He is known primarily for his role as the lead singer of the country band [[Shenandoah (band)|Shenandoah]], a role which he held from 1985 to 1997, until he rejoined the band in 2014. He recorded his first solo album, ''Marty Raybon'', in 1995 on [[Sparrow Records]].<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg&sql=11:09fuxqygldje~T1 |title=Marty Raybon biography |accessdate=January 25, 2008 |last=Hamilton |first=Andrew |work=[[Allmusic]]}}{{dead link|date=August 2021|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Before leaving Shenandoah in 1997, he and his brother Tim formed a duo known as the [[Raybon Brothers]], which had crossover success that year with the hit single \"[[Butterfly Kisses (song)|Butterfly Kisses]]\".\n\nThe Raybon Brothers split up in 1997, and Marty Raybon resumed his career as a solo artist. A second self-titled album was released in 2000, followed by 2003's ''Full Circle''. 2006 saw the release of ''When the Sand Runs Out'', which included the single \"Shenandoah Saturday Night\".\n\n==Discography==\n{{for|a complete discography of Shenandoah|Shenandoah discography}}\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:14em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n! Peak positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! style=\"width:65px;\"| [[Top Bluegrass Albums|US Bluegrass]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Marty Raybon''\n| \n* Release date: July 18, 1995\n* Label: Chordant Records\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Marty Raybon''\n| \n* Release date: February 15, 2000\n* Label: Tri Chord Records\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Full Circle''\n| \n* Release date: March 11, 2003\n* Label: [[Doobie Shea Records]]\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''When the Sand Runs Out''\n| \n* Release date: November 21, 2006\n* Label: Aspirion Records\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''This, That & the Other''\n| \n* Release date: April 30, 2009\n* Label: self-released\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''At His Best''\n| \n* Release date: April 6, 2010\n* Label: Hi Five\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Hand to the Plow''\n| \n* Release date: March 27, 2012\n* Label: [[Rural Rhythm Records|Rural Rhythm]]\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Southern Roots & Branches (Yesterday & Today)''\n| \n* Release date: April 10, 2012\n* Label: Rural Rhythm\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''The Back Forty''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cybergrass.com/node/2328|title=Marty Raybon Celebrates 40th Year with \"The Back Forty\"|publisher=Cybergrass. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Upchurch_(musician)","to":"Upchurch (musician)"}],"pages":{"50535249":{"pageid":50535249,"ns":0,"title":"Upchurch (musician)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country rapper (born 1991)}}\n{{Use American English|date=June 2023}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2023}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Ryan Upchurch\n| image             = Ryan Upchurch.jpg\n| caption           = Upchurch in 2017\n| birth_name        = Ryan Edward Upchurch\n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1991|05|24}}\n| birth_place       = [[Nashville, Tennessee]]\n| origin            = [[Cheatham County, Tennessee]]\n| years_active      = 2014\u2013present\n| genre             = {{hlist|[[Country rap]]||[[hip hop music|hip hop]]|[[Country music|country]]|[[southern metal]]|[[country rock]]|[[southern hip hop]]}}\n| occupation        = {{hlist|Rapper|singer|songwriter|comedian}}\n| label             = {{hlist|Mud to Gold Entertainment|Luce-N-Up Records}}\n| website           = {{URL|upchurchmerch.com}}\n| alias             = Upchurch, Upchurch the Redneck\n}}\n\n'''Ryan Edward Upchurch''' (born May 24, 1991), known as '''Upchurch''', is an American rapper, singer-songwriter, and comedian from [[Cheatham County, Tennessee|Cheatham County]], on the outskirts of [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]]. Upchurch became popular primarily as a comedian, creating videos on various platforms to garner support and fans. He sold merchandise and coined the phrase \"raise hell and eat cornbread\". Originally considered a \"[[country rap]]per\", Ryan Upchurch has diversified into many genres including rap, rock, and country.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|last=Kellman|first=Andy|title=Upchurch {{!}} Biography & History|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=mn0003067310/biography|pure_url=yes}}|work=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=May 13, 2016}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nUpchurch began uploading videos to [[YouTube]].<ref name=\"allmusic\" /> He released an extended play, ''Cheatham County'', in 2015, followed by a full-length album, ''Heart of America'', in 2016.<ref name=\"allmusic\" /> Both releases reached the top 30 of the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart.<ref name=\"Country Albums\" /> ''Heart of America'' sold 1,300 copies in its first week of release.<ref name=\"roughstock jan2016\">{{cite news|last1=Bjorke|first1=Matt|title=Country Album Sales Chart: January 25, 2016|url=http://roughstock.com/news/2016/01/39645-country-album-sales-chart-january-25-2016|access-date=May 13, 2016|work=Roughstock|date=January 23, 2016}}</ref>\n\nThe second full-length album, ''Chicken Willie'', was released in August 2016. It reached No. 22 on Billboard's Top Country Albums and No. 11 on the Rap Albums charts, selling 2,800 copies in the first week.<ref name=\"roughstock aug2016\">{{cite news |url=http://roughstock.com/news/2016/08/40756-country-albums-sales-chart-august-22-2016|title=Country Albums Sales Chart: August 22, 2016 |first=Matt |last=Bjorke |date= August 21, 2016 |work=Roughstock}}</ref> In 2017, Upchurch released another EP titled ''Summer Love'', which is completely [[Country music|country]]-oriented, with no elements of [[rap music]]; and another studio album titled ''Son of the South''. ''Summer Love'', debuted at No. 33 in the Top Country Albums chart with  3,700 copies sold, while ''Son of the South'' debuted at No. 29 with 48,100 copies sold.<ref name=\"roughstock may 2017\"/>\n\nUpchurch's fifth studio album, ''King of Dixie'', was released on November 10, 2017, and features 19 tracks. Upchurch's first rock album, ''Creeker'', was released on April 20 which was focused on rock with few rap elements. His August 2018 release, ''Supernatural'', a rap-focused album with some country elements, peaked at No. 6 on Billboard's Top Country Albums. His December 2018 album, ''River Rat'', peaked at No. 22.\n\nUpchurch released his next album, ''Creeker II'' in April 2019. Later that year, he released ''Parachute'' on September 24, followed by a collaboration album with [[Adam Calhoun]] entitled ''Hooligan'' on November 25.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Luce Vision\n|-\n| \"Miss My Buddies\"\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2021\n| \"Real Country\"\n|-\n| \"Broadway Girls (Remix)\"<br/>(with Chase Matthew)\n|-\n| rowspan=\"7\" | 2022\n|\"Peoples Champ\"\n|-\n|\"Look At These Dudes\"\n|-\n|\"Necks Too Red\"\n|-\n|\"Superstar\"\n|-\n|\"Built Like That\"\n|-\n|\"The Other Country Boy\"\n|-\n|\"Desperado\"\n|-\n| rowspan=\"8\" | 2023\n|\"Silver Circles\"\n|-\n|\"Pioneer\"\n|-\n|-\n|\"Middle Of the Night Ft. Brianna Harness\"\n|-\n|-\n|\"Bloodline\" (Creeker Sessions)\n|-\n|\"Flowers all Bloom\" (Creeker Sessions)\n|-\n|\"Ice Cold\" (Creeker Sessions)\n|-\n|\"Magic Mountain\" (Creeker Sessions)\n|-\n|\"Here There Now Then\" (Creeker Sessions)\n|-\n|\"Lonestar\" (Blue Genes)\n|\"Jumps the Gun\"\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{official website|https://upchurchmerch.com|name=Official website}}\n*{{allMusic}}\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Upchurch}}\n[[Category:1991 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:21st-century American comedians]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American rappers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American heavy metal musicians]]\n[[Category:American male rappers]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Comedians from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Country rap musicians]]\n[[Category:Country rock musicians]]\n[[Category:People from Cheatham County, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Rappers from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Southern hip hop musicians]]\n[[Category:Southern rock musicians]]\n|}"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Big_Kenny","to":"Big Kenny"}],"pages":{"2687695":{"pageid":2687695,"ns":0,"title":"Big Kenny","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country music singer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Big Kenny\n| image           = BigKennyApr10.jpg\n| caption         = Big Kenny in April 2010\n| birth_name      = William Kenneth Alphin\n| alias           = Kenny Alphin\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1963|11|01}}\n| origin          = [[Culpeper, Virginia]], U.S.\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 1999\u2013present\n| label           = [[Hollywood Records|Hollywood]], [[Warner Records|Warner Bros. Nashville]], Glotown/Love Everybody/[[Bigger Picture Music Group|Bigger Picture]]\n| current_member_of = [[Big & Rich]]\n| past_member_of    = luvjOi\n| website         = [http://www.bigkenny.tv/ http://www.bigkenny.tv/]\n}}\n'''William Kenneth Alphin''' (born November 1, 1963), best known by his stage name '''Big Kenny''', is an American [[country music]] singer. He and [[John Rich (musician)|John Rich]] comprise the duo [[Big & Rich]], who recorded four studio albums and charted fifteen singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart.\n\nBefore Big & Rich, Big Kenny recorded a solo album ''[[Live a Little (Big Kenny album)|Live a Little]]'' for [[Hollywood Records]] in 1999 (although it was not released until 2005) and fronted a band called '''luvjOi'''. He has also written or co-written several of Big & Rich's songs with Rich, as well as singles for [[Gretchen Wilson]], [[Jason Aldean]], [[McBride & the Ride]], and [[Tim McGraw]]. His first solo single, \"[[Long After I'm Gone]],\" was released to country radio on August 3, 2009, from the album ''[[The Quiet Times of a Rock and Roll Farm Boy]]''.  In 2010, his third solo album, ''Big Kenny's Love Everybody Traveling Musical Medicine Show Mix Tape, Vol. 1'', was released but did not produce any singles.\n\n==Biography==\nAlphin was raised on a farm in Culpeper, VA. In Nashville, he found work at [[Famous Music]].<ref name=\"scene2\">{{cite news|url=http://www.nashvillescene.com/2000-11-16/stories/feeling-the-luv/2|title=Feeling the Luv After departing Hollywood Records, Alphin moves on|last=Murray|first=Noel|date=October 1, 2000|work=Nashville Scene|page=2|access-date=July 11, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091114065228/http://www.nashvillescene.com/2000-11-16/stories/feeling-the-luv/2|archive-date=November 14, 2009|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n==Before Big & Rich==\nBefore Big & Rich, Big Kenny was signed to [[Hollywood Records]] in 1999 and recorded the album ''[[Live a Little (Big Kenny album)|Live a Little]]'' for the label. The album's release was delayed repeatedly, and was ultimately canceled, with Hollywood Records retaining control of the songs for five years<ref name=\"scene1\">{{cite news|url=http://www.nashvillescene.com/2000-11-16/stories/feeling-the-luv/|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130129115928/http://www.nashvillescene.com/2000-11-16/stories/feeling-the-luv/|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 29, 2013|title=Feeling the Luv After departing Hollywood Records, \"Big Kenny\" Alphin moves on|last=Murray|first=Noel|date=October 1, 2000|work=Nashville Scene|page=1|access-date=July 11, 2009}}</ref> and ultimately releasing it in 2005. One of its songs, \"Under the Sun\", was featured in the soundtrack to the 2001 film ''[[Gun Shy (2000 film)|Gun Shy]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r461655|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Gun Shy Soundtrack'' review|last=Phares|first=Heather|work=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=July 11, 2009}}</ref>\n\nAfter departing the label, he founded the band luvjOi, which included [[Adam Shoenfeld]] (guitar), Larry Babb (drums) and Justin Tocket (bass guitar).<ref name=\"scene1\"/> Although luvjOi had a degree of local success, including the single \"Discoball\" and two albums,<ref name=\"scene1\"/> the band eventually broke up.\n\n==Big & Rich==\n{{Main|Big & Rich}}\nBy this point in his career, Big Kenny had befriended [[John Rich (musician)|John Rich]], formerly the bass guitarist and co-lead vocalist of [[Lonestar]]. The two founded [[Big & Rich]] in the early 2000s after years of collaboration, including co-writing [[McBride & the Ride]]'s 2002 single \"[[Amarillo Sky (song)|Amarillo Sky]]\" as well as \"She's a Butterfly\", an album cut for [[Martina McBride]].<ref name=\"bigandrich\">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p637739/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Big & Rich biography|last=Loftus|first=Johnny|work=Allmusic|access-date=July 11, 2009}}</ref>\n\nBig & Rich signed to [[Warner Bros. Records]] in 2004. The duo recorded three studio albums for the label: ''[[Horse of a Different Color (Big & Rich album)|Horse of a Different Color]]'' (2004), ''[[Comin' to Your City]]'' (2005) and ''[[Between Raising Hell and Amazing Grace]]'' (2007), as well as two [[extended play|EP]]s and ten singles, including the Number One hit \"[[Lost in This Moment]]\".<ref name=\"bigandrich\"/> In 2011, Kenny rejoined John Rich to release the single ''Fake I.D.''\n\n==Muzik Mafia==\nBig & Rich also founded the [[MuzikMafia]], an association of singer-songwriters which also included [[Shannon Lawson (singer)|Shannon Lawson]], [[Gretchen Wilson]] and [[Cowboy Troy]].\n\n==Solo career==\nBig Kenny went on hiatus in 2008, as Kenny had to rehabilitate a neck injury that occurred when he was hit by a drunk driver in 2001. He launched his official online community at www.bigkenny.tv in mid-2009. There, he made his first solo single, \"Long After I'm Gone\", available as a free download. It was released to radio in August 2009 as the first single from his second solo album, ''[[The Quiet Times of a Rock and Roll Farm Boy]]'', which was rated number 13 on the 30 Best Country Albums of 2009 by Roughstock.<ref name=\"30best\">{{cite web |url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/the-30-best-country-albums-of-2009-20-11 |title=The 30 Best Country Albums of 2009 |last=Bjorke |first=Matt |date=December 3, 2009|work=Roughstock |access-date=December 30, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100101212920/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/the-30-best-country-albums-of-2009-20-11 |archive-date=January 1, 2010 }}</ref> Kenny also became a judge on the television talent show ''[[Can You Duet]]''.  Kenny released several non-album singles during this period.\n\n===Glotown===\n[[File:Freeuse2.jpg|100px|left]]In 2009 Big Kenny started his own record label: Glotown Records.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_headlines/article/0,3034,GAC_26063_5945527_,00.html |archive-url=https://archive.today/20120903201139/http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_headlines/article/0,3034,GAC_26063_5945527_,00.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 3, 2012 |title=News : Headlines : Big Kenny Balances Solo, Duet Lives : Great American Country |website=Gactv.com |date=August 3, 2009|access-date=March 28, 2012 }}</ref> Big Kenny's role within the label is to serve as Chief Imagination Officer while the rest of the label is composed of Bigger Pictures Entertainment, RMP Management, and CAA Booking Agency.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/62879/big-kenny-announces-staff-of-glotown-love-everybod |title=Big Kenny Announces Staff Of 'Glotown/Love Everybody' |website=Allaccess.com |date=August 2, 2009|access-date=March 28, 2012}}</ref> The label was launched in an effort to make music that changes lives. Glotown's first non-album online release, \"Cry With You,\" was released on February 15, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ereleases.com/pr/big-kenny-announces-digital-release-cry-you-31814 |title=Big Kenny Announces Digital Release of 'Cry With You' \u2013 Press Release |website=Ereleases.com |date=February 1, 2010|access-date=March 28, 2012}}</ref>\n\n===Love Everybody Traveling Musical Medicine Show===\nOn April 16, 2010, Big Kenny launched his first solo nationwide tour, the Love Everybody Traveling Musical Medicine Show. The tour launched in Agoura Hills, CA at the Canyon Club and introduced the world to Big Kenny's new band: ex-Counting Crows and Third Eye Blind drummer Steve Bowman, guitar virtuoso Jesse Howard, former Will Hogue multi-instrumentalist Devin Malone and Nashville veteran Jerry Navarro.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/something-big-in-store-for-big-kenny-90604034.html |title=Something BIG in Store for BIG KENNY \u2013 NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 12 /PRNewswire/ |location=Tennessee |publisher=Prnewswire.com |access-date=March 28, 2012}}</ref> That same year, Big Kenny released his third solo album, ''Big Kenny's Love Everybody Traveling Musical Medicine Show Mix Tape, Vol. 1'' as a tie-in to his tour.  It was sold exclusively through BigKenny.TV and BigSouthMusic.com.<ref name=\"bigsouthmusic.merchmo.com\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.pacificbrandwear.com/|title=Custom Logo Apparel For Business &#124; Hats, Shirts & Uniforms &#124; Pacific|website=Pacificbrandwear.com|access-date=March 27, 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"urbancountrynews.com\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.urbancountrynews.com/big-kennys-love-everybody-traveling-musical-medicine-show-hit-cma-fest/|title=Big Kenny's Love Everybody Traveling Musical Medicine Show Hit CMA Fest|website=Urbancountrynews.com|access-date=March 27, 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Songwriter==\nKenny has also written or co-written several of Big & Rich's songs with Rich, as well as singles for [[Gretchen Wilson]], [[Jason Aldean]], [[McBride & the Ride]], [[Martina McBride]] and [[Tim McGraw]].\n\nBig Kenny's co-writing credits also include \"[[Here for the Party (song)|Here for the Party]]\" for Gretchen Wilson and \"[[Hicktown]]\" for [[Jason Aldean]] (who also released a [[cover version|cover]] of \"Amarillo Sky\"). He is also the writer of [[Tim McGraw]]'s Number One hit \"[[Last Dollar (Fly Away)]]\".\n\n==Personal life==\nOn January 23, 2005, Big Kenny married Christiev Carothers. She has two sons from a previous marriage, Christopher Carothers and Cameron Carothers, and together they have one son, Lincoln William Holiday Alphin, born on November 2, 2005.  On September 17, 2010, Big Kenny and Christiev announced they had adopted a second son, Dakota Jefferson Holiday Alphin, in July 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2010/09/17/big-kenny-adopts-son-dakota-jefferson/ |title=Big Kenny Adopts Son Dakota Jefferson \u2013 Moms & Babies \u2013 Moms & Babies - People.com |publisher=Celebritybabies.people.com |date=June 2, 2011|access-date=March 28, 2012}}</ref>\n\nIn October 2007, Big Kenny traveled to [[Darfur]], [[Sudan]] to deliver medical and educational supplies. He also traveled back to Akon, a remote village in Northern Bahl Ghazel in Sudan for a similar mission with My Sisters Keeper Group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/articles/1572388/20071019/big_rich.jhtml|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120723103218/http://www.cmt.com/news/articles/1572388/20071019/big_rich.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=July 23, 2012|title=Big Kenny delivering school supplies to Sudan|work=[[Country Music Television]]|date=October 1, 2007|access-date=July 21, 2009}}</ref>\n\nIn January 2010, Big Kenny traveled to [[Haiti]] to assist in the rescue efforts in the aftermath of the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]].\n\n==Discography==\n{{See also|Big & Rich discography|John Rich}}\n\n===Studio albums===\n====Solo====\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Izzy_Miller","to":"Izzy Miller"}],"pages":{"44654838":{"pageid":44654838,"ns":0,"title":"Izzy Miller","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American musician and former politician (born 1993)}}\n{{Cleanup bare URLs|date=August 2022}}\n\n{{Use American English|date=December 2017}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2017}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name             = Izzy Miller\n| image            =\n| caption          = \n| image_size       = 250px\n| landscape        =\n| birth_name       = Izzy Miller\n| alias            = \n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1993|6|22|mf=y}}\n| birth_place      = [[Huntsville, Alabama]], U.S.\n| death_date       = \n| death_place      =\n| instrument       = Guitar, vocals, bass guitar, drums, organ\n| genre            = [[rock music|Rock]], [[country music|country]], [[indie rock|indie]], [[garage rock]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://paulwells.download/izzy-miller-and-the-black-market-salesmen-american-times-2017/ |title=Izzy Miller and the Black Market Salesmen \u2013 American Times (2017) &#124;.rar Zippyshare Mediafire Torrent Download &#124; Paul Wells |access-date=December 3, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171204222844/http://paulwells.download/izzy-miller-and-the-black-market-salesmen-american-times-2017/ |archive-date=December 4, 2017 |url-status=dead }}</ref> [[Americana (music)|Americana]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lamusiccritic.com/indie_voice_blog/get-it-or-forget-it-izzy-miller-a-swarm-of-the-sun-hedvig-mollestad-trio-the-vegabonds-alice-wallace/|title=Get it or forget it \u2013 Izzy Miller, A Swarm of the Sun, Hedvig Mollestad Trio, the Vegabonds, Alice Wallace|date=January 19, 2019}}</ref> [[pop rock]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://parapop.net/izzy-miller-if-we-cant-work-it-out/|title = Izzy Miller - if We Can't Work It Out - ParaPOP|date = April 25, 2020}}</ref>\n| occupation       = Musician\n| years_active     = 2007\u20132014, 2016\u2013present\n| label            = Long Week Records (2010\u20132015) <br /> 764 Entertainment (2016) <br /> The Standard (2017\u20132020) <br /> Turtle Mountain Records (2021 - Present)\n| associated_acts  = [[Hank Williams Jr.]], The Black Market Salesmen, [[Joey Huffman]], Storage\n| website          = {{URL|https://www.theizzymiller.com/|Official}}\n}}\n\n'''Izzy Miller''' (born June 22, 1993) is an American guitarist, singer, and songwriter.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://grungecake.com/omo-frenchie-charles-wesley-godwin/articles/50573|title=New Music Wednesdays: 10 new songs you should hear featuring Omo Frenchie and Charles Wesley Godwin \u2013 GRUNGECAKE|date=January 30, 2019 }}</ref> His first success came with his band Storage with the release of their 2009 single \"Just a Little More\". Miller left Storage in 2010 (with the exception of a short reunion tour in 2011) and began a solo career. After releasing ''Back From Nowhere'', his first solo album, in 2010, he paired up with drummer Smokin' Joey Gambrell. Miller and Gambrell went on to release ''Who Is That? Nobody'' in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/who-is-that-nobody-mw0002435804|title=Who Is That? Nobody - Smokin' Joey Gambrell, Izzy Miller - Songs, Reviews, Credits - AllMusic|website=AllMusic|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref>\n\nHe was named on [[The Birmingham News|AL.com]]'s \"14 up-and-coming North [[Alabama]] bands, solo acts poised to make noise in 2014\" list in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.al.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2013/11/14_up-and-coming_north_alabama.html|title=14 up-and-coming North Alabama bands, solo acts poised to make noise in 2014 (photos)|website=al.com|date=November 20, 2013|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref> His 2014 album, titled ''Commercially Inept'', was produced by [[Grammy Award|Grammy]]-nominated musician [[Joey Huffman]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.al.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2014/11/izzy_miller_track-by-track_hun.html|title=Izzy Miller track-by-track: Huntsville rocker goes country, asks 'What if someone was so lonesome they forgot to get drunk?'|website=al.com|date=November 4, 2014|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/commericially-inept-mw0002842802|title=Commercially Inept - Izzy Miller - Songs, Reviews, Credits - AllMusic|website=AllMusic|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref><ref name=\"discogs.com\">{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Izzy-Miller-Commercially-Inept/release/6579344|title=Izzy Miller - Commercially Inept|website=Discogs|date=November 11, 2014 |access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref>\n\nHe has shared festival stages and opened for acts such as [[Drivin N Cryin]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.al.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2014/05/whistlestop_weekend_2014_gets.html|title=WhistleStop Weekend 2014 gets off to sunny and (barbecue) smoky start in downtown Huntsville|website=al.com|date=May 3, 2014|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref> [[John Anderson (musician)|John Anderson]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.al.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2012/05/john_anderson_secret_sisters_a.html|title=John Anderson, Secret Sisters among musical highlights at WhistleStop Weekend|website=al.com|date=May 3, 2012|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref> and many others. He has had two entries on the [[Billboard charts#Rock|Billboard Rock Digital Songs]] chart, with 2013's \"Where to Land\" (number 49) and 2014's \"Rapid Decline\" (number 44).<ref name=\"wlrh\">{{cite web|url=http://www.wlrh.org/WritersCorner/invisible-city-november-28-2014-hour-1|title=Invisible City (November 28, 2014) Hour 1|date=December 5, 2014|website=wlrh.org|access-date=December 5, 2017|archive-date=December 6, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171206135855/http://www.wlrh.org/WritersCorner/invisible-city-november-28-2014-hour-1|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nIn September 2015, Miller announced that he would run for the office of mayor in Huntsville, Alabama, in 2016.<ref>https://www.facebook.com/izzymillerhuntsville/posts/1137558142940132 {{User-generated source|certain=yes|date=March 2022}}</ref>\n\nMiller largely withdrew from the music industry after the release of ''Commercially Inept'' in 2014 and rarely appeared on stage or in interviews for nearly two years. In August 2016, he announced that he had signed with 764 Entertainment. \"Back to Getting Over You\", his first single for the label, was released on September 16, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/izzymiller4|title=\u266b Back to Getting over You - Izzy Miller. Listen @cdbaby|website=cdbaby.com|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref><ref name=\"maximumvolumemusic.com\">{{cite web|url=http://www.maximumvolumemusic.com/review-izzy-miller-black-market-salesmen-american-times-2017/|title=REVIEW: IZZY MILLER AND THE BLACK MARKET SALESMEN - AMERICAN TIMES (2017) was - MaximumVolumeMusic|date=November 26, 2017|website=maximumvolumemusic.com|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref>\n\nMiller signed with the Standard in 2017 and began a collaboration with the Huntsville-based band the Black Market Salesmen. Their first single, \"Mr. TV Man\", was released on August 4, 2017.<ref name=\"al.com1\">{{cite web|url=http://www.al.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2017/08/cool_things_to_do_in_huntsvill_78.html|title=Cool things to do in Huntsville, Aug. 6-12|website=al.com|date=August 6, 2017|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0749FPVLG|title=Mr. TV Man|publisher=|access-date=December 5, 2017|via=Amazon}}</ref> A pre-sale for the single was announced on July 28 and the song immediately reached high peaks on multiple Amazon Best Sellers lists, including peaking at number 4 on the Amazon Movers & Shakers list (receiving over a 12,000% increase in sales), #28 on the Amazon Hot New Releases list, and #49 on the Amazon Best Sellers list.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://m.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=1787388254623781&id=164050513624238|title=Izzy Miller|website=m.facebook.com|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://m.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=1787465171282756&substory_index=0&id=164050513624238|title=Izzy Miller|website=m.facebook.com|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref>\n\nA collaboration album between Miller and the Black Market Salesmen, titled ''American Times'', was released on December 1, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.insertreviewhere.com/single-post/2017/09/20/Mr-TV-Man---Izzy-Miller-The-Black-Market-Salesmen|title=insertreviewhere|website=insertreviewhere|date=September 20, 2017|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref> The album features a guest appearance from Tawny Hillis and Joey Huffman on the track \"It Just Happens I Guess\".<ref name=\"maximumvolumemusic.com\"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://spiceradio.podbean.com/e/spicecast-153-izzy-miller-and-the-black-market-salesmen/|title=Spicecast #153 - Izzy Miller and the Black Market Salesmen|first=PodBean|last=Development|website=podbean.com|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.maximumvolumemusic.com/review-black-market-salesmen-brainstorm-2018/|title = Review: Black Market Salesmen - Brainstorm (2018)|date = August 17, 2018}}</ref> The title track from the album was featured in the April 2018 issue of [[Classic Rock (magazine)|''Classic Rock'']] magazine and appeared on their \"Firestarters\" compilation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Various-Firestarters/release/11760821|title = Firestarters (2018, CD)|website = [[Discogs]]| date=September 24, 2023 }}</ref><ref>Classic Rock Magazine, April 2018</ref>\n\nHe released ''Precipice'' on January 11, 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://genius.com/Genius-january-2019-album-release-calendar-annotated|title = Genius \u2013 January 2019 Album Release Calendar}}</ref><ref name=\"rockthepigeon.com\">{{Cite web|url=https://rockthepigeon.com/2019/01/13/izzy-miller-sings-the-ballad-of-a-lonesome-cowboy/|title=Izzy Miller Sings the Ballad of a Lonesome Cowboy|date=January 14, 2019}}</ref> The record features guest appearances from Joey Huffman, Mike Daly, Shane Davis, and Ben Jobe.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.maximumvolumemusic.com/review-izzy-miller-precipice-2019/|title = Review: Izzy Miller - Precipice (2019)| newspaper=Maximum Volume Music |date = November 19, 2018| last1=Thorley | first1=Andy }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://comeherefloyd.com/2019/01/common-ground-king-catcher-born-lion-izzy-miller-the-wit|title = (415) Common Ground // King Catcher // Born Lion // Izzy Miller // The Wit #CHF #lists #indie #indierock #indiefolk|date = January 22, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bsidesbadlands.com/taste-test-edition-17/|title=Taste Test, Edition #17: Heaven Smile, Emily Chambers, MOZA\u00cdK & more|date=January 25, 2019}}</ref>\n\nHis sixth studio release, ''Life on the One and Three'', was released on April 24, 2020.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.albumoftheyear.org/album/226620-izzy-miller-life-on-the-one-and-three.php|title = Izzy Miller - Life on the One and Three| newspaper=Album of the Year }}</ref>\n\nMiller is the co-founder of Turtle Mountain Records and released two singles on the label during 2021, \"Home Again\" and \"Who Am I to Blame\".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://musicmecca.org/alabama-ace-americana-singer-songwriter-izzy-miller-releases-new-single-who-am-i-to-blame/|title = Alabama Ace: Americana Singer-Songwriter Izzy Miller Releases New Single 'Who Am I to Blame'|date = November 18, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wewriteaboutmusic.com/reviews/izzy-miller-home-again|title = Izzy Miller delivers a soulful performance on \"Home Again\"| date=July 15, 2021 }}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nMiller began playing guitar and singing in bands at age thirteen. In 2007, Miller became a member of Before Existence,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://spice-radio.com/2014/11/izzy-miller-at-spice-rack-studios/|title=Izzy Miller at Spice Rack Studios - Spice Radio|website=spice-radio.com|date=November 2, 2014|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref> which would eventually evolve into Storage. Storage released their first single, \"Just a Little More\", in April 2009. The single achieved heavy rotation on radio in the southeastern United States. After leaving Storage in 2010, Miller released ''Back From Nowhere'', his debut solo record.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alabamamusicoffice.com/artists-a-z/m-1/2637-miller-izzy.html|title=Miller, Izzy|website=www.alabamamusicoffice.com|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref>\n\nShortly after the release of ''Back From Nowhere'', Miller teamed up with drummer Smokin' Joey Gambrell.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/artists/izzy-miller/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150806201432/http://www.mtv.com/artists/izzy-miller/|url-status=dead|archive-date=August 6, 2015|title=Music \u2013 Music News, New Songs, Videos, Music Shows and Playlists from MTV|website=www.mtv.com|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref> Miller and Gambrell released one album together (2012's ''Who Is That? Nobody''). After the release of the record, they released one last single before they split in late 2013, titled \"Where to Land\". The song was released as a free download on May 21, 2013, and peaked at #49 on the Billboard Rock Digital Songs chart. \"Where to Land\" has been played on YouTube nearly 80,000 times since it was released.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sxhsl_GApxw|title=Where To Land - Izzy Miller & Smokin' Joey Gambrell|last=Izzy Miller|date=May 21, 2013|publisher=|access-date=December 5, 2017|via=YouTube}}</ref>\n\nMiller began work on ''Commercially Inept'' in early 2014, and it was released on November 11, 2014.<ref name=\"discogs.com\"/> The record was recorded in [[Marietta, Georgia]] and produced by [[Joey Huffman]] and Kevin Sellors.<ref name=\"wlrh\"/> The first single from the record, \"Rapid Decline\", peaked at #44 on the Billboard Rock Digital Songs chart. The second single from the record, \"I Forgot to Get Drunk\", was released to country radio in 2015, but failed to chart.\n\nHe signed with 764 Entertainment in August 2016. A single, \"Back to Getting Over You,\" was released on September 16, 2016. It was Miller's first new release in nearly two years. The recording featured Shane Davis and Kris Poorman (both of the [[Huntsville, Alabama]]-based band the Black Market Salesmen). This would lead to a collaboration with the entire band on a single titled \"Mr. TV Man\" that was released in August 2017. The single was produced by Dan Bullard and Ben Jobe.<ref name=\"al.com1\"/>\n\nMiller rarely covers material by other artists, but he did post a performance of \"[[(What's So Funny 'Bout) Peace, Love, and Understanding]]\" on August 14, 2017, on his official Facebook page and YouTube account in response to the violence at the [[Unite the Right rally]] in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]], a few days prior.\n\nA collaboration album between Miller and the Black Market Salesmen, titled ''American Times'', was released on December 1, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://store.cdbaby.com/cd/izzymillertheblackmarket|title=\u266b American Times - Izzy Miller. Listen @cdbaby|website=cdbaby.com|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref> The album was met with positive reviews, with some comparing it to the sound of [[Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.al.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2017/12/cool_things_to_do_in_huntsvill_94.html|title=Cool things to do in Huntsville, Dec. 3-9|website=al.com|date=December 3, 2017|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref> [[Marah (band)|Marah]], and [[Steve Earle]].<ref name=\"maximumvolumemusic.com\"/>\n\nMiller released ''Precipice'' on January 11, 2019. He revealed in the liner notes for the EP that it was inspired by an (then) girlfriend leaving him for her ex.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://store.cdbaby.com/cd/izzymiller6|title=CD Baby Music Store}}</ref> The EP has been called \"uncomfortable, but incredible, listening\"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.maximumvolumemusic.com/review-izzy-miller-precipice-2019/|title = Review: Izzy Miller - Precipice (2019)| newspaper=Maximum Volume Music |date = November 19, 2018| last1=Thorley | first1=Andy }}</ref> as well as the leading single, \"Another Drink or Two\", being called \"the perfect portrayal of the loss of love and a haunting feeling of loneliness\".<ref name=\"rockthepigeon.com\"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://modernmusicmaker.com/music-reviews/mick-mullin-native-harrow-izzy-miller|title=* Mick Mullin * Native Harrow * Izzy Miller|date=January 23, 2019}}{{Dead link|date=September 2024 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>\n\nHis sixth studio release, \"Life on the One and Three\", was released on April 24, 2020. Two singles, \"If We Can't Work It Out\" and \"One More Day\", were released from the album.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.caesarlivenloud.com/2020/04/izzy-miller-shares-new-single-one-more-day.html | title=Izzy Miller Shares New Single 'One More Day' | date=April 24, 2020 }}</ref> The record has been described as \"timeless brilliance\".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.maximumvolumemusic.com/review-izzy-miller-life-on-the-one-and-three-2020/|title=Review: Izzy Miller - Life on the One and Three (2020)|date=April 28, 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Other work==\nOn August 23, 2014, Miller and Shane Davis released a collection of rough demo tracks titled ''Izzy & Shane Sing Country Classics''. The album featured Miller and Davis covering songs by artists such as [[Merle Haggard]] and [[George Jones]], among others and was recorded in late 2013. Miller also served as a producer and musician on Davis' debut solo album ''Light Me Another Drink'' (released on January 27, 2015) and his second album, \"Shane Davis\" (released on February 22, 2016). He continues to work with up-and-coming musicians.\n\nHe appears in an episode, titled \"Smuggler's Blues\", of the internet series ''Strings Attached''. The episode was posted on August 11, 2015, and features the cast at the 2015 Dallas International Guitar Festival trying to locate a rare 1960's \"Smuggler's\" [[Fender Telecaster]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wOIei7hjF50|title=Smuggler's Blues|last=Strings Attached|date=August 11, 2015|publisher=|access-date=December 5, 2017|via=YouTube}}</ref>\n\nIn 2020, he appeared in an episode of ''What's It Worth?'', an [[A&E (TV network)|A&E]] show hosted by [[Jeff Foxworthy]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt12841566/fullcredits?ref_=tt_cl_sm#cast|title = What's It Worth? (TV Series 2020\u2013 ) - IMDb|website = [[IMDb]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://play.aetv.com/shows/whats-it-worth/season-1/episode-9|title = Vintage Car Superstar &#124; A&E}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nMiller, who is single, currently resides in Huntsville, Alabama. He attended and graduated from [[Sparkman High School]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.waff.com/global/story.asp?s=7537593|title=Bryan Family at it again this holiday season... spreading cheer|website=waff.com|access-date=December 5, 2017|archive-date=August 21, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170821002906/http://www.waff.com/global/story.asp?s=7537593|url-status=dead}}</ref> He was affected by the [[2011 Super Outbreak]] and released a song about the event, \"Miracle Tonight (April 27th, 2011)\", on his album ''Who Is That? Nobody''. His home and one of his main guitars, a 1977 Fender Stratocaster, was damaged in the EF-5 tornado that hit [[Harvest, Alabama]].<ref name=\"al.com\">{{cite web|url=http://www.al.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2016/04/sounds_from_the_storm_5_years.html|title=Sounds from the storm: 5 years later, Alabama musicians recall tornadoes' impact|website=al.com|date=April 27, 2016|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref> He has also toured as part of [[Hank Williams Jr.]]'s road crew as a backline technician.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fohonline.com/current-issue/71-showtime/6382-hank-williams-jr.html|title=Hank Williams Jr. - FRONT of HOUSE|first=FOH|last=Staff|date=February 10, 2012|website=fohonline.com|access-date=December 5, 2017|archive-date=August 21, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170821003622/http://www.fohonline.com/current-issue/71-showtime/6382-hank-williams-jr.html|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{Cite AV media notes| title = Old School, New Rules| title-link = Old School New Rules| year = 2012| last = Williams, Jr.| first = Hank| type = Liner notes}}</ref><ref>{{Cite AV media notes| title = It's About Time| title-link  = It's About Time (Hank Williams, Jr. album)| year = 2016| last = Williams, Jr.| first = Hank| type = Liner notes}}</ref><ref name=\"ReferenceA\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.al.com/expo/life-and-culture/g66l-2019/01/6117fcd6521319/meet-a-guitardealing-hank-jr-roadieing-alabama-musicbiz-character.html|title = Meet a guitar-dealing, Hank Jr. Roadie-ing, Alabama music character|date = January 14, 2019}}</ref>\n\nHe revealed on his social media accounts in September 2018 that he was diagnosed with [[trigeminal neuralgia]] the previous year.<ref>https://m.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=2307177049311563&id=164050513624238 {{User-generated source|certain=yes|date=March 2022}}</ref>\n\nMiller collects [[vintage guitar]]s and also works as a vintage guitar dealer when not touring, running a shop called Izzy's Vintage Guitars.<ref name=\"ReferenceA\"/><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://grinningelkguitarshow.com/mr-izzy-miller-owner-founder-and-overseer-of-izzys-vintage-guitars/ |title=Mr. Izzy Miller- Owner, Founder, and Overseer of Izzy\u2019s Vintage Guitars. |access-date=April 11, 2019 |archive-date=April 11, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190411185501/https://grinningelkguitarshow.com/mr-izzy-miller-owner-founder-and-overseer-of-izzys-vintage-guitars/ |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://reverb.com/news/why-are-some-vintage-guitar-parts-so-valuable|title=Why Are Some Vintage Guitar Parts So Valuable?|date=October 7, 2021}}</ref> His collection reportedly includes around 100 vintage instruments, including a 1969 [[Fender Custom|Fender Maverick]] and a 1908 [[Gibson Style U]].<ref name=\"al.com\"/><ref name=\"ReferenceA\"/>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{|
