scope=\"row\"| \"Back on Track\" <small>(with Izzy Miller & Smokin' Joey Gambrell)</small>\n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"1\"| ''Who Is That? Nobody.''\n|-\n| 2013\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Where To Land\" <small>(with Izzy Miller & Smokin' Joey Gambrell)</small>\n| 49\n| rowspan=\"1\"| N/A\n|-\n| 2014\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Rapid Decline\"\n| 44\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''Commercially Inept''\n|-\n| 2015\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Forgot to Get Drunk\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2016\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Back to Getting Over You\"\n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"1\"| N/A\n|-\n| 2017\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Mr. TV Man\" <small>(with the Black Market Salesmen)</small>\n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"1\"| ''American Times''\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2019\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Another Drink or Two\" \n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''Precipice''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"So It Goes\" \n| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2020\n! scope=\"row\"| \"If We Can't Work It Out\" \n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''Life on the One and Three''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"One More Day\" \n| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2021\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Home Again\" \n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"3\"| N/A\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Who Am I to Blame\" \n| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"1\"| 2022\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Down at the Sutter\" \n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n==Filmography==\n{|class=\"wikitable unsortable\"\n|-\n! Year\n! Title\n! Role\n|-\n| 2015\n| ''Strings Attached''\n| Himself, uncredited \n|-\n| 2020\n| ''What's It Worth?''\n| Himself<ref>https://www.imdb.com/name/nm11863629/?ref_=nv_sr_srsg_0 {{User-generated source|certain=yes|date=March 2022}}</ref>\n|-\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist|30em}}\n\n==External links==\n* {{Facebook|izzymillerhuntsville|Izzy Miller}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Miller, Izzy}}\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American rock musicians]]\n[[Category:1993 births]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Huntsville, Alabama]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Alabama]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Alabama]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Bellamy_Brothers","to":"The Bellamy Brothers"}],"pages":{"1745350":{"pageid":1745350,"ns":0,"title":"The Bellamy Brothers","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American music duo}}\n{{Redirect|Howard Bellamy|the Doctors character of the same name|Howard Bellamy (Doctors)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name                = Bellamy Brothers\n| image               = The Bellamy Brothers.jpg\n| landscape           = yes\n| alt                 = The Bellamy Brothers standing before a purple-tinged sunset\n| caption             = The Bellamy Brothers in 2013: Howard (left) and David (right)\n| background          = group_or_band\n| origin              = [[Pasco County, Florida]], U.S.\n| genre               = {{Hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[country pop]]|[[soft rock]]| [[country rock]]}}\n| years_active        = 1968\u2013present\n| label               = [[Curb Records|Curb]]/[[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]]<br />Curb/[[Elektra Records|Elektra]]<br />Curb/[[MCA Records|MCA]]<br />[[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]<br />Jupiter<br />Bellamy Bros./[[Intersound Records|Intersound]]<br />Blue Hat\n| website             = [http://bellamybrothers.com bellamybrothers.com]\n| current_members     = David Bellamy<br />Howard Bellamy\n}}\n'''The Bellamy Brothers''' are an American [[pop music|pop]] and [[country music]] duo consisting of brothers David Milton Bellamy (born September 16, 1950)<ref name=\"about\">{{Cite web|url=http://countrymusic.about.com/od/charts/a/blbellamybros.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070212210842/http://countrymusic.about.com/od/charts/a/blbellamybros.htm|url-status=dead|title=Top 100 Country Music Artists of All Time - No.&nbsp;83 - The Bellamy Brothers|archive-date=February 12, 2007}}</ref> and Homer Howard Bellamy (born February 2, 1946),<ref name=\"about\"/> from [[Pasco County, Florida|Dade City, Florida]].<ref name=\"about\"/> The duo had considerable musical success in the 1970s and 1980s, starting with the release of their crossover hit \"[[Let Your Love Flow]]\" in 1976, a number one single on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web\n|url= {{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1522/biography|pure_url=yes}}\n|title= Biography\n|access-date= 2008-04-01\n|last= Erlewine\n|first= Stephen Thomas\n|author-link= Stephen Thomas Erlewine\n|work= The Bellamy Brothers\n|publisher= [[Allmusic]]\n}}</ref>\n\nStarting in the late 1970s, the Bellamy Brothers found success in country music as well, charting 20 number one singles, 25 top 10 and more than 50 hits overall on the [[Hot Country Songs|country charts]]. To date, they have released more than 50 albums, primarily on [[Curb Records]]. They have also enjoyed success in continental Europe, with a compilation album topping the [[VG-lista|Norwegian charts]] in 2011 and over two dozen hit songs that were released outside the US market. In 2013, their album ''Bellamy Brothers & Friends: Across the Sea'' landed at No. 5 in the [[Swiss Hitparade|Swiss music chart]] and took the top spot in album sales for weeks in Switzerland.<ref name=\"The Boot: New Album\">{{cite web|last1=Whitaker|first1=Sterling|title=Bellamy Brothers Score International Success With New Album |date=16 July 2013 |url=http://theboot.com/bellamy-brothers-international-success-new-album/|publisher=The Boot|access-date=19 December 2016}}</ref> It was their third major release in Europe in three years.<ref name=\"Broadway World\">{{cite web|last1=News Desk|title='Bellamy Brothers and Friends' Album Finds Success in Switzerland|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwmusic/article/Bellamy-Brothers-and-Friends-Album-Finds-Success-in-Switzerland-20130716#|publisher=Broadway World|access-date=19 December 2016}}</ref> Their album ''Mermaid Cowgirl'', recorded in Switzerland and released in 2014, won them Gold Record status in Switzerland.<ref name=\"AXS\">{{cite web|last1=Cooke|first1=Sherryjane|title=5 things you didn't know about The Bellamy Brothers|url=http://www.axs.com/5-things-you-didn-t-know-about-the-bellamy-brothers-81493|publisher=AXS|access-date=19 December 2016}}</ref> They also recorded four albums in Germany with [[Ralph Siegel]] for release to the European market.<ref name=\"CD Universe\">{{cite web|title=The Bellamy Brothers & Friends - Take Me Home CD|url=http://www.cduniverse.com/search/xx/music/pid/1014968/a/take+me+home.htm|publisher=CD Universe|access-date=19 December 2016}}</ref><ref name=\"45 Cat\">{{cite web|title=The Bellamy Brothers: Fly Me To Eden|url=https://www.45cat.com/record/nc318101de&ei=1|publisher=45 Cat|access-date=19 December 2016}}</ref><ref name=\"American Radio History\">{{cite web|title=Bellamy Brothers|url=http://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/90s/1991/BB-1991-12-07.pdf|publisher=American Radio History|access-date=19 December 2016}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nDavid and Howard Bellamy were inspired by many musical sources from an early age. Their father played [[country music]] around the house, and was also a member of a local [[Western swing]] band; in addition, they were inspired by the [[rock and roll]] music their sister played. Despite having never had formal music training, both brothers learned how to play [[guitar]], [[mandolin]], and [[banjo]]. In addition, David learned [[accordion]], [[fiddle]], [[organ (music)|organ]], and [[piano]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nTheir first musical gig was in 1968 at a benefit concert with their father in [[San Antonio, Florida]], at the Rattlesnake Roundup.<ref name=\"stage\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.thecountrystage.com/artists/BellamyBrothers/bio.htm|title=Bellamy Brothers - Biography|website=Thecountrystage.com|access-date=October 17, 2019|archive-date=March 21, 2005|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050321201034/http://www.thecountrystage.com/artists/BellamyBrothers/bio.htm|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=\"bellamy\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bellamybrothers.com/up_close.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070515143050/http://www.bellamybrothers.com/up_close.htm|url-status=dead|title=BellamyBrothers.com : Up Close|archive-date=May 15, 2007}}</ref>\n\nIn the late sixties the brothers and their band played for dances at the Dade City Civic Center and at Louie's in Brooksville. They played as The Accidents and later as The Heterogeneous Grouping, performing covers of many of the popular rock and roll and [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] tunes of the time. Three of their favorites were \"[[A Whiter Shade of Pale]]\", \"[[My Girl (The Temptations song)|My Girl]]\" and \"[[Little Bit O' Soul]]\".\n\nTheir first paid gigs were playing fraternity parties at the [[University of Florida]].<ref name=\"MTV.FR\">{{cite web|title=Bellamy Brothers|url=http://www.mtv.fr/musique/artistes/the-bellamy-brothers/hzp1f5|publisher=MTV.FR|access-date=19 December 2016|archive-date=20 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220170544/http://www.mtv.fr/musique/artistes/the-bellamy-brothers/hzp1f5|url-status=dead}}</ref> Soon after, the brothers moved to [[Atlanta]] and formed a band called Jericho.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> However, playing in bands and clubs proved tiresome for the brothers, who soon moved back home.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nThe brothers were soon noticed by a friend of recording artist [[Jim Stafford]], who eventually recorded \"[[Spiders & Snakes (song)|Spiders & Snakes]]\", written by Stafford and David. \"Spiders & Snakes\" went on to become a top five hit, providing the Bellamys with the money to move to [[Los Angeles]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/><ref name=\"stage\"/> Howard became a [[road manager]] for Stafford.<ref name=\"stage\"/>\n\n==Music career==\n===1970s===\nThe duo signed to [[Curb Records]] in 1975. A single featuring only David, \"Nothin' Heavy\", was unsuccessful. However, at the suggestion of [[Neil Diamond]]'s drummer Dennis St. John, the brothers recorded and released the single \"[[Let Your Love Flow]]\", written by Diamond's roadie Larry Williams. Released in 1976, \"Let Your Love Flow\" was a No.&nbsp;1 single on the U.S. [[Mainstream Top 40|pop charts]], as well as more than a dozen countries worldwide.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.luckmedia.com/bellamybrothers/biography.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090928090308/http://www.luckmedia.com/bellamybrothers/biography.html|url-status=dead|title=\"DUETS WITH THE DUET\": THE BELLAMY BROTHERS HOOK UP WITH COUNTRY SUPERSTARS FOR LONG-AWAITED ANGELS & OUTLAWS VOL. 1, ON CURB RECORDS, MARCH 29|archive-date=September 28, 2009}}</ref>\n\nAlthough \"Let Your Love Flow\" was also a hit on the [[Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] chart, the Bellamys' country music success was limited until 1979, when \"[[If I Said You Have a Beautiful Body Would You Hold It Against Me]]\" was released. The song, with its ''[[double entendre]]'' title derived from a [[Groucho Marx]] quote,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.songfacts.com/detail.php?id=7458|title=If I Said You Have a Beautiful Body (Would You Hold It Against Me) by The Bellamy Brothers|website=Songfacts.com}}</ref> landed the Bellamys their first country music No.&nbsp;1 in the United States. It was first played on radio in the United Kingdom in [[Northern Ireland]] in 1979 and went on to become Record of the Year in the UK in 1979.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/article2514572.ece|title=Bellamy brothers are coming ... so don't hold that song against them|website=Belfastelegraph.co.uk|access-date=October 17, 2019}}</ref> In a 2003 issue of ''Country Weekly'' magazine, the title was named the number 1 country [[pick-up line]] of all time.<ref name=\"The Boot Pick Up Lines\">{{cite web|title=Top 10 Pickup Lines in Country Music|url=http://theboot.com/pick-up-lines/|publisher=The Boot|access-date=21 December 2016}}</ref>\n\n===1980s and 1990s===\nAfter the success of \"If I Said You Have a Beautiful Body Would You Hold It Against Me\", the brothers continued with a run of country hits, including tunes such as \"[[Redneck Girl]]\", \"Santa Fe\", and the social commentary pieces \"[[Old Hippie]]\" and \"[[Kids of the Baby Boom]]\".<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' named the Bellamy Brothers as Top Country Duo,<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> and they eventually went on to set the record for most duo nominations from both the [[Academy of Country Music]] and [[Country Music Association]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.classicbands.com/BellamyBrothersInterview.html|title=Gary James' Interview With Howard Bellamy Of The Bellamy Brothers|website=Classicbands.com|access-date=October 17, 2019}}</ref>\n\nThe brothers worked on a number of collaborative efforts with other musicians during this period. They recorded \"Too Much Is Not Enough\" with [[The Forester Sisters]] in 1986<ref name=\"YouTube Forester Sisters\">{{cite web|title=Bellamy Brothers & The Forester Sisters - Too Much Is Not Enough| date=12 March 2009 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y-IvEnIdQ3M |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211213/Y-IvEnIdQ3M |archive-date=2021-12-13 |url-status=live|publisher=YouTube|access-date=21 December 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref> and \"[[Drive South]]\" with them in 1990.<ref name=\"YouTube Forester Sisters 1990\">{{cite web|title=\"1990\" \"Drive South\", Forester Sisters & Bellamy Brothers|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XEWi_ArYHqs|publisher=YouTube|access-date=21 December 2016}}</ref> In 1993, they recorded \"Stayin' in Love\" with [[Freddy Fender]] and [[Flaco Jim\u00e9nez]].<ref name=\"YouTube Freddy Fender & The Bellamy Brothers\">{{cite web|title=Freddy Fender & The Bellamy Brothers| date=10 March 2012 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=44Nm2LAOeoY |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211213/44Nm2LAOeoY |archive-date=2021-12-13 |url-status=live|publisher=YouTube}}{{cbignore}}</ref> In 1997, they recorded \"Catahoula\" with [[Eddy Raven]] and [[Jo-El Sonnier]],<ref name=\"Google Books\">{{cite web|last1=Evans Price|first1=Deborah|title=Bellamys Take a Step Over the Line|date=1997-05-24|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fA8EAAAAMBAJ&q=Catahoula+with+Eddy+Raven+and+Jo-El+Sonnier+and+bellamy+brothers&pg=PA36|access-date=21 December 2016}}</ref> while in 1997 they recorded \"Everyone's Somebody's Darlin'\" with [[Nicolette Larson]]. In 1999, they recorded \"(Don't Put Me In) The Ex Files\" with [[Buck Owens]],<ref name=\"YouTube Buck Owens\">{{cite web|title=Dont Put Me In The X files (Bellamy Brothers featuring Buck Owens)| date=6 July 2014 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kex7zl4WVSA |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211213/Kex7zl4WVSA |archive-date=2021-12-13 |url-status=live|publisher=YouTube|access-date=21 December 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref> and that same year they recorded \"Vertical Expression\" with Freddy Fender and then with [[Eduardo Araujo]].<ref name=\"YouTube Freddy Fender\">{{cite web|title=Vertical Expression of Horizontal Desire - The Bellamy Brothers featuring Freddy Fender| date=3 June 2011 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OIx7EyqlqVY |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211213/OIx7EyqlqVY |archive-date=2021-12-13 |url-status=live|publisher=[[YouTube]]|access-date=21 December 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref>\n\nIn 1991, the Bellamys switched to [[Atlantic Records]]. Their tenure there produced one album before the duo formed their own label, Bellamy Brothers Records. They were one of the first country music artists to have their own record label, and have been licensing albums from their own record label for 25 years.<ref name=\"All Music Biography\">{{cite web|last1=Erlewine|first1=Stephen Thomas|title=Artist Biography by Stephen Thomas Erlewine|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-bellamy-brothers-mn0000037026/biography|publisher=All Music|access-date=19 December 2016}}</ref><ref name=\"All Music Artists\">{{cite web|title=Bellamy Brothers|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-bellamy-brothers-mn0000037026|publisher=All Music|access-date=19 December 2016}}</ref> In 1999, they switched to Blue Hat Records for their ''Lonely Planet'' album.\n\n===2000s===\nIn 2005, the Bellamys returned to Curb Records to record ''Angels & Outlaws, Volume 1'', a compilation album featuring re-recordings of the duo's older hits with additional artists, including [[Dolly Parton]], [[George Jones]], [[Alan Jackson]], [[Tanya Tucker]] and [[Montgomery Gentry]].<ref name=\"luck\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.luckmedia.com/bellamybrothers/pressrelease.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070623201054/http://www.luckmedia.com/bellamybrothers/pressrelease.html|url-status=dead|title=Luck Media & Marketing INC.|archive-date=June 23, 2007}}</ref> A re-recorded version of \"If I Said You Had a Beautiful Body Would You Hold It Against Me\", featuring Dolly Parton, spent one week at No.&nbsp;60 on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart in 2005.\n\nIn March 2007, \"Redneck Girl\" was covered by [[Blake Shelton]] on the soundtrack to ''[[The Dukes of Hazzard: The Beginning]]''.\n\nThe Bellamys released an album of [[gospel music]], titled ''Jesus Is Coming'', on May 8, 2007.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/music-christian-dc-idUSN2023183320070521|title=Bellamy Brothers celebrate outlaw gospel spirit|date=May 21, 2007|website=Reuters.com|access-date=October 17, 2019}}</ref> Its title track was previously recorded on ''Native American'' in 1995. The album received two [[GMA Dove Award|Dove Award]] nominations, and a second gospel album, ''Pray for Me'', was released in 2012.<ref name=\"Taste of Country\">{{cite web|last1=Conaway|first1=Alanna|title=The Bellamy Brothers to Release New Gospel Album 'Pray for Me' on September 4 |date=12 August 2012 |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/bellamy-brothers-pray-for-me-album-release-date/|publisher=Taste of Country|access-date=21 December 2016}}</ref> They had many guest singers on this album. Their sister Ginger sang with them on the song \"Suppertime\", and Deborah Allen sang background vocals with Vicky Hampton on the album. Irish actor and musician Kieran McHugh played penny whistle for the song \"Hymn to Him\".<ref name=\"The Boot New Gospel Album\">{{cite web|last1=Evans-Price|first1=Deborah|title=The Bellamy Brothers Pack Emotional Punch on New Gospel Album |date=17 September 2012 |url=http://theboot.com/the-bellamy-brothers-gospel-album/|publisher=The Boot|access-date=21 December 2016}}</ref>\n\nIn 2008, the song \"Let Your Love Flow\" was used in the [[Barclaycard]] advert for their new contactless cards. The song re-entered the UK singles chart at No.&nbsp;48 based on downloads, peaked at No.&nbsp;21 in the pop charts in March 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://acharts.us/song/40093 |title=The Bellamy Brothers - Let Your Love Flow - Music Charts |publisher=Acharts.us |access-date=2012-05-03}}</ref> and was listed on BMI's list of Top 100 Song of the Century at No.&nbsp;68 that same year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.musicnewsnashville.com/current_articles/preshias.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091120073620/http://www.musicnewsnashville.com/current_articles/preshias.htm|url-status=dead|title=Preshias' Monthly Column: Music News|archive-date=November 20, 2009}}</ref> A cover by Petra Haden was used in a 2010 [[Toyota Prius]] commercial.\n\n''The Anthology, Vol. 1'' was released in 2009 and includes the single \"Guilty of the Crime\", which is a collaboration with the [[Bacon Brothers]]. The video features [[Shannen Doherty]] of ''[[Beverly Hills, 90210]]'' fame.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://top40-charts.com/news/Country/Bellamy-Brothers-Bacon-Brothers-Guilty-Of-The-Crime--New-Video-Debuts-On-CMT-Pure/49799.html|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20091129145316/http://top40-charts.com/news/Country/Bellamy-Brothers-Bacon-Brothers-Guilty-Of-The-Crime--New-Video-Debuts-On-CMT-Pure/49799.html|archive-date = 2009-11-29|title = Bellamy Brothers, Bacon Brothers 'Guilty of the Crime' - New Video Debuts on CMT Pure}}</ref> Both sets of brothers performed the song together on the [[Grand Ole Opry]] in Nashville, Tennessee, on September 1, 2009.\n\nIn 2010, the Bellamys recorded ''The Greatest Hits Sessions'' with Swiss rock star [[G\u00f6l\u00e4]] (Marco Pfeuti) and the project sold double platinum in Europe.<ref name=\"American Country Music Chart\">{{cite web|title=Bellamy Brothers Strike Platinum in Europe with BB&G Album!|url=http://americancountrymusicchart.com/bellamy-brothers-strike-platinum-in-europe-with-bbg-album/|publisher=American Country Music Chart|access-date=21 December 2016}}</ref> It was at number one of the Swiss Schweizer Hitparade for 7 weeks. In 2011, they created ''BB&G Platinum'' with G\u00f6l\u00e4. Then, in 2014, they teamed up again with G\u00f6l\u00e4 and recorded ''Mermaid Cowgirl'' in Switzerland. They achieved gold record status in Switzerland with this album.<ref name=\"AXS\" />\n\nIn June 2010, their song \"Jalepe\u00f1os\", about the problems of political correctness, was banned before it could even be released to radio because of its profanity.<ref>Buie, Lisa, St. Petersburg Times, Music: No rockin' chairs for Bellamy Brothers, June 4, 2010</ref> The video became a major [[YouTube]] hit with almost 3 million views.<ref name=\"YouTube The Bellamy Brothers - Jalapenos\">{{cite web|title=The Bellamy Brothers - Jalapenos| date=2 June 2010 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B4j_9IQ6wzk |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211213/B4j_9IQ6wzk |archive-date=2021-12-13 |url-status=live|publisher=YouTube|access-date=21 December 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref>\n\nIn 2012, the Bellamy Brothers collaborated with Austrian schlager singer [[DJ \u00d6tzi]] to create the album ''Simply the Best''. It was DJ \u00d6tzi's first full English-language album, and entered the [[GfK Entertainment Charts|German album charts]] at number three.<ref name=\"All Music  DJ Otzi\">{{cite web|title=DJ \u00d6tzi / The Bellamy Brothers|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/simply-the-best-mw0002352473|publisher=All Music|access-date=21 December 2016}}</ref>\n\nIn June 2014, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine ranked \"[[Old Hippie]]\" #95 in their list of the 100 greatest country songs.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-lists/100-greatest-country-songs-of-all-time-11200/|title=100 Greatest Country Songs of All Time|date=2014-06-01|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US|access-date=2019-07-24}}</ref>\n\nDuring these years the brothers worked on many other collaborative song efforts as well. They recorded \"Hello, Lady Harley\" with [[Truck Stop (band)|Truck Stop]] in 2003,<ref name=\"YouTube with Truck Stop\">{{cite web|title=Bellamy Brothers & Truck Stop -- Hello, Lady Harley - Live @ Country Night Schupfart -- 24.9.2011| date=27 September 2011 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7tUmSGEEZ-Q |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211213/7tUmSGEEZ-Q |archive-date=2021-12-13 |url-status=live|publisher=YouTube|access-date=21 December 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref> worked with Alan Jackson in 2005,<ref name=\"Daily Motion Alan Jackson\">{{cite web|title=The Bellamy Brothers & Alan Jackson - You Ain't Just Whistling Dixie|date=23 December 2015 |url=http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x3j688y_the-bellamy-brothers-alan-jackson-you-ain-t-just-whistling-dixie_music|publisher=Daily Motion|access-date=21 December 2016}}</ref> and collaborated with Tom Astor in 2007.<ref name=\"YouTube Tom Astor\">{{cite web|title=Tom Astor, The Bellamy Brothers - I Need More Of You| date=24 October 2009 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N9dWbpatPH4 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211213/N9dWbpatPH4 |archive-date=2021-12-13 |url-status=live|publisher=YouTube|access-date=21 December 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref>\n\nIn April 2018, the group released the memoir ''Let Your Love Flow - The Life and Times of the Bellamy Brothers''.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/let-your-love-flow-the-life-and-times-of-the-bellamy-brothers-by-david-bellamy-and-howard-bellamy|publisher=Fox News |date=April 17, 2018|title='Let Your Love Flow: The Life and Times of the Bellamy Brothers' by David Bellamy and Howard Bellamy}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.tampabay.com/news/Bellamy-Brothers-let-their-love-flow-on-Pasco-based-reality-TV-show_166871619/|publisher=Tampa Bay Times |author=Phyllis Day|date=April 3, 2018|title=Bellamy Brothers let their love flow}}</ref> The Bellamys then released their album ''Over the Moon'' in 2019, which consisted of 14 original songs written and recorded at the Bellamys' studio on their Darby ranch.<ref name=Billboard />\n\n==''Honky Tonk Ranch''==\n{{main article|Honky Tonk Ranch}}\nIn 2018 the brothers became the feature of the reality television series ''[[Honky Tonk Ranch]]'', which aired on the [[Cowboy Channel]], [[RFD-TV]] and now on the Circle Network. The series follows the Bellamys in addition to their friends and family. A second season of ''Honky Tonk Ranch'' aired in 2019.<ref name=Billboard />  In 2020, the show moved to the [[Circle (TV network)|Circle Network]] where seasons one and two aired along with season three.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://countryrebel.com/bellamy-brothers-honky-tonk-ranch-show-moves-to-brand-new-circle-network/|title=Bellamy Brothers' 'Honky Tonk Ranch' Show Moves To Brand-New Circle Network|date=13 January 2020 }}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nIn the late 1990s, David's sons Noah and Jesse became active in the music scene and the sons currently perform as the duo [[Jesse and Noah]].\n\nThe Bellamy Brothers live in Darby, Florida, on a 200-acre ranch, where they raise [[Brahman (cattle)|Brahman cattle]] and [[American Quarter Horse|quarter horses]], with three generations of their family living in the compound.<ref name=\"Stub Wire\" /> The ranch is also the location of the recording studio where much of their work is recorded.\n\nIn 2020, the brothers partnered with Florida [[medical cannabis]] company [[Trulieve]] to produce a signature line of [[Cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] products named \"Old Hippie Stash\".<ref>{{cite press release |date=April 9, 2020 |title=Trulieve Announces Partnership With Iconic International Duo Bellamy Brothers |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/trulieve-announces-partnership-iconic-international-160800494.html |location=Tallahassee, FL |publisher=Yahoo Finance |agency=CNW Group |access-date=April 11, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200607040702/https://finance.yahoo.com/news/trulieve-announces-partnership-iconic-international-160800494.html |archive-date=June 7, 2020 |url-status=dead}}</ref> Said David: {{Nowrap|\"[Cannabis}} has] helped Howard and me on many levels. There was a stigma for so long, but now people are talking about it seriously and considering cannabis as an alternative for stress, anxiety, pain management and many other health factors.\"<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Reuter |first1=Annie |title=Bellamy Brothers Partner With Cannabis Company Trulieve for 'Old Hippie Stash' Line: Exclusive |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/9354402/bellamy-brothers-old-hippie-stash-weed-trulieve |access-date=April 11, 2020 |magazine=Billboard |date=April 9, 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{For|a complete listing of The Bellamy Brothers albums and singles|The Bellamy Brothers discography}}\n\n==Honors and awards==\n*[[Grammy Award|Grammy]] nomination for Best Country Performance by a duo or group and Best Country & Western Song (1980)<ref name=\"Awards & Shows\">{{cite web|title=Grammy Awards 1980|url=http://www.awardsandshows.com/features/grammy-awards-1980-228.html|publisher=Awards & Shows|access-date=25 December 2016}}</ref>  \n*Named the Most Promising Group of the Year by CMA (1980){{citation needed|date=April 2020}}\n*Lifetime Membership of the Federation of International Country Air Personalities (1982)<ref name=\"allmusic\" />\n*Named Top Country Duo by ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' (1982){{citation needed|date=April 2020}}\n*Record for the most duo nominations in both the [[Academy of Country Music]] (ACM) and the [[Country Music Association Awards]] (CMA)<ref name=\"AXS\" /> \n*\"Let Your Love Flow\" placed on the BMI list of the top 100 most played songs of the 20th century (1999)<ref name=\"Archer 2000\">{{cite web|title=BMI Top 100 Songs of the Century|url=http://www.archer2000.net/sbs/awardsbmi.html|publisher=Archer 2000|access-date=25 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140713064201/http://www.archer2000.net/sbs/awardsbmi.html|archive-date=13 July 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=\"BMI\">{{cite web|title=BMI Announces Top 100 Songs of the Century|date=13 December 1999|url=http://www.bmi.com/news/entry/19991214_bmi_announces_top_100_songs_of_the_century|publisher=BMI|access-date=25 December 2016}}</ref>  \n*Received two [[GMA Dove Award|Dove]] nominations for \"Jesus Is Coming\"<ref name=\"Taste of Country\"/> \n*Members of the German Country Music Hall of Fame (only American members with the exception of Johnny Cash)<ref name=\"Top 40 Charts\">{{cite web|title=German Country Music Hall Of Fame says 'Gluckwunsche' to Lynn Anderson, January 29th|url=http://top40-charts.com/news.php?nid=12243|publisher=Top 40 Charts|access-date=25 December 2016}}</ref> \n*\"Old Hippie\" named by ''Rolling Stone'' as one of its top 100 greatest country songs of all time (2014)<ref name=\"Rolling Stone\">{{cite web|title=100 Greatest Country Songs of All Time|date=June 2014|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/pictures/100-greatest-country-songs-of-all-time-20140601/95-bellamy-brothers-old-hippie-1985-0243162|publisher=Rolling Stone|access-date=25 December 2016}}</ref>\n*Inducted into the [[Florida Artists Hall of Fame]] (2018)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dos.myflorida.com/cultural/programs/florida-artists-hall-of-fame/the-bellamy-brothers/|title=The Bellamy Brothers - Division of Cultural Affairs - Florida Department of State|website=dos.myflorida.com|access-date=2019-07-24}}</ref>\n\n==Tours==\nThe brothers have 200 or more concert dates worldwide each year.<ref name=\"Stub Wire\">{{cite web|title=Bellamy Brothers With Special Guest Drew Fish Band|url=http://www.stubwire.com/event/bellamybrotherswithspecialguestdrewfishband/silversaloon/terrell/13268/|publisher=Stub Wire|access-date=19 December 2016}}</ref>  They have had concerts in the United States, Europe, [[Australia]] and [[South Africa]] and have been to distant (from their US base) places like [[Dubai]], [[Saudi Arabia]], [[India]], [[Sri Lanka]], [[New Caledonia]], [[Qatar]], the [[Faroe Islands]] and the [[Czech Republic]].<ref name=\"American Cowboy Magazine\">{{cite web|last1=Huff|first1=Sandy|title=Riding on a Song|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6uoCAAAAMBAJ&q=unusual+tour+locations+for+Bellamy+brothers&pg=PA59|publisher=American Cowboy Magazine|access-date=19 December 2016}}</ref><ref name=\"AXS Playing Around World\">{{cite web|last1=Lealos|first1=Shawn S.|title=Bellamy Brothers talk about playing all over the world|url=https://www.axs.com/news/bellamy-brothers-talk-about-playing-all-over-the-world-88572|publisher=AXS|access-date=19 December 2016}}</ref> In 1999, The Bellamy Brothers played for American troops stationed in [[Bosnia]], and on [[Easter Sunday]] 2000, they gave a concert for American troops in war-torn [[Kosovo]] as well as a concert at a remote camp in Macedonia. In 2014, they toured in [[India]] and [[Sri Lanka]] and made history as the first country music act touring in those Asian countries.<ref name=\"For The Country Record\">{{cite web|title=Bellamy Brothers Make Touring History \u2013 First Country Act To Tour India & Sri Lanka|url=http://forthecountryrecord.com/2014/02/20/bellamy-brothers-make-touring-history-first-country-act-to-tour-india-sri-lanka/|publisher=For The Country Record|access-date=19 December 2016}}</ref> In 2019 and 2020, the Bellamy Brothers participated in [[Blake Shelton]]'s \"Friends and Heroes Tour\".<ref name=Billboard>{{cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8497193/bellamy-brothers-interview-blake-shelton-tour-new-album-honky-tonk-ranch|publisher=Billboard|title=Bellamy Brothers Gear Up for Blake Shelton Tour, New Album & Second Season of 'Honky Tonk Ranch'|date=February 9, 2019 |author=Deborah Evans Price}}</ref>\n\n==Charities==\nThe brothers have traveled around the world playing benefit concerts for [[United States Armed Forces|American troops]] abroad including performances throughout [[Germany]], [[Italy]], [[Japan]], [[Guam]], [[South Korea]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnia]] and [[Kosovo]]. When they played at [[Camp Bondsteel]] in Kosovo in 2000, it was the first time that the base had allowed a band to play.<ref name=\"MTV News\">{{cite web|title=Bellamy Brothers To Brighten Easter For U.S. Troops In Kosovo|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/820021/bellamy-brothers-to-brighten-easter-for-us-troops-in-kosovo/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161225144917/http://www.mtv.com/news/820021/bellamy-brothers-to-brighten-easter-for-us-troops-in-kosovo/|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 25, 2016|publisher=MTV News|access-date=25 December 2016}}</ref> In 2011, the brothers supported [[2011 Christchurch earthquake|earthquake]] victims in [[New Zealand]] when they joined the [[New Zealand Red Cross]] and Judy Seale International to raise support through live auctions.<ref name=\"The Boot Earthquake Help\">{{cite web|last1=Dunham|first1=Nancy|title=Bellamy Brothers Reach Out to New Zealand Earthquake Victims|date=17 March 2011 |url=http://theboot.com/bellamy-brothers-new-zealand-earthquake-auction/|publisher=The Boot|access-date=25 December 2016}}</ref> In 2016, the Bellamy Brothers partnered with the [[Susan G. Komen for the Cure|Susan G. Komen Foundation]] to release a video for \"Let Your Love Flow.\" They supported the foundation's breast cancer research by donating one dollar for every digital download of their 40 Year package.<ref name=\"Taste of Country 40 Year\">{{cite web|last1=Whitaker|first1=Sterling|title=Interview: The Bellamy Brothers Still Rolling Down the Road After 40 Years|date=15 November 2015 |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/bellamy-brothers-40-years-interview/|publisher=Taste of Country|access-date=25 December 2016}}</ref>\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* {{Official website|http://www.bellamybrothers.com/}}\n* {{Discogs artist|artist=Bellamy Brothers}}\n* {{Musicbrainz artist|id=252b5d32-5bd5-4cae-9d48-6aafa2145c33|name=Bellamy Brothers}}\n\n{{The Bellamy Brothers}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Bellamy Brothers, The}}\n[[Category:Country music groups from Florida]]\n[[Category:Atlantic Records artists]]\n[[Category:Businesspeople in the cannabis industry]]\n[[Category:American country music duos]]\n[[Category:Curb Records artists]]\n[[Category:Elektra Records artists]]\n[[Category:MCA Records artists]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 1968]]\n[[Category:People from Pasco County, Florida]]\n[[Category:Sibling musical duos]]\n[[Category:Warner Records artists]]\n[[Category:Pasco High School (Florida) alumni]]\n[[Category:Intersound Records artists]]\n[[Category:Country pop duos]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Miko_Marks","to":"Miko Marks"}],"pages":{"26862700":{"pageid":26862700,"ns":0,"title":"Miko Marks","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country singer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Miko Marks\n| image           =\n| caption         =\n| image_size      =\n| birth_name      = Miko Marks\n| birth_place     = [[Flint, Michigan]]\n| birth_date      =\n| origin          = Flint, Michigan\n| instrument      = Vocals, acoustic guitar\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer songwriter\n| years_active    = 2005\u2013present\n| label           = Mirrome, Brown Bear, Aspirion\n| website         = [http://www.mikomarks.com/]\n}}\n'''Miko Marks''' is an American Americana singer based in Oakland, California. She was born in [[Flint, Michigan]]. She attended from 1990 to 1994 [[Grambling State University]] in Louisiana where she got her degree in Political Science.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.mikomarks.com/about | title=About }}</ref>  She later moved to San Francisco. Marks was named ''Best New Country Artist'' at the 2006 [[New Music Weekly]] Awards.<ref name=\"Henderson\">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jtMDAAAAMBAJ&q=%22Miko+Marks%22&pg=PA88|title=The Storyteller Miko Marks|last=Henderson|first=Shirley|date=June 2008|work=[[Ebony (magazine)|Ebony]]|page=88|access-date=June 5, 2010}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nMarks released her debut single, \"Freeway Bound,\" in 2005. It was followed by her debut album, also titled ''Freeway Bound'', which was released on September 13, 2005. Three further singles (\"Kickin' Back,\" \"Mama,\" and \"Don't Come Cryin' to Me\") were released from the album in 2006. \"Mama\" featured Marks' first music video, which included a guest appearance by [[Erykah Badu]] assuming the title role.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mikomarks.com/about.html |title=Official Miko Marks Website - 2007 Country Album of the Year |access-date=April 7, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613005353/http://www.mikomarks.com/about.html |archive-date=June 13, 2010 }}</ref> Her second studio album, ''It Feels Good'', followed in 2007 after the release of lead-off single \"Locked and Loaded.\" Both were produced by [[Ron Cornelius]] and released under the Mirrome Records imprint.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mirrome.com/ |title=Home |website=mirrome.com}}</ref>\n\nIn his review of ''It Feels Good'', Stewart Mason of [[allmusic]] awarded the album 3 and 1/2 stars, drawing comparisons to the [[Dixie Chicks]] and [[Gretchen Wilson]] while commenting that the album \"clicks on every level, making it a solidly enjoyable neo-traditionalist country listen.\"<ref>{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r1112542|pure_url=yes}}</ref>\n\nIn 2021, Marks released \u201cOur Country'',''\u201d her first new album in over a decade.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Rodman|first=Sarah|date=2021-02-17|title=Black, Female and Carving Out Their Own Path in Country Music|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/17/arts/music/black-women-country-music.html|access-date=2021-02-19|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> The album's lead single and music video are \"We Are Here\".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1832519/premiere-miko-marks-video-we-are-here/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210409181322/http://www.cmt.com/news/1832519/premiere-miko-marks-video-we-are-here/|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 9, 2021|title = PREMIERE: Miko Marks Highlights the Struggles of Her Hometown in \"We Are Here\" Video}}</ref>\n\nIn October 2022, Marks performed on the [[Grand Ole Opry]] for the first time. According to [[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]], her performance received two standing ovations.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.cmt.com/news/5zcnk5/dream-realized-miko-marks-receives-two-standing-ovations-at-grand-ole-opry-debut | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221019072054/https://www.cmt.com/news/5zcnk5/dream-realized-miko-marks-receives-two-standing-ovations-at-grand-ole-opry-debut | url-status=dead | archive-date=October 19, 2022 | title=Dream Realized: Miko Marks Receives Two Standing Ovations at Grand Ole Opry Debut }}</ref>\n\nIn October of 2023, Marks collaborated with the Fisk Jubilee Singers for an updated version of her song \"Jubilee\" <ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2023/10/13/miko-marks-releases-jubilee-a-rootsy-collaboration-with-the-fisk-jubilee-singers/71166044007/ | title=Miko Marks releases 'Jubilee,' a rootsy collaboration with the Fisk Jubilee Singers | website=[[The Tennessean]] }}</ref>\n\n== Family ==\nShe married young and had a son, Justin. Her husband works as local firefighter.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.mikomarks.com/about | title=About }}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"1\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"1\"| Album details\n|-\n| 2005\n| align=\"left\"| '''''Freeway Bound'''''\n* Release date: September 13, 2005\n* Label: Mirrome/Brown Bear\n|-\n| 2007\n| align=\"left\"| '''''It Feels Good'''''\n* Release date: August 21, 2007\n* Label: Mirrome/Aspirion\n|-\n| 2021\n| align=\"left\"| '''''Our Country'''''\n* Release date: March 26, 2021\n* Label: Redtone\n|-\n| 2022\n| align=\"left\"| '''''Feel Like Going Home'''''<ref>{{cite web | url=https://musicrow.com/2022/10/miko-marks-new-album-feel-like-going-home-set-for-october-14/ | title=Miko Marks' New Album 'Feel Like Going Home' Set for October 14 | date=October 3, 2022 }}</ref>\n* Release date: October 14, 2022\n* Label: Redtone\n|}\n\n===Extended Plays===\n{| class=\"wikitable\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Rory_Feek","to":"Rory Feek"}],"pages":{"19022745":{"pageid":19022745,"ns":0,"title":"Rory Feek","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{Cleanup bare URLs|date=August 2022}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox person\n| name         = Rory Feek\n| image        = Rory Feek (cropped).jpg\n| caption      = Feek at the 45th [[Academy of Country Music Awards]] in 2010\n| image_size   =\n| birth_date   = {{Birth date and age|1965|4|25}}<ref name=\"cyd\">{{cite web |url=http://thislifeilive.com/hawaii-five-o/ |title=This Life I Live |access-date=February 4, 2016 }}</ref>\n| birth_place  = [[Atchison, Kansas]], U.S.\n| occupation   = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active = 1996\u2013present (songwriter)\n2008\u20132016, 2020\u2013present (singer)\n| website      =\n| module       = {{Infobox musical artist|embed=yes\n| background   = solo_singer\n| instrument   = Vocals\n| genre        = [[Country music|Country]]\n| label        = [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass)|Sugar Hill]]/[[Vanguard Records|Vanguard]] (in Joey + Rory)\n| spouse       = {{plainlist|\n* {{Marriage|Tamara Gilmer|1985|1992|end=divorced}}\n* {{Marriage|[[Joey Feek]]|2002|2016|end=died}}\n* {{Marriage|Rebecca|2024}}\n}}\n\n| past_member_of = [[Joey + Rory]]\n}}\n}}\n\n'''Rory Lee Feek''' (born April 25, 1965) is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. In his career, he has written singles for [[Clay Walker]], [[Blake Shelton]], [[Tracy Byrd]] and other artists. He and his wife, [[Joey Feek]], formed the duo [[Joey + Rory]] and was placed third on the first season of the [[Country Music Television|CMT]] talent show ''[[Can You Duet]]''. He also established Giantslayer Records for launching of new independent artists.\n\n==Personal life==\n[[File:RoryFeek GabeMccauley JoelSalatin At MusicRanchMontana.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Feek on stage with Gabe Mccauley and Joel Salatin at the Music Ranch Montana on July 10, 2021|Feek on stage with Gabe Mccauley and Joel Salatin at the Music Ranch Montana on July 10, 2021]]\n\nRory Lee Feek was born and raised in [[Atchison, Kansas]]. In his blog, ThisLifeILive.com,<ref>{{Cite web|title=The Blog|url=https://www.roryfeek.com/blog|access-date=2021-04-07|website=www.roryfeek.com|language=en}}</ref> he gives his birth year as 1965. Feek married Tamara Gilmer on August 3, 1985, and they divorced March 25, 1992. In 2002, he married [[Joey Feek]], with whom he started the duo [[Joey + Rory]]. They have one daughter, Indiana Boone (born February 17, 2014), who was born with [[Down syndrome]]. Feek also has two older daughters, [[Heidi Feek]] (born 1986) and Hopie Feek (born 1988),<ref>http://www.thislifeilive.com/happymothersdaydad</ref> from his previous marriage. Joey died of metastatic cervical cancer on March 4, 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|last=songrory|date=2016-03-13|title=dust to dust|url=https://www.roryfeek.com/post/dust-to-dust|access-date=2021-04-07|website=www.roryfeek.com|language=en}}</ref>\n\nFeek has a friendship<ref>{{Cite web|title=Joel Salatin's Blog|url=https://www.thelunaticfarmer.com/blog/6/18/2019/rory-feek|access-date=2021-07-20|website=wwww.thelunaticfarmer.com|date=June 18, 2019 |language=en}}</ref> and working relationship with [[Joel F. Salatin]] with whom he has collaborated in several performances promoting sustainable farming. Feek hosted a series of discussions on sustainable farming in 2020 <ref>{{Cite web|title=Rory's Squarespace Blog|url=https://roryfeek.squarespace.com/the-blog//a-frank-conversation|access-date=2021-07-20|website=roryfeek.squarespace.com|language=en}}</ref> and again in 2021 in an event billed as \"Songs, Stories & Sustainability with Joel Salatin and Rory Feek\" <ref>{{Cite web|title=Joel Salatin and Rory Feek \"the GENTLE MAN & the FARMER\"|url=https://bozemanmagazine.com/events/2021/07/10/92225-joel-salatin-and-rory-feek-the-gentle-man-the|access-date=2021-07-20|website=bozemanmagazine.com|language=en}}</ref> at the Music Ranch Montana. On Feek's property outside of Nashville, he has a farm, a concert hall and school house.<ref>{{Cite web|title=The School|url=https://www.roryfeek.com/school|access-date=2021-07-20|website=www.roryfeek.com|language=en}}</ref>\n\nEight years following the death of Joey, Feek married Rebecca on July 14, 2024 in [[Greycliff, Montana]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://people.com/country-singer-rory-feek-remarries-8-years-after-death-of-wife-joey-8680905|title=Country Singer Rory Feek Remarries 8 Years After Death of His Wife Joey: 'Blessed to Love Again'|author=Kimberlee Speakman|date=July 19, 2024|magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=July 19, 2024}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nInspired by [[Don Williams]], [[Merle Haggard]], and other artists, Feek began playing guitar at age 15. He later served two tours of duty in the [[United States Marine Corps]] after high school, before moving to [[Dallas]], Texas, where he played in nightclubs. Feek moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in 1995 after being encouraged by Nashville entertainment attorney Rod Phelps, and signed to a publishing contract. One of his first single releases as a songwriter was [[Collin Raye]]'s \"Someone You Used to Know,\" a Top Five country hit in 1999. A year later, [[Clay Walker]] reached Top Five as well with \"[[The Chain of Love]],\" another song that Feek co-wrote.<ref name=\"blacktop\">{{cite web |url=http://www.blacktopmusicgroup.com/rory_lee_feek.htm |title=Rory Lee Feek biography |access-date=February 4, 2009 |publisher=Blacktop Music Group}}</ref>\n\nFeek continued to write for other artists in the 2000s, including album tracks for [[Mark Wills]], [[Kenny Chesney]], [[Terri Clark]], [[Randy Travis]], and [[Lorrie Morgan]], as well as [[Tracy Byrd]]'s 2003 single \"[[The Truth About Men (song)|The Truth About Men]]\"<ref name=\"blacktop\"/> In 2004, Feek achieved his first Number One as a songwriter when [[Blake Shelton]] topped the country charts with \"[[Some Beach]],\" which he co-wrote with [[Paul Overstreet]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1497408/paul-overstreet-rory-lee-feek-bask-on-some-beach.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090911043049/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1497408/paul-overstreet-rory-lee-feek-bask-on-some-beach.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 11, 2009 |title=Paul Overstreet, Rory Lee Feek Bask on \"Some Beach\" |access-date=February 4, 2009 |last=Morris |first=Edward |date=February 23, 2005 |publisher=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]}}</ref> Also in 2004, Feek founded the Giantslayer Records label, on which [[Blaine Larsen]] recorded two studio albums in association with [[BNA Records]].\n\nIn 2008, Feek and his wife Joey founded a duo called [[Joey + Rory]]. They came in third place on the [[Country Music Television|CMT]] talent show ''[[Can You Duet]]'', and later that year signed to a recording contract with [[Vanguard Records]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://americannoise.com/introducing-joey-rory-like-two-names-carved-in-an-oak-tree-an-interview/ |title=Introducing Joey + Rory: \"Like Two Names Carved in an Oak Tree\" |access-date=January 10, 2020 |last=Malec |first=Jim |date=October 28, 2012 |publisher=American Noise}}</ref> Joey + Rory released their debut single \"[[Cheater, Cheater]]\" that year, and peaked at No.&nbsp;30 on the country singles charts with it. That same year, [[Jimmy Wayne]] charted on the country charts with \"[[I Will (Jimmy Wayne song)|I Will]],\" another Feek co-write.\n\n[[File:RoryFeekAtMusicRanchMontanaByKingElder.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Rory promoting his \"Gentle Man\" album at the Music Ranch Montana in July 2021|Rory at the Music Ranch Montana in July 2021]]\nRory\u2019s first solo album \"Gentle Man\" was released on June 18, 2021.<ref name=\"americansongwriter.com\">{{Cite web|date=2021-02-15|title=Rory Feek Readies Himself for Unchartered Territory on New Album 'Gentle Man'|url=https://americansongwriter.com/rory-feek-new-album-gentle-man-feature/|access-date=2021-04-07|website=American Songwriter|language=en-US}}</ref> It is the first album recorded since losing his wife and country music collaborator Joey to cancer in 2016. The album includes Feek and Jamie Teachenor's co-written single \u201cMet Him in a Motel Room\u201d with vocals by [[Trisha Yearwood]].<ref>{{Cite web|date=April 2, 2021|first=Cillea|last=Houghton|title=Listen: Rory Feek and Trisha Yearwood Find Redemption in 'Met Him in a Motel Room'|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/rory-feek-trisha-yearwood-met-him-in-a-motel-room-song/|access-date=2021-04-07|website=Taste of Country|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Songfacts|title=Met Him in a Motel Room by Trisha Yearwood - Songfacts|url=https://www.songfacts.com/facts/trisha-yearwood/met-him-in-a-motel-room|access-date=2021-04-07|website=www.songfacts.com|language=en}}</ref> Yearwood previously recorded the song for her 2014 album, \"PrizeFighter: Hit After Hit.\"<ref>{{Cite web|last=Watts|first=Cindy|title=Trisha Yearwood packs punch with 'PrizeFighter'|url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2014/11/16/trisha-yearwood-garth-brooks-prizefighter/18997493/|access-date=2021-04-07|website=The Tennessean|language=en-US}}</ref> The album also includes a cover of [[Bob Dylan]]\u2019s \u201c[[The Times They Are a-Changin' (song)|The Times They Are A-Changin]].\u2019\u201d<ref name=\"americansongwriter.com\"/>\n\nAs a filmmaker and storyteller, Feek wrote, shot much of, and edited his docu-series, This Life I Live,<ref>{{Cite web|title=This Life I Live|url=https://www.rfdtv.com/story/41828056/this-life-i-live|access-date=2021-04-07|website=www.rfdtv.com|language=en}}</ref> which premiered on [[RFD-TV]] in March 2020. Feek created the singer-songwriter show \"Muletown In the Round,\"<ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-02-28|title=Rory Feek's 'Muletown in the Round' Brings Nashville-Style Hit Makers' In-the-Round Music and Storytelling|url=https://countrymusictattletale.com/2020/02/28/rory-feeks-muletown-in-the-round-brings-nashville-style-hit-makers-in-the-round-music-and-storytelling/|access-date=2021-04-07|website=Country Music Tattle Tale - Your country music news source|language=en-US}}</ref> the educational series, \"The One Room Schoolhouse,\"<ref>{{Cite web|last=Powell|first=Jay|title=One Room Schoolhouse series takes students to the farm|url=https://www.columbiadailyherald.com/story/lifestyle/2020/09/19/rory-feek-launches-schoolhouse-web-series/5790063002/|access-date=2021-04-07|website=Columbia Daily Herald|language=en-US}}</ref> and others with Red King Productions.<ref>{{Cite web|title=shows|url=https://www.redking.red/shows|access-date=2021-04-07|website=redking|language=en}}</ref>  He also made the feature-length film Finding Josephine (2019),<ref>{{Cite web|last=Perkins|first=Joel|title=Rory Feek To Release \"Finding Josephine\" Film|url=https://countryfancast.com/rory-feek-to-release-finding-josephine/|access-date=2021-04-07|website=countryfancast.com|date=January 28, 2019 |language=en}}</ref> the full-length documentary To Joey, With Love (2016),<ref>{{Cite web|last=Bonaguro|date=2016-09-21|first=Alison|title=To Joey, With Love Chronicles Joey + Rory's Journey|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1771148/to-joey-with-love-chronicles-joey-rorys-journey/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160922135214/http://www.cmt.com/news/1771148/to-joey-with-love-chronicles-joey-rorys-journey/|url-status=dead|archive-date=September 22, 2016|access-date=2021-04-07|website=CMT News}}</ref> music videos for the album \"Gentle Man,\" and dozens of music videos over his career as a musician and songwriter.<ref>{{Citation|title=The Times They Are A-Changin' - rory feek| date=January 24, 2021 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2thobAZTU-4&list=PLSDO6ho2wHXILDZbrlNlUAi1B_tRSUA-9 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/2thobAZTU-4 |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|language=en|access-date=2021-04-07}}{{cbignore}}</ref>\n\nAs an author, Feek has written two memoirs and several children's books. His 2017 memoir, \"This Life I Live: One Man's Extraordinary, Ordinary Life and the Woman Who Changed It Forever\" (HarperCollins) hit top book lists including the Wall Street Journal, Publishers Weekly, the New York Times, the Washington Post, and USA Today.<ref>{{Cite web|date=March 7, 2017|first1=Angela|last1=Stefano|title='This Life I Live' Earns Spots on Multiple Bestsellers Lists|url=https://theboot.com/rory-feek-this-life-i-live-book-bestsellers-lists/|access-date=2021-04-07|website=The Boot|language=en}}</ref> Additional books include \"Once Upon a Farm\" (HarperCollins),<ref>{{Cite web|last=Feek|first=Rory|date=2018-06-14|title=Rory Feek Opens Up About How He's Grown Since His Wife Joey's Death|url=https://www.countryliving.com/life/inspirational-stories/a21291298/rory-feek-joey-garden/|access-date=2021-04-07|website=Country Living|language=en-US}}</ref> \"The Cow Said Neigh!\" (HarperCollins),<ref>{{Cite web|date=2018-10-03|title=Heartbreak, Single Fatherhood and a Ring He'll Never Take Off: Life for Rory Feek After Losing His Forever Duet Partner|url=https://www.eonline.com/news/973341/heartbreak-single-fatherhood-and-a-ring-he-ll-never-take-off-life-for-rory-feek-after-losing-his-forever-duet-partner|access-date=2021-04-07|website=E! Online}}</ref> \"The Day God Made You\" (HarperCollins),<ref>{{Cite web|title=Indiana, 6, Adorably Reads Proud 'Papa' Rory Feek's New Children's Book Celebrating Inclusivity|url=https://people.com/parents/rory-feek-daughter-indiana-new-childrens-book-day-god-made-you/|access-date=2021-04-07|website=PEOPLE.com|language=en}}</ref> and \"The Little Rooster\" (Milk Barn Kids).<ref>{{Cite web|title=The Little Rooster by Rory Feek {{!}} Milkbarn Kids\u00ae {{!}} Children's Books & Gifts|url=https://milkbarnkids.com/product/the-little-rooster-by-rory-feek/|access-date=2021-04-07|website=Milkbarn Kids\u00ae {{!}} Organic Baby Clothes & Accessories|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n{{Joey + Rory}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Feek, Rory Lee}}\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:People from Atchison, Kansas]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Kansas]]\n[[Category:Grammy Award winners]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Kansas]]\n[[Category:1965 births]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Lucy_Angel","to":"Lucy Angel"}],"pages":{"33681000":{"pageid":33681000,"ns":0,"title":"Lucy Angel","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country music vocal group}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Lucy Angel\n| image           = Lucy Angel at Bra Country Concert.jpg\n| caption         = Lucy Angel performing for Y100's Bra Country Concert on October 14th at the new \"Backstage At The Meyer\" in downtown Green Bay to benefit the Breast Cancer Family Foundation in 2015\n| origin          = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], [[United States|USA]]\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]<!--Do not change without source-->\n| years_active    = 2003\u2013present\n| label           = G-Force\n| website         = {{URL|http://www.lucyangel.com/}}\n| current_members = Kate Anderton<br />Lindsay Anderton<br />Emily Anderton\n}}\n\n'''Lucy Angel''' is an American [[country music]] vocal group from [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. The group consists of Kate Anderton (mandolin, vocals) and her two daughters, Lindsay (lead vocals, harmonica) and Emily (guitar, vocals). The group has charted one single, \"Crazy Too\", on [[Country Airplay]].\n\n==Music career==\n\n===Early years===\nKate first entered the world of country music when her husband entered her into a country music talent search show, the Wrangler Country Showdown (which later became the [[Colgate Country Showdown]]), which she won. Eldest daughter Lindsay started performing at age four, and by twelve had joined her mother in singing professionally. Originally from [[Arizona]], the family moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in 2003,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/lucy-angel-mn0002737815/biography|title=Artist Biography|last=Deming|first=Mark|date=|website=All Music|access-date=5 November 2019}}</ref> where Kate and Lindsay first took on the name Lucy Angel as the name of their duo.<ref>Segovia, Stacy Smith (Sep 16, 2005) \"BWC's Bike Week roars into town\". ''The Leaf Chronicle'' pg. D.3</ref> Youngest daughter Emily joined her mother and sister on the stage.\n\n===2004 - Present===\nLucy Angel's first public performance as a trio was opening for [[Neal McCoy]].<ref name=\"musicrow.com\">{{cite web|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2011/04/lucy-angel/|title=Lucy Angel \u2013 \"Serious\"|work=MusicRow - Nashville's Music Industry Publication - News, Songs From Music City|date=18 April 2011}}</ref> The group went on to open for headliner acts such as [[Taylor Swift]], [[Montgomery Gentry]] and [[Charlie Daniels]]. On July 22, 2011, they performed at the Country Thunder Music Festival in Twin Lakes, Wisconsin.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thecelebritycafe.com/reviews/country-fans-will-love-lucy-06-28-2011 |title=Country fans will love Lucy &#124; TheCelebrityCafe.com |accessdate=2011-11-08 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110630072540/http://thecelebritycafe.com/reviews/country-fans-will-love-lucy-06-28-2011 |archivedate=2011-06-30 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://emol.org/newclub/wisconsincountrythunder2011 |title=Wisconsin Country Thunder 2011 &#124; Entertainment Magazine |access-date=2011-11-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120405084554/http://emol.org/newclub/wisconsincountrythunder2011 |archive-date=2012-04-05 |url-status=dead }}</ref> In 2015, Lucy Angel opened shows for Jake Owen, Kip Moore, Craig Campbell, Chris Janson, Big & Rich, Lauren Alaina, James Otto, A Thousand Horses, LoCash, The Swon Brothers and more.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sevenvenues.com/events/detail/eaglefest-2015|title = Eaglefest 2015 &#124; SevenVenues}}</ref>\n\nApart from touring the United States, Lucy Angel has also performed internationally, visiting Japan, Switzerland, China and the United Kingdom. In 2006, Lucy Angel performed at the 13th Annual Country Sunshine Festival in [[Kumamoto, Japan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://public.fotki.com/jsrefugee/2006/lucy_angel_-_countr/|title=Lucy Angel - Country Sunshine|work=Fotki - www.fotki.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.judysealeinternational.com/artistontour_06.html |title=JSI Inc., - Entertainment Conglomerate - Artist Management, Corporate Endorsements and International Tours and Festivals |accessdate=2011-11-08 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425121638/http://www.judysealeinternational.com/artistontour_06.html |archivedate=2012-04-25 }}</ref> In 2008, Lucy Angel performed at the Sch\u00fctzenhaus Albisg\u00fctli in [[Zurich, Switzerland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://public.fotki.com/jsrefugee/1/lucy-angel---zurich/|title=Lucy Angel - Zurich, Switzerland|work=Fotki - www.fotki.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.judysealeinternational.com/lucy.zurich.2.22.08.html |title=JSI Inc., - Entertainment Conglomerate - Artist Management, Corporate Endorsements and International Tours and Festivals |accessdate=2011-11-08 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425121743/http://www.judysealeinternational.com/lucy.zurich.2.22.08.html |archivedate=2012-04-25 }}</ref>\n\nLucy Angel journeyed to China twice in 2009. The first time was in January when they gained the distinction of being the first American/Western group ever to be invited to perform at the [[Great Hall of the People]] in [[Tiananmen Square]], doing so before an audience of dignitaries and government officials.<ref name=\"musicrow.com\"/><ref>\"China Girls\". ''Country Weekly''. April 20, 2009</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=News : Headlines : Country Visits Unusual Places : Great American Country|url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_headlines/article/0,3034,GAC_26063_5940126,00.html|date=2012-04-01|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120401033350/http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_headlines/article/0,3034,GAC_26063_5940126,00.html|archive-date=2012-04-01|access-date=2020-05-09}}</ref> In May 2009, the group was invited back to China for the [[Zhangjiajie]] International Country Music Week in the [[Hunan Province]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://en.radio86.com/news/chinas-first-country-music-festival-kicks-hunan |title = China's first country music festival kicks off in Hunan &#124; gbtimes |archive-url=https://archive.today/20120708203829/http://en.radio86.com/news/chinas-first-country-music-festival-kicks-hunan |archive-date=8 July 2012 |url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.cultural-china.com/20090520142453.html|title=Music unites musicians in Zhangjiajie|access-date=2011-11-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120507034201/http://news.cultural-china.com/20090520142453.html|archive-date=2012-05-07|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\nThe group's first single, \"How Long\", was issued in 2007.\n\nLucy Angel released two singles in 2011, \"Only Woman Left\" and \"Serious\". \"Only Woman Left\", their breakout single, peaked at No. 45 on MusicRow\u2019s [[MusicRow]] CountryBreakout chart.<ref name=\"musicrow.com\"/>\n\"Serious\", their second single reached No. 31 on MusicRow\u2019s CountryBreakout chart and \nmade it to No. 42 on the Billboard Indicator chart.<ref name=\"billboard.com\">{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/465389/615-spotlight-lucy-angel-has-fame-in-reach|title=615 Spotlight: Lucy Angel Has Fame in Reach|date=9 November 2011|magazine=Billboard}}</ref> In addition, they have a holiday special single entitled \"Mr. Santa.\"<ref name=\"billboard.com\"/>\n\nLucy Angel's self-titled debut album was released digitally on January 13, 2015. Lucy Angel released \"Crazy Too\" to Country radio in May 2015. The single reached No. 51 on the Country Airplay chart. \"Crazy Too\" was a SiriusXM The Highway, ''Highway Find'' in November and December 2014.\n\nIn 2017 Lucy Angel released a new single to Country Radio entitled \"Public Pool Party\", the lead single comes from a forthcoming EP project yet to be released.\n\nIn 2019, Lucy Angel appeared as guest artists on the [[Ronnie Milsap]] album \"The Duets\". They were featured on the song \"Happy Happy Birthday Baby\".\n\n==Television==\n\n===Reality Show===\nLucy Angel starred in a 13 episode docu-series, \"Discovering Lucy Angel\" on AXS TV in the Spring of 2015. The show is set to air internationally in the UK on SHOWBIZ TV beginning February 14, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.axs.tv/press_articles/20219/|title=AXS TV'S COUNTRY MUSIC DOCU-SERIES 'DISCOVERING LUCY ANGEL' PREMIERES TUESDAY, JANUARY 13, 2015 AT 9 P.M. ET/6 P.M. PT - AXS TV|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://kmle108.radio.com/2011/09/16/photos-lucy-angel-up-close-and-personal/|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120711102018/http://kmle108.radio.com/2011/09/16/photos-lucy-angel-up-close-and-personal/|url-status=dead|archive-date=2012-07-11|title=[Photos] Lucy Angel: Up, Close And Personal|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.entertainment-focus.com/music-section/music-news/discovering-lucy-angel-coming-to-showbiz-tv/|title = Discovering Lucy Angel coming to Showbiz TV| date=25 January 2016 }}</ref>\n\n[[HGTV]] featured the band on the series \"Interiors Inc\", during which they premiered their song \"Cowboy Can.\"<ref>https://news.yahoo.com/lucy-angel-hgtv-interiors-inc-160249628.html {{Dead link|date=February 2022}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:8em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Lucy Angel''\n| \n* Release date: January 13, 2015\n* Label: G-Force Records\n|-\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:12em;\"| Single\n! Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"65\"| [[Country Airplay|US Country Airplay]]\n|-\n| 2007\n! scope=\"row\"| \"How Long\"\n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"2\" {{n/a}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2011\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Only Woman Left\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Serious\"\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"2\"| ''Lucy Angel''\n|-\n| 2015\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Crazy Too\"\n| 51\n|-\n| 2017\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Public Pool Party\"\n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"1\" {{n/a}}\n|-\n|}\n\"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.lucyangel.com Official Site]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n[[Category:American country music groups]]\n[[Category:Family musical groups]]\n[[Category:Musical trios from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Vocal trios]]\n[[Category:Musical groups from Nashville, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 2003]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Watson"}],"pages":{"13239406":{"pageid":13239406,"ns":0,"title":"B. B. Watson","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image           =\n| name            = B.B. Watson\n| image_size      =\n| birth_name      = Haskell Burl Watson\n| birth_date      = {{birth date|1953|7|10}}\n| origin          = [[Tyler, Texas|Tyler]], Texas, U.S.\n| death_date      = {{death date and age|2013|9|28|1953|7|10}}\n| death_place     = [[Pasadena, Texas|Pasadena]], Texas, U.S.\n| instrument      = Vocals\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 1991\u20132013\n| label           = [[BNA Records|BNA]], Oarfin\n}}\n\n'''Haskell Burl \"B. B.\" Watson''' (July 10, 1953 \u2013 September 28, 2013) was an American [[country music]] artist. He charted in 1991 with the single \"Light at the End of the Tunnel\" from his album of the same name.\n\n==Biography==\nHaskell Burl Watson was born July 10, 1953, in [[Tyler, Texas]], and raised in [[La Porte, Texas]]. His nickname \"B. B.\" stood for \"Bad Boy\".<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2017|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2017|pages=385|isbn=978-0-89820-229-8}}</ref> Watson spent his teenage and young adult years working as a musician throughout Texas before moving to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in 1991 to begin a music career. That same year, he was the first act signed to [[BNA Records]], then a new label division of [[RCA Records Nashville]]. His debut single \"Light at the End of the Tunnel\" was the label's first charted single, entering ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] in mid-1991.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/220438997 | title=Watson nets Crawdads as backup | work=The Times | date=October 18, 1991 | accessdate=February 17, 2023 | pages=11C}}</ref> The song peaked at number 23 that year. Another single, \"Lover Not a Fighter\", peaked at number 43. Both songs were included on his only BNA album, also titled ''Light at the End of the Tunnel''.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Nick Cristiano of ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' rated the album three out of four stars, comparing Watson's style favorably to [[Merle Haggard]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/175681600/ | title=Remembering Big Star; Mozart Quartets; B.B. Watson | work=The Philadelphia Inquirer | date=March 15, 1992 | accessdate=February 17, 2023 | pages=N10}}</ref> Michael McCall of ''[[Country Music (magazine)|Country Music]]'' magazine praised the album's [[honky-tonk]] sound and Watson's \"big voice\".<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-All-Music/Country-Music/90s/Country-Music-1992-01-02.pdf | title=Record reviews | author=Michael McCall | journal=Country Music | pages=19 | date=February 2, 1992}}</ref>\n\nHis only other release was 2001's ''Delta Dream'', which charted the single \"The Memory Is the Last Thing to Go\" that year.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Watson died in [[Baytown, Texas]], on September 28, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hosting-22185.tributes.com/show/Haskell-B-B-Watson-96466949|title=Haskell BB Watson \u2013 Crespo & Jirrels Funeral & Cremation Services|date=September 2, 2013|accessdate=December 30, 2013}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! width=\"45\"| [[RPM (magazine)|CAN Country]]<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/discover/films-videos-sound-recordings/rpm/Pages/list.aspx?OCRText=light+at+the+end+of+the+tunnel&Year=1991& | title=Search results for 'Light at the End of the Tunnel' | date=July 17, 2013 | publisher=RPM | accessdate=February 17, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/discover/films-videos-sound-recordings/rpm/Pages/list.aspx?OCRText=lover+not+a+fighter&Year=1992& | title=Search results for 'Lover Not a Fighter' | date=July 17, 2013 | publisher=RPM | accessdate=February 17, 2023}}</ref>\n|-\n|rowspan=2|1991\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Light at the End of the Tunnel\"\n| 23\n| 49\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"4\"| ''Light at the End of the Tunnel''\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| \"Eye for an Eye\"<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-All-Music/Gavin-Report/90/91/Gavin-1991-11-15.pdf | title=Up & Coming | journal=Gavin Report | pages=34 | date=November 15, 1991}}</ref>\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|- \n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1992\n! Cable Guy\n|image             = File:Larry the Cable Guy.jpg\n|caption           = Whitney in 2007\n|birth_name        = Daniel Lawrence Whitney\n|birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1963|2|17}}\n|birth_place       = [[Pawnee City, Nebraska]], U.S.<ref name=LJ>{{cite book |last1=Jones |first1=Loyal |title=Country music humorists and comedians |date=2008 |publisher=[[University
