Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Grascals","to":"The Grascals"}],"pages":{"11788043":{"pageid":11788043,"ns":0,"title":"The Grascals","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American bluegrass band}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = The Grascals\n| image             = Grascals Dec 22.jpg\n| image_size        = \n| background        = group_or_band\n| origin            = [[Nashville, Tennessee]] U.S.\n| genre             = [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[southern gospel]]\n| years_active      = 2004\u2013present\n| label             = {{Hlist | [[Rounder Records]] | [[Cracker Barrel]] | Saguaro Road Records | [[Mountain Home Records|Mountain Home]]}}\n| current_members   = {{Ubl\n  | Terry Smith\n  | Danny Roberts\n  | Kristin Scott Benson\n  | Jamie Johnson\n  | John Bryan\n  | Jamie Harper\n  }}\n| past_members      = {{Ubl\n  | Dave Talbot\n  | Jimmy Mattingly\n  | Aaron McDaris\n  | Jeremy Abshire\n  | Terry Eldredge\n  | Chris Davis\n  | Adam Haynes\n  }}\n| website           = {{URL|grascals.com}}\n}}\n\n'''The Grascals''' are a six-piece American [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] band from [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. Founded in February 2004, the band has gained a level of fame by playing on the [[Grand Ole Opry]] and bluegrass festivals around the country, as well as with [[Dolly Parton]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://grascals.com/about/|title=About {{!}} The Grascals|website=grascals.com|access-date=2019-05-01}}</ref><ref name=\"bluegrasstoday.com\">{{Cite web|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/the-grascals-open-dolly-partons-the-vintage-tour/|title=The Grascals open Dolly Parton's \"The Vintage Tour\"|date=2005-11-23|website=Bluegrass Today|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n\n==Members==\n*Terry Smith \u2013 [[upright bass]]/vocals\n*Danny Roberts \u2013 [[mandolin]]\n*Kristin Scott Benson \u2013 [[banjo]]\n*Jamie Harper \u2013 [[fiddle]]\n*John Bryan \u2013 guitar/vocals\n*Jamie Johnson \u2013 guitar/vocals\n\n=== Terry Smith ===\n\nTerry Smith was born June 15, 1960, in [[Reidsville, North Carolina]]. He moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] in his early teens, after starting out playing in a family band with his mother [[Hazel Smith]], father Patrick Smith, and brother, Billy Smith. Terry has played with such legends as [[Jimmy Martin]], [[Wilma Lee Cooper]], and the [[Osborne Brothers]]. Terry and his brother, Billy, recorded an album for [[Sony Music|CBS]] Records, which evolved to a number one video on [[CMT (U.S. TV channel)|CMT]] with \"Blues Stay Away From Me.\"  After touring with [[Grand Ole Opry]] member [[Mike Snider (musician)|Mike Snider]], Terry joined the Grascals and remains as a founding member.\n\n=== Danny Roberts ===\n\nDanny Roberts started playing guitar to back up Jimmy Mattingly when they were growing up in [[Leitchfield, Kentucky]]. He began to win contests for his guitar playing, and eventually, mandolin. In 1982, he co-founded the New Tradition, bluegrass/[[gospel music|gospel]] group that toured the country for close to 20 years. The band recorded 10 CDs, made \"Seed of Love\" song, the first bluegrass video to feature the [[banjo]], and even reached number one on the [[The Nashville Network|TNN]] channel. That band broke up in 2000, but Danny still continued to play with others including [[Marty Raybon]], [[Larry Cordle]], and [[Melonie Cannon]]. He also joined Ronnie Reno's band, the Reno Tradition. Danny joined the Grascals as a founding member, where he was reunited with Jimmy Mattingly.\n\n=== Kristin Scott Benson ===\nKristin Scott Benson grew up in South Carolina in a musical family and joined the Grascals in January 2009. She worked previously with Petticoat Junction, Larry Cordle & Lonesome Standard Time and the Larry Stephenson Band. She has won the International Bluegrass Music Awards and Society of the Preservation of Bluegrass Music of America Banjo Player of the Year numerous times. In September 2018, she was chosen as the recipient of the ''[[Steve Martin]] Prize for Excellence'' in Banjo and Bluegrass with a $50,000 reward. Kristin is married to [[IIIrd Tyme Out]] mandolin player [[Wayne Benson]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/kristin-scott-benson-talks-about-the-steve-martin-prize/|title=Kristin Scott Benson talks about the Steve Martin Prize|date=2018-09-26|website=Bluegrass Today|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-06}}</ref>\n\n=== John Bryan ===\nJohn Bryan sings lead vocals and plays guitar with the Grascals. He's been playing and singing bluegrass since he was a teen, with a deep, family connection to the music. John's great grandfather, Willard Watson, was a first cousin to Doc, and a fine old-time musician and dancer in his own right.  John was formerly with Larry Efaw and The Bluegrass Mountaineers when he joined the Grascals in April 2015.\n\n=== Jamie Johnson ===\nJamie Johnson was an original founding member since February 2004.  He was raised in Indiana and now makes his home in Hendersonville, Tennessee.  After an eight-year break, he has returned to the band on guitar and vocals.  The band is looking forward to singing and traveling with Jamie again and performing the incredible songs he has written.<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Grascals Welcome Back Founding Member, Jamie Johnson, and Look Toward 20th Anniversary |url=https://myemail.constantcontact.com/The-Grascals-Welcome-Back-Founding-Member--Jamie-Johnson--and-Look-Toward-20th-Anniversary.html?soid=1131760830668&aid=AInl0O-kGL0 |access-date=2022-12-15 |website=IVPR |language=en-US}}</ref>\n=== Jamie Harper ===\nJamie \u201cHarp\u201d Harper plays fiddle for the Grascals and helps out on vocals as of January 2023.   He is originally from North Carolina and now makes his home near Portland, TN with his wife Lakyn and son Stetson. \u201cHarp\u201d has a long bluegrass resume performing with Sideline and Junior Sisk among others [https://bluegrasstoday.com/jamie-harper-to-the-grascals/]\n\n==Line Up Changes==\n\n* December 2006: Dave Talbot left and was replaced by Aaron McDaris on banjo beginning in 2007.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1547660/bluegrass-bands-change-lineups/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190501223751/http://www.cmt.com/news/1547660/bluegrass-bands-change-lineups/|url-status=dead|archive-date=May 1, 2019|title=Bluegrass Bands Change Lineups|date=2006-12-08|website=CMT News|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n* July 2008: Jimmy Mattingly left and was replaced by Jeremy Abshire on fiddle.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/jeremy-abshire-to-the-grascals/|title=Jeremy Abshire to The Grascals|date=2008-05-16|website=Bluegrass Today|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n* January 2009: Aaron McDaris left and was replaced by Kristin Scott Benson on banjo.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thebluegrassspecial.com/archive/2009/january2009/bensongrascalsfeaturejan09.php|title=The Bluegrass Special {{!}} January 2009 {{!}} Features: The Grascals|website=www.thebluegrassspecial.com|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n* October 2013: Jeremy Abshire left and was replaced by Adam Haynes on fiddle.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/adam-haynes-to-the-grascals/|title=Adam Haynes to The Grascals|date=2013-10-25|website=Bluegrass Today|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n* April 2015: Jamie Johnson left and was replaced by John Bryan on guitar and vocals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/john-bryan-to-the-grascals/|title=John Bryan to The Grascals|date=2015-04-27|website=Bluegrass Today|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n* February 2019: Terry Eldredge left and former member Jamie Johnson returned for a few months filling the void.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web |date=2019-05-09 |title=Chris Davis to The Grascals |url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/chris-davis-to-the-grascals/ |access-date=2019-05-09 |website=Bluegrass Today |language=en-US}}</ref>\n*May 2019: Chris Davis joined the band on guitar and vocals.<ref name=\":0\" />\n*September 2022: Chris Davis departed the Grascals, 9/24/2022, playing his final show with the band at the LeConte Center, Pigeon Forge, TN<ref name=\":0\" />\n*December 2022: founding member Jamie Johnson returned to the band following an eight-year hiatus.<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Grascals Welcome Back Founding Member, Jamie Johnson, and Look Toward 20th Anniversary |url=https://myemail.constantcontact.com/The-Grascals-Welcome-Back-Founding-Member--Jamie-Johnson--and-Look-Toward-20th-Anniversary.html?soid=1131760830668&aid=AInl0O-kGL0 |access-date=2022-12-15 |website=IVPR |language=en-US}}</ref>\n*January 2023: Jamie Harper joined the Grascals, replacing Adam Haynes on fiddle  [https://bluegrasstoday.com/jamie-harper-to-the-grascals/]\n\n== History ==\n\nThe original concept of the Grascals occurred when the four core members, Terry Eldredge, Jamie Johnson, Jimmy Mattingly, and Dave Talbot, asked Terry Smith and Danny Roberts to join a new group they were wanting to start. They played one of their first shows at the Station Inn in February 2004 with special guest [[Osborne Brothers|Bobby Osborne]]. The Grascals began recording their first album in 2004, which would simply be a self-titled album on [[Rounder Records]]. This album featured such songs as \"Me and John and Paul\" written by [[Harley Allen]], \"[[Where Corn Don't Grow]]\" and another popular cover song, \"Viva Las Vegas,\" which featured Dolly Parton.  During the recording, [[Dolly Parton]] showed interest in wanting to play with the Grascals.  The band soon became Dolly's opening act, as well as her bluegrass band.<ref name=\"bluegrasstoday.com\"/> Performing at [[Dollywood]] and the [[Grand Ole Opry]], the band and Dolly played a cover version of [[Elvis]]'s song, [[Viva Las Vegas (song)|\"Viva Las Vegas.\"]] The [[The grascals (album)|first album]] made it on to the Billboard charts, as well as many country and bluegrass charts. Also on the album cover, Dolly is quoted saying, \"One of the greatest albums I've ever heard.\"<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/the-grascals|title=The Grascals Chart History|magazine=Billboard|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n\n== Notable accomplishments ==\n\n* 2004\u2013present: The Grascals have appeared on the stage of the Grand Ole Opry many times as a band.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.opry.com/artist/grascals|title=The Grascals|date=2013-12-20|website=Grand Ole Opry|language=en|access-date=2019-05-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cybergrass.com/node/1063#sthash.I025AnK5.dpbs|title=2 Cups. 4 Cups. 6 Cups, a Winner \u2013 The Grascals Make 115th Opry Appearance |website=www.cybergrass.com|access-date=2019-05-06}}</ref>\n*April 2, 2006: Performed at the Millennium Stage at the [[John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts]] in Washington, DC. The concert was part of the Center's C''ountry: A Celebration of America's Music'' series.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/the-grascals-to-perform-at-kennedy-center/|title=The Grascals To Perform at Kennedy Center|last=Brance|date=2006-03-31|website=Bluegrass Today|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n*August 2006: The album ''Long List of Heartaches'' was released and won the following 10 International Bluegrass Music Association ([[International Bluegrass Music Awards]]) awards.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ibma.org/recipients-inductees/|title=Recipients & Inductees|website=International Bluegrass Music Awards|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ibma.org/award-recipients/the-grascals/|title=The Grascals|website=International Bluegrass Music Awards|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-03}}</ref>\n\n* 2005 Emerging Artist of the Year \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2005 Song of the Year \"Me and John and Paul\", The Grascals (artists), Harley Allen (songwriter) \n* 2006 Album of the Year \u2013 Celebration of Life: Musicians Against Childhood Cancer (Compilation Project/Various Artists), Skaggs Family Records\n* 2006 Entertainer of the Year \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2007 Entertainer of the Year \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2008 Banjo Performer of the Year \u2013 Kristin Scott Benson\n* 2009 Banjo Performer of the Year \u2013 Kristin Scott Benson\n* 2010 Banjo Performer of the Year \u2013 Kristin Scott Benson\n* 2011 Banjo Performer of the Year (tie) \u2013 Kristin Scott Benson\n*2019 Banjo Performer of the Year \u2013 Kristin Scott Benson\n\n=== Society of the Preservation of Bluegrass Music of America ===\nThe Grascals have also been awarded these 28 awards by the Society for the Preservation of Bluegrass Music of America.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.spbgma.com/archives.html|title=Archives |website=www.spbgma.com|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n\n* 2006 Song of the Year \u2013 ''Me and John and Paul'' by The Grascals for Rounder Records\n* 2006 Bluegrass Album of the Year \u2013 ''The Grascals'' by The Grascals for Rounder Records\n* 2006 Mandolin Performer of the Year \u2013 Danny Roberts\n* 2006 Instrumental Group of the Year \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2007 Instrumental Group of the Year \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2007 Bluegrass Band of the Year (Overall) \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2008 Mandolin Performer of the Year \u2013 Danny Roberts\n* 2008 Instrumental Group of the Year \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2008 Bluegrass Band of the Year (Overall) \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2009 Bluegrass Album of the Year \u2013 ''Keep On Walkin''' by The Grascals for Rounder Records\n* 2009 Banjo Performer of the Year \u2013 Kristin Scott Benson\n* 2009 Instrumental Group of the Year \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2010 Bluegrass Band of the Year (Overall) \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2011 Mandolin Performer of the Year \u2013 Danny Roberts\n* 2011 Banjo Performer of the Year \u2013 Kristin Scott Benson\n* 2011 Instrumental Group of the Year \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2012 Banjo Performer of the Year \u2013 Kristin Scott Benson\n* 2012 Instrumental Group of the Year \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2013 Instrumental Group of the Year \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2014 Mandolin Performer of the Year \u2013 Danny Roberts\n* 2015 Mandolin Performer of the Year \u2013 Danny Roberts\n* 2015 Instrumental Group of the Year \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2016 Mandolin Performer of the Year \u2013 Danny Roberts\n* 2017 Mandolin Performer of the Year \u2013 Danny Roberts (Tie)\n* 2018 Banjo Performer of the Year \u2013 Kristin Scott Benson\n* 2019 Banjo Performer of the Year \u2013 Kristin Scott Benson\n* 2019 Bluegrass Band of the Year (Overall) \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2019 Instrumental Group of the Year \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2022 Bass Performer of the Year \u2013 Terry Smith\n\n=== Grammy Nominations ===\nThe Grascals have received three Grammy Nominations for the following:<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/grascals|title=The Grascals|date=2019-02-15|website=grammy.com|language=en|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n\n* 2005 Best Bluegrass Album \u2013 ''The Grascals'' (Rounder Records)\n* 2006 Best Bluegrass Album \u2013 ''Long List Of Heartaches'' (Rounder Records)\n* 2012 Best Bluegrass Album \u2013 ''Life Finds A Way'' (Mountain Home)\n\n=== style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart in that category.\n|-\n|}\n\n=== Music Videos ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Year\n! style=\"width:20em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 2006\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Me and John and Paul\"\n| Lark Watts\n|-\n| 2010\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Last Train to Clarksville]]\"\n| [[Marcel (singer)|Marcel Chagnon]]\n|-\n| 2011\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Am Strong\" <small>(with [[Dolly Parton]])</small>\n| David Corlew\n|-\n| 2013\n! scope=\"row\"| \"American Pickers\" <small>(with [[Dierks Bentley]])</small>\n| Zack Wilson\n|}\n\n== References ==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n* {{official website|http://grascals.com/}}\n*[https://andrearobertsagency.com/ Andrea Roberts Agency]\n*[https://mountainhomemusiccompany.com/ Mountain Home Music Company]\n*[https://rounder.com/ Rounder Records]\n*[http://www.hankjr.com/ Hank Williams Jr]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Grascals, The}}\n[[Category:American bluegrass music groups]]\n[[Category:Musical groups from Nashville, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 2004]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Joey_Feek","to":"Joey Feek"}],"pages":{"48555626":{"pageid":48555626,"ns":0,"title":"Joey Feek","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country singer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2016}}\n{{Infobox person\n| name               = Joey Feek\n| image              = Joey Feek (cropped).jpg\n| caption            = Feek at the 45th [[Academy of Country Music Awards]] in 2010\n| birth_name         = Joey Marie Martin<ref name=\"ToC Obituary\">{{cite web |first=Laura |last=McClellan |title=Joey Feek's Obituary Made Public |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/joey-feek-obituary/ |publisher=Taste of Country |accessdate=April 6, 2016 |date=March 7, 2016}}</ref>\n| birth_date         = {{birth date|1975|9|9}}<ref name=\"nash\">{{cite journal|date=March 28, 2016|title=Joey Martin Feek: A life well-loved|journal=[[Nash Country Weekly]]|volume=23|issue=13|pages=40\u201345|issn=2379-9137}}</ref>\n| birth_place        = [[Alexandria, Indiana]], U.S.\n| resting_place      = Feek Family Farm Cemetery<br />[[Lewisburg, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| death_date         = {{death date and age|2016|3|4|1975|9|10}}\n| death_place        = Alexandria, Indiana, U.S.\n| occupation         = Singer-songwriter\n| spouse             = [[Rory Feek]] (m. 2002; her death 2016)\n| children           = 1\n| module             = {{Infobox musical artist\n| embed           = yes\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[Christian country music|Christian country]]\n| instrument      = Vocals\n| years_active    = 2008\u20132016\n| past_member_of = [[Joey + Rory]]\n}}\n| website            = {{URL|http://www.thislifeilive.com/}}\n}}\n'''Joey Marie Feek''' ([[n\u00e9e]] '''Martin''', September 9, 1975 \u2013 March 4, 2016) was an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. From 2008 to 2016, the duo [[Joey + Rory]] comprised her and her husband, [[Rory Feek]].<ref name=\"CCM Story\">{{Cite journal|first=Andrew |last=Greer |title=Joey Feek \u2013 'He needs me singing up there' |url=http://www.ccmmagazine.com/features/joey-feek-he-needs-me-singing-up-there/ |journal=[[CCM Magazine]] |accessdate=March 31, 2016 |date=March 31, 2016}}</ref>\n\n==Life and musical career==\nJoey Marie Feek was born Joey Marie Martin on September 9, 1975, in [[Alexandria, Indiana]], to Jack and June Martin. She was the fourth of five children: three sisters (Jody, Julie, Jessie) and one younger brother, Justin, who in 1994 died in a car accident.<ref name=\"nucountry.com.au\">{{cite web|url=http://www.nucountry.com.au/articles/diary/august2009/300809_rory_joey.htm |title=Dave's Diary - 30/8/09 - Rory & Joey |website=Nucountry.com.au |date=August 30, 2009 |accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref> Her father, who played guitar, encouraged her to start singing and performing at an early age. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cx2r54TuwAs |title=YouTube |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date= |accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref> She moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] in 1998 to pursue a career as an assistant at a horse vet clinic, and established connections with [[LeAnn Rimes]]' father Wilbur, and [[Kix Brooks]] of [[Brooks & Dunn]]. At a songwriter night, she met songwriter [[Rory Lee Feek]], whom she married in June 2002.<ref name=\"thislifeilive.com\">{{cite web|url=http://www.thislifeilive.com |title=This Life I Live |publisher=This Life I Live |date= |accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref> She sang backing vocals on [[Blaine Larsen]]'s 2004 album ''[[Off to Join the World]]'', which her husband co-produced.<ref>{{Cite AV media notes |title=[[Off to Join the World]] |others=Blaine Larsen |year=2005 |type=CD insert |publisher=BNA Records |id= 66012}}</ref> Joey was signed to Sony Nashville and recorded an unreleased solo album in 2005 titled ''Strong Enough to Cry'', but due to change in management and restructuring at Sony, the planned major label release for her album was shelved.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nucountry.com.au |title=Welcome to Nu Country TV |website=Nucountry.com.au |date= |accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref><ref name=\"ReferenceA\">{{cite web|url=http://www.thislifeilive.com/the-blog/just-say-yes |title=just say yes \u2014 This Life I Live |website=Thislifeilive.com |date=April 7, 2014 |accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref>  The album, retitled ''If Not For You'', was eventually released by Farmhouse Recordings on April 7, 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/album-review-joey-feeks-if-not-for-you/|title = Album Review: Joey Feek's 'If Not for You'|date = April 7, 2017}}</ref>\n\nIn 2008, a friend suggested that Joey and Rory try out for ''[[Can You Duet]]'', a talent show airing on [[Country Music Television|CMT]] with the purpose of finding the next great country duo. They made an audition tape and came up with the name \"Joey + Rory,\" and finished in third place on ''Can You Duet''. The duo were signed to Sugar Hill/Vanguard Records, who released their first three studio albums.<ref name=\"ReferenceA\"/> The duo released eight albums overall and charted a Top 30 [[Hot Country Songs]] hit with \"[[Cheater, Cheater]]\".<ref name=\"nash\"/>\n\nExpecting a baby in early 2014, the couple decided to spend the year at home.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thislifeilive.com/the-blog/reading-ina-may |title=reading Ina May \u2014 This Life I Live |website=Thislifeilive.com |date=January 24, 2014 |accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref> Their daughter was born in 2014, and has [[Down syndrome]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thislifeilive.com/the-blog/we-were-born-yesterday |title=we were born yesterday \u2014 This Life I Live |website=Thislifeilive.com |date=February 18, 2014 |accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref><ref name=\"ReferenceB\">{{cite web|url=http://www.thislifeilive.com/the-blog/heart-check |title=heart check \u2014 This Life I Live |website=Thislifeilive.com |date=February 21, 2014 |accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref>\n\nA few months later in May 2014, Joey was diagnosed with [[cervical cancer]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/joey-rory-joey-martin-feek-cancer-surgery/|title=Joey Martin Feek Undergoes Surgery After Cancer Diagnosis|work=The Boot|accessdate=November 16, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160229234940/http://theboot.com/joey-rory-joey-martin-feek-cancer-surgery/|archive-date=February 29, 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref> After surgery and treatment, she was declared cancer free and did not receive any radiation or chemotherapy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thislifeilive.com/the-blog/home-of-the-brave-joey-courage-and-cancer |title=home of the brave - Joey, courage and cancer \u2014 This Life I Live |website=Thislifeilive.com |date=June 25, 2014 |accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref>\n\n==Cancer relapse==\nIn June 2015, after the family had finished filming their movie ''Josephine'',<ref name=\"ReferenceC\">{{cite web|url=http://www.thislifeilive.com/the-blog/a-prayer-for-cancer |title=a prayer for cancer \u2014 This Life I Live |website=Thislifeilive.com |date=June 14, 2015 |accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref> Feek was not feeling well again and sought medical advice.<ref name=\"ReferenceC\"/> After undergoing further medical testing, it was discovered that the cervical cancer had returned and metastasized to her colon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countryweekly.com/news/joey-rorys-joey-martin-feek-battling-stage-iv-cancer|title=Joey + Rory's Joey Martin Feek Battling Stage IV Cancer|work=Nash Country Weekly|accessdate=November 16, 2015}}</ref> In July 2015, Feek underwent a second surgery to remove a 3-inch tumor (recurrence of cervical cancer) that had invaded her colon and surrounding structures. The surgery was long and involved and required the use of inter-operative radiation as there were tumors the surgeon could not get clear margins on.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thislifeilive.com/the-blog/stage-four-love |title=stage 4 love \u2014 This Life I Live |website=Thislifeilive.com |date= |accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref> Still, the medical team was hopeful for Feek's situation, and she recovered from surgery to continue on to endure an intense round of radiation and chemotherapy in the summer of 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thislifeilive.com/the-blog/ring-the-bell |title=ring the bell \u2014 This Life I Live |website=Thislifeilive.com |date=October 3, 2015 |accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref> While undergoing treatment at Cancer Treatment Centers of America, she would record hymns in their hotel room for the last CD the couple would create together, ''[[Hymns That Are Important to Us]]''.<ref name=\"thislifeilive1\">{{cite web|url=http://www.thislifeilive.com/the-blog/a-song-to-sing |title=a song to sing \u2014 This Life I Live |website=Thislifeilive.com |date=August 31, 2015 |accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref>\n\nIn October 2015, Rory revealed in a blog post that Joey's cancer was [[Terminal illness|terminal]], and they were stopping all treatment as the chemotherapy and radiation she had suffered through for the last few months were not working. The MRI \"scans revealed that two quarter-sized tumors had already grown back in the same area that they had been blasting daily with chemo and radiation [and] that many more smaller tumors were visible all throughout the abdominal region. She said that the cancer was aggressively spreading\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thislifeilive.com/the-blog/enough |title=enough \u2014 This Life I Live |website=Thislifeilive.com |date=October 23, 2015 |accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref> There were no more treatment options available and all there was left to do was keep Joey as comfortable as possible for the time she had left.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/joey-and-rory-joey-feek-stops-cancer-treatment|title=Joey + Rory's Joey Feek Stops Cancer Treatment|work=The Boot|date=October 23, 2015 |accessdate=November 16, 2015}}</ref>\n\nBy November 2015, Feek was in [[hospice]] care.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thislifeilive.com|title=This Life I Live|accessdate=November 16, 2015}}</ref> In January 2016, her [[morphine]] dose needed to keep the cancer pain under control had quadrupled.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/music/celebrity/-rory-says-joey-feek-is-ready-to-come-home-to-god-in-emotional-post/ar-CCk3TP?li=BBnb7Kz |title=One Last Kiss: Rory Says Joey Feek Is 'Ready to Come Home' to God in Emotional Post |website=Msn.com |date=January 9, 2016 |accessdate=February 18, 2016}}</ref> She was able to celebrate Indiana's second birthday and Valentine's Day with her and Rory, see them receive a Grammy nomination for the song \"If I Needed You\",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thislifeilive.com/the-blog/the-power-of-the-plus-sign |title=the power of the plus-sign \u2014 This Life I Live |website=Thislifeilive.com |date=January 28, 2016 |accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref> and see and hear the final recording the duo would make together, an album of hymns that she had always wanted to make that debuted at number 8 on the Billboard 200 when it was released, and peaked at number 4 on the Billboard 200 three weeks after its release.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/304865/joey-rory/chart |title=Joey + Rory - Chart history |publisher=Billboard |date= |accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref><ref name=\"thislifeilive1\"/> She died on March 4, 2016, and Rory held a private funeral on their farm in Tennessee; Joey was buried in the family cemetery on the Feek farm.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wthr.com/story/31389161/indiana-musician-joey-feek-dies-after-long-cancer-fight|title=Indiana musician Joey Feek dies after long cancer fight|author=WTHR Channel 13|date=March 4, 2016|work=wthr.com|accessdate=March 5, 2016|archive-date=March 6, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306100851/http://www.wthr.com/story/31389161/indiana-musician-joey-feek-dies-after-long-cancer-fight|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/714632/joey-feek-dead-at-40-joey-rory-country-singer-remembered-as-loving-mom-after-battling-cervical-cancer|title=Joey Feek Dead at 40: Joey + Rory Country Singer Remembered as Loving Mom After Battling Cervical Cancer|date=March 4, 2016|work=E! Online|accessdate=March 5, 2016}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{see also|Joey + Rory#Discography}}\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! scope=\"row\"| ''If Not For You''\n| \n* Release date: April 7, 2017\n* Label: Farmhouse Recordings\n* Formats: [[Compact disc|CD]], [[music download]]\n| 6\n| 50\n|\n*US: 69,000<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.roughstock.com/news/2018/09/43378-top-10-country-albums-sales-chart-september-24-2018 |title=Top 10 Country Albums Sales Chart: September 24, 2018 |first= Matt |last= Bjorke |date= September 24, 2018 |work=Roughstock |accessdate=September 27, 2018}}</ref>\n|-\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist|colwidth=30em}}\n\n{{Joey + Rory}}\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Feek, Joey}}\n[[Category:1975 births]]\n[[Category:2016 deaths]]\n[[Category:Deaths from cancer in Indiana]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Indiana]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Deaths from cervical cancer in the United States]]\n[[Category:Grammy Award winners]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Indiana]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Roger_Springer","to":"Roger Springer"}],"pages":{"21488342":{"pageid":21488342,"ns":0,"title":"Roger Springer","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name                = Roger Springer\n| image                 = \n| image_size            = \n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          = {{birth date and age|1962|6|15}}\n| origin              = [[Caddo, Oklahoma]], US\n| instrument          = Vocals, guitar\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = 1992\u2013present\n| label               = [[MCA Nashville]]<br />[[Giant Records (Warner Bros. subsidiary label)|Giant]]\n| associated_acts     = [[Mark Chesnutt]]\n| website                 = \n}}\n\n'''Roger Springer''' (born June 15, 1962, in [[Caddo, Oklahoma]]) is an American [[country music]] artist. Springer's only single as a solo artist, \"The Right One Left,\" was released in 1992 on [[MCA Nashville]] and peaked at No.&nbsp;69 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs|Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] chart.\n\nIn 1998, Springer formed the country music trio '''Springer!''' with Shara Johnson and Joe Manuel.<ref name=\"business\">[http://www.allbusiness.com/retail-trade/miscellaneous-retail-retail-stores-not/4627561-1.html Popular Uprisings: Billboard's Weekly Coverage Of Hot Prospects For The Heatseekers Chart]</ref> Their first single, \"Don't Try to Find Me,\" peaked at No.&nbsp;64 on the Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart.<ref>[{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r424068/charts-awards|pure_url=yes}} allmusic ((( The Roger Springer Band > Charts & Awards > Billboard Singles )))]</ref> A second single, \"Ain't Nothing but a Cloud,\" was released in 1999 but failed to chart. Renamed '''The Roger Springer Band''', [[Giant Records (Warner Bros. subsidiary label)|Giant]] released the trio's eponymous debut album in July 1999 shortly before they disbanded.\n\nAs a songwriter, Springer has co-written single releases by [[Mark Chesnutt]] (\"I Might Even Quit Lovin' You,\" \"[[It's a Little Too Late (Mark Chesnutt song)|It's a Little Too Late]],\" \"Let It Rain,\" \"Thank God for Believers\"), [[Sammy Kershaw]] (\"Matches\")<ref name=\"business\" /><ref>[{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p317853/songs/songs-composed-by|pure_url=yes}} allmusic ((( Roger Springer > Songs > Songs Composed By )))]</ref> and [[Love and Theft (band)|Love and Theft]] (\"[[Dancing in Circles]]\").\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:14em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Album details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''The Roger Springer Band''\n| \n* Release date: July 20, 1999\n* Label: [[Giant Records (Warner)|Giant Records]]\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:14em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"2\"| Peak chart<br />positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[RPM (magazine)|CAN Country]]\n|-\n| 1992\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Right One Left\"\n| 69\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| single only\n|-\n| 1998\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Don't Try to Find Me\"\n| 64\n| 92\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"2\"| ''The Roger Springer Band''\n|-\n| 1999\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Ain't Nothing but a Cloud\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"5\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Video\n|-\n| 1992\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Right One Left\"\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p317853|pure_url=yes}} allmusic ((( Roger Springer > Overview )))]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Springer, Roger}}\n[[Category:1962 births]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Giant Records (Warner) artists]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:MCA Records artists]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jerry_Salley","to":"Jerry Salley"}],"pages":{"17481635":{"pageid":17481635,"ns":0,"title":"Jerry Salley","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{BLP sources|date=September 2010}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Jerry Salley\n| image           =\n| caption         = Jerry Salley's promotional photo.\n| origin          = United States\n| instrument      = Guitar<br />vocals\n| genre           = [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]]<br />[[country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter<br />musician\n| years_active    = 1982\u2013present\n| label           = Banner Music Publishing, [[Mountain Home Records|Mountain Home]]\n| website         = {{URL|www.jerrysalley.com}}\n| associated_acts = [[Carl Jackson]], [[Larry Cordle]]\n}}\n'''Jerry Salley''' is an American [[country music|country]] and [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] singer-songwriter. Salley won SESAC's 2003 \"Country Music Songwriter of the Year\" award.\n\nSalley has been writing and singing in Nashville, Tennessee since 1982. To date, he has had 300 songs recorded in his career, including by [[Reba McEntire]] (\"[[I'm Gonna Take That Mountain]]\"), [[Wild Rose (band)|Wild Rose]] (\"[[Breaking New Ground (song)|Breaking New Ground]]\"), [[John Anderson (musician)|John Anderson]] (\"[[I Fell in the Water]]\"), [[Wade Hayes]] (\"[[How Do You Sleep at Night]]\"), and ten (10) top twenty gospel songs.\n\n==Biography==\nSalley has had songs recorded by Toby Keith, Patty Loveless, Brad Paisley, Joe Nichols, Darryl Worley, The Whites, Loretta Lynn, and many others.\n\nSalley is a six-time Dove Award nominee, and won a Dove award in 1990 for Inspirational Song of the Year. He won the award for co-writing \"His Strength is Perfect\", with Steven Curtis Chapman.\n\nNumerous other nationally known country, gospel and bluegrass artists have also recorded Jerry's songs, including: IIIrd Tyme Out, The Seldom Scene, Mountain Heart, Lonesome River Band, [[Dale Ann Bradley]], [[Jeff & Sheri Easter]], The Isaacs, Bradley Walker, Newfound Road, Wildfire, Terri Gibbs, Kyle Petty, Barbara Fairchild, The Kingsmen, The Florida Boys, The Martins, Don Rigsby, Rock Country, David Peterson & 1946, Jake Hess, Lordsong, The Ruppes, Rebecca Lynn Howard, Melba Montgomery, Gary Stewart, Shenandoah, and Vern Jackson.\n\nAs an artist, Salley has performed on numerous stage shows, including the [[Grand Ole Opry]]. He has also appeared on [[Late Show with David Letterman]], [[Regis and Kathie Lee]], [[Today (NBC program)|Today Show]], and several shows on the former [[Spike (TV channel)|TNN]] network.\n\nIn addition to his Dove recognition from the Gospel Music Association, Jerry has received numerous awards from different associations for his songwriting accomplishments, from the IBMA, NSAI, SESAC, and Gospel Voice Magazine. Along with friends Carl Jackson and Larry Cordle, the trio (Cordle, Jackson & Salley) recorded the song \"You\u2019re Running Wild\" on the Louvin Brothers Tribute on Universal South Records, which features numerous country music stars singing songs made famous by the legendary duo. Entitled ''[[Livin', Lovin', Losin': Songs of the Louvin Brothers]]'', this project won the 2004 Grammy for Country Album of the Year. The trio tours across the country and performs the hits they wrote for others. Working on another project with Carl Jackson, Salley co-wrote \"Indian Crow\" for the critically acclaimed [[Mark Twain: Words & Music]] project.\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n*http://www.sesac.com/News/News_Details.aspx?id=1104\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Salley, Jerry}}\n[[Category:American country guitarists]]\n[[Category:American male guitarists]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Megan_Mullins","to":"Megan Mullins"}],"pages":{"14690232":{"pageid":14690232,"ns":0,"title":"Megan Mullins","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name              = Megan Mullins\n| image             = Megan Mullins 2007.jpg\n| caption           = Mullins performing at the [[Grand Ole Opry]] in 2007\n| image_size        = \n| background        = solo_singer\n| birth_name        = \n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1987|11|24}}\n| birth_place       = [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]], U.S.\n| instrument        = Vocals, [[fiddle]], [[mandolin]], guitar\n| genre             = [[country music|Country]]\n| occupation        = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active      = 2006\u2013present\n| label             = [[Broken Bow Records|Broken Bow]], Stoney Creek\n}}\n\n'''Megan Mullins''' (born November 24, 1987)<ref name=\"allmusic\" /> is an American [[country music]] singer, songwriter, and multi-instrumentalist. At age 18, she made her debut on the country music scene with the single \"Ain't What It Used to Be,\" a Top 40 hit on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. Her debut album was originally slated for release in 2006 but was never released.<ref name=\"fort\">{{cite news|url=http://www.journalgazette.net/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071005/ENT02/710050387 |title=Singing a Broken record |accessdate=December 13, 2007 |last=Penhollow |first=Steve |date=October 5, 2007 |newspaper=[[Fort Wayne Journal-Gazette]]}}</ref>\n\n==Biography==\nMullins was born in [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]].<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/megan-mullins-mn0001521468 | title=Megan Mullins Songs, Albums, Reviews, Bio & More | website=[[AllMusic]] }}</ref> She began to learn several instruments at an early age, and by age 3, she had won the Indiana State Fair Showmanship award at the State Fiddle Championship.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Many of her family members are also professional musicians, most notably her brother Marcus, with whom she performed on the [[Grand Ole Opry]] at age 14.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nBy 2006, she was signed to [[Broken Bow Records]], an independent record label. Her first single, titled \"Ain't What It Used to Be\" (also recorded by [[Billy Currington]] on his debut album) was issued early that year, reaching a peak of No.&nbsp;32 on the country music charts. A second single, \"Cryin' Days,\" failed to chart at all, and Mullins announced in October 2007 that she would be returning to the studio for further work on the album.<ref name=\"fort\"/>\n\nAlthough the album has not been released, Mullins remained on Broken Bow's roster. In 2008, Mullins recorded a duet with former [[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]] lead singer [[Randy Owen]] (who is also signed to Broken Bow), for his solo debut album ''[[One on One (Randy Owen album)|One on One]]''. Mullins also plays fiddle in Owen's road band.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/concertreview.asp?xid=327 |title=Randy Owen leaves Alabama behind |accessdate=December 2, 2008 |last=Remz |first=Jeffrey B. |date=August 3, 2008|work=[[Country Standard Time]]}}</ref> In April 2009, she switched to Stoney Creek, a sister label also started by the founder of Broken Bow. Her first release for Stoney Creek, \"Long Past Gone\", made its chart debut in May 2009, and peaked at No.&nbsp;48 later in the year. A second single for the label, \"Tradin' My Halo for Horns,\" failed to chart. In August 2010, Mullins and Stoney Creek parted ways.\n\n==Discography==\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Single\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"60\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n|-\n| 2006\n| align=\"left\"| \"Ain't What It Used to Be\"\n| 32\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"2\"| ''Megan Mullins'' <small>(unreleased)</small>\n|-\n| 2007\n| align=\"left\"| \"Cryin' Days\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2009\n| align=\"left\"| \"Long Past Gone\"\n| 48\n| rowspan=\"2\" {{n/a}}\n|-\n| align=\"left\"| \"Tradin' My Halo for Horns\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that failed to chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Guest singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Year\n! Single\n! Artist\n! Album\n|-\n| 2009\n| align=\"left\"| \"Holding Everything\"\n| [[Randy Owen]]\n| align=\"left\"| ''[[One on One (Randy Owen album)|One on One]]''\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Year\n! Single\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Steel_Woods","to":"The Steel Woods"}],"pages":{"55290108":{"pageid":55290108,"ns":0,"title":"The Steel Woods","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country music group}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = The Steel Woods\n| image            = Main Photo - Shot by @colecreasy.jpg\n| landscape        = yes\n| alt              = \n| caption          = Wes Bayliss, Tyler Powers and Johnny Stanton\n| alias            = \n| origin           = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], United States\n| genre            = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[southern rock]]|[[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]]|[[Americana (music)|Americana]]}}\n| years_active     = 2016\u2013present\n| label            = {{hlist|Woods Music|[[Thirty Tigers]]}}\n| associated_acts  = {{flatlist|\n*[[Jamey Johnson]], [[Brent Cobb]]\n}}\n| website          = {{URL|http://thesteelwoods.com}}\n| current_members  = Wes Bayliss<br/>Johnny Stanton<br/>Tyler Powers<br/>\n| past_members     = Jason \"Rowdy\" Cope<br/>Jay Tooke\n}}\n'''The Steel Woods''' are an American [[country music]] group.<ref name=\":0\">{{Citation |date=May 9, 2017 |title=10 New Country Artists You Need to Know: May 2017 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/lists/10-new-country-artists-you-need-to-know-may-2017-w481172/steel-woods-w481175 |access-date=September 19, 2017 }}</ref> from [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref>{{Citation |last=Stroud |first=Scott |date=June 1, 2017 |title=Review: The Steel Woods honor southern rock tradition |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |url=http://www.news-sentinel.com/20170601/review-the-steel-woods-honor-southern-rock-tradition&profile=1042M |access-date= September 19, 2017}}</ref> Their debut album, ''Straw in the Wind'', was released in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kmuw.org/post/steel-woods-plead-civility-old-news|title=The Steel Woods Plead For Civility With 'Old News'|last=Beaudoin|first=Jedd|website=www.kmuw.org|date=19 June 2019 |language=en|access-date=2020-04-16}}</ref>\n\nThe band has cited influences such as [[Willie Nelson]], [[Waylon Jennings]] and [[Led Zeppelin]],<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/artist-to-watch-the-steel-woods/|title=Band to Watch: The Steel Woods, One of Southern Rock's New Revivalists|last=Burchard|first=Jeremy|date=2017-05-17|website=Wide Open Country|language=en-US|access-date=2020-04-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.popmatters.com/the-steel-woods-straw-in-the-wind-2495386212.html|title=The Steel Woods: Straw in the Wind|date=2017-07-19|website=PopMatters|language=en|access-date=2020-04-16}}</ref> and have toured [[Opening act|in support]] of artists such as [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]], [[Dwight Yoakam]], [[Jamey Johnson]], [[Cody Jinks]], [[Miranda Lambert]], and [[Blackberry Smoke]].<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web|url=https://bozone.com/interview-steel-woods-live-divide-eagles-bozeman-june-2019/|title=Interview: Steel Woods @ Live Divide/Eagles Bozeman \u2013 June 2019|date=2019-06-14|website=The BoZone|language=en-US|access-date=2020-04-16}}</ref>\n\nFounding member and guitarist Jason \"Rowdy\" Cope died on January 16, 2021.<ref name=\"Hudak\">{{Cite magazine |last=Hudak |first=Joseph |date=2021-05-20 |title=The Metalhead Who Played Country Guitar |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/jason-rowdy-cope-steel-woods-all-of-your-stones-1172058/ |access-date=2022-09-10 |magazine=Rolling Stone |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n== History ==\nThe Steel Woods were cofounded by Wes Bayliss and Jason \"Rowdy\" Cope. Cope was the creative lead of the band as well as its [[lead guitar]]ist, songwriter and co-producer, while Bayliss is a multi-instrumentalist, lead singer and co-producer.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2019-02-04 |title=Hotstar: The Steel Woods Build A Career Show By Show - Pollstar News |url=https://news.pollstar.com/2019/02/04/hotstar-the-steel-woods-build-a-career-show-by-show/ |access-date=2022-09-12 |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nBayliss grew up in [[Woodland, Alabama]], playing music in his family's gospel band and learned to play harmonica, mandolin, and guitar. In 2007, he moved to [[Mobile, Alabama]], where he experimented further on different instruments. Cope began to learn guitar at the age of 11 in his hometown of [[Asheville, North Carolina]]. He later worked as a [[Los Angeles]]-based musician before moving to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] in 2007 and joined [[Jamey Johnson]]'s band. In his nine years with Johnson, Cope co-wrote \"Can't Cash My Checks\" and helped Johnson make the [[Grammy Award|Grammy]]-nominated \"[[That Lonesome Song]]\" (2008) and \"[[The Guitar Song]]\" (2010).<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.pisgahbrewing.com/shows/the-steel-woods/|title=The Steel Woods|last=Pisgah|first=Brewing|date=July 29, 2019|website=Pisgah Brewing|access-date=April 16, 2020|archive-date=April 8, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170408015228/http://www.pisgahbrewing.com/shows/the-steel-woods/|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nIn the early days of The Steel Woods, Bayliss and Cope spent a lot of time fishing and writing what would eventually evolve into the bands first studio album, ''Straw in the Wind'' (2017) released on [[Thirty Tigers]]/Woods Music. The album featured a guest vocal appearance by [[Lindi Ortega]], and [[Brent Cobb]] also contributed as a songwriter. On June 10, 2017, it reached number 42 on the [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] Independent Albums chart.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/independent-albums/2017-06-09|title=Independent Albums Chart|magazine=Billboard|access-date=2020-04-16}}</ref>\n\nIn the subsequent years, the band toured with fellow [[Southern rock]] artists [[Cody Johnson]], [[Cody Jinks]], [[Whiskey Myers]], and [[Blackberry Smoke]] as well as inspirations such as [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]] and [[Miranda Lambert]].<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite web |title=The Steel Woods \u2013 MoxieTalk with Kirt Jacobs |url=https://moxietalk.com/episodes/thesteelwoods/ |access-date=2020-04-16 |website=MoxieTalk |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nThey recorded their second album, ''Old News'', in [[Asheville, North Carolina|Asheville]] at the site of an old church during a break in their touring schedule. The album was released on January 18, 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://glidemagazine.com/218932/southern-rockers-the-steel-woods-take-a-big-leap-forward-with-riveting-old-news-album-review/ | title=Southern Rockers The Steel Woods Take a Big Leap Forward|website=glidemagazine.com| date=17 January 2019|access-date=2020-04-16}}</ref>\n\nCope died in January 2021.<ref name=\"Hudak\"/> The band's third album, ''All of Your Stones'', was released in May 2021.<ref name=\"ASAOYS\">{{cite web|url=https://americansongwriter.com/review-the-steel-woods-new-album-is-sadly-a-final-testament-to-its-late-co-founder/|title=Review: The Steel Woods' New Album Is Sadly A Final Testament To {{sic|I|t's|nolink=y}} Late Co-Founder|work=[[American Songwriter]]|last=Horowitz|first=Hal|date=May 12, 2021|access-date=May 14, 2021}}</ref>\n\nOn March 28, 2024, Wes Bayliss announced that after the completion of a final United States tour throughout 2024, The Steel Woods would disband, citing personal reasons to end the band and cancelling a scheduled autumn 2024 UK and European tour with fellow Southern rockers [[Blackberry Smoke]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Steel Woods Announce They\u2019ll Stop Touring At The End Of 2024 |url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/music/news/the-steel-woods-announce-they-ll-stop-touring-at-the-end-of-2024/ar-BB1kH9nY |access-date=2024-03-29 |website=www.msn.com}}</ref>\n\n==Personnel ==\n* Wes Bayliss \u2013 guitar and vocals\n* Jason Cope \u2013 guitar (d. 2021) \n* Johnny Stanton \u2013 bassist\n* Tyler Powers \u2013 guitar\n* Isaac Senty - drummer\n\n==Discography==\n'''Albums'''\n*''Straw in the Wind'' (2017)\n*''Old News'' (2019)\n*''All of Your Stones'' (2021)<ref name=\"ASAOYS\"/>\n*On Your Time (2023)\n\n==See also==\n* [[List of country music performers]]\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [https://open.spotify.com/artist/69B1gu9EjC0rNb59YYNVPM Spotify]\n* [https://itunes.apple.com/us/artist/the-steel-woods/1073094331?ign-gact=3&ls=1 Apple Music] \n* [https://www.pandora.com/station/play/4477864228065669439 Pandora]\n* [https://play.google.com/music/listen#/wst/artist/A46com75qthwwdnm4wr2arjlvci Google Play Music]\n* {{Discogs artist|The Steel Woods}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Steel Woods, The}}\n[[Category:American country rock groups]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 2016]]\n[[Category:2016 establishments in Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Musical groups from Nashville, Tennessee]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Gloriana_(band)","to":"Gloriana (band)"}],"pages":{"21267479":{"pageid":21267479,"ns":0,"title":"Gloriana (band)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country music band}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Gloriana\n| image           = Gloriana band.jpg\n| caption         = Gloriana at [[Walmart Soundcheck]], August 2012. L-R: Rachel Reinert, Tom Gossin, Mike Gossin\n| alt = Country music band Gloriana performing in concert.\n| landscape       = yes\n| image_size      =\n| origin          = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| years_active    = 2008\u20132017\n| label           = {{Plainlist|\n* Emblem\n* [[Reprise Records|Reprise Nashville]]\n* [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros. Nashville]]\n}}\n| website         = {{URL|http://www.gloriana.com}}\n| past_members    = {{Plainlist|\n* [[Cheyenne Kimball]]\n* [[Rachel Reinert]]\n* Mike Gossin\n* Tom Gossin\n}}\n}}\n'''Gloriana''' was an American [[country music]] group founded in 2008 by [[Cheyenne Kimball]] (vocals, [[mandolin]]), [[Rachel Reinert]] (vocals), and brothers Tom Gossin (vocals, guitar) and Mike Gossin (vocals, guitar). Prior to the group's foundation, Kimball recorded as a solo artist. The original lineup recorded one [[Gloriana (album)|self-titled album]] for Emblem/[[Reprise Records]] in 2009, which included their first chart hit, \"[[Wild at Heart (Gloriana song)|Wild at Heart]]\". Kimball left before the release of the band's second album ''[[A Thousand Miles Left Behind]]'', which produced their highest-charting single, \"[[(Kissed You) Good Night]]\", along with the top 20 \"[[Can't Shake You]]\". After a third album, ''[[Three (Gloriana album)|Three]]'', Reinert left as well, effectively disbanding the group.\n\n==History==\nBrothers Tom and Mike Gossin were born in [[Utica, New York]].<ref name=\"cmt\"/> They both took [[classical piano]] lessons from age 5.  At 10, Tom began studying jazz with a local [[jazz music|jazz]] musician and at 12, he began to play the guitar. Tom, along with third Gossin brother Stephen, founded their own band \"Oblique\" in high school. Stephen and Tom later moved to [[Wilmington, North Carolina]] together, where they attended [[University of North Carolina at Wilmington]], with Tom majoring in guitar. After a professor suggested that he pursue songwriting and performing, Tom dropped out of the university and started playing music and selling independent records at gigs he played.  Mike learned drums at age 8 and, like Tom, started playing guitar at 12.  He moved to Wilmington after high school to join Tom there.  He joined a group with Tom and Stephen during which time they filmed a reality series that did not last long. Tom and Mike moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], where they began performing as a duo.<ref name=\"cmt\">{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/gloriana/bio.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307034708/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/gloriana/bio.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 7, 2009|title=Gloriana biography|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]|access-date=2009-04-07}}</ref><ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p1110916/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Gloriana biography|last=Leggett|first=Steve|work=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=2009-06-15}}</ref>\n\n[[Rachel Reinert]] was born in [[Sarasota, Florida]], and lived in [[Marietta, Georgia]] before moving to [[Santa Ana, California]] with her family at age 6. She attended the [[Orange County School of the Arts]], a charter performing arts school, where she studied musical theatre from 7th to 10th grade. She started playing the guitar and turning her poetry into songs at age 14.  With a teacher's help, she began recording [[demo (music)|demos]], and was signed to a publishing deal out of Nashville at age 15.<ref name=\"cmt\"/> She graduated high school through independent study and moved to Nashville when she turned 16, and was working on her songwriting skills when she met the Gossins, who found her through her [[MySpace]] page.<ref name=\"cmt\"/>\n\nThe group's fourth and final member, [[Cheyenne Kimball]], was born in [[Jacksonville, North Carolina]] but raised in [[Frisco, Texas]]. A performer by age 10, she entered the television talent show ''[[America's Most Talented Kid]]'', and won the show's top honor at age 12.<ref name=\"cmt\"/>  One year after her win, Kimball recorded a solo album on [[Epic Records]]. This album included songs that she had written with [[John Rich]] of [[Big & Rich]], whom she met after a trip to Nashville. When Cheyenne was in her late teens she had a reality show on MTV that lasted one season. She joined the Gossin brothers and Reinert after meeting them in a nightclub, and the four members began writing songs and performing together.<ref name=\"cmt\"/>\n\n===2008\u20132010: ''Gloriana''===\n[[File:US_Navy_101105-N-7524O-001_Cheyenne_Kimball,_a_performer_with_the_country_music_band,_Gloriana,_performs_in_the_hangar_bay_of_the_aircraft_carrier.jpg|thumb|left|[[Cheyenne Kimball]], pictured here in 2010, was a vocalist and mandolinist in the group for their first album.|alt=Musician Cheyenne Kimball playing a mandolin.]]\nOnce the four members of Gloriana were in place, they began recording demos, and sent one to Emblem Records, a label owned by [[Matt Serletic]], a [[record producer]] who has worked with [[Matchbox 20]].<ref name=\"cmt\"/> The four members worked with Serletic, and Nashville songwriters such as [[Jeffrey Steele]], [[Brett James]] and [[Wayne Kirkpatrick]], among others.<ref name=\"cmt\"/> By February the group had signed with the label but had not yet come up with a name.\n\nIn early 2009, the group released its debut single \"[[Wild at Heart (Gloriana song)|Wild at Heart]]\", which Serletic wrote with [[Josh Kear]] and [[Stephanie Bentley]], another former Epic artist.<ref name=\"musicrow\">{{cite web |url=http://www.musicrow.com/2009/01/gloriana/ |title=Gloriana |access-date=2009-01-26 |last=Ross |first=David M. |date=2009-01-14 |work=Music Row}}</ref> It became the highest-selling country music debut single of 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=3116|title=Gloriana debut available for listening today|date=2009-07-29|work=[[Country Standard Time]]|access-date=2009-08-01}}</ref> The group also signed to [[Taylor Swift]]'s 2009-2010 [[Fearless tour]]. In May 2009, Gloriana released a four-song digital [[extended play|EP]], comprising \"Wild at Heart\" and three other songs from the album. On August 4, 2009, the band released its [[Gloriana (album)|self-titled]] debut, which peaked at No.&nbsp;2 on [[Top Country Albums]] and No.&nbsp;3 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], shortly before \"Wild at Heart\" peaked at No.&nbsp;15. The album's second single, \"[[How Far Do You Wanna Go?]]\", was released in September. The band won the [[American Music Award]]'s Breakthrough Artist of the Year in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.gactv.com/blog/2009/12/21/gloriana-attributes-breakthrough-to-fans/|title=Gloriana attributes breakthrough to fans|last=Roland|first=Tom|date=2009-12-21|work=[[Great American Country]]|access-date=2010-01-27}}</ref> It was announced on March 16, 2010 that the group had won the 2010 Academy of Country Music's Top New Vocal Group award. On August 18, 2010, \"Wild at Heart\" was certified Gold by the RIAA.\n\nA third single, \"[[The World Is Ours Tonight]],\" debuted in early 2010. It was included on a March 2010 reissue of the band's debut album.\n\n===2011\u20132013: ''A Thousand Miles Left Behind''===\nIn early 2011, the group announced the release of a new single, \"[[Wanna Take You Home]]\", which acted as the lead-off single to their second studio album, ''[[A Thousand Miles Left Behind]]''. \"Wanna Take You Home\" was released to country radio on 28 March 2011,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allaccess.com/country/future-releases|title=Future Releases for Country Radio Stations|publisher=All Access|access-date=February 23, 2011}}</ref> and went on to become the group's fourth Top 40 hit. On 11 July 2011, Gloriana announced the departure of Cheyenne Kimball.<ref name=\"trio\">{{cite magazine |url=http://www.countryweekly.com/news/gloriana-s-cheyenne-kimball-exits-band |title=Gloriana's Cheyenne Kimball Exits Band |magazine=[[Country Weekly]] |access-date=July 11, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714055602/http://www.countryweekly.com/news/gloriana-s-cheyenne-kimball-exits-band |archive-date=July 14, 2011 }}</ref> The band found out about Kimball's plan to leave via Twitter.  They continued working on their second album without Kimball,<ref>Giles, Jeff. \"Gloriana Describes the 'Evolving Process' Behind Their New Album, 'A Thousand Miles Left Behind'.\" CMT. September 25, 2011. Web. Retrieved 2012-04-18</ref> although she still appears in the \"Wanna Take You Home\" music video. The song's music video, directed by [[TK McKamy]], was shot over the course of several days at a private residence outside of Nashville.<ref name=trio/>\n\nOn October 4, 2011, Gloriana released their second single from the album, \"[[(Kissed You) Good Night]],\" on their official website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gloriana.com/news/501a2c-our-new-single-is/|title=(Kissed You) Good Night|publisher=All Access|access-date=October 4, 2011}}</ref> On 13 January 2012, the music video for \"(Kissed You) Good Night\" premiered on [[Freeform (TV channel)|ABC Family]].<ref>Gloriana. \"'[http://www.gloriana.com/news/kissed-you-good-night-first-look/ (Kissed You) Good Night' First Look!]\" Gloriana. Retrieved: 2012-04-18.</ref> On May 20, 2012, the band performed their single \"(Kissed You) Good Night\" on the television show ''[[The Bachelorette (American TV series)|The Bachelorette]]''. On 31 July 2012, the album was released On September 10, 2012, the album's third single, \"[[Can't Shake You]]\", was released. The single was featured on the season 2 finale of [[The CW]]'s [[Hart of Dixie]] with the band guest starring as themselves.\n\n===2014\u20132017: ''Three''===\nThe group released a new single, \"Best Night Ever,\" in February 2014, and it went on to be a minor Top 40 hit on the ''Billboard'' Country Airplay chart. It was followed later in the year by \"[[Trouble (Gloriana song)|Trouble]],\" which reached a peak of number 24 on the ''Billboard'' Country Airplay chart and served as the lead-off single to Gloriana's third studio album, ''[[Three (Gloriana album)|Three]]'', which was released on June 2, 2015. The album produced no other singles, and in January 2016, Reinert announced her departure from the band.<ref>{{cite web|author=Billy Dukes |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/rachel-reinert-leaves-gloriana/ |title=Rachel Reinert Leaves Gloriana |website=Tasteofcountry.com |date=7 January 2016 |access-date=2020-04-24}}</ref>\n\nTom Gossin began touring as a solo artist in 2017.<ref>{{cite web |author=Shannon McCabe |url=http://www.encorepub.com/long-road-home-singer-songwriter-tom-gossin-puts-down-roots-in-wilmington/ |title=LONG ROAD HOME: Singer-songwriter Tom Gossin puts down roots in Wilmington \u2013 ILM's Alternative Weekly Voice |website=Encorepub.com |date=2017-04-04 |access-date=2020-04-24 |archive-date=2017-11-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171114042338/http://www.encorepub.com/long-road-home-singer-songwriter-tom-gossin-puts-down-roots-in-wilmington/ |url-status=dead }}</ref> In mid-2018, Reinert released the solo single \"Cool\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/rachel-reinert-cool-interview/|title=HEAR FORMER GLORIANA SINGER RACHEL REINERT'S FIRST SOLO EFFORT, 'COOL' [EXCLUSIVE PREMIERE]|last=Dukes|first=Billy|date=July 25, 2018|work=Taste of Country|access-date=July 28, 2018}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Year\n! Association\n! Category\n! Result\n|-\n| rowspan=\"4\"|2009\n| rowspan=\"3\"|[[CMT Music Awards]]\n| Group Video of the Year \u2014 \"Wild at Heart\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/cmt-music-awards/nominees.jhtml|title=CMT : CMT Music Awards : June 10, 8/7c : Vote : Voting, Nominations, Performers and More|access-date=14 December 2015|archive-date=31 March 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331195757/http://www.cmt.com/cmt-music-awards/nominees.jhtml|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| USA Weekend Breakthrough Video of the Year \u2014 \"Wild at Heart\"\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Nationwide On Your Side Award\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| [[American Music Awards]]\n| Breakthrough Artist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| rowspan=4|2010\n| rowspan=2|[[Academy of Country Music Awards]]\n| Top New Vocal Group\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| Top New Artist\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| CMT Music Awards\n| Group Video of the Year - How Far Do You Wanna Go?\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[Teen Choice Awards]]\n| [[Teen Choice Award for Choice Music - Country Group|Choice Country Group]]\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"|2012\n| rowspan=\"3\"|[[American Country Awards]]\n| Artist of the Year: Breakthrough <ref>{{cite web|title = 2012 American Country Awards: Nominees & Winners|url = http://www.countryweekly.com/news/2012-american-country-awards-nominees-winners|website = Nash Country Weekly|access-date = 2015-12-14}}</ref>\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Single of the Year: Breakthrough \u2014 \"(Kissed You) Good Night\"\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Music Video of the Year: Group or Collaboration \u2014 \"(Kissed You) Good Night\"\n| {{nom}}\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist|2}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{Official website|http://www.gloriana.com/}}\n\n{{Gloriana}}\n{{American Music Award for New Artist of the Year}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n[[Category:Country music groups from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Musical duos from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Musical groups from Nashville, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 2008]]\n[[Category:Musical groups disestablished in 2017]]\n[[Category:Reprise Records artists]]\n[[Category:Warner Records artists]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Tim_Wilson_(comedian)","to":"Tim Wilson (comedian)"}],"pages":{"1900252":{"pageid":1900252,"ns":0,"title":"Tim Wilson (comedian)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Musical artist (1961\u20132014)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name            = Tim Wilson\n| image           = Tim wilson.png\n| caption         = A publicity photo of Tim Wilson.\n| alt = A head-shot of comedian and singer Tim Wilson.\n| image_size      =\n| background      = solo_singer\n| birth_name      = Timothy Collins Wilson\n| birth_date      = {{birth date|1961|8|5|mf=yes}}\n| birth_place     = [[Columbus, Georgia]], U.S.\n| death_date      = {{Death date and age|2014|2|26|1961|8|5|mf=yes}}\n| death_place     = Columbus, Georgia, U.S.\n| instrument      = Vocals, acoustic guitar\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[comedy music|comedy]], [[parody music|parody]], [[acoustic music|acoustic]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter, comedian\n| years_active    = 1984\u20132014\n| label           = Southern Tracks, [[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol Nashville]]\n}}\n\n'''Timothy Collins Wilson''' (August 5, 1961 \u2013 February 26, 2014) was an American comedian and [[country music]] artist, whose act combined stand-up comedy and original songs.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p138928|pure_url=yes}}|title=Tim Wilson biography|access-date=June 12, 2008|last=Ankeny|first=Jason|work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>\n\nHe released more than a dozen comedy albums, including several for [[Capitol Records]] Nashville, and made frequent appearances with ''Wilhite and Wall'', ''[[John Boy and Billy]]'', ''[[Big D and Bubba]]'' and ''[[Bob and Tom Show]]''. Wilson also appeared on numerous television programs, including ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'' and ''American Revolution Country Comedy'' on [[Country Music Television|CMT]]. In 2011, Wilson appeared on CMT's ''[[Ron White]]'s Comedy Salute to the Troops''.\n\nIn 2012, Wilson appeared on the [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] comedy special ''[[Billy Gardell]]'s: Road Dogs'' with Gardell hosting along with comedians Ben Creed and Kenny Rogerson.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://recoverycomedy.com/promo-ken-rogerson.html |title=Clean and Sober Comedy! |website=Recoverycomedy.com |access-date=April 13, 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Life and career==\nTimothy Collins Wilson was born August 5, 1961, in [[Columbus, Georgia]], and attended [[Presbyterian College]] in [[Clinton, South Carolina]], as an English major.<ref name=\"whitburn1\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc.|year=2008|page=472|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref> His parents were school teachers. He was a self-described [[Libertarianism|libertarian]], and sometimes included his political standpoints in his comedy routines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theadvocates.org/celebrities/tim-wilson.html|title=Tim Wilson \u2013 Libertarian|access-date=June 12, 2008 |work=TheAdvocates.org|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080423054811/http://www.theadvocates.org/celebrities/tim-wilson.html|archive-date=April 23, 2008}}</ref> He co-wrote several parodies for the 1980s comedy duo [[Pinkard & Bowden]], as well as comedian [[Jeff Foxworthy]]'s 1996 single \"[[Redneck 12 Days of Christmas]].\"<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> He wrote and recorded the novelty songs \"Garth Brooks Has Ruined My Life\" and \"The Ballad of John Rocker.\"<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2012|publisher=Record Research, Inc.|year=2013|page=377|isbn=978-0-89820-203-8}}</ref>\n\nWilson began his recording career in [[Atlanta]], on the Southern Tracks label with music publisher [[Bill Lowery (record producer)|Bill Lowery]]. Members of the [[Atlanta Rhythm Section]] played on many of Wilson's early recordings, with ARS keyboardist Dean Daughtry producing.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Wilson later recorded extensively in [[Muscle Shoals, Alabama]], with the [[Muscle Shoals Rhythm Section]]. He co-produced ''Allnight Allstars'' with Muscle Shoals engineer Steve Melton. The project appeared on [[Capitol Nashville]] and includes [[Levon Helm]], [[Gregg Allman]], [[Jimmy Hall]], [[Bobby Whitlock]], and members of both the Atlanta Rhythm Section and the Muscle Shoals Rhythm Section.<ref>{{cite web|title=All Night All Stars|url=http://www.probiography.com/bios/allnightallstars.htm|access-date=February 27, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309184616/http://www.probiography.com/bios/allnightallstars.htm|archive-date=March 9, 2012}}</ref>\n\nIn 2009, Wilson and Roger Keiss wrote a detective book entitled ''Happy New Year \u2013 ted'', about serial killer [[Ted Bundy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.glasgowdailytimes.com/entertainment/local_story_218111209.html?start:int=15|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130124092451/http://www.glasgowdailytimes.com/entertainment/local_story_218111209.html?start:int=15|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 24, 2013|title=Comedian Tim Wilson to perform at Plaza Saturday|last=Kinslow|first=Gina|date=August 6, 2009|work=Glasgow Daily Times|access-date=September 22, 2009}}</ref> He can be heard discussing his research and his book in great detail while visiting the ''Off The Air Podcast'', hosted by [[Chick McGee]] of the ''[[Bob and Tom Show]]''.\n\nWilson was posthumously inducted into the Georgia Music Hall of Fame in September 2015.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Associated Press|title=Georgia Music Hall of Fame inducts Gregg Almman, 8 others|url=http://savannahnow.com/news/2015-09-27/georgia-music-hall-fame-inducts-gregg-allman-8-others#|website=savannahnow.com|access-date=October 21, 2015}}</ref>\n\n==Death==\nWilson died of a heart attack on February 26, 2014. Early reports stated that he died in [[Nashville, Tennessee]]; however, his longtime friend and manager Chris Dipetta clarified that he had been traveling, but had made it to his hometown of [[Columbus, Georgia]], before he died.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fernandez|first1=Maria Elena|title=Comedic country singer Tim Wilson dies at 52|url=http://www.today.com/entertainment/comedic-country-singer-tim-wilson-dies-52-2D12183366|access-date=August 26, 2014|agency=[[Today (U.S. TV program)|''Today'']]|publisher=[[NBC News]]|date=February 27, 2014}}</ref> More details from the referenced story state: \"Wilson, 52, drove to Columbus from a gig in Michigan to visit his brother en route to a weekend show in Birmingham, Ala. when he started feeling ill, said Dipetta, who worked with Wilson for 30 years. Dipetta continued, \"I talked to him yesterday afternoon and he said he felt bad, was short of breath, and I said, \"get to the hospital now!\" Wilson's brother rushed him to a nearby hospital and Wilson suffered a massive heart attack and died at 9:15&nbsp;p.m. Wilson left behind his wife, and two children.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/bay-city/index.ssf/2014/02/bob_tom_show_comedian_tim_wils.html |title=Bob & Tom Show comedian Tim Wilson dies 4 days after giving last performance in downtown Bay City &#124; MLive.com |website=www.mlive.com |access-date=13 January 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227204838/http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/bay-city/index.ssf/2014/02/bob_tom_show_comedian_tim_wils.html |archive-date=27 February 2014 |url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>Stallings, Amy (February 27, 2014).[http://www.whas11.com/news/Report-Comedian-Tim-Wilson-dies-after-suffering-heart-attack-247479521.html Report: Comedian Tim Wilson dies after suffering heart attack] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140303063925/http://www.whas11.com/news/Report-Comedian-Tim-Wilson-dies-after-suffering-heart-attack-247479521.html |date=March 3, 2014 }} whas11.com; retrieved February 27, 2014.</ref>\n\n==Tribute show==\nOn May 9, 2014, The Bob and Tom show sponsored a tribute comedy show to honor Wilson and help provide an education for his son.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bobandtom.com/common/page.php?pt=Join+us+for+the+Tim+Wilson+Benefit+Show&id=1414&is_corp=0|title=Join us for the Tim Wilson Benefit Show|date=April 21, 2014|publisher=bobandtom.com|access-date=May 10, 2014|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140512214445/http://www.bobandtom.com/common/page.php?pt=Join+us+for+the+Tim+Wilson+Benefit+Show&id=1414&is_corp=0|archive-date=May 12, 2014}}</ref> This three-and-a-half-hour show was presented at the [[Paramount Theatre (Anderson, Indiana)]]. The announced lineup included ''the Bob and Tom show'' personalities ([[Bob Kevoian]], [[Tom Griswold]], [[Kristi Lee]], and [[Chick McGee]]), as well as [[John Means (comedian)|Dr. Gonzo]], Heywood Banks, [[Drew Hastings]], and [[Donny Baker]]. Surprise guests were introduced during the show and included, [[Duke Tumatoe]], [[Indianapolis Colts]] punter [[Pat McAfee]], Ricky Rydell and Scotty Bratcher. Additional music talent was provided by [[Steve Allee]], keyboard and PJ Yinger, trumpet. Additionally, Bob Kevoian did an emotional solo performance of a Tim Wilson tribute song on ukulele. Wilson's last appearance on The Bob and Tom Show was on December 10, 2013.\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"3\"| Peak chart positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! style=\"width:45px;\"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]\n! style=\"width:45px;\"| [[Top Comedy Albums|US Comedy]]\n! style=\"width:45px;\"| [[Top Heatseekers|US Heat]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Waking Up the Neighborhood''\n|\n* Release date: July 26, 1994\n* Label: Southern Tracks\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n!
