Kentucky]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Burns_&_Poe","to":"Burns & Poe"}],"pages":{"37013118":{"pageid":37013118,"ns":0,"title":"Burns & Poe","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Burns & Poe\n| image           = Burns and poe.jpg\n| image_size      =\n| landscape       = yes\n| alt             =\n| caption         = Burns & Poe at [[CMA Music Festival]], June 2010\n| origin          = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| years_active    = 2007-2014\n| label           = Country Thunder, Blue Steel\n| associated_acts = [[Trick Pony]]\n| website         =\n| current_members = Keith Burns<br />Michelle Poe\n}}\n'''Burns & Poe''' was an American [[country music]] duo composed of Keith Burns and Michelle Poe. The duo was founded in 2007 after Burns left the group [[Trick Pony]]. Poe was once a solo artist for [[DreamWorks Nashville]], and later played [[bass guitar]] for [[Dierks Bentley]] and [[Hank Williams Jr.]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/burns_and_poe/bio.jhtml|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130119201502/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/burns_and_poe/bio.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 19, 2013|title=Burns & Poe biography|work=[[Country Music Television]]|accessdate=14 September 2012}}</ref> The two met in 2007 while Burns was holding auditions to recruit a new lead singer for Trick Pony after Aubrey Collins (who had replaced original lead singer [[Heidi Newfield]] just months earlier) left.<ref name=\"gac1\">{{cite web|url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,gac_26071_6023961,00.html|title=Burns & Poe Biography (page 1 of 2)|work=[[Great American Country]]|accessdate=14 September 2012|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20130124051506/http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,gac_26071_6023961,00.html|archivedate=24 January 2013}}</ref>\n\nThey released a two-disc, self-titled album in late 2010 through their website, followed by a Christmas single titled \"Hear the Angels Singing\" in November of that year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theboot.com/2010/11/24/burns-and-poe-hear-the-angels-singing/|title=Burns & Poe Offer Fans Limited Edition Album and Holiday Single|last=Conaway|first=Alanna|date=November 24, 2010|work=The Boot|accessdate=14 September 2012}}</ref> Blue Steel Records gave it a wide release in 2011. The same year, ''Music Row'' magazine awarded them as Independent Artist of the Year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://americajr.com/entertainment/burnsandpoealbum0503.html|title=New country duo Burns & Poe releases two-disc, self-titled debut album|last=Rzucidlo|first=Jason|date=May 4, 2011|work=AmericaJr.com|accessdate=14 September 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110617140416/http://americajr.com/entertainment/burnsandpoealbum0503.html|archive-date=17 June 2011|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=\"gac2\">{{cite web|url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,3028,GAC_26071_6023961_02,00.html|title=Burns & Poe biography (page 2 of 2)|work=Great American Country|accessdate=14 September 2012|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20130123215424/http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,3028,GAC_26071_6023961_02,00.html|archivedate=23 January 2013}}</ref> They promoted the dual album on tour in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/new-artist-spotlight-burns-poe|title=New Artist Spotlight: Burns & Poe|last=Dauphin|first=Chuck|date=April 30, 2011|work=Roughstock|accessdate=14 September 2012|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013123838/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/new-artist-spotlight-burns-poe|archivedate=13 October 2012}}</ref> Alex Henderson of [[Allmusic]] rated the album 3 stars out of 5, saying that \"they sound like they genuinely enjoy working together\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/burns-poe-mw0002122106|title=''Burns & Poe'' review|last=Henderson|first=Alex|work=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=14 September 2012}}</ref>\n\nLater in 2011, Burns & Poe released a video for a fourth song, \"I Need a Job\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/burns-and-poe-i-need-a-job/|title=Burns and Poe, 'I Need a Job' \u2013 Song Review|last=Dukes|first=Billy|date=September 15, 2011|work=Taste of Country|accessdate=14 September 2012}}</ref> In 2014, Burns rejoined Trick Pony.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.countryweekly.com/news/trick-pony-reunites|title = The Country Daily}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:20em;\"| Album details\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| ''Burns & Poe''\n| \n* Release date: April 26, 2011\n* Label: Blue Steel Records\n* Format: [[compact disc|CD]]\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Single\n! Album\n|-\n|rowspan=2| 2009\n! scope=\"row\"|\"Gone as All Get Out\"\n| rowspan=\"5\"| ''Burns & Poe''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"|\"It's Always a Woman\"\n|-\n| 2010\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Don't Get No Better Than That\"\n|-\n| rowspan=2|2011\n! scope=\"row\"| \"How Long Is Long Enough\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Second Chance\"\n|}\n\n===Videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 2010\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Don't Get No Better Than That\"\n| Douglas Bruce/Stephen Shively\n|-\n| rowspan=2|2011\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Second Chance\"\n| Kelly Brooks\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Need a Job\"\n|Steve Freeman\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://burnsandpoe.com Official website]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Burns and Poe}}\n[[Category:Country music groups from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:American country music duos]]\n[[Category:Musical groups from Nashville, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 2007]]\n[[Category:2007 establishments in Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Musical duos from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Male\u2013female musical duos]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Kippi_Brannon","to":"Kippi Brannon"}],"pages":{"14921648":{"pageid":14921648,"ns":0,"title":"Kippi Brannon","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country music singer|bot=PearBOT 5}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name            = Kippi Brannon\n| background      = solo_singer\n| image           =\n| caption         = \n| birth_name      = Kippi Rolynn Binkley<ref name=\"oldies\"/>\n| alias           = \n| birth_date      = {{birth year and age|1966}}<ref name=\"oldies\"/>\n| birth_place     = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| origin          = \n| genre           = [[country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = [[Singing|Singer]]\n| instrument      = [[singing|Vocals]]\n| years_active    = 1981\u20131982, 1988\u20131997\n| label           = [[MCA Records|MCA]], [[Curb Records|Curb]]/[[Universal Records|Universal]]\n| associated_acts = [[Jeff Carson]]\n| website         = \n}}\n\n'''Kippi Brannon''' (born '''Kippi Rolynn Binkley''', 1966)<ref name=\"oldies\">{{cite web |url=http://www.oldies.com/artist-biography/Kippi-Brannon.html |title=Kippi Brannon Biography |accessdate=2007-12-23 |work=Oldies.com}}</ref> is an American [[country music]] singer. She made her debut on the country music scene as a teenager, releasing four singles on [[MCA Records]] in the early 1980s before leaving her career in favor of a college education. By 1992, she returned to the country music scene, eventually releasing her debut album ''I'd Be with You'' in 1997.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p184539|pure_url=yes}} |title=Kippi Brannon Biography |accessdate=2007-12-23 |last=Erlewine |first=Stephen Thomas |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nKippi Rolynn Binkley was born in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref name=\"oldies\"/> A singer and musician at an early age, she began singing professionally before she was a teenager. At age 12, she gave a performance at a local shopping mall, when an executive for [[MCA Records]] discovered her.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/><ref name=\"coast\"/> With the help of record producer Chuck Howard, Jr., Kippi was signed to MCA in 1981. Her surname was altered to Brannon, after Brannon Auto Parts, a local automotive parts store.<ref name=\"oldies\"/><ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\n==Career==\nBrannon charted three singles in the early 1980s, in addition to receiving a New Female Vocalist of the Year nomination from the [[Academy of Country Music]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> She was also signed as an opening act for other country artists. Although she was gaining in popularity, Brannon decided to leave her career and attend college, first at [[Belmont University]] and later at the [[University of Tennessee]]-Knoxville.<ref name=\"oldies\"/> During her hiatus from the country music scene, she also married and had a daughter, Kasey;<ref name=\"coast\">{{cite web |url=http://archive.southcoasttoday.com/daily/05-97/05-28-97/c04ae214.htm |title=Still \"Daddy's Little Girl\": Former teen star Kippi Brannon returns to country music |accessdate=2007-12-23 |last=Patterson |first=Jim |date=1997-05-28 |work=South Coast Today}}</ref> she later divorced and married a second time.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nBy 1988, Brannon resumed her music career, signing to [[Curb Records]] this time around. Her first single for the label, \"I Ain't Never\", failed to make the charts upon its 1992 release. Working with producers [[Matt Rollings]] and [[James Stroud]], she began a search for additional songs to record; however, by the end of 1992, she once again had to take a hiatus, as she had divorced a second time, and had to care for her ailing father.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> \n\nHer first album, ''I'd Be with You'', was released in early 1997, under the production of [[Mark Bright (record producer)|Mark Bright]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Though the album's first single, \"Daddy's Little Girl\", only reached number 42 on Billboard's [[Hot Country Songs]] chart -- which tracked only radio airplay at the time -- it was a retail success, spending 23 weeks and reaching number 6 on the Country Single Sales chart, and number 23 on the 1997 year-end Country Single Sales chart.<ref>{{cite web |title=Billboard-1997-12-27 |url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-All-Music/Billboard/90s/1997/Billboard-1997-12-27.pdf |website=World Radio History}}</ref> The song was also blended with fellow [[Curb Records]] artist [[Jeff Carson]]'s solo recording of [[Bob Carlisle]]'s similarly-themed hit single \"[[Butterfly Kisses (song)|Butterfly Kisses]]\" as an additional track on Carson's [[Butterfly Kisses (Jeff Carson album)|album of the same name]]. Like Brannon's single, Carson's version of \"Butterfly Kisses\" struggled on the airplay charts but was a sales success, spending 15 weeks on the Country Single Sales chart and peaking at number 6. ''I'd Be with You'' reached number 53 on the [[Top Country Albums]] chart.\n\nBrannon has not recorded since.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:10em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"2\"| Peak chart<br />positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[Top Heatseekers|US Heat]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''I'd Be with You''\n| \n* Release date: April 22, 1997\n* Label: [[Curb Records|Curb]]/[[Universal Records|Universal]]\n| 53\n| 48\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"2\"| Peak chart<br />positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[Bubbling Under Hot 100|US Bubbling]]\n|-\n| 1981\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Slowly (Webb Pierce song)|Slowly]]\"\n| 37\n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"4\" {{n/a}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1982\n! scope=\"row\"| \"If I Could See You Tonight\"\n| 55\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"He Don't Make Me Cry\"\n| 87\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 1983\n! scope=\"row\"| \"In My Dreams\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 1992\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[I Ain't Never]]\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"4\"| ''I'd Be with You''\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 1997\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Daddy's Little Girl\"\n| 42\n| 20\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I'd Be with You\"\n| 53\n| 20\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Greatest Love I've Ever Known\"<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://americanradiohistory.com/Archive-RandR/1990s/1997/RR-1997-11-07.pdf|title=Going for Adds|journal=[[Radio & Records]]|page=65|date=November 7, 1997}}</ref>\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"5\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Year\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 1997\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Daddy's Little Girl\"\n| John Scarpati\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Brannon, Kippi}}\n[[Category:1966 births]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Curb Records artists]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:MCA Records artists]]\n[[Category:Singers from Nashville, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Trace_Adkins","to":"Trace Adkins"}],"pages":{"487964":{"pageid":487964,"ns":0,"title":"Trace Adkins","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country singer and actor (born 1962)}}\n{{Distinguish|Rhett Akins}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2024}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image            = File:Trace_Adkins_2011_(cropped).jpg\n| caption          = Adkins in 2011\n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = Tracy Darrell Adkins\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1962|01|13}}\n| birth_place      = [[Sarepta, Louisiana]], U.S.\n| origin           = [[Springhill, Louisiana]], U.S.\n| instrument       = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar}}\n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]]<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n| years_active     = 1987\u2013present\n| occupation       = {{hlist|Singer|actor}}\n| label            = {{hlist|[[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol Nashville]]|[[Show Dog-Universal Music|Show Dog-Universal]]|[[Broken Bow Records|Wheelhouse]]|[[Waffle Records]]|Verge Records}}\n| associated_acts  = \n| website          = {{URL|traceadkins.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Tracy Darrell Adkins'''<ref name=\"allmusic\" /> (born January 13, 1962)<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2021/01/13/UPI-Almanac-for-Wednesday-Jan-13-2021/4791610505329/|title= UPI Almanac for Wednesday, Jan. 13, 2021|work= [[United Press International]] | date= January 13, 2021|access-date=February 27, 2021 | archive-date= February 27, 2021|archive-url= https://archive.today/20210227210816/https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2021/01/13/UPI-Almanac-for-Wednesday-Jan-13-2021/4791610505329/|url-status=live|quote = ...country singer Trace Adkins in 1962 (age 59)...}}</ref> is an American [[country music]] singer and actor. Adkins made his debut in 1996 with the album ''[[Dreamin' Out Loud]]'', released on [[Capitol Records]] Nashville. Since then, he has released ten more studio albums and two Greatest Hits compilations. In addition, Adkins has charted more than 20 singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country music charts, including the Number One hits \"[[(This Ain't) No Thinkin' Thing]]\", \"[[Ladies Love Country Boys]]\", and \"[[You're Gonna Miss This]]\", which peaked in 1997, 2007, and 2008, respectively.\n\n\"[[I Left Something Turned on at Home]]\" went to No.&nbsp;1 on Canada's country chart. At least six of his studio albums have received gold or platinum certification in the United States; his highest-selling to date is 2005's ''[[Songs About Me]]'', which has been certified 2\u00d7 Multi-Platinum for shipping two million copies. Adkins is widely known for his distinctive bass-baritone singing and speaking voice.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/trace-adkins-mn0000012180/biography|title=Trace Adkins Biography |first=Steve|last=Huey|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=September 11, 2013|archive-date=December 25, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191225072612/https://www.allmusic.com/artist/trace-adkins-mn0000012180/biography|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.traceadkins.com/wired/about-2/|title=Trace Adkins|access-date=September 11, 2013|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130911183951/http://www.traceadkins.com/wired/about-2/|archive-date=September 11, 2013}}</ref>\n\nHe has also made several appearances on television, including as a panelist on the game shows ''[[Hollywood Squares]]'' and ''[[Pyramid (game show)|Pyramid]]'', as a 2008 finalist and as the 2013 winner on ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. season 7)|The All Star Celebrity Apprentice]]'', as the voice for recurring character Elvin on ''[[King of the Hill]]'', and the main role of Albie Roman on ''[[Monarch (American TV series)|Monarch]]'', as well as in television commercial voice-overs for [[KFC]] and [[Firestone Tire and Rubber Company|Firestone]].\n\nAlso, Adkins has written an autobiography titled ''A Personal Stand: Observations and Opinions from a Free-Thinking Roughneck'', which was released in late 2007. He has appeared in numerous films, including ''[[The Lincoln Lawyer (film)|The Lincoln Lawyer]]'', ''[[Moms' Night Out]]'', and ''[[I Can Only Imagine (film)|I Can Only Imagine]]''.\n\n==Early life and education==\n[[File:Trace Adkins from Sarepta IMG 3574.JPG|left|thumb|[[Sarepta, Louisiana]], honors its home-town celebrity, Trace Adkins]]\nAdkins was born in [[Sarepta, Louisiana]], the son of Peggy Carraway and Aaron Doyle Adkins.<ref name=\"allmusic\" /><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.cmt.com/news/qnqdax/trace-adkins-father-dies | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220922050439/https://www.cmt.com/news/qnqdax/trace-adkins-father-dies | url-status=dead | archive-date=September 22, 2022 | title=Trace Adkins' Father Dies }}</ref> His maternal uncle was the Christian musician James W. Carraway (1923\u20132008).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americanprofile.com/article/4104.html|title=A Dream Come True for Trace Adkins|author=McCall, Michael|work=American Profile|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061018121756/http://www.americanprofile.com/article/4104.html|archive-date=October 18, 2006|date=June 13, 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|date=November 26, 2007 |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/articles/1575050/20071126/adkins_trace.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071129234235/http://www.cmt.com/news/articles/1575050/20071126/adkins_trace.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=November 29, 2007 |title=Trace Adkins: A Personal Stand |publisher=Cmt.com |access-date=2011-12-08}}</ref> His musical interest came at an early age when he was ten and his father bought him a guitar and hired someone to give him lessons.<ref name=\"billboard\">{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/transcripts/728603619 |title=Trace Adkins Interview with Ask Me Another |access-date=2019-12-01  |work=[[NPR]]}}</ref>\n\nAt Sarepta High School, since defunct, Adkins joined a [[gospel music]] group called the New Commitments.<ref name=\"encyclocountry\"/> He was also a member of the [[National FFA Organization|FFA]]. Later, Adkins attended [[Louisiana Tech University]] in [[Ruston, Louisiana|Ruston]].<ref name=\"encyclocountry\"/> A [[walk-on (sports)|walk-on]] [[offensive lineman]] on their [[Louisiana Tech Bulldogs football|football team]], Adkins left the team after his freshman season due to a knee injury, without ever playing in a game.<ref name=\"American Cowboy 2000\">{{citation|last1=Sweetland|first1=Phil|title=Trace elements|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-eoCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA24|website=American Cowboy|pages=24\u201327|date=September 2000}}</ref>{{rp|26}}<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gardiner|first1=Amy|title=Singer Trace Adkins reunites with Baylor's Kim Mulkey|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/college/womensbasketball/story/2012-02-12/baylor-kim-mulkey-trace-adkins/53066562/1|website=USA Today|access-date=January 4, 2015|date=February 13, 2012}}</ref><ref>Tracy Adkins is not listed in Louisiana Tech's letterwinners list. {{cite web|title=Letterwinners|url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/latc/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/2014-15/misc_non_event/14bowl_6.pdf|website=Louisiana Tech 2014 Heart of Dallas Bowl Media Guide|publisher=Louisiana Tech University|page=176|date=2014}}</ref> Adkins never graduated. After leaving college, he worked on an [[Petroleum|oil]] rig. He also played music in a band called Bayou.<ref name=\"encyclocountry\"/> Adkins also worked as a pharmacy technician before pursuing a career in music. He lost the [[pinky finger]] on his left hand in an accident using a knife to open a bucket, and asked doctors to reattach the finger at an angle so that he could continue to play guitar.<ref name=\"billboard\"/> Adkins moved to play in [[honky tonk|honky-tonk]] bars for the next few years in the [[Ark-La-Tex]] area and eventually moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in 1992.<ref name=\"encyclocountry\"/> In late-1994, Adkins met Rhonda Forlaw, who was an executive at Arista Records Nashville. Forlaw had numerous music industry friends come out to hear Adkins over the next few years. Scott Hendricks of [[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol Nashville]] signed him \"on the spot\" one night while Adkins was playing at Tillie and Lucy's bar in [[Mount Juliet, Tennessee|Mt. Juliet]], [[Tennessee]].<ref name=\"encyclocountry\"/>\n\n==Music career==\n===Early career===\n[[File:Trace Adkins 1997.jpg|thumb|Adkins in 1997]]\nAdkins' first single, which he wrote himself,<ref name=\"encyclocountry\"/> \"There's a Girl in Texas\", was released in 1996, reaching the Top 20 on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] charts. It was followed by the release of his debut album, ''[[Dreamin' Out Loud]]'', later that year. The album produced several hit singles, including his first Top 5 single, \"[[Every Light in the House]]\", his first Number One in \"[[(This Ain't) No Thinkin' Thing]]\", and another Top 5 hit in \"[[I Left Something Turned on at Home]]\". The latter single was also a Number One hit in Canada. His second album, ''[[Big Time (Trace Adkins album)|Big Time]]'', produced a Top 5 in \"[[The Rest of Mine]]\", but subsequent singles proved less successful.<ref name=\"billboard\"/> Adkins was named \"Top New Male Artist\" by the [[Academy of Country Music]] in 1997.<ref name=\"encyclocountry\">{{cite book|title=The Encyclopedia of Country Music|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tLZz02EzmBYC&pg=PA166|date=1 February 2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-992083-9|page=6}}</ref> In 1998, Adkins appeared on the [[PBS]] music program ''[[Austin City Limits]]'' (season 23). A change in management delayed the release of Adkins' third album,<ref>{{cite web|author=Edward Morris |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1445103/20010712/adkins_trace.jhtml |title=CMT.com : Trace Adkins : Trace Adkins Nixed Song That's Now His Album's Lead Single |date=2001-07-12 |access-date=2013-05-14 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327010935/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1445103/20010712/adkins_trace.jhtml |archive-date=March 27, 2008 }}</ref> but the album (titled ''[[More... (Trace Adkins album)|More...]]'') was eventually released in late 1999. Although the album's title track reached Top 10, ''More...'' failed to achieve gold status. Adkins' daughter, Mackenzie, was featured in the \"More\" video.\n\n===2001\u20132004===\nIn 2001, Adkins was injured in a tractor accident and had to cancel touring temporarily.<ref>[http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1458085/20021011/adkins_trace.jhtml] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930040832/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1458085/20021011/adkins_trace.jhtml|date=September 30, 2007}}</ref> Shortly after the release of his ''[[Chrome (Trace Adkins album)|Chrome]]'' album, he entered a 28-day alcohol rehabilitation program in Nashville.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1459611/20030121/adkins_trace.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080424172232/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1459611/20030121/adkins_trace.jhtml |archive-date=2008-04-24 |title=CMT.com : Trace Adkins : Trace Adkins Completes Rehab Program |date=2003-01-21 |access-date=2013-05-14}}</ref> ''Chrome'' was his first album to reach the Top 5 on the country albums charts; its [[Chrome (Trace Adkins song)|title track]] reached Top 10 in late 2002.<ref name=\"billboard\"/>\n\nIn 2003, Adkins released two albums\u2014a Greatest Hits collection and ''[[Comin' on Strong]]''.<ref name=\"billboard\"/> The same year, he was inducted into the [[Grand Ole Opry]].<ref>[http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1472693/20030616/adkins_trace.jhtml] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927184724/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1472693/20030616/adkins_trace.jhtml|date=September 27, 2007}}</ref> He also made appearances as the center square on the game show [[Hollywood Squares]],<ref>[http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1483835/20031219/adkins_trace.jhtml] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930061549/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1483835/20031219/adkins_trace.jhtml|date=September 30, 2007}}</ref> and did voice-overs in commercials for fast-food chain [[KFC]].<ref>[http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1485535/20040303/adkins_trace.jhtml] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930044829/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1485535/20040303/adkins_trace.jhtml|date=September 30, 2007}}</ref> Only one single, \"[[Then They Do]]\", was released from this Greatest Hits compilation. This album, which succeeded the Greatest Hits collection, produced two singles: the Top 5 single \"[[Hot Mama]]\" and \"[[Rough & Ready]]\", which peaked at No.&nbsp;13.\n\nAdkins and [[Travis Tritt]] played the roles of prison convicts in a February 2004 episode of the television series ''[[Yes, Dear]]'' ([[Greg and Jimmy's Criminals|Greg & Jimmy's Criminals]]).\n\n===2005\u20132007===\nIn March 2005, Adkins released his album entitled ''[[Songs About Me]]''.<ref name=\"billboard\"/> The [[Songs About Me (song)|title track]] was released as its first single in December 2004. The album's second single, \"[[Arlington (song)|Arlington]]\", generated controversy over its content (a first-person account of a fictional soldier who was about to be buried in [[Arlington National Cemetery]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usaweekend.com/06_issues/060521/060521country_music.html |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130205154001/http://www.usaweekend.com/06_issues/060521/060521country_music.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=2013-02-05 |title={{pipe}} USA WEEKEND {{pipe}} usaweekend.com |website=Archive.is |date=2013-02-05 |access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref> It was followed by \"[[Honky Tonk Badonkadonk]]\",  which became a crossover hit, bringing Adkins into the Top 40 of the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] for the first time.\n\n2006 saw the release of Adkins' seventh studio album, ''[[Dangerous Man]]''. \"[[Swing (Trace Adkins song)|Swing]]\", the album's lead-off single, peaked at No.&nbsp;20, while the follow-up \"[[Ladies Love Country Boys]]\" became Adkins' second Number One single on the country charts and his first since \"(This Ain't) No Thinkin' Thing\" in 1997. Adkins' daughter, Brianna, was featured in the \"Ladies Love Country Boys\" video. The album's final release, \"I Wanna Feel Something\", proved unsuccessful on the charts; as a result, Adkins announced that he would stop supporting the single.\n\nIn August 2007, Adkins released a single entitled \"[[I Got My Game On]]\".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1050617/adkins-impatient-to-unveil-new-single-album |title=Adkins Impatient To Unveil New Single, Album |access-date=2007-07-26 |last=Benson |first=John |work=Billboard.com}}</ref> Originally, the song was planned to be the lead-off to a new album, tentatively titled ''Game On''; however, Adkins decided not to release a full album, and instead released his second Greatest Hits compilation, ''[[American Man: Greatest Hits Volume II]]'', for which \"I Got My Game On\" served as the lead-off single.<ref name=\"game\">{{cite web |url=http://www.countryondemand.com/news/2007/10/trace-and-trump.shtml\n |title=Trace and Trump |access-date=2007-10-26 |date=2007-10-26 |work=Country on Demand |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20071114113937/http://www.countryondemand.com/news/2007/10/trace-and-trump.shtml <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archive-date = 2007-11-14}}</ref> The album has also produced Adkins' fastest-climbing single to date in its second single, \"[[You're Gonna Miss This]]\".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thatscountry.com/am2/publish/Country_News_2/004152.shtml |title=Trace Adkins brings \"The Boardroom\" to Nashville |access-date=2008-03-10 |work=That's Country.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080328020139/http://www.thatscountry.com/am2/publish/Country_News_2/004152.shtml |archive-date=2008-03-28 }}</ref> \"You're Gonna Miss This\" has also become his third Number One hit on the [[Hot Country Songs]], as well as the most successful single to date on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 (#12), [[Billboard Pop 100]] (#19), and [[Hot Digital Songs]] charts (#8).\n\nAdkins released his first book, entitled ''A Personal Stand: Observations and Opinions from a Free-Thinking Roughneck''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hotschatzpr.com/news.php?id=71 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090110020847/http://www.hotschatzpr.com/news.php?id=71 |url-status=dead |archive-date=2009-01-10 |title=First Book by Country Star Trace Adkins Hits Bookshelves Nationwide |access-date=2008-02-17 |date=2007-09-24 |work=Hot Schatz.com }}</ref>\n\n===2008\u20132009===\n\nIn 2008, Adkins released the single \"[[Muddy Water (Trace Adkins song)|Muddy Water]],\" the lead single from ''[[X (Trace Adkins album)|X]]'', which was released on November 25. The video for \"Muddy Water\" has an appearance by fellow ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. season 7)|Celebrity Apprentice]]'' competitor [[Stephen Baldwin]] as a man being baptized in a muddy river, and later approaching Adkins as a friend. It reached the Top 30 on the country charts, peaking at number 22. \"[[Marry for Money]]\" and \"[[All I Ask For Anymore]]\" were released as the album's second and third singles, and both peaked at No.&nbsp;14 on the country charts.\n\nIn November 2008, Adkins made an appearance at the [[Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade]]. He rode with his family on the \"[[Jimmy Dean]]\" float and performed his famous song \"You're Gonna Miss This\". In 2009, Adkins appeared in local [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]] commercials to advertise season tickets and the 50th season of the [[National Football League]]'s [[Kansas City Chiefs]].\n\nAdkins recorded a duet with country legend [[Ronnie Milsap]] called \"My First Ride\" to benefit fire-fighters and police officers in the U.S. and [[Canada]]. Then, after the song's release, the label said 'no' to radio stations playing it with no explanation given. Milsap led a protest at [[Capitol Records]] to \"Free Trace\" and allow the song to be played.\n\nIn November 2009, Adkins embarked on the Shine All Night Tour, a co-headline venture with fellow country artist [[Martina McBride]]. Also, in 2009, he recorded a duet with [[Blake Shelton]] titled \"Hillbilly Bone\", which was released as the lead-off single from Shelton's upcoming sixth album. On October 18, 2009, Adkins made an appearance on ''[[Extreme Makeover: Home Edition]]'' to help [[Ty Pennington]] and his design team build a new home for the Marshall family.\n\n===2010\u20132014: Move to Show Dog-Universal Music===\nIn January 2010, Adkins parted ways with his long-time record label, [[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol Nashville]], and subsequently signed with [[Show Dog-Universal Music]].<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2010/01/adkins-joins-show-dog-universal|title=Adkins Joins Show Dog Universal|magazine=MusicRow|date=2010-01-13|access-date=2010-04-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Staff|url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/trace-adkins-joins-show-dog-universal-records|title=Trace Adkins Joins Show Dog-Universal Records|publisher=Roughstock.com|date=2010-01-13|access-date=2010-04-27|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100526043556/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/trace-adkins-joins-show-dog-universal-records|archive-date=2010-05-26}}</ref>\n\nAdkins' first single with the label, \"[[This Ain't No Love Song]]\", was released on May 17, 2010, and served as the lead-off single to his ninth studio album, ''[[Cowboy's Back In Town]]''. It debuted at No.&nbsp;54 on the chart for the week of May 29, 2010. The album's second single \"Brown Chicken, Brown Cow\" released to country radio on January 10, 2011.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}}\n\nTwo men in a small Dodge pickup truck lost their lives after crashing into one of Trace Adkins' tour buses on February 13, 2010. The truck was believed to have crossed the \"no passing\" line in the center of the road which resulted in the crash. Several members of Adkins' band were aboard the bus but were not seriously injured. Adkins himself was not on board the bus at the time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tmz.com/2010/02/13/trace-adkins-tour-bus-fatal-crash|title=Trace Adkins' Tour Bus Involved in Fatal Crash|date=February 13, 2010|publisher=[[TMZ.com|TMZ]]|access-date=February 20, 2010}}</ref> On October 10, 2010, Adkins sang the [[national anthem]] at [[Dallas Cowboys Stadium]].{{citation needed|date=December 2011}}\n\nOn December 18, 2010, Adkins performed at [[WWE]]'s annual extravaganza ''[[WWE Tribute to the Troops|Tribute To The Troops]]'' to amazing reception by the soldiers in attendance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/tributetothetroops/exclusives/tributetothetroopsperformers|title=WWE \"Trace Adkins, Diddy-Dirty Money, Cedric the Entertainer and Ariel Winter to perform on WWE Tribute to the Troops\"|publisher=WWE.com|date=2010-12-07|access-date=2011-12-08}}</ref> He appeared once again in an episode of [[WWE SmackDown|SmackDown]] live from Nashville, Tennessee, on May 13, 2011, as the special member of the WWE audience.\n\nIn March 2011, Adkins released \"Just Fishin\" which featured his youngest daughter, Trinity, in the video, which was shot at their farm. The song reached #6 on Billboard. On June 4, 2011, at approximately 3:35 pm, Adkins' home in [[Brentwood, Tennessee]], burned down.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/06/05/trace-adkins-house-burns-down_n_871442.html | work=Huffington Post|title=Country Star's House Burns Down|date=2011-06-05}}</ref> On October 20, 2011, Adkins sang the National Anthem at game 2 of the [[2011 World Series]] in [[St. Louis]].{{citation needed|date=August 2017}}\n\nIn April 2011, Adkins revealed that he had a crush on the [[Baylor Lady Bears basketball|Baylor Lady Bears]]' head coach, [[Kim Mulkey]], while the two were in college at Louisiana Tech, then dedicated his performance of \"[[One in a Million You]]\" to her.<ref>{{cite video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yJLOZynTaIM |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211222/yJLOZynTaIM |archive-date=2021-12-22 |url-status=live|title=Trace Adkins|access-date=2012-09-25|date=2011-04-15|publication-date=2011-04-18|publisher=YouTube|author=ZEPFAN269}}{{cbignore}}</ref>\n\nMulkey's sister arranged a phone call in December 2011 between the singer and coach, during which Kim Mulkey invited him to sing at Baylor's home game against [[Connecticut Huskies women's basketball|Connecticut]];<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wacotrib.com/sports/baylor/138909134.html|title=Affection for Kim Mulkey brings Trace Adkins to Waco|author=Cherry, Brice|newspaper=Waco Tribune-Herald|access-date=2012-09-25|date=2012-02-08|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120211010227/http://www.wacotrib.com/sports/baylor/138909134.html|archive-date=2012-02-11}}</ref> Adkins, unable to attend, arranged to perform the National Anthem at the Lady Bears' February 2012 home game against the [[Texas A&M Aggies women's basketball|Texas A&M Aggies]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/womensbasketball/story/2012-02-12/baylor-kim-mulkey-trace-adkins/53066562/1|title=Singer Trace Adkins reunites with Baylor's Kim Mulkey|newspaper=USA Today|author=Gardiner, Andy|date=2012-02-13|access-date=2012-09-25}}</ref>\n\nIn March 2012, Adkins visited the Lady Bears while on tour in Kansas City to encourage them before their NCAA Championships semi-final match; the team attended one of his concerts later that week.<ref>{{cite video|url=http://espn.go.com/video/clip?id=7762678|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130124133857/http://espn.go.com/video/clip?id=7762678|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 24, 2013|title=Mulkey's biggest fan|access-date=2012-09-25|date=2012-04-01|publisher=ESPN}}</ref>\n\nIn February 2012, Adkins appeared as a guest vocalist on [[Meat Loaf]]'s album ''[[Hell in a Handbasket]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.meatloaf.net/content/legacy-recordings-announces-stateside-release-hell-handbasket-new-full-length-studio-album-m|title=Legacy Recordings Announces The Stateside Release Of Hell In A Handbasket, The New Full-Length Studio Album From|publisher=Meat Loaf|access-date=2013-05-14|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120814121441/http://meatloaf.net/content/legacy-recordings-announces-stateside-release-hell-handbasket-new-full-length-studio-album-m|archive-date=2012-08-14}}</ref>\n\nAdkins performed \"[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]\" at the [[West Virginia Mountaineers football|West Virginia Mountaineers]]' home football game against the [[Baylor Bears football|Baylor Bears]] on September 29, 2012; his was just the third live performance of the national anthem in the 32-year history of Mountaineer Field.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.58wchs.com/includes/news_items/7/news_items_more.php?id=43401&section_id=7|title=Trace Adkins Will Perform Anthem Saturday In Morgantown|publisher=WCHS Radio 58|access-date=2012-09-25}}</ref>\n\nAdkins released a new album, ''[[Love Will...]]'', on May 14, 2013. The album's first single, \"Watch the World End\", was released to country radio on May 13, 2013. In September 2013, it was announced that he was no longer on the Showdog roster according to the official website.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}}\n\nAdkins released his first Christmas album, ''[[The King's Gift]]'', on October 29, 2013.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sterdan|first=Darryl|title=Miley Cyrus, NIN top the 2013 fall music preview|url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/2013/08/29/21084671.html|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130830234630/http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/2013/08/29/21084671.html|url-status=usurped|archive-date=August 30, 2013|access-date=August 30, 2013|newspaper=Canoe.ca|date=August 29, 2013}}</ref>\n\n===2015\u2013present: Move to Wheelhouse Records===\nOn April 6, 2015, it was announced that Adkins had signed with [[Broken Bow Records]], under the Wheelhouse imprint.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/record-labels/6524233/trace-adkins-eyes-radio-with-bbr-music-group-deal-i-can-ring |title=Trace Adkins Eyes Radio With BBR Music Group Deal: 'I Can Ring the Bell Another Time or Two' |last=Stark |first=Phyllis |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=April 6, 2015 |access-date=April 7, 2015}}</ref> In August 2015, Broken Bow announced that Adkins was one of the first artists signed to the label's new imprint, Wheelhouse Records.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://tasteofcountry.com/bbr-music-label-wheelhouse-records/ | title=BBR Music Launches New Label, Starting With Trace Adkins and Granger Smith | publisher=Taste of Country | date=August 31, 2015 | access-date=September 5, 2015}}</ref> His first single for the label was \"[[Jesus and Jones]]\", which was released to country radio on January 18, 2016, and peaked at number 41 on the Country Airplay chart. \"Lit\" was released to country radio on July 25, 2016, though it failed to chart. Both singles are on the album ''Something's Going On'', which was released on March 31, 2017, via Wheelhouse Records, and its title track became a video.\n\nOn July 4, 2016, Adkins made a surprise appearance at his hometown Independence Day celebration in Sarepta, Louisiana. He joined on stage the Backbeat Boogie Band with several unrehearsed songs.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.shreveporttimes.com/story/life/luxuryliving/sceneandheard/2016/07/16/trace-adkins-headlines-sarepta-july-4-celebration/87079488/|title=Trace Adkins headlines Sarepta July 4 celebration|author=Maggie Martin|newspaper=[[The Times (Shreveport)|The Shreveport Times]]|date=July 16, 2016|access-date=July 17, 2016}}</ref>\n\nIn 2019, Adkins appeared on [[Hardy (singer)|Hardy]]'s new album, ''Hixtape Volume 1''. On the album, he appears on the song \"Redneck Tendencies\" with [[Joe Diffie]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://traceadkins.com/blogs/news/trace-adkins-to-take-part-in-hardys-hixtape-volume-1-project|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20200930183206/https://traceadkins.com/blogs/news/trace-adkins-to-take-part-in-hardys-hixtape-volume-1-project|archive-date = 2020-09-30|title = Trace Adkins to Take Part in Hardy's \"HIXTAPE Volume 1\" Project &#124; Latest News| date=12 September 2019 }}</ref> also in 2019, Adkins later reunited with Blake Shelton in [[Hell Right]] in Shelton's completion album [[Fully Loaded: God's Country]]\n\n===Spokesperson===\nIn 2012, Adkins signed a deal with [[truck stop]] chain [[Pilot Flying J]] to become the company's new spokesman.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pilotflyingj.com/country-music-star-trace-adkins-to-serve-as-spokesperson-for-pilot-flying-j-the-driver-driven-company |title=Pilot Flying J |publisher=Pilot Flying J |date=2012-02-17 |access-date=2013-05-14}}</ref> Adkins also lent his signature voice to Firestone as part of the \"Drive a Firestone\" campaign to revitalize the brand in 2012.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://979kickfm.com/country-stars-and-their-product-endorsements/|title = Country Stars and Their Product Endorsements| date=October 2013 }}</ref>\n\n== Television career ==\nAdkins was a January\u2013March 2008 contestant on NBC's ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. season 7)|The Celebrity Apprentice]]''.<ref name=\"game\"/> Each celebrity contestant was playing for donations to their selected charity. Adkins played for the [[Food Allergy Research & Education|Food Allergy & Anaphylaxis Network]]. Adkins chose the charity because his daughter suffers from life-threatening reactions to peanuts, milk, and eggs. Ultimately, he was the runner-up of that season, losing to [[Piers Morgan]].\n\nAdkins returned for the All-Stars version of ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. season 13)|The All-Star Celebrity Apprentice]]''. He was the project manager for his team, Plan B, in the first task, which was to sell meatballs and won $670,072, a Celebrity Apprentice record for a first task, for his charity [[The American Red Cross]]. Together with Vegas illusionist [[Penn Jillette]], Adkins made it to the finals again (becoming the first and only person in the history of the show to do so), where Adkins won and became The All-Star Celebrity Apprentice. He also broke the record for the highest amount of money raised for his charity by any one person in the history of the show, with $1,524,072 raised for the American Red Cross.\n\nIn 2019, Adkins became the host of a new series on [[INSP (TV network)|INSP]], ''[[Ultimate Cowboy Showdown]]''.  The series has run for three seasons.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.wfla.com/daytime/trace-adkins-talks-season-3-of-ultimate-cowboy-showdown/ | title=Trace Adkins talks season 3 of 'Ultimate Cowboy Showdown' | date=21 April 2022 }}</ref>\n\n==Filmography==\n===Film===\n{| class=\"wikitable sortable\"\n|- \n! 4th one in production\n|-\n| 2022 || ''[[Monarch (American TV series)|Monarch]]'' || Albie Roman || Main cast\n|-\n| 2023 || ''[[Barmageddon]]'' || Himself || Episode: \"[[Mike Vrabel]] vs. Trace Adkins\"\n|}\n\n==Personal life==\nAdkins has two daughters, Tarah and Sarah, with his first wife, Barbara Lewis, and three daughters with his third wife, the former Rhonda Forlaw: Mackenzie, Brianna, and Trinity. Adkins endorsed [[Mitt Romney]] and performed at the [[2012 Republican National Convention]] in [[Tampa|Tampa, Florida]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/reliable-source/post/tampa-musical-acts-some-republican-stalwarts-but-others-cross-party-lines/2012/08/27/9ebd9db0-f08b-11e1-adc6-87dfa8eff430_blog.html |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130412034141/http://articles.washingtonpost.com/2012-08-27/lifestyle/35492328_1_bebe-winans-democratic-convention-gop-convention  |archive-date=2013-04-12 |title=Tampa musical acts: Some Republican stalwarts, but others cross party lines |newspaper=Washington Post|date=2012-08-12 |access-date=2013-05-14}}</ref> He performed the National Anthem at Tennessee governor [[Bill Haslam]]'s second inauguration in 2015 and a year later during candidate [[Donald Trump]]'s nomination at the 2016 Republican National Convention [https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/513891-former-celebrity-apprentice-star-trace-adkins-sings-at-gop-convention].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tennessean.com/picture-gallery/news/politics/2015/01/17/gov-bill-haslam-2015-inauguration/21924177/ |title=Gov Bill Haslam 2015 inauguration |website=Tennessean.com |date=2015-01-17 |access-date=2020-04-03}}</ref>\n\nAt age 17, Adkins was in an automobile accident in which his 1955 Chevrolet pickup truck hit a school bus head-on. He broke some ribs, punctured both lungs and his nose was partially torn off.<ref name=\"wideopencountry.com\">{{cite web |url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/insane-life-trace-adkins/ |title=Did You Know Trace Adkins Was Shot and Survived a Hurricane? |website=www.wideopencountry.com |access-date=15 January 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190704225825/https://www.wideopencountry.com/insane-life-trace-adkins/ |archive-date=4 July 2019 |url-status=dead}}</ref> Adkins was forced to give up [[college football]] after a severe knee injury at Louisiana Tech. He has also experienced a number of serious injuries as an adult, including being shot by his second ex-wife Julie Curtis in 1994.<ref>{{cite web|author=John Geromeap |url=http://www.nevadaappeal.com/article/20071213/ENTERTAINMENT/71212016 |title=Trace Adkins' life an open book with 'A Personal Stand' |publisher=NevadaAppeal.com |date=2007-12-13 |access-date=2011-12-08}}</ref> The bullet went through his heart and both lungs. He survived and chose not to press charges. They got divorced after 3 years.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Samantha|title=Mr. Invincible|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20122480,00.html|access-date=January 11, 2015|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=June 23, 1997}}</ref> In 1989, Adkins, along with nine coworkers, were stranded on an offshore oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico during [[Hurricane Chantal (1989)|Hurricane Chantal]].<ref name=\"wideopencountry.com\"/>\n\nIn 2001, Adkins entered a 28-day alcohol rehabilitation facility. After relapsing in early 2014, Adkins checked into rehabilitation for [[alcoholism]] after getting into an altercation on a cruise ship.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20776357,00.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116000434/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20776357,00.html|archive-date=2014-01-16|title=Trace Adkins Checks into Rehab}}</ref> In March 2014, Rhonda filed for divorce citing irreconcilable differences.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/03/27/trace-adkins-divorce_n_5043981.html | work=Huffington Post | title=Trace Adkins Is Getting Divorced After 18 Years Of Marriage | date=2014-03-27}}</ref> Rhonda  and Trace then dismissed  and expunged the divorce petition via T.C.A. Section 36-4-127 (Expunction of Divorce Records upon Reconciliation of Parties) due to an attempted reconciliation.<ref name=\":0\">'Adkins v. Adkins'', 2023 Tenn. App. LEXIS 344, *3</ref> Less than a month later, Trace filed for divorce. Since this time, the matter has been pending, with the parties awaiting finalization of their divorce. On August 24, 2023, the Tennessee Court of Appeals finalized said divorce.<ref name=\":0\" /> The case has now been remanded to the lower court.\n\nOn October 12, 2019, Adkins married Canadian actress [[Victoria Pratt]] in [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.today.com/today/tdna164562|title=Blake Shelton officiated pal Trace Adkins' wedding to Victoria Pratt|last=Cappadona|first=Bryanna|work=[[Today (American TV program)|NBC Today]]|date=October 14, 2019|access-date=November 6, 2019}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Trace Adkins discography}}\n\n===Studio albums===\n*1996: ''[[Dreamin' Out Loud]]''\n*1997: ''[[Big Time (Trace Adkins album)|Big Time]]''\n*1999: ''[[More... HARD TARGET) |website=ASCAP |publisher=American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers |access-date=April 27, 2023}}</ref>\n}}\n'''Redneck Souljers''' are an American [[country rap]] duo from [[Winchester, Tennessee]], composed of rappers Wesley \"Fatt Tarr\" Alonso and Christopher \"C-Hubb\" Walls. They were formed in 2009 as a novelty act, parodying popular hits and remixing songs in a [[Country rap|hick-hop]] style, then in 2013 they went \"serious\" with their debut ''Tiller Gang'' release.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/redneck-souljers-mn0003255572/biography|title=Redneck Souljers {{!}} Biography & History {{!}} AllMusic|last=Jeffries|first=David|website=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=October 3, 2018}}</ref> Their first full-length studio album, ''Firewater'', debuted on the [[Billboard charts|''Billboard'' charts]].\n\n== Discography ==\n;Studio albums\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|+List of studio albums, with selected chart positions\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jessie_James_Decker","to":"Jessie James Decker"}],"pages":{"18442704":{"pageid":18442704,"ns":0,"title":"Jessie James Decker","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country pop singer (born 1988)}}\n{{Redirect|Jessie James|the outlaw|Jesse James|the self-titled album|Jessie James (album)}}\n{{For|people with similar names|Jessica James (disambiguation){{!}}Jessica James}}\n{{Use American English|date=August 2022}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name         = Jessie James Decker\n| image        = Jessie James at the Tour for the Troops concert in Incirlik Air Base 01 (cropped).JPG\n| caption      = Decker in 2009\n| birth_name   = Jessica Rose James\n| alias        = Jessie James\n| birth_date   = {{birth date and age|1988|04|12|mf=y}}\n| birth_place  = [[Vicenza]], [[Veneto]], Italy\n| genre        = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[Pop music|pop]]<ref name=allmusic>Leahey, Andrew. \"[{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1141239|pure_url=yes}} Jessie James > Overview]\" [[Allmusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]]. Retrieved June 24, 2010.</ref>}}\n| occupation   = Singer\n| years_active = 2003\u2013present\n| label        = {{hlist|[[Mercury Records|Mercury]]|[[The Island Def Jam Music Group|Island Def Jam]]|[[Show Dog Nashville|Show Dog-Universal Music]]|[[Epic Records|Epic]]|[[Warner Music Nashville]]}}\n| website      = {{URL|jessiejamesdecker.com}}\n| spouse = {{Marriage|[[Eric Decker]]|June 22, 2013}}\n}}\n\n'''Jessica Rose James Decker''' (born April 12, 1988) is an American [[country pop]] singer. At age 15, after auditioning for and being rejected by most of the country labels in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], Decker began working with Carla Wallace of Big Yellow Dog Music. One of her songs attracted the attention of [[Mercury Records]], which offered her a recording contract. She released her debut album, ''[[Jessie James (album)|Jessie James]]'', in 2009. A few years later in 2013, she starred with her husband [[Eric Decker]], a [[wide receiver]] in the [[National Football League]], in the [[E!]] reality show ''[[Eric & Jessie: Game On]]''.\n\nOn April 18, 2014, Decker released an EP through [[iTunes]] entitled ''[[Comin' Home (EP)|Comin' Home]]''.<ref name=\"iTunes-2014\">{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/comin-home-ep/id863025641?ign-mpt=uo%3D2 |title=Comin Home \u2013 EP by Jessie James Decker |publisher=iTunes Store |date=April 18, 2014 |access-date=July 6, 2014}}</ref> On [[Epic Records|Epic]] in 2017, she released a five-track EP, ''[[Gold (Jessie James Decker EP)|Gold]]'', followed by a collaboration on [[Austin John Winkler]]'s 2016 song titled \"Howlin'\" from his debut EP Love Sick Radio and released a surprise live EP on June 9, 2017, titled ''[[Blackbird Sessions]]''. On October 13, 2017, she released her second full-length album and first for Epic Records, ''[[Southern Girl City Lights]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://clizbeats.com/jessie-james-decker-announces-new-album-southern-girl-city-lights-out-october-1354/|title=JESSIE JAMES DECKER ANNOUNCES NEW ALBUM SOUTHERN GIRL CITY LIGHTS OUT OCTOBER 13 \u2013 Clizbeats.com|date=August 29, 2017}}</ref> ''[[On This Holiday]]'', her first full-length Christmas album, was released on October 26, 2018.<ref name=\"apple.com\">{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/on-this-holiday/1438568267|title=On This Holiday by Jessie James Decker|website=[[iTunes]]|date=October 26, 2018}}</ref>\n\nOn October 22, 2021, she released the EP [[The Woman I've Become (EP)|''The Woman I've Become'']]. The project spawned a headlining tour, which wrapped in August 2022 after hitting major cities across the nation.<ref name=\"Iahn\">{{Cite web |last=Iahn |first=Buddy |date=2022-09-30 |title=Jessie James Decker releases fan favorite 'Grow Young With You' |url=https://themusicuniverse.com/jessie-james-decker-releases-fan-favorite-grow-young-with-you/ |access-date=2022-10-01 |website=The Music Universe |language=en-US}}</ref> On September 30, 2022 \"Grow Young With You\" was the first official track from the Big Yellow Dog/Atlantic Records/Warner Music Nashville recording artist since the release of her ''The Woman I've Become'' EP the previous year.<ref name=\"Iahn\"/> On November 2 she released her second holiday EP ''[[Decker the Halls]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hollabaugh |first=Lorie |date=2023-11-03 |title=Jessie James Decker Celebrates The Season With Festive New EP |url=https://musicrow.com/2023/11/jessie-james-decker-celebrates-the-season-with-festive-new-ep/ |access-date=2023-11-04 |website=MusicRow.com |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nDecker was born Jessica Rose James on April 12, 1988, in [[Vicenza]], in the Italian [[Regions of Italy|region]] of [[Veneto]] on an American military base<ref name=allmusic/><ref name=\"bio\">{{cite web |url=http://www.thisisjessiejames.com/bio.aspx |title= Jessie James Official Website|website=www.thisisjessiejames.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100305073329/http://www.thisisjessiejames.com/bio.aspx |archive-date=March 5, 2010}}</ref> to her mother, Karen Johnson and father Robert James. Her stepfather, Steve Parker, who Karen married in the early 2000s, served in the [[United States Air Force|U.S. Air Force]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Eisenband|first1=Jeff|title=Eric Decker, Jessie James Create New Foundation From Personal Experiences|url=http://www.thepostgame.com/blog/good-sports/201407/eric-decker-jessie-james-decker-foundation-dogs-new-york-jets-denver-broncos|website=ThePostGame|publisher=Sports Media Ventures, Inc.|access-date=December 26, 2016}}</ref> As a result, she lived in [[Iowa]], [[Kentucky]], [[Texas]], [[Louisiana]], and [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. She graduated from Warner Robins High School in Warner Robins, GA in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Perry|first1=Clayton|title=Interview: Jessie James \u2013 Singer and Songwriter|url=http://blogcritics.org/interview-jessie-james-singer-and-songwriter/|website=Blogcritics Magazine|publisher=WordPress|access-date=December 26, 2016}}</ref> Decker has two younger siblings, Sydney Rae Bass (born 1991) and John James (born 1994), two stepsiblings, Ashley and Alex Parker (from Steve's first marriage) and two siblings-in-law, [[Anthony Bass]] and Alison James (formerly Green).\n\nDecker began singing when she was two. She won her first talent contest in [[Baker, Louisiana]], at age nine, singing \"[[I Want to Be a Cowboy's Sweetheart]]\". By then, she had already been writing songs on a plastic guitar and had performed at [[SeaWorld]] and in [[Warner Robins, Georgia]] in 2000. At age fifteen, she made weekly trips to Nashville to hone her songwriting skills.\n\n==Career==\n=== Music ===\nAt seventeen, Decker was introduced to Carla Wallace of independent label Big Yellow Dog Music, who helped her with her songwriting and singing. One of her songs, \"Gypsy Girl\", was written with two writers from Yellow Dog and made it into the hands of record executive [[David Massey (music executive)|David Massey]], who brought her to the attention of [[L.A. Reid]]. She auditioned for Reid by singing her song \"My Cowboy\", produced by [[John Rich (musician)|John Rich]]. Decker soon signed a contract with [[Mercury Records]].<ref name=billboard>{{cite magazine |first=Alisa |last=Kolenovic|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/268369/jessie-james |title=Jessie James |magazine=Billboard |date=June 15, 2009 |access-date=July 6, 2014}}</ref>\n\nEven though she originally thought that she would be producing a country record, Decker was later told to record a pop album by record executives.<ref name=rough/> She also claimed to have been asked to sound like pop singer [[Britney Spears]].<ref name=cmt>{{cite web|first=Chris |last=Parton |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1680698/jessie-james-reloads-for-another-shot-in-country.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311065806/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1680698/jessie-james-reloads-for-another-shot-in-country.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=March 11, 2012 |title=Jessie James Reloads for Another Shot in Country |publisher=CMT |date=March 7, 2012 |access-date=March 26, 2012}}</ref> She described the recording process as \"intense\" due to the genre crossing.<ref name=rough>{{cite web |first=Matt |last=Bjorke |url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/new-artist-spotlight-meet-jessie-james |title=New Artist Spotlight: Meet Jessie James |publisher=Roughstock.com |access-date=March 26, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120413211427/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/new-artist-spotlight-meet-jessie-james |archive-date=April 13, 2012 |url-status=dead}}</ref> She described herself in an interview as \"a country girl at heart,\" having grown up listening to this music.<ref name=beatweek/>\n\nHer debut album, ''Jessie James'', was released in August 2009, debuting at number 23 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. It was a fusion between country and pop music, with more emphasis placed on the latter as dictated by her label. The album also featured writing credits from Decker and seasoned pop songwriter [[Kara DioGuardi]] and [[Mitch Allan]], among others.<ref name=beatweek>{{cite web |url=http://www.beatweek.com/music/musicianinterviews/7003-jessie-james-interview/ |title=Jessie James interview |work=Beatweek |date=September 7, 2010 |access-date=October 14, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=September 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The album received mixed receptions from critics. [[Allmusic]] received the album positively, but found that despite being marketed as such and featuring some country-influenced production, the music on the album was a far cry from country music.<ref>{{cite web|last=Thomas |first=Stephen |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/r1612463/review |title=Jessie James \u2013 Jessie James |website=AllMusic |date=August 11, 2009 |access-date=March 26, 2012}}</ref> ''[[Slant (magazine)|Slant]]'' thought that the album only superficially pulled together influences from pop, country and hip-hop while failing to pander to any of those audiences.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.slantmagazine.com/music/review/jessie-james-jessie-james/1802 |title=Jessie James: Jessie James &#124; Music Review |work=Slant Magazine |date=August 10, 2009 |access-date=March 26, 2012}}</ref> The album's first single, \"[[Wanted (Jessie James song)|Wanted]]\", produced by Allan, had been released in April and peaked at number 40 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].\n\nDecker later performed in the Middle East with singer [[Kid Rock]] and comedian [[Carlos Mencia]] for US troops stationed overseas.<ref name=bio/>\n\nDecker began working on her second album, ''Sweet American Dreams'',<ref name=title/> in 2010, which was initially planned to be released in late summer.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.beatweek.com/news/6760-jessie-james-reveals-new-album-title-daughter-of-a-gypsy/ |archive-url=https://archive.today/20120730001917/http://www.beatweek.com/news/6760-jessie-james-reveals-new-album-title-daughter-of-a-gypsy/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=July 30, 2012 |title=Jessie James reveals new album title: Daughter of a Gypsy |work=Beatweek |date=July 16, 2010 |access-date=October 14, 2011 }}</ref> The album was to have the same country-pop sound as her debut, with Decker being given more leeway by Mercury in incorporating country sounds.<ref name=beatweek/> The first single, \"Boys in the Summer\", released in June, was a minor country success but failed to chart on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100. Having struggled with accepting her career path as a pop singer, Decker told her label in the midst of preparations for her album that she did not want to be a pop artist and wanted to record country music.<ref name=cmt/> After negotiations, Massey asked Mark Wright from [[Show Dog-Universal Music]], which had facilitated the country release of \"Boys in the Summer\" in November, to help Mercury/IDJ launch Decker in the country genre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allaccess.com/nashville-iq/archive/12336/headline-of-the-day---january-18-2012 |title=Headline of the Day \u2013 January 18, 2012|website=Allaccess.com |date=January 18, 2012 |access-date=March 26, 2012}}</ref> Decker began recording in April 2011.<ref name=\"title\">https://www.twitter.com/iamjessiejames/status/54724151990165504 {{dead link|date=September 2015}}</ref> \"When You Say My Name\" was produced by Wright and released on January 31, 2012. \"Military Man\" was released on May 22, 2012. She was removed from the Show Dog Universal roster in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sdumusic.com/artists.html |title=Artists |publisher=Show Dog \u2013 Universal Music |access-date=July 6, 2014}}</ref> Decker released an extended play, ''Comin' Home'', on April 18, 2014, which hit number one on iTunes top albums chart and debuted in the top 5 on ''Billboard''{{'}}s top country albums chart.<ref name=\"iTunes-2014\" />\n\nDecker was featured on former [[Hinder]] lead singer [[Austin John]]'s debut solo EP ''Love Sick Radio'', on the track \"Howlin'\". The EP was released April 22, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01DUSSVS6?ie=UTF8&keywords=austin%20john&qid=1461006530&ref_=sr_1_4&sr=8-4 |title=Howlin' (feat. Jessie James Decker) |website=Amazon.com |access-date=July 26, 2016}}</ref>\n\nShe finished the ''Lights Down Low'' tour. On her new label Epic she released a five-track EP, ''Gold'', on February 17, 2017, and released a surprise live EP on June 9, 2017, titled ''Blackbird Sessions''. On October 13, 2017, she released her second full-length album and first for Epic Records, ''Southern Girl City Lights''.\n\nOn November 27, 2017, Decker appeared in 12 Days of Cracker Barrel campaign, ending on December 8.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://shop.crackerbarrel.com/12-days-of-cracker-barrel|title=12 Days of Cracker Barrel \u2013 Cracker Barrel Old Country Store|website=shop.crackerbarrel.com}}</ref> Each day got a new YouTube video in the style of the original [[The Twelve Days of Christmas (song)|\"The Twelve Days of Christmas\" song]].\n\nOn April 3, 2022, Decker performed \"[[America the Beautiful]]\", in front of a nearly 80,000 crowd at WWE's WrestleMania 38, at AT&T Stadium, in Dallas, Texas.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.people.com/country/brantley-gilbert-jessie-james-decker-to-sing-america-the-beautiful-wrestlemania-38/%3famp=true}}</ref>\n\nOn November 23,2023 during the 97th Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade she celebrated the holidays with a performance of \u201cTangled in Tinsel\u201d live for the first time.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hollabaugh |first=Lorie |date=2023-11-03 |title=Jessie James Decker Celebrates The Season With Festive New EP |url=https://musicrow.com/2023/11/jessie-james-decker-celebrates-the-season-with-festive-new-ep/ |access-date=2023-12-17 |website=MusicRow.com |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n=== Reality television ===\nIn 2013, Decker starred with her husband [[Eric Decker]], a [[wide receiver]] in the [[National Football League]], in the [[E!]] reality show ''[[Eric & Jessie: Game On]].'' It ended its run in April 2014, but returned in September 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2013/11/e-renews-total-divas-eric-jessie-hello-ross-for-second-season-643091/|title=E! Renews 'Total Divas', 'Eric & Jessie' & 'Hello Ross' For Second Season|date=November 25, 2013|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|access-date=August 12, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2013/04/e-orders-wwe-divas-jessie-james-eric-decker-reality-series-ross-mathews-talk-show-will-develop-the-soup-spinoff-480422/|title=E! Orders WWE Divas, Jessie James & Eric Decker Reality Series, Ross Mathews Talk Show, Will Develop 'The Soup' Spinoff|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|date=April 22, 2013|work=Deadline Hollywood|access-date=August 12, 2016}}</ref> It ran for 20 episodes in three seasons.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.eonline.com/shows/eric_and_jessie/news/863380/eric-jessie-is-back-get-the-scoop-on-season-3-of-eric-decker-and-jessie-james-decker-s-hit-e-show|title=Eric & Jessie Is Back! Get the Scoop on Season 3 of Eric Decker and Jessie James Decker's Hit E! Show on Eric And Jessie|work=E! Online|access-date=June 28, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nOn September 8, 2022, Decker was announced as a contestant on [[Dancing with the Stars (American season 31)|season 31]] of [[Dancing with the Stars (American TV series)|''Dancing with the Stars'']]. She was partnered with [[Alan Bersten]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Dancing with the Stars: Teresa Giudice, Wayne Brady, Selma Blair and More Celebs Join Season 31 |url=https://people.com/tv/dancing-with-the-stars-season-31-cast-reveal/ |access-date=2022-09-08 |website=Peoplemag |language=en}}</ref> She finished in 10th place.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Rice |first1=Lynette |date=2022-10-25 |title='Dancing With The Stars': A Reality Star Survives But A Singer Goes Home On Michael Bubl\u00e9 Night |url=https://deadline.com/2022/10/dancing-with-the-stars-recap-michael-buble-night-1235153981/ |access-date=2022-11-08 |website=Deadline |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n=== Kittenish ===\nDecker launched a clothing line called Kittenish online.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/jessie-james-decker-and-justfab-launch-partnership-this-fall-1027571711|title=Jessie James Decker and JustFab Launch Partnership This Fall {{!}} Markets Insider|last=GmbH|first=finanzen net|website=markets.businessinsider.com|access-date=March 3, 2019}}</ref> Kittenish opened its first physical location in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], Tennessee.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://people.com/style/jessie-james-decker-opens-kittenish-store-nashville/|title=Jessie James Decker Opens First Kittenish Store in Nashville: 'It's Fun, Flirty and Fabulous'|website=PEOPLE.com|language=en|access-date=March 3, 2019}}</ref> A second branch is located near Destin, Florida.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.foxnews.com/lifestyle/jessie-james-decker-kittenish-store-location|title=Jessie James Decker announces second Kittenish store location|date=May 17, 2019|website=New York Post|language=en-US|access-date=May 18, 2019}}</ref>\n\n==Musical style and influences==\nDecker co-wrote the majority of the songs on her debut album.<ref name=blogcritics>{{cite web |url=http://blogcritics.org/music/article/interview-jessie-james-singer-and-songwriter/ |title=Interview: Jessie James \u2013 Singer and Songwriter |publisher= Blogcritics.org |access-date=August 31, 2010}}</ref> The album is of a country-pop fusion genre, revealing her taste for not only country music, but pop and soul music as well.<ref name=blogcritics/>\n\nThe beat for \"Blue Jeans\" was a recording of Decker [[Stepping (African-American)|stepping]]; this talent stems from her time on the step team at her school.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artistdirect.com/nad/news/article/0,,5289793,00.html |title=Interview: Jessie James @ARTISTdirect |publisher=Artistdirect.com |access-date=September 18, 2015}}</ref> Initially, she faced opposition for her soul music-inspired vocal runs when trying to get signed in Nashville.<ref name=blogcritics/>\n\nShe has listed [[Christina Aguilera]], [[Jessica Simpson]], [[Bobbie Gentry]], [[Janis Joplin]], [[Shelby Lynne]], and [[Shania Twain]] as her musical influences.<ref name=blogcritics/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://top40.about.com/b/2009/05/28/artist-in-the-wings-jessie-james.htm |title=Artist in the Wings \u2013 Jessie James |publisher=Top40.about.com |date=May 28, 2009 |access-date=August 31, 2010 |archive-date=June 29, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629200745/http://top40.about.com/b/2009/05/28/artist-in-the-wings-jessie-james.htm |url-status=dead }}</ref> She has said that she initially wanted a career similar to those of Gentry and Twain, who were signed to pop labels but found crossover success in both country and pop music.<ref name=blogcritics/>\n\n==Personal life==\nOn June 22, 2013, Jessie married [[Eric Decker]], an NFL wide receiver who at the time played for the [[Denver Broncos]].<ref>{{cite web|first=Tim |last=Keeney |url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1682193-eric-decker-and-jessie-james-wedding-attendees-photos-and-details |title=Eric Decker and Jessie James Wedding: Attendees, Photos and Details |website=Bleacher Report |date=June 23, 2013 |access-date=July 6, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/index.php/2012/04/03/singer_jessie_james_engaged_to_broncos |title=Singer Jessie James Engaged To Broncos' Eric Decker |publisher=Starpulse.com |date=April 3, 2012 |access-date=April 12, 2012 |archive-date=October 23, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141023165805/http://www.starpulse.com/news/index.php/2012/04/03/singer_jessie_james_engaged_to_broncos |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2012/extramustard/hotclicks/04/02/eric-decker-jessie-james-engaged-wrestelmania-xxviii-recap/index.html |title=Jessie James-Eric Decker engaged; WrestleMania XXVIII recap: Hot Clicks |magazine=Sports Illustrated |date=April 2, 2012 |access-date=April 12, 2012 |archive-date=April 5, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120405005816/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2012/extramustard/hotclicks/04/02/eric-decker-jessie-james-engaged-wrestelmania-xxviii-recap/index.html |url-status=dead }}</ref> They have four children.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://people.com/jessie-james-decker-is-pregnant-singer-expecting-baby-no-4-7734934|title=Jessie James Decker Is Pregnant! Singer Expecting Baby No. 4 with Husband Eric Decker|website=people.com|access-date=August 22, 2023|date=August 22, 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n!
