<https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"JJ_Lawhorn","to":"JJ Lawhorn"}],"pages":{"40144076":{"pageid":40144076,"ns":0,"title":"JJ Lawhorn","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country music singer-songwriter (born 1993)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = JJ Lawhorn\n| image           =\n| image_size      =\n| landscape       =\n| alt             =\n| caption         =\n| birth_name      = Jonathan Wayne Lawhorn\n| birth_date      = {{birth-date and age|September 1993}}\n| birth_place     = [[Hanover County, Virginia]]\n| origin          =\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar, banjo\n| years_active    = 2010\u2013present\n| label           = [[Average Joes Entertainment]] {{small|(former)}}\n| associated_acts = [[Justin Moore]]<br />[[Jeremy Stover]]<br />[[Ryan Upchurch]]\n| website         = {{URL|http://jjlawhorn.com/}}\n}}\n'''Jonathan Wayne \"JJ\" Lawhorn''' (born September 1993) in [[Hanover County, Virginia]]) is an American [[country music]] singer-songwriter. Lawhorn was discovered online by producer [[Jeremy Stover]] in 2010.<ref name=\"theboot\">{{cite news|last=Whitaker|first=Sterling|title=JJ Lawhorn Interview: Newcomer Talks Debut Album, 'Original Good Ol' Boy'|url=http://theboot.com/jj-lawhorn-interview-2013/|access-date=March 4, 2014|newspaper=The Boot|date=July 17, 2013}}</ref> He signed with [[EMI Music Publishing]] within a year.<ref name=\"gac\">{{cite news|last=Doerschuk|first=Bob|title=New Artist Spotlight: JJ Lawhorn|url=http://blog.gactv.com/blog/2013/07/24/new-artist-spotlight-jj-lawhorn/|access-date=March 4, 2014|newspaper=[[Great American Country]]|date=July 24, 2013}}</ref> He signed a recording contract with [[Average Joes Entertainment]], a record label owned by [[Colt Ford]], in June 2011 when he was 17 years old.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|last=Leggett|first=Steve|title=JJ Lawhorn {{!}} Biography|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=mn0002738497/biography|pure_url=yes}}|work=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=March 4, 2014}}</ref>\n\nLawhorn's debut album, ''Original Good Ol' Boy'', was released by Average Joes on July 16, 2013.<ref name=\"theboot\" /> The album was produced by Stover.<ref name=\"gac\" /> Lawhorn wrote or co-wrote all thirteen tracks.<ref name=\"allmusic\" /> Matt Bjorke of ''Roughstock'' gave the album four stars out of five, calling Lawhorn \"an artist well worth seeking out.\"<ref>{{cite news|last=Bjorke|first=Matt|title=Album Review: JJ Lawhorn \u2013 Original Good Ol' Boy|url=http://www.roughstock.com/reviews/album-review-jj-lawhorn-original-good-ol-boy|access-date=March 4, 2014|newspaper=Roughstock|date=July 16, 2013|archive-url=https://archive.today/20140304190936/http://www.roughstock.com/reviews/album-review-jj-lawhorn-original-good-ol-boy|archive-date=March 4, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref> The album sold 4,000 copies in its first week of release, debuting at number 20 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart and number 91 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Bjorke|first=Matt|title=Country Album Chart News: The Week of July 24, 2013: Travis Tritt, Luke Bryan, Florida Georgia Line, Jason Aldean, Blake Shelton, Hunter Hayes, Mud Digger 4|url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/country-album-chart-news-the-week-of-july-24-2013-travis-tritt-luke-bryan-florida-georgia-line-jason-aldean-blake-shelton-hunter-hayes-mud-digger-4|access-date=March 4, 2014|newspaper=Roughstock|date=July 24, 2013|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005103309/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/country-album-chart-news-the-week-of-july-24-2013-travis-tritt-luke-bryan-florida-georgia-line-jason-aldean-blake-shelton-hunter-hayes-mud-digger-4|archive-date=October 5, 2013}}</ref>\n\nThe single \"Good Ol' Boys Like Us\" was released to country radio on February 17, 2014.<ref>{{cite news|last=Thompson|first=Gayle|title=JJ Lawhorn Releasing New Single|url=http://theboot.com/jj-lawhorn-good-ol-boys-like-us/|access-date=March 4, 2014|newspaper=The Boot|date=February 13, 2014}}</ref> The song received a favorable review from Taste of Country, which called it \"a great lyric and a strong vocal performance.\"<ref>{{cite news|title=JJ Lawhorn \u2013 'Good Ol' Boys Like Us' [Listen]|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/jj-lawhorn-good-ol-boys-like-us/|access-date=March 4, 2014|newspaper=Taste of Country|date=February 17, 2014}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nLawhorn graduated from [[Hanover High School (Mechanicsville, Virginia)|Hanover High School]] in [[Mechanicsville, Virginia]].\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Marty_Brown_(singer)","to":"Marty Brown (singer)"}],"pages":{"16296894":{"pageid":16296894,"ns":0,"title":"Marty Brown (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name                = Marty Brown\n| image                 = \n| caption            = \n| image_size            = \n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          = Dennis Martin Brown<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=65|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref>\n| birth_date                = {{Birth date and age|1965|07|25}}\n| origin              = [[Maceo, Kentucky]], United States\n| instrument          = Vocals<br />rhythm guitar\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = 1991\u20131996, 2013\u2013present\n| label               = [[MCA Records|MCA]]<br />[[HighTone Records|HighTone]]<br />Plowboy Records\n| associated_acts     = \n| website                 = http://www.martybrownmusic.com\n}}\n'''Dennis Marty Brown''' (born July 25, 1965) is an American [[country music]] artist. Active between 1991 and 1996, he has released six studio albums and has charted one single on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. Marty Brown and his wife, Shellie, currently reside in Simpson County, Franklin, Kentucky, since July 2004.\n\n==Career==\nBrown's first recording contract was with [[MCA Records]] in 1991. While on that label, he recorded three studio albums: 1991's ''High and Dry'', 1993's ''Wild Kentucky Skies'', and 1994's ''Cryin', Lovin', Leavin'''. Although all three of these albums received critical acclaim for his [[neotraditionalist country]] style and solid songwriting,<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1536/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Marty Brown biography |access-date=March 14, 2008 |last=Huey |first=Steve |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref><ref name=\"oldies\">{{cite web |url=http://www.oldies.com/artist-biography/Marty-Brown.html |title=Marty Brown biography |access-date=March 14, 2008 |work=Oldies.com}}</ref> none of them produced any major hits.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> His fourth studio album, ''Here's to the Honky Tonks'', was released in 1996 on [[HighTone Records]].  He also co-wrote [[Tracy Byrd]]'s \"[[I'm from the Country (song)|I'm from the Country]]\", [[Perfect Stranger (band)|Perfect Stranger]]'s \"The Hits\", [[Trace Adkins]]' \"When I Stop Loving You\", [[Brooks & Dunn]]' \"It Ain't Me If It Ain't You\", and [[William Michael Morgan]]' \"I Pulled a Hank\".\n\nBrown was a contestant on [[America's Got Talent (season 8)|season eight]] of ''[[America's Got Talent]]'' and advanced as far as the semi-final rounds.  After competing on ''America's Got Talent'', he signed a record deal with Independent Label, Dreamlined Entertainment. His new single, Make You Feel My Love, was available for download on February 5, 2016. Brown is currently signed to Plowboy Records in Nashville. Brown released his first studio album in 25 years, American Highway on May 17, 2019.  Marty Brown's music career is currently on display at the Kentucky Music Hall of Fame in Mt. Vernon, Kentucky.\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n! actor (born 1970)}}\n{{redirect|Palace Music|the racehorse|Palace Music (horse)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2020}}\n{{Use American English|date=July 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name             = Will Oldham\n| image            = Bonnie-Prince-Billy-060609 (614bw) (3606166772).jpg\n| caption          = Oldham in 2009\n| landscape        = yes\n| image_size       = <!-- Only for images smaller than 220 pixels -->\n| birth_name       =\n| alias            = Palace Brothers<br />Palace Music<br />Palace Songs<br />Bonnie \"Prince\" Billy\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1970|01|15}}\n| birth_place      = [[Louisville, Kentucky]], U.S.\n| origin           = \n| instrument       = \n| genre            = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country rock]]<ref name=Gribbins>{{cite web |url=https://www.clevescene.com/music/white-lies-bishop-allen-and-others-get-graded-1534927 |title=White Lies, Bishop Allen And Others Get Graded |last=Gribbins |first=Keith |date=March 18, 2009 |publisher=CleveScene |access-date=2022-04-14}}</ref>\n* [[freak folk]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2005/10/bjork-the-music-from-drawing-restraint-9.html |title=Bj\u00f6rk: Bj\u00f6rk \u2013 The music from Drawing Restraint 9 |website=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]] |date=June 30, 2008 |access-date=August 8, 2016}}</ref>\n* [[gothic country]]<ref name=Gribbins/>\n* [[Lo-fi music|lo-fi]]<ref name=Gribbins/>\n* [[indie folk]]\n* [[alternative country]]\n}}\n| occupation       = \n| years_active     = 1993\u2013present\n| label            = {{flatlist|\n*[[Drag City (record label)|Drag City]]\n*[[Domino Recording Company|Domino]]\n*Spunk\n}}\n| associated_acts  = [[Faun Fables|Dawn McCarthy]], [[Boxhead Ensemble]], [[Emmett Kelly (musician)|The Cairo Gang]], [[Mekons]], [[Matt Sweeney]], [[Mick Turner]], [[Tortoise (band)|Tortoise]], [[Trembling Bells]], [[Harem Scarem]], The Picket Line, [[Alex Neilson]], [[Bj\u00f6rk]], [[Slint]], [[Silver Jews]], [[Joan Shelley]], [[Bill Callahan (musician)|Bill Callahan]]\n| website          = {{URL|bonnieprincebilly.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Joseph Will Oldham''' (born January 15, 1970) is an American singer-songwriter and actor. From 1993 to 1997, he performed and recorded in collaboration with dozens of other musicians under variations of '''Palace''' (Palace, Palace Brothers, Palace Songs, and Palace Music).<ref>{{Cite web |title=Will Oldham (Bonnie Prince Billy) |url=https://www.wypr.org/podcast/essential-tremors/2022-04-28/will-oldham-bonnie-prince-billy |access-date=2022-06-14 |website=WYPR |language=en}}</ref> After briefly publishing music under his own name, in 1998 he adopted '''Bonnie''' \"'''Prince'''\" '''Billy''' as the name for most of his work.\n\n==Early life and education==\nOldham was born on January 15, 1970, in [[Louisville, Kentucky]].<ref>Alan Licht (Ed.) (2012), ''Will Oldham on Bonnie \"Prince\" Billy''. Faber and Faber Ltd., London, pp. viii. {{ISBN|978-0-571-25814-7}}.</ref> His mother, Joanne Lei Will Tafel Oldham, was a teacher and artist.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Joanne Oldham (1942 - 2020) - Obituary|url=https://www.legacy.com/amp/obituaries/louisville/195122836|access-date=2020-10-23|website=legacy.com}}</ref> His father, Joseph Collins Oldham, was an attorney and photographer.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Joseph Oldham - Obituary|url=https://www.legacy.com/amp/obituaries/louisville/19382161|access-date=2020-10-23|website=legacy.com}}</ref> Oldham graduated from the [[J. Graham Brown School]] in 1988. He attended [[Brown University]] sporadically while pursuing a career as an actor, and living between [[Brooklyn]], [[Los Angeles]], and [[Bloomington, Indiana]].<ref name=\"IPM\">{{cite web | publisher = [Indiana Public Media] | date = February 17, 2016 | author=Adam Schwartz | title = Bonnie \"Prince\" Billy Tells of His Royal Roots | url=https://indianapublicmedia.org/arts/bonnie-prince-billy-tells-of-his-royal-roots.php | access-date = July 14, 2021 }}</ref> He began making music during this time, initially as a project for his professor [[Jeff Todd Titon]], an ethnomusicologist at Brown University.<ref name=\"wire\">{{cite web | publisher = [[The Wire (magazine)|The Wire]] | date = March 14, 2013 | author=Derek Walmsley | title = Exclusive Bonnie 'Prince' Billy Interview | url=http://www.thewire.co.uk/in-writing/interviews/exclusive-bonnie_prince_billy-interview | access-date = January 25, 2016 }}</ref>\n\n== Career ==\n[[File:Will Oldham 2017.jpg|thumb|Oldham in 2017]]\nOldham is known for his \"[[DIY ethic|do-it-yourself]] punk aesthetic and blunt honesty\",<ref name=\"chico\">{{cite web | publisher = Chico News & Review | date = March 28, 2002 | author=Baldwin, C. | title = The Wanderer | url=http://www.newsreview.com/chico/Content?oid=8724 | access-date = May 8, 2007 }}</ref> and his music has been likened to [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[American folk music|folk]], [[Traditional music|roots]], [[country music|country]], [[punk music|punk]], and [[indie rock]]. He has been called an \"[[Appalachia]]n [[post-punk]] [[solipsist]]\",<ref name=\"chico\"/> with a voice that has been described as \"a fragile sort-of warble frittering around haunted melodies in the American folk or country tradition.\"<ref name=\"chico\"/>\n\nOldham first performed and recorded under various permutations of the Palace name, including Palace Brothers, Palace Songs, Palace Music, and simply Palace. Regarding the name changes during this period (1993\u20131997), Oldham said:\n{{cquote|I guess the idea is that when you have a name of a group or an artist, then you expect that the next record, if it has the same name, should be the same group of people playing on it. And I just thought we were making a different kind of record each time, with different people, and different themes, and different sounds. So I thought it was important to call it something different so that people would be aware of the differences.<ref name=\"phoenix\"/>}}\n\nWill stated in a 1995 interview with [[KCRW]] that the name Palace Flophouse was inspired by reading [[John Steinbeck]]'s ''[[Cannery Row (novel)|Cannery Row]]''. Beginning in 1998, Oldham has primarily used the moniker Bonnie 'Prince' Billy, which draws inspiration from several sources:\n{{cquote|[T]he name has so many different references that it could almost have a life of its own. [[Bonnie Prince Charlie]] has such a beautiful ring to it, and I was very conscious of appropriating that mellifluous sound. And I was also thinking about the name [[Nat King Cole]]. But it wasn't until later, and this may have been subconscious, that I remembered that [[Billy the Kid]] was William Bonney or Billy Bonney.<ref name=\"phoenix\">{{cite web | work = [[The Phoenix (newspaper)|The Phoenix]] | date = January 20, 2003 | author = Ashare, Matt | title = Mystery Man: Palace Brother Will Oldham becomes Bonnie 'Prince' Billy | url = http://www.bostonphoenix.com/boston/music/top/documents/02671921.htm | access-date = May 9, 2007 | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20081202151640/http://www.bostonphoenix.com/boston/music/top/documents/02671921.htm | archive-date = December 2, 2008 | df = mdy-all }}</ref>}}\n\nHe has explained that \"the primary purpose of the pseudonym is to allow both the audience and the performer to have a relationship with the performer that is valid and unbreakable.\"<ref>{{cite web | publisher = Foggy Notion |date=April 2003 | title = Bonnie 'Prince' Billy | url=http://www.dragcity.com/press/pimages/pressclips/dc233fn_art.pdf | access-date = May 8, 2007 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070710021351/http://www.dragcity.com/press/pimages/pressclips/dc233fn_art.pdf <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archive-date = July 10, 2007}}</ref>\n\n===Critical reception===\nSome of his albums, such as ''[[There Is No-One What Will Take Care of You]]'' (1993),<ref>{{cite book | last = Irvin | first = Jim |author2=Colin McLear  | title = The Mojo Collection: The Ultimate Music Companion | publisher = Canongate | year = 2003|edition=3rd | page = [https://archive.org/details/mojocollectiongr00jimi/page/585 585] | isbn = 1-84195-438-1 | title-link = The Mojo Collection }}</ref> ''[[Viva Last Blues]]'' (1995),<ref>{{cite web | publisher = Pitchfork Media | date = November 17, 2003 | author = LeMay, Matt | title = The Top 100 Albums of the 1990s | url = http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/feature/36737-staff-list-top-100-albums-of-the-1990s/page_5 | access-date = May 8, 2007 | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070506045834/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/feature/36737-staff-list-top-100-albums-of-the-1990s/page_5 | archive-date = May 6, 2007 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> and ''[[I See a Darkness]]'' (1999),<ref>{{cite book | last = Irvin | first = Jim | author2 = Colin McLear | title = The Mojo Collection: The Ultimate Music Companion | publisher = Canongate | year = 2003 | edition = 3rd | page = [https://archive.org/details/mojocollectiongr00jimi/page/651 651] | isbn = 1-84195-438-1 | url-access = registration | url = https://archive.org/details/mojocollectiongr00jimi/page/651 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | publisher = Pitchfork Media | date = November 17, 2003 | author=Bowers, William | title = The Top 100 Albums of the 1990s | url=http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/feature/36737-staff-list-top-100-albums-of-the-1990s/page_10 | access-date = May 8, 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Dimery | first = Robert | title = 1001 Albums You Must Hear Before You Die | publisher = Universe | year = 2006 | page = [https://archive.org/details/albumsyoumusthea00dime/page/n429 854] | isbn = 0-7893-1371-5 | title-link = 1001 Albums You Must Hear Before You Die }}</ref> have appeared on greatest albums lists.\n \n[[Johnny Cash]] recorded a version of \"I See a Darkness\" on his [[American Recordings (US)|American Recordings]] disc ''[[American III: Solitary Man]]'' (2000). Oldham provided backing vocals. Spanish singer [[Rosal\u00eda]] also recorded a version of \"I See a Darkness\" for her debut album ''[[Los \u00c1ngeles (album)|Los \u00c1ngeles]]''. [[Marianne Faithfull]] included Oldham's \"A King at Night\" on her 2003 ''Kissin Time'' tour. [[Steve Adey]] also covered \"I See a Darkness\" on his 2006 LP ''[[All Things Real]]''. [[Mark Kozelek]] recorded a version of Oldham's \"New Partner\" on his 2008 disc, ''[[The Finally LP]]''. [[Katatonia]] covered \"Oh How I Enjoy the Light\" on their 2001 EP ''[[Tonight's Music]]'', and their song \"Don't Tell a Soul\" is about and contains an interpolation of the Palace Brothers song \"You Will Miss Me When I Burn\". In 2009 [[Mark Lanegan]] and [[Soulsavers]] recorded a cover version of \"You Will Miss Me When I Burn\". The release is a split single, backed with the Lanegan-penned \"Sunrise\" featuring vocals by Oldham. In 2011, [[Deer Tick (band)|Deer Tick]]'s cover of Oldham's song \"Death to Everyone\" appeared in an episode of ''[[Hell on Wheels (TV series)|Hell On Wheels]]''. [[Cadaverous Condition]] covered \"Black\" on their ''To the Night Sky'' album (2006).\n\n===Acting===\n====Film and television====\nOldham's first film acting role was as the teen preacher in [[John Sayles]]'s film ''[[Matewan]]'' (1987), a dramatization of the life of Appalachian mining community in the 1920s and the [[Battle of Matewan]]. Following this, he moved to Hollywood to pursue a career as an actor.<ref name=\"dallasobs\">{{cite news|last=Roberts|first=Randall|date=June 3, 2009|title=Will Oldham's Trouble with Hollywood|publisher=Dallas Observer|url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/2009-06-04/music/will-oldham-s-trouble-with-hollywood/|access-date=January 16, 2010}}</ref> He played the role of Chip McClure (father of [[Jessica McClure|Baby Jessica]]) in ''[[Everybody's Baby: The Rescue of Jessica McClure]]'' (1989), and the role of Miles in the film ''[[Thousand Pieces of Gold (film)|Thousand Pieces of Gold]]'' (1991). Oldham also played minor roles in ''[[Julien Donkey-Boy]]'' (1999), ''[[Junebug (film)|Junebug]]'' (2005), and ''[[The Guatemalan Handshake]]'' (2006).\n\nIn 2004, Oldham appeared as himself in the short documentary film ''Tripping With Caveh'', wherein he took [[psilocybin mushrooms]] with autobiographical filmmaker [[Caveh Zahedi]].<ref name=\"nyt\">''[[New York Times]]'' article: \"[https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/30/magazine/caveh-zahedi-documentary-film.html A Filmmaker Bared His Soul. It Ruined His Life].\"</ref><ref name=\"tripping\">\"[https://vimeo.com/65958992 Tripping With Caveh] on Caveh Zahedi's [[Vimeo]] page.</ref> The project was intended as the pilot episode of a reality/documentary series, with the concept being that Zahedi would take [[psychedelic drug|psychedelics]] in the company of a different celebrity in each episode.<ref name=\"nyt\" /> The project was never picked up by a television network, but the short with Oldham finally saw official release in the 2015 retrospective box set ''Digging My Own Grave: The Films of Caveh Zahedi''.<ref>Factory Twenty Five: \"[https://www.factorytwentyfive.com/shop/digging-my-own-grave Digging My Own Grave].\"</ref>\n\nOldham played a lead role as Kurt in [[Kelly Reichardt]]'s film ''[[Old Joy (film)|Old Joy]]'' (2006), and had a brief role in the director's next film ''[[Wendy and Lucy]]'' (2008). Oldham played Pastor Pigmeat in the \"Horse Apples\" episode of the second season of the [[MTV]] [[children's show]] parody ''[[Wonder Showzen]]'' and appeared in an episode of Chatman and Lee's subsequent television show, ''[[Xavier: Renegade Angel]]'' as a Reverend.<ref>{{Citation |last1=Bertoldo |first1=Marco |title=Signs from Godrilla |date=2008-01-06 |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1171491/?ref_=ttep_ep9 |series=Xavier: Renegade Angel |access-date=2023-03-02 |last2=Chatman |first2=Vernon |last3=Lee |first3=John}}</ref> In 2007, he starred alongside [[Zach Galifianakis]] in a music video for [[Kanye West]]'s \"[[Can't Tell Me Nothing]]\".<ref>[https://www.wired.com/underwire/2007/07/the-kanye-westw/ The Kanye West/Will Oldham/Zach Galifianakis Collabo You Never Saw Coming]. [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]], July 25, 2007. Retrieved on August 23, 2012.</ref>\n\nAlso in 2010, Oldham appeared in ''[[Jackass 3D]]'' as a gorilla trainer. As part of an agreement to play that role, he wrote a theme song, in the style of a Saturday-morning cartoon show, for filmmaker [[Lance Bangs]].<ref>[http://www.buzzgrinder.com/2011/will-oldham-new-album-jackass-3d/ Will Oldham Discusses Jackass 3D, Working on 'Blueprints' for New Album] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110312102807/http://www.buzzgrinder.com/2011/will-oldham-new-album-jackass-3d/ |date=March 12, 2011 }}. Buzzgrinder.com (March 9, 2011). Retrieved on May 4, 2012.</ref>\n\nIn 2011, Oldham played a father telling a bedtime story to his son in [[David Lowery (director)|David Lowery's]] short film ''Pioneer''.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Salovaara |first=Sarah |date=2015-04-22 |title=Watch: David Lowery's Pioneer {{!}} Filmmaker Magazine |url=https://filmmakermagazine.com/93910-watch-david-lowerys-pioneer/ |access-date=2023-10-26 |website=Filmmaker Magazine {{!}} Publication with a focus on independent film, offering articles, links, and resources. |language=en-US}}</ref> In 2017, he appeared as \"Prognosticator\" in the feature film ''[[A Ghost Story]]'', also directed by David Lowery.\n\n====Voice work====\nIn 2009, Oldham narrated ''Madam and Little Boy'', a documentary film about atomic weapons, directed by Swedish artist [[:sv:Magnus B\u00e4rt\u00e5s|Magnus B\u00e4rt\u00e5s]]. In 2010, Oldham narrated ''[[Music Makes a City]]'', a documentary about the formation of the [[Louisville Orchestra]], directed by Owsley Brown III and [[Jerome Hiler]].<ref>{{Cite news|last=Webster|first=Andy|date=September 17, 2010|title=Louisville, Ky., as a Contemporary Music Hub|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/17/movies/17music.html|access-date=May 19, 2020|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>  Oldham provided voice work and inspiration for the character \"Will\" in the video game ''[[Kentucky Route Zero]]'', released in 2013.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.factmag.com/2016/08/23/kentucky-route-zero-ben-babbitt/ | title=Kentucky Route Zero: How Ben Babbitt scored a Lynchian modern classic | date=August 23, 2016 }}</ref>\n\n== Personal life ==\nOldham married the textile artist Elsa Hansen in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Watch Bonnie \"Prince\" Billy Cover Merle Haggard With His Dogs on Morning TV Show \u2013 Pitchfork|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/72956-watch-bonnie-prince-billy-cover-merle-haggard-with-his-dogs-on-morning-tv-show/|access-date=August 2, 2017|website=pitchfork.com|date=April 17, 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Pak|first=Minju|date=April 4, 2017|title=Pop Culture Figures \u2013 Rendered in Embroidery|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/04/t-magazine/elsa-hansen-oldham-art-embroidery-cross-stitching.html|access-date=August 2, 2017}}</ref> They had a child together in 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Episode 40: Will Oldham/Bonnie 'Prince' Billy ClifTones W/ JC Denison podcast|date=December 18, 2018 |url=https://player.fm/series/cliftones-w-jc-denison/episode-40-will-oldhambonnie-prince-billy}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Will Oldham discography}}\n\n=== Studio albums ===\n* ''[[There Is No-One What Will Take Care of You]]'' \u2013 Palace Brothers (1993)<ref>Knott, Alex. 2019}}</ref>\n* ''Superwolves'' \u2013 [[Matt Sweeney]] & Bonnie \"Prince\" Billy (2021)<ref>{{Cite web |last=Carriere |first=Michael |date=2022-03-03 |title=Bonnie \"Prince\" Billy and Matt Sweeney You]]'' \u2013 Bonnie \"Prince\" Billy (2023)\n\n== Filmography ==\n=== Film ===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|+\n!Year\n!Title\n!Role\n!Notes\n|-\n|1985\n|''What Comes Around''\n|Young Tom Honor\"\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n{{Commons category|Will Oldham}}\n* [http://www.bonnieprincebilly.com/ Bonnie \"Prince\" Billy] official website\n* country guitarists]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American folk guitarists]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male guitarists]]\n[[Category:American folk singers]]\n[[Category:Brown University alumni]]\n[[Category:Drag City (record label) artists]]\n[[Category:Domino Recording Company artists]]\n[[Category:Gothic country musicians]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Singers from Louisville, Kentucky]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Kentucky]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Kentucky]]\n[[Category:Folk musicians from Kentucky]]\n[[Category:J. Graham Brown School alumni]]\n[[Category:Guitarists from Kentucky]]\n[[Category:Silver Jews members]]\n[[Category:Boxhead Ensemble members]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American guitarists]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]\n[[Category:Western Vinyl artists]]\n[[Category:Will Oldham| ]]\n[[Category:Record Collection artists]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Keith_Anderson","to":"Keith Anderson"}],"pages":{"2429867":{"pageid":2429867,"ns":0,"title":"Keith Anderson","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country singer (born 1968)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2024}}\n{{other people}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|name            = Keith Anderson\n|image           = Keith Anderson.jpg\n|caption         = Anderson in concert\n|background      = solo_singer\n|birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1968|01|12}}\n|origin          = [[Miami, Oklahoma]], U.S.\n|instrument      = Vocals, guitar\n|genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n|occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n|years_active    = 2001\u2013present<!--since he wrote Beer Run in 2001-->\n|label           = [[Arista Nashville]]<br />[[Sony Music Nashville|Columbia Nashville]]\n|website         = {{URL|keithanderson.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Keith Anderson''' (born January 12, 1968) is an American [[country music]] singer. Before signing to a record deal, Anderson was one of several co-writers on \"Beer Run (B Double E Double R-U-N)\", a duet by [[Garth Brooks]] and [[George Jones]], released in late 2001. Anderson was signed as a recording artist to [[Arista Nashville]] in 2004. His debut single \"[[Pickin' Wildflowers]]\" was released that year, as the lead-off track from his debut album ''[[Three Chord Country and American Rock & Roll]]''. Counting \"Pickin' Wildflowers\", the album produced a total of four hit singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, and was certified gold by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]].\n\nIn addition to his own material, Anderson co-wrote [[Big & Rich]]'s single \"[[Lost in This Moment]]\", a Number One hit on the country music charts in mid-2007. Anderson switched to the [[Columbia Records|Columbia]] label in 2007, and his second album, ''[[C'mon! (Keith Anderson album)|C'mon!]]'', was released on August 5, 2008. The second single from the album, \"[[I Still Miss You]]\", became his first Top 5 country hit.\n\nHis latest release is a six-song EP album titled ''I'll Bring the Music''; it was released May 12, 2015.\n\n== Early life ==\nWhile growing up in Miami, Oklahoma, he played sports during [[Middle School|middle]] and high school, and began his music career by playing in a band at church.<ref name=\"bio\">{{cite web|url=http://www.keithanderson.com/bio/index.php|title=Biography|publisher=Keith Anderson|access-date=September 19, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120701050947/http://www.keithanderson.com/bio/index.php|archive-date=July 1, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref> After graduating from high school, he attended [[Oklahoma State University]],<ref name=\"bio\" /> where he was a member of [[Delta Tau Delta]] fraternity. During his college career, he obtained a degree in engineering.<ref name=\"TCC\">{{cite web|url=http://countrymusic.about.com/od/keithanderson/a/blkanderson_bio.htm|title=Keith Anderson Bio \u2013 Three Chord Country and American Rock & Roll|last=Fabian|first=Shelly|publisher=About|access-date=September 19, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081022065656/http://countrymusic.about.com/od/keithanderson/a/blkanderson_bio.htm|archive-date=October 22, 2008|url-status=dead}}</ref> He also played baseball during his college years, and was approached by the [[Kansas City Royals]].<ref name=\"bio\" /> After a shoulder injury ended his pursuit of a professional baseball career, Anderson tried bodybuilding and placed second in the Mr. Oklahoma competition.<ref name=\"bio\" />\n\n== Career ==\nAfter graduating, he accepted a position with an engineering firm in [[Dallas]], Texas. A year and a half later, he resigned to pursue a career in music. He attended clubs at night, began writing songs, and began learning guitar from his brother, Brian.\n\nIn Dallas, he auditioned for ''Grapevine Opry'', a show that had produced other country stars in the past. He performed on the show for three years, before performing at the [[Texas State Fair]] and [[Six Flags]].\n\nDue to financial difficulties, he was forced to find additional work, as a [[landscaper]] and as a [[personal trainer]].<ref name=\"TCC\" /> He also enrolled in the [[physical therapy]] program at [[University of Texas at Austin|University of Texas]].<ref name=\"TCC\" /> One month before starting, he decided to put his education on hold, and began producing his first CD. He said, \"The month before I started, I thought, 'Wait a minute. This is going to be a whole bunch of commitment. If I'm ever going to do music, I need to go for it 100%. NOW. Physical therapy will always be there, and my engineering degree will always be there.'\"<ref name=\"TCC\" />\n\nAfter recording his CD in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], he began marketing it to radio stations.<ref name=\"TCC\" /> In 2000, he put together a band. His first hit as a songwriter came in 2001, when [[Garth Brooks]] and [[George Jones]] recorded \"Beer Run (B Double E R-U-N)\", which Anderson co-wrote with several other writers, including [[George Ducas (singer)|George Ducas]].<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p691984|pure_url=yes}} |title=Keith Anderson biography |access-date=September 19, 2008 |last=Jeffries |first=David |work=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref><ref name=\"salina\">{{cite web|url=http://www.saljournal.com/rdencore/story/Keith-Anderson-4-25|title=Keith Anderson trades baseball dreams for country glory.|publisher=Salina|access-date=September 19, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927153835/http://www.saljournal.com/rdencore/story/Keith-Anderson-4-25|archive-date=September 27, 2011|url-status=dead}}</ref> He opened for [[Montgomery Gentry]] in 2002, and performed at many events, where he earned his recording deal with [[Arista Nashville]]. Since then, he has written songs for [[Gretchen Wilson]], as well as [[Big & Rich]]'s Number One single \"[[Lost in This Moment]]\".<ref name=\"salina\" />\n\n=== 2004\u20132006: ''Three Chord Country and American Rock and Roll'' ===\nIn 2004, Anderson signed to Arista Nashville.<ref name=\"allmusic\" /> His debut album, entitled ''[[Three Chord Country and American Rock & Roll]]'', produced chart singles in \"[[Pickin' Wildflowers]]\", \"[[XXL (Keith Anderson song)|XXL]]\", and \"[[Every Time I Hear Your Name]]\". After the latter, the title track was remixed by [[Mark Hudson (musician)|Mark Hudson]] with [[Aerosmith]] lead singer [[Steven Tyler]] as a guest vocalist.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_feature/article/0,,gac_26499_4803230,00.html |title=News : Features : Aerosmith's Steven Tyler Joins Keith Anderson on Rockin' New Single : Great American Country |access-date=February 6, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100917233703/http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_feature/article/0,,gac_26499_4803230,00.html |archive-date=September 17, 2010 |url-status=dead }}</ref> After it failed to chart, \"[[Podunk (song)|Podunk]]\" was released as the album's final single and peaked at number 34.\n\n=== 2007\u20132009: ''C'mon!'' ===\nAnderson released a song called \"[[Sunday Morning in America]]\" in early 2007 as the lead-off single to a second album for Arista. This song peaked at No.&nbsp;28, however, and the album was delayed. Later the same year, Anderson switched from Arista Nashville to [[Columbia Records]] Nashville.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.keithanderson.com/news.php/news?title=keith_anderson_visits_manassas_wal_mart&more=1&c=1&tb=1&pb=1|title=KEITH ANDERSON VISITS MANASSAS WAL-MART|date=August 14, 2008|publisher=Keith Anderson|access-date=September 19, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140324141245/http://www.keithanderson.com/news.php/news?title=keith_anderson_visits_manassas_wal_mart&more=1&c=1&tb=1&pb=1|archive-date=March 24, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref> His first single for the label, \"[[I Still Miss You]]\", was released in 2008 and became his third Top Ten hit. It was the lead-off single to his second album ''[[C'mon! (Keith Anderson album)|C'mon!]]'', released in August 2008, and \"Sunday Morning in America\" was included on it,<ref name=\"allmusic\" /> as well as his own rendition of \"Lost in This Moment\" and a cover of [[Foster & Lloyd]]'s \"[[Crazy Over You]]\". The album's third single, \"Somebody Needs a Hug\", peaked at No.&nbsp;46. The fourth single, \"She Could've Been Mine\", peaked at No.&nbsp;56 in early 2009. Anderson parted ways with Columbia Nashville in October of that year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1623208/keith-anderson-i-still-miss-you-singer-leaves-record-label.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607022203/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1623208/keith-anderson-i-still-miss-you-singer-leaves-record-label.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 7, 2011|title=Keith Anderson, \"I Still Miss You\" Singer, Leaves Record Label|website=Cmt.com|access-date=April 30, 2020}}</ref>\n\n=== 2010\u2013present: ''I'll Bring the Music'' ===\nSince 2010, Anderson has recorded and released a few tracks, via his fan club on his official website. Those songs include \"Wild Girls\" and the underground hit \"Your Town for Now\". In May 2014, Anderson released the single \"I'll Bring the Music\" which received airplay on [[The Highway (Sirius XM)|The Highway]].\n\nAnderson released a six-song EP album titled ''I'll Bring the Music'' on May 12, 2015, via iTunes and Amazon. He also released a full-length album of the same name available at his website and his shows in 2014.\n\n== Personal life ==\nAnderson married Lauren Woodruff in December 2010, after ten years of dating. They welcomed a daughter, Crozle J. Anderson, on October 5, 2011, and a son Jaxon born November 2013. Keith was divorced in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/keith-anderson-wife-baby-girl/|title=Keith Anderson and Wife Welcome a Baby Girl|first=Alanna|last=Conaway|website=Tasteofcountry.com|date=October 6, 2011 |access-date=April 30, 2020}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"2\"| Peak chart<br />positions\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:8em;\"| [[Music recording sales certification|Certifications]]<br /><small>([[List of best selling music artists|sales threshold]])</small>\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]<br /><ref>{{cite magazine|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=keith anderson|chart=Country Albums C}}|title=Keith Anderson Album & Song Chart History \u2013 Country Albums|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|access-date=November 13, 2011}}</ref>\n! width=\"45\"| [[Billboard 200|US]]<br /><ref>{{cite magazine|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=keith anderson|chart=Billboard 200}}|title=Keith Anderson Album & Song Chart History \u2013 Billboard 200|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|access-date=November 13, 2011}}</ref>\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Three Chord Country and American Rock & Roll|Three Chord Country<br />and American Rock & Roll]]''\n|\n* Release date: May 3, 2005\n* Label: [[Arista Nashville]]\n* Formats: CD, [[music download]]\n| 12\n| 71\n| align=\"left\"|\n* [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]]: Gold<ref>{{Cite certification|region=United States|type=album|title=Three Chord Country and American Rock & Roll|artist=Keith Anderson}}</ref>\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[C'mon!
