Year\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Video\n! style=\"width:11em;\"| Director\n|-\n| 2004\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Pickin' Wildflowers\"\n| Eric Welch\n|-\n| 2005\n! scope=\"row\"| \"XXL\"\n| [[Trey Fanjoy]]\n|-\n| 2006\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Every Time I Hear Your Name\"\n| Kristin Barlowe\n|-\n| 2007\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Podunk\"\n| Tony Holden\n|-\n| 2008\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Still Miss You\"\n| Traci Goudie\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.keithanderson.com/ Official website]\n* {{allmusic}}\n\n{{Keith Anderson}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Anderson, Keith}}\n[[Category:1968 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:People from Miami, Oklahoma]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Columbia Records artists]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Oklahoma]]\n[[Category:Arista Nashville artists]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Oklahoma]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Monty_Byrom","to":"Monty Byrom"}],"pages":{"23655571":{"pageid":23655571,"ns":0,"title":"Monty Byrom","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American musician and song-writer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2016}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Monty Byrom\n| birth_date       = 1958\n| birth_place      = [[Corpus Christi, Texas]], U.S.\n| genre            = [[Rock music|Rock]], [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[Country music|Country]], [[Album oriented rock]]\n| occupations      = songwriter, singer, musician, producer\n| instruments      = guitar, keyboards\n| current_member_of = The Byrom Brothers\n| past_member_of   = [[Billy Satellite]]<br />New Frontier<br />[[Big House (American band)|Big House]]<br />[[The Buckaroos]]<br />Zen Road Pilots<br />Monty Byrom & the Road Pilots\n}}\n\n'''Monty Byrom''' (born 1958) is an American [[rock music|rock]], [[blues music|blues]] and [[country music|country]] guitarist, singer, songwriter and producer.<ref name=\":7\">{{Cite web |title=Monty Byron Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/monty-byrom-mn0000925418/credits |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=AllMusic |language=en}}</ref> He fronted the rock band [[Billy Satellite]], co-writing several songs for the band that later became hits for [[Eddie Money]].  Byrom later became more involved in collaborations with Money, writing or co-writing songs on future Money albums and touring with Money on occasion.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web |last=Mu\u00f1oz |first=Matt |date=2012-09-05 |title=Band reunion is magical for Zen Road Pilots {{!}} Bakotopia |url=http://www.bakotopia.com/content/band-reunion-magical-zen-road-pilots |access-date=2022-06-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120905050134/http://www.bakotopia.com/content/band-reunion-magical-zen-road-pilots |archive-date=September 5, 2012 }}</ref> Later while leading the \"soul country\" band [[Big House (American band)|Big House]], Byrom made a significant contribution to the new [[Bakersfield Sound]], with a nod to his Bakersfield roots.<ref name=\":8\">{{Cite web |last=Timmons |first=Joseph |date=2019-02-21 |title=Artists Spotlight: Monty Byrom, American Music Legend and his group The Byrom Brothers |url=https://indiepulsemusic.com/2019/02/21/monty-byrom/ |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=IndiePulse Music Magazine |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n== Early life ==\nByrom was born in\n[[Corpus Christi, Texas|Corpus Christi]], [[Texas]] and raised in [[Bakersfield, California|Bakersfield]], [[California]].<ref name=\":8\" /> His original musical influences were [[Merle Haggard]], [[Billy Mize]], [[Buck Owens]], [[Otis Redding]], and [[Bobby Womack]].<ref name=\":9\">{{Cite web |title=Monty Byrom |url=https://wtfrecords.net/music-alive-in-the-new-york-times/ |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=WTF Records |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nWhen he was seventeen, he joined the [[United States Navy]].<ref name=\":9\" /> After attending the Norfolk Navy School of Music, he played in the Navy band, performing at high schools and colleges across the United States.<ref name=\":9\" />\n\nAlthough Bakersfield had a rising country music scene, he grew to prefer the music of [[Eric Clapton]], [[Creedence Clearwater Revival]], [[Deep Purple]], [[Jimi Hendrix|Jim Hendrix]], and [[Santana (band)|Santana]].<ref name=\":1\">\"[https://heavyharmonies.ipbhost.com/topic/34309-billy-satellite-ii/ Billy Satellite - II]\". ''Heavy Harmonies Forums''. Retrieved 2022-06-24.</ref> After the Navy, he played in a Bay Area band, The Heaters.<ref name=\":1\" /> In the 1980s, he played with the Dead Family.<ref name=\":8\" />\n\n== Career ==\n=== Billy Satellite ===\n{{Main|Billy Satellite}}\nIn the early 1980s, Byrom was a founding member of the [[Alameda, California]] band [[Billy Satellite]].<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web |title=Billy Satellite Songs, Albums, Reviews, Bio & More |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/billy-satellite-mn0001541500 |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=AllMusic |language=en}}</ref><ref name=\":0\" /> He provided lead vocals and played guitar and keyboards for the [[Album-oriented rock]] band.<ref name=\":2\" /> He also co-wrote the band's songs.<ref name=\":7\" /> The band signed with [[Capitol Records]] by [[John S. Carter]] in 1983.<ref name=\":1\" /><ref name=\":9\" /> Their album, ''Billy Satellite'', was produced by [[Don Gehman]] and recorded at [[Rumbo Recorders]] in [[Los Angeles]].<ref name=\":2\" /> The band toured with [[Night Ranger]] and [[Jefferson Starship]] in support of the album, which yielded two minor hits.<ref name=\":1\" /> Although recorded, the band's second album was never released and they were dropped by Capitol. Billy Satellite broke up shortly afterward.<ref name=\":2\" />\n\n=== New Frontier ===\nAfter Billy Satellite, Byrom formed the band [[New Frontier (band)|New Frontier]] which [[Glenn Letsch]] ([[Gamma (band)|Gamma]]) on bass, Marc Nelson on drums, and David Neuhauser on keyboards.<ref name=\":1\" /> The band signed with MIKA Records, an imprint of [[Polydor Records]], and released a self-titled album in 1987.<ref name=\":1\" /> Because all of its members were involved in other bands and projects, this group was short-lived.<ref>{{Cite web |date=December 8, 2019 |title=New Frontier - New Frontier (1988) |url=https://hardrockaorheaven.blogspot.com/2019/12/NEW-FRONTIER-New-Frontier-1988-Billy-Satellite-Richie-Zito-John-Waite.html |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=Hard Rock / AOR Heaven}}</ref>\n\n=== Eddie Money ===\nByrom began writing songs for Eddie Money after the latter had a hit with a cover of \"I Wanna Go Back\" by Billy Satellite (co-written by Byrom).<ref name=\":1\" /> Money's version of \"I Wanna Go Back\" received the ASCAP/BMI Song of the Year Award, based on airplay.<ref name=\":8\" /> He also toured with Money's band for several years.<ref name=\":8\" />\n\nByrom was the producer, engineer, and mixer on Money's 1991 album ''[[Right Here (Eddie Money album)|Right Here]]'', along with providing backing vocals and playing guitar and keyboards.<ref name=\":7\" /> He also co-wrote six of the album's ten tracks, including \"Another Nice Day in L.A.,\" \"Fall In Love Again,\" \"Fire and Water,\" \"Prove It Every Night,\" \"She Takes My Breath Away,\" and \"Things Are Much Better Today.\"<ref>{{Citation |title=Eddie Money - Right Here Album Reviews, Songs & More {{!}} AllMusic |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/right-here-mw0000265111 |language=en |access-date=2022-06-25}}</ref> He also produced and played guitar on Money's 1992 release ''[[Unplug It In]]''.<ref name=\":7\" />\n\n=== Big House ===\n{{Main|Big House (American band)}}\nFollowing a gathering of musicians in Bakersfield in the mid-1990s, Byrom founded the country music band, [[Big House (American band)|Big House]], with David Neuhauser from New Frontier.<ref name=\":1\" /><ref name=\":8\" /> The duo shared song-writing for the band, and Byrom played guitar and sang lead vocals.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web |title=Big House Albums and Discography |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/big-house-mn0000760611/discography |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=AllMusic |language=en}}</ref><ref name=\":7\" /> Byrom's brother, Tanner, was also a member of Big House, playing the drums.<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite web |last=Ankeny |first=Jason |title=Big House Biography |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/big-house-mn0000760611/biography |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=AllMusic |language=en}}</ref> They signed with [[MCA Nashville]] and released three albums between 1997 and 2000, including ''Big House'', ''Travelin' Kind'', and ''Woodstock Nation''.<ref name=\":5\">{{Cite web |last=Gile |first=Pete |date=2021-06-20 |title=Bakersfield Legend: Monty Byrom |url=https://www.thetroubadourpodcast.com/montybyrom/ |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=The Troubadour Podcast episode #126 |language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=\":4\" /> Their fourth album, ''Never Ending Train'', was released in 2008.<ref name=\":3\" /> He produced all four of the band's albums.<ref name=\":7\" /> They were nominated for a [[Academy of Country Music Award]] for top new vocal duet or group in 1998.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Morden |first=Darryl |date=February 25, 1998 |title=Mcgraw Leads With 7 ACM Nominations |url=https://www.spokesman.com/stories/1998/feb/25/mcgraw-leads-with-7-acm-nominations/ |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=The Spokesman Review}}</ref><ref name=\":8\" /> They also had four Top 40 Country hits, including \"Cold Outside\" and \"You Ain't Lonely Yet.\"<ref name=\":9\" /><ref name=\":10\">{{Cite web |title=Byrom Brothers |url=https://www.bigbigslo.com/band-blog/2018/11/28/byrom-brothers |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=Big, Big SLO! |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n=== The Buckaroos ===\n{{Main|The Buckaroos}}\nAfter the death of his friend [[Buck Owens]], Byrom was invited to join Owens' band [[The Buckaroos]] at The Crystal Palace in [[Bakersfield, California]], fronting the band one weekend a month.<ref name=\":5\" /> Byrom played with The Buckaroos for thirteen years, from 2007 to 2019.<ref name=\":6\">{{Cite web |last=Price |first=Robert |date=January 16, 2019 |title=After 13 years, Monty Byrom, Buck Owens' Crystal Palace part ways |url=https://www.bakersfield.com/entertainment/music/after-13-years-monty-byrom-buck-owens-crystal-palace-part-ways/article_ebf0fa24-1900-11e9-b44f-a7273646ba4d.html |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=The Bakersfield Californian |language=en}}</ref> Upon leaving the group, he said, 'Thirteen years and time to move on. I'm going to miss those boys and Jennifer [Keel, backing singer], that's for sure. Finally, in the end, it just came down to...time to move on.\"<ref name=\":6\" /> One of the reasons he quit was because of the increasing success of The Byrom Brothers.<ref name=\":6\" />\n\n=== Zen Road Pilots ===\nIn 2012, Byrom formed the Zen Road Pilots with Tom \"Fee\" Falletti and Ira Walker, former bandmates from Billy Satellite.<ref name=\":0\" /> The band recorded one self-titled album.<ref name=\":0\" />  Changing its name to Monty Byrom and The Road Pilots, this five-piece band played Americana-infused rock and soul in the old-school tradition.<ref name=\":8\" /> They released ''100 Miles South of Eden'' in 2016.<ref name=\":8\" />\n\n=== The Byrom Brothers ===\nThe Road Pilots became The Byrom Brothers, which includes his brother and [[Big House (American band)|Big House]] drummer Tanner Byrom.<ref name=\":6\" /><ref name=\":8\" /> Byrom plays guitar and sings lead vocals.<ref name=\":10\" /> The band also includes studio musician Wil Anderson on bass and keyboardist Chris Neufeld, who was a member of The Road Pilots and also played with Eddie Money.<ref name=\":8\" /><ref name=\":10\" /> Their current release, an album of covers titled ''The Age Of Music'', was released in 2016.<ref name=\"CDBaby\">{{Cite web |title=CD Baby Music Store |url=https://store.cdbaby.com/m/cd/byrombrothers}}</ref>\n\n=== Other ===\nIn 1984, he provided backing vocals for [[Barbra Streisand]] on her album, ''Emotion''.<ref name=\":7\" /> The producer of that track was [[Don Felder]] ([[Eagles (band)|Eagles]]), who mentored Byrom, leading to other projects with major acts.<ref name=\":8\" /> As a result, Byrom wrote songs that were recorded by [[Rita Coolidge]], [[Ace Frehley]], [[Beth Hart]], [[The Knack]], [[Gregg Rolie]], [[David Lee Roth]], [[Stray Cats]], [[George Thorogood]], [[Van Halen]], [[Walela]], and [[Waylon (singer)|Waylon]].<ref name=\":7\" /><ref name=\":8\" />\n\nIn 1992, he played guitar and provided backing vocals for [[Danny Tate]]'s self-named album.<ref name=\":7\" /> He also played guitar on recordings by [[J'Son (singer)|J'Son]], New Frontier, and [[Kathy Troccoli]].<ref name=\":7\" /> In addition, he produced and played instruments on albums for [[Jay Boy Adams]], [[Jared Tyler]], and [[Ted Z & the Wranglers]].<ref name=\":7\" />\n\nHe also worked on numerous movie and film soundtracks, including ''Blackdog'', ''[[The Kids Are Alright (TV series)|The Kids Are Alright]]'', ''Made in America'', ''[[The Slugger's Wife|The Slugger\u2019s Wife]]'', ''[[Secret Admirer (film)|Secret Admirer]]'', and ''[[Sunset Beach (TV series)|Sunset Beat]]''.<ref name=\":8\" /><ref name=\":7\" />\n\n== Awards and honors ==\n\n* Byrom won The Guitar Wars in northern California.<ref name=\":8\" />\n* \"I Wanna Go Back,\" a song he co-wrote, won the ASCAP/BMI Song of the Year Award.<ref name=\":8\" />\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Byrom, Monty}}\n[[Category:1958 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Corpus Christi, Texas]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Bakersfield, California]]\n[[Category:American rock musicians]]\n[[Category:American country guitarists]]\n[[Category:American male guitarists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American guitarists]]\n[[Category:21st-century American guitarists]]\n[[Category:American producers]]\n[[Category:Songwriters from California]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Dean_Miller","to":"Dean Miller"}],"pages":{"13110876":{"pageid":13110876,"ns":0,"title":"Dean Miller","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country singer, songwriter and music producer (born 1965)}}\n{{About||the middle distance runner|Dean Miller (athlete)|the American historian|Dean A. Miller}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2022}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image           =\n| name            = Dean Miller\n| birth_name      = Roger Dean Miller Jr.\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1965|10|15}}\n| birth_place     = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], U.S.\n| origin          = [[Santa Fe, New Mexico]], U.S.\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter, Music Producer \n| years_active    = 1997\u2013present\n| label           = [[Capitol Records|Capitol]], [[Universal South Records|Universal South]], [[Koch Entertainment|Koch]]/[[Audium Entertainment|Audium]]\n| associated_acts = [[Trace Adkins]], [[Terri Clark]], [[Roger Miller]]\n| website         = \n}}\n'''Roger Dean Miller Jr.''' (born October 15, 1965)<ref name=\"cst\">{{cite web |url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/article.asp?xid=609 |title=Dean Miller makes his own path |accessdate=September 5, 2007 |last=Bernstein |first=Joel |work=Country Standard Time}}</ref> is an American [[country music|country]] singer, songwriter and music producer known professionally as '''Dean Miller'''. He is the son of [[Roger Miller]], a [[country pop]] artist who had several hit singles from the 1960s through the 1980s. Dean Miller has recorded four studio albums (one of which was not released), in addition to charting four singles on the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts and writing singles for [[Trace Adkins]] and [[Terri Clark]]. His highest-peaking single as a performer was \"Nowhere, USA\", which reached No.&nbsp;54 in 1997. He has had many songs recorded by artists including [[George Jones]], [[Trisha Yearwood]], and [[Jamey Johnson]].\nDean has produced music with some of the biggest names in music, including [[Dolly Parton]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[Merle Haggard]], [[Kris Kristofferson]] and many more.\n\n==Biography==\nAlthough born in [[Los Angeles, California]], Miller was also raised in [[Santa Fe, New Mexico]] and [[San Antonio, Texas]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> He got his musical start in local clubs around Santa Fe, before moving back to Los Angeles in the early 1980s and joining a band called the Sarcastic Hillbillies.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p224399|pure_url=yes}} |title=Dean Miller |accessdate=September 5, 2007 |last=Ankeny |first=Jason |work=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> At the same time, he attended college, in addition to briefly pursuing a career in acting.<ref name=\"cst\"/><ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Miller later moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], where he worked as a staff songwriter for Sony/Tree Publishing, and later various other staff songwriter positions.\n\nBy 1995, he was signed to the Nashville division of [[Capitol Records]] Nashville. Two years later, his eponymous debut album was released on the Capitol label. The lead-off single \"Nowhere, USA\" received significant airplay in Chicago even before its release date;<ref name=\"cst\"/> however, it and two additional singles failed to reach Top 40 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts. Another single, \"Wake Up and Smell the Whiskey\", was co-written and previously recorded by [[Brett James]], who would later become a popular Nashville songwriter in the 2000s. Miller parted ways with Capitol not long afterward.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> In 2000, two country artists charted with singles that Miller co-wrote: [[Terri Clark]]'s \"[[A Little Gasoline]]\" and [[Trace Adkins]]'s \"I'm Gonna Love You Anyway\".\n\nIn 2002, Miller signed to the newly formed [[Universal South Records]], where he recorded his second album, ''Just Me''. The lead-off single \"Love Is a Game\" peaked at No.&nbsp;58, but the album was never released. Universal also released a rendition of \"[[Old Toy Trains]]\", which Roger had written for Dean when he was two years old; this version included Roger's vocals dubbed in on the chorus.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Bessman|first=Jim|date=December 7, 2002|title=Words & Music|magazine=Billboard|volume=114|issue=49|page=68|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Og0EAAAAMBAJ&dq=%22old+toy+trains%22+%22dean+miller%22&pg=PA68}}</ref> Miller later left Universal South's roster as well.<ref name=\"cmt1\">{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1509945/20050920/miller_dean.jhtml |archive-url=https://archive.today/20070930062157/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1509945/20050920/miller_dean.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 30, 2007 |title=For Dean Miller, It's Out-of-the-Box ''Platinum'' |accessdate=September 5, 2007 |last=Morris |first=Edward |date=September 2, 2005|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT.com]]}}</ref>\n\nMiller signed to the country music division of [[Koch Entertainment]] in 2005. His third album, titled ''Platinum'', was released that same year.<ref name=\"cmt1\"/> This album included the track \"Right Now\", which the band [[Rushlow]] had previously recorded as the title track of their 2003 debut album, as well as the non-charting single \"Hard Love\". Koch Entertainment closed its country division in 2005, however, and Miller was yet again without a record deal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1511641/20051017/miller_dean.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930023904/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1511641/20051017/miller_dean.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 30, 2007 |title=Koch Entertainment Closes Country Division |accessdate=September 5, 2007 |last= |first= |date=October 1, 2005|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT.com]]}}</ref>\n\nDean has produced music with some of the biggest names in music, including [[Dolly Parton]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[Merle Haggard]], [[Kris Kristofferson]] and many more.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Dean Miller (album)|Dean Miller]]''\n| \n* Release date: August 26, 1997\n* Label: [[Capitol Records|Capitol Nashville]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Platinum (Dean Miller album)|Platinum]]''\n| \n* Release date: September 6, 2005\n* Label: Audium/Koch\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| '''Til You Stop Getting Up''\n| \n* Release date: July 8, 2014\n* Label: Off The Verge\n|-\n|}\n\n===Extended plays===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| ''Stay EP''\n| \n* Release date: December 10, 2013\n* Label: Off the Verge\n|-\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:27em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"60\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1997\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Nowhere, USA\"\n| 54\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"3\"| ''Dean Miller''\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| \"My Heart's Broke Down (But My Mind's Made Up)\"\n| 67\n|- \n| 1998\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Wake Up and Smell the Whiskey\"\n| 57\n|- \n|rowspan=2|2002\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Love Is a Game\"\n| 58\n| align=\"left\"|''Just Me''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Old Toy Trains]]\" <small>(with [[Roger Miller]])</small>\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"|single only\n|-\n| 2003\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Gun Ain't Loaded (But I Am)\"\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=2|''Just Me''\n|- \n| 2004\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Carry My Kisses\"\n| \u2014\n|- \n| 2005\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Hard Love\"\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| ''Platinum''\n|- \n| rowspan=2|2014\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Begging for a Bullet\"\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| '' 'Til You Stop Getting Up''\n|- \n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"M Song\"\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| \n|- \n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Year\n! style=\"width:14em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 1997\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Nowhere, USA\"\n| \n|-\n| 2005\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Hard Love\"\n| Dale Resteghini\n|-\n| 2014\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Til You Stop Getting Up\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/dean-miller/1003690/til-you-stop-getting-up.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305051705/http://www.cmt.com/videos/dean-miller/1003690/til-you-stop-getting-up.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 5, 2016|title=CMT : Videos : Dean Miller : Til You Stop Getting Up|publisher=[[Country Music Television]]|accessdate=February 21, 2014}}</ref>\n| Dean Miller\n|-\n| 2018\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Are You Ready for Some Hanky Panky?\"\n| Jim Phelan\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.deanmillerentertainment.com/ Official website]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Miller, Dean}}\n[[Category:1965 births]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Singers from Los Angeles]]\n[[Category:Capitol Records artists]]\n[[Category:MNRK Music Group artists]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from California]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from California]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Kevin_Fowler","to":"Kevin Fowler"}],"pages":{"2312578":{"pageid":2312578,"ns":0,"title":"Kevin Fowler","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{For|the actor whose legal name is Kevin Fowler|Kevin Spacey}}\n{{short description|American singer-songwriter|bot=PearBOT 5}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name                = Kevin Fowler\n| image               = Kevin Fowler.jpg\n| caption             = Fowler in 2016\n| image_size          = \n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          = \n| alias               = \n| birth_place                = [[Amarillo, Texas]]\n| birth_date                = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1966|5|11}}\n| origin              = Amarillo, Texas, United States\n| instrument          = Vocals, guitar, piano\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = 2000\u2013present\n| label               = Tin Roof<br />[[Equity Music Group|Equity]]<br />Super Loud<br />[[Lyric Street Records|Lyric Street]]<br />[[Average Joe's Entertainment]]\n| past_member_of = [[Dangerous Toys]]\n| website             = http://www.kevinfowler.com\n}}\n'''Kevin Fowler''' (born May 11, 1966) is an American singer-songwriter. He has released five studio albums, and has charted four singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, including the top 40 hit \"Pound Sign (#?*!)\". In addition, he wrote [[Sammy Kershaw]]'s 2003 single \"Beer, Bait & Ammo\", [[Mark Chesnutt]]'s 2004 single \"The Lord Loves the Drinkin' Man\" and [[Montgomery Gentry]]'s 2009 single \"[[Long Line of Losers]]\".\n\n==Early life==\nFowler was born in [[Amarillo, Texas]], the younger of two children. His father introduced him to country music when he was a child, and as a teenager Fowler also developed a liking for rock music.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> He graduated in 1984 from [[Tascosa High School]] in Amarillo.{{citation needed|date=August 2019}} Long interested in making music, Fowler began piano lessons as a young child. When he was twenty, he realized that he wanted to seriously pursue a career in music and moved to Los Angeles, California, to attend the Guitar Institute of Technology. For the next year, he learned how to play the guitar and began writing songs.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nAfter gaining a good knowledge of the guitar, Fowler left Los Angeles for [[Austin, Texas]]. He was a guitarist with the rock band ''[[Dangerous Toys]]'' in the early 1990s, but left to form his own [[Southern rock|Southern hard-rock]] band, ''Thunderfoot.'' In 1998, he left rock music all together to form a new band that would concentrate instead on Texas country music. Fowler and his new band earned themselves a weekly gig at Babe's on [[6th Street (Austin)|Sixth Street]] in Austin. Two years later, with no recording contracts, Fowler recorded and released his own debut album, ''[[Beer, Bait & Ammo]]''. This album sold over 30,000 copies in Texas, with the title track receiving a great deal of airplay. This song was popular enough that [[Mark Chesnutt]] began playing it in his live show, and [[Sammy Kershaw]] recorded it for one of his own albums.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web  | last = Birchmeier  | first = Jason  | title = Kevin Fowler Biography  | publisher = AllMusic  | url ={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p457811|pure_url=yes}} | access-date = March 16, 2007}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nFowler signed with country singer [[Clint Black]]'s independent ''[[Equity Music Group|Equity Music]]'' (a label distributed by [[Koch Entertainment]]) and released two additional albums for that label until Equity ceased operations in December 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hypebot.com/hypebot/2008/12/nashville-feels.html|title=Nashville Feels The Pain: Equity Music Group Folds|website=Hypebot.com|access-date=January 1, 2019}}</ref> [[Montgomery Gentry]] recorded a cover of Fowler's \"[[Long Line of Losers]].\"<ref name=\"lyric\"/>\n\nIn January 2010, Fowler signed to [[Lyric Street Records]], releasing \"Beer Season\" that same month.<ref name=\"lyric\">{{cite web|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2010/01/lyric-street-signs-kevin-fowler/|title=Lyric Street signs Kevin Fowler|last=Cronin|work=The Boot|first=Peter|date=January 27, 2010|access-date=April 19, 2010}}</ref> His second single, \"Pound Sign (#?*!),\" followed in April. That same month, Lyric Street Records announced its closure, and Fowler was one of four artists to be transferred to parent company [[Disney Music Group]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wacotrib.com/accesswaco/arts/Kevin-Fowler-turns-strange-song-title-into-surprise-hit.html |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130208234827/http://www.wacotrib.com/accesswaco/arts/Kevin-Fowler-turns-strange-song-title-into-surprise-hit.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 8, 2013 |title=Kevin Fowler turns strange song title into surprise hit |last=Hoover |first=Carl |date=June 20, 2010 |work=Waco Herald-Tribune |access-date=June 23, 2010 }}</ref> In May 2010, \"Pound Sign\" became Fowler's first Top 40 hit on the country music charts, peaking at No.&nbsp;34.<ref>{{cite magazine|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=kevin fowler|chart=all}}|title=Chart listing for \"Pound Sign (#?*!)\"|magazine=Billboard|access-date=August 29, 2010}}</ref>\n\nFowler also collaborated with [[country rap]] artist [[Colt Ford]] on the song ''Hip Hop in a Honky Tonk'', on Ford's 2010 song ''[[Chicken & Biscuits]]'', in which he sings vocals on the song's chorus.{{citation needed|date=August 2019}} In 2011, Fowler signed to Ford's label, [[Average Joe's Entertainment]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.averagejoesent.com/artists/295-kevin-fowler |title=Kevin Fowler |work=Average Joe's Entertainment |access-date=May 30, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110904185705/http://www.averagejoesent.com/artists/295-kevin-fowler |archive-date= September 4, 2011 }}</ref> In early 2011, Fowler released the single \"Girl in a Truck,\" which hit number 1 on the Texas Music Chart released February 21, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.texasmusicchart.com/Pages/Chart.htm|title=Texas Music Chart|access-date=February 23, 2011}}</ref> The song was released regionally to radio stations in the Texas and Oklahoma areas. Fowler's sixth album, ''[[Chippin' Away]]'', was released via [[Average Joe's Entertainment]] in 2011.\n\nFowler's single, \"Here's To Me and You,\" peaked at No. 1 on the Texas Music Chart and held that position for 3 weeks in a row.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/109877/kevin-fowler-tops-texas-music-chart|title=Kevin Fowler Tops Texas Music Chart|website=All Access|access-date=January 1, 2019}}</ref> The official music video for \"Here's To Me and You\" premiered on CMT.com on September 19, 2012. On November 21, Fowler released a limited-time only free download of a brand new, unreleased song, \"Santa Got Busted By The Border Patrol.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kevinfowler.com/home/394-santa-got-busted-by-the-border-patrol-free-download |title=\"Santa Got Busted by the Border Patrol\" FREE Download |access-date=February 13, 2013 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121128212639/http://www.kevinfowler.com/home/394-santa-got-busted-by-the-border-patrol-free-download |archive-date=November 28, 2012 }}</ref>\n\nOn September 24, 2013, Fowler released a new single, \"How Country Are Ya?\" The single is the title track of Fowler's seventh studio album. On January 21, 2014, Fowler released a new single, \"Love Song,\" from the album. The album, ''How Country Are Ya?'', was released on March 4, 2014. \"Before Somebody Gets Hurt\" (feat. Amy Rankin of The Rankin Twins), Fowler's fourth single off of the \"How Country Are Ya?\" album, hit No. 1 on the Texas Music Charts on June 8, 2015.\n\nDuring 2013 and 2014, Fowler starred in television commercials for Benny Boyd Auto Group, Rodeo Austin and the [[Texas Department of Transportation]]. Fowler previewed music from an upcoming record in March 2016. From the preview, he released his new single \"Sellout Song\" feat. [[Zane Williams]] in April 2016. On Friday, October 21, 2016, Kevin Fowler released Coming to a Honky Tonk Near You, an eight-song album featuring \"Texas Forever.\" In 2017, Fowler was featured in a television commercial for the [[Texas Commission on Environmental Quality]]. Fowler was promoting the \"Take Care of Texas\" campaign regarding state parks and environmental education.\n\n== Discography ==\n{{Main|Kevin Fowler discography}}\n*''[[Beer, Bait & Ammo]]'' (2000)\n*''[[High on the Hog (Kevin Fowler album)|High on the Hog]]'' (2002)\n*Live at Billy Bob's Texas (2002)\n*''[[Loose, Loud & Crazy]]'' (2004)\n*''[[Bring It On (Kevin Fowler album)|Bring It On]]'' (2007)\n*''[[Chippin' Away]]'' (2011)\n*''[[How Country Are Ya?]]'' (2014)\n*''[[Coming to a Honky Tonk Near You]]'' (2016)\n*''Barstool Stories'' (2019)\n*''Dos Borrachos'' w/ Roger Creager (2019)\n\n==Sources==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n{{Commons category|Kevin Fowler}}\n*[http://www.kevinfowler.com/ Kevin Fowler's official site]\n\n{{Kevin Fowler}}\n{{Dangerous Toys}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Fowler, Kevin}}\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Amarillo, Texas]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Texas]]\n[[Category:Equity Music Group artists]]\n[[Category:Lyric Street Records artists]]\n[[Category:Tascosa High School alumni]]\n[[Category:Average Joes Entertainment artists]]\n[[Category:Musicians Institute alumni]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Texas]]\n[[Category:1966 births]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Colt_Ford","to":"Colt Ford"}],"pages":{"23460631":{"pageid":23460631,"ns":0,"title":"Colt Ford","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter (born 1969)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2024}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Colt Ford\n| image             = Colt_Ford_Live_@_Outlawz_Ardmore_Ok._3_20_10.JPG\n| caption           = Ford in 2010\n| image_size        = \n| birth_name        = Jason Farris Brown\n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1969|08|27}}\n| origin            = [[Athens, Georgia]], U.S.<ref name=\"cmt\"/>\n| instrument        = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar}}\n| genre             = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country rap]]\n* [[country]]\n* [[Southern hip hop]]\n* [[Southern rock]]}}\n| occupation        = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter|rapper|record label owner}}\n| years_active      = 2008\u2013present\n| label             = [[Average Joes Entertainment|Average Joes]]\n| website           = {{URL|coltford.com}}\n}}\n'''Jason Farris Brown''' (born August 27, 1969) known professionally as '''Colt Ford''', is an American [[country rap]] musician, songwriter, entrepreneur, and former [[professional golfer]]. He is also the co-founder of record label [[Average Joes Entertainment]]. Ford has released seven albums through Average Joes and has charted multiple singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] and [[Country Airplay]] charts. In addition, he co-wrote \"[[Dirt Road Anthem]]\" for [[Jason Aldean]], \"[[Country Must Be Country Wide]]\" for [[Brantley Gilbert]], and \"[[Mind on You (George Birge song)|Mind on You]]\" for [[George Birge]].\n\n==Biography==\nJason Farris Brown was born and raised in [[Athens, Georgia]].<ref>{{cite web|author=David Jeffries |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/colt-ford-mn0001028746/biography |title=Colt Ford &#124; Biography & History |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref> He was a [[Professional golfer|professional golf]]er,<ref name=\"cmt\"/> playing on the Nationwide Tour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbssports.com/golf/story/11789089|title=Up & Down: Mickelsons appreciate thoughts; sour note by singer|last=Elling|first=Steve|work=[[CBS]] Sports|access-date=2009-07-03}}</ref> Later, he turned his interests to music, taking influence from [[country music]] and [[hip hop music|hip hop]].<ref name=\"cmt\">{{cite web |title=Colt Ford biography |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/ford__colt/bio.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080620194200/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/ford__colt/bio.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=June 20, 2008 |work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]] |access-date=1 July 2009}}</ref> Assuming the [[stage name]] Colt Ford, he released his debut album, ''[[Ride Through the Country]]'', on December 2, 2008, through [[Average Joes Entertainment]], which he cofounded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goerie.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100605/ENTERTAINMENT0302/306059983/-1/entertainment03|title=Ford takes a different country road|last=Talbott|first=Chris|date=4 June 2010|work=GoErie.com|access-date=26 July 2011|archive-date=22 September 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120922073207/http://www.goerie.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100605/ENTERTAINMENT0302/306059983/-1/entertainment03|url-status=dead}}</ref> This album included the singles \"No Trash in My Trailer\"<ref name=\"sun\">{{cite web |title=Ford brings upbeat style, 'No Trash in My Trailer' crooner to perform country/hip-hop mix |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=MB&s_site=myrtlebeachonline&p_multi=MB&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=122DE17536DB9FF8&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |date=2008-08-29 |work=Sun News |access-date=1 July 2009}}</ref> (a cover of a Mike Dekle/[[Byron Hill]] song) and \"Ride Through the Country\" (a duet with [[John Michael Montgomery]]), the latter of which did not chart until the week of October 10, 2009, when it debuted at number 57 on [[Hot Country]]\n\nHe also appeared on a rap [[remix]] of [[Montgomery Gentry]]'s late-2008 Number One single \"[[Roll with Me]]\".<ref name=\"boot\">{{cite web |title=New Faces: Colt Ford |url=http://www.theboot.com/2009/02/02/new-faces-colt-ford/ |date=2009-02-02 |work=The Boot |access-date=1 July 2009}}</ref> Ford's debut album also has guest appearances from country singer [[Jamey Johnson]], as well as [[Bone Crusher (rapper)|Bone Crusher]] and [[Jermaine Dupri]], Adrian Young of [[No Doubt (band)|No Doubt]], and Jeremy Popoff of [[Lit (band)|Lit]].<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |title=Colt Ford biography |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1065034|pure_url=yes}} |author=David Jeffries |work=[[Allmusic]] |access-date=1 July 2009}}</ref> The album did not enter the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' albums charts until 2009.\n\nFord co-wrote and originally recorded the song \"[[Dirt Road Anthem]]\" for his debut album ''Ride Through the Country''; it was later released by [[Brantley Gilbert]], who co-wrote the song, on his 2010 album ''[[Halfway to Heaven (album)|Halfway to Heaven]]'',<ref>{{cite web|last=Waterman |first=Doug |url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2011/09/the-story-behind-the-song-dirt-road-anthem/ |title=The Story Behind The Song: \"Dirt Road Anthem\" \u00ab American Songwriter |website=Americansongwriter.com |date=2011-09-21 |access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=CMT.com : Brantley Gilbert : Album |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/gilbert__brantley/2506478/album.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100326125555/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/gilbert__brantley/2506478/album.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=March 26, 2010 |work=CMT |access-date=2011-02-05}}</ref> and again by [[Jason Aldean]] on his album ''[[My Kinda Party]]'', also from 2010.<ref>{{cite web |title=My Kinda Party >> Music >> Jason Aldean |url=http://www.jasonaldean.com/music/all/my_kinda_party-6 |work=Jason Aldean |access-date=2011-02-05}}</ref>\n\nFord wrote the theme song \"Buck 'em\" for the [[Professional Bull Riders]] association. He also appears as a guest vocalist on the track \"Tailgatin'\" on [[Cledus T. Judd]]'s 2009 album ''[[Polyrically Uncorrect]]'', a song which Ford wrote with Johnson and Popoff.<ref>{{cite web |title=Music |url=http://www.cledustjudd.net/music.html |work=Cledus T. Judd |access-date=1 July 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090623072013/http://www.cledustjudd.net/music.html |archive-date=23 June 2009 }}</ref> Ford's second studio album, ''[[Chicken & Biscuits]]'', was released in April 2010, following the release of its title track.\n\nFord released a third studio album on May 3, 2011, called ''Every Chance I Get''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allaccess.com/country/future-releases|title=Future Releases for Country Radio Stations|publisher=All Access|access-date=February 11, 2011}}</ref> The album's lead-off single, \"Country Thang\", debuted at number 55 for the country chart week ending February 19, 2011. \"She Likes to Ride in Trucks\", featuring [[Craig Morgan (singer)|Craig Morgan]], served as the album's second single.\n\nFord's fourth album, ''[[Declaration of Independence (album)|Declaration of Independence]]'', became his first number 1 album on Top Country Albums. Its first charted single is \"Back\", a duet with [[Jake Owen]]. \"Back\" is Ford's highest charting single to date, making Top 40 on [[Hot Country Songs]]. In 2012, Colt Ford headlined the Declaration Of Independence Tour with supporting acts [[The Lacs]], [[Lenny Cooper]], and [[JB and the Moonshine Band]]. In the fall of 2012 Ford announced he would be touring with [[JJ Lawhorn]] on the Answer To No One Tour.\n\nColt Ford's fifth studio album, ''[[Thanks for Listening (Colt Ford album)|Thanks for Listening]]'', was released on July 1, 2014.\n\n\"4 Lane Gone\" is the first single from his sixth studio album, ''[[Love Hope Faith]]''. Ford released a music video for the single on September 11, 2016<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vOgszDDOAx8 |title=YouTube |publisher=[[YouTube]] |access-date=2020-04-05}}{{cbignore}}{{Dead Youtube links|date=February 2022}}</ref> ''Love Hope Faith'' was released on May 5, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/love-hope-faith/id1207486899|title=Love Hope Faith by Colt Ford on iTunes|date=5 May 2017 |publisher=[[Apple Inc.]]|access-date=May 5, 2017}}</ref>\n\nColt's next album ''[[We the People, Volume 1]]'' was released in September 2019.\n\nOn April 5, 2024, Ford suffered a [[heart attack]] after a concert in [[Arizona]], and was placed in [[intensive care]] soon after.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://people.com/colt-ford-suffered-heart-attack-arizona-performance-icu-8627453 | title=Colt Ford in ICU After Suffering Heart Attack Following Arizona Performance }}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n{{main|Colt Ford discography}}\n* ''[[Ride Through the Country]]'' (2008)\n* ''[[Chicken & Biscuits]]'' (2010)\n* ''[[Every Chance I Get (album)|Every Chance I Get]]'' (2011)\n* ''[[Declaration of Independence (album)|Declaration of Independence]]'' (2012)\n* ''[[Thanks for Listening (Colt Ford album)|Thanks for Listening]]'' (2014)\n* ''[[Love Hope Faith]]'' (2017)\n* ''[[We the People, Volume 1]]'' (2019)\n* ''Must Be the Country'' (2023)\n\n== Awards and nominations ==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Year\n! Association\n! Category\n! Result\n|-\n| 2011\n| [[Academy of Country Music Awards]]\n| Vocal Event of the Year \u2014 \"Cold Beer\" <small>(with [[Jamey Johnson]])</small><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theboot.com/2011/02/01/2011-acm-awards-nominees/|title=2011 ACM Awards Nominees|date=February 2011 |publisher=The Boot|access-date=February 24, 2011}}</ref>\n| {{nom}}\n|}\n\n== References ==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n{{Colt Ford}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Ford, Colt}}\n[[Category:1969 births]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male rappers]]\n[[Category:American male golfers]]\n[[Category:Average Joes Entertainment artists]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Georgia (U.S. state)]]\n[[Category:Country rap musicians]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Athens, Georgia]]\n[[Category:Rappers from Georgia (U.S. state)]]\n[[Category:Georgia (U.S. state) Republicans]]\n[[Category:21st-century American rappers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male musicians]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Georgia (U.S. state)]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Western_Flyer","to":"Western Flyer"}],"pages":{"9397127":{"pageid":9397127,"ns":0,"title":"Western Flyer","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country music band}}\n{{About|the American band||Western Flyer (disambiguation)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2012}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name                = Western Flyer\n| image                 = WesternFlyer-2011.jpg\n| caption            =\n| image_size            =\n| background          = group_or_band\n| origin              = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| genre               = [[country music|Country]]\n| years_active        = 1992\u20131997\n| label               = [[Step One Records|Step One]]\n| past_members        = Steve Charles<br />Bruce Gust<br />T. J. Klay<br />[[Chris Marion]]<br />Danny Myrick<br />Roger Helton\n| associated_acts     = [[Little River Band]]\n}}\n'''Western Flyer''' was an American [[country music]] band founded in 1992 by Danny Myrick (lead vocals, bass guitar), [[Chris Marion]] (keyboards, vocals), T. J. Klay (harmonica, [[mandolin]], vocals), Bruce Gust (drums, vocals), Steve Charles (lead guitar, vocals), and Roger Helton ([[acoustic guitar]], [[banjo]], vocals). The band released two albums for [[Step One Records]], as well as six singles. Their highest peaking single is \"What Will You Do with M-E?\", which reached No.&nbsp;32 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts in 1996. After Western Flyer disbanded, Marion joined the [[Little River Band]], and Myrick began writing songs for other artists.\n\n==History==\nWestern Flyer was founded in 1992 by lead singer and bass guitarist Danny Myrick and keyboardist Chris Marion. Completing the lineup were harmonicist/mandolinist T.J. Klay, drummer Bruce Gust, lead guitarist Steve Charles, and guitarist/banjoist Roger Helton. The band members met in Nashville at a church where some of them had been playing in the church band.  The band took the name Western Flyer from a brand of bicycle.<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=456|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Rush |first=Diane Samms |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=qbwwAAAAIBAJ&pg=6755%2C4222623 |title=Western Flyer's in gear |work=[[Lakeland Ledger]] |date=November 27, 1994 |page=6C |accessdate=2015-08-30 }}</ref>\n\nThe group signed to the independent Step One Records label in 1993, and released a self-titled debut album a year later. This album accounted for five chart singles, of which four reached the lower regions of the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts. The album's third release, \"[[Cherokee Highway]]\", did not chart in the U.S., although it was a Top 40 hit on the ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Country Tracks charts and received media attention for its story of interracial violence.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/405063/COUNTRY-SONG-DARES-TO-ATTACK-RACISM-HEAD-ON.html?pg=all |title=Country song dares to tackle racism head-on |accessdate=2008-08-04 |date=February 18, 1995 |work=[[Deseret News]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Rose |first=Van |url=http://archives.timesleader.com/1994_13/1994_10_03_FOR_BAND_WESTERN_FLYER__NO_ROAD_S_TOO_ROUGH__NO_SUBJECT_S_TOO_TO.html |title=For Band Western Flyer, No Road's Too Rough, No Subject's Too Tough |work=[[Times Leader]] |date=October 3, 1994 |accessdate=2015-08-30 }}</ref>\n\nWestern Flyer's second album, 1996's ''Back in America'', produced its highest charting single in \"What Will You Do with M-E?\" which reached No.&nbsp;32 on the U.S. country charts.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Also included on this album were \"She Wants to Be Wanted Again,\" which [[Ty Herndon]] also released on his 1996 album ''[[Living in a Moment]]'' and released as a single in 1997, and \"Lost in You\", which received a \"Critic's Choice\" review in ''Billboard''.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vQkEAAAAMBAJ&q=%22western+flyer%22+billboard&pg=PA78 |title=Reviews and Previews |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=November 16, 1996 |page=78 |accessdate=2015-08-30 }}</ref> ''Back in America'' produced no other chart singles, and Western Flyer disbanded in 1997. Marion subsequently joined the [[Little River Band]], a [[rock music|rock]] group, in 2004. Danny Myrick signed to a songwriting contract with 3 Ring Circus Music, which is owned by [[Jeffrey Steele]]. Myrick has co-written \"[[International Harvester (song)|International Harvester]]\" for [[Craig Morgan (singer)|Craig Morgan]], \"Loud\" for [[Big & Rich]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.3ringcircusmusic.com/content/home_c.htm |title=3 Ring Circus Music |accessdate=2008-04-01 }}</ref> the Number One hit \"[[She's Country]]\" for [[Jason Aldean]], and \"[[How Far Do You Wanna Go?]]\" by [[Gloriana (band)|Gloriana]].\n\n==''Western Flyer'' (1994)==\n{{Infobox album\n| italic_title = no\n| name         = Western Flyer\n| type         = studio\n| artist       = Western Flyer\n| cover        = westernflyer1.jpg\n| alt          =\n| released     = August 20, 1994\n| recorded     =\n| venue        =\n| studio       =\n| genre        = Country\n| length       =\n| label        = Step One No.&nbsp;85\n| producer     = [[Ray Pennington]], Western Flyer\n| prev_title   =\n| prev_year    =\n| next_title   = Back in America\n| next_year    = 1996\n}}\n\n===Track listing===\n#\"Western Flyer\" (Danny Myrick, Tony Wood) \u2013 3:53\n#\"She Should've Been Mine\" ([[Kent Blazy]], Jim Dowell, [[Rob Crosby]]) \u2013 3:41\n#\"His Memory\" ([[Donny Kees]], Richard Ross) \u2013 3:20\n#\"Cherokee Highway\" (Myrick, Wood) \u2013 4:45\n#\"I Would Give Anything\" (Roger Ball) \u2013 3:10\n#\"Friday Night Stampede\" ([[Marcus Hummon]], [[Monty Powell]]) \u2013 3:07\n#\"Liar's Moon\" (Myrick, Don Pfrimmer, Philip Douglas) \u2013 2:41\n#\"A Hundred Others Like It\" (Myrick, Wood) \u2013 2:45\n#\"The One Who Understands\" (Greg Barnhill, Richard Bach) \u2013 3:43\n#\"Pathway to the Moon\"  (Hummon, Michael Puryear) \u2013 3:43\n\n===Personnel===\n\n====Western Flyer====\n*Steve Charles- [[electric guitar]], background vocals\n*Bruce Gust- [[drums]], [[percussion]], background vocals\n*Roger Helton- [[banjo]], [[fiddle]], [[acoustic guitar]], background vocals\n*T.J. Klay- acoustic guitar, [[harmonica]], [[mandolin]], background vocals\n*[[Chris Marion]]- [[Keyboard instrument|keyboards]], background vocals\n*Danny Myrick- [[bass guitar]], lead vocals\n\n====Additional musicians====\n*Cory Hutchinson- background vocals\n*Steve Mauldin- string arrangements\n*Kris Wilkinson- [[String instrument|strings]]\n\n==''Back in America'' (1996)==\n{{Infobox album\n| italic_title = no\n| name         = Back in America\n| type         = studio\n| artist       = Western Flyer\n| cover        = westernflyer2.jpg\n| alt          =\n| released     = July 23, 1996\n| recorded     =\n| venue        =\n| studio       =\n| genre        = Country\n| length       =\n| label        = Step One No.&nbsp;98\n| producer     = Ray Pennington, Western Flyer\n| prev_title   = Western Flyer\n| prev_year    = 1994\n| next_title   =\n| next_year    =\n}}\n\n===Track listing===\n#\"Back in America\" ([[Layng Martine, Jr.]]) \u2013 3:52\n#\"Lost in You\" (Bryan Smith) \u2013 3:36\n#\"Wish You Were Here\" (Bob Dellaposta) \u2013 3:54\n#\"Surrender\" ([[Joe Diffie]], [[Kent Blazy]], [[Lonnie Wilson]]) \u2013 2:52\n#\"I Know Where You're Coming From\" (Jerry Taylor, Ashe Underwood) \u2013 3:41\n#\"What Will You Do with M-E?\" (Craig Martin, Rick Tiger) \u2013 4:38\n#\"New Tin Roof\" (Chapin Hartford, Jeff Moseley) \u2013 3:11\n#\"[[She Wants to Be Wanted Again]]\" (Billy Henderson, Steven Dale Jones) \u2013 4:09\n#\"Less Than a Minute\" (Tommy Barnes) \u2013 3:15\n#\"Black and Blue\" (Danny Myrick, Tony Wood) \u2013 3:05\n#\"Rhythm of the Highway\" (Myrick, Wood) \u2013 4:17\n#\"[[Sixteen Tons]]\" ([[Merle Travis]]) \u2013 8:14\n\n===Personnel===\n\n====Western Flyer====\n*Steve Charles - [[electric guitar]], background vocals\n*Bruce Gust - [[drums]], [[percussion]], background vocals\n*Roger Helton - [[banjo]], [[fiddle]], [[acoustic guitar]], background vocals\n*T.J. David Smith - [[bass guitar]]\n*Kevin Williams - acoustic guitar\n\n==Singles==\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"2\"| Peak chart<br />positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[RPM (magazine)|CAN Country]]\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1994\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Western Flyer\"\n| 61\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"5\"| ''Western Flyer''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"She Should've Been Mine\"\n| 62\n| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 1995\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Cherokee Highway]]\"{{efn|\"Cherokee Highway\" peaked at number 34 on ''[[Cashbox (magazine)|Cashbox]]'' Top 100 Country Singles.<ref name=\"cashbox\">{{cite journal | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-All-Music/Cash-Box/90s/1995/CB-1995-05-06.pdf | title=Top 100 Country Singles | journal=Cashbox | pages=22 | date=May 6, 1995}}</ref>}}\n| \u2014\n| 38\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Friday Night Stampede\"\n| 71\n| 62\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"His Memory\"\n| 74\n| 80\n|-\n| 1996\n! scope=\"row\"| \"What Will You Do with M-E?\"\n| 32\n| 36\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"3\"| ''Back in America''\n|-\n|rowspan=2|1997\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Wish You Were Here\"<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-RandR/1990s/1997/RR-1997-03-07.pdf | title=Going for Adds | journal=[[Radio & Records]] | pages=81 | date=March 7, 1997}}</ref>\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Lost in You\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"5\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n;notes\n{{notelist}}\n\n==Music videos==\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Director\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1994\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Western Flyer\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/western-flyer/384598/western-flyer.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305074436/http://www.cmt.com/videos/western-flyer/384598/western-flyer.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 5, 2016|title=CMT : Videos : Western Flyer : Western Flyer|publisher=[[Country Music Television]]|accessdate=October 14, 2011}}</ref>\n| rowspan=\"3\"| Greg Crutcher\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"She Should've Been Mine\"\n|-\n| 1995\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Cherokee Highway\"\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.tjklay.com Official TJ Klay website]\n* [http://www.brucegust.com Official Bruce Gust website]\n* [http://www.stevenpcharlesmusic.com Official Steve Charles website]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n[[Category:Country music groups from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Musical groups from Nashville, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 1992]]\n[[Category:Musical groups disestablished in 1997]]\n[[Category:Step One Records artists]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jaron_Lowenstein","to":"Jaron Lowenstein"}],"pages":{"26137601":{"pageid":26137601,"ns":0,"title":"Jaron Lowenstein","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer|bot=PearBOT 5}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Jaron Lowenstein\n| image           =\n| caption         =\n| birth_name      = Jaron David Lowenstein\n| alias           = Jaron and the Long Road to Love\n| birth_date      = {{Birth date and age|1974|03|18}}<ref name=\"Associated Press\">{{cite web | url = http://www.boston.com/news/history/articles/2011/03/18/today_in_history/ | title = Today in History | work = [[The Associated Press]] | date = March 18, 2011 | quote = Evan and Jaron Lowenstein are 37}}</ref>\n| origin          = [[Tucker, Georgia|Tucker]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], U.S.\n| genre           = [[Country pop]]\n| years_active    = 1994\u2013present\n| label           = Jaronwood<br>[[Universal Republic Records]]<br>[[Big Machine Records|Big Machine]]<br>[[Republic Nashville]]<br>Nine North\n| past_member_of= [[Evan and Jaron]]\n}}\n\n'''Jaron David Lowenstein''' (born March 18, 1974) is an American singer who formerly recorded with his [[identical twin]] brother, Evan, in the musical duo [[Evan and Jaron]]. As '''Jaron and the Long Road to Love''', he released his debut [[single (music)|single]], \"Pray for You\" to country radio in November 2009. This song reached the top 15 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, and is included on the album ''[[Getting Dressed in the Dark]]''. The second single, \"That's Beautiful to Me\", was released in September 2010.\n\n== Life and career ==\nLowenstein was born in [[Tucker, Georgia]], the son of Leslie (n\u00e9e Diamond) and Charles Lowenstein. He was raised in an [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jewish]] family, and attended [[Greenfield Hebrew Academy]] and [[Yeshiva Atlanta|Yeshiva High School]] (which have since merged to form the [[Atlanta Jewish Academy]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atlantajewish.com/content/2004/evanandjaron.html|title=American Jewish Life Magazine|website=Atlantajewish.com|accessdate=7 June 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100212153007/http://www.atlantajewish.com/content/2004/evanandjaron.html|archive-date=12 February 2010|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.ajc.com/radio-tv-talk/2010/08/30/former-atlanta-rocker-jaron-of-evan-and-jaron-lassos-a-hit-in-country-music/ |title=Former Atlanta rocker Jaron of Evan and Jaron lassos a hit in country music &#124; Radio & TV Talk |accessdate=July 18, 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120514114718/http://blogs.ajc.com/radio-tv-talk/2010/08/30/former-atlanta-rocker-jaron-of-evan-and-jaron-lassos-a-hit-in-country-music/ |archivedate=May 14, 2012 }}</ref> Through his mother, he is related (by marriage) to actor [[Logan Lerman]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0503567/bio|title=Logan Lerman|website=IMDb.com|accessdate=7 June 2016}}</ref> In the late 1990s and early 2000s, Lowenstein recorded with his [[identical twin]] brother, Evan, in the [[pop music|pop]] duo [[Evan and Jaron]].<ref name=\"boot\">{{cite web|url=http://www.theboot.com/2010/03/12/jaron-long-road-love-songs/|title=Jaron Prescribes Music as Antidote to Tough Times|date=March 12, 2010|work=The Boot|accessdate=March 12, 2010}}</ref> Evan and Jaron charted three [[single (music)|singles]], including \"[[Crazy for This Girl]],\" which reached number 15 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] charts in 2000.<ref name=\"weekly\">{{cite journal|date=1 February 2010|title=Who's New|journal=[[Country Weekly]]|volume=17|issue=5|pages=17|issn=1074-3235}}</ref> The duo split up in 2003 so that Evan could focus on raising his family.<ref name=\"boot\"/>\n\nJaron co-wrote and recorded his first solo single, \"[[Pray for You (Jaron and the Long Road to Love song)|Pray for You]]\", as Jaron and the Long Road to Love in late 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.cmt.com/2009-11-20/jaron-lowenstein-offers-a-prayer-for-your-ex/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091123193835/http://blog.cmt.com/2009-11-20/jaron-lowenstein-offers-a-prayer-for-your-ex/|url-status=dead|archive-date=November 23, 2009|title=Jaron Lowenstein Offers a Prayer for Your Ex|last=Bonaguro|first=Alison|date=November 20, 2009|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]|accessdate=November 24, 2009}}</ref> Starting in February 2010, [[Big Machine Records]] assumed promotion of the single and a forthcoming album, which was distributed through a partnership of Jaron's Jaronwood label and [[Universal Republic]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/71765/jaron-long-run-ink-deal-with-universal-republic?ref=search|title=Jaron & Long Run Ink Deal With Universal Republic|date=March 5, 2010|work=All Access|accessdate=March 25, 2010}}</ref> The song reached the top 40 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart and the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].\n\nJaron told [[Technorati]] that the song \"wasn't started or pushed by some major label or organization. I would love to take the credit for its success, but honestly this is something fans want and they are the ones calling radio to have them play it.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://technorati.com/entertainment/article/even-celebrities-arent-immune-to-valentines1/|title=Even Celebrities Aren't Immune To Valentine's Day Pressure|date=February 16, 2010|work=Technorati|accessdate=March 26, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100219010143/http://technorati.com/entertainment/article/even-celebrities-arent-immune-to-valentines1/|archive-date=February 19, 2010|url-status=dead}}</ref> Hank Friedmann directed a [[music video]] for the song, which has aired on [[CMT Pure Country]] (CMT Pure) and [[Great American Country]] (GAC).<ref name=\"cmtvid\">{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/jaron-and-the-long-road-to-love/467605/pray-for-you.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100108012801/http://www.cmt.com/videos/jaron-and-the-long-road-to-love/467605/pray-for-you.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 8, 2010|title=Music video for \"Pray for You\"|work=CMT|accessdate=March 23, 2010}}</ref> A second video, which includes [[Jaime Pressly]], debuted in April 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.cmt.com/2010-04-12/jaron-gives-the-back-story-in-new-pray-for-you/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725192819/http://blog.cmt.com/2010-04-12/jaron-gives-the-back-story-in-new-pray-for-you/|url-status=dead|archive-date=July 25, 2011|title=Jaron Gives the Back Story in New \"Pray for You\"|last=Bonaguro|first=Alison|date=April 12, 2010|work=CMT|accessdate=April 12, 2010}}</ref>\n\nHis debut album, ''Getting Dressed in the Dark'', was released on June 22, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theboot.com/2010/04/07/jaron-long-road-to-love-getting-dressed-in-the-dark-new-album/|title=Jaron Gets 'Dressed' for New Album|last=Hughes|first=Donna|date=April 7, 2010|work=The Boot|accessdate=April 12, 2010}}</ref> The album's second single is \"That's Beautiful to Me\", which debuted on the country chart at number 59 in September 2010.\n\nIn early 2011, Lowenstein parted ways with [[Big Machine Records]] and [[Republic Nashville]]. Despite leaving the label, a third single from ''Getting Dressed in the Dark'', \"It's a Good Thing\", was released on April 18, 2011, with promotion from Nine North Records. However, the single failed to chart.\n\nOn May 31, 2011, Lowenstein released \"Beautiful Lies\", which features [[Big Kenny]], one-half of the [[country music]] duo [[Big & Rich]]. The song is the lead-off single to Lowenstein's second album. The song also failed to chart.\n\nIn 2011, eleven songs were released as a self-titled album by the band Cordovas. The band is made out of [[Joe Firstman]], Jaron Lowenstein, Jon Loyd, Johnny Gray, Parker Gins and Toby Weaver.  The album was made available as a free download on the band's official website <ref name=\"Official Site\">{{cite web|url=http://www.cordovasband.com|title=Cordovas|date=2011}}</ref> as well as other traditional paying outlets.\n\nThe songs \"Old Dog\" and \"All I Found\" had videos released online.\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n!
