Year\n! Association\n! Category\n! Result\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2010\n| rowspan=\"2\"| [[American Country Awards]]\n| New/Breakthrough Artist of the Year<ref name=\"ACA\">{{cite web|url=http://dailypostal.com/2010/10/16/2010-american-country-awards-nominations-aca-nominees/|title=2010 American Country Awards Nominees|publisher=www.dailypostal.com|accessdate=October 18, 2010}}</ref>\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Single by New/Breakthrough Artist \u2014 \"Pray for You\"<ref name=\"ACA\" />\n| {{nom}}\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist|30em}}\n\n==External links==\n*[https://web.archive.org/web/20130617211706/http://jaron.heyconvo.com/index1.php Official Website]\n*[https://www.facebook.com/jaronlowenstein Artist's Official Facebook Site]\n*[http://www.cordovasband.com/ Cordovas Official Web Site]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Lowenstein, Jaron}}\n[[Category:1974 births]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Big Machine Records artists]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:People from Tucker, Georgia]]\n[[Category:American Orthodox Jews]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Georgia (U.S. state)]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American Jews]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Georgia (U.S. state)]]\n[[Category:Identical twin males]]\n[[Category:Singers from Atlanta]]\n[[Category:American twins]]\n[[Category:Jewish American rock musicians]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jerrod_Niemann","to":"Jerrod Niemann"}],"pages":{"19894424":{"pageid":19894424,"ns":0,"title":"Jerrod Niemann","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Jerrod Niemann\n| image           = USO Holiday Tour at Mor\u00f3n Air Base 171221-D-PB383-070 (25340554668).jpg\n| caption         = Niemann performing at [[Mor\u00f3n Air Base]] in Spain\n| birth_name      = Jerrod Lee Niemann\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1979|07|24}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wbkr.com/jerrod-niemann-pam-tillis-celebrate-birthdays-today-july-24-video/|title=Jerrod Niemann, Pam Tillis Celebrate Birthdays \u2014 Today July 24 [Video]|first=Moon|last=Mullins|website=Wbkr.com}}</ref>\n| origin          = [[Liberal, Kansas]], U.S.\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 1999\u2013present\n| label           = {{hlist|[[Mercury Nashville]]|[[Category 5 Records|Category 5]]|[[Sea Gayle Music]]/[[Arista Nashville]]|[[Curb Records|Curb]]}}\n| website         = http://www.jerrodniemannofficial.com/\n}}\n\n'''Jerrod Lee Niemann''' (born July 24, 1979) is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. He has released one single for [[Category 5 Records]] (2006); three albums for [[Sea Gayle Music]]/[[Arista Nashville]]: ''[[Judge Jerrod & the Hung Jury]]'' (2010), ''[[Free the Music]]'' (2012), and ''[[High Noon (Jerrod Niemann album)|High Noon]]'' (2014); and one album, ''[[This Ride]]'' (2017), for [[Curb Records]]. These albums have produced a combined ten Top 40 entries on the [[Hot Country Songs]] and [[Country Airplay]] charts, including the Platinum Number 1 singles \"Lover, Lover\" (a cover of [[Sonia Dada]]'s \"[[You Don't Treat Me No Good]]\") and \"[[Drink to That All Night]]\" and Gold Top 5 single \"[[What Do You Want]]\". He has also co-written three singles for [[Garth Brooks]]: the chart topping [[Chris LeDoux]] tribute \"[[Good Ride Cowboy]]\", as well as \"That Girl Is a Cowboy\" and \"Midnight Sun\". [[Jamey Johnson]], [[Lee Brice]], [[Blake Shelton]], [[Colbie Caillat]], [[Diamond Rio]], [[The Cadillac Three]], [[Mark Chesnutt]], [[John Anderson (musician)|John Anderson]], [[Neal McCoy]], [[Christian Kane]], and [[Julie Roberts]] have also recorded Niemann's songs.\n\n==Career==\n\n===Singer===\nNiemann was born in [[Harper, Kansas]], but raised in [[Liberal, Kansas]]. From an early age, he was influenced by country acts such as [[Lefty Frizzell]], [[Keith Whitley]], and [[George Strait]]. He learned to play his first musical instrument on a [[Tracy Lawrence]] autographed guitar his mother won in a contest at a Lawrence concert.\n\nAfter graduating from [[Liberal High School (Kansas)|Liberal High School]], Niemann attended [[South Plains College]] in [[Levelland, Texas]]. Niemann began his professional music career by singing and playing acoustic guitar in Texas clubs and bars, particularly the Stockyard Saloon and the historic White Elephant Saloon located in the [[Fort Worth Stockyards]]. In 1999 he self-released his debut album ''Long Hard Road''.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p880844/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Jerrod Niemann biography|last=Leggett|first=Steve|work=Allmusic|access-date=July 6, 2010}}</ref>\n\nNiemann moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in September 2000. He signed a developmental deal with [[Mercury Records]] in August 2001 but did not release anything on the label.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> After parting with Mercury Records, Niemann and his band continued touring the club circuit across America playing venues such as the Grizzly Rose in [[Denver]] and the [[Wildhorse Saloon]] in Nashville. He soon traveled to Europe to tour with the band Kane consisting of members [[Christian Kane]] and Steve Carlson.\n\nIn 2006, he signed to [[Category 5 Records]] and charted with the single \"[[I Love Women (My Momma Can't Stand)]]\". The label closed shortly after this single's release, and the album ''Behind This Microphone'' was never released.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\n===2010{{ndash}}2015: Arista Nashville===\n[[File:Jerrod.jpg|200px|thumb|left|Niemann at [[CMA Music Festival]], 2010.]]\nNiemann signed to [[Arista Nashville]]'s Sea Gayle division, co-owned by [[Brad Paisley]], in 2010. His debut single \"[[Lover, Lover]]\", was released in early 2010; it was originally recorded by the [[folk music]] group [[Sonia Dada]] under the title \"You Don't Treat Me No Good\" and was a Number 1 single in Australia in 1992.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/69880/jerrod-niemann-releases-debut-arista-single|title=Jerrod Niemann releases debut Arista single|work=All Access|access-date=February 28, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Who's New: Jerrod Niemann|journal=[[Country Weekly]]|date=May 24, 2010|volume=17|issue=21|pages=21|issn=1074-3235}}</ref> In March 2010, \"Lover, Lover\" became Niemann's first Top 40 single on the country music charts and in August 2010 hit Number 1. The song is included on his first major-label album, ''[[Judge Jerrod & the Hung Jury]],\" ''which debuted at Number 1 on [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] Top Country Sales Chart.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> The album also was named one of [[The New York Times]] Top 10 Albums of the Year. The album's second single, \"[[What Do You Want]]\", debuted on the U.S. [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] [[Hot Country Songs]] chart that October.  In November 2010, Niemann was nominated in the \"New Artist\" category for that year's [[Country Music Association]] [[Country Music Association Awards]].  At the 2010 [[American Country Awards]], Niemann was nominated for \"Artist of the Year: Breakthrough Artist,\" \"Single of the Year: Breakthrough Artist,\" and \"Music Video: Breakthrough Artist\" for \"[[Lover, Lover]].\"  He was also nominated for \"Breakthrough Video of the Year\" for \"Lover, Lover\" at the 2011 [[Country Music Television]] [[Country Music Television Music Awards]].  In May 2011, \"What Do You Want\" peaked at Number 4. The album's third single, \"[[One More Drinkin' Song]]\", reached Number 13 in December 2011.  Niemann finished up the year with four nominations at the [[American Country Awards]], including \"Artist of the Year: New Artist,\" \"Music Video of the Year,\" \"Music Video: Male,\" and \"Music Video; New Artist\" for \"[[What Do You Want]].\"\n\nNiemann released his fourth Arista single, \"[[Shinin' on Me]]\", on April 9, 2012. His second Arista album, ''[[Free the Music]]'', was released on October 2, 2012. The album's second single, \"[[Only God Could Love You More]]\", charted late in the year.<ref>{{cite magazine|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=jerrod niemann|chart=Country Airplay}}|title=Jerrod Niemann: Chart History: Country Airplay|magazine=Billboard|accessdate=8 November 2012}}</ref>\n\n\"[[Drink to That All Night]]\" was released in late 2013 as the first single off of his third album for Arista. The album, ''[[High Noon (Jerrod Niemann album)|High Noon]]'', was released in March 2014, debuting at Number 2 on [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] Top Country Sales.   In April 2014, \"Drink to That All Night\" became his second Number 1 single.  Niemann collaborated with [[Pitbull (rapper)]] on the remix of the song.  Singles \"[[Donkey (song)|Donkey]]\" and \"[[Buzz Back Girl]]\" were also released off this album.\n\n===2016{{ndash}}present: Curb===\nNiemann parted ways with Arista Nashville in January 2016, shortly after releasing another single titled \"[[Blue Bandana]]\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/149646/jerrod-niemann-parts-ways-with-arista-nashville|title=Jerrod Niemann Parts Ways With Arista Nashville|work=All Access|date=January 20, 2016}}</ref> In March 2016, Niemann signed a record deal with [[Curb Records]]. His first single for the label was \"[[A Little More Love (Jerrod Niemann and Lee Brice song)|A Little More Love]]\", a duet with [[Lee Brice]]. It reached the top 30 of the Country Airplay chart.\n\nIn March 2017, Niemann released \"God Made a Woman,\" which he called his \"favorite song I\u2019ve ever recorded.\"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.soundslikenashville.com/music/listen-to-jerrod-niemanns-romantic-new-single-god-made-a-woman/|title=Listen to Jerrod Niemann's Romantic New Single, 'God Made a Woman'|date=March 1, 2017|work=Sounds Like Nashville|access-date=March 20, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref> Niemann's wife, Morgan, is featured in the music video. It served as the lead-off single to his fourth studio album, ''[[This Ride]]'', which was released via Curb Records on October 6, 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/us/album/this-ride/1269104156|title=This Ride by Jerrod Niemann|via=music.apple.com}}</ref> \"I Got This\" was released as the album's second single, and it peaked in the top 40 of the Country Airplay chart.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://jerrodniemannofficial.com/news/2017/8/22/jerrod-niemann-returns-with-daring-new-album-this-ride-october-6|title=Jerrod Niemann Returns With Daring New Album 'This Ride' October 6|website=Jerrodniemannofficial.com}}</ref>\n\nAfter exiting Curb, Niemann independently released a digital-only album entitled ''Lost & Found'' in 2020. The release includes two singles: \"Ghost Rider\" and \"Tequila Kisses\".<ref name=\"lost and found\">{{cite web | url=https://www.digitaljournal.com/entertainment/jerrod-niemann-talks-tequila-kisses-ghost-rider-quarantine/article/576320 | title=Jerrod Niemann talks 'Tequila Kisses,' 'Ghost Rider,' quarantine (Includes interview) | publisher=Digital Journal | date=August 13, 2020 | accessdate=March 24, 2022}}</ref>\n\n===Songwriting===\nAt the age of 8, Niemann was writing several songs a year. He found legendary Nashville songwriters such as [[Whitey Shafer]], [[Dean Dillon]], and [[Paul Overstreet]] to be very influential in his songwriting and went on to co-write with all three while living there. Aged 10 he performed original songs in local talent shows in Kansas. After collecting several compositions throughout high school, Niemann recorded his debut album ''Long Hard Road'' in [[Clovis, New Mexico]], while attending college in [[Levelland, Texas]].\n\nIn May 2001, Niemann was contacted by [[Garth Brooks]] to collaborate, along with fellow songwriter Richie Brown. Niemann went on to co-write three singles for [[Garth Brooks]]: the [[Chris LeDoux]] tribute \"[[Good Ride Cowboy]]\",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.prleap.com/pr/58771/ |title=Category 5 Records Signs Jerrod Niemann |access-date=October 22, 2008 |last=Stark |first=Phyllis |date=December 15, 2006 |work=PRLeap.com}}</ref> as well as \"That Girl Is a Cowboy\" and \"Midnight Sun\". \"Good Ride Cowboy\" earned Niemann a [[Broadcast Music Incorporated]] award for being one of the most played country songs of 2006. Niemann was awarded two BMI awards in 2012 for \"What Do You Want\" and \"One More Drinking Song\", each being one of the most played songs of the year.\n\nOther artists who have recorded Niemann's work include [[Jamey Johnson]], [[Lee Brice]], [[Blake Shelton]], [[Colbie Caillat]], [[Diamond Rio]], [[The Cadillac Three]], [[Mark Chesnutt]], [[John Anderson (musician)]], [[Neal McCoy]], [[Christian Kane]], and [[Julie Roberts]].  Niemann has signed publishing deals throughout his career with Marathon Key Music (a co-venture with [[Warner/Chappell Music]]) and Sea Gayle Music.<ref name=\"radioinfo\">{{cite web|last=Stark |first=Phyllis |title=Sea Gayle Sets Sail With New Label |url=http://www.radio-info.com/programming/country/sea-gayle-sets-sail-with-new-label |date=October 16, 2009 |work=Radio-Info.com |access-date=October 21, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110814014952/http://www.radio-info.com/programming/country/sea-gayle-sets-sail-with-new-label |archive-date=August 14, 2011 }}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nOn March 6, 2012, Niemann's tour bus caught fire. He was unharmed. Niemann credits fellow country singer [[Lee Brice]] for alerting him to the dangerous blaze.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20576586,00.html |title=Jerrod Niemann Survives Tour Bus Explosion|access-date=March 7, 2012 |date=March 7, 2012 |magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]]}}</ref>\n\nNiemann became engaged to longtime girlfriend Morgan Petek in New Orleans in late 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/jerrod-niemann-engaged/|title=Jerrod Niemann Getting Married This Year|first=Christina|last=Vinson|website=Tasteofcountry.com}}</ref> Niemann and Petek appeared on [[TLC (TV channel)|TLC]] TV series ''[[Say Yes to the Dress]]'' with Niemann's family to pick out Petek's wedding dress. They married on October 12, 2014, in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://people.com/country/jerrod-niemann-marries-morgan-petek/|title=Jerrod Niemann Marries Morgan Petek|website=People.com}}</ref> Niemann and Petek founded non-profit \"Free the Music USA\", which provides musical equipment and education to children in need. They are also actively involved with many animal rescue non-profits. Niemann is also involved with the [[United Service Organizations]] and went to Afghanistan, Kuwait, Romania, and Kosovo in 2016 on his first overseas tour. Jerrod and Morgan divorced after more than four years of marriage. The divorce was finalized on December 17, 2018.\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Jerrod Niemann discography}}\n'''Studio albums'''\n* ''Long Hard Road'' (1999)\n* ''Jukebox of Hard Knocks'' (2004)\n* ''[[Judge Jerrod & the Hung Jury]]'' (2010)\n* ''[[Free the Music]]'' (2012)\n* ''Yellow Brick Road'' (2013)\n* ''[[High Noon (Jerrod Niemann album)|High Noon]]'' (2014)\n* ''[[This Ride]]'' (2017)\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.jerrodniemannofficial.com/ Official Website]\n\n{{Commons category}}\n\n{{Jerrod Niemann}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Niemann, Jerrod}}\n[[Category:1979 births]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Arista Nashville artists]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Kansas]]\n[[Category:Curb Records artists]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:People from Liberal, Kansas]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Kansas]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Tom_Hambridge","to":"Tom Hambridge"}],"pages":{"33058717":{"pageid":33058717,"ns":0,"title":"Tom Hambridge","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American drummer}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2024}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Tom Hambridge\n| image             = Tom Hambridge Bio.jpg\n| caption        =\n| image_size        =\n| birth_name      = Thomas Jay Hambridge\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1960|12|20}}\n| birth_place     = [[Buffalo, New York]], United States\n| instruments      = Drums, vocals\n| genre           = Rock, [[Country music|country]], [[blues]]\n| occupations      = Record producer, musician, songwriter, singer\n| label           = Artemis Records, Superstar Records, [[EMI Music Publishing]], Black Rose, Ocean Records, UTR Music Group\n| website            = [http://hambridgetunes.com// Official Website]\n}}\n\n'''Thomas Jay Hambridge'''<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ascap.com/ace/search.cfm?requesttimeout=300&mode=results&searchstr=1528370&search_in=c&search_type=exact&search_det=t,s,w,p,b,v&results_pp=10&start=1 |title=American Society of Composers |work=ascap.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> (born December 20, 1960)<ref>{{cite web | url=http://zildjian.com/Artists/H/Tom-Hambridge |title=Artist Website \u2013 Bio |work=zildjian.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> is an American rock, [[Country music|country]], and [[blues]], producer, songwriter, musician and vocalist. Hambridge has received two [[Grammy Awards]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.grammy.com/news/and-the-grammy-went-to-buddy-guy  |title=Grammy Website \u2013 Living Proof |publisher=National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> an ASCAP award,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ascap.com/eventsawards/awards/ascapcma/2007/winners.html |title=ASCAP Awards 2007 |work=ascap.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> seven Grammy nominations,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nashvillemusicguide.net/october-2010-producers-spotlight-tom-hambridge/ |title=Nashville Music Guide \u22122010 Producers Spotlight, Tom Hambridge |work=nashvillemusicguide.net |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> seven Boston Music Awards, and has been inducted into the Buffalo Hall of Fame.<ref name=\"buffalo\">{{cite web | url=http://www.buffalomusic.org/2001_thambridge.html  |title=Buffalo Hall of Fame Inductees \u2013 2001 |work=buffalomusic.org |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> In December 2015, Hambridge was given the key to his hometown of [[Buffalo, New York]] with Mayor [[Byron Brown]] declaring December 28 \"Tom Hambridge Day.\"<ref>{{cite web | url= http://buffalonews.com/2015/12/28/music-talent-tom-hambridge-has-his-own-day-in-buffalo/ |title= Tom Hambridge Day|work=buffalonews.com |year=2015 |accessdate=January 25, 2017}}</ref> Hambridge's songs have been recorded by several notable artists and have been featured in movie productions, commercials and television programs. He has been referred to as \"The White [[Willie Dixon]]\" by Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Inductee [[Buddy Guy]]<ref>{{cite web | url= http://zildjian.com/Artists/H/Tom-Hambridge|title= White Willie Dixon |work=zildjian.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> and [[Susan Tedeschi]]'s \"Secret Weapon\".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.moderndrummer.com/updatefull/200001290/Tom%20Hambridge|title= Susan Tedeschi's Secret Weapon |website=Moderndrummer.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref>\n\n==Biography==\nBorn and raised in [[Buffalo, New York]], Hambridge began learning the drums at the age of 5. He played his first paying gig, a bar mitzvah, in third grade. Throughout his school years, Hambridge played in garage bands, his high school orchestra and jazz band. After graduating from high school in 1979, he received a scholarship at Boston's Berklee College of Music.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.berklee.edu/bt/131/alum_profile.html |title=Alum Profile: Tom Hambridge 83-Renaissance Man in a City of Specialists &#124; Berklee College of Music|first= Mark|last=Small|work=berklee.edu |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref>\n[[File:Tom Hambridge Drums.jpg|thumb|left |alt= Tom Playing Drums.| Tom Hambridge]]\n \nHe received his degree in Professional Music in 1983. After graduation, he worked for three years as drummer and lead singer for the blues guitarist [[Roy Buchanan]]. While working with Buchanan, Hambridge contributed as a musician on Buchanan's release, ''Live: Amazing Grace''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/live-amazing-grace-r1626349/credits |title=Roy Buchanan \u2013 Live Amazing Grace |first= Roy|last=Buchanan |publisher=AllMusic |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> In the meantime, he formed the band \"T.H. and the Wreckage\". In 1988, the band released ''Born to Rock,''<ref name=\"blackrose\">{{cite web | url=http://www.blackroserecords.net/store.html|title= Black Rose Records |work=blackroserecords.net |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> one of several independent, self-produced albums Hambridge has completed. ''Born To Rock'' was the first of the many [[Boston Music Awards]] he has received. In the meantime, he assisted promoters assemble backup bands for artists such as [[Bo Diddley]], [[Percy Sledge]], [[Chuck Berry]], [[Gary Puckett]], and [[Sha Na Na]].<ref name=\"buffalo\"/>\n\nHambridge released his own album ''Still Running'' in 1996.<ref name=\"stillrunning\">{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/still-running-r289975|title= Still Running, Hambridge |last= Tom Hambridge |publisher=AllMusic |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref>\n\nIn 1997, he produced [[Susan Tedeschi]]'s ''[[Just Won't Burn]]''. Hambridge wrote Tedeschi's Top 10 hits \"Rock Me Right\" and \"It Hurt So Bad\".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.eminashville.com/bios/thambridge.html |title=EMI Nashville \u2013 Tom Hambridge |work=eminashville.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> In the meantime, he also released his own album ''Balderdash'' in 2000.<ref name=\"balderdash\">{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/balderdash-r503030|title= Balderdash, Hambridge |last= Tom Hambridge |publisher=AllMusic |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> Hambridge received a subsequent 2004 Grammy nomination ([[Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Blues Album]]) for his contributions on [[Johnny Winter]]'s release ''I'm A Bluesman''  (\"Cheatin' Blues\" and \"Lone Wolf\").<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.artistdirect.com/nad/store/artist/album/0,,2890478,00.html |title= Artist Direct \u2013 Johnny Winter -I'm A Bluesman |work=artistdirect.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> Shortly thereafter, Hambridge released his album ''Bang N' Roll'' (2004) and the album ''Live'' (2007).<ref name=\"bangnroll\">{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/bang-n-roll-r705780|title= Bang N' Roll, Hambridge |publisher=AllMusic |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref>\n\nIn 2008, he received Grammy nominations ([[Grammy Award for Best Traditional Blues Album]]) for his work on [[Buddy Guy]]'s ''[[Skin Deep (Buddy Guy album)|Skin Deep]]''. ''Skin Deep'' debuted at number 68 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] which was the highest position of any of Guy's previous albums, and was number 1 on the Billboard Blues Album Chart. Hambridge released his own album ''Boogieman'' (2009).<ref name=\"boogieman\">{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/boogieman-r1553953|title= Boogieman, Hambridge |publisher=AllMusic |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> In 2011, he won the [[Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Blues Album]] for co-writing and producing [[Buddy Guy]]'s album ''[[Living Proof (Buddy Guy album)|Living Proof]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2010-10-31-buddy-guy_N.htm |title= USA Today \u2013 Buddy Guy, Living Proof |first=Steve |last=Jones |work=Artistdirect.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref>\n\nHe was credited as the producer, songwriter and percussionist for [[George Thorogood and the Destroyers]] 2011 release ''[[2120 South Michigan Ave.]]'', which included the song \"Going Back\" that reached number 1 on Classic Rock Radio. Also in 2011, he wrote and produced [[B. B. King]] and [[Buddy Guy]]'s duet \"Stay Around A Little Longer.\"<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.grammy.com/news/and-the-grammy-went-to-buddy-guy |title= Grammy \u2013 Buddy Guy, Stay Around A Little Longer |publisher=National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref>\n\nOther recognized 2011 successes include writing/co-writing all songs on [[Quinn Sullivan (musician)|Quinn Sullivan]]'s release ''Cyclone''<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/cyclone-r2141383&sa=U&ei=eoJvTqq4AvSKsALZtLjCCQ&ved=0CBgQFjABOAo&usg=AFQjCNEm_JWDfRJwNJvB369YVbpAFE9pQw |title=Quinn Sullivan, Cyclone |publisher=AllMusic |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> (2011, number 7 on the Billboard Blues chart, July 30, 2011).<ref name=\"cyclone\">{{cite magazine | url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2011-07-30/blues-albums |title=Quinn Sullivan, Cyclone |magazine=Billboard |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> Later in 2013, Hambridge would do the same on [[Quinn Sullivan (musician)|Quinn Sullivan]]'s release ''Getting There'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/getting-there-mw0002550681 |title=Getting There |publisher=AllMusic |accessdate=January 25, 2017}}</ref> which charted at 38 on the Billboard Blues Chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/277262/quinn-sullivan/chart|title=Billboard Blues Charts \u2013 Getting There |magazine=Billboard |accessdate=January 25, 2017}}</ref>\n\nIn 2015, Hambridge earned his second [[Grammy Award for Best Blues Album]] for his contributions as a musician, producer, composer and mixer on [[Buddy Guy]]'s [[Born to Play Guitar]].\n\nIn 2016, Hambridge produced [[Mike Zito]]'s album, ''Make Blues Not War'',<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.allmusic.com/album/make-blues-not-war-mw0002985066  |title= Mike Zito \u2013 Make Blues Not War |publisher=AllMusic |year=2016 |accessdate=January 25, 2017}}</ref> which debuted at number 1 on the [[Billboard Chart]] on December 10, 2016<ref>{{cite magazine | url= http://www.billboard.com/artist/311241/mike-zito/chart?sort=position&f=308  |title= Billboard Music Charts \u2013 Mike Zito|magazine=Billboard |year=2016 |accessdate=January 25, 2017}}</ref> and earned his seventh [[Grammy Award]] Nomination<ref>{{cite magazine | url= http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7597556/grammys-nominees-complete-list-2017  |title= Grammy Nomination \u2013 Kenny Neal's Bloodline|magazine=Billboard |year=2016 |accessdate=January 25, 2017}}</ref> for his production work on [[Bloodline (Kenny Neal album)|Bloodline]].\n\nHambridge's songs and productions have appeared on a variety of television shows, movies and commercials.  These include \"It Hurt's So Bad\" ([[Susan Tedeschi]]) on [[PBS]]'s ''Austin City Limits'',<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.tvguide.com/detail/tv-show.aspx?tvobjectid=191387&more=ucepisodelist&episodeid=955221|title= TV Guide |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> ''Autumn Hearts'',<ref name=\"autumn\">{{cite web | url= http://www.artistdirect.com/nad/store/movies/title/0,,3788547,00.html |title= Autumn Hearts (motion picture) |work=artistdirect.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> [[VH1]]'s ''Born To Diva'',<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.starpathmusic.com/press_txt.html |title= VH1 Born To Diva |work=starpathmusic.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> [[NBC]]'s ''[[Conan O'Brien]]'',<ref>{{cite web | url= https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1442910/filmoyear |title= Conan O'Brien |publisher=IMDb |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> and ''The Late Late Show with Craig Kilborn''.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.thefreelibrary.com/BLUES,+NOT+BUBBLEGUM%3B+TESDECHI+GOES+FOR+GRAMMY.-a083391601|title= Late Late Show With Craig Kilborn |work=thefreelibrary.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> In addition, \"Rock Me Right\" (Susan Tedeschi) appeared in ''Autumn Hearts'',<ref name=\"autumn\"/> ''[[David Letterman Show]]'', ''NASCAR Rocks II'' (1999),<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/472491/NASCAR-Rocks-II/ |title= NASCAR Rocks II (1999) |work=tcm.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> and ''[[Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.cduniverse.com/search/xx/music/pid/1249806/a/Flintstones+in+Viva+Rock+Vegas,+The.htm |title= Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas |work=cduniverse.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> \"I Fell in Love\" (Susan Tedeschi) appeared on the [[Bug (soundtrack)|''Bug'' soundtrack]].<ref>{{cite web | url= https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1442910/filmoyear |title= I Fell in Love |publisher=IMDb |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> Plus, \"Road Trip\" and \"I Got A New Car\" (Tom Hambridge) appeared in the movie ''[[Cars (soundtrack)|Cars]]''. \"Flying By\" ([[Billy Ray Cyrus]]) appeared in the film, ''Flying By''.\n\nHambridge has performed multiple times at the [[White House]].  On February 21, 2012, he joined [[Buddy Guy]], [[Keb Mo]], [[Susan Tedeschi]], [[Derek Trucks]], [[Mick Jagger]], [[B. B. King]] and others in a performance for the White House's \"Red, White and Blues\" Black History Month celebration concert.  During the performance, President [[Barack Obama]] provided a brief history of the Blues and accompanied the group during the song \"[[Sweet Home Chicago]]\".  On October 14, 2015, Hambridge returned to the [[White House]] with [[Buddy Guy]], [[Marty Sammon]], [[Trombone Shorty]], [[Carol Burnett]], [[Queen Latifah]], [[MC Lyte]], [[Keb Mo]], [[Smokey Robinson]] and others for \"A Celebration of American Creativity: In Performance at the White House\", commemorating the 50th anniversary of the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]].\n\n==Credits==\n;As leader\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! style=\"text-align: center; font-weight: bold;border: 1px solid #000;\" | Year\n! style=\"text-align: center; font-weight: Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"John_Rich","to":"John Rich"}],"pages":{"2669208":{"pageid":2669208,"ns":0,"title":"John Rich","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country musician}}\n{{About|the American musician}}\n{{Use American English|date=August 2023}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2023}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = John Rich\n| image             = File:John Rich 190503-F-LU725-0114 (cropped).jpg\n| caption           = Rich performing in 2019\n| background        = solo_singer\n| birth_name        = \n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1974|1|7}}\n| birth_place       = [[Amarillo, Texas]], U.S.\n| origin            = [[Dickson, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| instrument        = Vocals, bass guitar, guitar\n| genre             = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation        = Singer-songwriter, record producer\n| years_active      = 1992\u2013present\n| label             = [[BNA Records|BNA]], [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros. Nashville]], [[Reprise Records|Reprise]]\n| current_member_of = [[Big & Rich]]\n| past_member_of    = [[Lonestar]]\n| website           = {{URL|johnrich.com}}\n}}\n\n'''John Rich''' (born January 7, 1974) is an American [[country music]] singer-songwriter. From 1992 to 1998, he was a member of the country band [[Lonestar]], in which he played bass guitar and alternated with [[Richie McDonald]] as lead vocalist.  After departing from the band in 1998, he embarked on a solo career on [[BNA Records]] in the late 1990s, releasing two singles for the label and recording ''[[Underneath the Same Moon]]'', which was not released until 2006. In 2001, he self-released ''Rescue Me'', an album he was inspired to record by a cancer patient named Katie Darnell.  By 2003, he joined [[Big Kenny]] to form the duo [[Big & Rich]], who released three albums on [[Warner Bros. Records]] as well as ten singles, including the Number One \"[[Lost in This Moment]]\". After Big & Rich went on hiatus in 2007, Rich began work on a third solo album, ''[[Son of a Preacher Man (John Rich album)|Son of a Preacher Man]]'', which has produced two more chart singles. In 2011, Rich released two extended plays, ''[[Rich Rocks]]'' and ''[[For the Kids (EP)|For the Kids]]'', before re-establishing Big & Rich in 2012.\n\n==Music career==\n\n===Lonestar===\n{{Main|Lonestar}}\nJohn Rich was born on January 7, 1974, in [[Amarillo, Texas]],<ref>{{Cite web |title=John Rich Biography, Songs, & Albums |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/john-rich-mn0000233467/biography |access-date=August 22, 2023 |website=AllMusic |language=en}}</ref> the son of Jim, a Baptist preacher, and Judy Overton Rich.  John graduated from Dickson County Senior High in [[Dickson, Tennessee]] and after graduation moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] where he worked as a singer at [[Opryland USA]]. He wanted to be a professional [[Team roping|team roper]]. Not long after, he met up with the group Texasee, which eventually changed its name to Lonestar. While in Lonestar, Rich was the bass guitarist and co-lead vocalist with [[Richie McDonald]]. Their 1996 single \"[[Heartbroke Every Day]]\" was the only one to feature Rich on lead vocals. Rich also co-wrote two of the band's singles: \"[[Come Cryin' to Me]]\" and \"[[Say When (song)|Say When]]\", the former being a number-one single for the group. In January 1998, Rich departed from Lonestar, but was never officially replaced, causing Lonestar to continue as a four-piece band.<ref name=\"usa\">{{cite web |url=http://www.usanetwork.com/series/nashvillestar/theshow/characterprofiles/rich/index.html |title=Character profile: John Rich |access-date=January 30, 2008 |work=USA Networks |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110215083929/http://www.usanetwork.com/series/nashvillestar/theshow/characterprofiles/rich/index.html |archive-date=February 15, 2011 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Afterward, Rich became a solo artist with [[BNA Records]], the same label to which Lonestar was signed. He charted two singles for the label and recorded an album which did not see release until 2006. In 2001, he recorded and self-released ''Rescue Me'', an album he was inspired to record after meeting cancer patient Katie Darnell.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.mc.vanderbilt.edu:8080/reporter/index.html?ID=1362 |title=Reporter |access-date=September 21, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170921144212/http://www.mc.vanderbilt.edu:8080/reporter/index.html?ID=1362 |archive-date=September 21, 2017 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n===Big & Rich===\n{{Main|Big & Rich}}\n[[File:JohnRichApr10.jpg|thumb|right|Rich in 2010]]\nRich joined [[Big Kenny]] in 2002 to form the duo [[Big & Rich]].<ref>{{cite book|title=MuzikMafia: From the Nashville Scene to the National Mainstream|author=Pruett, David B.|year=2010 |publisher=University Press of Mississippi.|location=Jackson, MS}}</ref> The duo recorded three studio albums for [[Warner Bros. Records]]: ''[[Horse of a Different Color (Big & Rich album)|Horse of a Different Color]]'', ''[[Comin' to Your City]]'' and ''[[Between Raising Hell and Amazing Grace]]'', in 2004, 2005 and 2007 respectively. These albums accounted for ten singles on the country charts, including the Number One \"[[Lost in This Moment]]\". Rich also co-wrote all of the duo's singles, primarily with Big Kenny. In the wake of Big & Rich's success, his 1999 solo album ''[[Underneath the Same Moon]]'' was issued via BNA, coinciding with the release of Big Kenny's previously unreleased solo album ''[[Live a Little (Big Kenny album)|Live a Little]]''.  A fourth Big & Rich studio album was released in the summer of 2012, with the inspiring \"That's Why I Pray\" reaching No. 15 on the country charts.\n\n===Work for other artists===\n{{Main|List of songs written by John Rich}}\nDuring Big & Rich's success, Rich also worked as a songwriter and producer for other artists. His work included production for [[Gretchen Wilson]], [[Keith Anderson]], [[Jewel (musician)|Jewel]] and [[John Anderson (musician)|John Anderson]]. In the same time span, he co-wrote multiple singles for other artists, including the Number One hits \"[[Redneck Woman]]\" for Wilson, \"[[Mississippi Girl]]\" for [[Faith Hill]] and \"[[Why (Jason Aldean song)|Why]]\" for [[Jason Aldean]].\n\nHe also has a co-write on [[Taylor Swift]]'s 2008 album ''[[Fearless (Taylor Swift album)|Fearless]]'', titled \"[[The Way I Loved You (Taylor Swift song)|The Way I Loved You]]\".\n\nIn 2011, Rich recorded a song with [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]] band [[Black Label Society]], entitled \"Darkest Days\", featured on their compilation album, ''[[The Song Remains Not the Same]]''.\n\nIn 2016, Rich added his voice to a duet with [[Marie Osmond]] on her album ''[[Music Is Medicine]]'' with the song titled \"Love This Tough\".\n\n===''Son of a Preacher Man''===\nIn January 2009, Rich released his third solo single on Warner Bros. Records. The song, \"Another You\", is the lead-off single to Rich's second studio album, ''[[Son of a Preacher Man (John Rich album)|Son of a Preacher Man]]'', which was released on March 24, 2009. He followed this song up with another single, \"[[Shuttin' Detroit Down]]\", recorded only one week before its release in January 2009. Rich promoted the song, which addresses the [[Chrysler]] and [[General Motors]] bailouts, at Michigan radio stations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freep.com/article/20090129/COL27/90129001 |title=John Rich's \"Shuttin' Detroit Down\" sizzling on country radio, Web |last=McGraw |first=Bill |work=Motor City Journal |publisher=[[Detroit Free Press]] |access-date=February 3, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201054932/http://freep.com/article/20090129/COL27/90129001 |archive-date=February 1, 2009 }}</ref> The song debuted at No.&nbsp;34 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart for the chart week of February 14, 2009, becoming his first solo Top 40 hit and peaking at No.&nbsp;10 in April. A third single, \"The Good Lord and the Man\", debuted at No.&nbsp;59 on the country chart and peaked at No.&nbsp;56 in July 2009.\n\n===''Rich Rocks'' and ''For the Kids''===\nBoth ''[[Rich Rocks]]'' and ''[[For the Kids (Extended Play)|For the Kids]]'' have only produced one single between them. ''Country Done Come to Town'' was released as a single from ''Rich Rocks'' in mid-2010 and was a minor chart success.\n\n==Television work==\n[[Image:John Rich McCain Rally.JPG|thumb|Rich performing \"Raisin' McCain\" at a [[John McCain]] campaign rally in O'Fallon, Missouri]]\nIn 2007, Rich hosted the first season of a reality show on [[Country Music Television]] called ''[[Gone Country (television series)|Gone Country]]'', which featured celebrities such as [[Brady Bunch]] actress [[Maureen McCormick]], singers [[Bobby Brown]], [[Sisqo]], [[Julio Iglesias Jr.]], [[Dee Snider]], [[Carnie Wilson]] and [[American Idol]] runner-up [[Diana DeGarmo]] as they try to become songwriters with the help of [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] songwriters as the celebrities are paired together with the songwriters. The show was filmed at the former home of [[Barbara Mandrell]]. He has hosted two more seasons since then.\n\nRich also served as a judge on the 2008 version of ''[[Nashville Star]]'' on NBC along with [[Jewel (singer)|Jewel]], singer-songwriter [[Jeffrey Steele]], and host [[Billy Ray Cyrus]].\n\nRich was a candidate in the 2011 season of ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. season 11)|The Celebrity Apprentice]]'', which premiered on March 6. In episode 5, he lost as Project Manager for the men's team, Backbone. Despite the first loss, he later won 2 more tasks as Project Manager, raising $1,266,908 for [[St. Jude Children's Research Hospital]]. Rich competed with [[Marlee Matlin]] in the live season finale, where he was declared the season winner, and received an additional $250,000 for his charity.\n\nRich served as a mentor in the 2012 reality/competition series ''[[The Next: Fame Is at Your Doorstep]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2012/07/30/the-winner-of-the-cws-the-next-to-earn-recording-contract-with-atlantic-records-683405/20120730cw02/|title=The Winner of The CW's \"The Next\" to Earn Recording Contract With Atlantic Records|website=[[The Futon Critic]]|date=July 3, 2012|access-date=August 13, 2012}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nJohn Rich and his wife, Joan, married on December 6, 2008.<ref>{{cite web |title=Big & Rich's John Rich Marries Longtime Girlfriend |url=https://www.accessonline.com/articles/big-richs-john-rich-marries-longtime-girlfriend-66565 |website=Access |date=December 7, 2008 |access-date=January 28, 2020 |language=en}}</ref> He has two sons, Cash and Colt.\n\n===Political views===\nIn the 2008 U.S. presidential race, Rich originally supported [[Fred Thompson]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newsmeat.com/celebrity_political_donations/John_Rich.php |title=Celebrity Political Donations: John Rich |publisher=Newsmeat.com |access-date=July 21, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716090950/http://newsmeat.com/celebrity_political_donations/John_Rich.php |archive-date=July 16, 2011 |url-status=dead }}</ref> He later released a campaign song on his website in support of presidential candidate [[John McCain]] in August 2008 called \"Raisin' McCain\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.johnrich.com|title=Official site|publisher=Johnrich.com|access-date=July 21, 2011}}</ref> He performed in the closing ceremony of the [[Republican National Convention]] on September 3, 2008. He endorsed the [[Conservative Party (United States)|Conservative Party]] candidate [[Doug Hoffman]] in the [[New York's 23rd congressional district special election, 2009|special congressional election in Northern New York]] in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wwnytv.com/news/local/66913342.html|title=Country Music Star to Stump For Hoffman? Not Likely|website=Wwnytv.com|date=October 2, 2009|access-date=July 21, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120223081436/http://www.wwnytv.com/news/local/66913342.html|archive-date=February 23, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref> In 2010 he endorsed [[Zach Wamp]] for Governor of Tennessee and hosted parties at his Nashville home in support of Wamp's campaign.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://nashvillecitypaper.com/content/city-news/john-rich-endorses-zach-wamp-governor |title=John Rich Endorses Zach Wamp for Governor |access-date=May 16, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120612042101/http://nashvillecitypaper.com/content/city-news/john-rich-endorses-zach-wamp-governor |archive-date=June 12, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nOn April 7, 2015, Rich's song \"Shuttin' Detroit Down\" was featured in Senator [[Rand Paul]]'s [[Rand Paul presidential campaign, 2016|2016 presidential campaign]] announcement.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Larson|first1=Leslie|title=Rand Paul's campaign announcement began with this anti-Wall Street country song|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/rand-pauls-campaign-announcement-began-with-this-anti-wall-street-country-song-2015-4|website=Wall Street Journal|access-date=August 7, 2017}}</ref> He later declared his support for presumptive nominee [[Donald Trump]] following Paul's exit from the race.<ref>{{cite web|title=John Rich: I'm glad Trump is running for president|url=http://video.foxnews.com/v/4316343329001/?#sp=show-clips|website=Fox News| date=June 23, 2015 |access-date=August 7, 2017}}</ref> Big & Rich would later perform at a pre-inaugural ceremony on January 19, 2017, after Trump's victory in the [[2016 United States presidential election|general election]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Betts|first1=Stephen L|title=Big & Rich to Perform at Trump Inauguration Gala|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/big-rich-to-perform-at-trump-inauguration-gala-w459115|access-date=August 7, 2017|publisher=Rolling Stone}}</ref> On May 30, 2019, he released \"Shut Up About Politics\" featuring presenters of the [[Fox News Channel]] programme ''[[The Five (talk show)|The Five]]''.\n\n==Discography==\n{{See also|Big & Rich discography|Big Kenny}}\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n! John Rich)</small>\n| [[Nova Rockafeler]]\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{Commons category-inline|John Rich (musician)|John Rich}}\n*{{allMusic}}\n\n{{Big & Rich}}\n{{Lonestar}}\n{{MuzikMafia}}\n{{The Apprentice (American TV series)}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Rich, John}}\n[[Category:1974 births]]\n[[Category:American country bass guitarists]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Big & Rich members]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Amarillo, Texas]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Texas]]\n[[Category:Warner Records artists]]\n[[Category:Lonestar members]]\n[[Category:BNA Records artists]]\n[[Category:Texas Republicans]]\n[[Category:Reprise Records artists]]\n[[Category:American country record producers]]\n[[Category:Guitarists from Texas]]\n[[Category:American male bass guitarists]]\n[[Category:People from Dickson, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Texas]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Record producers from Texas]]\n[[Category:21st-century American bass guitarists]]\n[[Category:Participants in American reality television series]]\n[[Category:The Apprentice winners]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Judges in American reality television series]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jimmy_Fortune","to":"Jimmy Fortune"}],"pages":{"13396434":{"pageid":13396434,"ns":0,"title":"Jimmy Fortune","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{for|the jockey|Jimmy Fortune (jockey)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Jimmy Fortune\n| image           = Jimmy-fortune-1107.jpg\n| caption         = Fortune (center) with [[Dailey & Vincent]]\n| birth_name      =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1955|03|11}}\n| birth_place     = [[Williamsburg, Virginia]]\n| origin          = [[Nelson County, Virginia]]\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer\n| instruments     = Vocals, guitar\n| years_active    = 1982\u2013present\n| label           = {{Flatlist|\n*[[Audium Entertainment|Audium]]\n*Song Garden\n*Fortune Enterprises}}\n| past_member_of  = [[The Statler Brothers]]\n| website         = [http://www.jimmyfortune.com Official Website]\n}}\n\n'''Jimmy Fortune''' (born March 11, 1955) is an [[Americans|American]] [[country music]] singer from [[Nelson County, Virginia]]. Fortune sang [[tenor]] for [[The Statler Brothers]] for 21 years, and wrote the song \"[[Elizabeth (The Statler Brothers song)|Elizabeth]]\" for the group.<ref name=\"wilson post\">{{cite news |url=http://wilsonpost.com/fortune-smiles-on-jimmy-fortune-cms-87393 |title=Fortune smiles on Jimmy Fortune |first=Ken |last=Beck |date=February 23, 2016 |work=The Wilson Post |access-date=May 29, 2017 |archive-date=August 25, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160825181209/http://wilsonpost.com/fortune-smiles-on-jimmy-fortune-cms-87393 |url-status=live }}</ref> Shortly after the Statler Brothers disbanded, he began to perform as a solo artist. \n\nFortune, commonly referred to as the Amish Elvis, was inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|Country Music Hall of Fame]] in 2008 as a member of The Statler Brothers.\n\n==Biography==\nFortune grew up in [[Nelson County, Virginia]], where he attended Nelson County High School in [[Lovingston, Virginia]].<ref name=\"cleveland\">{{cite news |url=http://www.cleveland.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2015/10/statlers_jimmy_fortune_talks_h.html |title=Statlers' Jimmy Fortune talks 'Hits & Hymns' with PD critic (and former classmate) |first=Chuck |last=Yarborough |work=The Plain Dealer |date=October 16, 2015 |access-date=May 29, 2017 |archive-date=November 18, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151118082241/http://www.cleveland.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2015/10/statlers_jimmy_fortune_talks_h.html |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nThe original tenor of the Statler Brothers, [[Lew DeWitt]], heard Fortune sing at a local ski resort.  When DeWitt was suffering from [[Crohn's disease]] and needed a temporary replacement, he asked Fortune to come to audition for the band in Nashville.  Fortune started performing with the Statler Brothers in 1982, originally as a temporary replacement for DeWitt. He joined the group permanently later in the year when DeWitt decided to quit the group due to his illness.<ref name=\"cleveland\"/>\n\nFortune wrote several number-one songs that were recorded by the [[Statler Brothers]], including \"[[Elizabeth (Statler Brothers song)|Elizabeth]]\", \"[[Too Much on My Heart]]\", and \"[[My Only Love (song)|My Only Love]]\". \"[[More Than a Name on a Wall]]\" was a top ten country hit. \"Elizabeth\" recently was a top bluegrass release for [[Dailey & Vincent]]. He spent 21 years touring, singing, and performing with the Statler Brothers.\n[[File:Jimmy Fortune Statue - 02.jpg|thumb|Statue of Fortune in [[Nelson County, Virginia]]]]\n\nIn 2002, after the Statlers disbanded, Fortune continued his career as a solo artist with an extensive performance schedule in the U.S. and Canada. He has continued as a songwriter and has recorded some projects in Nashville that he mostly produced himself. In 2015 he released ''Hits & Hymns'' produced by Ben Isaacs.<ref name=\"cleveland\"/>  The album reached the Top Ten on ''Billboard'''s [[Top Country Albums]] chart. The DVD release of a TV special, \"Jimmy Fortune: Hits & Hymns,\" hosted by Bill Gaither, debuted at No. 1 on the Billboard Music Video chart.<ref name=\"wilson post\"/>\nIn 2020, Fortune collaborated with [[Bradley Walker (singer)|Bradley Walker]], Ben Isaacs, and Mike Rogers, and formed a group later named Brothers of the Heart.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ccmmagazine.com/ccm-cafe/a-conversation-with-brothers-of-the-heart-fortune-walker-rogers-isaacs/ |title=A Conversation with Brothers of the Heart (Fortune, Walker, Rogers, Isaacs) |first=Brandon |last=Woolum |date=February 10, 2023 |work=CCM Magazine |access-date=April 20, 2023 |archive-date=April 19, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230419183008/https://www.ccmmagazine.com/ccm-cafe/a-conversation-with-brothers-of-the-heart-fortune-walker-rogers-isaacs/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/jimmy-fortune-isaacs-rogers-walker-elizabeth-premiere/ |title=Jimmy Fortune, Ben Isaacs, Mike Rogers and Bradley Walker Deliver New Take on Statlers' Classic 'Elizabeth' |first=Deborah |last=Evans Price |date=September 18, 2020 |work=Sounds Like Nashville |access-date=April 20, 2023 |archive-date=April 20, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230420124458/https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/jimmy-fortune-isaacs-rogers-walker-elizabeth-premiere/ |url-status=live }}</ref> They have released three albums to date: ''Brotherly Love'' (2020),<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thechristianbeat.org/index.php/new-music/8383-jimmy-fortune-bradley-walker-mike-rogers-ben-isaacs-release-gaither-music-group-cd-dvd-tv-special |title=Jimmy Fortune, Bradley Walker, Mike Rogers & Ben Isaacs Release Gaither Music Group CD, DVD & TV Special |date= September 3, 2020 |first= Herb |last=Longs|work=The Christian Beat }}</ref> ''Listen To The Music'' (2023),<ref>{{cite web |url=https://todayschristianent.com/music-news-brothers-of-the-heart-to-perform-on-the-opry-feb-7-listen-to-the-music-hits-1-on-billboard-christian-album-chart/ |title=Music News: Brothers of the Heart to perform on The Opry Feb. 7; 'Listen To The Music' hits #1 on Billboard Christian album chart |work=Today Christian Entertainment |access-date=2023-04-20 |archive-date=2023-04-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230419181504/https://todayschristianent.com/music-news-brothers-of-the-heart-to-perform-on-the-opry-feb-7-listen-to-the-music-hits-1-on-billboard-christian-album-chart/ |url-status=live }}</ref> and ''Will The Circle Be Unbroken'' (2023).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ccmmagazine.com/news/brothers-of-the-heart-to-release-third-album-will-the-circle-be-unbroken-on-nov-3/|title=Brothers of the Heart To Release Third Album 'Will The Circle Be Unbroken' on Nov. 3|date=27 October 2023 }}</ref>\n\nOn July 8, 2023, a bronze statue of Fortune was unveiled in Nelson County, Virginia. Fortune attended the ceremony, where a statue of fellow Nelson County native [[Earl Hamner Jr.]] was also dedicated.<ref>Shipley, Kaylee. [https://wset.com/news/local/nelson-county-virginia-unveils-earl-hamner-jr-and-jimmy-fortune-statues-historical-societys-oakland-museum-july-2023 \"Nelson County unveils Earl Hamner Jr. and Jimmy Fortune statues\"]. ''ABC13 News''. Published July 9, 2023. Accessed January 3, 2024.</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Cory_Marks","to":"Cory Marks"}],"pages":{"64947614":{"pageid":64947614,"ns":0,"title":"Cory Marks","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Canadian country singer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Cory Marks\n| image           = Cory Marks.jpg\n| caption         = Marks performing in 2023\n| image_size      =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1989|10|11}}\n| birth_name      =\n| birth_place     = [[North Bay, Ontario]], Canada\n| alias           = Lion Man, Sunshine\n| origin          =\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar, drums\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[country rock]]|[[outlaw country]]|[[hard rock]]}}\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 2011\u2013present\n| label           = {{hlist|[[Better Noise Music|Better Noise]]|Big Star}}\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{URL|corymarks.com/}}\n}}\n'''Cory Gerald Joseph Marquardt''' (born October 11, 1989<ref name=\"Nugget\">{{cite news|title=Marquardt signs record deal|url=https://www.nugget.ca/entertainment/music/marquardt-signs-record-deal |work=[[North Bay Nugget]]|publisher=[[Postmedia Network]]|date=September 26, 2018}}</ref>) is a Canadian [[country rock]] singer-songwriter better known by his stage name '''Cory Marks'''. He is signed to [[Better Noise Music]].<ref name=\"Invictus\">{{cite news|title=Cory Marks - Biography|url=http://www.iegroup.ca/artists/cory-marks/|work=Invictus Entertainment Group|accessdate=August 14, 2020}}</ref> He has released two albums, ''[[This Man (album)|This Man]]'' in 2015 under Big Star Recordings, and most recently ''[[Who I Am (Cory Marks album)|Who I Am]]'' in 2020 under Better Noise. Since the release, the album has accumulated over 260 million global streams with his debut single \"[[Outlaws & Outsiders]]\" being certified Platinum in Canada, Gold in the US and reaching top 10 at US rock radio and #3 in Germany, making Marks the first to ever do so as a Canadian country act.\n\n==Early life==\nMarks was raised in [[North Bay, Ontario]], the younger brother of professional hockey player [[Matt Marquardt]], and learned how to skate at three years old.<ref>{{cite web|title= Cory Marks rise to stardom|url=https://www.mainstreet-nashville.com/opinion/cory-marks-rise-to-stardom/article_aca7ec08-f430-11ea-a269-d7e44b38b3ff.html|first=Bethany|last=Bowman|date=September 11, 2020}}</ref> He cites [[Merle Haggard]], [[Waylon Jennings]], [[Bryan Adams]], [[Ozzy Osbourne]], and [[Rush (band)|Rush]] as early musical influences.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cory Marks - Bio|url=http://www.corymarks.com/bio|work=CoryMarks.com|accessdate=August 15, 2020}}</ref> Marks played university hockey at the [[Royal Military College of Canada]] where he also pursued dreams of becoming a fighter pilot.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cory Marks hits a live wire with \"Outlaws and Outsiders\"|url= https://www.mynorthbaynow.com/49948/cory-marks-hits-a-live-wire-with-outlaws-and-outsiders/|first=Kortney|last=Kenney|work=My North Bay Now|date=November 20, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=INTERVIEW: CORY MARKS \u2013 Ontario, CA; 2020|url=https://www.musicalypse.net/cory-marks-ontario-ca-2020/|work=Musicalypse|date=March 12, 2020}}</ref> He had never performed music publicly until his friends encouraged him to do so while at a bar in college.<ref>{{cite news|title=Interview~ Mixing country music with the hard-hitting stomp of rock & roll, Cory Marks|url=https://ignitemusicmag.com/2020/03/31/interview-mixing-country-music-with-the-hard-hitting-stomp-of-rock-roll-cory-marks/|first=Bryan Joe|last=Corder|work=Ignite Music Magazine|date=March 31, 2020}}</ref> He has performed using the name \"Cory Marks\" since the release of his debut album.<ref name=\"Nugget\"/> Marks achieved his private pilot license in 2021.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cory Marks' single certified Gold|url=https://www.nugget.ca/news/cory-marks-single-certified-gold |work=[[North Bay Nugget]]|first=Michael|last=Lee|publisher=[[Postmedia Network]]|date=April 29, 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\n===2014\u20132015: ''This Man''===\nIn July 2014, he released his first single to Canadian country radio, \"Smartphone\".<ref name=\"Smartphone\"/> His second single, \"21\", was released in April 2015.<ref name=\"TwentyOne\"/> His first album, ''[[This Man (album)|This Man]]'' was released on May 26, 2015 through Big Star Recordings.<ref name=\"ThisMan\">{{cite web|title=Cory Marquardt releases his first album \"This Man\"|url=https://www.kissnorthbay.com/2015/05/26/cory-marquardts-releases-his-first-album-this-man/|work=Kiss 100.5 North Bay|date=May 26, 2016}}</ref><ref name=\"BayT\">{{cite news|last=Dawson|first=Chris|title=Marquardt releases first album today|url= https://www.baytoday.ca/local-news/marquardt-releases-first-album-today-18775|work=BayToday.ca|date=May 26, 2015}}</ref> The album included his first two singles, as well as two further singles, \"This Man\",<ref name=\"TM\">{{cite web|title= INTRODUCING, THIS MAN, CORY MARQUARDT|url= https://www.soundcheckentertainment.ca/introducing-this-man-cory-marquardt/|work=Sound Check Entertainment|date= July 26, 2015|accessdate=August 14, 2020}}</ref> and \"Nowhere With You\".<ref name=\"NWY\">{{cite web|title=New video released by Cory Marquardt|url= https://canadianbeats.ca/2016/01/06/new-video-released-by-cory-marquardt-3/|work=Canadian Beats Media|first=Jenna|last=Melanson|date=January 6, 2016}}</ref>\n\n=== 2016\u20132020: ''Who I Am'' ===\nIn 2016, Marks signed a deal to work with award-winning producer [[Kevin Churko]], known for work with [[Ozzy Osbourne]], [[Shania Twain]], and [[Five Finger Death Punch]].<ref>{{cite web|title=More good news for local artist Cory Marquardt|url=https://www.baytoday.ca/local-news/more-good-news-for-local-artist-cory-marquardt-305484|work=BayToday.ca|first=Chris|last=Dawson|date=May 27, 2016}}</ref> In 2018, he signed a record deal with [[Eleven Seven Label Group|Eleven Seven Music]] (later rebranded as [[Better Noise Music]]) as their flagship country artist.<ref name=\"Nugget\"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Cory Marks Signs Record Deal with Eleven Seven Music|url=http://www.iegroup.ca/news/cory-marks-signs-record-deal-eleven-seven-music/|work=Invictus Entertainment Group|date=September 26, 2018}}</ref>\n\nIn November 2019, Marks released his first single on Better Noise, \"[[Outlaws & Outsiders]]\", featuring [[Ivan Moody (vocalist)|Ivan Moody]], [[Travis Tritt]], and [[Mick Mars]],<ref>{{cite web|title=North Bay's Cory Marks' new song is number one on iTunes Canada|url= https://northernontario.ctvnews.ca/north-bay-s-cory-marks-new-song-is-number-one-on-itunes-canada-1.4703034|first=Jessica|last=Gosselin|work=[[CTV News]] Northern Ontario|date=November 26, 2019}}</ref> which debuted at #1 on [[iTunes]] in Canada as well as #1 on the [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] [[Rock Digital Songs]] and [[Rock Digital Songs|Hard Rock Digital Songs]] charts and #7 on the [[Country Digital Song Sales|Country Digital Songs]] charts.<ref>{{cite web|title= Cory Marks Throws Down in Single \"Outlaws & Outsiders\" ft. Travis Tritt, Ivan Moody & Mick Mars|url= http://frontporchmusic.ca/music/cory-marks-outlaws-outsiders/|work=Front Porch Music|date=January 26, 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"Billboard\"/> The song would later peak inside the top 10 on US [[Mainstream Rock (chart)|Mainstream Rock]] radio, top 5 on German rock radio, and peaked at #12 on [[Canada Rock]] radio.<ref>{{cite web|title=Big day for North Bay's Cory Marks|url=https://www.baytoday.ca/local-news/big-day-for-north-bays-cory-marks-2617951|work=BayToday.ca|date=August 7, 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"CanRock\"/> It was also certified Gold by [[Music Canada]].<ref>{{cite web|first=Chris|last=Dawson|title=Cory Marks is golden|url=https://www.timminstoday.com/local-news/cory-marks-is-golden-3681473|work=Timmins Today|date=May 1, 2021}}</ref>\n\nIn June 2020, Marks released \"[[Drive (Cory Marks song)|Drive]]\",<ref name=\"Drive\"/><ref name=\"Drive2\"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://themusicuniverse.com/cory-marks-announces-who-i-am/|title= CORY MARKS ANNOUNCES 'WHO I AM'|work=The Music Universe|first=Buddy|last=Iahn|date=June 5, 2020}}</ref> and announced it as the second single to country radio off his second album, ''[[Who I Am (Cory Marks album)|Who I Am]]'', which was released on August 7, 2020 through Better Noise.<ref name=\"WhoIAm\"/><ref name=\"CountryNote\">{{cite news|title=Cory Marks, The Critically Acclaimed Next Generation of Country Rock, Releases Debut Album, WHO I AM|url=https://www.thecountrynote.com/in-the-news/cory-marks-the-critically-acclaimed-next-generation-of-country-rock-releases-debut-album-who-i-am/|date=August 7, 2020|work=The Country Note}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://themusicuniverse.com/cory-marks-who-i-am-debuts-worldwide/|title= CORY MARKS 'WHO I AM' DEBUTS WORLDWIDE|work=The Music Universe|first=Buddy|last=Iahn|date=August 11, 2020}}</ref> In October 2020, \"[[Blame It on the Double]]\" was released as the second single to rock radio in Germany and the United Kingdom.<ref name=\"BOD\">{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/corymarksmusic/status/1313249605916733440|title=Cory Marks on Twitter: \"Very excited to announce that my single #BlameItOnTheDouble is now at UK & [German] rock radio!! \ud83e\udd43\ud83e\udd43 @BetterNoise \ud83c\uddec\ud83c\udde7\ud83c\udde8\ud83c\udde6\"|via=Twitter|accessdate=October 5, 2020}}</ref> Marks also released his first Christmas single \"Jingle My Bells\", a cover of a song by [[The Tractors]], that month.<ref name=\"JMB\"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://themusicuniverse.com/cory-marks-releasing-jingle-my-bells/|title=CORY MARKS RELEASING 'JINGLE MY BELLS'|work=The Music Universe|first=Buddy|last=Iahn|date=October 8, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Cory Marks has a new Christmas tune and it's catchy!|url=https://www.baytoday.ca/local-news/cory-marks-has-a-new-christmas-tune-and-its-catchy-3142123|work=BayToday.ca|first=Chris|last=Dawson|date=December 1, 2020}}</ref> In April 2021, Marks released a new version of \"Blame It on the Double\" featuring Tyler Connolly of [[Theory of a Deadman]] and [[Jason Hook]].<ref>{{cite news|title=CORY MARKS PUTS THE HAMMER DOWN FOR 'BLAME IT ON THE DOUBLE' COLLAB|first=Chris|last=Parton|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/music/cory-marks-blame-it-on-the-double-collab/|work=Sounds Like Nashville|date=April 30, 2021|accessdate=May 4, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|title=Cory Marks Drops Single With Jason Hook & Theory of a Deadman's Tyler Connolly|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/rock/cory-marks-blame-it-double-single-video-9565706/|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|first=Dave|last=Brooks|date=April 30, 2021}}</ref>\n\n=== 2021\u2013present: ''Sorry for Nothing'' and extended plays ===\nOn June 18, 2021, Marks released the extended play ''Nashville Mornings''. It included a cover of [[Blaze Foley]]'s \"If I Could Only Fly\", as well as a \"Country Mix\" of \"[[Blame It on the Double]]\" featuring Tyler Connolly, which was sent to Canadian country radio.<ref name=\"NM\">{{cite web|title=CORY MARKS' NEW 'NASHVILLE MORNINGS' EP OFFERS REFRESHED APPROACH TO THE COUNTRY-ROCKER'S CATALOGUE|url=https://rocknloadmag.com/news/cory-marks-new-nashville-mornings-ep-offers-refreshed-approach-to-the-country-rockers-catalogue/|website=Rock N' Load Magazine|date=June 17, 2021|access-date=June 18, 2021|archive-date=June 18, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210618113122/https://rocknloadmag.com/news/cory-marks-new-nashville-mornings-ep-offers-refreshed-approach-to-the-country-rockers-catalogue/|url-status=dead}}</ref> He followed that up with the extended play ''Nashville Nights'' on August 20, 2021, which included a new track \"In Me I Trust\",<ref>{{cite web|title=Cory Marks - In Me I Trust \n|url=https://newcountrysongs.com/cory-marks/in-me-i-trust/|work=New Country Songs|accessdate=August 31, 2021}}</ref> the solo version of \"[[Outlaws & Outsiders]]\", and live versions of \"[[Drive (Cory Marks song)|Drive]]\" and \"Blame It on the Double\".<ref name=\"Nights\">{{cite web|url=https://tuonelamagazine.com/review-cory-marks-ep-nashville-nights/|title=REVIEW: Cory Marks \u2013 EP: Nashville Nights|work=Tuonela Magazine|date=August 13, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://canadianbeats.ca/2021/08/31/cory-marks-leaps-into-the-world-of-rock-heavy-with-the-release-of-his-latest-ep-nashville-nights-and-announces-his-fall-tour-dates/|title=Cory Marks leaps into the world of rock-heavy with the release of his latest EP, Nashville Nights and announces his fall tour dates|first=Nanci|last=Dagg|date=August 31, 2021|work=Canadian Beats Media}}</ref>\n\nIn November 2022, Marks released the extended play ''I Rise'', which included the singles \"Burn It Up\" and \"Flying\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.music-news.com/news/Underground/153522/Cory-Marks-releases-new-EP-I-Rise|title=Cory Marks releases new EP 'I Rise'|date=November 11, 2022|access-date=November 18, 2022|work=Music-News.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Jenna|last=Melanson|title=Cory Marks unveils new EP, I Rise (Interview)|url=https://canadianbeats.ca/2022/11/16/cory-marks-unveils-new-ep-i-rise-interview|work=Canadian Beats Media|date=November 16, 2022|access-date=November 22, 2022}}</ref> He supported [[Five Finger Death Punch]] on their headlining tour in the United States in the fall and winter of 2022 alongside [[Brantley Gilbert]].<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/pro/cory-marks-major-tour-pandemic-delayed-live-music/|title=Cory Marks Ready to Support a Major Tour, After 3-Year Pandemic Delay|date=November 4, 2022|access-date=November 18, 2022|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|first=Dave|last=Brooks|url-access=subscription}}</ref> \n\nIn June 2024, Marks released two songs, \"Guilty\u201d, which featured [[Bad Wolves]]'s lead singer DL, and \"Drunk When I'm High\", which was serviced to Australian country radio.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.rock101.net/2024/06/28/cory-marks-premieres-new-song-guilty-featuring-bad-wolves-dl/|title=Cory Marks premieres new song, \"Guilty,\" featuring Bad Wolves' DL|work=Rock 101.1|date=June 28, 2024|first=Josh|last=Johnson|location=[[Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan]]|access-date=July 29, 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mnprmagazine.com/news/cory-marks-guilty-drunk-when-im-high/|title= \nCory Marks Releases Two Tracks \u2013 'Guilty' feat. DL of Bad Wolves and 'Drunk When I'm High'|date=June 28, 2024|work=MNPR Magazine|first=Richard|last=Bolwell|access-date=July 29, 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baytoday.ca/local-news/marks-enjoys-homecoming-while-releasing-new-tunes-9152530|title=Marks enjoys homecoming while releasing new tunes|first=Chris|last=Dawson|work=BayToday|date=June 30, 2024|access-date=July 29, 2024}}</ref> On October 11, 2024, Marks will release his third studio album ''Sorry for Nothing''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nugget.ca/entertainment/cory-marks-getting-some-big-name-salutes-for-one-of-his-singles|title=Cory Marks getting some big name salutes for one of his singles|work=[[North Bay Nugget]]|first=Greg|last=Estabrook|date=December 6, 2023|access-date=December 10, 2023}}</ref><ref name=\"SFN\"/> He released the song \"(Make My) Country Rock\" featuring [[Sully Erna]], [[Travis Tritt]], and [[Mick Mars]], concurrently with the announcement of the forthcoming album.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.1057thepoint.com/music-news/sully-erna-mick-mars-guest-on-new-cory-marks-song-make-my-country-rock/|title=Sully Erna, Mick Mars guest on new Cory Marks song, \"(Make My) Country Rock\"|work=105.7 The Point|date=July 26, 2024|access-date=August 22, 2024}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Drive (Cory Marks song)|Drive]]\"<ref name=\"Drive\">{{cite magazine|title=Cory Marks New Track 'Drive' Is The Feel Good Country Hit of the Summer|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/cory-marks-song-drive-9405832/|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|first=Dave|last=Brooks|date=June 19, 2020}}</ref>\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|\n|-\n!
