singer-songwriters]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Blaine_Larsen","to":"Blaine Larsen"}],"pages":{"1959958":{"pageid":1959958,"ns":0,"title":"Blaine Larsen","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Blaine Larsen\n| image_size      =\n| birth_name      =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1986|2|2}}<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p660581/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Blaine Larsen biography |accessdate=June 3, 2008 |last=Leggett |first=Steve |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>\n| birth_place     = [[Tacoma, Washington]], U.S.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar\n| genre           = [[country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 2004\u2013present\n| label           = Giantslayer<br>[[BNA Records|BNA]]<br> Treehouse/Stroudavarious\n}}\n\n'''Blaine Larsen''' (born February 2, 1986) is an American [[country music]] artist. He was raised in [[Buckley, Washington]]. At age fifteen, he recorded his debut album ''In My High School'' on Giantslayer Records, an independent record label. The album was re-issued in 2005 as ''[[Off to Join the World]]'' by [[BNA Records]]. Blaine's second album, ''[[Rockin' You Tonight]]'', was issued in June 2006, also on BNA. Larsen's two albums for that label have produced five chart singles on the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, of which the highest-peaking was \"How Do You Get That Lonely\" at number 18. Larsen left BNA in 2009, in favor of Treehouse Records and consequently with [[Stroudavarious Records]], but is now unsigned.\n\n==Career==\nLarsen was introduced to music very early. By age 10, Larsen had begun singing along to country karaoke tapes, and by age 13 he learned to play guitar as well.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> When Larsen was a junior in high school, he and his family made a trip to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], where Larsen recorded a demo CD composed mainly of cover songs. This CD also included a song that he had co-written with his school teacher.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Nashville songwriters [[Rory Lee Feek]] and [[Tim Johnson (songwriter)|Tim Johnson]] discovered Larsen's demo CD. They then flew him back Nashville again to hold a recording session with him, and by 2004, his debut album ''In My High School'' was released on Feek and Johnson's label, Giantslayer Records.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> The album's lead-off single, which was the title track, received some airplay particularly in [[Seattle]] also reaching 60 on the country charts that year.\n\nAfter \"In My High School\" began receiving airplay, Sandy Conklin, an employee at BMG in Seattle sent a note to Joe Galante, head of the BMG labels in Nashville, recommending Larsen. Galante auditioned him and agreed to sign him at the end of 2004. Larsen was signed to BMG-affiliated [[BNA Records]] label.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20050104014849/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/larsen_blaine/bio.jhtml CMT: Blaine Larsen biography]</ref> BNA then added a bonus track to ''In My High School'', re-releasing the album in early 2005 under the title ''[[Off to Join the World]]''.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Larsen had co-written six of the ten songs on the album. BNA also released two more singles from the album: \"[[How Do You Get That Lonely]]\", which peaked at number 18. It was followed by \"The Best Man\" at number 36.\n\nIn 2006, Larsen released his second studio album, also a joint effort between BNA and Giantslayer. Entitled ''[[Rockin' You Tonight]]'', this album produced two more chart singles for Larsen: the 24 \"I Don't Know What She Said\" and the 42 \"Spoken Like a Man\". The former was co-written by [[Warner Bros. Records]] artist [[Lane Turner]]. ''Rockin' You Tonight'' also included [[cover version|cover]]s of [[Mac Davis]] \"[[Baby, Don't Get Hooked on Me]]\" and [[Mark Chesnutt]]'s \"I'm in Love with a Married Woman\", as well as a duet with [[Gretchen Wilson]] entitled \"Lips of a Bottle\". He also recorded separately a cover of \"I Wish That I Could Fall in Love Today\" on a tribute album to [[Barbara Mandrell]]. He also toured with renowned artists opening for their shows, including [[Brad Paisley]], [[Rascal Flatts]] and [[Kenny Chesney]]. He charted with a cover of \"[[Away in a Manger]]\", and also co-wrote the track \"[[I Gotta Get to You]]\" on [[George Strait]]'s album ''[[Twang (album)|Twang]]''.\n\nLarsen exited BNA in 2008, and signed to Treehouse Records, a label founded by his management company, in June 2009.<ref name=\"musicrow\">{{cite web|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2009/06/treehouse-records-launches-blaine-larsen/|title=Treehouse Records Launches Blaine Larsen|last=Skates|first=Sarah|work=Music Row|date=June 15, 2009 |accessdate=June 18, 2009}}</ref> He was the first artist to sign for the label. After one year of operations, Treehouse Records merged in [[Stroudavarious Records]]. Larsen's next album ''Not Too Bad'' was tipped to be under the new label. A lead-off single from the prospective album, entitled \"It Did,\" made its chart debut in August 2009. It was followed by \"Chillin'\" (a minor Top 40 hit) and \"Leavin',\" but the album was eventually shelved after Stroudavarious folded into J&R Records without signing Larsen.\n\n==Personal life==\nLarsen was born in [[Tacoma, Washington]]. When he was five years old, his parents divorced; he, his mother Jenny, and his sister Lindsey then moved to [[Buckley, Washington]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> His father often promised to visit or call, but he never did. A family friend named Woody who worked side jobs as a contractor took Blaine Larsen with him on weekend jobs. One of those jobs, converting Larsen's grandmother's garage into a living space, led to romance between Woody and Blaine's mother Jenny. They later married, and Woody legally adopted Larsen just before he turned 18. Larsen wrote the autobiographical song \"The Best Man\" about his own family.<ref>[http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/65814/be-pink-martini-blaine-larsen ''Billboard'': A different sort of young country]</ref>\n\nFlying has been one of Larsen's biggest passions and he is a pilot. He never took any singing lessons, but his step father encouraged him to sing and learn to play the guitar.\n\nLarsen married Sammie in December 2005. They had their first daughter Zoe in April 2008. They had their second child, a son they named Noble in April 2011.<ref>[http://tasteofcountry.com/blaine-larsen-wife-sammi-baby-noble/ Taste of Country site: Blaine Larsen and Wife Sammi Welcome Baby Boy]</ref>\n\nLarsen became an ambassador for [[Compassion International]] and in 2010 went to a one-week trip with the organization to [[Colombia]], also sponsoring one of the Colombian kids he met during his mission.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Sean_Patrick_McGraw","to":"Sean Patrick McGraw"}],"pages":{"23174495":{"pageid":23174495,"ns":0,"title":"Sean Patrick McGraw","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2024}}\n\n{{BLP sources|date=December 2013}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name                = Sean Patrick McGraw\n| image               = SeanPatrickMcgraw1(by Scott Dudelson).jpg\n| caption             = in concert\n| background          = solo_singer\n| origin              = \n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = 2005\u2014present\n| label               = Little Engine Records\n| associated_acts     = \n| website             = \n}}\n'''Sean Patrick McGraw''', an American [[country music]] singer, is a former ''[[Nashville Star]]'' semi-finalist who leads a prominent unsigned touring act. Following the 2005 release of his CD ''Songs for Saturday Night'', McGraw and his band went on tour and continue to be on the road.  In 2007, McGraw played over 140 dates, from [[Toronto]] to [[Mobile, Alabama|Mobile]] to [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], garnering good reviews from critics and concert-goers alike.\n\nDescribing his music as \"something like [[Lyle Lovett]] singing [[Bruce Springsteen|Springsteen]] songs while wearing [[Dwight Yoakam]]'s hat\", McGraw has earned respect among songwriters as well. His song \"Fiona\" won top honors at the 2007 Independent Music Awards, first place at the American Songwriting Competition and at the Mountain Stages New Song Festival,<ref>(August 31, 2006). \"Area man among NewSong winners\", ''[[The Charleston Gazette]]'', p. D13.</ref> as well as being named finalist in the [[International Songwriting Competition]] and the Mid-Atlantic Song Competition. An esteemed Music Row critic/columnist hailed \"Fiona\" as \"The classiest country rocker I've heard all year.\" This cut and others from ''Songs For Saturday Night'' are featured in the short-length documentary''Ten Days on Tour'' which aired on [[Country Music Television|CMT]] in 2006.<ref>[http://www.seanpatrickmcgraw.com/blogs/] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090615182010/http://www.seanpatrickmcgraw.com/blogs/ |date=June 15, 2009 }}</ref>\n\nMcGraw is also sponsored by [[Fender Musical Instruments Corporation|Fender]] Guitars, [[Jagermiester]], [[Budweiser (Anheuser-Busch)|Budweiser]], The Summit Group, Harley Davidson Footwear and [[Gowanda]].<ref>[http://www.seanpatrickmcgraw.com]   {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509191750/http://www.seanpatrickmcgraw.com/ |date=May 9, 2008 }}</ref>\n\nA song he co-wrote, \"Dollar Ain't Worth a Dime\", with David Kroll, appeared in regular rotation on [[Country Music Television|CMT]] in 2009.<ref>Smith, William (May 25, 2009). \"Former resident's song lands on CMT\", [[McClatchy News|McClatchy-Tribune Business News]]. Originally printed in ''[[The Hawk Eye]]''.</ref>\n\nDuring the summer of 2009, he made his national television debut on \"Jimmy Kimmel Live!\" and opened several dates for Toby Keith and Trace Adkins on America's Toughest Tour, garnering great reviews as well as expanding his dedicated fan base.\n\nFollowing the tour with [[Toby Keith]] and [[Trace Adkins]], Sean Patrick McGraw headlined his own show at the [[Hard Rock Cafe]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] on January 27, 2010. Critics claimed that the show \"Bubbled over with the Zietgeisty brand of country-rock that Sean Patrick McGraw has become known for.\"\n\nFebruary 2010 brought many new accomplishments for McGraw. He was published in ''[[Country Weekly]]'', a prominent country music magazine, as a selection for their \"Who to Watch in 2010\" feature.<ref name=COUNTRY_WEEKLY_-_WHO_TO_WATCH_IN_2010>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.seanpatrickmcgraw.com/news#country-weekly-who-to-watch-in-2010 |title=News |publisher=Sean Patrick Mcgraw |date=June 11, 2013 |accessdate=December 5, 2013}}</ref> Later that month, Sean joined [[Eric Church]] and [[Josh Thompson (singer)|Josh Thompson]] for the 2010 [[J\u00e4germeister]] Tour. He opened six dates in cities such as [[Clifton Park, New York]], [[Boston, Massachusetts]] and [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. His stay on the tour spanned from February 12 to the 25th.<ref name=Sean_Patrick_McGraw_Joins_Jagermeister_Tour_for_Select_Dates>[http://www.urbancountryblog.com/2010/02/sean-patrick-mcgraw-joins-jagermeister.html]  {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100218101834/http://www.urbancountryblog.com/2010/02/sean-patrick-mcgraw-joins-jagermeister.html |date=February 18, 2010 }}</ref>\n\nOn April 18, 2010, McGraw sang the [[national anthem]] at the [[NHRA]] (National Hot Rod Association) Summit Finals race in Las Vegas.<ref name=Sean_Patrick_McGraw_Sings_the_National_Anthem_at_NHRA_Finals>[http://www.urbancountryblog.com/2010/04/sean-patrick-mcgraw-sings-national.html]  {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717173232/http://www.urbancountryblog.com/2010/04/sean-patrick-mcgraw-sings-national.html |date=July 17, 2011 }}</ref>\n\nIn June 2010, McGraw took part in Nashville's annual [[CMA Music Festival]] and joined several popular country acts like [[Cowboy Troy]], [[The McClymonts]], and [[Sarah Buxton]] among others to perform on the [[Hard Rock Cafe]] stage.<ref name=Hard_Rock_Cafe_Stage_Line-Up_for_CMA_Fest>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrymusictattletale.com/2010/06/05/hard-rock-cafe-stage-line-up-for-cma-fest |title=Hard Rock Cafe Stage Line-Up for CMA Fest |publisher=Country Music Tattle Tale |date=June 5, 2010 |accessdate=December 5, 2013}}</ref> [[CMA Music Festival]] is a yearly concert series that features performances and autograph events from both up-and-coming acts and veteran, established country artists. Also in June 2010, two of Sean Patrick McGraw's singles were featured in episodes of the [[HBO]] vampire series \"[[True Blood]]\" \u2013 \"Drink with Hank\" on June 13 and \"Anyone but Me\" on June 20.<ref name=Sean_Patrick_McGraw_Makes_True_Blood_Debut>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrymusictattletale.com/2010/06/17/sean-patrick-mcgraw-makes-true-blood-debut |title=Sean Patrick McGraw Makes True Blood Debut |publisher=Country Music Tattle Tale |date=June 17, 2010 |accessdate=December 5, 2013}}</ref>\n\nOn July 26, McGraw delivered another national anthem performance as well as acoustic set on the home plate of [[US Cellular Field]], home of the Chicago [[White Sox]]. The crowd numbered around 30,000 for the event, with Sean singing prior to the first pitch of the game, in which the [[White Sox]] played the [[Seattle Mariners]].<ref name=Dunkirk_Native_McGraw_Sings_Anthem_At_White_Sox_Game>{{cite web|last=Emke |first=Dave |url=http://post-journal.com/page/content.detail/id/564022.html?nav=5018 |title=Dunkirk Native McGraw Sings Anthem At White Sox Game|publisher=[[The Post-Journal]] |date=August 7, 2010 |accessdate=December 5, 2013}}</ref>\n\nMcGraw, a native of [[Dunkirk, New York]], often appears at events in [[Western New York]].\n\n== Discography ==\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Songs for Saturday Night''\n|\n* Release date: August 19, 2005\n* Label: [[self-released]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Long Way from Slowin' Down''\n|\n* Release date: November 7, 2008\n* Label: Little Engine Records\n|}\n\n=== Singles ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Album\n|-\n| 2008\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Fiona\"\n| ''Songs from Saturday Night''\n|-\n| 2009\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Dollar Ain't Worth a Dime\"\n| ''Long Way from Slowin' Down''\n|-\n| 2010\n! scope=\"row\"| \"My So Called Life\"\n| ''Must Be Living Tonight''\n|-\n| 2012\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Git Yer Cowboy On\"\n| ''Long Way from Slowin' Down''\n|-\n| 2013\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I'm That Guy\"\n| ''Hard Way to Make an Easy Living''\n|}\n\n=== Music videos ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 2009\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Dollar Ain't Worth a Dime\"\n| rowspan=\"3\"| Michael Estrella\n|-\n| 2010\n! scope=\"row\"| \"My So Called Life\"\n|-\n| 2011\n! scope=\"row\"| \"What I'd Do\"\n|-\n| 2014\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I'm That Guy\"\n|\n|}\n\n== References ==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n*{{official website|http://www.seanpatrickmcgraw.com/}}\n*[http://post-journal.com/page/content.detail/id/564022.html?nav=5018 Post-journal.com]\n*[https://web.archive.org/web/20110717173232/http://www.urbancountryblog.com/2010/04/sean-patrick-mcgraw-sings-national.html Urbancountryblog.com]\n*[https://web.archive.org/web/20100218101834/http://www.urbancountryblog.com/2010/02/sean-patrick-mcgraw-joins-jagermeister.html Urbancountryblog.com]\n*[http://www.countrymusictattletale.com/2010/06/17/sean-patrick-mcgraw-makes-true-blood-debut Countrymusictattletale.com]\n*[http://www.countrymusictattletale.com/2010/06/05/hard-rock-cafe-stage-line-up-for-cma-fest Countrymusictattletale.com]\n\n{{Nashville Star}}\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:McGraw, Sean Patrick}}\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Nashville Star contestants]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]\n[[Category:Independent Music Awards winners]]\n[[Category:People from Dunkirk, New York]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from New York (state)]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Joanna_Smith","to":"Joanna Smith"}],"pages":{"55667507":{"pageid":55667507,"ns":0,"title":"Joanna Smith","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"#REDIRECT [[Jo Smith]]\n\n{{R from move}}"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Joey_+_Rory","to":"Joey + Rory"}],"pages":{"18990932":{"pageid":18990932,"ns":0,"title":"Joey + Rory","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country and bluegrass duo}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Joey + Rory\n| image           = Joeyandrory (cropped).jpg\n| caption         = Joey (left) and Rory Lee Feek (right) in 2010.\n| landscape       = yes\n| origin          = [[Columbia, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[Christian country music|Christian country]]\n| label           = {{hlist|[[Vanguard Records|Vanguard]]/[[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass)|Sugar Hill]]|Farmhouse|[[Gaither Music Group]]}}\n| years_active    = 2008\u20132016\n| website         = {{URL|http://www.joeyandrory.com}}\n| past_members    = {{hlist|[[Joey Feek]]|[[Rory Feek]]}}\n}}\n''' Joey + Rory ''' was an American [[country music|country]] and [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] duo composed of singer-songwriters [[Rory Feek]] (born April 25, 1965) and [[Joey Feek]] (September 9, 1975 \u2013 March 4, 2016), who were husband and wife. Both members of the duo were vocalists and songwriters, with Rory also playing [[acoustic guitar]]. Rory Lee Feek had written singles for other artists prior to the duo's foundation. The duo was the third-place finalist on [[Country Music Television|CMT]]'s competition ''[[Can You Duet]]'' in 2008. The duo recorded eight studio albums for [[Vanguard Records]] and [[Gaither Music Group]] and charted three singles on [[Hot Country Songs]].\n\n==History==\nBefore the duo's foundation, Rory Lee Feek worked as a songwriter in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], and continued to work as a songwriter as a member of Joey + Rory. Songs he wrote for other artists include [[Clay Walker]]'s Top Five hit \"[[The Chain of Love]]\", [[Blake Shelton]]'s Number One hit \"[[Some Beach]]\", [[Easton Corbin]]'s \"A Little More Country Than That\", [[Blaine Larsen]]'s 2005 hit, \"[[How Do You Get That Lonely]]\", and [[Jimmy Wayne]]'s 2008 single \"[[I Will (Jimmy Wayne song)|I Will]]\". Rory also founded the independent label Giantslayer Records in 2004, on which Joey recorded a solo album entitled ''Strong Enough to Cry'' in 2005. This album was released in CD format and digital download in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.mac.com/rlfeek/Joey+Rory_site/Download.html |access-date=August 23, 2008 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080421033956/http://web.mac.com/rlfeek/Joey%2BRory_site/Download.html |archive-date=April 21, 2008 |title=Strong Enough To Cry }}</ref> Rory also recorded a solo album on Giantslayer Records, titled ''My Ol' Man'', which he made available only as a download.\n\nJoey + Rory performed on the [[Country Music Television|CMT]] competition ''[[Can You Duet]]'' in 2008, in which they were third-place finalists. Shortly after the competition, they were signed to the independent label [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass)|Sugar Hill Records]]. They returned to the ''Can You Duet'' stage to perform \"Cheater, Cheater\" on \"Original Song Night\" for the series' second season, which aired on July 25, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/misc/410600/can-you-duet-206-original-song-night-3.jhtml?id=1616432|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090807081624/http://www.cmt.com/videos/misc/410600/can-you-duet-206-original-song-night-3.jhtml?id=1616432|url-status=dead|archive-date=August 7, 2009|title=Can You Duet 206 \"Original Song Night\" \u2013 3|work=CMT|access-date=16 November 2015}}</ref>\n\n===2008\u20132009: ''The Life of a Song''===\nThe duo's debut album, ''[[The Life of a Song (Joey + Rory album)|The Life of a Song]]'', was released on October 28, 2008, on Sugar Hill Records.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/joeyandrory/bio.jhtml |access-date=August 23, 2008 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080915135409/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/joeyandrory/bio.jhtml | title =Artists: Biography - Joey & Rory |archive-date=September 15, 2008 }}</ref> The album debuted at No.&nbsp;10 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart, and No.&nbsp;61 on the all-genre [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. Its lead-off single, \"[[Cheater, Cheater]]\", was originally recorded by the duo [[Bomshel]]. Kristy Osmonson, one-half of that duo, co-wrote the song with the Feeks and Wynn Varble. Bomshel's version was released as a single in early 2008, although it did not chart. Joey + Rory's version was released in September 2008, featuring a music video that included a cameo from [[Naomi Judd]], who had been a judge on ''Can You Duet''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/joey/266100/cheater-cheater.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080831121944/http://www.cmt.com/videos/joey/266100/cheater-cheater.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=August 31, 2008|title=Joey + Rory \u2013 Cheater Cheater \u2013 Music Video \u2013 CMT|work=CMT|access-date=16 November 2015}}</ref> Joey + Rory's version peaked at No.&nbsp;30 on the country music charts in early 2009. The duo has also appeared in television commercials for the online retailer [[Overstock.com]] in late 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.cmt.com/2008-09-15/joey-rory-will-be-back-on-tv/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080919004816/http://blog.cmt.com/2008-09-15/joey-rory-will-be-back-on-tv/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 19, 2008 |title=Joey & Rory Will Be Back on TV |access-date=2008-10-22 |last=Parton |first=Chris |date=2008-09-15 |work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]}}</ref> In February 2009, the duo was nominated for the [[Academy of Country Music Awards]] Top Vocal Duo.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1604784/brad-paisley-heidi-newfield-top-list-of-acm-nominees.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090213130258/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1604784/brad-paisley-heidi-newfield-top-list-of-acm-nominees.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 13, 2009 |title=Brad Paisley, Heidi Newfield Top List of ACM Nominees |access-date=2009-02-11 |last=Gilbert |first=Calvin |date=2009-02-11 |work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]}}</ref> Although a cover of [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]]'s \"[[Free Bird]]\" was originally to have been released as the second single, it was withdrawn after two weeks, and replaced in March 2009 with \"Play the Song\", which failed to chart. The album's third single, \"[[To Say Goodbye]]\", was released to radio on July 27, 2009, debuting at number 54 as Billboard Magazine's \"Hot Shot Debut\" on the \"Hot Country Songs\" chart.<ref>Billboard Magazine, July 27, 2009</ref>\n\nJoey + Rory released their first holiday single, the [[Carl Jackson]]-produced \"It's Christmas Time,\" on November 16, 2009, to country radio and November 24, 2009, to digital retailers.<ref name=\"rodeo\">{{cite web|url=http://www.rodeoattitude.com/spur/countrymusic/headlines/its-christmas-time-for-cm-3637.shtml|title=rodeoattitude.com redirect|work=rodeoattitude.com|access-date=16 November 2015}}</ref> The single was released in partnership with ''CMT One Country'', which donated a portion of proceeds from the single to various charities (including The Second Harvest Food Bank of Middle Tennessee).<ref name=\"rodeo\"/> Additionally, Rory Feek, along with Tim Johnson, created the Song Trust, under which an album of Christmas songs performed by children, titled ''Merry Kidsmas'', was released.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2009/12/18/joey-rory-put-focus-on-the-song-with-the-song-trust/ |access-date=December 18, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://archive.today/20120707014539/http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2009/12/18/joey-rory-put-focus-on-the-song-with-the-song-trust/ |title = Joey + Rory put focus on the song with the Song Trust |archive-date=July 7, 2012 }}</ref>\n\n===2010\u20132011: ''Album Number Two''===\n[[File:Fourth of July in Guantanamo DVIDS297046.jpg|thumb|Joey + Rory (2010)]]\nJoey + Rory announced on October 15, 2009, that they were in the studio working on the follow-up album to ''The Life of a Song''. The album, titled ''[[Album Number Two]]'', was announced in January 2010 and released on September 14, 2010. The lead-off single, \"[[This Song's for You]]\", was released to radio in July 2010; originally \"That's Important to Me\" had been chosen, but the single choice was changed. The music video for \"This Song's for You\" was directed by [[Darren Doane]] and was released in August 2010. \"That's Important to Me\" was released as the album's second single in October 2010. It debuted at number 58 on the Hot Country Songs chart for the week ending February 12, 2011.\n\nOn March 16, 2010, it was announced that the duo were the winners of the 2010 [[Academy of Country Music Award]] for Top New Vocal Duo, and would compete alongside [[Luke Bryan]] and [[Gloriana (band)|Gloriana]] for the Top New Artist award.<ref name=\"ACM award\">{{cite web|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2010/03/luke-bryan-gloriana-joey-rory-win-acm-awards-move-to-next-round/|title=Luke Bryan, Gloriana, Joey + Rory Win ACM Awards, Move To Next Round|work=MusicRow \u2013 Nashville's Music Industry Publication \u2013 News, Songs From Music City|date=16 March 2010|access-date=16 November 2015}}</ref> Joey + Rory performed new songs from their upcoming album, were interviewed, and received their award on the [[Great American Country|GAC]] special \"ACM Top New Artists\" on April 1, 2010.<ref name=\"ACM award\"/>\n\n===2011\u20132012: ''A Farmhouse Christmas'' and ''His and Hers''===\nOn August 29, 2011, Joey + Rory released a new single, titled \"Headache,\" to country radio, though it failed to chart and was not included on an album. Joey + Rory released their first Christmas album, ''[[A Farmhouse Christmas]]'', on October 11, 2011.<ref name=\"farmhouse christmas\">{{cite web|url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/joey-rory-to-release-christmas-album-in-2011 |title=Joey + Rory To Release Christmas Album in 2011 |publisher=Roughstock |access-date=July 26, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111202214126/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/joey-rory-to-release-christmas-album-in-2011 |archive-date=December 2, 2011 }}</ref>\n\nJoey + Rory's third studio album, ''[[His and Hers (album)|His and Hers]]'', was released on July 31, 2012. \"When I'm Gone\" and \"Josephine\" served as the album's first two singles and were simultaneously released to radio before the album,<ref>{{cite news|last=Wyland|first=Sarah|title=Joey + Rory to Release His and Hers July 31|url=http://blog.gactv.com/blog/2012/05/31/joey-rory-to-release-his-and-hers-july-31/|access-date=June 1, 2012|newspaper=[[Great American Country]]|date=May 31, 2012|archive-date=June 7, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120607012851/http://blog.gactv.com/blog/2012/05/31/joey-rory-to-release-his-and-hers-july-31/|url-status=dead}}</ref> though neither charted. In late 2015, due to a spike in sales for \"When I'm Gone\" after the video was featured in some press about Joey + Rory, it managed to enter the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart at number 21.\n\n===2013\u20132016: Final recordings ===\nJoey + Rory announced on the red carpet of the [[ACM Awards]] that the duo had recorded their first album of gospel music. Joey Feek told ''Billboard'' that \"It's kind of an inspirational album, of old gospel songs that I grew up singing and listening to my mom sing.... It\u2019s an album I\u2019ve wanted to do for a long, long time.\"<ref>{{cite news|last=Brandle|first=Lars|title=Joey + Rory Finish New Gospel Album|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/1556667/joey-rory-finish-new-gospel-album|access-date=April 11, 2013|publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=April 9, 2013}}</ref> The album, ''Inspired: Songs of Faith & Family'', was released on July 16, 2013, via Gaither Music Group. It debuted at number 166 on the Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 3,000, while also peaking at number 31 on the Top Country Albums chart and at number 6 on the Top Christian Albums chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/country-album-chart-news-the-week-of-july-24-2013-travis-tritt-luke-bryan-florida-georgia-line-jason-aldean-blake-shelton-hunter-hayes-mud-digger-4 |access-date=July 25, 2013 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005103309/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/country-album-chart-news-the-week-of-july-24-2013-travis-tritt-luke-bryan-florida-georgia-line-jason-aldean-blake-shelton-hunter-hayes-mud-digger-4 |title= Country Album Chart News: The Week of July 24, 2013: Travis Tritt, Luke Bryan, Florida Georgia Line, Jason Aldean, Blake Shelton, Hunter Hayes, Mud Digger 4 |archive-date=October 5, 2013 }}</ref>\n\nAfter the release of their Gospel album, Joey + Rory announced that they would be releasing their fifth studio album, ''Made to Last'', in late 2013 via their own Farmhouse Recordings record label (their first self-released project). ''Made to Last'' was released on October 8, 2013, and debuted at No. 44 on the Top Country Albums chart. Their sixth studio album, ''Country Classics: A Tapestry of Our Musical Heritage'', was released exclusively to [[Cracker Barrel]] in May 2014, with a wide release following on October 14, 2014. Their second project on Gaither Music Group, the record consists of cover versions of classic country songs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/country-classics-a-tapestry-of-our-musical-heritage-mw0002661289/credits|title=Country Classics: A Tapestry of Our Musical Heritage|work=AllMusic|access-date=16 November 2015}}</ref>\n\n''[[Hymns That Are Important to Us]]'', the duo's seventh and final studio album, was released on February 12, 2016, via Gaither Music Group.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stefano|first=Angela|title=Joey + Rory Announce 'Hymns That Are Important to Us' Deluxe Edition|url=http://theboot.com/joey-and-rory-hymns-that-are-important-to-us-deluxe-edition/|access-date=January 13, 2016|publisher=The Boot|date=January 12, 2016}}</ref> The set, which was a \"dream project\" for Joey Feek, consists of twelve covers of Christian [[hymns]], plus a reprise of \"When I'm Gone,\" which was first featured on the duo's ''His and Hers'' album in 2012. Some proceeds of the album's deluxe edition will go towards the Loeys-Dietz Syndrome Foundation, a charity selected by Joey Feek in honor of her daughter's friend who has Loeys-Dietz syndrome. ''Hymns That Are Important to Us'' debuted at the top of the ''Billboard'' [[Top Country Albums]] and [[Top Christian Albums]] charts, with first week sales of 68,000 copies, making it their highest-charting release and the duo's best sales week ever.<ref name=\"Jim Asker\">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6889326/joey-rory-hyms-country-albums-chart-kelsea-ballerini-dibs|title=Joey + Rory's Bittersweet 'Hymns' Debuts at No. 1 on Top Country Albums Chart|author=Jim Asker|date=February 23, 2016|publisher=Billboard.com|access-date=February 23, 2016}}</ref>\n\nRory Feek wrote and produced a film, ''Josephine'', which was set in the American Civil War and included the couple's song of the same name. .<ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/news/rory-feeks-josephine-brings-true-civil-war-love-story-to-theaters-20160418 \"Rory Feek's 'Josephine' Brings Civil War Love Story to Theaters\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171202102807/https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/news/rory-feeks-josephine-brings-true-civil-war-love-story-to-theaters-20160418 |date=2017-12-02 }}. ''Rolling Stone'', By Stephen L. Betts April 18, 2016</ref> It was shot at the [[Nathan Bedford Forrest Boyhood Home]], the childhood home of Confederate General [[Nathan Bedford Forrest]] owned by the [[Sons of Confederate Veterans]] in [[Chapel Hill, Tennessee]].<ref name=\"thetennesseanmeethecaretaker\">{{cite news|last1=Bliss|first1=Jessica|title=Meet the caretaker of Nathan Bedford Forrest's boyhood home in Tennessee|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/2017/08/18/meet-caretaker-nathan-bedford-forrests-boyhood-home-tennessee/577878001/|access-date=December 2, 2017|work=The Tennessean|date=August 18, 2017}}</ref> The film later debuted at the Nashville Film Festival in summer 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/714632/joey-feek-dead-at-40-joey-rory-country-singer-remembered-as-loving-mom-after-battling-cervical-cancer|title=Joey Feek Dead at 40 After Battling Cervical Cancer|website=eonline.com|date=4 March 2016|access-date=22 April 2018}}</ref>\n\nJoey was diagnosed with [[cervical cancer]] in late 2015 and died of the disease in March 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/714632/joey-feek-dead-at-40-joey-rory-country-singer-remembered-as-loving-mom-after-battling-cervical-cancer|title=Joey Feek Dead at 40: Joey + Rory Country Singer Remembered as Loving Mom After Battling Cervical Cancer|date=March 4, 2016|work=E! Online|accessdate=March 5, 2016}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Title\n! <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Crossin_Dixon","to":"Crossin Dixon"}],"pages":{"14690080":{"pageid":14690080,"ns":0,"title":"Crossin Dixon","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country music and Southern rock band}}\n{{Single source|date=April 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Crossin Dixon\n| image           =\n| alias           = Kyote Wylde\n| origin          = [[Mississippi]], [[United States]]\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[Southern rock]]\n| years_active    = 2002\u20132015\n| label           = [[Broken Bow Records|Broken Bow]]<br>[[Broken Bow Records|Stoney Creek]]\n| associated_acts = [[Jason Aldean]]<br />[[Paul Thorn]]<br />[[Jamie Davis (musician)|Jamie Davis and Soul Gravy]]\n| website         = http://www.crossin-dixon.com/\n| past_members    = Jason Miller<br />Michael Bole <br /> Brandon Hyde<br />Charlie Grantham\n}}\n\n'''Crossin Dixon''' is an American [[country music]] and [[Southern rock]] group signed to the independent [[Broken Bow Records|Stoney Creek Records]] label. It was founded by Jason Miller (vocals), Michael Bole, Brandon Hyde and Charlie Grantham.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p972084|pure_url=yes}} |title=allmusic ((( Crossin Dixon > Biography ))) |accessdate=2007-12-13 |last=Leahey |first=Andrew |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> They have released three singles, of which two have charted on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts.\n\n==Biography==\nThe four members of Crossin Dixon first performed together in 2002. Originally, they assumed the name Kyote Wylde, but after developing a significant fanbase, the band changed its name to Crossin Dixon in 2004, to reflect their widespread touring.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> The band was recommended to record producer [[Michael Knox (record producer)|Michael Knox]], who had also worked with [[Jason Aldean]], and by 2006, Crossin Dixon was signed to [[Broken Bow Records]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Their first single, entitled \"Guitar Slinger\", was released to radio in July 2007; both it and the followup, \"Make You Mine\", charted on the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts that year. They released a third single, \"I Love My Old Bird Dog (& I Love You Too)\" in 2008, but the single failed to chart.  Their self-titled debut was released digitally on December 16, 2008. They released a single called \"Lovin in the Country\" to radio and  on August 31, 2010, as the first single for an upcoming, untitled second album. A new single, \"Goodbye to Henry\", was released on December 6, 2010, but it failed to chart. \n\nCrossin Dixon took a brief hiatus in 2012 following the announcement of former singer, Jason Miller, to pursue a solo career. After careful thought and consideration for their fans, the two remaining members of Crossin Dixon, Brandon Hyde and Charlie Grantham, decided they would continue their tour starting in January 2013. The band broke up sometime in 2015, without making much noise or a formal announcement. \n\n==Discography==\n===''Crossin Dixon'' (2008)===\n{{Infobox album\n| italic_title = no\n| name       = ''Crossin Dixon''\n| type       = Studio\n| artist     = Crossin Dixon\n| cover      = CrossinDixon.jpg\n| alt        =\n| released   = November 18, 2008\n| recorded   =\n| venue      =\n| studio     =\n| genre      = Country\n| length     = 38:53\n| label      = [[Broken Bow Records|Broken Bow]]\n| producer   = [[Michael Knox (record producer)|Michael Knox]]\n| prev_title =\n| prev_year  =\n| next_title =\n| next_year  =\n}}\n;Track listing\n#\"Guitar Slinger\" ([[Rodney Clawson]], Jon Stone, [[Bob DiPiero]]) - 3:23\n#\"Don't Give Up on Me\" ([[Lee Brice]], Garrett Parris, [[Kyle Jacobs (musician)|Kyle Jacobs]]) -   3:37\n#\"Stomp\" (Clawson, Blair Daly, [[John Rich]]) - 3:07\n#\"Don't Waste Your Pretty\" ([[Willie Mack (musician)|Willie Mack]], Giles Godard) - 2:49\n#\"Let the Bad Times Roll\" ([[Brett James]], [[Hillary Lindsey]], [[Troy Verges]], Blair Daly) - 3:42\n#\"[[Nineteen (song)|Nineteen]]\" ([[Jeffrey Steele]], [[Gary Nicholson (singer)|Gary Nicholson]], [[Tom Hambridge]]) - 3:09\n#\"Make You Mine\" (Clawson, Stone) - 3:52\n#\"I Love My Old Bird Dog (& I Love You)\" (Bill Luther, James) - 4:09\n#\"I Can Try\" ([[Dave Berg (songwriter)|Dave Berg]], George Teren) - 3:06\n#\"Moonshine and Mountain Dew\" ([[Chris Tompkins]], [[Josh Kear]], [[Mark Irwin (songwriter)|Mark Irwin]]) - 3:13\n#\"Just Look What You've Done\" (James, [[John Bettis]]) - 4:46\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Lane_Turner","to":"Lane Turner"}],"pages":{"19566266":{"pageid":19566266,"ns":0,"title":"Lane Turner","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter (born 1967)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name                = Lane Turner\n| image                 = \n| caption            = \n| image_size            = \n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          = Michael Lane Turner\n| origin              = [[Monahans, Texas]], United States\n| instrument          = Vocals, Acoustic Guitar<ref name=\"westernunderground.com\">{{cite web|url=http://www.westernunderground.com/fr_home.cfm |title=westernunderground Resources and Information |website=Westernunderground.com |date= |accessdate=April 29, 2020}}</ref>\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = 2004\u2013present\n| label               = [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]]\n| associated_acts     = [[Blaine Larsen]], [[Chris LeDoux]]\n| website                 = \n}}\n'''Michael Lane Turner''' (born February 3, 1967, in [[Monahans, Texas]]) is an American singer-songwriter. Signed to [[Warner Bros. Records]] since 2004, he released two singles for the label, including \"Always Wanting More (Breathless)\", which reached No.&nbsp;56 on the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts in 2004. Lane signed with Original Signal Recordings in 2009.\n\n== Early life ==\nTurner was born in Monahans, Texas, and attended school in [[Levelland, Texas|Levelland]], which he described as \"a place so flat you can watch your dog run away for two days\".<ref>{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Natalie|title=Lane Turner could be the next country star|work=[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]|date=September 2, 2008|url=http://www.lubbockonline.com/stories/090208/liv_326496802.shtml|accessdate=October 1, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Meet \"The Next GAC Star\" Finalist Lane Turner, Page 1|publisher=[[Great American Country]]|url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_feature/article/0,3038,GAC_26499_5917657_01,00.html|accessdate=October 1, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120211172244/http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_feature/article/0,3038,GAC_26499_5917657_01,00.html|archive-date=February 11, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref> He received his first guitar as a gift from his parents when he was eleven years old and his father taught him to play the songs he heard on the radio.<ref name=Bio>{{cite web|title=Lane Turner|publisher=[[New Country Star]]|url=http://www.newcountrystar.com/LaneTurner.htm|accessdate=October 1, 2008}}</ref> He attended [[Texas Tech University]] in [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]], where he was an [[All-America]]n [[decathlon|decathlete]]. He also played in a band called Diamondback during his time in college.<ref name=Bio /><ref>{{cite web|title=Meet \"The Next GAC Star\" Finalist Lane Turner, Page 2|publisher=[[Great American Country]]|page=2|url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_feature/article/0,3038,GAC_26499_5917657_02,00.html|accessdate=October 1, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916222058/http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_feature/article/0,3038,GAC_26499_5917657_02,00.html|archive-date=September 16, 2008|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n== Singing career ==\nTurner signed to Warner Bros. Records in 2004. He released two singles for the label\u2014\"Always Wanting More (Breathless)\" and \"Let You Go\"\u2014but no album. He also co-wrote [[Blaine Larsen]]'s single \"I Don't Know What She Said\".\n\nIn 2008, Turner was a contestant on ''The Next GAC Star'', which aired on the network [[Great American Country]]. He completed the competition as runner up to winning band One Night Rodeo.<ref name=Bio /><ref>{{cite news|last=Keel|first=Beverly|date=September 1, 2008|title=2 from Tennessee compete in Bravo model search|work=The Tennessean|url=http://www.tennessean.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080915/COLUMNIST0501/809150347/1005/ENTERTAINMENT|accessdate=October 1, 2008}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Votes Are In: Who's The Next GAC Star?|publisher=[[Great American Country]]|url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_headlines/article/0,3034,GAC_26063_5937578_,00.html|accessdate=October 1, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080926154459/http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_headlines/article/0,3034,GAC_26063_5937578_,00.html|archive-date=September 26, 2008|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nAs of early 2011, Lane has replaced Dustin Evans as lead vocalist for the country music band Western Underground, originally fronted by [[Chris LeDoux]].<ref name=\"westernunderground.com\"/>\n\nLane has continued in the Western Underground tradition as the base player for Ned Ledoux\u2019s band.  [[Ned LeDoux]].\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:22em;\"| Single\n!| Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! style=\"width:65px;\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n|-\n| 2004\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Always Wanting More (Breathless)\"\n| 56\n| style=\"text-align:left;\" rowspan=\"3\"| ''Right On Time''\n|-\n| 2006\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Let You Go\"\n|  \u2014\n|-\n| 2008\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Little Book of Matches\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2009\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Where's a Sunset (When You Need One)\"\n| \u2014\n| style=\"text-align:left;\"| ''Lane Turner''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss?url=search-alias%3Ddigital-music&field-keywords=lane+turner&x=6&y=22 |title=lane turner: Digital Music |website=Amazon.com |date=April 2, 2020|accessdate=April 29, 2020}}</ref>\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Simpson"}],"pages":{"42522959":{"pageid":42522959,"ns":0,"title":"Sturgill Simpson","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country music singer-songwriter}}\n{{good article}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2019}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name         = Sturgill Simpson\n| image        = Sturgill Simpson photo 2016 background = solo_singer\n| genre        = {{Hlist|[[Alternative country]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.varsity.co.uk/music/22020#google_vignette |title=Album review: alt-country star Sturgill
