to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Johnny_Van_Zant","to":"Johnny Van Zant"}],"pages":{"1473365":{"pageid":1473365,"ns":0,"title":"Johnny Van Zant","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer (born 1960)}}\n{{BLP sources|date=December 2020}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2015}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Johnny Van Zant\n| image             = Johnny Van Zant (Lynyrd Skynyrd) (cropped).jpg\n| image_size        = \n| caption           = Van Zant in 2012\n| birth_name        = John Roy Van Zant\n| alias             = \n| birth_date        = {{Birth date and age|1960|2|27}}\n| birth_place       = [[Jacksonville, Florida]], U.S.\n| origin            = \n| genre             = [[Southern rock]], [[Country music|country]]\n| occupation        = Singer\n| years_active      = 1976\u2013present\n| label             = \n| current_member_of = [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]]\n| past_member_of    = [[Van Zant (band)|Van Zant]]\n}}\n\n'''John Roy Van Zant''' (born February 27, 1960), also known as '''Johnny Van Zant''', is an American singer and the current lead vocalist of [[Southern rock]] band [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]]. He is the younger brother of Lynyrd Skynyrd co-founder and former lead vocalist [[Ronnie Van Zant]], and of the [[38 Special (band)|38 Special]] founder [[Donnie Van Zant]].\n\n==Biography==\nDuring the 1970s, Van Zant performed with his first band, the Austin Nickels Band. They later changed their name to [[The Johnny Van Zant Band]] releasing their debut solo album, ''[[No More Dirty Deals]]'', in 1980. Early members of the Johnny Van Zant Band consisted of Van Zant on lead vocals, Robbie Gay on guitar, Danny Clausman, on bass, Erik Lundgren on lead guitar, Robbie Morris, drums and [[Joan Hecht]] (previously Joan Cusimano) and Nancy Henderson on background vocals. Van Zant released three more solo albums between 1981 and 1985, before taking a break from the music business.\n\nHe became lead vocalist and chief songwriter for the reunited Lynyrd Skynyrd in 1987 and continues to record and perform with them today. He released another solo album, ''Brickyard Road'', in 1990, which featured the popular title track, which was a #1 hit on the U.S. [[Mainstream Rock Tracks]] chart for three weeks. He also records and performs with his brother, Donnie, as [[Van Zant (band)|Van Zant]] since 1998. Van Zant and Lynyrd Skynyrd performed in Arizona on April 9, 2022, during Arizona Bike Week at WestWorld of Scottsdale. He stated that original member [[Gary Rossington]] was recovering and still needed prayers.\n\nIn May 2006, less than one day before he was to perform at [[KSAN (FM)|KSAN-FM]] 107.7 ''The Bone's Bone Bash 7'', Van Zant underwent emergency surgery to have his [[Vermiform appendix|appendix]] removed. Treated at [[Stanford University Medical Center]] in [[Palo Alto, California]], after reporting pain to a doctor earlier in the day. The incident forced the band to cancel three U.S. shows.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4997130.stm Notice of Johnny Van Zant surgery], bbc.co.uk; accessed August 11, 2015.</ref>\n\nVan Zant is a fan of the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]]. He recorded a video, along with remaining members of Lynyrd Skynyrd, that is played at every Jaguars home game on the [[TIAA Bank Field]] video board.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2018-08-31 |title=Jaguars and Skynyrd a Natural Fit |url=https://www.samsportsline.com/jaguars-and-skynyrd-a-natural-fit/ |access-date=2022-05-11 |website=Jacksonville Sports News, Sam Kouvaris SamSportsline.com |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nAccording to Skynyrd's website, Van Zant was again hospitalized on August 6, 2011, at the [[Hennepin County Medical Center]] in [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]], due to complications from a previous surgery. According to the website, Van Zant had a \"surgical site\" infected with [[cellulitus]] which required both hospitalization and IV/Antibiotic treatment. He began displaying signs of a [[staphylococcal infection|staph infection]] and other symptoms related to the infection. His subsequent illness resulted in a number of scheduled performances being cancelled.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Newton|first=Steve|date=2011-08-11|title=Lynyrd Skynyrd's Johnny Van Zant hospitalized, numerous shows cancelled {{!}} Georgia Straight Vancouver's News & Entertainment Weekly|url=https://www.straight.com/blogra/lynyrd-skynyrds-johnny-van-zant-hospitalized-numerous-shows-cancelled|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305005923/http://www.straight.com/blogra/lynyrd-skynyrds-johnny-van-zant-hospitalized-numerous-shows-cancelled|archive-date=2016-03-05|access-date=2022-02-06|website=[[The Georgia Straight]]|language=en}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n[[File:Johnny Van Zant.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Van Zant performing with Lynyrd Skynyrd in 2012]]\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n\n!Title !! Release !! Year\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Video\n|-\n| 1990\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Brickyard Road\"\n|}\n\n\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n{{commons category}}\n* [https://lynyrdskynyrd.com Lynyrd Skynyrd website]\n\n{{Lynyrd Skynyrd}}\n{{Van Zant}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Van Zant, Johnny}}\n[[Category:1960 births]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singers]]\n[[Category:American male singers]]\n[[Category:American people of Dutch descent]]\n[[Category:American rock singers]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Lynyrd Skynyrd members]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Jacksonville, Florida]]\n[[Category:Singers from Florida]]\n[[Category:Van Zant (band) members]]\n[[Category:American blues rock musicians]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Isaacs","to":"The Isaacs"}],"pages":{"17578151":{"pageid":17578151,"ns":0,"title":"The Isaacs","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Bluegrass Southern gospel group}}\n{{about|the bluegrass band|other uses|Isaacs (disambiguation)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = The Isaacs\n| image            = \n| caption          = \n| background       = group_or_band\n| origin           = [[Hendersonville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| genre            = [[Southern gospel]], [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]], [[Country music|Country]]\n| years_active     = 1987-present\n| label            = Horizon, Gaither, K-Tel, Spring Hill, Isaacs House\n| website          = {{URL|http://www.theisaacs.com}}\n| associated_acts  = \n| current_members  = Lily Isaacs <br> Ben Isaacs <br> [[Sonya Isaacs]] <br> Becky Isaacs  \n| past_members     = John Bowman <br> [[Jimmy Yeary]] <br> Levi Bowman <br> Joe Isaacs <br> Thomas Wywrot <br> Tim Surrett\n}}\n'''The Isaacs''' are a bluegrass [[Southern gospel]] music group consisting of mother Lily Isaacs (b. September 20, 1947), daughters Becky (b. Aug. 2, 1975) and [[Sonya Isaacs]] (b. July 22, 1974) and son Ben Isaacs (b. July 25, 1972), along with John Bowman (husband of Becky Isaacs) as an instrumentalist and songwriter. Joe Isaacs, formerly a singer and banjo player in the group, has left since his 1998 divorce from Lily Isaacs. He now does solo work on a far more localized level.\n\nFormer Kingsmen Quartet bass player, lead singer and baritone Tim Surrett was a member of group from 1997 until 2002. Surrett was married to Sonya Isaacs during this time period. Thomas Wywrot was a member from 2008 to 2011. Sonya Isaacs' husband, [[Jimmy Yeary]], took his place.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.singingnews.com/Southern-Gospel-News/11655741/ |title=Jimmy Yeary Joins The Isaacs &#124; The Southern Gospel Music Magazine |publisher=SingingNews.com |date=2011-08-30 |accessdate=2012-07-06 |archive-date=2011-10-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111017015300/http://www.singingnews.com/Southern-Gospel-News/11655741/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nCurrently, the Isaacs consists of [[Sonya Isaacs|Sonya Isaacs Yeary]], Lily Isaacs, Becky Isaacs Bowman and Ben Isaacs. On August 10, 2021, they were invited to become [[List of Grand Ole Opry members|members]] of the [[Grand Ole Opry]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://eu.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/2021/08/11/the-isaacs-join-grand-ole-opry/5566431001/|title=Grand Ole Opry invites the Isaacs to become newest member}}</ref>\n\n==History==\nThe group's roots go back to 1971,<ref name=\"people\">{{cite news |last1=Etienne |first1=Vanessa |title=The Isaacs Premiere 'The American Face' Music Video: 'United We Stand' |url=https://people.com/music/isaacs-premiere-the-american-face-music-video-united-we-stand/ |access-date=12 July 2021 |work=PEOPLE.com |language=en}}</ref> when Joe and Lily Isaacs began a bluegrass band. Lily's parents are [[The Holocaust in Poland|Polish Jewish Holocaust]] survivors. A few years after they were liberated from a concentration camp in Germany in 1945, her parents moved two year old Lily to New York City, where, in 1958, she got a recording contract with [[Columbia Records]] and started performing in night clubs. While performing with his Kentucky band at the [[Gerde's Folk City]], Joe met Lily and they were married in 1970. After Joe's brother died in an automobile accident, Joe and Lily became Christians, and the group began to perform only bluegrass gospel music.<ref name=\"lufkin\">{{cite news |last1=BARCLAY |first1=BRITTANY |title=The Isaacs to bring bluegrass gospel to The Pines |url=https://lufkindailynews.com/news/community/article_94d60ad4-b88c-5651-a672-7ce01b2b7c36.html |access-date=12 July 2021 |work=The Lufkin Daily News |language=en}}</ref> The group was initially named the Calvary Mountain Boys and later became Sacred Bluegrass before settling on the family name, the Isaacs. The group performed primarily on weekends, part-time, until 1986.<ref name=\"sgn\">{{cite news |last1=Gilmore |first1=Justin |title=The Year Of Jubilee: A Conversation with Lily Isaacs of the Isaacs |url=https://www.sgnscoops.com/year-jubilee-conversation-lily-isaacs-isaacs/ |access-date=12 July 2021 |work=Southern Gospel News SGNScoops Digital |date=25 February 2017}}</ref> As their son and daughters became old enough, they joined the group.<ref name=\"eagm\">{{cite book |last1=McNeil |first1=W. K. |title=Encyclopedia of American Gospel Music |date=2013 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=9781135377007 |page=196 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=beGNAQAAQBAJ&q=Isaacs+music&pg=PA196 |accessdate=5 July 2018 |language=en}}</ref>\n\nIn 1992, the Isaacs moved from [[Morrow, Ohio]], and settled in [[LaFollette, Tennessee]].<ref name=\"eagm\" />\n\n== Recording ==\nAs the Calvary Mountain Boys and Sacred Bluegrass, the group recorded for Pine Tree and Old Homestead labels. As the Isaacs, they had more success with Morning Star Records and Horizon record labels.<ref name=\"eagm\" />\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! Rugged Cross'' \"Consider The Lilies\" (Becky & Sonya)\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n===Grammy Awards===\nThe [[Grammy Awards]] are presented annually by the [[National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences]] of the [[United States]] for outstanding achievements in the music industry. The awards were established in 1958. The Isaacs have been nominated three times.\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n|[[59th Annual Grammy Awards|2016]]\n|''[[Nature's Symphony in 432|Nature's Symphony In 432]]''\n| rowspan=3| [[Grammy Award for Best Roots Gospel Album|Best Roots Gospel Album]]\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n|[[60th Annual Grammy Awards|2018]]\n|''Favorites: Revisited By Request'' \n|{{nom}}\n|-\n|[[64th Annual Grammy Awards|2022]]\n|''Songs for the Times''\n|{{nom}}\n{{end}}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.theisaacs.com Official website of the Isaacs]\n* [http://www.faithtalks.com/posts/lily-isaacs/ Interview with Lily Isaacs]\n* [https://www.fiii.org/ The Fishman Isaacs Israel Initiative]\n\n{{Grand Ole Opry members}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Isaacs, The}}\n[[Category:American bluegrass music groups]]\n[[Category:American folk musical groups]]\n[[Category:Family musical groups]]\n[[Category:Musical groups from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Southern gospel performers]]\n[[Category:Converts to Christianity from Judaism]]\n[[Category:People from LaFollette, Tennessee]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"pages":{"12996344":{"pageid":12996344,"ns":0,"title":"McHayes","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country music duo}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name                = McHayes\n| image                 = \n| caption            = \n| image_size            = \n| background          = group_or_band\n| origin              = [[Nashville]], [[Tennessee]], [[United States]]\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]]\n| years_active        = 2003\n| label               = [[Universal South Records|Universal South]] = \n| past_members        = [[Wade Hayes]]<br />Mark McClurg\n}}\n'''McHayes''' was an American [[country music]] duo established in 2003 by [[Wade Hayes]] (guitar, vocals) and Mark McClurg (fiddle, vocals). Prior to the duo's foundation, Hayes was a solo artist, and McClurg was a member of [[Alan Jackson]]'s road band, The Strayhorns. Active only in the year 2003, McHayes recorded an unreleased studio album on the [[Universal South Records]] label, in addition to charting one single on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts. After disbanding, McClurg rejoined Jackson's band, and Hayes joined former [[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]] lead singer [[Randy Owen]]'s backing band.\n\n==History==\nBetween 1995 and 2002, McHayes frontman [[Wade Hayes]] was a solo artist, recording four studio albums, and charting more than a dozen singles on the ''Billboard'' country music charts, including the number 1 single \"[[Old Enough to Know Better (song)|Old Enough to Know Better]]\". After poor performance of his fourth studio album, ''[[Highways & Heartaches (Wade Hayes album)|Highways & Heartaches]]'', he partnered with musician Mark McClurg, who had previously played fiddle in [[Alan Jackson]]'s road band The Strayhorns, to form the duo McHayes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystarsonline.com/reviewarchives/McHayes.htm |title=McHayes Debut on the Grand Ole Opry |accessdate=2007-10-12 |last=Neal |first=Helen |work=Country Stars Online.com |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070817103456/http://countrystarsonline.com/reviewarchives/McHayes.htm |archivedate=2007-08-17 |url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1470185/20030226/hayes_wade.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071113105247/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1470185/20030226/hayes_wade.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=November 13, 2007 |title=CMT.com : Wade Hayes : Wade Hayes Forms Duo, Signs New Deal |accessdate=2007-10-12 |work=CMT.com}}</ref> Signed to [[Universal South Records]] in 2003, McHayes charted one single, titled \"It Doesn't Mean I Don't Love You\",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nashvillepost.com/news/2003/2/28/new_country_duo_mchayes_signs_with_universal_south |title=New country duo McHayes signs with Universal South |accessdate=2007-10-12 |last=Ruble |first=Drew |work=Nashville Post.com}}</ref> which peaked at number 41 on the U.S. country charts.<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=273|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref> McHayes also recorded an album titled ''Lessons in Lonely'', which was slated for release in mid-2003 under the production of [[Brent Rowan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/lessons-in-lonely-mw0001299550|title=''Lessons in Lonely'' review|last=Dinoia|first=Maria Konicki|work=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=3 November 2012}}</ref> The album was never released, and the duo exited Universal South's roster.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystarsonline.com/reviewarchives/Trap_JoeN_McHayes.htm |title=Universal-South Artists Capture The Trap |accessdate=2007-10-12 |last=Neal |first=Helen |work=Country Stars Online.com |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070816163133/http://countrystarsonline.com/reviewarchives/Trap_JoeN_McHayes.htm |archivedate=2007-08-16 |url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/articles/1480570/20031120/bogguss_suzy.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041123170051/http://www.cmt.com/news/articles/1480570/20031120/bogguss_suzy.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=November 23, 2004 |title=CMT.com : News : Nashville Skyline : Some Orphaned CDs of 2003 |accessdate=2007-10-12 |last=Flippo |first=Chet |work=CMT.com}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"65\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n|-\n| 2003\n! scope=\"row\"| \"It Doesn't Mean I Don't Love You\"\n| 41\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"2\"| ''Lessons in Lonely'' <small>(unreleased)</small>\n|-\n| 2004\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Tulsa Time]]\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Video\n|-\n| 2004\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Tulsa Time\"\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n{{Wade Hayes}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Machayes}}\n[[Category:Country music groups from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:American country music duos]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 2003]]\n[[Category:Musical groups disestablished in 2003]]\n[[Category:Show Dog-Universal Music artists]]\n[[Category:2003 establishments in Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Nashville, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:American male musical duos]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Veronica_Ballestrini","to":"Veronica Ballestrini"}],"pages":{"24146305":{"pageid":24146305,"ns":0,"title":"Veronica Ballestrini","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Italian-American singer and songwriter}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|name             = Veronica Ballestrini\n|image            = Veronica Ballestrini Hardrock.png\n|caption          = \n|birth_name       = Veronica Jean Ballestrini\n|birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1991|10|29}}\n|birth_place      = [[Waterford, Connecticut]], United States\n|genre            = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[Pop music|pop]]}}\n|background       = solo_singer\n| associated_acts = {{hlist|[[Secondhand Serenade]]|The Rebel Roads}}\n|occupation       = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter}}\n|instrument       = {{hlist|Guitar|keyboard|vocals}}\n|years_active     = 2008\u2013present\n|label            = Timbob\n|website          = {{official URL|veronicaballestrini.net}}\n}}\n\n'''Veronica Jean Ballestrini'''  also known as '''Veronica Vesely''' (born October 29, 1991) is an Italian-American singer and songwriter. She has released two studio albums. Her self-made success story has caught national attention as Jon Caramanica wrote in ''[[The New York Times]]'', \"...&nbsp;When someone like Ms. Ballestrini arrives essentially unannounced and begins to attract attention, it's significant.\"<ref>Caramanica, Jon. (July 31, 2009) [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/02/arts/music/02cara.html?pagewanted=all Following in Taylor Swift's Footsteps, Young Women Change the Face of Country]. ''The New York Times''. Retrieved on September 18, 2011.</ref>\n\n== Biography ==\nBallestrini was born in [[New London, Connecticut]], and raised in [[Waterford, Connecticut]]. She comes from a large family of four brothers and one sister. Her father Rosario Ballestrini and mother Carol Marandino Ballestrini are both [[Italian-American]].<ref>[http://www.veronicaballestrini.net/bio.php Veronica's family] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120702132833/http://www.veronicaballestrini.net/bio.php |date=July 2, 2012 }}. Veronicaballestrini.net. Retrieved on September 18, 2011.</ref>\n\n[[File:VeronicatCMAfest.png|thumb|left|upright=1|alt=Veronica signing at CMA Festival.|Ballestrini signing at CMA Festival.]]\n\nBallestrini began playing [[guitar]] and writing songs at the age of thirteen, the same year she started her [[MySpace]] music page. With only cover songs up at the time, she still managed to attract many fans.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090502001149/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/veronica_ballestrini/artist.jhtml Veronica growing up]. CMT. Retrieved on September 18, 2011.</ref>  Veronica's popularity increased after writing and composing her song \"Daddy\" and posting it to her MySpace playlist. At age fourteen Ballestrini began performing around her home state of [[Connecticut]] at local talent contests and [[fairs]]. In November 2006, Ballestrini won 1st place at the USA World Showcase in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], performing her song \"Daddy\". Her internet status caught the attention of Nashville record producers, who then contacted her about recording in [[Music City]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090502001149/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/veronica_ballestrini/artist.jhtml Ballestrini gaining popularity through MySpace]. Cmt.com. Retrieved on September 18, 2011.</ref>\n\nWhile still in high school, Ballestrini made her professional singing debut. Ballestrini created an independent label in 2009 and worked with producer Cliff Downs, with whom she has written many songs. Downs produced her debut album \"What I'm All About\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.veronicaballestrini.net/bio.php/|title=Ballestrini growing up biography|access-date=January 6, 2019|archive-date=July 2, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120702132833/http://www.veronicaballestrini.net/bio.php}}</ref>\n\n==Music career==\n<!--  [[File:VeronicaB10.png|thumb|left|Ballestrini performing in Philadelphia, PA]]  -->\n\n===2009-2010: ''What I'm All About''===\nBallestrini went on to record her debut album ''What I'm All About'' which was released on August 21, 2009 on her own independent label. Her first single \"Amazing\" charted at #24 on the [[Music Row]] chart.<ref>[http://www.musicrow.com/2010/06/veronica-ballestrini-3/ Music row Veronica]. Musicrow.com (June 20, 2010). Retrieved on September 18, 2011.</ref> and the music video debuted at No.&nbsp;3 on [[CMT Pure Country|CMT Pure]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090504083822/http://www.cmt.com/videos/veronica-ballestrini/377285/amazing.jhtml CMT music video]. Cmt.com. Retrieved on September 18, 2011.</ref> \"Don't Say\" and \"Out There Somewhere\" were two other singles released off this album.<ref>[http://www.musicrow.com/2010/06/veronica-ballestrini-3/]. MusicRow.com Retrieved on November 1, 2011.</ref> Ballestrini was named one of six \"Artists to Watch For\" by [[Marie Claire]] Magazine.<ref>Annie Reuter [http://www.marieclaire.com/world-reports/opinion/cma-bands CMA 2009: Six Artists To Watch].\nJuly 10, 2009</ref>\n\nBallestrini's song \"Destiny\" is featured in the Diary of an Ex-Child Star (formerly Leaving Hollywood) movie and on the soundtrack. \"Destiny\" is also on her \"What I'm All About\" CD.{{citation needed|date=June 2016}}\n\n===2010: ''If I Can Dream''===\nIn April 2010, Ballestrini was chosen as the \"Editors Pick\" in the [[If I Can Dream (web series)|If I Can Dream]] MySpace contest, created by [[Simon Fuller]]. She visited the Dream House in Beverly Hills from June 4\u20137, 2010. Ballestrini returned to the Dream House on June 23, 2010. During her stay she recorded her song \"Fascinated\" and worked with top writers, vocal coaches and had a romantic link to [[Alex Lambert]].<ref>[http://www.hulu.com/watch/160616/if-i-can-dream-who-wants-a-happy-ending#s-p2-so-i0 Veronica on \"If I Can Dream\"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100722122240/http://www.hulu.com/watch/160616/if-i-can-dream-who-wants-a-happy-ending#s-p2-so-i0 |date=July 22, 2010 }}. Hulu.com. Retrieved on September 18, 2011.</ref> She was at the house for two weeks. Lambert and Ballestrini broke up Winter 2010. For her audition video, Ballestrini sang \"Blessed The Broken Road\" by [[Rascal Flatts]].<ref name=\"auto\">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FoKcEvrn3Iw |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/FoKcEvrn3Iw |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|title=Veronica's Dream Break Weekend on If I Can Dream|last=ificandream|date=June 10, 2010 |access-date=January 6, 2019|via=YouTube}}{{cbignore}}</ref>\n\n===2010-2012: ''Gotta Make A Change''===\nIn 2010, Ballestrini was part of the \"Mead Five Star\" Music Insider nationwide sweepstake along with 9 other bands. In October 2010 it was announced Veronica was the winner of the fan voted contest, scoring $25,000.<ref>[http://neonuniverse.org/downloads/?p=1020]. Ballestrini wins MEAD Five Star Contest</ref> Ballestrini used that money to work on new music.\n\nIn 2011, Ballestrini began working on a project titled ''Gotta Make A Change'', a process that set in motion her \"Gotta Make A Change\" tour. Throughout the summer 2011, Ballestrini performed shows at various camps, festivals, Girl Scout events and women's correctional facilities across the U.S. to help spread the project's motivational message.<ref>[http://www.gottamakeachange.com \"Gotta Make A Change\"]. \"Gotta Make A Change\". Retrieved on September 18, 2011.</ref>\n\n[[File:Veronicaperformingguitar.png|thumb|right|upright=1|alt=Veronica performing 2012.|Ballestrini performing 2012.]]\n\nIn July 2011, Ballestrini announced to her fans her new single would be \"Temporary Fix\". The music video for this single was shot in Malibu, California.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y_torytqhrk \"Temporary Fix Video Shoot\"]. Youtube.com (June 25, 2011). Retrieved on September 18, 2011.</ref> \"Temporary Fix\" was released on iTunes on August 11, 2011 and the music video, released on September 24, 2011. In November 2011, Ballestrini charted on the [[Billboard Social 50]] chart and #2 for Country artists.<ref>[http://www.billboard.com/artist/veronica-ballestrini/discography/songs/1097508#/artist/veronica-ballestrini/discography/songs/1097508  \"Billboard Social 50\"]. \"Social 50 Billboard Chart\". Retrieved on November 18, 2011.</ref>\n\nIn 2012, Ballestrini released another single \"Don't Give Up On Me\", along with a music video.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7-srQ_kL0EA \"Don't Give Up On Me\"]. Youtube.com (May 13, 2013). Retrieved on September 18, 2011.</ref>\n\nBallestrini was in a relationship with country singer Shay Mooney from [[Dan and Shay]] from Summer 2011 to March 2013. During their relationship, they would post cover and original songs on YouTube and reached over 400,000 views combined.<ref name=\"auto\"/> The pair co-wrote songs for Ballestrini's sophomore album \"Flip Side\". The album was released on June 17, 2014.<ref name=\"auto\"/>\n\n===2014-present: ''Flip Side''===\nIn 2014, Ballestrini changed her album title name from \"Gotta Make A Change\" to \"Flip Side\". Ballestrini still continued to work on this album with producer/engineer [[Brandon Metcalf]]. While working on her album, Ballestrini went on a U.S. tour with [[Secondhand Serenade]] and [[Juliet Simms]]. The tour kick off show was in Lexington, KY on March 8 and ended in Hollywood, CA on April 9.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://newemmylou.wordpress.com/2013/03/12/veronica-ballestrini-on-tour-with-secondhand-serenade/|title=Veronica Ballestrini On Tour With Secondhand Serenade|last=maggienoonan|date=March 12, 2013|access-date=January 6, 2019}}</ref>\n\nBallestrini has three duets on [[Secondhand Serenade]]'s album ''Undefeated'', which was released in October 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5DQSVftA358 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/5DQSVftA358 |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|title=Secondhand Serenade-Heart Stops (By The Way) (feat. Veronica Ballestrini) (Undefeated Album)|last=Azizi Azmi|date=January 31, 2015 |access-date=January 6, 2019|via=YouTube}}{{cbignore}}</ref> Ballestrini is also featured on the [[Secondhand Serenade]] cover of \"[[Say Something (A Great Big World song)|Say Something]]\".\n\nIn April 2014, Ballestrini was chosen by Ford to be an agent for the Ford Fiesta Movement as part of a promotion with Ford and YouTube. She received a 2015 Ford Fiesta for a year, along with free gas, insurance, and all expenses paid.<ref>[https://archive.today/20130615192937/http://www.fiestamovement.com/agents/VeronicaBal \"Ford Fiesta Veronica]. Fiestamovement.com. Retrieved on May 13, 2013</ref>\n\nOn April 24, 2015, Ballestrini became engaged to [[Secondhand Serenade]] front man John Vesely.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YONPo5sWfH4 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/YONPo5sWfH4 |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|title=Secondhand Serenade Lead Singer Marriage Proposal|last=Dean Klinhom|date=April 24, 2015 |access-date=January 6, 2019|via=YouTube}}{{cbignore}}</ref> The couple met at Destiny Recording Studio in Nashville in early 2013 to record a [[Secondhand Serenade]] duet titled \"By The Way\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gb8Rz4FATcg |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/gb8Rz4FATcg |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|title=Secondhand Serenade - Heart Stops ( By The Way ) Feat. Veronica Ballestrini|last=SecondhandSerenadeTV|date=February 22, 2014 |access-date=January 6, 2019|via=YouTube}}{{cbignore}}</ref> Veronica and John were married on April 1, 2017, in Vero Beach, Florida.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/VeronicaBallestriniMusic/photos/a.335722365781/10155076027385782/?type=3|title=Veronica Ballestrini|website=www.facebook.com|access-date=January 6, 2019}}</ref>\n\n===The Rebel Roads===\n\nVeronica and John Vesely form The Rebel Roads, a country duo. Their first single \"First To Know\" was released in 2016. \n\nThey have since released 8 singles together and working on an upcoming album. \n\n<ref>{{cite news |author=Jimmy Lane |title=The Laney Report: Duo brings its songs to you Friday |work=The Bulletin |url= https://www.norwichbulletin.com/story/entertainment/columns/2020/04/29/the-laney-report-duo-brings/1273412007/ |date=April 29, 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:14em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''What I'm All About''\n| \n* Release date: August 21, 2009\n* Label: Timbob Records\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Flip Side''\n| \n* Release date: June 17, 2014\n* Label: Timbob Records\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:14em;\"| Single\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Blackberry_Smoke","to":"Blackberry Smoke"}],"pages":{"31954940":{"pageid":31954940,"ns":0,"title":"Blackberry Smoke","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American rock band}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2022}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Blackberry Smoke\n| image             = Blackberry Smoke live in Oklahoma City on April 28, 2018.jpg\n| caption           = Blackberry Smoke performing in 2018\n| image_upright     = 1.2\n| origin            = [[Atlanta, Georgia]], U.S.\n| genre             = {{hlist|[[Southern rock]]|[[country rock]]|[[hard rock]]|[[blues rock]]|[[jam band]]}}\n| years_active      = 2000\u2013present\n| label             = [[BamaJam]], Southern Ground, [[Rounder Records|Rounder]], 3 Legged, [[Earache Records|Earache]] (Europe)\n| website           = {{URL|blackberrysmoke.com}}\n| current_members   = * Paul Jackson\n* Charlie Starr\n* Richard Turner\n* Brandon Still\n* Benji Shanks\n* Kent Aberle*\n* * Touring member since 2022\n| past_members      = * Brit Turner\n* Preston Holcomb\n}}\n\n'''Blackberry Smoke''' is an American country rock band formed in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], in 2000. The lineup consists of Charlie Starr (lead vocals, guitar), Richard Turner (bass, backing vocals), Paul Jackson (guitar, backing vocals), and Brandon Still (keyboards).  Richard's brother Brit Turner was the band's drummer before his death in March 2024. In 2018, they added touring members Benji Shanks (guitar) and Preston Holcomb (percussion). They have released eight studio albums, two live albums and five extended plays.\n\n== History ==\nBlackberry Smoke was formed in Atlanta, Georgia, in 2000. They are the first independently released artist to hit No. 1 on the [[Billboard Country Albums|Billboard Country Album]] charts in modern history. Their debut album, ''Bad Luck Ain't No Crime'', was released in 2003. Their second album released in 2009, ''Little Piece of Dixie''. has been featured by ''[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]'' magazine and other publications.<ref name=\"pastemag\">{{cite web |url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/blogs/whitman/2009/05/blackberry-smoke----little-piece-of-dixie.html |title=Blackberry Smoke \u2013 Little Piece of Dixie :: Blogs :: Andy Whitman on Music :: Paste |publisher=Pastemagazine.com |date=May 14, 2009 |access-date=January 9, 2013 |archive-date=March 5, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130305010734/http://www.pastemagazine.com/blogs/whitman/2009/05/blackberry-smoke----little-piece-of-dixie.html |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Phillips |first=Fred |url=http://somethingelsereviews.com/2012/08/12/blackberry-smoke-the-whippoorwill-2012/ |title=Blackberry Smoke \u2013 The Whippoorwill (2012) |date=August 12, 2012 |publisher=Somethingelsereviews.com |access-date=January 9, 2013}}</ref>\n\nIn 2015 Blackberry Smoke became the first small independent outfit to have an album, ''Holding All The Roses'', go to No. 1 on the Billboard Country Albums chart. This was the first time a non-mainstream-supported artist or band was able to achieve this feat in the modern era. Blackberry Smoke's 2016 album ''Like An Arrow'' did the same.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.savingcountrymusic.com/blackberry-smoke-goes-1-in-album-sales-with-you-hear-georgia/ |title=Blackberry Smoke Goes #1 in Album Sales with \"You Hear Georgia\" |work=Saving Country Music|date=June 7, 2021 }}</ref> They have performed throughout the United States, Europe, Australia, and South America. They have performed alongside numerous artists such as [[Tedeschi Trucks Band]], [[Guns n' Roses]], [[Zac Brown Band]], [[ZZ Top]], [[Eric Church]] and [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]].\n\n[[File:Blackberry Smoke in 2012.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|Blackberry Smoke performing in 2012]]\nThe band had their first chart success with their third album, ''[[The Whippoorwill]]'', released in August 2012, reaching Top 40 on [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://rockrevoltmagazine.com/blackberry-smoke-video-pictures/ |title=Watch Blackberry Smoke's new video & check out live pics! |work=Rock Revolt Magazine|date=January 18, 2013 }}</ref> The album was released under the Southern Ground record label.<ref name=\"sga-label\">{{cite web |url=http://www.southerngroundrecords.com/2011/05/12/zac-brown-launches-southern-ground-artists-label/ |title=Zac Brown Launches Southern Ground Artists Label \u00ab Southern Ground |publisher=Southerngroundrecords.com |date=May 12, 2011 |access-date=January 9, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120624075433/http://www.southerngroundrecords.com/2011/05/12/zac-brown-launches-southern-ground-artists-label/ |archive-date=June 24, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> On August 26, 2012, they performed at a charity benefit called the Boot Ride with the cast of ''[[Sons of Anarchy]]'', partnered with The Boot Campaign at the Happy Ending Bar and Grill in [[Hollywood, Los Angeles|Hollywood]], [[California]].<ref name=\"boot-ride\">{{cite web |url=http://bootride.com/home.html |title=Boot Ride \u2014 Get Your Tickets NOW! |publisher=Bootride.com |access-date=January 9, 2013 |archive-date=August 17, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120817235718/http://www.bootride.com/home.html |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://somethingelsereviews.com/2012/08/12/blackberry-smoke-the-whippoorwill-2012/|title=Blackberry Smoke \u2013 The Whippoorwill (2012) \u2013 Something Else!|work=Something Else!|date=August 12, 2012|access-date=February 13, 2015}}</ref>\n\nOn November 12, 2014, they appeared among many others \u2013 [[Jamey Johnson]], [[Trace Adkins]], [[Warren Haynes]], [[Peter Frampton]], [[Gregg Allman]], etc. \u2013 in a show in tribute to Lynyrd Skynyrd at the Fox Theatre in Atlanta.\n\nThey moved to [[Rounder Records]] in 2014,<ref name=\"BS-Rounder-release\">{{cite web |url=http://www.blackberrysmoke.com/entry/blackberry-smoke-leave-zac-brown-s-label-ink-rounder-deal-for-new-album.html/ |title=Blackberry Smoke Leave Zac Brown's Label, Ink Rounder Deal for New Album |publisher=blackberrysmoke.com |date=November 6, 2014 |access-date=November 12, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141112155510/http://www.blackberrysmoke.com/entry/blackberry-smoke-leave-zac-brown-s-label-ink-rounder-deal-for-new-album.html/ |archive-date=November 12, 2014 |url-status=dead }}</ref> and released ''[[Holding All the Roses]]'' produced by [[Brendan O'Brien (record producer)|Brendan O'Brien]] in early 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.loudersound.com/reviews/blackberry-smoke-holding-all-the-roses-1 |title=Blackberry Smoke: Holding All The Roses |work=Louder Sound |first=Polly |last=Glass |date=January 23, 2015}}</ref> The album reached No. 1 on Billboard's Country Albums chart. The band spent much of the summer of 2016 on tour with [[Gov't Mule]].\n\nBlackberry Smoke released their fifth studio album, ''[[Like an Arrow]]'', featuring Gregg Allman, on October 14, 2016, via their own record label, 3 Legged Records.<ref>{{cite web|title=Album of the Month (October 2016): Blackberry Smoke, 'Like an Arrow' Read More: Album of the Month (October 2016): Blackberry Smoke, 'Like an Arrow' |url=http://theboot.com/blackberry-smoke-like-an-arrow-october-2016-album/|website=The Boot|date=October 3, 2016 |publisher=Taste of Country Network|access-date=October 27, 2016}}</ref> The album landed at No. 1 on the US ''[[Billboard charts|Billboard]]'' Country<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Top Country Albums|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/country-albums|magazine=Billboard|publisher=Billboard|access-date=October 27, 2016}}</ref> and Americana/Folk<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Americana/Folk Albums|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/americana-folk-albums|magazine=Billboard|publisher=Billboard|access-date=October 27, 2016}}</ref> charts as well as the UK Rock<ref>{{cite web|title=Official Rock & Metal Albums Charts|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/charts/rock-and-metal-albums-chart/|website=Official Charts|publisher=The Official UK Charts Company|access-date=October 27, 2016}}</ref> and Independent Albums<ref>{{cite web|title=Official Independent Albums Chart Top 50|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/charts/independent-albums-chart/|website=Official Charts|publisher=The Official UK Charts Company|access-date=October 27, 2016}}</ref> charts during release week. The band released its sixth studio album, ''Find A Light'', on December 19, 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.blackberrysmoke.com/find-a-light|title=Blackberry Smoke \u2013 Find a Light|access-date=October 8, 2019|archive-date=October 8, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191008173715/https://www.blackberrysmoke.com/find-a-light|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nIn 2019, the band released via [[Earache Records]] a live album and a film ''Homecoming: Live in Atlanta'', recorded at their annual Brothers And Sisters Holiday Homecoming event at the [[Tabernacle (concert hall)|Tabernacle]] in Atlanta in November 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.loudersound.com/news/blackberry-smoke-announce-homecoming-live-in-atlanta-live-album-and-film |title=Blackberry Smoke announce Homecoming: Live In Atlanta live album and film|first= Fraser |last=Lewry |date= September 9, 2019 |work=Louder Sound}}</ref> In 2021 the band released its seventh studio album, ''You Hear Georgia.''<ref>{{Cite web|last=Ehrenclou|first=Martine|date=February 24, 2021|title=Blackberry Smoke To Release New Album 'You Hear Georgia' Out May 28th, Share Title Track|url=https://www.rockandbluesmuse.com/2021/02/24/blackberry-smoke-to-release-new-album-you-hear-georgia-out-may-28th-share-title-track/|access-date=October 13, 2021|website=Rock and Blues Muse|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nOn May 28, 2021, their album ''[[You Hear Georgia]]'' was released. It debuted at No. 1 on the Billboard Americana/Folk Chart.<ref>{{cite magazine|url= https://www.billboard.com/charts/americana-folk-albums/2021-06-12/ |title=Blackberry Smoke Americana/Folk Charts|date= June 12, 2021 |magazine=Billboard}}</ref> It sold over 33k copies the first week, 12,239 copies in pure album sales. This was good enough to put it also at No. 1 in album sales in both country and rock, and No. 3 in all of music. The album also racked up another nearly 1 million streams its debut week. The album was produced by [[Dave Cobb]] and also features appearances by [[Jamey Johnson]] and [[Warren Haynes]].\n\nIn March 2024, the band announced drummer Brit Turner had died after a battle with [[glioblastoma]]. He was 57, and was diagnosed with the cancer in 2022.<ref>{{cite news |title=Blackberry Smoke Drummer Brit Turner Dies at 57 |url=https://therockrevival.com/rock-news/blackberry-smoke-drummer-brit-turner-dies-from-brain-cancer/ |access-date=4 March 2024 |publisher=The Rock Revival |date=4 March 2024}}</ref>\n\nOn April 5, 2024 Preston Holcomb announced via Facebook his last show would be April 27th and he would no longer be touring with the band. \n\n==Band members==\n'''Current members'''\n* Charlie Starr (Gray)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.loudersound.com/features/southern-comfort-the-unconventional-story-of-blackberry-smoke|title=Southern comfort: the unconventional story of Blackberry Smoke|work=Louder|first=Polly|last=Glass|date=July 2, 2021|access-date=January 22, 2024}}</ref> \u2013 lead vocals, guitar (2000\u2013present)\n* Richard Turner \u2013 bass, backing vocals (2000\u2013present)\n* Paul Jackson \u2013 guitar, backing vocals (2000\u2013present)\n* Brandon Still \u2013 keyboards (2009\u2013present)\n\n* Benji Shanks \u2013 guitar, mandolin, dobro (2018\u2013present)\n\n'''Touring members'''\n\n* Kent Aberle \u2013 drums, percussion (2022\u2013present)\n\n'''Former members'''\n* Brit Turner- drums (2000\u20132024) (his death)\n* Preston Holcomb \u2013 percussion (2018\u20132024)\n\n== Discography ==\n\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|+List of studio albums, with selected peak chart positions and sales\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:20em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"5\"| Peak chart positions\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:9em;\"| Sales\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Randy_Owen","to":"Randy Owen"}],"pages":{"8938611":{"pageid":8938611,"ns":0,"title":"Randy Owen","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use American English|date=October 2023}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2023}}\n{{short description|American country singer (born 1949)}}\n{{BLP sources|date=March 2011}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name                = Randy Owen\n| image               = Randy Owens cropped.jpg\n| caption             = Owen in 2013\n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          = Randy Yeuell Owen\n| alias               = \n| birth_date          = {{birth date and age|1949|12|13}}\n| birth_place         = [[Fort Payne, Alabama]], U.S.\n| origin              =\n| instrument          = Vocals, guitar\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]], [[southern rock]], [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]]\n| occupation          = Singer, songwriter\n| years_active        = 1969\u2013present\n| label               = [[RCA Records Nashville|RCA Nashville]] (in Alabama)<br />DMP/New Revolution (solo)<br />[[Broken Bow Records|Broken Bow]] (solo)\n| current_member_of = [[Alabama (band)|Alabama]]\n| website             = {{URL|randyowen.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Randy Yeuell Owen''' (born December 13, 1949) is an American [[country music|country]] musician. He is best known for his role as the lead singer of [[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]], a [[country rock]] band that saw tremendous mainstream success throughout the 1980s and 1990s. Alabama became the most successful band in country music, releasing over 20 gold and platinum records, dozens of number 1 singles, and selling over 75&nbsp;million records during their career. Owen also maintains a career as a solo performer. He released his solo debut ''[[One on One (Randy Owen album)|One on One]]'' in late 2008 and charted two singles from it.\n\nOwen was inducted into the [[Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum]] in 2019.\n\n== Biography ==\nRandy Yeuell Owen grew up on a farm near Fort Payne, Alabama. He is of [[English people|English]] and [[Scottish people|Scots]] ancestry. He dropped out of high school in the ninth grade, but he returned and graduated from Fort Payne High in 1969.\nIn the late 1960s, Owen and his cousin, Teddy Gentry, began playing music together. They recruited another cousin, Jeff Cook, to form a band, which they called Wildcountry. Their first public performance was at a high school talent show, which they won.\n\nOwen's music career was put on hiatus as he earned an English degree from [[Jacksonville State University]]. He was also a member of [[Pi Kappa Phi]], Delta Epsilon Chapter. Upon his graduation, however, the three cousins moved into an apartment in [[Anniston, Alabama]], and by 1973 were pursuing a full-time music career. In 1980, the band, now called [[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]], were signed to a recording contract by RCA Records and quickly reached country superstardom. For the next twenty-two years, Alabama had a tremendous impact on [[country music]], attracting a younger group of listeners, crossing over into pop radio, and paving the way for groups to be successful on country radio.\n\nAlabama released 21 gold, platinum, and multi-platinum albums, 42 singles that topped the charts at #1, and sold over 75 million records in total.  They have a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] and were named the [[Academy of Country Music]]'s Artist of the Decade in 1989, and the [[Recording Industry Association of America]]'s Country Group of the Century in 1999.\n\nIn May 2002, the band announced their retirement during the [[Academy of Country Music]] Awards telecast.  For the rest of 2002 and 2003, they performed throughout the country in their American Farewell Tour.  In 2005, the band was inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]].\n\nOwen lives on his cattle ranch outside Fort Payne. He currently serves as an at-large member of the Board of Trustees of [[Jacksonville State University]]. In 2007, he was a judge on Season 5 of the country talent show ''[[Nashville Star]]''.\n\nOwen took over hosting duties for ''Country Gold'', the Saturday night [[classic country]] request program on [[Westwood One (1976\u20132011)|Westwood One]], beginning July 21, 2012. The show was reformatted upon Owen's arrival, switching to a pre-recorded format (the show's predecessor, ''Country Gold Saturday Night'', was originally live; requests are handled, as they had been with Owen's immediate predecessor, by an [[answering machine]]) [[voice-tracking|voicetracked]] from Owen's home, drifting to a more open-ended \"traditional country\" format (one that includes more 1990s songs and even some 2000s songs along with country-pop tunes more commonly associated with the [[classic hits]] format while moving away from the core songs of the classic country format) and shortening the show from five hours to four. (In protest of the change of format, previous ''Country Gold'' host Rowdy Yates relaunched his version of the show as \"The Original Country Gold\" through [[Compass Media Networks]] a year later.) Owen ended his run as host on April 2, 2016, with [[Terri Clark]] replacing him the following weekend.\n\n== Discography ==\n{{See also|Alabama discography}}\n\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:10em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"3\"| Peak chart positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]<br /><ref name=\"Allmusic albums\">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p111754|pure_url=yes}}|title=allmusic ((( Randy Owen > Charts & Awards > Billboard Albums )))|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=April 4, 2010}}</ref>\n! width=\"45\"| [[Billboard 200|US]]<br /><ref name=\"Allmusic albums\" />\n! width=\"45\"| [[Independent Albums|US Indie]]<br /><ref name=\"Allmusic albums\" />\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[One on One (Randy Owen album)|One on One]]''\n|\n* Release date: November 4, 2008\n* Label: [[Broken Bow Records]]\n| 14\n| 77\n| 5\n|}\n\n=== Singles ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:20em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"60\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]<br /><ref name=\"Allmusic singles\">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p111754|pure_url=yes}}|title=allmusic ((( Randy Owen > Charts & Awards > Billboard Singles )))|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=April 4, 2010}}</ref>\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2008\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Braid My Hair\"\n| 45\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"3\"| ''One on One''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Like I Never Broke Her Heart\"\n| 41\n|-\n| 2009\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Holding Everything\" <small>(with [[Megan Mullins]])</small>\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}2022 Gaither Easter Marathon \u201cI Need Thee Every Hour\u201d featuring Randy Owen and The Issacs.\n\n== Publications ==\n*''Born Country: My Life in Alabama \u2013 How Faith, Family, and Music Brought Me Home''.  HarperOne (2008)\n\n== References ==\n{{reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n{{Commons category}}\n*[http://www.thealabamaband.com/ Alabama Official Website]\n*[https://web.archive.org/web/20070206130635/http://www.cmt.com/news/articles/1524156/02102006/alabama_1.jhtml CMT Interview]\n\n{{Westwood One}}\n{{Alabama (band)|Alabama}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Owen, Randy}}\n[[Category:1949 births]]\n[[Category:People from Fort Payne, Alabama]]\n[[Category:American people of English descent]]\n[[Category:American people of Scottish descent]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Alabama (American band) members]]\n[[Category:BBR Music Group artists]]\n[[Category:Jacksonville State University alumni]]\n[[Category:American radio personalities]]\n[[Category:Country Music Hall of Fame inductees]]\n[[Category:Members of the Country Music Association]]\n[[Category:Alabama Republicans]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Alabama]]\n[[Category:Judges in American reality television series]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Anthony_Smith_(singer)","to":"Anthony Smith (singer)"}],"pages":{"11791067":{"pageid":11791067,"ns":0,"title":"Anthony Smith (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Anthony Smith\n| image_size      =\n| birth_name      = Ralph Anthony Smith<ref>Full name per [[ASCAP]] BMI listings</ref>\n| origin          = [[Nashville, Tennessee]]\n| instrument      = Vocals, electric guitar\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter, record producer, guitarist\n| years_active    = 2002\u2013present\n| label           = [[Universal Music Group Nashville|Mercury Nashville]], Krankit Records\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{url|anthonysmith.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Ralph Anthony Smith''' is an American singer, songwriter and record producer. As a Nashville recording artist, Smith's debut album, ''[[If That Ain't Country]]'', on [[Mercury Records Nashville]] . Produced three Top 40 singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts.\nAs a songwriter Smith has had over 250 songs recorded by other Nashville recording artist Such as George Strait, Blake Shelton, Tim McGraw, Rascal Flatts, Trace Adkins, Faith Hill and more.\n\n==Biography==\nAnthony Smith was raised in eastern Tennessee<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/article.asp?xid=760 |title=If that ain't country, that ain't Anthony Smith |accessdate=August 23, 2008 |last=MacIntosh |first=Dan |date=August 2002 |work=[[Country Standard Time]]}}</ref> His musical interests began at the early age of 5. At age nine, he had joined his first band, and by age twelve he was arranging music at his church.<ref name=\"guild\">[http://www.songwritersguild.com/smith_interview.htm Smith, Writer of Hits for George Strait, Tim McGraw, Faith Hill, Trace Adkins, Montgomery Gentry, Rascal Flatts and Many More, Shares Advice With SGA Members] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070503220432/http://www.songwritersguild.com/smith_interview.htm |date=May 3, 2007 }}</ref> Smith moved to [[Kentucky]] in his early 20s and joined several bands. Luke Lewis, the boss of [[Mercury Nashville]] Records, received a demo tape of Smith's music, and signed the artist to a record deal.<ref name=\"media\">[{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p529055/biography|pure_url=yes}} allmusic ((( Anthony Smith > Biography )))]</ref> Meanwhile, Smith wrote songs for other artists, including \"[[Run (George Strait song)|Run]] and \"[[Cowboys Like Us]]\" by [[George Strait]], \"[[I'm Tryin']]\" and \"[[Chrome (Trace Adkins song)|Chrome]]\" by [[Trace Adkins]], \"Didn't I\" and \"[[What Do Ya Think About That]]\" by [[Montgomery Gentry]], and \"What Brothers Do\" by [[Confederate Railroad]].<ref name=\"media\"/> \"My Worst Fear\" for [[Rascal Flatts]] \"[[Kristofferson (song)|Kristofferson]]\" for [[Tim McGraw]] \"Chasing Down a Good Time\" by [[Randy Houser]]\n\nSmith's debut album was released on Mercury Nashville, the same year that he was granted a songwriting deal from [[Broadcast Music Incorporated|BMI]].<ref>[http://www.bmi.com/news/entry/200028 BMI.com | Anthony Smith]</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://countrymusic.about.com/cs/productreviews/gr/aaprasitac.htm |title=Anthony Smith \u2013 If That Ain't Country |access-date=June 15, 2007 |archive-date=December 8, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208062333/http://countrymusic.about.com/cs/productreviews/gr/aaprasitac.htm |url-status=dead }}</ref> The album, titled ''[[If That Ain't Country]]'', produced three Top 40 singles, of which the title track was the highest-charting. After exiting Mercury, Smith continued to write songs for other artists, including \"[[Cowboys Like Us]]\", another single release by George Strait. In 2007, two other singles that Smith co-wrote entered the country charts \"Daisy\" by [[Halfway to Hazard]], and \"[[What Do Ya Think About That]]\", another release by Montgomery Gentry. In 2008, [[Tim McGraw]] charted in the Top 20 with \"[[Kristofferson (song)|Kristofferson]]\", which Smith co-wrote with [[Reed Nielsen]]. In 2016, released the Houser single \"Chasing Down a Good Time\" which Smith co-wrote with [[Jeffrey Steele]]. Later that year, he signed to a second recording contract, this time with [[Stroudavarious Records]]. His first single for the label, \"Bringin' Back the Sunshine\", was released in July 2009, and debuted at No.&nbsp;60 on the Hot Country Songs chart. Smith also released an [[extended play]] for the label, then left in early 2010 to form his own label, Krankit Records. His first release on this label was \"Love Is Love Is Love.\"<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rodeoattitude.com/spur/countrymusic/headlines/anthony-smith-launches-ne-3827.shtml |title=Anthony Smith Launches New Label Based In Nashville |access-date=February 5, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005181343/http://www.rodeoattitude.com/spur/countrymusic/headlines/anthony-smith-launches-ne-3827.shtml |archive-date=October 5, 2011 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"2\"| Peak chart<br>positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[Top Heatseekers|US Heat]]\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[If That Ain't Country]]''\n| \n* Release date: June 25, 2002\n* Label: [[Universal Music Group Nashville|Mercury Nashville]]\n* Formats: CD\n| 26\n| 16\n|}\n\n===Extended plays===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Sunshine EP''\n| \n* Release date: September 1, 2009\n* Label: [[Stroudavarious Records]]\n* Formats: CD, [[music download]]\n|-\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:14em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"60\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2002\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[If That Ain't Country (song)|If That Ain't Country]]\"\n| 26\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"3\"| ''If That Ain't Country''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"John J. Blanchard\"\n| 40\n|-\n| 2003\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Half a Man\"\n| 40\n|-\n| 2009\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Bringin' Back the Sunshine\"\n| 60\n| align=\"left\"| ''Sunshine EP''\n|-\n| 2010\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Love Is Love Is Love\"\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| Non-album song\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Year\n! style=\"width:14em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 2002\n! scope=\"row\"| \"If That Ain't Country\"\n| Charley Randazzo\n|-\n| 2009\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Bringin' Back the Sunshine\"\n| Traci Goudie\n|-\n| 2010\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Love Is Love Is Love\"\n| [[Marcel (singer)|Marcel]]\n|-\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Smith, Anthony}}\n[[Category:American country guitarists]]\n[[Category:American male guitarists]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]\n[[Category:Singers from Nashville, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Mercury Records artists]]\n[[Category:R&J Records artists]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Indiana]]\n[[Category:People from Warsaw, Indiana]]\n[[Category:Guitarists from Indiana]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Indiana]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Tennessee]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Ray_Stevens","to":"Ray Stevens"}],"pages":{"212165":{"pageid":212165,"ns":0,"title":"Ray Stevens","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country musician (born 1939)}}\n{{About|the singer|other persons of the same name|Ray Stevens (disambiguation)}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name             = Ray Stevens\n| image            = Ray Stevens.jpg\n| caption          = Stevens on ''[[The Johnny Cash Show]]'', {{circa}} 1971\n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = Harold Ray Ragsdale\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|mf=y|1939|1|24}}\n| birth_place      = [[Clarkdale, Georgia]], U.S.\n| instruments      = {{flatlist|\n*Vocals\n*keyboards \n*trumpet}}\n| genre            = {{flatlist|\n*[[country music|Country]]\n*[[pop music|pop]]\n*[[gospel music|gospel]] \n*[[Novelty song|novelty]]\n*[[comedy music|comedy]]}}\n| occupations       = {{flatlist|\n*Singer-songwriter\n*arranger\n*comedian}}\n| years_active     = 1957\u2013present\n| label            = {{flatlist|\n*[[National Recording Corporation|NRC]]\n*[[Mercury Records|Mercury]]\n*[[Monument Records|Monument]]\n*[[Barnaby Records|Barnaby]]\n*[[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]]\n*[[RCA Records|RCA]]\n*[[MCA Nashville Records|MCA]]\n*[[Curb Records|Curb]]\n*[[Columbia Records|CBS]]\n*[[Janus Records|Janus]]}}\n| spouse = {{marriage|Penny Jackson|March 30, 1961|December 31, 2021|reason=died}}\n}}\n\n'''Harold Ray Ragsdale''' (born January 24, 1939),<ref name=\"rays-bio\">{{cite web| url=https://raystevens.com/about/| title=Ray Stevens just thinks funny| date=January 8, 2016| website=Ray Stevens| access-date = February 3, 2018}}</ref><!--<ref>[http://www.raystevens.com/bio/index.php] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090921153550/http://www.raystevens.com/bio/index.php |date=September 21, 2009 }}</ref> --> known professionally as '''Ray Stevens''', is an American [[country music|country]]<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/11/arts/music/11singleton.html| title=Shelby Singleton, Nashville Producer, Dies at 77| newspaper=[[The New York Times]]| date=October 10, 2009| first=Bill| last=Friskics-Warren| access-date=October 10, 2022| url-access=subscription}}</ref> and pop singer-songwriter and comedian.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/06/02/ray-stevens-comes-streaking-back-with-immigration-song/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0|title=Ray Stevens Comes Streaking Back With Immigration Song|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 2, 2010 |access-date=August 20, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Roy |first=Don |editor-last=Kingsbury |editor-first=Paul |date=1998 |chapter=Ray Stevens |title=The Encyclopedia of Country Music |chapter-url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopediaofco00coun/page/507/mode/1up |chapter-url-access=registration |location=New York |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0195116717 |page=507 |via=[[Internet Archive]]}}</ref> He is best known for his [[Grammy]]-winning recordings \"[[Everything Is Beautiful]]\" and \"[[Misty (song)|Misty]]\", as well as novelty hits such as \"[[Gitarzan]]\" and \"[[The Streak (song)|The Streak]]\". Stevens has received [[Music recording sales certification|gold albums]] for his music sales and has worked as a producer, music arranger, and television host. He is also an inductee of the [[Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame]], the [[Georgia Music Hall of Fame]], the Christian Music Hall of Fame, and the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum]].\n\n==Early life==\nHarold Ray Ragsdale was born on January 24, 1939, in [[Clarkdale, Georgia]].<ref name=\"rays-bio\"/> He is the elder of two sons born to Willis Harold Ragsdale (1915\u20132001) and Frances Stephens Ragsdale (1916\u20131997).<ref>{{cite web| title=Ray Stevens {{!}} Artist Bio| url=https://countrymusichalloffame.org/artist/ray-stevens/| access-date=2022-02-12| website=Country Music Hall of Fame| language=en-US}}</ref> His younger brother, John, who died in 2020 at the age of 75, became an actor and writer.<ref>{{cite web| title=Ray Stevens' Younger Brother Has \"Unexpectedly\" Died At Age 75| url=https://classiccountrymusic.com/ray-stevens-younger-brother-has-unexpectedly-died-at-age-75/| access-date=2022-02-12| website=Classic Country Music| date=2 April 2020| language=en-US}}</ref> While attending high school, Stevens formed his first band, a [[rhythm and blues]] group named The Barons. He began studying [[business administration]] at [[Georgia State University|Georgia State College]], but very quickly switched to become a music major. Stevens left after completing three of the four years required to obtain a degree, which he felt that he did not need.<ref name=\"Hieronymus\">{{cite magazine |last=Hieronymus |first=Clara |date=December 1970 |title=Ray Stevens |magazine=BMI: The Many Worlds of Music |location=New York |publisher=[[Broadcast Music, Inc.]] |page=19}}</ref><ref name=\"AMC\">{{cite book |last=Woodstra |first=Chris |title=All Music Guide to Country: The Experts' Guide to the Best Country Recordings |year=1997 |publisher=Backbeat Books |isbn=978-0-8793-0475-1 |author2=Erlewine, Steven Thomas |author3=Bogdanov, Vladamir |author4=Erlewine, Michael |page=448}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\n===Early career===\nAt age 18, Stevens signed to [[Capitol Records]]' Prep Records division in 1957,<ref name=\"AMC\"/> and produced the single \"Silver Bracelet\", with a cover of \"Rang Tang Ding Dong\" as the B-side. The single was met with a positive review from ''Billboard''.<ref>{{cite magazine| title=Reviews and Ratings| page=52| magazine=Billboard| date=January 24, 1957}}</ref> The B-side was originally recorded by doo-wop group The Cellos in 1956.<ref>{{cite book| last=Warner| first=Jay| title=American Singing Groups: A History, From 1940 to Today| year=2006| publisher=Hal Leonard| isbn=978-0-352-33533-3| page=100}}</ref>\n\nStevens signed with [[Mercury Records]] in 1961.<ref>{{cite book| last=Wadhams| first=Wayne| title=Inside the Hits: The Seduction of a Rock and Roll Generation (Pop Culture)| year=2001| publisher=Berklee Press| pages=78\u201382| isbn=978-0-6340-1430-7}}</ref>\n\n===1970s===\nIn the 1970s, Stevens became a producer and studio musician in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]]. He recorded songs for [[Barnaby Records]] and [[Warner Brothers]] during 1970\u201379. Stevens' biggest hit in the U.S. was his gospel-inflected single \"[[Everything Is Beautiful]]\" (1970). It won a [[Grammy Award]], was the theme song for his summer 1970 TV show, a number one hit on both the pop and Adult-Contemporary charts, and marked his first time in the Top 40 on the country charts, peaking at number 39. The single sold over one million copies and was awarded a [[music recording sales certification|gold disc]].<ref name=\"The Book of Golden Discs\">{{cite book| first=Joseph| last=Murrells| year=1978| title=The Book of Golden Discs| edition=2nd| publisher=Barrie and Jenkins Ltd| location=London| page=[https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/286 286]| isbn=978-0-2142-0512-5| url-access=registration| url=https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/286}}</ref>\n\nStevens had a transatlantic chart-topping hit in 1974 with \"[[The Streak (song)|The Streak]],\" a novelty song about [[streaking]] that reached number one on the American and British singles charts.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Bronson |first1=Fred |title=The Billboard Book of Number 1 Hits |date=2003 |publisher=Billboard Books |isbn=978-0-8230-7677-2 |page=365 |edition=updated and expanded 5th |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PgGqNrqfrsoC&q=%22ray+stevens%22+%22the+streak%22&pg=PT374 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref><ref name=\"British Hit Singles & Albums\">{{cite book| first=David| last=Roberts| year=2006| title=[[British Hit Singles & Albums]]| edition=19th| publisher=Guinness World Records Limited| location=London| isbn=978-1-9049-9410-7| page=301}}</ref>\n\nThrough the late 1970s and early 1980s, with some exceptions (such as \"[[Shriner's Convention (song)|Shriner's Convention]]\" in 1981), Stevens focused mostly on serious material, as he felt that the novelty song was becoming less popular in the era.<ref name=nutsoversquirrel>{{cite magazine| date=December 8, 1984| title=Stevens Nuts over 'Squirrel'| magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]| pages=39, 42| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zSQEAAAAMBAJ&q=%22mississippi+squirrel+revival%22&pg=RA1-PA39}}</ref> Stevens had an adult contemporary crossover hit in 1979 with \"[[I Need Your Help Barry Manilow]],\" a cut from Stevens's [[Barry Manilow]] tribute/parody album ''[[The Feeling's Not Right Again]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine| url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/adult-contemporary/1979-04-28| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161105210838/http://www.billboard.com/charts/adult-contemporary/1979-04-28| url-status=dead| archive-date=November 5, 2016| title=Adult Contemporary Chart| magazine=Billboard}}</ref>\n\n===1980s===\nStevens then joined MCA in 1984. Feeling that novelty songs were becoming popular again, he authorized the rush release of \"[[Mississippi Squirrel Revival]]\" in 1984, which reached the country top 20.<ref name=nutsoversquirrel/> In 1985, Stevens performed at the [[Lanierland Music Park]] in Georgia with Pinkard & Bowden.<ref name=\"Inc.1985\">{{cite magazine| title=Box Score Top Grossing Concerts| magazine=Billboard| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4yQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT48| date=June 1, 1985| page=48| issn=0006-2510}}</ref>\n\n===21st century===\nIn February 2002, following the [[September 11 attacks]], Stevens released ''[[Osama\u2014Yo' Mama: The Album]]'' after the title track, which was released as a single in late 2001, peaked at #48 on the [[Hot Country Songs]] chart in 2001. The album reached #29 on the US Top Country Albums chart.\n\nIn April 2010, Stevens released ''We the People'', a CD/DVD of political songs. This album reached Top-5 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Comedy Album chart.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/ray-stevens/biography/| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130223091419/http://www.cmt.com/artists/ray-stevens/biography| url-status=dead| archive-date=February 23, 2013| title=Ray Stevens Bio: Ray Stevens Career| website=CMT Artists| access-date=April 12, 2017| language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://shop.raystevens.com/we-the-people-cd| title=We The People CD| website=Ray Stevens| access-date=April 12, 2017}}</ref>\n\n''RAY-ality TV'' ended its digital TV run in January 2014. Two months later, a [[webisode]] series, also titled ''Rayality TV'' was launched. Later in 2014, Stevens co-starred in the movie ''Campin' Buddies''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10152378293854871&set=a.10150358709939871.369677.99557674870&type=1&theater |title=Ray Stevens \u2013 Timeline Photos |website=Facebook |access-date=August 20, 2014}}</ref>\n\nStevens published his autobiographical memoir ''Ray Stevens' Nashville'' in 2014.<ref>{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LSOsoAEACAAJ| title=Ray Stevens' Nashville| first1=Ray| last1=Stevens| first2=C. W. Buddy| last2=Kalb| date=March 1, 2014| publisher=Harold R.Ragsdale A/K/A Ray Stevens| isbn=978-0-6159-9308-9| access-date=October 27, 2017| via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine| url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/ray-stevens-nashville-details-comic-performers-versatile-career-95889/| title=''Ray Stevens' Nashville'' Details Comic Performer's Versatile Career: Comedic country legend writes memoir of good old days in Music City| author=Betts, Stephen L.| access-date=June 20, 2014| date=June 20, 2014| magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]}}</ref>\n\nIn 2015, Stevens began producing and hosting ''Ray Stevens Nashville'', a 30-minute weekly music variety show on cable TV. Since then, the show has been rebranded as ''Ray Stevens CabaRay Nashville'' and is now filmed on stage at his own CabaRay Showroom, which opened to the public in early 2018. The show currently airs on PBS public television stations around the country.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://raystevenscabaray.com/about/ray/ | title=Ray Stevens' Live Music in Nashville - Nashville Attractions & Events This Weekend | newspaper=Ray Stevens Cabaray }}</ref>\n\nStevens released the album ''Here We Go Again'' on March 24, 2015, which includes the [[Taylor Swift]] spoof single \"Taylor Swift is Stalking Me\"<ref>Billboard, March 24, 2015 \u2013 [https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/6509612/ray-stevens-interview-taylor-swift-is-stalkin-me-video Ray Stevens Returns With 'Taylor Swift Is Stalkin' Me' \u2013 By Chuck Dauphin]</ref> and \"Come to the USA\".<ref>{{cite magazine| magazine=Billboard| date=March 24, 2015| url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/957953/ray-stevens-has-youtube-hit-with-pro-arizona-song| title=Ray Stevens Has YouTube Hit With Pro-Arizona Song| first=Chuck| last=Dauphin| access-date=October 10, 2022}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nStevens was married to Penny Jackson Ragsdale for over 60 years, until her death on December 31, 2021, after a lengthy battle with cancer. Two days prior, he had canceled his New Year's Eve concert at CabaRay, due to Penny's rapidly declining health. They had two daughters, [[Suzi Ragsdale|Suzi]] and Timi, and four grandchildren.<ref>{{cite web |last=Dukes |first=Billy |title=Ray Stevens' Wife Penny Has Died |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/ray-stevens-wife-penny-dead-dies/ |website=Taste of Country |date=January 2022 |access-date=January 1, 2022}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Ray Stevens discography}}\n\n==Accolades==\n===Grammy awards===\n{| class=\"wikitable sortable\"\n|-\n! first=Larry| last=McShane| newspaper=[[The Telegraph (Nashua)|The Telegraph]]| location=Nashua, NH| agency=[[Associated Press]]| page=35}}</ref>\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External
