Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Bo_Bice","to":"Bo Bice"}],"pages":{"1589371":{"pageid":1589371,"ns":0,"title":"Bo Bice","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer and musician}}\n{{Distinguish|Bo Bruce}}\n{{BLP sources| date=May 2011}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2023}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Bo Bice\n| image           = Bo Bice.jpg\n| caption         = Bo Bice in [[The American Idol Experience]] motorcade at [[Walt Disney World]].\n| birth_name      = Harold Elwin Bice Jr.\n| birth_date      = {{Birth date and age|1975|11|1}}\n| birth_place     = [[Huntsville, Alabama]], U.S.\n| origin          = [[Helena, Alabama]], U.S.\n| website         = \n| occupation      = {{hlist|Singer|musician}}\n| years_active    = 1994\u2013present\n| instrument      = {{hlist|[[Acoustic guitar]]|[[electric guitar]]|[[lap steel guitar]]|[[mandolin]]|[[harmonica]]|[[piano]]|[[saxophone]]|[[Singing|vocals]]}}\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Southern rock]]|[[hard rock]]|[[country rock]]}}\n| label           = {{hlist|[[RCA Records|RCA]]|Sugarmoney|Saguaro Road|[[Lofton Creek Records|Lofton Creek]]}}\n| past_member_of  = {{hlist|SugarMoney|[[Blood, Sweat & Tears]]}}\n}}\n\n'''Harold Elwin''' \"'''Bo'''\" '''Bice Jr.''' (born November 1, 1975) is an American singer and musician who was the runner-up against [[Carrie Underwood]] in the [[American Idol (season 4)|fourth season]] of ''[[American Idol]]''. Prior to auditioning for ''American Idol'', Bice released a solo album as well as a few albums with his bands while performing on the night club circuit.\n\nBice charted in 2005 at number two on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] with a rendition of \"[[Inside Your Heaven]]\" from ''American Idol''. He released the album ''[[The Real Thing (Bo Bice album)|The Real Thing]]'' after ''American Idol'' to minor success before being dropped by RCA Records. He started his own record label Sugar Money and subsequently released two more albums, ''[[See the Light (Bo Bice album)|See the Light]]'' and ''[[3 (Bo Bice album)|3]].'' He was also the lead singer of [[Blood, Sweat & Tears]] from 2013 until 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bloodsweatandtears.com/ |title=Blood Sweat & Tears official web site |access-date=2014-10-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006092029/http://www.bloodsweatandtears.com/ |archive-date=2014-10-06 |url-status=live}}</ref>\n\n== Childhood ==\nBice was born in [[Huntsville, Alabama]] to Nancy and Harold Elwin Bice. His mother was a gospel singer as were his grandmother, great-grandmother, and aunts. Bice was [[nickname]]d \"Bogart\" as a newborn by his grandmother, \"Granny Madge\", because she thought he had \"[[Humphrey Bogart]] eyes\". His family continued to call him Bogart, but when Bice was in kindergarten he shortened it to \"Bo\" because he did not think Bogart was cool. Bice's parents divorced when he was very young, and his mother remarried years later. Bice grew up with his mother and step-father, Earle Downes, a Coca-Cola manager, step-sisters Jenny and Sharan Downes, and half-brother John Cohran. Bice has two other half-siblings, Candace and Matthew, on his biological father's side. The Downes family moved around the [[Southern United States|South]] frequently. They lived in [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[Alabama]], and [[Florida]], including the metro area of [[Atlanta]]. In 1990 when Bice was 14 years old they moved to England, as part of his step-father's European assignment with [[Coca-Cola]] in London.\n\nBice spent his teenage years living in [[Gerrards Cross]]. Bice attended [[London Central High School]], a [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] school primarily for children whose parents served in the military or worked at the U.S. Embassy. In high school, he carried his [[guitar]] everywhere and played [[American football|football]]. It was around this time when Bice worked with some English [[alternative rock]] musicians.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} He formed his first band, Spinning Jenny, while living there. Bice would have graduated in 1994, but in the fall of 1993, Bice dropped out of high school just before turning 18 to move back to Alabama, where he earned his [[GED]] and attended classes at [[Calhoun Community College]] from November 1996 to May 1997.\n\n== Career==\n===Career beginnings and ''American Idol'': 1997\u20132005===\nUpon leaving Calhoun and spending one semester at the [[University of North Alabama]] in [[Florence, Alabama|Florence]], Bice turned professional and performed in shows all across the United States, the United Kingdom, [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], and Europe. He was a veteran of the [[nightclub]] circuit, releasing his first CD in 1995 with his band Purge.<ref>{{cite web |last=Ortega |first=Shawna |url=http://www.songfacts.com/int/2008/08/bo-bice.html |title=Bo Bice: Songwriter Interviews |publisher=Songfacts |date=2008-07-23 |access-date=October 5, 2008 |archive-date=October 18, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091018125127/http://www.songfacts.com/int/2008/08/bo-bice.html |url-status=dead }}</ref> His other pre-''Idol'' bands include Blue Suede Nickel and [[Sugar Money (band)|SugarMoney]]. Among his credits were opening for [[Blackfoot (band)|Blackfoot]] and [[Warrant (American band)|Warrant]] as well as performing live and recording with [[Johnny Neel]], formerly of [[The Allman Brothers Band]]. Bice had recorded other albums prior to his stint on ''American Idol'', which included ''Ex Gratia'' (1999) with his band Purge, and ''Recipe for Flavor'' (2000) with SugarMoney. In 2001, Bice was charged with purchasing [[cocaine]] at a [[strip club]]. In 2003, Bice was arrested for possession of [[Cannabis (drug)|marijuana]], [[drug paraphernalia]] and [[public intoxication]]. He avoided jail time by agreeing to enter a [[drug rehabilitation|drug program]].<ref>[https://archive.today/20120906201505/http://www.popcrunch.com/busted-100-celebrities-arrested-for-drug-possession/Busted! 100 Celebrities Arrested For Drug Possession] from PopCrunch.com</ref><ref>[http://www.thesmokinggun.com/archive/0427051_bo_bice_american_idol_1.html \"Idol\" Finalist Dodged Cocaine, Pot Raps] from ''[[The Smoking Gun]]''</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1500954/20050428/id_0.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080502050128/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1500954/20050428/id_0.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=May 2, 2008 |title='Idol' Singer Bo Bice Has Drug Rap Sheet, Court Papers Show |publisher=MTV News}}</ref>\n\nFor the 2005 season, ''Idol'' producers raised their required age limit from 16\u201324 to 16\u201328. In August 2004, Bice\u2019s mother and several other family members encouraged him to go try out, since he was within the eligible age limit (he would turn 29 in November 2004). Along with [[Constantine Maroulis]] and [[Taylor Hicks]] (winner of Season 5), Bice was one of the oldest contestants to audition and participate on ''American Idol''. Bice and Maroulis were among the first contestants to compete using the [[Rock music|rock]] idiom.<ref name=\"Kaufman\">{{Cite web |last=Kaufman |first=Gil |title='American Idol' Vets Bo Bice, Constantine Maroulis Can't Stop Rockin' |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1560421/20070524/bice__bo.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070528063956/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1560421/20070524/bice__bo.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=May 28, 2007 |access-date=2016-05-17 |publisher=MTV }}</ref> His performance in the audition stage of The Allman Brothers Band's song \"[[Whipping Post (song)|Whipping Post]]\" drew raves from the judges. His later performances established him as one of the favorites in the competition. During the final three performance show, Bice took the risk of performing without a band or backup singers. He sang \"In a Dream\", an obscure song recorded by [[Badlands (American band)|Badlands]].\n\nIn June 2005, Bice was quoted in ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine that his last thought during the ''Idol'' finale was, \"Please, God, don't let me win this thing.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2002&dat=20050616&id=7L8iAAAAIBAJ&sjid=E7YFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5114,4458921 |title=Bice: 'Please, God, Don't Let Me Win This Thing.' |work=Beaver County Times |date=2005-06-15 |via=Google News Archive Search}}</ref> In comments during a subsequent appearance on ''[[Today (NBC program)|The Today Show]]'', Bice backed off this stance a bit, saying that he thanked all those who had voted for him. He lost the final, ending up runner-up to [[Carrie Underwood]]. In Alabama, May 24 was declared \"Bo Bice Day\" by Governor [[Bob Riley (Alabama)|Bob Riley]]. Two members of the group [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]] surprised Bice during his trip home from ''Idol'' and performed \"[[Sweet Home Alabama]]\" with him in his home town of [[Helena, Alabama]].\n\n;Idol performances\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n!Week\n!Theme\n!Song\n!Original artist\n!Result\n|-\n|rowspan=\"2\"| Auditions\n| Contestant's Choice\n| \"In a Dream\"\n| [[Badlands (American 6\n| 21st Century\n| \"[[I Don't Want to Be]]\"\n| [[Gavin DeGraw]]\n| Safe\n|-\n| Top 5\n| [[Leiber & Stoller]]<br />Current Billboard Chart\n| \"[[Stand by Me (Ben E. King song)|Stand by Me]]\"<br />\"[[Heaven (Los Lonely Boys song)|Heaven]]\"\n| [[Ben E. King]]<br />[[Los Lonely Boys]]\n| Safe\n|-\n| Top 4\n| Country<br />Gamble & Huff\n| \"[[It's a Great Day to Be Alive]]\"<br />\"[[For the Love of Money]]\"\n| [[Jon Randall]]<br />[[The O'Jays]]\n| Safe\n|-\n| Top 3\n| Clive Davis' Choice<br />Judge's Choice<br />Contestant's Choice\n| \"[[Don't Let the Sun Go Down on Me]]\"<br />\"[[(I Can't Get No) Satisfaction]]\"<br />\"In a Dream\"\n| [[Elton John]]<br />[[The Rolling Stones]]<br />Badlands\n| Safe\n|-\n| Finale\n| Idol Single<br />Contestant's Choice<br />Contestant's Choice\n| \"[[Inside Your Heaven]]\"<br />\"Long Long Road\"<br />\"Vehicle\"\n | [[Carrie Underwood]]/Bo Bice<br />Christian Leuzzi<br />The Ides of March\n| Runner Up\n|}\n\n===Post-''Idol'', marriage and fatherhood: 2005===\nSigned to [[RCA]] Records, Bice's first single, released June 21, 2005, was his version of \"[[Inside Your Heaven]]\". The single debuted at number two on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 Chart and number one on the ''Billboard'' Hot Single Sales chart. Bice's single replaced [[Carrie Underwood]]'s version of the same song at number one. It was [[Gold certification|certified Gold]] in late July 2005. Bice was invited to the [[Bonnaroo Music Festival]] by [[Trey Anastasio]]. He sang a song with [[Willie Nelson]] at a Birmingham concert and was invited by Nelson to perform at [[Farm Aid]]. Bice appeared on [[Carlos Santana]]'s 2005 album ''[[All That I Am (Santana album)|All That I Am]]'' with the song \"Brown Skin Girl\". On June 15, 2005, Bice married long-time girlfriend Caroline Fisher in [[Helena, Alabama]]. Bice had met her when he was working as a guitar store manager, and frequented the Ragtime Cafe in [[Hoover, Alabama]] where she was working her way through college as a waitress. Their first child, a son, was born in September 2005.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2005-06-30-bice-marries_x.htm |work=USA Today |title='American Idol' runner-up Bo Bice marries |date=2005-06-30}}</ref> A second son was born in August 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.usmagazine.com/american-idol-bo-bice-and-wife-welcome-baby-boy |title=EXCLUSIVE: American Idol Runner-Up Bo Bice & Wife Welcome Baby Boy |date=2008-08-05 |work=Us Magazine |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080903094459/http://www.usmagazine.com/american-idol-bo-bice-and-wife-welcome-baby-boy |archive-date=2008-09-03}}</ref> A third son was born in January 2010 this was Ean Bice.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://people.com/parents/bo-bice-welcomes-son-ean-jacob/amp/ |title=Bo Bice Welcomes Son Ean Jacob |date=2010-01-22 |work=People |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100130012523/http://celebrity-babies.com/2010/01/22/bo-bice-welcomes-son-ean-jacob/ |archive-date=2010-01-30 |access-date=2020-02-25}}</ref>  Their fourth child and first daughter was born in April 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/bo-bice-baby-girl/ |title=Bo Bice Welcomes Baby Girl |date=24 April 2012 |work=Taste of Country}}</ref> They reside in [[Covington, Georgia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://gocovington.com/Newsroom/newton-countys-newest-resident-bo-bice |title=Newton County's Newest Resident- Bo Bice |publisher=Covington-Newton County Chamber of Commerce |access-date=May 10, 2016 |archive-date=June 4, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604092628/http://gocovington.com/Newsroom/newton-countys-newest-resident-bo-bice |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nOn July 31, 2005, Bice broke his foot while performing in concert in [[Manchester, New Hampshire]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.today.com/popculture/bo-bice-busts-his-foot-onstage-wbna8790926 |title=Bo Bice busts his foot onstage |work=TODAY.com|date=August 2005 }}</ref> but carried on with the tour. On August 18, Bice, who had been suffering from stomach pain for months, was rushed to the hospital for emergency intestinal surgery to remove a blockage caused by a life-threatening intestinal condition called [[intussusception (medical disorder)|intussusception]]. He was sidelined from the tour for several shows. During his absence from the tour, fellow contestants Anwar, Nikko, Scott, Anthony and Constantine paid tribute to Bice by singing \"[[Sweet Home Alabama (song)|Sweet Home Alabama]]\" and wearing Bo Bice T-shirts.<ref>[http://www.foxesonidol.com/cgi-bin/ae.pl?mode=1&article=article1763.art&page=1 foxes on idol] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051016204318/http://www.foxesonidol.com/cgi-bin/ae.pl?mode=1&article=article1763.art&page=1 |date=October 16, 2005 }}</ref> Bice returned to the tour for the final two concerts in [[Syracuse, New York]], September 10 and September 11 (a [[benefit concert]] with proceeds going to the [[American Red Cross]] to help victims of [[Hurricane Katrina]]). In addition to playing that concert, he opened his home in Helena, Alabama to a family displaced by Hurricane Katrina.\n\nOn October 7, 2005, Bice introduced his own band, SugarMoney, in [[Mobile, Alabama]] at [[Bayfest (Mobile)|Bayfest]]. He performed two concerts the following week, including a benefit concert for the victims of Hurricane Katrina, but was back in the hospital the next day with surgery complications. In November Bice was named \"Heartland Hero of the Week\" on [[John Kasich]]'s show, ''[[Heartland with John Kasich|Heartland]]'', for giving up his house to the family displaced by Hurricane Katrina and for using his music to raise money for victims of Hurricane Katrina. [[Jim Croce]]'s family awarded Bice the \"Jim Croce 20th Annual Music Award\" because the Croce family had been greatly moved by Bice's performance of Croce's song \"Time in a Bottle\" while he was a contestant on ''American Idol''.\n\n===''The Real Thing'' and recurring medical problems: 2005\u20132006===\nBice's solo debut album, ''[[The Real Thing (Bo Bice album)|The Real Thing]]'', was released on December 13, 2005. It opened at number four. ''The Real Thing'' has the seventh-highest opening for a debut album by an ''American Idol'' finalist. Bice's band at the time appears with him on three tracks on ''The Real Thing'''s DualDisc version. In January 2006, [[Country Music Television|CMT]] aired an hour-long TV special\u2014called ''Bo Bice: In the Moment''\u2014which chronicled Bice's life post-Idol during the recording of his album, ''The Real Thing''. Their cameras had followed Bice around for months during the making of his album. The film showed both his joy with making an album and his frustration with recording other people's pop songs. The cameras also captured the birth of his son, Aidan. On December 18, Bice started [[coughing up blood]] while rehearsing for a performance on the 2005 [[Radio Music Awards]], and had to miss the show.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/Entertainment/2005/12/19/bo_bice_out_of_radio_music_awards/7382/ |title=Top News, Latest headlines, Latest News, World News & U.S News |work=United Press International |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090124151135/http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/Entertainment/2005/12/19/bo_bice_out_of_radio_music_awards/7382/ |archive-date=2009-01-24}}</ref>\n\nIn February 2006, Bice kicked off a radio promo tour. During the ensuing year of promotional appearances and touring, Bice continued to suffer with the recurring intestinal condition which had not been repaired by the August 2005 surgery. In the span of just a few months during his various tours, Bice was hospitalized 20 times, checking out of the hospitals each time to honor his performance commitments. In March 2006, Bice sang on the ''American Idol'' Top 16 Results Show. In April 2006, Bice was one of the celebrity drivers featured in the [[Toyota Pro/Celebrity Race]] held in [[Long Beach, California]], that was sponsored by [[Toyota]] to benefit various children's hospitals of Southern California. On September 12, 2006, Bice released a cover of [[The Chambers Brothers]] 1968 smash hit, \"[[Time Has Come Today]]\", which was the theme song for a new [[Monopoly (game)|Monopoly]] commercial. In September 2006, Bice was a special guest star in a TV special called ''Decades Rock Live: Lynyrd Skynyrd & Friends''\u2014the friends being Bice, [[Hank Williams Jr.]], and [[3 Doors Down]].\n\nOn October 5, 2006, Bice underwent emergency surgery in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] to correct his recurring intestinal problem. The surgery came after several rounds of tests and doctors deemed his condition serious enough to operate immediately. The day after that surgery, a complication occurred and Bice had to undergo another surgery. During the subsequent recovery time, [[Ben Stiller]] invited Bice to record for the [[Will Ferrell]] film ''[[Blades of Glory]]'' produced by Stiller. Bice made several promotional appearances in connection with the releases. Bice was presented with a [[Music recording sales certification|gold record]] for ''The Real Thing'' not long after [[RCA]] dropped Bice from its roster.\n\n=== Sugar Money Records, ''See The Light'' and ''3'': 2007\u20132013 ===\nIn the spring and summer of 2006, Bice began to talk of his hopes for a second CD, saying that \"[he]'d like to go more rootsy, more country, more southern rock Bo.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.semissourian.com/story/1167395.html |title=seMissourian.com: Entertainment: Banking on Bo (09/08/06) |work=seMissourian.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061017223120/http://www.semissourian.com/story/1167395.html |archive-date=2006-10-17}}</ref> Bice encouraged his fans to start a petition asking [[Clive Davis]] for Bo's original southern rock songs on a subsequent CD. The Grassroots Coalition to Hear More Bo started the online Petition to Hear More Bo, which collected over 5,300 signatures before it was closed February 21, 2007, after word broke that Bice was no longer with RCA. Bice subsequently formed his own record label called Sugar Money/StratArt (in partnership with [[Strategic Artist Management]]). He spent the next few months planning, writing, and recording music for his new album, ''[[See the Light (Bo Bice album)|See the Light]]''. Bice introduced many of his newly written songs on a short acoustic tour which began in May 2007 and ended a few weeks later with his hospitalization for flu and bronchitis. ''[[See the Light (Bo Bice album)|See the Light]]'' was released October 23, 2007.\n\n[[File:Bo Bice Share the Beat Atlanta 2008.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Bice in September 2008]]\nIn October 2007, Bice made an appearance on the TV show ''[[American Chopper|American Chopper: The Series]]'' in an episode which featured a custom-built Peavey Bike with a built-in guitar, microphone, and amp. [[Peavey Electronics|Peavey Electronics Corporation]] and Bice were working together to develop a Bo Bice guitar for their line of products. Bice had made appearances in Peavey Electronics Corporation's after school programs (in conjunction with National Afterschool Alliance) during which Peavey donated instruments to schools. In February 2008, Bice traveled to [[Kuwait]] and [[Afghanistan]] to perform for U.S. troops deployed in the region, and to thank them for their service. He went back to the war region in Fall 2008. During Spring and Summer 2008, Bice continued his tour promoting his ''See the Light'' album. He simultaneously spent a few weeks participating in a special tour called ''It Was Forty Years Ago Today'' with [[Todd Rundgren]], [[Denny Laine]], [[Lou Gramm]], and [[Christopher Cross]]. The tour paid tribute to the fortieth anniversary of the release of the [[Beatles]]' ''[[Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band|Sgt. Pepper\u2019s Lonely Hearts Club Band]]''.\n\nOn September 13, Bice participated in \"Share the Beat\", a benefit for the Georgia Transplant Foundation and the James Redford Institute for Transplant Awareness. Bice sang two tracks on the ''Brothers of the Southland'' CD,<ref>[http://www.southernfriedmagazine.com/magazine/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=185&mode=thread&order=0&thold=0 Southern Fried Magazine'' August 1, 2007]</ref> a compilation spearheaded by [[The Marshall Tucker Band]]'s [[George McCorkle]] who had died from cancer just days prior to the recording sessions. On December 2, Bice was invited to Washington to perform for President Bush. Throughout 2009, Bice continued touring to support ''See the Light''. Bice did tour dates with Lynyrd Skynyrd. Bice was honored with the prestigious Lifetime Presidential Volunteer Service Award for volunteering more than 4,000 hours of his time for worthy causes, such as [[Habitat for Humanity]], Katrina assistance, [[muscular dystrophy]], organ transplants, two concert tours for the military troops in Iraq, Kuwait, and Afghanistan, Safe House, and many others. In addition to the hours for which he received recognition, he has donated instruments, music equipment, meaningful personal memorabilia, and some of his own paintings to be auctioned off for charities.\n\nBice started 2010 with an acoustic tour to introduce some newly written songs that he was recording for his upcoming album.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} Bice's Sugar Money record label cooperated with [[Time Life]] for the album which was called ''3'', which was officially released on [[Saguaro Road Records]] on May 18, 2010.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} On October 12, 2010, Bice guest-starred on the syndicated game show ''[[Don't Forget the Lyrics!]]'' and won the $50,000 grand prize for his charity, [[MusiCares]]. Bice was the first celebrity contestant to win the grand prize by correctly singing the lyrics to all the songs in his round.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.al.com/mcolurso/2010/10/taylor_hicks_bo_bice_on_dont_f.html |title=Bo Bice, Taylor Hicks to appear on 'Don't Forget the Lyrics' (with videos) |work=AL.com|date=October 12, 2010 }}</ref>\n\nIn 2013, Bice sang \"[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]\" at the [[NASCAR]] [[Feed the Children 300]] in [[Sparta, Kentucky]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}}\n\n== Discography ==\n\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"3\"| Peak chart<br />positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| [[Music recording sales certification|Certifications]]<br /><small>([[List of best selling music artists|sales threshold]])</small>\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! style=\"width:30px;\"| [[Billboard 200|US]]<br /><ref>{{cite magazine |url={{BillboardURLbyName |artist=bo bice |chart=Billboard 200}}|title=Bo Bice Album & Song Chart History: Billboard 200|magazine=Billboard|access-date=2010-08-01}}</ref>\n! style=\"width:30px;\"| [[Independent Albums|US Indie]]<br /><ref>{{cite magazine |url={{BillboardURLbyName |artist=bo bice |chart=Independent Albums}}|title=Bo Bice Album & Song Chart History: Independent Albums|magazine=Billboard|access-date=2010-08-01}}</ref>\n! style=\"width:30px;\"| [[Canadian Albums Chart|CAN]]<br /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Charts/ALBUMS.html |archive-url=https://archive.today/20041226005640/http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Charts/ALBUMS.html |archive-date=2004-12-26 |url-status=usurped |title=CANOE -- JAM! Chatter 09-22-2010\">{{cite web |url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/idolchatter/post/2010/09/idol-album-sales-fantasia-sells-best-chris-sligh-josiah-leming-debut/1 |title='Idol' album sales: Fantasia sells best; Chris Sligh, Josiah Leming debut |work=USA Today}}</ref>\n|-\n| colspan=\"6\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|}\n\n=== Singles ===\n{| class=\"wikitable\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Single\n! colspan=\"4\"| Peak chart positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| [[Music recording sales Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Lacs","to":"The Lacs"}],"pages":{"36380015":{"pageid":36380015,"ns":0,"title":"The Lacs","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American hip hop group}}\n{{Use American English|date=January 2023}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2023}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = The LACs\n| origin           = [[Baxley, Georgia]], United States\n| genre            = [[Country rap]]\n| years_active     = 2002\u2013present\n| label            = {{hlist|Side Ya Mouth|[[Average Joes Entertainment|Backroad Records]]|Dirt Rock Empire}}\n| current_members  = Brian Andrew \"Rooster\" King<Br />Robert Clayton \"Uncle Snap\" Sharpe<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ascap.com/repertory#/ace/search/workID/898010045 |title=DEAD MAN WALKING |website=ASCAP |publisher=American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers |access-date=April 27, 2023}}</ref> <Br />\n| past_members   = Dennis Morgan\n}}\n'''The Lacs''' is an American [[country rap]] duo that consists of Robert Clayton (Clay) \"Uncle Snap\" Sharpe and Brian Andrew \"Rooster\" King.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/5679824/the-lacs-score-career-best-rank-on-top-country-albums|title=The Lacs' Score Career-Best Rank On Top Country Albums|magazine=Billboard|access-date=May 3, 2016}}</ref> At first, the group also featured Brandon Herndon on the three self-released albums on Side Ya Mouth Records.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.showcaseyourmusic.com/LACS|title=SYM \u2013 LACS|website=Showcase Your Music|access-date=May 3, 2016}}</ref>\n\nThe Lacs have recorded six albums for Backroad Records, a subsidiary of [[Average Joes Entertainment]], an independent label co-owned by fellow country rap artist [[Colt Ford]]. Four albums have entered the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]: ''Keep it Redneck'' (2013), ''Outlaw in Me'' and ''American Rebelution'' (2017).\n\nThe Lacs created their own record label ''Dirt Rock Empire''<ref name=\"dirtrocksite\">{{cite web |url=http://www.dirtrockempire.com/ |title=DirtRockEmpire.com |work=DirRockEmpire }}</ref> in 2017. On September 22, 2017, The Lacs released the first album from Dirt Rock titled ''Dirtbagz, Vol. 1'' which is a compilation album featuring many of the labels artists such as Nate Kenyon, Crucifix and Hard Target.\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Tyler_Dickerson","to":"Tyler Dickerson"}],"pages":{"26415275":{"pageid":26415275,"ns":0,"title":"Tyler Dickerson","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- For individuals; see Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name                = Tyler Dickerson\n| image               = \n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          = \n| birth_date          = {{birth year and age|1993}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.gactv.com/blog/2009/12/14/tyler-dickerson-a-potential-counterpunch-to-commercial-country/|title=Tyler Dickerson: A Potential Counterpunch to Commercial Country|last=Roland|first=Tom|date=14 December 2009|work=[[Great American Country]]|access-date=3 March 2010}}</ref>\n| birth_place         = [[Hattiesburg, Mississippi]], U.S.<ref name=\"cst\"/>\n| origin              = \n| instrument          = Vocals\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation          = Singer\n| years_active        = early 2000s-present\n| label               = [[Lyric Street Records|Lyric Street]]\n| associated_acts     = Rockin Rouge\n}}\n\n'''Tyler Dickerson''' (born 1993 in [[Hattiesburg, Mississippi]]) is an American [[country music]] artist signed to [[Lyric Street Records]]. He released his debut [[single (music)|single]], \"Tell Your Sister I'm Single,\" to radio in early 2010.\n\n==Biography==\nTyler Dickerson was born in [[Hattiesburg, Mississippi]] to Steven and Crystal Dickerson. He began performing at an early age, and by eleven he had started performing at venues in [[Florida]]. In 2005, he won Florida Male Vocalist and Male Entertainer of the Year awards for his age group.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=888&dat=20051109&id=TrsNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hnIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4016,4609483|title=A real crowd-pleaser: Eleven-year-old Tyler Dickerson is on his way to becoming a star in the country music industry|last=Miller|first=Michelle|date=9 November 2005|work=Pasco Times|pages=3|access-date=3 March 2010}}</ref> He had also become a regular performer at [[Tootsie's Orchid Lounge]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref name=\"cst\">{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem2.asp?xid=3792|title=Tyler Dickerson releases debut single|date=14 February 2010|work=[[Country Standard Time]]|access-date=3 March 2010}}</ref>\n\nDickerson signed to a recording contract with [[Lyric Street Records]] in late 2009 after entering a talent search associated with [[John Rich]] of [[Big & Rich]],<ref name=\"cst\"/> who also mentored him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://communities.canada.com/REGINALEADERPOST/blogs/ploughboymansion/archive/2010/03/01/tyler-dickerson-s-career-is-on-the-move.aspx|title=Tyler Dickerson's career is on the move|last=Dedekker|first=Jeff|date=1 March 2010|work=The Leader-Post|access-date=3 March 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120714091748/http://communities.canada.com/REGINALEADERPOST/blogs/ploughboymansion/archive/2010/03/01/tyler-dickerson-s-career-is-on-the-move.aspx|archive-date=14 July 2012}}</ref> He released his first [[single (music)|single]], \"Tell Your Sister I'm Single,\" in February 2010.<ref name=\"cst\"/> The song is written by Amanda Williams, Trevor Rosen, and Isaac Rich (brother of John Rich).  Dickerson also signed on as an opening act for [[Brooks & Dunn]]'s Last Rodeo Tour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theboot.com/2010/02/26/tyler-dickerson-tour/|title=Tyler Dickerson to Join Brooks & Dunn's Last Rodeo Tour|last=Conaway|first=Alanna|date=26 February 2010|work=The Boot|access-date=3 March 2010}}</ref> Bobby Peacock of Roughstock gave the song a positive review, saying that Dickerson \"clearly plays the premise for laughs.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/tyler-dickerson-tell-your-sister-i-m-single-|title=Tyler Dickerson \u2014 \"Tell Your Sister I'm Single\"|last=Peacock|first=Bobby|date=29 January 2010|work=Roughstock|access-date=3 March 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100202160351/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/tyler-dickerson-tell-your-sister-i-m-single-|archive-date=2 February 2010}}</ref> \"Tell Your Sister I'm Single\" debuted at number 51 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts dated for the week ending March 13, 2010.\n\nDickerson now sings in the Louisiana-based band Rockin Rouge.\n\nDickerson auditioned for ''[[The Voice (U.S. season 9)|The Voice]]'' on September 28, 2015. He performed \"[[Hard to Handle (song)|Hard to Handle]],\" and was chosen by [[Blake Shelton]] (the only one who turned his chair) to be on his team. He was eliminated from the show in the top 48, after losing to Zach Seabaugh on a performance of [[Travis Tritt]]'s \"[[I'm Gonna Be Somebody]].\"\n\n{| class=\"wikitable\" style=\"text-align:center; font-size:90%; line-height:16px;\"\n|-\n! scope=\"col\" | Stage\n! scope=\"col\" | Song\n! scope=\"col\" | Original Artist\n! scope=\"col\" | Date\n! scope=\"col\" | Order\n! scope=\"col\" | Result\n|-\n! scope=\"row\" | Blind Audition\n| \"[[Hard to Handle (song)|Hard to Handle]]\"\n| [[Otis Redding]]\n| September 28, 2015\n| 3.13\n| [[Blake Shelton]] turned<br>Defaulted to Team Blake\n|-\n! scope=\"row\" | The Battles (Top 48)\n| \"[[I'm Gonna Be Somebody]]\" <small>(vs. Zach Seabaugh)</small>\n| [[Travis Tritt]]\n| October 12, 2015\n| 7.2\n| Defeated\n|}  \n<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://rockinrouge.com/|title=Rockin' Rouge' Rockin, Your Good Times Band|website=rockinrouge.com|access-date=2019-05-15}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:14em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"50\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n|-\n| 2010\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Tell Your Sister I'm Single\"\n| 47\n|-\n| colspan=\"10\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart \n|-\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n{{The Voice (U.S.)}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Dickerson, Tyler}}\n[[Category:1993 births]]\n[[Category:American child singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Lyric Street Records artists]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Mississippi]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Hattiesburg, Mississippi]]\n[[Category:Date of birth missing (living people)]]\n[[Category:The Voice (franchise) contestants]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Mississippi]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Drew_Davis_Band","to":"Drew Davis Band"}],"pages":{"15439501":{"pageid":15439501,"ns":0,"title":"Drew Davis Band","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American musical group}}\n{{use American English|date=September 2024}}\n{{use mdy|date=September 2024}}\n{{one source|date=April 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Drew Davis Band\n| image             = \n| caption           = \n| image_size        = \n| origin            = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]]\n| genre             = [[Rock music|Rock]], [[Country music|country]]\n| years_active      = 2001\u20132010\n| label             = Windswept, 903, [[Lofton Creek Records|Lofton Creek]]\n| past_members      = Drew Davis<br/> Mike Drake<br/> Loren Ellis<br/> Jay Hawks<br/> Mo Levone<br/> Roger Malinowski\n}}\n\nThe '''Drew Davis Band''' was an American [[Rock music|rock]], [[country music]] group established in 2001 by Drew Davis ([[lead vocals]], [[guitar]]), Mike Drake (guitar, [[harmonica]], [[fiddle]]), Loren Ellis ([[banjo]], guitar, [[mandolin]], vocals), Jay Hawks ([[Drum kit|drums]]), Mo Levone ([[bass guitar]], vocals), and Roger Malinkowski (keyboards).<ref name=\"cmt\">{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/davis__drew/bio.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080927071633/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/davis__drew/bio.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 27, 2008 |title=The Drew Davis Band biography |accessdate=2008-01-26 |work=[[Country Music Television]]}}</ref>\n\nIn 2004, the band competed in and won the [[Colgate Country Showdown]]; shortly afterward, they were signed to Windswept Publishing, with a self-titled EP being released that year. Eventually, they were transferred to 903 Music, a short-lived record label founded by [[Neal McCoy]]; upon the label's closure in 2007, the band was transferred to [[Lofton Creek Records]]. Both Mike Drake and Jay Hawks have since left the group. The band's debut single, \"Back There All the Time\", entered the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. It was included on both their self-titled EP and on their 2008 album ''Crossroads''. Roger Malinowski left the band in 2009 to be David Spade's stuntman.\n\nThe Drew Davis Band was featured on an episode of ''[[Gene Simmons Family Jewels]]'' on August 9, 2009.  The episode also featured a guest appearance by [[Trace Adkins]]. They also performed the theme song for the [[Disney Channel]] series ''[[Phil of the Future]]'' and ''[[The Suite Life of Zack & Cody]]''.\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Crossroads''\n| \n* Release date: July 8, 2008\n* Label: DELM Records\n|}\n\n===Extended plays===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Drew Davis Band'' EP\n| \n* Release date: October 4, 2005\n* Label: Windswept Records\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"60\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n|-\n| 2005\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Back There All the Time\"\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| ''Drew Davis Band'' EP\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2008\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Back There All the Time\" <small>(re-release)</small>\n| 58\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"2\"| ''Crossroads''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"How Do I\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Year\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Video\n|-\n| 2005\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Back There All the Time\"\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n[[Category:Country music groups from California]]\n[[Category:Lofton Creek Records artists]]\n[[Category:Musical groups from Los Angeles]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 2004]]\n\n\n{{US-country-band-stub}}"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Red_Steagall","to":"Red Steagall"}],"pages":{"7877271":{"pageid":7877271,"ns":0,"title":"Red Steagall","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2020}}\n{{BLP sources|date=January 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Red Steagall\n| image            = Red steagall 2007.jpg\n| caption          = Red Steagall at the 2007 Texas Book Festival.\n| image_size       = \n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = Russell Steagall\n| alias            = \n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1938|12|22}}\n| birth_place      = [[Gainesville, Texas]], United States\n| origin           = [[Sanford, Texas]], United States\n| death_date       = \n| instrument       = Guitar\n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation       = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active     = 1968\u2013present\n| label            = [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Western]]\n[[Capitol Records|Capitol Nashville]][[Dot Records|Dot]]\n| associated_acts  =\n| website          = {{URL|www.redsteagall.com}}\n}}<br />\n\n'''Russell \"Red\" Steagall''' (born December 22, 1938)<ref name=\"Slatta2001\">{{cite book|last=Slatta|first=Richard W.|title=The mythical West: an encyclopedia of legend, lore, and popular culture|url=https://archive.org/details/mythicalwestency0000slat|url-access=registration|access-date=August 5, 2011|year=2001|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-57607-151-9|pages=[https://archive.org/details/mythicalwestency0000slat/page/331 331]\u2013}}</ref> is an American actor, musician, poet, and stage performer, who focuses on [[Western (genre)|American Western]] and [[country music]] genres.\n\n==Early life and day jobs==\nHe was born in [[Gainesville, Texas]], United States.<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|page=392}}</ref> He became a [[bull rider]] at [[rodeo]]s while he was still a teenager, but at the age of 15, he was stricken with [[polio]].<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> He took up the guitar and the [[mandolin]] as [[physical therapy]] to recover the [[physical strength|strength]] and [[dexterity]] of his arms and hands.<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> Based out of Amarillo, he formed a dance band, Russell Don & The Premiers making his first recordings (which were unreleased) at [[Norman Petty]] Studios in [[Clovis, New Mexico]], in April 1961. Steagall entered a career in [[agricultural chemistry]] after graduating from [[West Texas A&M University|West Texas State University]] with a degree in [[animal science]] and [[agronomy]].<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> After five years spent as a soil analyst for Sand Mark Oil,<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> Steagall then spent eight years as a [[music industry]] executive in Hollywood, and has spent the last 40 years as a recording artist, songwriter, and television and motion picture personality. He currently maintains offices outside of [[Fort Worth, Texas]], where he is involved in the production of motion pictures and television shows.\n\nOn December 28, 1974, ''[[Hee Haw]]'' season six, episode 16, Steagall saluted his hometown of [[Sanford, Texas]], population 181.\n\n==Television and radio personality==\nSteagall made numerous appearances on [[syndicated television]] shows such as ''[[Hee Haw]]'' and ''Nashville on the Road''. He also spent four years as host of the nationally televised [[National Finals Rodeo]], was host of the Winston Pro Tour on [[ESPN]] for the 1985 season, and co-hosted the [[College National Finals Rodeo]] for the Freedom Sports Network from 1988 through 1991. He was also the host of ''Western Theater'' on America One Television.\n\nSteagall currently hosts a one-hour syndicated radio show, ''Cowboy Corner'', on 170 stations in 43 states. ''Cowboy Corner'' celebrates the lifestyle of the [[American West]] through the poems, songs, and stories of the American [[cowboy]]. In 2010, ''In the Bunkhouse with Red Steagall ''began airing on the RFD-TV network; as of 2017, Steagall now hosts ''Red Steagall is Somewhere West of Wall Street'' for the same channel. His down-home, friendly manner and considerable musical talents make him a favorite of rural America.\n\n== Motion pictures ==\nSteagall had a major role in the motion picture ''[[Benji the Hunted]]'', which was released in the summer of 1987. He also appeared in the motion pictures ''Dark Before Dawn'' and ''Abilene''. He produced the motion picture ''[[Big Bad John (film)|Big Bad John]]'', starring [[Jimmy Dean]], [[Jack Elam]], [[Ned Beatty]], and [[Bo Hopkins]], and directed by [[Burt Kennedy]].\n\nSteagall is a trustee of the Pro Rodeo Hall of Champions, honorary member of the [[Cowboy Artists of America]], and former board chairman of the Academy of Country Music.\n\n== Musical and literary accomplishments ==\nAlong with [[Don Lanier]], in 1966, Steagall co-wrote the song \"[[Here We Go Again (Ray Charles song)|Here We Go Again]]\", most notably recorded by [[Ray Charles]].<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/>\n\nIn 1974, he discovered a then-unknown [[Reba McEntire]] and signed her to [[Mercury Records]] the following year.<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> He discovered her while she was performing the [[The Star-Spangled Banner|national anthem]] at the National Rodeo Finals competition in [[Oklahoma City]], Oklahoma.<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> Two years later, in October 1977, McEntire released her first album on Mercury Records, and though most of her Mercury albums were commercial failures, in 1984, she picked up with her big album, ''[[My Kind of Country (Reba McEntire album)|My Kind of Country]]''.\n\nIn March 1993, [[Texas Christian University Press]] published Steagall's first book, entitled ''Ride for the Brand'', a 168-page collection of poetry and songs embracing the Western lifestyle. The book is illustrated by [[Cowboy Artists of America]] members [[Bill Owen (American writer)|Bill Owen]], Fred Fellows, [[Joe Beeler]], and [[Howard Terpning]].\n\nIn September 2003, [[Texas Tech University Press]] published ''Born to This Land'', a joint effort between Steagall and [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning photographer Skeeter Hagler. The book contains Hagler's black-and-white studies of modern [[ranching]], accompanied by Steagall's award-winning poetry. The Academy of Western Artists named ''Born to This Land' as recipient of the [[Will Rogers]] Award for best book of 2003.\n\nSteagall has won the Wrangler Award for original music five times: 1993 (for his Warner Western album, ''Born to This Land''), 1995 (for the Warner Western album, ''Faith and Values''), 1997 (for his Warner Western album, ''Dear Mama, I'm a Cowboy''), 1999 (for ''Love of the West''). In fall 2002, Steagall released his 20th album, ''Wagon Tracks'', which also won the Wrangler Award from the National Cowboy and Western Heritage Museum.\n\nHe released his new album ''Here We Go Again'' in August 2007. ''Here We Go Again'' features duets with [[Toby Keith]], [[Reba McEntire]], [[Charley Pride]], [[Ray Benson]], [[Neal McCoy]], [[Larry Gatlin]], and [[Charlie Daniels]].\n\nIn May 2011, Bunkhouse Press released Steagall's CD ''Dreamin' of......When the Grass Was Still Deep'', featuring eight songs and two poems.\n\n== Honors and awards ==\nThe [[Texas Legislature]] named Red Steagall the Official Cowboy Poet of Texas in April 1991. Steagall was an early participant in the American Cowboy Culture Association, which holds the annual National Cowboy Symposium and Celebration each September in [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cowboy.org/About/History-And-Purpose|title=National Cowboy Symposium & Celebration, Inc. (Lubbock, Texas)|publisher=cowboy.org|access-date=September 5, 2013|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130826204027/http://www.cowboy.org/About/History-And-Purpose|archive-date=August 26, 2013}}</ref>\n\nSteagall is also the official Cowboy [[Poet Laureate]] of [[San Juan Capistrano, California]].\n\nSince 1991, Steagall has hosted the annual Red Steagall Cowboy Gathering in the Stockyards National Historic District of [[Fort Worth, Texas|Fort Worth]]. The event features a ranch rodeo, [[chuckwagon]] cookoff, children's poetry contest, [[Western swing]] dances, cowboy music and poetry, a trappings show, and [[horsemanship]] clinics.\n\nIn 1999, Steagall was inducted into the [[Texas Trail of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Red Steagall|url=http://texastrailoffame.org/inductees/red-steagall/|website=Western Heritage from the Texas Trail of Fame|access-date=April 14, 2018|date=May 26, 2013}}</ref>\n\nIn April 2003, Steagall was inducted into the [[Hall of Great Westerners]] at the [[National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum|National Cowboy and Western Heritage Museum]] in [[Oklahoma City]], joining the likes of Will Rogers, [[Theodore Roosevelt]], [[Charles Goodnight]], and [[Charles Marion Russell|Charlie Russell]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Hall of Great Westerners |url=https://nationalcowboymuseum.org/great-westerners/red-steagall/ |website=National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum |access-date=August 21, 2021}}</ref>\n\nIn January 2004, he received the Spirit of Texas Award and was inducted into the [[Texas Cowboy Hall of Fame]] in Fort Worth.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tchof.com/post/red-steagall|title=Red Steagall|publisher=Texas Cowboy Hall of Fame {{!}} Fort Worth Texas|access-date=March 8, 2020}}</ref>\n\nIn April 2005, he was inducted to the [[Texas Rodeo Cowboy Hall of Fame]] in Belton, Texas.<ref>{{cite web |title=Past Inductees |url=http://texasrodeocowboy.com/past_inductees.html |website=Texas Rodeo Cowboy Hall of Fame |access-date=March 28, 2020}}</ref>\n\nHe was named \"2006 [[Poet Laureate]] of the State of Texas\" at the Capital in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]] in the spring of 2005. Steagall is the first \"cowboy\" poet to be named the poet laureate of Texas.\n\nIn 2007, he was inducted into the [[National Multicultural Western Heritage Museum]] in Fort Worth, Texas.<ref>{{cite web |title=Hall of Fame Inductees |url=https://nmwhm.org/hall-of-fame-inductees/ |website=National Multicultural Western Heritage Museum |access-date=June 3, 2023}}</ref>\n\nHe was named the 2023 [[List of ProRodeo Hall of Fame inductees#Legends of ProRodeo|Legend of ProRodeo]].\n\n===Red Steagall Institute of Western Art===\nIn 2024, the [[National Ranching Heritage Center]] in [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]], Texas, announced the forthcoming location at the center of the Red Steagall Institute of Western Art, which will feature interactive classes and displays for the public to learn about Western culture. The Texas Tech System Board of Regents approved the NRHC's $28 million dollar expansion in May 2024. Jim Bret Campbell, executive director of the NRHC, said that the project comes after Steagall and his wife sought a location to donate his collection of Western songs, poetry, and various radio and television recordings of his programs.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.lubbockonline.com/story/news/local/2024/06/09/national-ranching-heritage-center-to-expand-with-new-28-million-western-art-interactive-institute/73703457007/#:~:text=The%20National%20Ranching%20Heritage%20Center%20will%20soon%20be,include%20the%20Red%20Steagall%20Institute%20of%20Western%20Art.|title=National Ranching Heritage Center to expand with new Western art, interactive institute|author=Mateo Rosiles|publisher=Lubbock Avalanche-Journal|date=June 9, 2024|accessdate=June 10, 2024}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! LeDoux"}],"pages":{"1589105":{"pageid":1589105,"ns":0,"title":"Chris LeDoux","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country singer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2015}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Chris LeDoux\n| image            = Chris LeDoux promo photo.png\n| caption          = LeDoux in May 1999\n| birth_name       = Christopher Lee LeDoux<ref>{{cite web | url=https://repertoire.bmi.com/Search/Catalog?num=Ik7dfDtu1Xp6b%252bdT%252bHRDSQ%253d%253d&cae=EXUbCKDA%252br169YV0FkVmbw%253d%253d&partType=WriterList&search=%7B%22Main_Search_Text%22%3A%22lean%20mean%20and%20hungry%22%2C%22Sub_Search_Text%22%3Anull%2C%22Main_Search%22%3A%22Title%22%2C%22Sub_Search%22%3Anull%2C%22Search_Type%22%3A%22all%22%2C%22View_Count%22%3A100%2C%22Page_Number%22%3A0%2C%22Part_Type%22%3Anull%2C%22Part_Id%22%3Anull%2C%22Part_Id_Sub%22%3Anull%2C%22Part_Name%22%3Anull%2C%22Part_Cae%22%3Anull%2C%22Original_Search%22%3Anull%2C%22DisclaimerViewed%22%3Anull%7D&resetPageNumber=True&partIdSub=YO0HedHMatLb45JzS23DVw%253d%253d | title=Search results for LeDoux, Christopher Lee | publisher=BMI | accessdate=September 13, 2024}}</ref>\n| birth_date       = {{Birth date|1948|10|2}}\n| birth_place      = [[Biloxi, Mississippi]], U.S.\n| origin           = [[Cheyenne, Wyoming]], U.S.\n| death_date       = {{death date and age|2005|3|9|1948|10|2}}\n| death_place      = [[Casper, Wyoming]], U.S.\n| genre            = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[country rock]]|[[Western music (North America)|Western music]]}}\n| occupation       = {{hlist|Musician|singer-songwriter|[[rodeo]] competitor}}\n| instrument       = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar|harmonica}}\n| years_active     = 1971\u20132005\n| label            = {{hlist|[[Liberty Records|Liberty]]|[[Capitol Records|Capitol]]|American Cowboy Songs}}\n| associated_acts  = \n}}\n\n'''Christopher Lee LeDoux''' (October 2, 1948 \u2013 March 9, 2005) was an American [[country music]] singer-songwriter, [[Bronze sculpture|bronze sculptor]], and hall of fame [[rodeo]] champion. During his career, LeDoux recorded 36 albums (many self-released), which have sold more than six million units in the United States as of January 2007. He was awarded two gold and one platinum album certifications from the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA), was nominated for a [[Grammy Award]], and was honored with the [[Academy of Country Music]] Cliffie Stone Pioneer Award. LeDoux is also the only person to participate and also perform at the [[Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo]].\n\n==Biography==\n\n===Early years===\nLeDoux was born in [[Biloxi, Mississippi]], on October 2, 1948. He was of [[French people|French]] descent on his father's side. His father was in the [[US Air Force]] and was stationed at Keesler Air Force Base at the time of his birth. The family moved often when he was a child, due to his father's Air Force career. He learned to ride horses while visiting his grandparents on their [[Wyoming]] farm.<ref name=\"cmt\"/> At age 13, LeDoux participated in his first rodeo, and before long was winning junior rodeo competitions.<ref name=\"huey\">{{cite web |last= Huey |first= Steve |title= Chris LeDoux |publisher= [[Allmusic]] |year= 2005 |url ={{BillboardURLbyName |artist=chris ledoux |bio=true}} |access-date= 2007-03-16}}</ref>\n\nLeDoux continued to compete in rodeo events and played football through his high-school years. When his family moved to [[Cheyenne, Wyoming]], he attended [[Cheyenne Central High School]].  After twice winning the Wyoming State Rodeo Championship bareback riding title during high school, LeDoux earned a rodeo scholarship to [[Casper College]] in [[Casper, Wyoming|Casper]]. During his junior year at [[Eastern New Mexico University]], LeDoux won the Intercollegiate National [[saddle bronc and bareback riding|bareback riding]] championship.<ref name=\"cmt\">{{cite web |title= Chris LeDoux Biography |publisher= [[Country Music Television]] |year= 2005 |url= http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/ledoux_chris/bio.jhtml |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20111107135707/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/ledoux_chris/bio.jhtml |archive-date= November 7, 2011 |access-date= 2007-03-16 |url-status= dead}}</ref>\n\nLeDoux married Peggy Rhoads on January 4, 1972. They had five children: Clay, [[Ned LeDoux|Ned]], Will, Beau, and Cindy.<ref name=\"dillon\">{{cite web |last= Dillon |first= Jenni |title= Cowboy, Singer LeDoux dies in Casper |newspaper=[[Casper Star-Tribune]] |date= March 10, 2005 |url =https://trib.com/news/cowboy-singer-ledoux-dies-in-casper/article_4f7cb8ee-196b-56a0-bb2a-ca2b7355c248.html | access-date= March 16, 2007}}</ref>\n\n===Rodeo success and music beginnings===\nIn 1970, LeDoux became a professional rodeo cowboy on the national circuit.<ref name=\"huey\"/>  To help pay his expenses while traveling the country, he began composing songs describing his lifestyle.<ref name=\"cmt\"/>  Within two years, he had written enough songs to make up an album, and soon established a recording company, American Cowboy Songs, with his father.  After recording his songs in a friend's basement, LeDoux \"began selling his tapes at rodeo events out of the back of his pickup truck\".<ref>{{cite web |title=Chris LeDoux - LeDoux Country - Discography |url=https://www.ledouxcountry.com/discography/ |website=www.ledouxcountry.com |access-date=April 11, 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"huey\"/>\n\nIn 1976, LeDoux won the world bareback riding championship at the [[National Finals Rodeo]] in [[Oklahoma City]].<ref name=\"huey\"/> Winning the championship gave LeDoux more credibility with music audiences, as he now had proof that the cowboy songs he wrote were authentic.<ref name=\"coon\">{{cite web |last= Coon |first= Chuck |title= Chris LeDoux: Missing Chris |publisher= ChrisLedoux.com |year= 2005 |url =http://www.chrisledoux.com/bio3.htm |access-date= 2007-03-16 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070309150925/http://chrisledoux.com/bio3.htm |archive-date= March 9, 2007}}</ref> LeDoux continued competing for the next four years. He retired in 1980.<ref name=\"huey\"/>\n\n===Music career===\nWith his rodeo career at an end, LeDoux and his family settled on a ranch in [[Kaycee, Wyoming]]. LeDoux continued to write and record his songs, and began playing concerts.<ref name=\"huey\"/> His concerts were very popular, and often featured a [[mechanical bull]] (which he rode between songs) and fireworks.<ref name=\"coon\"/> By 1982, he had sold more than 250,000 copies of his albums, with little or no marketing.  By the end of the decade, he had self-released 22 albums.<ref name=\"huey\"/>\n\nDespite offers from various record labels, LeDoux refused to sign a recording contract, instead choosing to retain his independence and control over his work while enjoying his regional following.  In 1989, however, he shot to national prominence when he was mentioned in [[Garth Brooks]]' top-10 country hit \"[[Much Too Young (To Feel This Damn Old)]]\". Capitalizing on the sudden attention, LeDoux signed a contract with [[Capitol Records]] subsidiary Liberty Records and released his first national album, ''[[Western Underground]]'', in 1991. His follow-up album, ''[[Whatcha Gonna Do with a Cowboy]]'', was certified gold and reached the top 10. The [[Whatcha Gonna Do with a Cowboy (song)|title track]], a duet with Brooks, became LeDoux's first and only top-10 country single, reaching number seven in 1992.<ref name=\"huey\"/> In concert, he ended the song by saying, \"Thanks, Garth!\"\n\nFor the 35th annual Grammy Awards in 1992, the single track \"Whatcha Gonna Do with a Cowboy\" was nominated for Best Country Vocal Collaboration.<ref>{{cite web |title=Chris LeDoux |url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/chris-ledoux |website=grammy.com |access-date=24 August 2017 |date=14 May 2017}}</ref> LeDoux and Brooks also received nominations from the [[Academy of Country Music]] for Vocal Duo of the Year and from the TNN/Music City News Country Awards for Vocal Collaboration of the Year.\n\nFor the next decade, LeDoux continued to record for Liberty. He released six additional records, including ''[[One Road Man]]'', which made the country top 40 in 1998.<ref name=\"huey\"/> Toward the end of his career, LeDoux began recording material written by other artists, which he attributed to the challenge of composing new lyrics.<ref name=\"coon\"/> With his 2000 release, ''Cowboy,'' he returned to his roots, re-recording many of his earliest songwriting creations.<ref name=\"huey\"/>\n\nThe RIAA certified two gold and one platinum recordings for LeDoux. On February 22, 1993, the single \"Whatcha Gonna Do with a Cowboy\" went gold. On June 2, 1997, the album ''The Best of Chris LeDoux'' went gold. And on October 5, 2005, the album ''20 Greatest Hits'' went platinum.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gold & Platinum - Chris LeDoux |url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&se=chris+ledoux#search_section |website=RIAA |publisher=Recording Association of America}}</ref><ref name=\"remaster\" />\n\n===Illness and death===\nIn August 2000, LeDoux was diagnosed with [[primary sclerosing cholangitis]], which required him to receive a [[liver]] transplant. [[Garth Brooks]] volunteered to donate part of his liver, but it was incompatible. An alternative donor was located, and LeDoux received a transplant on October 7, 2000.<ref name=\"gardner\">{{cite web |last= Gardner |first= Tom |title= Chris LeDoux Back After Transplant |publisher= PlanetGarth.Com |date= June 20, 2001 |url =http://www.planetgarth.com/news/article.php?cid=00547 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924073947/http://www.planetgarth.com/news/article.php?cid=00547 |archive-date=September 24, 2015 |access-date= March 16, 2007}}</ref> After his recovery, he released two additional albums. In November 2004, LeDoux was diagnosed with [[cholangiocarcinoma]], for which he underwent radiation treatment until his death.<ref name=\"huey\"/>\n\nLeDoux died of cancer on March 9, 2005, at age 56. His funeral was held on March 11.\n[[File:Chris Ledoux Monument.jpg|thumb|\"Good Ride Cowboy\" Sculpture in Kaycee, Wyoming.]]\n\n==Tributes==\nShortly after his death, LeDoux was named as one of six former rodeo cowboys to be inducted into the [[ProRodeo Hall of Fame]] in [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]], in 2005.  He was the first person to be inducted in two categories, for his bareback riding and in the \"notables\" category \"for his contributions to the sport through his music\".<ref name=\"prorodeo\">{{cite web |title= LeDoux Named to ProRodeo Hall of Fame |publisher= [[Country Music Television]] |date= April 22, 2005 |url= http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1500641/04222005/ledoux_chris.jhtml |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070930035937/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1500641/04222005/ledoux_chris.jhtml |archive-date= September 30, 2007 |access-date= March 16, 2007 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nIn 2004, the [[Academy of Country Music]] awarded LeDoux their Cliffie Stone Pioneer Award during ceremonies.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cliffiestone.com/Cliffie/cliffie_c_awardlist.htm |title=The Cliffie Stone Pioneer Award |website=www.cliffiestone.com |access-date=May 9, 2017}}</ref> In 2005, Garth Brooks accepted the award on behalf of LeDoux's family.<ref name=\"pioneer\">{{cite web |title= Brooks to Accept LeDoux's Pioneer Award |publisher= [[Country Music Television]] |date=April 27, 2005 |url= http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1500885/04272005/ledoux_chris.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930014409/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1500885/04272005/ledoux_chris.jhtml |archive-date=September 30, 2007 |access-date=March 16, 2007 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nIn late 2005, Brooks briefly emerged from retirement to record \"[[Good Ride Cowboy]]\" as a tribute to LeDoux. Brooks remarked:<ref name=\"smith\">{{cite web |last= Smith |first= Hazel |title= A Conversation with Garth Brooks Country Music Television |date= November 1, 2005 |url= http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1512744/11012005/ledoux_chris.jhtml |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070930041246/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1512744/11012005/ledoux_chris.jhtml |archive-date= September 30, 2007 |access-date= March 16, 2007 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n::\"I knew if I ever recorded any kind of tribute to Chris, it would have to be up-tempo, happy ... a song like him ... not some slow, mournful song. He wasn't like that. Chris was exactly as our heroes are supposed to be. He was a man's man. A good friend.\"\n\nGarth Brooks performed the song on the ''39th Annual CMA Awards'' on November 15, 2005, live from Times Square in New York City.  Later that evening, LeDoux was honored with the CMA Chairman's Award of Merit, presented by [[Kix Brooks]] of [[Brooks & Dunn]], to LeDoux's family.\n\nFriends have also collaborated to produce an annual rodeo, art show, and concert in Casper, Wyoming to honor LeDoux's memory. The art show features sculpture and sketches that LeDoux completed for friends; none of his works were ever officially exhibited before his death.<ref name=\"graves\">{{cite web |last= Stoelzle Graves |first= Deirdre |title= Losing, and finding, Chris LeDoux |newspaper=[[Casper Star-Tribune]] |date= October 30, 2006 |url =http://www.casperstartribune.net/articles/2006/10/30/news/casper/64ec836ff5a9d8988725721600211708.txt | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170818045511/http://trib.com/news/local/losing-and-finding-chris-ledoux/article_397d93d8-9897-5f57-947d-3ea686df5df6.html | archive-date=August 18, 2017 | access-date= March 16, 2007}}</ref> However, LeDoux did have two pieces of sculpture that won awards while he was alive; it was more than just a hobby.<ref name=\"Cackett\">{{cite web |title=Chris LeDoux Biography |url=https://alancackett.com/chris-ledoux-biography |website=Alan Cackett |access-date=January 15, 2019}}</ref><ref name=\"NationalCowboy\">{{cite web |title=Chris LeDoux, A True American Cowboy |url=https://nationalcowboymuseum.org/explore/chris-ledoux-a-true-american-cowboy/ |website=National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum |access-date=January 15, 2019}}</ref>\n\nTo mark the second anniversary of LeDoux's death, in April 2007, Capitol Records released six CDs featuring remastered versions of 12 of the albums he recorded between 1974 and 1993.<ref name=\"remaster\">{{cite web |title= Chris LeDoux's Catalog Gems Remastered by Capitol Nashville / EMI |publisher= [[Capitol Records]] |date= January 22, 2007 |url =http://www.chrisledoux.com/news3.htm |access-date= March 16, 2007 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070205113333/http://chrisledoux.com/news3.htm |archive-date= February 5, 2007}}</ref>\n\nArtist and sculptor D. Michael Thomas created a one-and-a-half times life-size sculpture of Chris LeDoux during his 1976 World Championship ride on Stormy Weather. The statue, called \"Good Ride Cowboy\", is on display at the Chris LeDoux Memorial Park in his hometown of Kaycee, Wyoming.<ref name=\"ledouxstatue\">{{cite web |title= Chris LeDoux Immortalized in Bronze |publisher= ChicagoAtHome.Com |date= March 7, 2007 |url= http://www.chicagoathome.com/Detail.aspx?dct=62&id=96097&mid=1797 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120210161350/http://www.chicagoathome.com/Detail.aspx?dct=62&id=96097&mid=1797 |archive-date= February 10, 2012 |access-date= March 16, 2007 |url-status= live }}</ref>\n\nSon Beau LeDoux, himself a rodeo competitor, on July 24, 2007, spread his father's ashes over Frontier Park Arena during the annual [[Cheyenne Frontier Days]] rodeo.<ref>Johnke, Jeremiah. [https://archive.today/20120919191808/http://www.wyomingnews.com/articles/2007/07/25/sports/19sports_07-25-07.txt \"Remembrance: Singer's ashes spread on Frontier Park Arena\"] \u2013 ''[[Wyoming Tribune-Eagle]]'' \u2013 July 25, 2007</ref>\n\nThe city in which LeDoux attended college, Casper, Wyoming, celebrates LeDoux each November with the Chris LeDoux Memorial Rodeo, a weekend event that includes an art show featuring a number of LeDoux's works, a PRCA rodeo, and a country music concert.\n\nIn 2010, Robert Royston created ''One Ride'', a music and dance production that tells the story of the rodeo cowboy.\n\nIn 2010, country singer [[Luke Kaufman]] paid tribute to LeDoux in his song ''Broncin''' from the album ''Cowboy Baller, \"Soakin' up tapes of Chris LeDoux\".''\n\nIn 2011, country music artist Brantley Gilbert paid tribute to LeDoux in his single \"Country Must Be Countrywide\", with the line \"From his Wranglers to his boots \u2013 he reminded me of Chris LeDoux. With that Copenhagen smile, Country must be countrywide.\"<ref>{{cite web |title=Brantley Gilbert |url=http://brantleygilbert.com/ |website=Brantley Gilbert web site |access-date=August 7, 2021}}</ref>\n\nIn 2021, a bronze statue of LeDoux was placed at Cheyenne Frontier Days in Frontier Park in his honor. It is a large statue sculpted by Buffalo sculptor D. Michael Thomas. It is titled ''Just LeDoux It''. It was unveiled at the opening of Frontier Days, during the celebration of its 125th anniversary. The statue displays LeDoux on a bucking bronc, and also depicts a guitar.<ref>{{cite web |title=Wyoming Rodeo Hero Chris LeDoux Celebrated With Statue At Cheyenne Frontier Days |url=https://cowboystatedaily.com/2021/07/16/wyoming-rodeo-hero-chris-ledoux-celebrated-with-statue-at-frontier-park/ |website=Cowboy State Daily |access-date=August 7, 2021 |date=July 16, 2021}}</ref> Fellow musical artist Garth Brooks and Chris's son Ned LeDoux attended the unveiling.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Moore |first1=Bobby |title=Chris LeDoux Statue Unveiled For Cheyenne Frontier Days' 125th Anniversary |url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/chris-ledoux-statue/ |website=Wide Open Country |access-date=7 August 2021 |date=July 27, 2021}}</ref>\n\nSince 2011, the town of Kaycee, Wyoming has hosted Chris LeDoux Days, a festival held along Nolan Avenue featuring a rodeo and live music performances headlined by Chris's son, Ned.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Chris LeDoux Days {{!}} Travel Wyoming |url=https://travelwyoming.com/event/chris-ledoux-days/ |access-date=2024-06-17 |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Rodeo honors==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Year\n! Honor\n|-\n| 2003\n| [[Cheyenne Frontier Days Old West Museum|Cheyenne Frontier Days and Old West Museum Hall of Fame]]<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.cfdrodeo.com/cfd-old-west-museum/our-story/history/cheyenne-frontier-days-hall-of-fame-inductees/ |title=Cheyenne Frontier Days and Old West Museum Hall of Fame |website=ww.cfdrodeo.com  |access-date=9 May 2017}}</ref>\n|-\n|2005\n|Inducted into the ProRodeo Hall of Fame as Bareback Bronc Rider and Notable<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.prorodeohalloffame.com/inductees/bareback-riding/chris-ledoux/ |title=Chris LeDoux - Pro Rodeo Hall of Fame |work=Pro Rodeo Hall of Fame |access-date=9 May 2017}}</ref>\n|-\n| 2006\n| [[Rodeo Hall of Fame]]<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://nationalcowboymuseum.org/rodeo-hall-of-fame/5320/\n |title=Chris LeDoux|publisher=Rodeo Hall of Fame Inductees |work=National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum |access-date=9 May 2017}}</ref> at the [[National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum]] in [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]]\n|-\n| 2007\n| [[Texas Trail of Fame]] historic [[Fort Worth Stockyards]] in [[Fort Worth, Texas]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://texastrailoffame.org/inductees/chris-ledoux/ |title=Chris LeDoux |date=June 11, 2013 |work=Western Heritage from the [[Texas Trail of Fame]] |access-date=11 May 2017 }}</ref>\n|-\n| 2009\n|Wyoming Sports Hall of Fame<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://archives.collegian.com/2009/02/12/fornstrom_named_to_wyoming_hall_of_fame/ |title=Fornstrom named to Wyoming Hall of Fame \u2013 Collegian Archives |website=archives.collegian.com |access-date=30 May 2017 |archive-date=November 27, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181127064713/http://archives.collegian.com/2009/02/12/fornstrom_named_to_wyoming_hall_of_fame/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n|-\n|2012\n|Cowboy Keeper<ref>{{cite web |title=Cowboy Keeper Hall of Fame |url=http://nationaldayofthecowboy.com/?page_id=83 |website=National Day of the Cowboy |access-date=April 30, 2019 |date=February 11, 2012}}</ref>\n|}\n\n==Rodeo career milestones==\n{| class=wikitable\n|-\n! Year\n! unknown}} Obituary by Peter Cooper, ''[[The Tennessean]]'', March 10, 2005\n\n{{Chris LeDoux}}\n{{Use American English|date=August 2021}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2021}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Ledoux, Chris}}\n[[Category:1948 births]]\n[[Category:2005 deaths]]\n[[Category:People from Biloxi, Mississippi]]\n[[Category:American people of French
