This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jeffrey_Steele","to":"Jeffrey Steele"}],"pages":{"6772074":{"pageid":6772074,"ns":0,"title":"Jeffrey Steele","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter (born 1961)}}\n\n{{For|the British painter|Jeffrey Steele (artist)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name                = Jeffrey Steele\n| image               = Jeffrey Steele by Gage Skidmore.jpg\n| caption             = Steele performing in 2021\n| image_size          = \n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          = Jeffrey LeVasseur<ref name=\"bmi1\"/>\n| birth_date          = {{birth date and age|1961|08|27}}<ref>{{cite web |url=http://countrymusic.about.com/b/2007/08/28/country-music-birthdays-august-27-september-1-2007.htm |title=Country Music birthdays |access-date=April 29, 2008 |last=Fabian |first=Shelly |work=[[About.com]] |archive-date=May 20, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090520051303/http://countrymusic.about.com/b/2007/08/28/country-music-birthdays-august-27-september-1-2007.htm |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n| birth_place         = [[Burbank, California]], U.S.\n| origin              = \n| instrument          = Vocals, guitar, bass guitar, piano\n| genre               = [[country music|Country]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = 1990\u2013present\n| label               = [[Curb Records|Curb]], [[Monument Records|Monument]], 3 Ring Circus/[[Lofton Creek Records|Lofton Creek]]\n| past_member_of    = [[Boy Howdy]]\n| website             = {{URL|www.jeffreysteele.net/}}\n}}\n'''Jeffrey LeVasseur''' (born August 27, 1961),<ref name=\"cmt\">{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/steele_jeffrey/bio.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040704092326/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/steele_jeffrey/bio.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=July 4, 2004 |title=Jeffrey Steele: Biography |access-date=July 21, 2007 |work= CMT.com}}</ref> known as '''Jeffrey Steele''', is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. Along with recording his own material, Steele has become a prolific Nashville songwriter, having co-written more than 60 hit songs for such artists as [[Montgomery Gentry]], [[Tim McGraw]], [[Faith Hill]], [[LeAnn Rimes]], [[Rascal Flatts]], [[Billy Ray Cyrus]], and others.\n\nBetween 1990 and 1996, Steele was the lead singer and bass guitarist in the country music band [[Boy Howdy]], which recorded two albums and an [[Extended play|EP]] on [[Curb Records]], in addition to charting seven singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country music charts. After Boy Howdy disbanded, Steele embarked on a solo career, recording seven studio albums (one of which was not released). He also charted four singles as a solo artist, with the highest-peaking (\"Somethin' in the Water\") reaching No.&nbsp;33 on the country charts in 2001.\n\n==Biography==\nJeffrey LeVasseur was born in [[Burbank, California]] to a musical family. His mother was a singer, and his father had aspirations to become a country music songwriter.<ref name=\"cmt\"/> He first gained his own interest in music at age eight, when he sang [[Three Dog Night]]'s \"[[Joy to the World (Three Dog Night song)|Joy to the World]]\" at a church function. This rendition earned him a standing ovation, so he sang the song an additional seven times.<ref name=\"cmt\"/><ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p206695/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=allmusic (((Jeffrey Steele > Biography))) |access-date=July 21, 2007 |work=Allmusic}}</ref> Later, he shifted his focus to songwriting. By age 17, he was performing with local groups, and playing keyboards at various gigs on the [[Sunset Strip]] in Los Angeles.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> In 1987, after the death of his father, LeVasseur changed his last name to Steele as a tribute to his father, who processed steel for a living.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nu.musiccitynetworks.com/index.htm?id=7285&sid=3042 |title=Jeffrey Steele |access-date=July 21, 2007 |work=Nashville Underground |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927041300/http://nu.musiccitynetworks.com/index.htm?id=7285&sid=3042 |archive-date=September 27, 2007 }}</ref>\n\n==Boy Howdy==\n{{main|Boy Howdy}}\nIn 1990, Steele and three other California musicians \u2013 Hugh Wright, along with brothers Cary and Larry Park \u2013 formed the band [[Boy Howdy]], in which he served as lead vocalist and bass guitarist.<ref name=\"allmusic2\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p26222/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=allmusic (((Boy Howdy > Biography))) |access-date=July 21, 2007 |work=Allmusic}}</ref> Jeffrey Steele wrote a song, 'When Johnny Comes Marching Home' about the returning veterans from the Gulf war, Curb signed Boy Howdy but made them change their group name to 'New Frontier'  they went to appear on 'Nashville Now'  hosted by Ralph Emery who liked the band name Boy Howdy this helped convince Curb records to let them keep the Boy Howdy name.  The war ended so soon that the single was never released. Boy Howdy signed to [[Curb Records]] in 1992, recording three albums and an [[extended play]] for the label, in addition to charting seven singles on the country music charts.<ref name=\"allmusic2\"/> While in Boy Howdy, Steele was named Best Bassist and Best Male Vocalist by the California Country Music Association.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> As the band's primary songwriter, he also earned [[Broadcast Music Incorporated|BMI]] awards for co-writing their highest-charting singles, \"[[She'd Give Anything (song)|She'd Give Anything]]\" and \"[[They Don't Make 'Em Like That Anymore]]\".<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\n==Solo career and success as songwriter==\nSteele re-located to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] in 1994, two years before Boy Howdy disbanded. In 1996, he released three solo singles, as well as a self-titled solo album which was never shipped.<ref name=\"bmi1\">{{cite web |url=http://www.bmi.com/musicworld/entry/233539 |title=Jeffrey Steele |access-date=July 21, 2007 |work=BMI.com|date=February 28, 2001 }}</ref><ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Steele was eventually signed to a songwriting contract, however, and he began writing singles for other artists. Among his first hits as a songwriter were \"[[If You Love Somebody]]\" by [[Kevin Sharp (country singer)|Kevin Sharp]], \"[[Unbelievable (Diamond Rio song)|Unbelievable]]\" by [[Diamond Rio]], and \"[[Big Deal (LeAnn Rimes song)|Big Deal]]\" by [[LeAnn Rimes]], all three of which earned him additional BMI awards.<ref name=\"bmi1\"/><ref name=\"allmusic\"/> He also sang backing vocals on Sharp's first two albums.\n\nIn 2001, Steele was signed to his second solo recording contract, this time with [[Monument Records]]. His solo debut album, ''Somethin' in the Water'', was issued late that year. In addition to producing the album, Steele wrote or co-wrote every song on it.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> The album's title cut reached a peak of No.&nbsp;33 on the [[Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] chart, becoming Steele's only Top 40 hit as a solo artist.\n\nMeanwhile, he continued to write songs for other artists, with [[Faith Hill]], [[Tim McGraw]], [[Trace Adkins]], and [[Montgomery Gentry]] all recording songs he had co-written.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Steele earned his first Number One song with [[Tim McGraw]]'s \"[[The Cowboy in Me]]\" in 2002. In addition, [[Rascal Flatts]] reached Number One on the country charts in late 2002 with \"[[These Days (Rascal Flatts song)|These Days]]\", their first Number One single. Steele also continued to record studio albums even while writing hits for other artists; his albums ''Gold, Platinum, Chrome and Steele'' and ''You Gotta Start Somewhere'' were both released in 2003, the same year that he was named Songwriter of the Year by both BMI and the Nashville Songwriters Association International (NSAI).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://songwriter101.com/articles/716_0_6_0_M/ |title=Jeffrey Steele, Jesse Harris, Butch Walker, & Pat Green: Songwriters on Songwriting |access-date=July 21, 2007 |work=Songwriter101.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927211358/http://songwriter101.com/articles/716_0_6_0_M/ |archive-date=September 27, 2007 }}</ref><ref name=\"find\">{{cite news |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/nashville/stories/2005/10/17/daily2.html |title=Jeffrey Steele named Songwriter of the Year by NSAI |access-date=July 21, 2007 |work=FindArticles.com |date=October 17, 2005}}</ref> 2004 saw the release of his fourth studio album, ''Outlaw'', on the [[Lofton Creek Records]] label.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bmi.com/news/entry/234206 |title=Jeffrey Steele Anticipates Arrival of \"Outlaw\" |access-date=July 21, 2007 |work=bmi.com|date=October 7, 2004 }}</ref> By 2005, more than sixty of his songs had become chart hits for other artists;<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> that same year, he received a second Songwriter of the Year award from the NSAI.<ref name=\"find\"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1511639/20051017/steele_jeffrey.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930044156/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1511639/20051017/steele_jeffrey.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 30, 2007 |title=Five Members Welcomed to Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame |access-date=July 21, 2007 |work=CMT.com}}</ref>\n\nHis most successful single as a songwriter is \"[[What Hurts the Most]]\", co-written with English songwriter [[Steve Robson]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/steve-robson/5638 |title=Steve Robson page at Grammy.com |access-date=May 11, 2021}}</ref>  The song was a Number One single on both the [[Hot Country Songs]] and [[Hot Adult Contemporary Tracks]] charts for [[Rascal Flatts]] in 2006, and was also a chart single for [[Cascada]] in 2007. Another one of Steele's compositions, [[Steve Holy]]'s Number One single \"[[Brand New Girlfriend (song)|Brand New Girlfriend]]\", earned him yet another BMI award in 2006, as well as the Rascal Flatts hit \"[[My Wish]]\" just as Steele released his album, ''Hell on Wheels''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1545353/20061109/steele_jeffrey.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927184151/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1545353/20061109/steele_jeffrey.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 27, 2007 |title=BMI Honors Writers of Steve Holy's Hit |access-date=July 21, 2007 |work=BMI.com}}</ref> \"What Hurts the Most\" would later earn him the Songwriter of the Year and Song of the Year awards from BMI, as well as the Songwriter of the Year award from [[MusicRow]] magazine.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bmi.com/news/entry/334991 |title=\"These Days\", It's Good To Be Jeffrey Steele |access-date=July 21, 2007 |work=BMI.com|date=September 29, 2006 }}</ref> Steele has since released two other albums, his second greatest hits record \"Gold, Platinum, No Chrome, and More Steele\" was released in 2007 and his country classics tribute album \"Countrypolitan\" which was released in 2008. Steele also produced [[Keith Anderson]]'s two studio albums: 2005's ''[[Three Chord Country and American Rock & Roll]]'' and 2008's ''[[C'mon (Keith Anderson album)|C'mon!]]'', as well as Montgomery Gentry's 2004 album ''[[You Do Your Thing]]'' and 2006 album ''[[Some People Change]]'' In 2016 \"Chasing Down a Good Time\" Steele co-wrote with [[Anthony Smith (singer)|Anthony Smith]] by [[Randy Houser]].\n\nIn April 2008, Steele joined [[Jewel (musician)|Jewel]] and [[John Rich (musician)|John Rich]] of [[Big & Rich]] as judges on the talent show ''[[Nashville Star]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/music/news/e3i312d811d7acd5b879fa12126eae71548 |title=Jeffrey Steele, Jewel bound for 'Nashville' |access-date=April 28, 2008 |last=Tucker |first=Ken |date=April 23, 2008 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080511103649/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/music/news/e3i312d811d7acd5b879fa12126eae71548 |archive-date = May 11, 2008}}</ref> Steele has also guest hosted for [[Bob Kingsley]] twice on the radio show ''[[Bob Kingsley's Country Top 40]]'', a weekly radio countdown show based on the ''[[Mediabase]]'' country charts: for the weeks of September 13\u201314, 2008 and October 3\u20134, 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jeffreysteele.net/calendar/ |title=Calendar |access-date=September 14, 2008 |work=JeffreySteele.net |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081005050644/http://www.jeffreysteele.net/calendar/ |archive-date=October 5, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jeffreysteele.net/2009/09/bob-kingsley-country-top-40/|title=Bob Kingsley Country Top 40|work=Jeffrey Steele.net|access-date=October 4, 2009|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100102030042/http://www.jeffreysteele.net/2009/09/bob-kingsley-country-top-40/|archive-date=January 2, 2010}}</ref>\n\nIn September 2008, The Country Music Hall of Fame honored Steele as a Poet & Prophet in the Hall of Fame's quarterly series.<ref>[http://www.countrymusichalloffame.com/site/news_detail.aspx?cid=3861]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>\n\nIn 1996, he was nominated for Best Country Instrumental Performance at the [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] Awards.\n\nIn 2006, he was nominated for Best Country Song at the Grammy Awards.\n\nIn 2014, he was nominated for Best Country Song at the Grammy Awards.\n\nSteele signed a deal with [[Best Buy]] to release 3 of his albums November 18, 2008: \"Hell On Wheels\", \"Gold, Platinum, No Chrome, and More Steele: Greatest Hits Vol. II\", and \"Countrypolitan\"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=2267|title=Jeffrey Steele releases three CDs, writes with Miley Cyrus|website=Countrystandardtime.com|access-date=February 26, 2020}}</ref>\n\nSteele also co-wrote the song \"[[I Thought I Lost You]]\" with [[Miley Cyrus]] for the 2008 [[Walt Disney Pictures|Disney]] animated film ''[[Bolt (2008 film)|Bolt]]'', which Cyrus sings as a duet with [[John Travolta]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tennessean.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20081106/TUNEIN/81106042|title=None|website=Tennessean.com|access-date=February 26, 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:24em;\"| Album details\n|-\n! Brad Murano\n|-\n| 2001\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Somethin' in the Water\"\n| [[Paul Holahan]]\n|-\n| 2004\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Once a Cowboy\"\n| \n|}\n\n==Songs written by Jeffrey Steele==\n{{main|List of songs written by Jeffrey Steele}}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist|2}}\n\n==External links==\n* [https://web.archive.org/web/20080511172824/http://www.jeffreysteele.net/ Official site]\n* [http://blog.musicbusinessradio.com/ Radio Interview with Jeffrey Steele]\n\n{{Boy Howdy}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Steele, Jeffrey}}\n[[Category:1961 births]]\n[[Category:American country bass guitarists]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Burbank, California]]\n[[Category:Monument Records artists]]\n[[Category:Lofton Creek Records artists]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from California]]\n[[Category:Guitarists from California]]\n[[Category:American male bass guitarists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American bass guitarists]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from California]]\n[[Category:20th-century American male musicians]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Judges in American reality television series]]\n[[Category:Brother Clyde members]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Cowboy_Crush","to":"Cowboy Crush"}],"pages":{"11133558":{"pageid":11133558,"ns":0,"title":"Cowboy Crush","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country music band}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Cowboy Crush\n| image           =\n| caption         =\n| image_size      =\n| origin          = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], United States\n| genre           = [[country music|Country]]\n| years_active    = 2003\u20142009\n| label           = [[Asylum Records|Asylum]]-[[Curb Records|Curb]]\n| past_members = Trenna Barnes<br />Debbie Johnson<br /> Darla Perlozzi<br />[[Becky Priest]]<br />Rena\u00e9 Truex\n}}\n'''Cowboy Crush''' was an American [[country music]] band signed to [[Curb Records]]' Asylum/Curb division. The group is composed of Trenna Barnes ([[lead vocals]]), Debbie Johnson ([[bass guitar]], vocals), Becky Priest ([[Keyboard instrument|keyboards]], vocals), and Rena\u00e9 Truex ([[fiddle]], [[mandolin]]). Until 2006, Darla Perlozzi ([[Drum kit|drums]]) was also a member of the group. Perlozzi co-wrote [[Big & Rich]]'s 2007 single \"Loud\".\n\nAll five founding members of Cowboy Crush had previously worked throughout [[Nashville, Tennessee]] before meeting at [[Belmont University]].<ref name=\"cmt\">[https://web.archive.org/web/20050716075122/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/cowboy_crush/bio.jhtml CMT.com : Cowboy Crush : Biography]</ref> They held their first practice together in a garage on March 18, 2003.<ref name=\"cmt\"/> Cowboy Crush is also known for its high-energy concerts and backstage antics.<ref>[http://www.countrymusicfestival.com/ccrushinfo.htm Cowboy Crush] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070707210902/http://www.countrymusicfestival.com/ccrushinfo.htm |date=2007-07-07 }}</ref> The group's debut single, \"Nobody Ever Died of a Broken Heart\", was previously recorded by [[Trick Pony]]. Cowboy Crush's debut album was released to digital retailers on July 14, 2009.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:10em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Album details\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| ''Cowboy Crush''\n| \n* Release date: July 14, 2009\n* Label: [[Curb Records]]\n|-\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|- \n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:20em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"65\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n|- \n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2005\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Nobody Ever Died of a Broken Heart\"\n| 56\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"He's Coming Home\"\n| \u2014\n|- \n| 2006\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Hillbilly Nation\"<ref>{{cite web | url=https://music.apple.com/us/album/hillbilly-nation-single/129511827 | title='Hillbilly Nation' - Single | publisher=iTunes | accessdate=June 26, 2023}}</ref>\n| \u2014\n|- \n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2007\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Some Men Don't Cheat\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Miss Difficult\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2009\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Tougher Than a Man\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Hillbilly Soldier\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Year\n! style=\"width:20em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 2005\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Nobody Ever Died of a Broken Heart\"\n| Eric Welch\n|-\n| 2007\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Miss Difficult\"\n|\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.cowboycrush.com Official website]\n*[http://www.trennabarnes.com Official Trenna Barnes website]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n[[Category:American all-female bands]]\n[[Category:Country music groups from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Curb Records artists]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 2003]]\n[[Category:Musical groups from Nashville, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:All-female country bands]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Neal_Coty","to":"Neal Coty"}],"pages":{"5229356":{"pageid":5229356,"ns":0,"title":"Neal Coty","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name                = Neal Coty\n| image                 = \n| caption            = \n| image_size            = \n| birth_date = {{birth date and age|1964|5|13}}<ref name=\"whitburn\"/>\n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          = Neal Lee Angleberger<ref name=\"whitburn\"/>\n| origin              = [[Thurmont, Maryland]],  U.S.\n| instrument          = Vocals\n| genre               = [[country music|Country]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = 1997\u2013present\n| label               = [[Mercury Nashville Records|Mercury Nashville]]\n}}\n'''Neal Lee Angleberger''' (born May 13, 1964), known professionally as '''Neal Coty''', is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. He has released two albums for [[Mercury Records Nashville]], and has written several singles for other artists.\n\n==Biography==\nCoty was born Neal Lee Angleberger on May 13, 1964, in [[Thurmont, Maryland]].<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2017|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2017|page=93|isbn=978-0-89820-229-8}}</ref> He was adopted at an early age, and never met his biological father.<ref name=\"hurst\">{{cite web | url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1997-07-04-9707040172-story.html | title=At the margins of country, Neal Coty may be the next big thing | publisher=The Chicago Tribune | date=July 4, 1997 | accessdate=July 25, 2020 | author=Jack Hurst}}</ref> Coty drew musical inspiration from his uncles, who were fans of both country music and [[Southern rock]]. He began playing guitar as a child after his grandmother gave him one.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nAfter graduating high school, Coty attended a cosmetology school, but dropped out after only two months.<ref name=\"hurst\"/> He then attended a theater program at [[Towson University]] as a young adult, and would perform his own material during open-mic nights. He was booked as a touring act for [[Kathy Mattea]] after being discovered by a talent agent.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/neal-coty-mn0000380597/biography | title=Neal Coty biography | publisher=AllMusic | accessdate=July 25, 2020 | author=Zac Johnson}}</ref> Next he spent time in [[New York City]] and [[Los Angeles]] in pursuit of an acting career; in the latter city, he found some small success writing commercial jingles.<ref name=\"stark\"/> Encouraged by a friend, he then moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] to pursue a country music career, something which he was inspired to do by reading the names of the songwriters on album liner notes.<ref name=\"stark\"/> Through the assistance of a music publisher, he then began writing songs with [[Randy VanWarmer]] and [[Roger Murrah]]; one of these songs, \"Collect from Wichita\", was cut by [[Ronna Reeves]].<ref name=\"hurst\"/> From this songwriting success came a contract with [[Mercury Records Nashville]], which issued his debut album ''[[Chance and Circumstance]]'' in 1997. The album was produced by [[Keith Stegall]], best known for his work with [[Alan Jackson]].<ref name=\"hurst\"/> \"Tainted\" was sent to country radio as the album's lead single that same year.<ref name=\"robert\"/> Mike Joyce of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reviewed the album favorably, calling him \"a first-rate storyteller who puts most of the competition in country music to shame.\"<ref name=\"chance\">{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1997/09/19/neal-coty/18800afd-e8a2-4b75-86b3-8c622e3c6a08/ | title=''Chance and Circumstance'' review | newspaper=The Washington Post | date=September 19, 1997 | accessdate=July 25, 2020 | author=Mike Joyce}}</ref>\n\nCoty released his second Mercury album, ''Legacy'', in 2001. The album's title track served as lead single, spending eleven weeks on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts and peaking at number 49.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Coty wrote six of the album's eleven tracks, also covering [[Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers]]' \"[[You Got Lucky]]\" and [[Bruce Springsteen]]'s \"[[Sad Eyes (Bruce Springsteen song)|Sad Eyes]]\". The title track was inspired by a line of dialogue from an episode of the television series ''[[Ally McBeal]]''.<ref name=\"stark\">{{cite magazine | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/00s/2001/BB-2001-02-10.pdf | title=Coty hopes to have 'Legacy' with Mercury set | author=Phyllis Stark | magazine=Billboard | pages=43 | date=February 10, 2001}}</ref> To promote the album, Coty drove to various radio stations in a truck with his picture painted on it, and the label partnered with [[Jones Radio Networks]] and the television channel [[Great American Country]] (GAC) to hold a sweepstakes in which said truck was the grand prize.<ref name=\"stark\"/> Ray Waddell of ''Billboard'' reviewed ''Legacy'' favorably, stating that Coty was in \"creative, confident mode\" and calling him an \"edgy yet melodic tunesmith\".<ref name=\"legacy review\">{{cite magazine | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/00s/2001/BB-2001-03-10.pdf | title=Reviews & Previews: Albums | magazine=Billboard | pages=30 | date=March 10, 2001}}</ref> Kevin Oliver of [[Country Standard Time]] was more mixed, stating that Coty was \"more focused on mainstream country sounds than his debut\" but \"sounds too much like others and not himself\".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=2043 | title=''Legacy'' review | publisher=Country Standard Time | accessdate=July 25, 2020 | author=Kevin Oliver}}</ref>\n\nCoty has not recorded an album since ''Legacy'', although he has continued to write songs since the album's release. Six songs that he co-wrote have been Hot Country Songs entries for other artists: \"[[She Was]]\" by [[Mark Chesnutt]], \"[[Every Friday Afternoon]]\" by [[Craig Morgan]], \"I'm One of You\" by [[Hank Williams Jr.]], \"[[Playboys of the Southwestern World]]\" by [[Blake Shelton]], \"Last Good Time\" by [[Flynnville Train]], and \"[[Real (James Wesley song)|Real]]\" by [[James Wesley]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.musicvf.com/songs.php?page=artist&artist=Neal+Coty&tab=songaswriterchartstab | title=Songs written by Neal Coty | publisher=MusicVF | accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> Coty has been signed to Roger Murrah's publishing company Murrah Music Group since 1994, and between 2006 and 2007 he was also part of a [[joint venture]] with Bicycle Music.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/1316977/coty-murrah-music-ink-exclusive-deal | title=Coty, Murrah Music Ink Exclusive Deal | publisher=Billboard | date=November 9, 2007 | accessdate=July 25, 2020}}</ref> Murrah Music Group was acquired by Bug Music in 2009.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/1274259/bug-music-pub-murrah-music-sign-catalog-deal | title=Bug Music Pub, Murrah Music Sign Catalog Deal | publisher=Billboard | date=February 19, 2009 | accessdate=July 25, 2020 | author=Ed Christman}}</ref>\n\n==Musical style==\nPhyllis Stark of ''Billboard'' wrote that Coty \"plays the [[hillbilly]] card to mask a sharp intelligence that, nevertheless, reveals itself in his songwriting.\"<ref name=\"stark\"/> The same publication's Ray Waddell compared Coty's storytelling songs favorably to those of [[Steve Earle]],<ref name=\"legacy review\"/> a comparison also made by Mike Joyce of ''The Washington Post''.<ref name=\"chance\"/>\n\n==Personal life==\nAt the time that ''Legacy'' was released, Coty had been on his second marriage. He had one son and one daughter with his then-wife, Kelly, who also had two children from her previous marriage.<ref name=\"stark\"/><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.fredericknewspost.com/archives/thurmont-native-a-hit-with-country-crowd/article_7cf09051-1bb5-5ba4-8d18-1fdbaf9bca88.html | title=Thurmont native a hit with country crowd | work=The Frederick News Post | date=December 9, 2000 | accessdate=July 25, 2020 | author=Barbara Brown}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:14em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Chance and Circumstance]]''\n| \n* Release date: August 5, 1997\n* Label: [[Universal Music Group Nashville|Mercury Nashville]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Legacy''\n| \n* Release date: March 6, 2001\n* Label: Mercury Nashville\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:19em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"60\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]<br /><ref name=\"whitburn\"/>\n|-\n| 1997\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Tainted\"<ref name=\"robert\">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/113420567/ | title=Not exactly what's expected: Neal Coty's original lyrics and style define his debut album | work=[[The Tennessean]] | date=September 26, 1997 | accessdate=July 25, 2020 | author=Robert K. Oermann | author-link=Robert K. Oermann | pages=4F}}</ref>\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| ''Chance and Circumstance''\n|-\n| 2000\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Legacy\"\n| 49\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=2| ''Legacy''\n|-\n| 2001\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Right Down Through the Middle of Us\"<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-RandR/2000s/2001/RR-2001-07-06.pdf | title=New & Active | journal=Radio & Records | pages=60 | date=July 6, 2001}}</ref>\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Year\n! style=\"width:10em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 1997 \n! scope=\"row\"| \"Tainted\"<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5ynEJho2fdk  |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211214/5ynEJho2fdk |archive-date=2021-12-14 |url-status=live| title='Tainted' video | publisher=Vevo | accessdate=July 25, 2020}}{{cbignore}}</ref>\n| \n|-\n| 2000\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Legacy\"<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5RAEAAAAMBAJ&dq=%22Brad+Murano%22+%22legacy%22&pg=PA99 | title=Production notes | magazine=Billboard | pages=99 | date=November 11, 2000}}</ref>\n| rowspan=\"2\"| Steven T. Miller/Brad Murano\n|-\n| 2001\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Breathin'\"<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MhQEAAAAMBAJ&dq=%22neal+coty%22+%22Breathin%22&pg=PA93 | title=Production notes | magazine=Billboard | pages=93 | date=July 14, 2001}}</ref>\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Coty, Neal}}\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Mercury Records artists]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Maryland]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Maryland]]\n[[Category:People from Frederick, Maryland]]\n[[Category:1964 births]]\n[[Category:American adoptees]]\n[[Category:People from Thurmont, Maryland]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Katie_Armiger","to":"Katie Armiger"}],"pages":{"12646357":{"pageid":12646357,"ns":0,"title":"Katie Armiger","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Country music singer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2016}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|name         = Katie Armiger\n|image        = Katie Armiger 7-28-11 Everett, Washington.jpg\n|caption      = Katie Armiger performs on July 28, 2011, in Everett, Washington\n|background   = solo_singer\n|birth_name   = Kaitlyn Michelle Armiger\n|birth_date   = {{birth date and age|1991|6|23}}\n|origin       = [[Sugar Land, Texas]], U.S.\n|genre        = [[Country music|Country]]\n|occupation   = Singer\n|instrument   = Guitar, vocals\n|years_active = 2007\u20132015\n|label        = Cold River\n|website      = {{URL|http://www.katiearmiger.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Kaitlyn Michelle Armiger''' (born June 23, 1991) is a country artist from [[Sugar Land, Texas]], U.S. She was first inspired to pursue country music after winning a [[Houston]], [[Texas]], citywide competition for young country singers.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=2007_4355797 |title=Chron.com{{!}}News, search and shopping from the Houston Chronicle<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=August 7, 2007 |archive-date=October 16, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121016171737/http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=2007_4355797 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>Guerra, Joey (May 30, 2007). ''[[Houston Chronicle]]'', \"Katie Armiger, 16, dreams about a career in music.\"</ref> As of 2014, Armiger has released four albums for Cold River Records and has charted seven singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] and [[Country Airplay]] charts.\n\n==Career==\nKatie Armiger's self-titled debut album was released on Cold River Records in the U.S. on August 21, 2007. It was produced by Mark Oliverius, the producer for other country acts such as [[Lorrie Morgan]] and [[Trick Pony]].<ref>[http://www.omgnashville.com/comments.htm OMG Nashville - Oliverius Music Group<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070811172925/http://www.omgnashville.com/comments.htm |date=August 11, 2007 }}</ref> The first seven tracks of her album were co-written by Armiger with Oliverius and [[Ashlee Hewitt]].\n\nArmiger entered the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart for the first time in 2010 with \"Kiss Me Now,\" which reached a peak of number 55. It served as the lead-off to her third album, ''Confessions of a Nice Girl'', which was released in October 2010, and became her first album to chart. It charted on both Billboard Top Country Albums and Billboard Heatseekers. This album was Armiger's first self-titled album and featured nine tracks that Armiger co-wrote with Nashville songwriters. \"Leaving Home\" and \"Best Song Ever\" followed as the album's second and third singles, the former failed to chart, while the latter peaked at number 42. Her third album was re-released on September 20, 2011 to include her fourth single, \"I Do But Do I\", which was released to radio on July 11, 2011.<ref name=new>In October 2011, Katie released her fourth charting single, SCREAM, which hit 47 on the Billboard Charts.  [http://www.musicrow.com/2011/07/new-releases-coming-katie-armiger-and-reggaes-gone-country/ New Releases Coming: Katie Armiger and Reggae\u2019s Gone Country]</ref> The re-release also included three more new songs, a dance mix of \"Best Song Ever\", and the music videos for \"I Do But Do I\" and \"Best Song Ever.\"<ref name=new/> \"Scream,\" which was released as the fifth and final single from the album in October 2011, peaked at number 47 on the Hot Country Songs chart.\n\n\"Better in a Black Dress\" was released in mid-June 2012, debuting at number 54 on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'''s [[Hot Country Songs]] chart for the week of June 23, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2012-06-23/country-songs?order=gainer |title=The Wind - Zac Brown Band |publisher=Billboard Magazine|accessdate=October 8, 2012}}</ref> Since then, the song has become her highest charting single. The album that followed on January 22, 2013, ''[[Fall Into Me (album)|Fall Into Me]]'', became her highest charting album to date. It marked Armiger's first entry on the [[Independent Albums]] chart (No. 6) and the all-genre [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] (No. 32). It also became her first top 10 country album, debuting at number 7. The album's second single, \"Playin' with Fire\", was released February 11, 2013.\n\nKatie Armiger left the music business in 2015. She later said she had been blacklisted after complaining about sexual harassment.  Lawsuits between Armiger and Cold River Records and its founder Pete O\u2019Heeron were settled in 2019.  Terms of the settlement are confidential.<ref>{{Cite web | date= | title=Country Aircheck &#124;&#124; News | url=https://www.countryaircheck.com/art/35660 | website=CountryAircheck.com | access-date=March 16, 2019 | quote=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | last=Country | first=Taste of | date=June 18, 2015 | title=Katie Armiger taking 'a breather' from country music career | url=https://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/katie-armiger-taking-a-breather-from-country-music-career | website=FoxNews.com | publisher=FOX News Network, LLC | access-date=March 16, 2019 | quote=Katie Armiger has abruptly called off her upcoming album after deciding to put her country music career on hold.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=October 25, 2019|publisher=Rolling Stone|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/katie-armiger-cold-river-records-lawsuit-pete-oheeron-903936/|title= Katie Armiger, Cold River Records Settle Breach of Contract Lawsuit}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! (July 12, 2007) ''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' \"Faces in the crowd/Sugar Land teen spends summer on the road/Katie Armiger promotes first CD of country music.\" Section: This week; Page 2.\n* Broadcast News (August 8, 2007) ''[http://www.wqdr.net/misc14284.asp Prep-Country Road.]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}'' (reprinted by WQDR-94.7 FM).\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Armiger, Katie}}\n[[Category:1991 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:People from Sugar Land, Texas]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American child singers]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Texas]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Texas]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Brad_Martin","to":"Brad Martin"}],"pages":{"11933822":{"pageid":11933822,"ns":0,"title":"Brad Martin","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country music singer-songwriter (1973\u20132022)}}\n{{other people}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image           =\n| name            = Brad Martin\n| image_size      =\n| birth_name      = Bradley Curtis Martin\n| birth_date      = {{birth date|1973|5|3}}\n| birth_place     = [[Chillicothe, Ohio]], U.S.\n| death_date      = {{death date and age|2022|3|11|1973|5|3}}\n| death_place     = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| instrument      = Vocals\n| genre           = [[country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 2002\u20132022\n| label           = [[Epic Records|Epic]], [[Curb Records|Curb]]\n| past_member_of = Martin Ramey\n}}\n\n'''Bradley Curtis Martin''' (May 3, 1973 \u2013 March 11, 2022)<ref name=\"obi\">{{cite web |url=https://www.murrayfettro.com/obituary/bradley-martin|title=Bradley Curtis Martin 1973 - 2022 Obituary|date=|accessdate=August 13, 2022|website=murrayfettro.com}}</ref> was an American [[country music]] singer-songwriter. He made his debut on the American country music scene in 2002 with the release of his debut album ''[[Wings of a Honky-Tonk Angel]]'', which produced the No. 15 single \"[[Before I Knew Better]]\". In 2008, he and songwriter John Ramey briefly founded the duo Martin Ramey.\n\n==Biography==\nMartin was taught to play the guitar at an early age. He later gained an interest in songwriting, and moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] in his early 20s.<ref name=\"allmusic\">[{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p304699/biography|pure_url=yes}} AllMusic ((( Brad Martin > Biography )))]</ref> He performed daily in a nightclub, and was eventually spotted by Joe Carter, an artist manager who had previously worked with [[Tracy Byrd]].<ref name=\"about\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.liveabout.com/country-4688258|title=Country|website=LiveAbout.com}}</ref> Carter saw potential in the young artist and he was soon signed to Sony Epic Record Label.<ref name=\"about\"/>\n\nMartin was signed to [[Epic Records]] in 2000. His debut single, \"Before I Knew Better\", was released in 2002, the first single from his debut album ''Wings of a Honky-Tonk Angel''.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/><ref name=\"about\"/> The album received a favorable review from [[About.com]] for its neotraditionalist sound.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.liveabout.com/country-artists-similar-to-george-strait-933904|title=5 Country Artists Similar to George Strait|first=Shelly|last=Fabian|website=LiveAbout.com}}</ref> In addition, \"Before I Knew Better\" won an award from [[Broadcast Music Incorporated|BMI]] for being among the fifty most played country songs of 2003.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1480197/20031105/id_0.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930040757/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1480197/20031105/id_0.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=September 30, 2007|website=Cmt.com |title=2003 BMI Award Winners}}</ref> However, the second single from ''Wings of a Honky-Tonk Angel'', \"Rub Me The Right Way\", failed to make Top 40, as did \"Just Like Love\". A non-album single, \"One of Those Days\", followed in 2003 before Martin exited Epic's roster. He remained inactive in country music until joining songwriter John Ramey to found the duo Martin Ramey in 2008. Martin Ramey signed to [[Curb Records]] that year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soundclick.com/bands/default.cfm?bandID=907965|title=Martin Ramey|website=Soundclick.com|accessdate=June 6, 2009}}</ref>\n\nMartin died in Nashville on March 11, 2022, at the age of 48.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Whitaker |first1=Sterling |title=Country Hitmaker Brad Martin Dead At 48 |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/country-singer-brad-martin-dead-dies/ |access-date=12 March 2022 |publisher=Taste of Country |date=12 March 2022}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"2\"| Peak chart<br />positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[Top Heatseekers|US Heat]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Wings of a Honky-Tonk Angel]]''\n| \n* Release date: June 18, 2002\n* Label: [[Epic Records]]\n| 34\n| 32\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:14em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"2\"| Peak chart<br />positions\n! rowspan=\"2\" |Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[Bubbling Under Hot 100|US Bubbling]]\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 2002\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Before I Knew Better]]\"\n| 15\n| 8\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"3\"| ''Wings of a Honky-Tonk Angel''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Rub Me the Right Way\"\n| 51\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Just Like Love\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2003\n! scope=\"row\"| \"One of Those Days\"\n| 50\n| \u2014\n| {{NA}}\n|-\n| colspan=\"5\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Year\n! style=\"width:14em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 2002\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Before I Knew Better\"\n| [[Shaun Silva]]\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* {{discogs artist|Brad Martin (2)}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Martin, Brad}}\n[[Category:1973 births]]\n[[Category:2022 deaths]]\n[[Category:Epic Records artists]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Ohio]]\n[[Category:People from Greenfield, Ohio]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Ohio]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jeff_Cook","to":"Jeff Cook"}],"pages":{"11193804":{"pageid":11193804,"ns":0,"title":"Jeff Cook","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2023}}\n{{Short description|American country musician (1949\u20132022)}}\n{{Other people}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Jeff Cook\n| image            = Jeff Cook.jpg\n| caption          = Cook performing with [[Alabama (band)|Alabama]] in 2014\n| image_size       = \n| birth_name       = Jeffrey Alan Cook\n| birth_date       = {{Birth date|1949|08|27}}\n| birth_place      = [[Fort Payne, Alabama]], U.S.\n| instrument       = Vocals, guitar, fiddle, piano\n| death_date       = {{Death date and age|2022|11|07|1949|08|27}}\n| death_place      = [[Destin, Florida]], U.S.\n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]], [[country rock]]\n| occupation       = Musician, songwriter\n| years_active     = 1972\u20132022\n| past_member_of = [[Alabama (band)|Alabama]]\n}}\n\n'''Jeffrey Alan Cook''' (August 27, 1949 \u2013 November 7, 2022) was an American [[country music|country]] musician. He was best known for being a founding member of the band [[Alabama (band)|Alabama]], in which he contributed to occasional lead vocals, guitar, [[fiddle]], piano and other musical instruments.\n\n==Life and career==\nJeffrey Alan Cook was born in [[Fort Payne, Alabama]]. He was a graduate of [[Fort Payne City Schools|Fort Payne High School]] and [[Jacksonville State University]]. He obtained a [[Broadcast engineering|broadcast engineer]] license three days after his fourteenth birthday, and worked at a local radio station as a [[disc jockey]] while still in high school.<ref name=\"official\">[http://cookandglenn.com/bio_jeff.html Jeff Cook and the AGB: Jeff Cook biography]</ref>\n\nCook co-founded the band Wildcountry, along with his cousins [[Randy Owen]] and Teddy Gentry, in 1972 (the name was changed to Alabama in 1977).  He contributed lead as well as backing vocals, lead guitar, keyboard, and fiddle to the group's productions.<ref>[{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1500|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic Biography: Alabama]</ref>  Since the band ceased active production and performance in 2004, Cook has formed the groups Cook & Glenn and the Allstar Goodtime Band, with which he performed.<ref>\"Songwriters Honored with Special Concert,\" ''The Huntsville Times'', September 13, 2007, p. 7G</ref>\n\nIn addition to his performance work, Cook founded Cook Sound Studios, Inc., in his native Fort Payne, and also established radio station WQRX-AM, which he later sold, in adjacent [[Valley Head, Alabama]].<ref name =\"official\"/>  Cook is also noted for his culinary endeavors, having operated a restaurant and marketed his own sauce.<ref>\"Cook's 'Zesty' Hobby a Feature of Saturday Event,\" ''The Huntsville Times'', July 25, 2007, p, 1C</ref>\n\nCook endorsed the 2008 presidential candidacy of former [[Arkansas]] governor [[Mike Huckabee]], and made appearances with the candidate in Alabama.<ref>[http://blog.al.com/spotnews/2008/02/huckabee_tells_huntsville_crow.html \"Huckabee Tells Huntsville Crowd He'll Stay in Race,\" ''The Birmingham News'' blogs, February 2, 2008]</ref>\n\nCook was inducted into the [[Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum]] in 2019.\n\n==Personal life and death==\nOn April 11, 2017, Cook disclosed that he was diagnosed with [[Parkinson's disease]] four years earlier. He stopped touring regularly with Alabama in 2018,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2017/04/11/exclusive-alabama-member-reveals-parkinsons-diagnosis/100325784/|title=Exclusive: Alabama member reveals Parkinson's diagnosis|work=USA TODAY|access-date=May 27, 2017|language=en}}</ref> but did join the band for their 50th Anniversary tour in 2022.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Raucoules |first1=Gregory |title=Alabama 50th Anniversary Tour coming to Knoxville |url=https://www.wate.com/news/local-news/alabama-50th-anniversary-tour-coming-to-knoxville/ |access-date=March 19, 2022 |work=WATE 6 On Your Side |date=February 15, 2022}}</ref> Cook died of complications from Parkinson's disease in [[Destin, Florida]], on November 7, 2022, at the age of 73.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/jeff-cook-alabama-guitarist-dead-obituary-1234627084/ | title=Jeff Cook, Alabama Co-Founder and Guitarist, Dead at 73 | magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] | date=November 8, 2022 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2022/11/08/jeff-cook-alabama-2022-band-co-founding-member-dies/69611215007/ | title=Jeff Cook, co-founding member of country band Alabama, dies at 73 | work=[[The Tennessean]] | date=November 8, 2022 | accessdate=November 8, 2022 | author=Matthew Leimkuehler}}</ref>\n\n==Solo discography ==\n*2005: ''On Fire''\n*2008: ''Just Pickin'''\n*2009: ''Ashes Won't Burn''\n*2009: ''Jeff Cook Presents Christmas Joy''\n*2009: \"Tribute to a Soldier\" (single with [[Charlie Daniels]] and Ken Randolph)\n*2010: ''Shaken... Not Stirred''\n*2011: ''2 Rock 4 Country''\n*2011: ''Bits & Pieces / Odds & Ends''\n*2012: ''Shaken Not Stirred''\n*2018: ''Why Not Me'' with William Shatner\n\n== References ==\n{{Reflist}}\nhttps://www.mynewsletterbuilder.com/email/newsletter/1416074853\n\n==External links==\n{{cc}}\n*[http://www.jeffcook-agb.com/index.html Jeff Cook and the AGB] official website\n*[http://www.thealabamaband.com/ The Alabama Band] official website\n* {{discogs artist|Jeff Cook (2)}}\n* {{imdb name|1187954}}\n\n{{Alabama (band)|Alabama}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Cook, Jeff}}\n[[Category:1949 births]]\n[[Category:2022 deaths]]\n[[Category:Alabama (American band) members]]\n[[Category:Alabama Republicans]]\n[[Category:American country fiddlers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Deaths from Parkinson's disease in Florida]]\n[[Category:People from Fort Payne, Alabama]]\n[[Category:Country Music Hall of Fame inductees]]\n[[Category:Members of the Country Music Association]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Alabama]]\n[[Category:Jacksonville State University alumni]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Donny_Parenteau","to":"Donny Parenteau"}],"pages":{"31167506":{"pageid":31167506,"ns":0,"title":"Donny Parenteau","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Canadian musician}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2021}}\n{{Use Canadian English|date=November 2021}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Donny Parenteau\n| image            = \n| alt              = \n| caption          = \n| image_size       = \n| birth_name       = \n| alias            = \n| birth_date       = \n| birth_place      = [[Prince Albert, Saskatchewan]]\n| origin           = \n| death_date       = <!-- {{death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date 1st) -->\n| death_place      = \n| genre            = {{flatlist|\n*[[Country music|Country]]\n*[[Western swing]]<ref name=calledbycountry>{{Cite web|url=https://www.saskmusic.org/news/cover-artists/view,artist/249/donny-parenteau|first=Lorena|last=Kelly|title=Donny Parenteau: Called by Country|publisher=Sask Music|accessdate=14 April 2020}}</ref>\n}}\n| occupation       = {{flatlist|\n*Musician\n*singer-songwriter\n*record producer\n}}\n| instrument       = {{flatlist|\n*[[Fiddle]]\n*acoustic guitar\n*electric guitar\n*[[mandolin]]\n*[[electric mandolin]]\n*double neck guitar and mandocaster<ref name=calledbycountry/>\n}}\n| years_active     = 1991\u2013present\n| label            = Independent, 306 Records/[[EMI Music Canada]]\n| associated_acts  = {{flatlist|\n*[[Neal McCoy]]\n*[[Brad Johner]]\n*[[Sierra Noble]]\n}}\n| website          = http://www.donnyparenteaumusic.com\n}}\n\n'''Donny Parenteau''' (born in [[Prince Albert, Saskatchewan]]) is singer-songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, and record producer.  He is best for known his solo career and his work as fiddle player, guitarist, and mandolin player for country music singer [[Neal McCoy]].  In February 2011, Parenteau signed with the record label 306 Records/[[EMI Music Canada]] to help distribute his albums.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://cashboxcanada.ca/donny-parenteau-signs-%E2%80%9C360-recordsemi-0|title = Donny Parenteau signs with \"360 Records/EMI|publisher = CashBoxCanada.ca|date = 18 February 2011|accessdate = 12 March 2011}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nAt 14, Parenteau took up the fiddle.  After mastering the fiddle, he picked up other instruments like the guitar (both acoustic and electric) and the mandolin (both acoustic and electric).  Parenteau cites some of his influences as Bryan Sklar,<ref name=calledbycountry/> Freddie Pelltier,<ref name=calledbycountry/> and George Pistun<ref name=calledbycountry/>\n\n==Career==\nAfter picking up the violin at a young age, by 19 he was playing professionally.<ref name=calledbycountry/> In 1991, Parenteau was playing in [[Edmonton|Edmonton, Alberta]] and was invited to a show by Neal McCoy who was also playing in Edmonton.<ref name=calledbycountry/> Upon talking with McCoy, Parenteau discovered they had similar taste in music.<ref name=calledbycountry/> McCoy was looking for a fiddle player, but didn't have the money to hire one.  Parenteau wanted the chance to audition and would not let up until he got the chance to audition.  Parenteau listened to the group [[Jam session|jamming]] and had a grasp of what they were playing.  It was that song he would use as the audition piece.<ref name=calledbycountry/> During his time touring with McCoy, Parenteau got to open for such artists as [[Merle Haggard]],<ref name=calledbycountry/> [[Tim McGraw]],<ref name=calledbycountry/> [[Faith Hill]],<ref name=calledbycountry/> [[Buck Owens]],<ref name=calledbycountry/> [[George Jones]],<ref name=calledbycountry/> [[Charlie Pride]],<ref name=calledbycountry/> [[Loretta Lynn]],<ref name=calledbycountry/> [[Charlie Daniels]],<ref name=calledbycountry/> [[Hank Williams, Jr.]],<ref name=calledbycountry/> [[Reba McEntire]],<ref name=calledbycountry/> [[Garth Brooks]],<ref name=calledbycountry/> and [[Shania Twain]].<ref name=calledbycountry/> Parenteau also graced the [[Grand Ole Opry]] stage.<ref name=calledbycountry/> Parenteau was the only member of the live band that was also on the recordings.<ref name=calledbycountry/> After performing with Neal McCoy for 12 years and playing 250\u2013300 shows a year, Parenteau returned to Prince Albert to embark on a solo career.<ref name=calledbycountry/>\n\n==Charity work==\nParenteau has done a number of humanitarian and charity work.  In 2001 SCMA International Humanitarian Award for his efforts.  He also appears on [[Telemiracle]] starting on the 32nd edition of the telethon.  Parenteau co-wrote the current Telemiracle opening theme song with [[Brad Johner]] entitled \"You are the Miracle\".  It became the theme in 2011.  He also embarks on a tour of elementary schools in Saskatchewan each year as a motivational speaker in which he spreads his message of anti-bullying.\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center\"\n|-\n!scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"1\" style=\"width:24em;\"|Title\n!scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"1\" style=\"width:19em;\"|Album details\n|-\n! In 2008, Parenteau was nominated for his country's highest honour by being nominated for a Juno Award.\n\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! style=\"text-align:center;\"|Year\n! 2022}}</ref>\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.donnyparenteaumusic.com Official website]\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Parenteau, Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Sonya_Isaacs","to":"Sonya Isaacs"}],"pages":{"15101458":{"pageid":15101458,"ns":0,"title":"Sonya Isaacs","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2019}} \n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name             = Sonya Isaacs\n| image            = Sonya_Isaacs.jpg\n| caption          = \n| image_size       = \n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = Sonya Melissa Isaacs<ref>{{cite web|url=http://repertoire.bmi.com/writer.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&page=1&fromrow=1&torow=25&querytype=WriterID&keyid=167141&keyname=ISAACS+SONYA+MELISSA&CAE=223528489&Affiliation=BMI|title=Search results for Isaacs, Sonya Melissa|work=[[Broadcast Music Incorporated]]|access-date=December 23, 2010}}</ref>\n| birth_place      = \n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1974|07|22}}<ref>{{cite journal |date=July 28, 2008 |title=Birthdays |journal=[[Country Weekly]] |volume=15 |issue=15 |pages=62}}</ref>\n| origin           = [[LaFollette, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| instrument       = [[singing|Vocals]], [[mandolin]]\n| genre            = Bluegrass, and Southern Gospel\n| occupation       = [[Singing|Singer]], [[songwriter]]\n| years_active     = 1999\u2013present\n| label            = [[Lyric Street Records|Lyric Street]]\n| current_member_of = [[The Isaacs]]\n| spouse = {{marriage|[[Jimmy Yeary]]|2009}}\n}}\n'''Sonya Melissa Isaacs''' (born July 22, 1974) is an American [[country music|country]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass gospel]] and [[Christian music]] singer. Isaacs grew up near [[Morrow, Ohio]], and graduated from [[Little Miami High School (Ohio)|Little Miami High School]] in 1992. Her maternal  grandparents are [[The Holocaust in Poland|Polish Jewish Holocaust]] survivors and were liberated from a concentration camp in Germany in 1945.<ref name=\"lufkin\">{{cite news |last1=BARCLAY |first1=BRITTANY |title=The Isaacs to bring bluegrass gospel to The Pines |url=https://lufkindailynews.com/news/community/article_94d60ad4-b88c-5651-a672-7ce01b2b7c36.html |access-date=12 July 2021 |work=The Lufkin Daily News |language=en}}</ref><ref name=\"people\">{{cite news |last1=Etienne |first1=Vanessa |title=The Isaacs Premiere 'The American Face' Music Video: 'United We Stand' |url=https://people.com/music/isaacs-premiere-the-american-face-music-video-united-we-stand/ |access-date=12 July 2021 |work=PEOPLE.com |language=en}}</ref>\n\nShe has released one album on [[Lyric Street Records]], and has charted five singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. Three were included on her self-titled debut album, released in 2000. A fourth was a Christmas single included on the label's multi-artist collection ''No Wrapping Required: A Christmas Album''. Her highest-charting single, \"No Regrets Yet\", peaked at number 36 on the country charts but did not appear on an album.\n\nShe parted ways with Lyric Street in 2004.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allbusiness.com/transportation-communications/communications-radio/4361802-1.html |title=On the Row: Compadre Records Signs Three Artists |access-date=January 4, 2008 |last=Stark |first=Phyllis |date=March 12, 2004 |work=Airplay Monitors}}</ref> Isaacs, along with several of her family members, also comprise a [[gospel music]] band called [[The Isaacs]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/isaacs/bio.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050225200135/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/isaacs/bio.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 25, 2005 |title=The Isaacs biography |access-date=January 4, 2008 |work=[[Country Music Television]]}}</ref> Sonya recorded the song \"The Battlefield\" for the soundtrack to the 2006 film ''[[Broken Bridges]]''. She and [[Vince Gill]] contributed guest vocals to a cover of \"[[Misty (song)|Misty]]\" on [[Cledus T. Judd]]'s 2007 tribute album ''[[Boogity, Boogity \u2013 A Tribute to the Comedic Genius of Ray Stevens]]''.\n\nShe also sang a duet with [[Dolly Parton]] to \"The Angels Rejoiced\".\n\nIsaacs married singer-songwriter [[Jimmy Yeary]] on December 20, 2009, with whom she co-wrote [[Martina McBride]]'s 2011 single \"[[I'm Gonna Love You Through It]]\".\n\nIsaacs and Yeary have two sons born in 2011 and 2015, and a daughter born in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|author=Brad Schmitt |url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/2016/08/26/sonya-isaacs-healing-stillborn-birth/89225046/ |title=Sonya Isaacs healing from stillborn birth |publisher=Tennessean.com |access-date=August 26, 2016}}</ref>\n\nAs a member of ''The Isaacs'', Isaacs became a [[List of Grand Ole Opry members|member]] of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] in 2021.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ricky Skaggs invites family bluegrass group The Isaacs to become Grand Ole Opry members |url=https://www.tennessean.com/videos/entertainment/2021/08/11/ricky-skaggs-invites-family-bluegrass-group-isaacs-become-grand-ole-opry-members/5566500001/ |access-date=8 March 2022 |work=The Tennessean}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Opry in the News: The Isaacs Inducted as Newest Members |url=https://www.opry.com/story/opry-in-the-news-the-isaacs-inducted-as-newest-members/ |website=Grand Ole Opry |access-date=8 March 2022 |language=en}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n!
