Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Bill_Engvall","to":"Bill Engvall"}],"pages":{"1539811":{"pageid":1539811,"ns":0,"title":"Bill Engvall","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American comedian and actor}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2022}}\n{{Infobox person \n| name = Bill Engvall\n| image = Bill Engvall 2010.jpg\n| caption = Engvall performing at the USO Gala in the Marriott Wardman Park Hotel in Washington, D.C., in October 2010\n| birth_name = William Ray Engvall Jr.\n| birth_date = {{birth date and age|1957|7|27}} \n| birth_place = [[Galveston, Texas]], U.S.\n| death_date = \n| death_place =  \n| alma_mater = \n| years_active = 1988\u20132022\n| occupation = {{flatlist|\n* Comedian\n* actor\n}}\n| parents = \n| signature = \n| known_for          =  {{plainlist|\n* [[Blue Collar Comedy Tour]]\n* ''[[The Jeff Foxworthy Show]]''\n* ''Country Fried Home Videos''\n* ''[[Delta Farce]]''\n* ''[[The Bill Engvall Show]]''\n* ''[[Lingo (U.S. game show)|Lingo]]'' (2011 Run)\n}}\n| spouse = {{marriage|Mary Gail Watson|1982}}\n| children = 2\n| module = \n{{Infobox comedian|embed=yes\n| medium = {{flatlist|\n* Stand-up\n* film\n* television\n}}\n| genre = {{flatlist|\n* Country comedy\n* {{nowrap|[[observational comedy]]}}\n* satire\n}}\n| subject = {{plainlist|\n* [[Culture of the Southern United States|Southern American culture]]\n* everyday life\n* marriage\n* [[parenting]]\n* [[self-deprecation]]\n}}\n| website = {{URL|billengvall.com}}\n}}\n}}\n\n'''William Ray Engvall Jr.''' (born July 27, 1957)<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> is an  American  retired stand-up comedian, actor, and television host. Engvall has released a number of stand-up comedy albums through [[Warner Records]] and the defunct [[BNA Records]]. His commercially successful album is the 1996 debut ''[[Here's Your Sign]]'', certified platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]]. The album derives its name from Engvall's signature routine \"here's your sign\", wherein he offers \"signs\" to people whom he deems lacking in intellect. He has toured as a comedian both by himself and as a member of [[Blue Collar Comedy Tour]], which included [[Jeff Foxworthy]], [[Larry the Cable Guy]], and [[Ron White]]. Engvall's television roles include ''[[Delta (American TV series)|Delta]]'', ''[[The Jeff Foxworthy Show]]'', ''[[The Bill Engvall Show]]'', and ''[[Lingo (American game show)|Lingo]]''.\n\n==Early life==\nWilliam Ray Engvall Jr. was born in [[Galveston, Texas]] on July 27, 1957.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> His father, William Ray Engvall Sr., was a U.S. Navy doctor, who then went into private practice. Engvall spent most of his childhood living first in Galveston, then in [[Winslow, Arizona]], then moving back to near [[Dallas]], Texas during middle school. Following graduation from [[Richardson High School]] in [[Richardson, Texas]], where he chose trombone when the teacher gave him the choice of either that or the tuba which led him into the jazz marching band,<ref>{{Cite book |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=b2Y4LyfBBkQC&dq=Bill+Engvall+trombone&pg=PA89 |title=Just a Guy |publisher=[[St. Martin\u2019s Press]] |year=2007 |isbn=9780312362676 |accessdate=May 8, 2022}}</ref> Engvall attended [[Southwestern University]] in [[Georgetown, Texas]], intending to earn a bachelor's degree and become a teacher.<ref name=\"auto\">{{cite web|url=http://www.tbs.com/stories/story/0,,107945,00.html|title=The Bill Engvall Show bio|publisher=TBS.com|access-date=June 5, 2011|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120106031333/http://www.tbs.com/stories/story/0%2C%2C107945%2C00.html|archive-date=January 6, 2012}}</ref> While at Southwestern he was a member of Xi Chapter of the [[Kappa Alpha Order]]. Engvall left college without graduating and worked a series of jobs, including tour guide at [[Inner Space Caverns]], and disc jockey in a [[Dallas]], Texas nightclub.<ref name=\"auto1\">{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/engvall_bill/bio.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040612024634/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/engvall_bill/bio.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 12, 2004|title=Bill Engvall biography|publisher=CMT.com|access-date=June 5, 2011}}</ref> It was while working as the club DJ that he first ventured into stand-up comedy at amateur and open mic nights around Dallas.\n\n==Career==\nIn 1990, Bill Engvall moved to Southern California to dedicate full-time to comedy. Early notoriety came from hosting the cable show ''A Pair of Jokers'' with [[Rosie O'Donnell]] and an appearance on ''[[The Golden Palace]]'' where he played Blanche's son Matthew, a stockbroker turned aspiring comic. Other early appearances included hosting [[A&E Network]]s ''[[The Improv|An Evening at The Improv]]'' as well as stand-up routines on ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]''<ref>{{cite web |title=Bill Engvall Makes His First Appearance on Network Television {{!}} Carson Tonight Show | website=[[YouTube]] |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gzfDimg14Vo |access-date=19 October 2022 |language=en |date=1989-07-13}}</ref> and the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]].<ref name=\"auto1\"/>\n\nA career breakthrough happened in 1992 when Engvall was named Best Male Standup at the [[American Comedy Awards]]. His first role as a series regular came soon after when he was cast in the ABC series ''[[Delta (American TV series)|Delta]]'', starring [[Delta Burke]]. However, the show only lasted one season and Engvall returned to making the rounds of comedy clubs and the occasional television appearance until 1996 when he was cast with fellow comic and best friend [[Jeff Foxworthy]] in the [[NBC]] version of ''[[The Jeff Foxworthy Show]]''. Signed by [[Warner Records]] in 1996, Engvall released the first of a series of successful comedy albums, ''[[Here's Your Sign]]'', based on his signature joke. The album was [[Music recording sales certification|certified Platinum]] and peaked at number 5 on the Billboard Country album chart. Excerpts from this album were remixed into a musical track titled \"Here's Your Sign (Get the Picture)\", featuring a chorus sung by country music artist [[Travis Tritt]].<ref name=\"auto\"/> \"Here's Your Sign (Get the Picture)\" charted at number 29 on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] and number 43 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] in 1997.<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2017|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2017|page=120|isbn=978-0-89820-229-8}}</ref> Engvall released two more albums by the end of the 1990s: ''[[Dorkfish]]'' in 1998 and ''[[Here's Your Christmas Album]]'' in 1999. The latter featured narrations by Engvall, as well as songs he co-wrote sung by session musicians.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/bill-engvall-mn0000775644/biography | title=Bill Engvall biography | publisher=AllMusic | accessdate=July 11, 2022}}</ref> One of these original compositions, \"Here's Your Sign Christmas\", also made the country charts in both 1998 and 1999.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/>\n\nIn 2000, Engvall exited Warner Records for [[BNA Records]], citing managerial changes at Warner. His only BNA album, ''[[Now That's Awesome]]'', came out that same year.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Stark|first=Phyllis|date=August 12, 2000|title=Comedian Bill Engvall switches to BNA and delivers an 'awesome' 4th album|magazine=Billboard|page=31|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fBAEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA31}}</ref> Like most of the albums before it, this included two tracks that interpolated stand-up lines from the album with a musical track. The title track featured guest vocals from [[T. Graham Brown]], [[Tracy Byrd]], and [[Neal McCoy]], while \"Shoulda Shut Up\" featured [[Julie Reeves]].<ref name=\"whitburn\"/>\n\nEngvall moved back to Warner for all subsequent albums. ''Cheap Drunk: An Autobiography'' in 2002, ''Here's Your Sign Reloaded'' in 2003, ''15\u00b0 Off Cool'' in 2007, and ''Aged and Confused'' in 2009.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nIn 2021, Engvall announced his intention to retire from stand-up comedy after his \"Here's Your Sign, It's Finally Time\" farewell tour.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://variety.com/2021/tv/news/bill-engvall-retired-comedy-standup-heres-your-sign-1235039053/|last=Schneider|first=Michael|date=August 11, 2021|accessdate=January 10, 2023|title=Bill Engvall to Retire From Stand-Up, Announces Farewell Comedy Tour|magazine=Variety}}</ref> He posted a video on YouTube confirming his retirement on December 30, 2022. His final performance was at the [[Eccles Theater]] in [[Salt Lake City]] the following day.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3iFaH2lDxzk Bill Engvall Retires From Stand Up Comedy, says THANK YOU! - YouTube]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cracked.com/article_36356_blue-collar-comedy-tour-bill-engvall-is-retiring-and-so-is-the-funny-one.html|last=Kelly|first=Keegan|title=Blue Collar Comedy Tour: Bill Engvall Is Retiring, and So Is The Funny One|magazine=Cracked|date=December 20, 2022|accessdate=January 10, 2023}}</ref>\n\n===Blue Collar Comedy Tour===\n{{main|Blue Collar Comedy Tour}}\nIn 2000, [[Jeff Foxworthy]] and Engvall launched the first of six [[Blue Collar Comedy Tour]]s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/reviews/movies|title=Movie Reviews|date=April 28, 2020|website=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> The tours also featured [[Ron White]] and [[Larry the Cable Guy]] and were largely responsible for their breakout success. Each of the six years of the tour was very successful and spawned three films, a satellite radio show, and a television series titled ''[[Blue Collar TV]]'' on [[The WB Television Network|The WB Network]].\n\n===The Bill Engvall Show===\n{{main|The Bill Engvall Show}}\nIn 2007, Engvall starred in his own sitcom where he played himself as a family counselor. The show lasted three seasons.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0926732/|title=The Bill Engvall Show (TV Series)|website=imdb.com}}</ref>\n\n===Game show host===\nOn June 6, 2011, Engvall took over as host of ''[[Lingo (U.S. game show)|Lingo]]'' on [[Game Show Network]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://gameshows.about.com/b/2011/01/13/gsn-bringing-lingo-back-with-new-host.htm |title=GSN Bringing Lingo Back with New Host |access-date=January 29, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110210221705/http://gameshows.about.com/b/2011/01/13/gsn-bringing-lingo-back-with-new-host.htm |archive-date=February 10, 2011 |url-status=dead }}</ref> According to an interview in ''American Profile'' magazine, Engvall said that he jumped at the chance to host the show, citing the fun that his friend Foxworthy had hosting ''[[Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?]]'' Engvall had been a fan of ''Lingo'' when it aired a few years previously before ending in 2007, admitting that his wife always beat him to the answers. When asked if there were any plans to have buddies Foxworthy or Larry the Cable Guy appear on ''Lingo'', he replied, \"You never know! I would love to have them on the show because it would be a blast. I would really dig that.\"<ref>''American Profile'' newsmagazine. Article title: \"Q&A with Bill Engvall\". June 5, 2011</ref>\n\n===''Dancing with the Stars''===\nIn 2013, Engvall was announced as a contestant on the [[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. season 17)|17th season]] of ''[[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. TV series)|Dancing with the Stars]]'' paired with professional dancer [[Emma Slater]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/dancing-with-the-stars-leah-remini-valerie-harper-snooki-among-new-cast/|title=\"Dancing with the Stars\": Leah Remini, Valerie Harper, Snooki among new cast|website=Cbsnews.com|date=September 4, 2013 }}</ref> In the first week, he danced the Foxtrot and received a score of 18. The second week was Latin week and he saw some higher scores from the judges receiving a 21 for his Jive. And the third week of competition, Bill saw his highest score of 24 with a Paso Doble to the Lone Ranger theme song. Throughout the rest of the show, the judges usually placed Engvall and Slater at the bottom of the leaderboard, but an enormous fan base kept them in the competition, resulting in higher-scoring contestants, e.g. [[Christina Milian]], [[Snooki]], [[Brant Daugherty]], [[Elizabeth Berkley]], and [[Leah Remini]] being voted out instead.\n\nOn November 18, Engvall and Slater made it to the finals, along with [[Amber Riley]], [[Jack Osbourne]] and [[Corbin Bleu]]. The two finished in fourth place.\n\n==Comedic style==\nEngvall's most well-known routine is \"here's your sign\". In this routine, he offers \"signs\" to people whom he considers lacking in intellect. These jokes typically take the form of another person asking Engvall a \"stupid question\", to which Engvall typically responds with a sarcastic response before telling the person \"here's your sign\".<ref name=\"blue\">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/243672967/ | title=Blue collar blues | work=Argus Leader | date=January 11, 2007 | accessdate=July 11, 2022 | pages=15D}}</ref> Other jokes in Engvall's routine include anecdotes about his life as a father and husband, typically in the form of [[self-deprecation]].<ref name=\"blue\"/>\n\n==Personal life==\nBill and Gail Engvall (born August 5, 1960) have been married since December 18, 1982. They have a daughter named Emily (born June 9, 1986), a 2008 graduate from the [[University of Puget Sound]] who is married to Will Holden, as well as a son, Travis (born June 25, 1991), a 2015 graduate from [[Northern Arizona University]]; both of whom are often mentioned during his routines. Engvall resides in Utah when not on tour and maintains a blog for the [[Los Angeles Angels]] on the website of Fox Sports West.<ref>[http://ww2.somdnews.com/stories/06252010/weektop112652_32198.shtml An interview with Bill Engvall: blogging, acting, a new outlook.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425063820/http://ww2.somdnews.com/stories/06252010/weektop112652_32198.shtml |date=April 25, 2012 }} SoMdNews.com. Retrieved June 11, 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.foxsportswest.com/pages/bill_engvall_index Main page of Bill Engvall's LAA Blog] FoxSportsWest.com. Retrieved September 30, 2013</ref> Engvall is an ordained minister. He graduated with a degree in Christian Studies from [[Grand Canyon University]] in 2021.<ref>{{Cite press release |date=May 12, 2021 |title=No joke: Comedian Bill Engvall becoming GCU grad |first1=Lana |last1=Sweeten-Shults |url=https://news.gcu.edu/2021/05/no-joke-comedian-bill-engvall-becomes-gcu-grad/ |access-date=June 20, 2021 |publisher=Grand Canyon University}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! It was re-released in 2005.\n* C {{anchor|endnote_C}}'''[[#ref C|^]]''' ''A Decade of Laughs'' was the second number 1 album upon the 2004 debut of the Billboard \"[[Comedy Albums|Top Comedy Albums]]\" chart, after ''[[Lord, I Apologize]]'' by fellow Blue Collar Comedy star [[Larry the Cable Guy]].\n{{refend}}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:24em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"3\"| Peak chart positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Hot Country Songs|U.S. Country]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[Billboard Hot 100|U.S.]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[RPM (magazine)|CAN Country]]\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1997\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Here's Your Sign (Get the Picture)\" {{small|(with [[Travis Tritt]])}}\n| 29\n| 43\n| 72\n| rowspan=\"3\" align=\"left\" {{n/a}}\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Warning Signs\" {{small|(with [[John Michael Montgomery]])}}\n| 56\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 1998\n! scope=\"row\"| \"It's Hard to Be a Parent\"\n| 72\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I'm a Cowboy\"\n| 60\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"2\" align=\"left\"| ''Dorkfish''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Here's Your Sign Christmas\"\n| 50\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 1999\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Hollywood Indian Guides\"\n| 72\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\" {{n/a}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 2000\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Blue Collar Dollar\" <br />{{small|(with [[Jeff Foxworthy]] and [[Marty Stuart]])}}\n| 63\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| ''[[Blue Collar Comedy Tour]]''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Now That's Awesome\"<br />{{small|(with [[Neal McCoy]], [[Tracy Byrd (musician)|Tracy Byrd]] and [[T. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Stacey_Earle","to":"Stacey Earle"}],"pages":{"13050295":{"pageid":13050295,"ns":0,"title":"Stacey Earle","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{distinguish|Stacy Earl}}\n{{BLP sources|date=October 2008}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name          = Stacey Earle\n| background    = solo_singer \n| image         = \n| landscape = yes\n| caption       = \n| birth_name    = Stacey Carol Earle\n| birth_date    = {{Birth date and age|1960|09|25|mf=y}}\n| birth_place   = [[Lake Charles, Louisiana]]\n| death_date    =\n| death_place   =\n| genre         = {{flatlist|\n* [[Americana (music)|Americana]]\n* [[Folk music|folk]]\n* [[Country music|country]]\n}}\n| occupation    = Singer-songwriter, musician\n| instrument    = Vocals, guitar\n| label         = Gearle Records\n| associated_acts = {{flatlist|\n* [[Steve Earle]]\n* [[Steve Earle and the Dukes|Dukes]]\n* Mark Stuart\n}}\n| website       = {{URL|http://staceyearle.com/}}\n| notable_instruments       =\n}}\n\n'''Stacey Earle''' (born September 25, 1960) is an American singer-songwriter.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Hardcore Troubadour|last=St John|first=Lauren|publisher=Fourth Estate|year=2002|isbn=978-1-84115-611-8|pages=14}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nEarle was born in [[Lake Charles, Louisiana|Lake Charles]], Louisiana, and raised in [[San Antonio]], Texas. She first taught herself to play a [[ukulele]] and then began playing a gut string guitar, left behind by her musician brother, [[Steve Earle]]. She was given her own guitar as a Christmas present when she was 16 years old, but became a mother at 17 and played and sang at home, developing her own style of finger picking.<ref name=triste />\n\n==Career==\nWhen she was 29 years old, Earle moved to [[Nashville]] to live with her brother Steve, and sang backing vocals and played rhythm guitar on his 1991 album ''[[The Hard Way (Steve Earle album)|The Hard Way]]'', and for the subsequent world tour.<ref name=\"triste\">{{cite web|author1=Steve Wilcox|title=Stacey Earle \u2013 Not Such A Simple Gearle|url=http://www.triste.co.uk/artstacey.htm|website=Triste magazine UK: Triste Archive|accessdate=November 3, 2017}}</ref> She appeared on her brother's subsequent albums: ''Shut Up and Die Like an Aviator'' and ''[[Transcendental Blues]]''.\n\nAfter returning from tour, she wrote songs and performed them at writer's nights in Nashville.<ref name=triste /> Later, she set up her own songwriters' night to get some more time on stage. During this time, she met fellow guitarist and singer Mark Stuart who became her partner in running the events and then later became her second husband.<ref name=triste />\n\nEarle signed a contract with Nashville's Ten Ten Music Group as a staff songwriter<ref name=triste /> and received notice for her song \"For Years\", which appeared on [[Sammy Kershaw]]'s 1996 CD ''[[Politics, Religion and Her]]''.<ref name=\"bio\">{{cite web|author1=Jason Ankeny|title=Stacey Earle biography|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/stacey-earle-mn0000165051/biography|publisher=[[Allmusic]] website|accessdate=November 3, 2017}}</ref>\n\nIn 1998 she released the album ''Simple Gearle'' which later appeared on ''[[The New York Times]]'' \"Favorite CD's You Nearly Missed\" list. Reviewer [[Jon Pareles]] stated: \"On an album completed in four days, Stacey Earle's songs came out homespun and pristine. She examines marriage, divorce and starting over in quiet, folky vignettes full of tears and determination.\"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/01/13/arts/the-pop-life-favorite-cd-s-you-nearly-missed.html|title=The Pop Life; Favorite CD's You Nearly Missed|last=Strauss|first=Neil|date=2000|work=The New York Times|access-date=October 6, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Stacey Earle and Mark Stuart===\n*''Must Be Live'' (2001, Gearle Records), a double live album\n*''Never Gonna Let You Go'' (2003, Gearle/Evolver)\n*''S&M Communion Bread'' (2005, Gearle/Funzalo)\n*''Town Square'' (2008, Gearle Records)\n\n===Stacey Earle solo===\n*''[[Simple Gearle]]'' (1998, Gearle Records)\n*''[[Dancin' With Them That Brung Me]]'' (2000, Gearle Records)\n\n===Mark Stuart solo===\n*''Songs from a Corner Stage'' (1999, Gearle Records)\n*''Left of Nashville'' (2007, Gearle Records)\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://staceyearle.com/ Official web site]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Earle, Stacey}}\n[[Category:1960 births]]\n[[Category:Musicians from San Antonio]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Texas]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Lake Charles, Louisiana]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Texas]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Louisiana]]\n[[Category:Earle musical family]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Louisiana]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Leigh"}],"pages":{"4681961":{"pageid":4681961,"ns":0,"title":"Danni Leigh","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country singer and businesswoman (born 1970)}}\n{{Distinguish|DaniLeigh}}\n{{Infobox person\n| image           =\n| caption         =\n| birth_name      = Michelle Sheetz\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1970|02|09}}\n| birth_place     = [[Strasburg, Virginia]], US\n| occupation      = {{Hlist|Singer|businesswoman}}\n| years_active    = 1998\u2013present\n| spouse          = Mike McKenzie\n| children        = 1\n| module          = {{Infobox musical artist|embed=yes\n| origin          = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], US\n| instrument      = Vocals\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| label           = {{Hlist|[[Decca Records|Decca]]|[[Monument Records|Monument]]|[[Audium Entertainment]]}}\n| associated_acts = \n}}\n}}\n'''Michelle Sheetz'''<ref name=\"WinchesterStar\">{{cite news |title=Country musician singing a new tune, opens downtown business |url=https://www.winchesterstar.com/arts_and_entertainment/country-musician-singing-a-new-tune-opens-downtown-business/article_57ca8b83-161e-5e23-b764-f68a5dbeaf05.html |accessdate=September 2, 2020 |work=The Winchester Star |date=August 23, 2018}}</ref> (born February 9, 1970), better known as '''Danni Leigh''', is an American [[country music]] singer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/danni-leigh-mn0000670807/biography|title=Danni Leigh|website=AllMusic|access-date=December 16, 2016}}</ref> At age 19, she relocated to [[Orlando, Florida]], intending to audition as a singer at [[Disney World]], but ended up moving to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in 1994.<ref name=\"Danni Leigh: Biography\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/leigh_danni/bio.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040315014004/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/leigh_danni/bio.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 15, 2004|title=Danni Leigh: Biography|accessdate=February 3, 2008|publisher=CMT}}</ref>\n\nShe was signed with Audium Records,<ref name=\"One More for Her\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Issue/story?oid=oid:82478|title=One More For Her|accessdate=February 3, 2008|date=July 21, 2001|author=Jerry Renshaw|work=The Austin Chronicle}}</ref> after changing labels several times,<ref name=\"Danni Leigh No Worries with a 'Shot of Whiskey and a Prayer'\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/article.asp?xid=567|title=Danni Leigh No Worries with a 'Shot of Whiskey and a Prayer'|accessdate=February 3, 2008|date=March 2001|author=Joel Bernstein|work=Country Standard Time}}</ref> following Decca's closure, and her by Sony's Monument label.<ref name=\"Sony Deals Danni Leigh a Parting 'Shot'\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1443645/20010513/leigh_danni.jhtml|title=Sony Deals Danni Leigh a Parting 'Shot'|accessdate=February 3, 2008|date=April 2, 2001|author=Michael Gray|work=CMT}}{{dead link|date=July 2024|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Although she has limited success in the US, she has had more success in Europe due to the different methods consumers learn about new music.<ref name=\"Danni Leigh No Worries with a 'Shot of Whiskey and a Prayer'\"/> Over time, she has also developed a following in [[Korea]], [[Brazil]], and Japan.<ref name=\"Danni Leigh Is Off to a Second Start\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1472770/20030617/leigh_danni.jhtml|title=Danni Leigh Is Off to a Second Start|accessdate=February 3, 2008|date=April 4, 2000|author=Edward Morris|work=CMT}}{{dead link|date=July 2024|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> In 1999, she was nominated for the Rising Star Trophy, a British Country Music Award.<ref name=\"British Country Music Awards\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1474602/20030723/leigh_danni.jhtml|title=British Country Music Awards|accessdate=February 3, 2008|date=February 24, 1999|work=CMT}}{{dead link|date=July 2024|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> In 2001, she released ''[[A Shot of Whiskey and a Prayer]].''<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1121719/danni-leigh-takes-shot-at-country-big-time/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220125312/http://www.mtv.com/news/1121719/danni-leigh-takes-shot-at-country-big-time/|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 20, 2016|title=Danni Leigh Takes ''Shot'' At Country Big Time|newspaper=MTV News|access-date=December 16, 2016|date=July 2, 2000}}</ref>\n\nLeigh has also performed a number of small gigs in the [[Austin, Texas]], area,<ref name=\"Bombs Over Baghdad\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Issue/column?oid=oid%3A226212|title=Bombs Over Baghdad|accessdate=February 3, 2008|date=August 27, 2004|author=Christopher Gray|work=The Austin Chronicle}}</ref> where she moved in 2002.<ref name=\"Immigrant Song\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Issue/story?oid=oid:104026|title=Immigrant Song|accessdate=February 3, 2008|date=October 4, 2002|author=John T. Davis|work=The Austin Chronicle}}</ref>\n\nAs her career declined in the US, Leigh later moved again, this time to Spain, many years later and performed elsewhere in Europe and Asia. She even reached the rest of South America. During the tours, she met and eventually married her bandmate Mike McKenzie.<ref name=WinchesterStar/> The couple returned to Nashville in order to restart her career, but the birth of her only child, a son, in 2010 led her to emphasize both motherhood and becoming a businessperson. Leigh then moved with her husband back to [[Strasburg, Virginia]], her birthplace, where she started her boutique-cum-fitness studio in 2018 and opened another in [[Winchester, Virginia|Winchester]].<ref name=WinchesterStar/>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Marcel_(singer)","to":"Marcel (singer)"}],"pages":{"7782611":{"pageid":7782611,"ns":0,"title":"Marcel (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image            =\n| name             = Marcel\n| image_size       = \n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = Marcel Francois Chagnon\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1975|02|09}}<ref name=\"hockeydb\">[http://www.hockeydb.com/ihdb/stats/pdisplay.php?pid=21981 Hockey statistics]</ref>\n| origin           = [[Grosse Pointe, Michigan]], United States<ref name=\"gac\">{{cite web |url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/cda/article_print/0,3008,GAC_26071_5903534_DS-ARTICLE-WITH-GROUPS,00.html |title=Marcel biography |accessdate=2008-07-25 |work=[[Great American Country]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006195448/http://www.gactv.com/gac/cda/article_print/0,3008,GAC_26071_5903534_DS-ARTICLE-WITH-GROUPS,00.html |archive-date=2014-10-06 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n| instrument       = {{hlist|Vocals|Acoustic guitar|Harmonica}}\n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation       = {{hlist|Singer|Songwriter|Music video director}}\n| years_active     = 2003-present\n| label            = {{hlist|[[Mercury Nashville]]|[[Lyric Street Records|Lyric Street]]|Red Stripe Plane}}\n| spouse = {{Marriage|[[Jessica Andrews]]|2011}}\n}}\n'''Marcel Francois Chagnon''' (born February 9, 1975), known professionally as '''Marcel''', is an American [[country music]] singer, songwriter, and music video director. Signed to [[Mercury Nashville Records]] in 2003, he released his debut album ''You, Me, and the Windshield'' that year and charted on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts with the single \"Country Rock Star\". Five years later, he signed to [[Lyric Street Records]] and released the single \"I Love This Song\", which has also charted. In addition to his recording career, Marcel has directed several music videos, and has written charted singles for [[Josh Gracin]], [[Trace Adkins]], and [[Jessica Andrews]], to whom he is married.\n\n== Career ==\nBorn in [[Grosse Pointe, Michigan]], Marcel was a [[semi-professional sports|semi-pro]] [[ice hockey|hockey]] player until signing with [[Mercury Nashville Records]] in 2002.<ref name=\"gac\"/><ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p559061/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Marcel biography |accessdate=2008-07-25 |last=Kergan |first=Wade |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> For four years prior to this, while waiting for an opportunity, he sang at clubs, bars, and waited tables for extra money.\n\nIn 2003, he released his debut album ''[[You, Me and the Windshield]]''.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> The tracks \"Country Rock Star\" and \"Tennessee\" from this album were released as singles. After this he returned to writing songs for other artists.\n\nMarcel has co-written two of [[Josh Gracin]]'s singles: \"[[Nothin' to Lose (Josh Gracin song)|Nothin' to Lose]]\", which previously appeared on ''You, Me and the Windshield'', and \"[[Favorite State of Mind]]\". [[Jessica Andrews]] also released two of his songs as singles: \"[[There's More to Me Than You]]\" and \"Everything\". [[Rascal Flatts]], [[LeAnn Rimes]], and [[Big & Rich]] have also recorded his songs.<ref name=\"gac\"/>\n\nIn 2008, Marcel signed to [[Lyric Street Records]], releasing his third single, \"I Love This Song\" that year.<ref name=\"gac\"/> When the song failed to reach Top 40, he exited Lyric Street's roster. In February 2009, he signed to the Red Stripe Plane label. He had a cameo in ''[[Hannah Montana: The Movie]]'', playing guitar in [[Billy Ray Cyrus]]' band. He is also shown in Cyrus' video for \"[[Back to Tennessee (song)|Back to Tennessee]]\".\n\nOn February 17, 2009, Marcel released his fourth single, \"Believin'\", which is also the title track to his second album. The album was released on the Red Stripe Plane label, but neither the album or single charted on any ''Billboard'' chart.  In June 2010, Marcel released a new single titled \"It's Summertime.\" Later in the year, Marcel began directing [[music video]]s for other artists.\n\n==Personal life==\nMarcel became engaged to [[Jessica Andrews]] in October 2010, and the two were married on November 11, 2011.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120107213345/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1676414/top-10-country-newlyweds-of-the-year.jhtml CMT.com story on 2011 weddings]</ref> Andrews gave birth to the couple's son [[Rockwell Francois Chagnon]] on February 6, 2018. They had a daughter in 2022.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.onecountry.com/jessica-andrews-baby-boy-2532785269.html |title=\"Who I Am\" Singer Jessica Andrews and Husband Marcel Welcome First Child - One Country |website=www.onecountry.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180223110918/https://www.onecountry.com/jessica-andrews-baby-boy-2532785269.html |archive-date=2018-02-23}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Edge of 18\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/steve-dorian/1524189/edge-of-18.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160821214605/http://www.cmt.com/videos/steve-dorian/1524189/edge-of-18.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=August 21, 2016|title=CMT : Videos : Steve Dorian : Edge of 18|publisher=[[Country Music Television]]|accessdate=August 12, 2016}}</ref>\n| Steve Dorian\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"After Midnight\"\n| JT Hodges\n|-\n| 2017\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Po-Dunk\"\n| [[Kid Rock]]\n|-\n| 2018\n! scope=\"row\"| \"This is It\"\n| [[Scotty McCreery]]\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[https://web.archive.org/web/20061010132846/http://www.marcelmusic.com/ Official Site]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Marcel}}\n[[Category:American country harmonica players]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Michigan]]\n[[Category:People from Grosse Pointe, Michigan]]\n[[Category:American music video directors]]\n[[Category:Mercury Records artists]]\n[[Category:Lyric Street Records artists]]\n[[Category:1975 births]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Michigan]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Rio_Grand","to":"Rio Grand"}],"pages":{"14758866":{"pageid":14758866,"ns":0,"title":"Rio Grand","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{For|the river|Rio Grande}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name                = Rio Grand\n| image                 = \n| caption            = \n| image_size            = \n| background          = group_or_band\n| origin              = [[Texas]], United States\n| genre               = [[country music|Country]]\n| years_active        = 2006\u20132012\n| label               = [[Curb Records|Curb]]\n| associated_acts     = 37 South, Lucious Funk\n| website                 = http://www.riograndband.com\n| past_members = Lance Leslie<br />Tommy Rennick<br />Danny Rivera<br />Fred Stallcup\n| }}\n'''Rio Grand''' was an American [[Texas Country]] group founded by Lance Leslie (harmonica, vocals), Tommy Rennick (vocals, bass guitar), Danny Rivera (lead vocals, guitar, banjo, lap steel guitar, Dobro, and Fred Stallcup (lead guitar, vocals).<ref name=\"wma\">{{cite web|url=http://www.wma.com/rio_grand/Bio/rio_grand_bio.pdf|date=25 October 2007|title=RIO GRAND Biography|accessdate=2015-08-22}}</ref> All four members were natives of the state of [[Texas]]. In addition, Tommy Rennick was previously a member of 37 South and the [[Allison Paige]] band. Fred Stallcup was previously a member of Lucious Funk.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://countrymusic.about.com/od/interviews/a/RioGrandInt.htm |title=Rio Grand Interview - Part 1 |accessdate=2007-12-18 |last=Petricka |first=Laurie |work=About.com}}</ref> Lance Leslie was formerly in [[South 65]].\n\nIn 2006, the group was signed to [[Curb Records|Asylum-Curb Records]]. Shortly afterward, their first single (titled \"Kill Me Now\") was released to radio, reaching a peak of 42 on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. Co-written by [[John Rich]], [[Vicky McGehee]] and Anthony L. Smith, it received a positive rating from Deborah Evans Price of ''Billboard'', who called it \"promising\".<ref name=\"google\">{{cite book|title=Billboard|date=2003-10-04|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|issn=0006-2510|url=https://archive.org/details/bub_gb_EBEEAAAAMBAJ|page=[https://archive.org/details/bub_gb_EBEEAAAAMBAJ/page/n49 50]|accessdate=2015-08-22}}</ref> The band released an album, ''Painted Pony'', in 2010.\n\nStallcup and Rivera found a second band in 2012 called Sweetwater Rain, which was also signed with Curb.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sweetwaterrain.com/biography/ |title=Biography {{!}} Sweetwater Rain |website=sweetwaterrain.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121119223122/http://sweetwaterrain.com/biography |archive-date=2012-11-19}} </ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Extended plays===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Painted Pony''\n|\n* Release date: January 5, 2010\n* Label: [[Curb Records]]\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Kill Me Now\"\n| 42\n| align=\"left\"| ''Painted Pony''\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2007\n! scope=\"row\"| \"That's My Memory\"\n| \u2014\n| {{n/a}}\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Storm Inside of Me\"\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"2\"| ''Painted Pony''\n|-\n| 2008\n! scope=\"row\"| \"God's Got a Bigger Plan\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2009\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Nothing to Go On\"\n| \u2014\n| {{n/a}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 2010\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Painted Pony\"\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| ''Painted Pony''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Beckett's Back Forty\"\n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"2\" {{n/a}}\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Love Beer\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.riograndband.com Official Website]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n[[Category:Country music groups from Texas]]\n[[Category:Curb Records artists]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 2006]]\n[[Category:Musical groups disestablished in 2012]]\n[[Category:2006 establishments in Texas]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Scooter_Lee","to":"Scooter Lee"}],"pages":{"46317971":{"pageid":46317971,"ns":0,"title":"Scooter Lee","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2015}}{{Infobox musical artist\n| name         = Scooter Lee\n| image        =\n| caption      =\n| birth_name   = Scooter Lee\n| birth_date   = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1957|3|10}}\n| birth_place  = [[New Orleans, Louisiana]], U.S.\n| genre        = {{flat list|\n* [[Country music|Country]]\n* [[country pop]]\n* [[Gospel music|gospel]]\n}}\n| occupation   = {{flat list|\n* Singer-songwriter\n* record producer\n* philanthropist\n}}\n| years_active = 1971\u2013present\n| label        = {{flat list|\n* [[Universal Music Group|Universal]]\n* [[Sony Music Entertainment|Sony Music]]\n* [[Bill Lowery (record producer)|Lowery Music]]\n* Scootway\n* Superline\n}}\n| website      = {{URL|https://www.scooterlee.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Scooter Lee''' (born March 10, 1957) is an American singer-songwriter & line dance entertainer. Raised on St. Charles Avenue in [[New Orleans, Louisiana]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Scooter Lee loves giving line dance instructions to senior citizens|url=https://linedanceinstructions2.wordpress.com/|website=Line Dance Instructions|accessdate=4 April 2015|date=August 22, 2009}}</ref> her career started at age 14 when she was signed to [[Allen Toussaint|Allen Toussaint's]] record label in New Orleans, recording with [[Irma Thomas]], [[Jerry Lee Lewis]] and [[Fats Domino]]. There, she was labeled as 'the little lady with the big voice'; recording country blues for the label. She soon settled in on recording country music with a blues overtone.\n\nDuring the 1970s, Scooter Lee toured alongside major artists, including [[Linda Ronstadt]], [[Kris Kristofferson]], [[Tammy Wynette]] and [[Johnny Cash|Johnny]] & [[June Carter Cash]]. In the 1980s, Scooter Lee gained ground with her 5 piece band sponsored by the [[RJ Reynolds Tobacco Company]], working 10 months a year at every major state fair and other regional festivals. Performing 2-3 shows daily, 300 dates a year, taught her the art of fully commanding a stage. Spotted in Los Angeles in 1985, Scooter Lee was invited to join the [[Bob Hope]] [[United Service Organizations|USO Tours]] and gained experience on stages in war-torn countries.\n\nScooter Lee grabbed the attention of the country music dance community during the early 1990s when she was signed to [[Sony Records]] to follow in the footsteps of [[Billy Ray Cyrus]], [[Brooks & Dunn]], [[Tracy Byrd]] and [[Reba McEntire]] just as the '[[line dance]]' phenomenon emerged. She developed and perfected the formula of writing & recording a perfectly phrased song that was not only 'dancer friendly' but 'radio friendly' as well.<ref>{{cite web|title=Scooter Lee Biography|url=http://stompede.com/scooter_lee.html|website=Sundance Stompede|accessdate=4 April 2015}}</ref> Some of her most successful singles include J'ai du Boogie, Dizzy, Rose Garden, High-Test Love, Ribbon Of Highway, Roll Back The Rug, Honky Tonk Twist, OeeOeeO, Rock & Roll Waltz, Rompin' Stompin', Louisiana Hot Sauce, This Little Light Of Mine, Splish Splash and Break Away.\n\nIn [[Nashville, TN]], Scooter Lee is considered one of the hardest working artist on the road, performing more than 175 days a year worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hanson|first1=Eric|title=Recording Artist Scooter Lee to Perform at San Francisco Gay Rodeo & Festival|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2006/08/prweb427854.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080925045603/http://www.prweb.com/releases/2006/08/prweb427854.htm|url-status=dead|archive-date=September 25, 2008|website=PRWeb|accessdate=4 April 2015|location=San Francisco, CA|date=August 23, 2006}}</ref> She tours 27 countries, including: the USA, England, Scotland, Wales, Ireland, Denmark, France, Belgium, Netherlands, Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, Malaysia, Sweden, Japan, Canada, Finland, Norway, Germany, Switzerland and Belgium.\n\nCurrently, Scooter Lee resides in [[Atlanta, Georgia]] where she owns and operates her international distribution company for audio and video as well as founding a senior health [[501(c) organization|501(c)(3) charity organization]] that uses line dance as its chosen form of exercise. The nonprofit charity, Dancing For The Dream, Inc., promotes healthy lifestyles for seniors throughout the United States & abroad<ref>{{cite web|last1=Murugap|first1=Revathi|title=Line dance to health|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/story/?file=%2F2008%2F10%2F11%2Fhealth%2F2222347|website=The Star|accessdate=4 April 2015|date=October 11, 2008}}</ref> and encourages \"Dancing For The Health Of It\".<ref>{{cite web|title=Dancing For The Dream Health Seminars for Active Adults|url=https://dancingforthedream.com/|website=Dancing For The Dream|accessdate=5 April 2015}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n* ''Honky Tonk Twist'' (1994)\n* ''Scooter Lee's New Album'' (1995)\n* ''High-Test Love'' (1997)\n* ''In the Name of Love'' (1997)\n* ''Moving On Up'' (1998)\n* ''By Request\u2026 The Disco/Dance Album'' (1999)\n* ''Would You Consider'' (2000)\n* ''The Best of Scooter Lee'' (2000)\n* ''Dancing in the Streets'' (2001)\n* ''Steppin' Out'' (2001)\n* ''Set the Northpole on Fire'' (2002)\n* ''More of the Best'' (2002)\n* ''Puttin' on the Ritz'' (2003)\n* ''Walking on Sunshine'' (2004)\n* ''Test of Time'' (2005)\n* ''Go to the Rock'' (2007)\n* ''Home to Louisiana'' (2008)\n* ''Sing a New Song, Dance a New Dance'' (2011)\n* ''Big Bang Boogie'' (2011)\n* ''Welcome to Scooterville'' (2013)\n* ''I'm Gonna Love You Forever'' (2014)\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n* [http://www.allmusic.com/artist/scooter-lee-mn0000836566/ Scooter Lee's discography on AllMusic.com]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Lee, Scooter}}\n[[Category:1957 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:American country Louisiana]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Buckaroos","to":"The Buckaroos"}],"pages":{"11201296":{"pageid":11201296,"ns":0,"title":"The Buckaroos","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American band;  Grammy-winning band led by Buck Owens}}\n{{More citations needed|date=January 2017}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = The Buckaroos\n| image             = \n| image_size        = \n| alt               = \n| caption           = \n| background        = group_or_band\n| alias             = \n| origin            = [[Bakersfield, California]], United States\n| genre             = [[Bakersfield sound]], [[Country music|country]], [[rockabilly]]\n| years_active      = 1963\u20132005\n| associated_acts   = [[Buck Owens]], [[The Strangers (American band)|The Strangers]], [[Merle Haggard]]\n| label             = [[Capitol Records]]\n| current_members   = \n| past_members      = [[Buck Owens]]<br />[[Don Rich]]<br />[[Doyle Holly]]<br />[[Tom Brumley]]<br />[[Willie Cantu]]<br />[[Merle Haggard]]<br />Wayne Wilson<br />Jana Jae<br />Victoria Hallman<br />Connie Bonar<br/>Jesse Rose McQueen<br />Jerry Wiggins<br />[[Jerry Brightman]]<br />Doyle Curtsinger<br />Ronnie Jackson<br />Jim Shaw<br />[[JayDee Maness]]<!--not \"Jay Dee\"--><br />Wayne \"Moose\" Stone<br />Jay McDonald<br />Ken Presley<br />Terry Christoffersen<br/>Jim McCarty<br />James Harold Brown<br />David Wulfekuehler<br />Brian Coll<br />Kim Maccabee<br />Chuck Seaton<br />Drew Harness}}\n\n'''The Buckaroos''' were an American band led by [[Buck Owens]] in the 1960s and early 1970s, who, along with [[Merle Haggard]]'s [[The Strangers (American band)|The Strangers]], were involved in the development and presentation of the \"[[Bakersfield sound]].\" Their peak of success was from 1965 to 1970. In 2005, [[Country Music Television|CMT]] named the Buckaroos No. 2 on its list of the 20 Greatest Country Music Bands.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/shows/dyn/greatest_series/90579/episode_countdown.jhtml |archive-url=https://archive.today/20120724144840/http://www.cmt.com/shows/dyn/greatest_series/90579/episode_countdown.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=July 24, 2012 |title=TV Shows : Watch Full Episodes Online : Featured Shows, Schedules and Top 20 Video Countdown |website=Cmt.com |accessdate=2017-01-10}}</ref>\n\n==History==\n[[Don Rich]], [[Doyle Holly]], [[Tom Brumley]] and [[Willie Cantu]] were the original members of the Buckaroos during the 1960s. The 1970s version included Don Rich, Jerry Wiggins, [[Jerry Brightman]], Doyle Curtsinger, and Jim Shaw. Various [[Sideman|sidemen]] throughout the years included [[JayDee Maness]]<!--not \"Jay Dee\"-->, Wayne \"Moose\" Stone, Jay McDonald, Ken Presley, and very early on, [[Merle Haggard]]. Haggard, who worked a short time with Owens in 1962, suggested the group's name.<ref>\"Merle Haggard: The Real Deal\". ''Biography''. A&E TV. November 15, 2000.</ref> Fiddle player [[Jana Jae]] became the group's first female member after being invited onstage with Buck Owens to play \"[[Orange Blossom Special (song)|Orange Blossom Special]]\". Vocalist Victoria Hallman (a.k.a. Jesse Rose McQueen) toured with the Buckaroos, sang with them on Hee Haw and recorded one Buck Owens record \"Let Jesse Rob the Train\" with the group.{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} Drummer/singer Rick Taylor replaced Jerry Wiggins in 1978, when he left the band to manage his wife, Susan Raye. Rick performed his first appearance at the Golden Nugget in Las Vegas \"winging it\" as there was no time for rehearsals before the sold-out performances. Rick had seen Buck and the original Buckaroos live in Omaha when he was 13 years old and dreamed of performing with Buck on Hee Haw. At age 19 he made his way to Nashville and 5 years later, he was performing in a rock cover group at a Nashville night club when Buck himself came to watch him at the urging of Hee Haw music director, Charlie McCoy, and Hee Haw staff band players, [[Leon Rhodes]], and Tommy Williams. Buck hired Rick on the spot and invited him to the Hee Haw set the next day where his dream became a reality. Rick's first taping was the Hee Haw 10th Anniversary Show taped at the Grand Ole Opry House in Nashville, Tn in October 1978. He was with the Buckaroos until leaving in 1981, following the band's nomination and win as \"Touring Band of the Year\" at the ACM Awards, to join the Epic Records vocal group Nightstreets, voted Billboard Magazine's Vocal Group of the Year 1981 for the single, \"Love In The Meantime\". Nightstreets featured female vocalist, Joyce Hawthorne, met Rick while recording as a background singer with the Buckaroos in the 1970s. Nightstreets toured with George Jones and Tammy Wynette from 1981 through 1982. Rick retired from the music industry in 1986.\n\nKnown for their signature red, white and blue colored guitars and fiddles, the Buckaroos in 1966 became only the second country music band to appear at [[Carnegie Hall]] in [[New York City]]. The recording of this performance, released as ''[[Carnegie Hall Concert (Buck Owens album)|Carnegie Hall Concert]]'', is considered one of the greatest live country music albums. They also recorded and released live albums from appearances in [[London]], [[Norway]], [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]], and [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]].  The Buckaroos also appeared on the Buck Owens Show.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.buckaroo.xyz/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304025259/https://www.buckaroo.xyz/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=2016-03-04 |title=Home |date= |accessdate=2020-04-12}}</ref>\n\nThe Buckaroos recorded eight albums from 1967 to 1970, all of which were top sellers. They also earned numerous awards, including [[Grammy]]s. They were nominated as \"Band Of The Year\" by the [[Academy of Country Music]] in eight consecutive years, winning the award four times, 1965\u20131968. The Buckaroos were also nominated as \"Instrumental Group of the Year\" in the Country Music Awards for five consecutive years, 1967\u20131971, winning the honor in 1967 and 1968.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmaawards.com/2007/database/ArtistDetail.aspx?artistId=764 |title=Homepage - 2016 CMA Awards |website=Cmaawards.com |date= |accessdate=2017-01-10}}</ref>\n\nIn 1970, [[Doyle Holly]] received \"Bass Player of the Year\" award from the [[Academy of Country Music]] as a member of the Buckaroos. He left the group the next year to pursue a solo career, in which he released two Top 20 hit albums. He is honored in the [[Rockabilly Hall of Fame]] and received a block in the walkway of stars at the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]] in 1980. Holly died in 2007.<ref name=\"cst\">{{cite web|last =Johnson| first =Jon| title =Doyle Holly and the Buckaroos are together again| work =CountryStandardTime.com| publisher =Jeffrey Remz|date=June 2003|url =http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/article.asp?fn=doyleholly.asp|accessdate =2008-10-16}}</ref>\n\n[[Tom Brumley]] left the Buckaroos in 1969 to join [[Ricky Nelson]]'s band, where he was a member for over a decade. His performance on \"Together Again\" has been considered \"one of the finest steel guitar solos in the history of country music.\"<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090205003031/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1604311/tom-brumley-member-of-buck-owens-buckaroos-dies-in-texas.jhtml \"Tom Brumley, Member of Buck Owens' Buckaroos, Dies in Texas\"], ''[[Country Music Television]]'', February 4, 2009. Accessed February 5, 2009.</ref> His unique steel guitar sound was known as \"The Brumley Touch\", and he was recognized by the [[Academy of Country Music]] as the top steel guitarist. He was inducted into both the Texas Steel Guitar Hall of Fame and the [[Steel Guitar Hall of Fame|International Steel Guitar Hall of Fame]]. Brumley died in 2009.<ref name=LATimesObit>Mclellan, Dennis. [http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-tom-brumley6-2009feb06,0,6613593.story \"Tom Brumley dies at 73; steel guitarist for Buck Owens and Rick Nelson\"], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', February 6, 2009. Accessed February 5, 2009.</ref>\n\n[[Don Rich]] died in a motorcycle accident in 1974. At the time Rich was the only original member still with the Buckaroos and the band was struggling to find their way back at the top of the Country Music Charts. His death marked the end of the Buckaroos reign as the top Country Music band.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.buckowens.com/aboutbuck23.html |title=Home - Buck Owens Crystal PalaceBuck Owens' Crystal Palace |website=Buckowens.com |accessdate=2017-01-10 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081231174118/http://www.buckowens.com/aboutbuck23.html |archivedate=2008-12-31 }}</ref>\n\n[[Jerry Brightman]] left in 1975 and migrated into the business side with his involvement with [[WWVA Jamboree]] and [[Jamboree in the Hills]].\n\n==Members==\n{{Col-begin}}\n{{Col-3}}\n*[[Jerry Brightman]] (pedal steel)\n*[[Tom Brumley]] (pedal steel)\n*[[Willie Cantu]] (drums)\n*[[Merle Haggard]] (bass)\n*Toby Minter (drums)\n*Doyle Holly (bass)\n*[[Jana Jae]] (fiddle)\n*Mel King (drums)\n*Jay McDonald (pedal steel)\n{{Col-3}}\n*[[JayDee Maness]]<!--not \"Jay Dee\"--> (pedal steel)\n*Kenny Pierce\n*Ken Presley (drums)\n*[[Don Rich]] (guitar, fiddle, vocals)\n*Jim Shaw (keyboards, vocals)\n*Ronnie Jackson (guitar, banjo)\n*Doyle Curtsinger (bass, vocals)\n{{Col-3}}\n*Wayne \"Moose\" Stone (drums)\n*Jerry Wiggins (drums)\n*Rick Taylor (drums, vocals)\n*Wayne Wilson (bass)\n*Terry Christoffersen (pedal steel, guitar, banjo, dobro, vocals)\n*Connie Bonar (fiddle)\n*Don Lee (guitar, vocals) \n*David Wulfekuehler (drums)\n*Buck Dupree\n*Fred Gates (pedal steel)\n*Bob Morris (songwriter/guitar)\n*James Harold Brown (guitar)\n*Bob Baty (guitar)\n*Victoria Hallman (vocals)\n*Kim Maccabee (vocals)\n*Chuck Seaton (guitar, vocals)\n*Drew Harness (guitar, vocals)\n{{col-end}}\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Lenny_Cooper","to":"Lenny Cooper"}],"pages":{"43744530":{"pageid":43744530,"ns":0,"title":"Lenny Cooper","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country rap singer-songwriter|bot=PearBOT 5}}\n{{for|the English cricketer|Lenny Cooper (cricketer)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Lenny Cooper\n| image           =\n| image_size      =\n| landscape       =\n| alt             =\n| caption         =\n| birth_name      =\n| birth_date      = 1988\n| birth_place     = [[Jacksonville, North Carolina]]\n| origin          =\n| genre           = [[Country rap]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| instrument      = Vocals\n| years_active    = 2012\u2013present\n| label           = [[Average Joes Entertainment]], [[Backroad]]\n| associated_acts = [[Colt Ford]] \n*[[Bucky Covington]]\n*[[Bubba Sparxxx]]\n| website         = {{URL|www.lennycoopermusic.com/}}\n}}\n'''Lenny Cooper''' (born 1988 in [[Jacksonville, North Carolina]]<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|last=Leggett|first=Steve|title=Lenny Cooper {{!}} Biography|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=mn0002519137/biography|pure_url=yes}}|work=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=September 4, 2014}}</ref>) is an American [[country rap]] singer-songwriter.<ref>[http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/6229298/lenny-cooper-the-grind-interview \"Lenny Cooper Explains How His Father & Brother Turned Him Into a Country Rapper\"] ''Billboard''. Retrieved February 4, 2015.</ref> Cooper is signed to [[Colt Ford]]'s record label, [[Average Joes Entertainment]], and released his debut album, ''Diesel Fuel'', in 2012.<ref name=\"allmusic\" /> Cooper's second album, ''Mud Dynasty'', was released on May 7, 2013.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Carter|first1=Liv|title=UCN Interview \u2013 Lenny Cooper: \"The new album feels totally like me.\"|url=http://www.urbancountrynews.com/ucn-interview-lenny-cooper-the-new-album-feels-totally-like-me/|accessdate=September 4, 2014|work=Urban Country News|date=April 26, 2013}}</ref> It sold 3,000 copies in its first week of release, debuting at number 34 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart and number 198 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bjorke|first1=Matt|title=Country Album Chart News For May 15, 2013: Lady Antebellum Debuts At #1; Pistol Annies Top 5 with New Albums; Country Music Dominates|url=http://roughstock.com/news/country-album-chart-news-for-may-15-2013-lady-antebellum-debuts-at-1-pistol-annies-top-5-with-new-albums-country-music-dominates/|accessdate=September 4, 2014|work=Roughstock|date=May 15, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140905051232/http://roughstock.com/news/country-album-chart-news-for-may-15-2013-lady-antebellum-debuts-at-1-pistol-annies-top-5-with-new-albums-country-music-dominates/|archive-date=September 5, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nCooper released his third album, ''The Grind'', on August 26, 2014.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Frazer|first1=Bear|title=Lenny Cooper: Staying On The Grind|url=https://arena.com/article/lenny-cooper-staying-on-the-grind|accessdate=September 4, 2014|work=Arena|date=August 20, 2014}}</ref> The album features collaborations with Ford, [[Bucky Covington]] and [[Bubba Sparxxx]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Thompson|first1=Gayle|title=Lenny Cooper Releasing 'The Grind'|url=http://theboot.com/lenny-cooper-the-grind/|accessdate=September 4, 2014|work=The Boot|date=August 9, 2014}}</ref> It sold 2,400 copies in its first week of release, debuting at number 17 on the ''Billboard'' Top Country Albums chart and number 142 on the ''Billboard'' 200.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bjorke|first1=Matt|title=Country Album Sales Report \u2013 September 3, 2014|url=http://roughstock.com/news/country-album-sales-report-09-03-2014/|accessdate=September 4, 2014|work=Roughstock|date=September 3, 2014|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140904072435/http://roughstock.com/news/country-album-sales-report-09-03-2014/|archivedate=September 4, 2014}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{redirect|Diesel Fuel|the fuel used in diesel engines|Diesel fuel}}\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"McGuffey_Lane","to":"McGuffey Lane"}],"pages":{"18776139":{"pageid":18776139,"ns":0,"title":"McGuffey Lane","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Refimprove|date=September 2010}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name                = McGuffey Lane\n| image                 =\n| caption            =\n| image_size            =\n| background          = group_or_band\n| origin              = [[Athens, Ohio]], United States\n| genre               = [[Country rock]]\n| years_active        = 1972\u2013present\n| label               = Atco<br/>[[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]<br/>HCH\nLick\n| current_members     = Terry Efaw<br/>Steve Reis<br/> John Schwab<br/>Randy Huff<br/>Molly Pauken<br/>Kevin Reed\n| past_members        = Joe Pate<br/>Bobby Gene McNelley<br/>Tebes Douglass\n| associated_acts     =\n}}\n\n'''McGuffey Lane''' is an American [[country rock]] band from [[Athens, Ohio]], and/or [[Columbus, Ohio]], United States. The group was formed in 1972 by Terry Efaw and Steve Reis, who played together under the name Scotch & Soda. After adding songwriter, lead singer, and guitarist Bobby E. McNelley, they branded themselves McGuffey Lane, the location of Reis's [[Athens, Ohio]], home.\n\nThe band eventually expanded to a sextet and became well-known locally, releasing their first album on their own Paradise Island record label. The [[LP record|LP]] sold more than 40,000 copies,<ref name=amg>{{cite web|author=Sandra Brennan |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/mcguffey-lane-mn0000397192/biography |title=McGuffey Lane &#124; Biography & History |website=[[AllMusic]] |date= |accessdate=2020-04-11}}</ref> and eventually resulted in their signing with [[Atco Records]]. They reissued the debut in 1980 and toured with the [[Charlie Daniels Band]], [[The Judds]], and the [[Allman Brothers Band]]. The follow-up, ''Aqua Dream'', featured the single \"Start It All Over\", which spent three weeks on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], peaking at number 97 in February 1982.<ref name=\"Hot 100 chart history\">{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/mcguffey-lane |title=McGuffey Lane &#124; Billboard |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=2019-02-22 |archive-date=2019-02-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190223094337/https://www.billboard.com/music/mcguffey-lane |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nThe group scored several minor hits on the country charts, but their label wanted to market them more as a pop-country act in the vein of [[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]]. They moved to [[Atlantic Records]] to focus more on country chart success, but as they prepared 1984's ''Day By Day'', keyboardist Tebes Douglass was killed in a [[car crash]]. Soon after, Bobby Gene McNelley left the group to pursue a solo career as a songwriter in [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. In 1985, McGuffey Lane was dropped from Atlantic. In 1986, they released a [[Christmas]] album in support of the Central Ohio Lung Association; toward the end of that year, they inked a sponsorship with [[Miller Beer]], but a planned comeback fizzled.\n\nThe group played into the late 1980s but had dissolved by 1990. In 1995, they reunited after releasing a greatest hits album, and continued performing locally in Ohio into the 2000s. Two full-length releases followed the reunion, in 1998 and 2002. On August 18, 2009,  they opened for [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]] at [[Lifestyle Communities Pavilion|The LC]] in Columbus, Ohio. In March 2010, Lick Records signed a distribution deal with E1 Entertainment, which allows the new McGuffey Lane album to be sold in [[Wal-Mart]] and [[Best Buy]].\n\n==Zachariah's Red Eye Reunion==\nEvery January, McGuffey Lane holds an annual reunion concert featuring many acts who also played at Zachariah's Red Eye Saloon. The first two reunions were held at Villa Milano Banquet and Conference Center, located on Schrock Road on the northeast side of Columbus, Ohio. After the initial two events, John Schwab (who is the organizer of the event) started looking for a larger venue to host the reunion concert, as it had outgrown Villa Milano. He settled on Lifestyles Communities Pavilion (now [[KEMBA Live!]]). The 2013 Reunion currently holds the indoor attendance record at the LC. The fourteenth anniversary took place on January 25, 2014.\n\nSome acts who have taken part in the event are: Rob McNelly (son of original lead singer Bobby Gene McNelly and current guitarist for [[Bob Seger and The Silver Bullet Band]]), John David Call (steel guitarist for [[Pure Prairie League]]), Steve Smith, Gary Ballen, Delyn Christian, Tom Ingham, the Dan Orr Project, Cliff Cody, Grassanine, and [[Erica Blinn]].\n\n==Members==\n*Terry Efaw \u2013 Steel guitar, gutstring guitar, electric guitar\n*Steve Reis \u2013 Bass, vocals\n*Molly Pauken- Mandolin, acoustic guitar, vocals\n*Randy Huff \u2013 Drums, vocals\n*Kevin Reed- Harmonica, vocals\n*John Schwab \u2013 Lead guitar, lead vocals\n*Mike Nugen \u2013 Lead guitar, vocals(select dates)\n\n==Former members==\n*Bobby Gene McNelly \u2013 Lead vocals, acoustic guitar\n*Stephen \"Tebes\" Douglass \u2013 Keyboards, harmonica, vocals\n*Dick Smith \u2013 Drums, guitar, vocals\n*Dave Rangeler \u2013 Drums, vocals\n*Tom Ingham \u2013 Acoustic guitar, harmonica, vocals\n*Delyn Christian \u2013 Harmonica, vocals\n*Casey McKeown \u2013 Keyboards\n*Craig Goodwin \u2013 Acoustic guitar, vocals\n*John Campigotto \u2013 Drums, vocals\n*Dave Robins \u2013 Saxophone\n*Joe Pate \u2013 Drums, also batman\n*Tammy Walkup- Backing vocals\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{|
