mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Shannon_Brown_(singer)","to":"Shannon Brown (singer)"}],"pages":{"2666946":{"pageid":2666946,"ns":0,"title":"Shannon Brown (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name            = Shannon Brown\n| image           = Warm up act Shannon Brown (cropped).jpg\n| caption         = Brown in 2004\n| background      = solo_singer\n| birth_name      = Shannon Leigh Brown\n| birth_date      = {{Birth date and age|1973|7|23}}\n| birth_place     = [[Spirit Lake, Iowa]], U.S.\n| genre           = [[country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 1997\u2013present\n| label           = [[Arista Nashville]]<br />[[BNA Records|BNA]]<br />[[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]]\n| website         =\n}}\n'''Shannon Leigh Brown''' (born July 23, 1973) is an American [[country music]] singer from [[Spirit Lake, Iowa]]. Although she has recorded three albums on various labels, only one of these \u2013 2006's ''[[Corn Fed (album)|Corn Fed]]'' \u2014 was released. In her career, she has charted four singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts, with her highest-charting single being a 2002 cover of [[Deborah Allen]]'s \"Baby I Lied,\" at number 40. She also contributed the song \"Half a Man\" to the soundtrack for the 1998 film ''[[Happy, Texas (film)|Happy, Texas]]''.\n\n==Biography==\n\nAfter several years of touring the Midwest with her father running the soundboard and her mom running lights, Shannon decided to make the move to [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. She paid the bills singing songwriters' demo sessions and managed to maintain her touring schedule of 160 dates a year. Her vocal stylings and industrious approach did not go unnoticed. She is married to video director [[Shaun Silva]] who directed the video for \"Corn Fed.\"\n\n==Career==\nBrown's first recording contract was with [[Arista Nashville]] in 1997. A year later, she began work on her debut album ''A Tour of My Heart''. Although the album's lead-off single (titled \"I Won't Lie\") entered the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts, ''A Tour of My Heart'' was ultimately unreleased. Brown also contributed the song \"Half a Man\" to the soundtrack of the film ''[[Happy, Texas (film)|Happy, Texas]]'' in 1998\n\nIn late 2001, she left for the [[BNA Records|BNA]] label. While on BNA, she began work on a second album, from which two singles were released. The first of these, a song titled \"Baby I Lied,\" was a cover of [[Deborah Allen]]'s Top 5 hit single from 1983. Brown's cover became her only Top 40 hit upon its release. A second single from her BNA album, titled \"Untangle My Heart,\" also charted. Brown's second album also remained unreleased, however, and she exited BNA not long afterward.\n\n[[Warner Bros. Records]] signed Brown to her third recording contract in late 2005. That year, she made her fourth chart entry with the song \"Corn Fed.\" Reaching a peak of 47 on the country music charts, it served as the lead-off single to her first album for Warner Bros., also titled ''[[Corn Fed (album)|Corn Fed]]''. Her third album overall, ''Corn Fed'' was also Brown's first album to be released commercially. The album was produced by [[John Rich (musician)|John Rich]], one half of country music duo [[Big & Rich]]. After its second single, \"Pearls,\" failed to chart, Brown and Warner Bros. parted ways.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:10em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"3\"| Peak chart positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[Billboard 200|US]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[Top Heatseekers|US Heat]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Corn Fed (album)|Corn Fed]]''\n| \n* Release date: February 28, 2006\n* Label: [[Warner Bros. Records]]\n| 34\n| 163\n| 6\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:10em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"60\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n|-\n| 1998\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Won't Lie\"{{efn|\"I Won't Lie\" also reached number 67 on the ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Country Tracks chart in Canada.}}<ref>{{Cite news |date=October 23, 1998 |title=Going for Adds: Country |work=[[Radio & Records]] |page=69 |issue=1271}}</ref>\n| 58\n| align=\"left\"| ''A Tour of My Heart'' <small>(unreleased)</small>\n|-\n| 1999\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Half a Man\"\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| ''[[Happy, Texas (film)|Happy, Texas]]'' <small>(soundtrack)</small>\n|-\n| 2001\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Baby I Lied]]\"\n| 40\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"2\"| ''Untangle My Heart'' <small>(unreleased)</small>\n|-\n|2002\n! scope=\"row\" | \"Untangle My Heart\"<ref>{{Cite news |date=February 15, 2002 |title=Going for Adds: Country |work=[[Radio & Records]] |page=33 |issue=1440}}</ref>\n| 58\n|-\n| 2005\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Corn Fed\"\n| 47\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"2\"| ''Corn Fed''\n|-\n| 2006\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Pearls\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Year\n! style=\"width:10em;\"| Title\n! Director\n|-\n| 1998\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Won't Lie\"\n| [[Steven Goldmann]]\n|-\n| 1999\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Half a Man\"\n|\n|-\n| 2005\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Corn Fed\"\n| [[Shaun Silva]]\n|}\n\n==Notes==\n{{notelist}}\n\n== External links ==\n{{commons category}}\n*{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p355563|label=Shannon Brown}}\n\n== References ==\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Brown, Shannon}}\n[[Category:1973 births]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:BNA Records artists]]\n[[Category:Warner Records artists]]\n[[Category:Arista Nashville artists]]\n[[Category:People from Spirit Lake, Iowa]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Iowa]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Iowa]]\n\n<references />{{Authority control}}"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jo-El_Sonnier","to":"Jo-El Sonnier"}],"pages":{"12190980":{"pageid":12190980,"ns":0,"title":"Jo-El Sonnier","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter (1946\u20132024)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image             = Joelsonnier.jpg\n| name              = Jo-El Sonnier\n| image_size        = 200\n| caption           = Sonnier in 2006\n| birth_name        = Joel Sonnier\n| birth_date        = {{birth date|1946|10|2}}\n| birth_place       = [[Rayne, Louisiana]], U.S.\n| death_date        = {{death date and age|2024|01|13|1946|10|02}}\n| death_place       = [[Llano, Texas]], U.S.\n| origin            =\n| instruments       = [[Cajun accordion]], guitar, harmonica, vocals\n| genre             = [[country music|Country]], [[Cajun music|Cajun]]\n| occupations       = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active      = 1967\u20132024\n| label             = [[Goldband Records|Goldband]], [[Mercury Records|Mercury]], [[Rounder Records|Rounder]], [[RCA Records|RCA]], [[Capitol Records|Capitol]], [[Liberty Records|Liberty]]\n| website           = http://www.jo-elsonnier.com/\n}}\n\n'''Jo-El Sonnier''' ({{IPAc-en|\u0292|o\u028a|\u02cc|\u025b|l|_|s|\u0252|n|\u02c8|j|e\u026a}}; born '''Joel Sonnier'''; October 2, 1946 \u2013 January 13, 2024) was an American singer-songwriter and [[accordionist]] who performed [[country music]] and [[Cajun music]]. Originally signed to [[Mercury Records|Mercury Nashville Records]], Sonnier charted several minor singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts in the late 1970s. By the late 1980s, he had signed to RCA Records, breaking through with the Top Ten hits \"No More One More Time\" and a cover of [[Richard Thompson (musician)|Richard Thompson]]'s \"[[Tear-Stained Letter]]\". Although his chart success waned at the beginning of the 1990s, he continued recording music, releasing more than thirty albums primarily on independent labels.\n\n==Biography==\nJo-El Sonnier was born to French-speaking [[sharecropper]]s in [[Rayne, Louisiana]], on October 2, 1946.<ref name=\"sonnier\">{{Cite web|url=https://jo-elsonnier.com/|title=Jo-el Sonnier|first=Jo-el|last=Sonnier|website=Jo-el sonnier.com|access-date=January 8, 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2017|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2017|page=338|isbn=978-0-89820-229-8}}</ref><ref name=\"LarkinCountry\">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|pages=384/5}}</ref> At age three, he began to play his brother's [[accordion]]. By age six, Sonnier had performed on the radio; at age 11, he made his first recordings.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1812/biography|first=Jo-El|last=Sonnier|tab=Biography|label=Jo-El Sonnier Biography}}</ref> He also released several independent singles and four albums as a teenager.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> By the 1970s, he was signed to [[Mercury Nashville Records]], but without much success in the country music field.\n\nSonnier temporarily abandoned his pursuit of a country music career in favor of recording Cajun music on the independent [[Rounder Records]] label.<ref name=\"sonnier\"/> Although his independent album did not produce much commercial success, it was nominated for a [[Grammy Award]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> After being signed as [[Merle Haggard]]'s opening act, Sonnier later decided to return to country music; he was signed to [[RCA Records]] in the 1980s, where his biggest successes came in the singles \"No More One More Time\" and a cover of British singer [[Richard Thompson (musician)|Richard Thompson]]'s \"[[Tear-Stained Letter]]\", songs which landed in the Top 10 on the country charts.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nIn the 1990s, Sonnier moved to [[Capitol Records]], but his solo career faltered soon afterwards. He continued to find success as a session musician, and briefly took up acting as well.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> In the late 1990s, he returned to Rounder Records to record Cajun music once more, occasionally collaborating with [[Michael Doucet]] of [[BeauSoleil]]. Sonnier also saw his second Grammy nomination, for the 1997 album ''Cajun Pride''; a third soon followed with 2001's ''Cajun Blood'' being nominated for Best Traditional Folk Album.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nIn 2009, Sonnier was inducted into the [[Louisiana Music Hall of Fame]].{{cn|date=January 2024}}\n\nSonnier made a brief cameo appearance as a member of a dance band in the third episode of the first season of the HBO crime series ''[[True Detective]]'', which is set in southern Louisiana.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt2356777/fullcredits|title=True Detective (TV Series 2014\u2013 ) |website=IMDb.com|access-date=January 8, 2020}}</ref>\n\nOn February 8, 2015, Sonnier won a [[Grammy Award]] for Best Regional Roots Music Album.\n\nSonnier died of a heart attack on January 13, 2024, just after a performance at Llano Country Opry in [[Llano, Texas|Llano]], Texas, where he had played for over an hour and received a standing ovation. His performance ended with his signature \"Tear-Stained Letter\" and an encore of \"[[Jambalaya (On the Bayou)|Jambalaya]]\". He was 77.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://999ktdy.com/ixp/36/p/louisiana-cajun-country-music-artist-jo-el-sonnier-dead/|title=Louisiana Cajun and Country Legend Jo-El Sonnier Passes Away After Show in Texas|first=DJ DigitalDJ|last=Digital|date=January 14, 2024|website=99.9 KTDY}}</ref><ref name=\"bill\">{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/jo-el-sonnier-dead-1235581574/|title=Jo-El Sonnier, Grammy-Winning Cajun & Country Singer-Songwriter, Dies at 77|first=Ashley|last=Iasimone|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=January 15, 2024}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nIn 2017, Sonnier self-published a book titled ''The Little Boy Under the Wagon'', in which he revealed that he had been diagnosed with [[Asperger syndrome]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.theadvertiser.com/story/news/2017/12/06/jo-el-sonnier-reveals-disorder-childrens-book/928405001/ | title=Cajun musician's new book addresses his autism challenges | publisher=The Advertiser | date=December 6, 2017 | accessdate=May 29, 2024}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Diana_DeGarmo","to":"Diana DeGarmo"}],"pages":{"467401":{"pageid":467401,"ns":0,"title":"Diana DeGarmo","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2019}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name         = Diana DeGarmo\n| image        = Diana DeGarmo March 2015.jpg\n| caption      = DeGarmo on the 2015 [[USO]] tour\n| birth_name   = Diana Nicole DeGarmo\n| birth_date   = {{birth date and age|1987|6|16}}\n| birth_place  = [[Birmingham, Alabama]], U.S.\n| genre        = [[country music|Country]], pop\n| origin       = [[Snellville, Georgia]], U.S.\n| years_active = 1996\u2013present\n| occupation   = Singer, songwriter, actress\n| label        = [[RCA Records|RCA]], [[Mailboat Records|Mailboat]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mailboatrecords.com/news.html |title=News |publisher=Mailboat Records |access-date=November 19, 2012 |archive-date=November 27, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121127064126/http://www.mailboatrecords.com/news.html |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n| spouse = [[Ace Young]] (m. 2013)\n| website      = {{URL|www.dianadegarmo.com}}\n}}\n'''Diana Nicole DeGarmo''' (born June 16, 1987<ref>{{cite web |author=HL Intern |url=http://www.hollywoodlife.com/2011/06/16/diana-degarmo-birthday-celebrity-horoscope/ |title=Happy Birthday, Diana DeGarmo! Today, Jun. 16, You're 24 Years Old! |publisher=Hollywood Life |date=June 16, 2011 |access-date=November 19, 2012 |archive-date=December 6, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111206174037/http://www.hollywoodlife.com/2011/06/16/diana-degarmo-birthday-celebrity-horoscope/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>) is an American singer-songwriter and actress. She rose to fame in 2004 as the runner-up of the [[American Idol (season 3)|third season]] of ''[[American Idol]]'', releasing her debut studio album, ''[[Blue Skies (Diana DeGarmo album)|Blue Skies]]'', later that year. The following year, DeGarmo ventured into a career in musical theatre. She has starred in two [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]], one off-Broadway and three national tours. She made her television acting debut in a six-month arc as [[Angelina Veneziano]] on ''[[The Young and the Restless]].'' DeGarmo has since released two extended plays, ''Unplugged in Nashville'' (2009) and ''Live to Love'' (2012). She is married to [[American Idol (season 5)|fifth season]] ''American Idol'' finalist [[Ace Young]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Helling |first=Steve |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20705569,00.html |title=Ace Young Marries Diana DeGarmo |work=People |date=July 31, 2014 |access-date=August 4, 2014}}</ref>\n\n== Early life ==\nDiana DeGarmo was born on June 16, 1987 in [[Birmingham, Alabama]], but was raised primarily in the [[Atlanta]] suburb of [[Snellville, Georgia]]. DeGarmo began singing at a young age, including the 1997 Georgia Music Hall of Fame Awards, and in Atlanta-based stage productions of ''[[Annie (musical)|Annie]]'' and ''[[Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat]].\nAt age ten she was part of the Cartoon Gang on The Cartoon Network, appearing in various bumper segments. As a third grader she was a Coca-Cola Kid during the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, Georgia. The next year she sang at Opryland USA during the Christmas season. In 2002, she was named [[Miss Georgia's Outstanding Teen|Miss Georgia Teen]] and was also a finalist on the NBC talent search program ''America's Most Talented Kid''.\n\n== Career ==\n=== ''American Idol'' ===\nDeGarmo took part in the third season of ''[[American Idol]]'' in 2004, finishing second to winner [[Fantasia Barrino]].<ref name=\"GarmoAI\">{{cite news |first= Jaime |last= Holguin |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/fantasia-wins-american-idol/ |work= CBS News |title= Fantasia Wins 'American Idol' |date= November 24, 2004}}</ref> She was 16 years old at the time she competed.\n\nDuring her run on ''American Idol'' she was thrice in the bottom three, but was the first contestant sent to safety each time and thus never in the bottom two. She became one of the front-runners by week 6.\n\nShe performed around the country with the other third-season top-ten contestants during the summer of 2004.\n\n====Performances====\n{|class=\"wikitable\"\n|-  style=\"text-align:Center; background:#ccc;\"\n| colspan=\"100\"|'''Week #'''\n| colspan=\"100\"|'''Song choice'''\n| colspan=\"100\"|'''Original artist'''\n| colspan=\"100\"|'''Result'''\n|-  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"\n| colspan=\"100\"|Top 32\n| colspan=\"100\"|\"[[I've Got the Music in Me]]\"\n| colspan=\"100\"|[[Kiki Dee]]\n| colspan=\"100\"|Advanced\n|-\n| colspan=\"100\"  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"|Safe\n|-  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"\n| colspan=\"100\"|Top 6\n| colspan=\"100\"|\"[[Turn the Beat Around]]\"\n| colspan=\"100\"|[[Vicki Sue Robinson]]\n| colspan=\"100\"|Safe\n|-\n| colspan=\"100\"  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"|Top 5\n| colspan=\"100\"  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"|\"[[Someone to Watch Over Me (song)|Someone to Watch Over Me]]\"<br>\"[[Get Happy (song)|Get Happy]]\"\n| colspan=\"100\"  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"|[[Gertrude Lawrence]]<br>[[Ruth Etting]]\n| colspan=\"100\"  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"|Safe\n|-\n| colspan=\"100\"  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"|Top 4\n| colspan=\"100\"  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"|\"[[This Is It (Van McCoy song)|This Is It]]\"<br>\"[[No More Tears (Enough Is Enough)]]\"\n| colspan=\"100\"  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"|[[Melba Moore]]<br>[[Donna Summer]] & [[Barbra Streisand]]\n| colspan=\"100\"  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"|Safe\n|-\n| colspan=\"100\"  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"|Top 3\n| colspan=\"100\"  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"|\"[[Ain't No Mountain High Enough]]\"<br>\"[[Because You Loved Me]]\"<br>\"[[Don't Cry Out Loud (song)|Don't Cry Out Loud]]\"\n| colspan=\"100\"  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"|[[Marvin Gaye]] & [[Tammi Terrell]]<br>Celine Dion<br>[[Ray, Goodman & Brown|The Moments]]\n| colspan=\"100\"  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"|Safe\n|-\n| colspan=\"100\"  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"|Finale\n| colspan=\"100\"  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"|\"[[I Believe (Fantasia song)|I Believe]]\"<br> \"No More Tears (Enough Is Enough)\"<br>\"Don't Cry Out Loud\" (Encore)\n| colspan=\"100\"  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"|[[Fantasia Barrino]]/Diana DeGarmo<br>Donna Summer & Barbra Streisand<br>The Moments\n| colspan=\"100\"  style=\"text-align:center; background:#faf6f6;\"|Runner-up\n|}\n\n=== Post-''Idol'' music ===\n[[File:Diana DeGarmo with flag.jpg|DeGarmo on a 2005 [[USO]] tour|thumb|left]]\nDeGarmo was signed to RCA Records shortly after the ''Idol'' finale and released her single, \"[[Dreams (Diana DeGarmo song)|Dreams]],\" on June 29, 2004.  The single reached number 2 in Canada and number 14 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart. The single also included her version of \"[[I Believe (Fantasia song)|I Believe]]\" and a remake of [[Melissa Manchester]]'s \"Don't Cry Out Loud\". She recorded her debut album in between ''Idol'' summer tour stops.\n\nDeGarmo's debut album, ''[[Blue Skies (Diana DeGarmo album)|Blue Skies]]'', was released on December 7, 2004, to opening week sales of 47,000. The album debuted at number 52 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and included songs written by future American Idol judge [[Kara DioGuardi]], as well as [[Desmond Child]], Adam Shankman, and Andreas Carlsson, among others. As of fall 2008, the album had sold 168,000 copies with little to no advertising.<ref>[http://blogs.usatoday.com/idolchatter/2008/10/kristy-lee-take.html#more]  {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081004082639/http://blogs.usatoday.com/idolchatter/2008/10/kristy-lee-take.html#more |date=October 4, 2008 }}</ref> The lone single from the CD, \"Emotional\", was released to radio in November 2004, peaking at number 54 on the [[Mediabase Pop Chart]]. She toured independently in the spring and summer of 2005 in support of ''Blue Skies.'' During the same time she recorded a song for the soundtrack of the [[Walt Disney Company|Disney]] movie ''[[Ice Princess]]''. \"Reaching for Heaven\", written by Desmond Child, can be heard during the climactic ice skating scene in the movie.<ref>{{cite web|last=Phares |first=Heather |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/ice-princess-mw0000670136 |title=Ice Princess \u2013 Original Soundtrack : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |website=[[AllMusic]] |date=March 15, 2005 |access-date=November 19, 2012}}</ref> In June 2005, RCA and DeGarmo parted ways. On September 17, 2005, DeGarmo received the Horizon Award at the Georgia Music Hall Of Fame Awards ceremony; the award recognizes Georgia artists on the path to successful and lengthy careers.\n\nDeGarmo began recording a pop/R&B album in 2007;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.al.com/mcolurso/2007/04/diana_degarmo_not_a_girl_not_y.html |title=Diana DeGarmo growing up, finding her way &#124; AL.com |website=Blog.al.com |date=April 27, 2007 |access-date=August 4, 2014}}</ref> however, she backed out of the project to return to her country music roots.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1581697/gone-countrys-diana-degarmo-moves-to-nashville.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080218203252/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1581697/gone-countrys-diana-degarmo-moves-to-nashville.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 18, 2008 |title=News : Gone Country's Diana DeGarmo Moves to Nashville |publisher=CMT |date=February 15, 2008 |access-date=August 4, 2014}}</ref> After filming [[Country Music Television|CMT]]'s ''[[Gone Country (television series)|Gone Country]]'' in late 2007, she relocated to Nashville. She signed to John Rich's production company and recorded material with him in 2008. The songs were never released and DeGarmo moved on to other collaborators.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1046162/catching-up-with-past-american-idol-finalists |title=Catching Up With Past 'American Idol' Finalists |magazine=Billboard |access-date=August 4, 2014}}</ref> In February 2009 she self-released a four-song acoustic country EP, ''Unplugged in Nashville'', to digital retailers.\n\nIn March 2012, DeGarmo wrote \"Good Goodbye\" for use with her character on ''The Young and the Restless''. It was released to iTunes and was included on her May 2012 EP ''Live to Love''. After producing a music video for \"Good Goodbye,\" fans were asked to vote on two versions of the video on the ''American Idol'' website.<ref name=\"music video\" /> The winning video became available on iTunes.\n\nDeGarmo's second album, ''Gemini'', was released August 2, 2019 with a release concert at [[Sony Hall]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/8500187/diana-degarmo-gemini|title=Diana DeGarmo Gemini, Billboard}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.timessquarenyc.org/whats-happening/diana-degarmo|title=Diana DeGarmo, Times Square NYC}}</ref> DeGarmo presented and streamed a live concert of ''Gemini'' in the summer of 2020, ultimately winning the 2020 BroadwayWorld Award for Best Streamed Concert.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Winners-Announced-For-The-2020-BroadwayWorld-Cabaret-Awards-20210113|title=Winners Announced for the 2020 BroadwayWorld Cabaret Awards}}</ref>\n\n=== Musical theatre ===\nDeGarmo made her major stage debut as Maria in an [[American Musical Theatre of San Jose]] production of ''[[West Side Story (musical)|West Side Story]]'' in November 2005. She followed with her Broadway debut in a four-month run of ''[[Hairspray (musical)|Hairspray]]'' as nerdy [[Penny Pingleton]] taking over for Tracy Miller in February 2006. She also performed the lead role of Brooklyn in the 2006 national tour of ''Brooklyn: The Musical'' alongside one of her idols, [[Melba Moore]]. DeGarmo returned to ''Hairspray'' for a second engagement from September 2006 to February 2007. She made her [[Carnegie Hall]] debut in April 2007 at a tribute to Neil Sedaka.\n\nIn 2008, DeGarmo was set to star in a Broadway revival of ''[[Godspell]]'' at the [[Ethel Barrymore Theatre]], but on August 19, it was announced that the show was postponed indefinitely due to the loss of an investor.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/120416.html |title=Broadway Revival of Godspell Postponed |work=Playbill |access-date=August 4, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224015019/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/120416.html |archive-date=February 24, 2009 }}</ref>\n\nIn May 2009, DeGarmo starred in the musical revue ''[[Back to Bacharach and David]],'' which featured the songs of [[Burt Bacharach]] and [[Hal David]]. The [[Kathy Najimy]] created and produced show played a limited two-week engagement in Los Angeles at the Music Box Theater on Hollywood Boulevard.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/127306.html |title=Birdsong, DeGarmo, Lowe and Thomas to Star in Back to Bacharach and David |work=Playbill |date=March 13, 2009 |access-date=August 4, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090416214847/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/127306.html |archive-date=April 16, 2009 }}</ref> In July 2009, she starred as the narrator in the Oklahoma Lyric's Theatre production of ''[[Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat]]'' alongside ''Idol'' alum [[Anthony Federov]].<ref>[http://www.americanidol.com/news/view/pid/1752 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090611150514/http://www.americanidol.com/news/view/pid/1752 |date=June 11, 2009 }}</ref> Her next role saw her return to New York City when she debuted in August 2009 as Sarah, the \"sexy, blind librarian\" and love interest of Toxie, in the off-Broadway musical ''[[The Toxic Avenger (musical)|The Toxic Avenger]].''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/131099-DeGarmo_to_Join_Cast_of_Off-Broadway%27s_Toxic_Avenger |title=DeGarmo to Join Cast of Off-Broadway's Toxic Avenger |work=Playbill |date=July 14, 2009 |access-date=August 4, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090717034309/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/131099-DeGarmo_to_Join_Cast_of_Off-Broadway%27s_Toxic_Avenger |archive-date=July 17, 2009 }}</ref> The show was housed at New World Stages. DeGarmo remained with ''Avenger'' until it closed on January 3, 2010.\n\nDeGarmo made her return to Broadway, starring as Sheila in the Broadway company of ''[[Hair (musical)|Hair]]'' where she met her future husband, Ace Young. She succeeded original cast member [[Caissie Levy]] beginning March 9, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadway.com/shows/hair/buzz/kyle-riabko-ace-young-and-diana-degarmo-hair-new-headliners-complete-cast-announced/ |title=Kyle Riabko, Ace Young and Diana DeGarmo Are Hair's New Headliners; Complete Cast Announced &#124; Broadway Buzz |website=Broadway.com |date=February 16, 2010 |access-date=August 4, 2014}}</ref> She played Sheila until the show's closure on June 27, 2010.\n\nDeGarmo played the role of Doralee Rhodes in the national tour of ''[[9 to 5 (musical)|9 to 5]]'', which was launched in [[Nashville]] on September 21, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/141603-Diana-DeGarmo-Cast-in-National-Tour-of-9-to-5 |title=Diana DeGarmo Cast in National Tour of 9 to 5 |work=Playbill |access-date=August 4, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808054412/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/141603-Diana-DeGarmo-Cast-in-National-Tour-of-9-to-5 |archive-date=August 8, 2014 }}</ref> She ended her run as Doralee after the July 2011 Minneapolis tour stop.\n\nDeGarmo appeared on musical theatre composer Scott Alan's third album, ''What I Wanna Be When I Grow Up'' with the song \"I Wish\", released November 1, 2010.\n\nShe reprised the role of Penny Pingleton in the [[Hollywood Bowl]] production of ''Hairspray'', which ran from August 5\u20137, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://broadwayworld.com/article/HAIRSPRAY-at-the-Hollywood-Bowl-to-Star-Fierstein-Winokur-Bleu-Carey-DeGarmo-Jonas-Stamos-More-20110524 |title=HAIRSPRAY at the Hollywood Bowl to Star Fierstein, Winokur, Bleu, Carey, DeGarmo, Jonas, Stamos & More |website=Broadwayworld.com |date=August 15, 2002 |access-date=August 4, 2014}}</ref>\n\nDeGarmo has done several readings for new musicals over the years, starting with ''In Your Dreams'' in early October 2006. In 2009, she played the title role in a concert for ''Liberty: A New Musical'' at the New York Musical Theatre Festival (NYMF) and in 2009 played the role of ''Chris'' in the much anticipated reading of an updated [[Carrie (musical)|''Carrie: The Musical'']]. In 2011 and again in 2013 she played Fern/Vylette in Manhattan industry readings of \"Jawbreaker,\" a musical based on the 1990s movie of the same name.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://broadwayworld.com/article/Diana-DeGarmo-Van-Hughes-et-al-Lead-JAWBREAKER-Reading-20110928 |title=Diana DeGarmo, Van Hughes, et al. Lead JAWBREAKER Reading |website=Broadwayworld.com |date=September 28, 2011 |access-date=November 19, 2012}}</ref>\n\nIn January 2013, DeGarmo played \"Sally\" in the pre-Broadway run of the new musical \"NERDS,\" in Raleigh, NC, for the North Carolina Theatre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/172265-North-Carolina-Staging-of-Broadway-Aimed-Nerds-to-Feature-Darren-Ritchie-Stanley-Bahorek-Leslie-Kritzer-Diana-DeGarmo |title=North Carolina Staging of Broadway-Aimed Nerds to Feature Darren Ritchie, Stanley Bahorek, Leslie Kritzer, Diana DeGarmo |work=Playbill |access-date=August 4, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808054441/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/172265-North-Carolina-Staging-of-Broadway-Aimed-Nerds-to-Feature-Darren-Ritchie-Stanley-Bahorek-Leslie-Kritzer-Diana-DeGarmo |archive-date=August 8, 2014 }}</ref>\n\nDeGarmo played The Narrator in the national tour of [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]]'s musical ''[[Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat]]'' from March 4, 2014, to April 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/181233-Husband-and-Wife-Ace-Young-and-Diana-DeGarmo-Will-Lead-2014-Tour-of-Joseph-and-the-Amazing-Technicolor-Dreamcoat |title=Husband and Wife Ace Young and Diana DeGarmo Will Lead 2014 Tour of Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat |work=Playbill |access-date=August 4, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140303001839/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/181233-Husband-and-Wife-Ace-Young-and-Diana-DeGarmo-Will-Lead-2014-Tour-of-Joseph-and-the-Amazing-Technicolor-Dreamcoat |archive-date=March 3, 2014 }}</ref>\n\nIn June 2015, DeGarmo starred as Dorothy in Studio Tenn's production of ''[[Adaptations of The Wonderful Wizard of Oz|The Wizard of Oz]]'' at The Schermerhorn Symphony Theater in Nashville, Tennessee.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.studiotenn.com/news-press|title=Press|website=Studiotenn.com|access-date=2020-04-08|archive-date=July 15, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190715111409/http://www.studiotenn.com/news-press|url-status=dead}}</ref> She and Young are set to lead the first national tour of ''[[First Date (musical)|First Date]]'', which is set to launch in the fall of 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Diana-DeGarmo-and-Ace-Young-To-Lead-FIRST-DATE-National-Tour-20190613 |title=Diana DeGarmo and Ace Young To Lead FIRST DATE National Tour |website=Broadwayworld.com |date=June 13, 2019 |access-date=June 14, 2019}}</ref>\n\nShe played Lucy in the 2016 to 2017 world tour of ''[[Jekyll & Hyde (musical)|Jekyll & Hyde]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/south-korea/article/Photo-Flash-World-Tour-of-JEKYLL-AND-HYDE-Opens-in-South-Korea-Starring-Kyle-Dean-Massey-and-Diana-Degarmo-20170312|title=Photo Flash: World Tour of JEKYLL AND HYDE Opens in South Korea Starring Kyle Dean Massey and Diana Degarmo|last=Musbach|first=Julie|date=March 12, 2017|access-date=March 29, 2023|work=BroadwayWorld}}</ref>\n\nIn 2023, she played the Witch in a regional production of ''[[Into the Woods]]''. In 2024, she returned to the regional stage as Audrey in [[Little Shop of Horrors (musical)|''Little Shop of Horrors'']].<ref>[https://www.broadwayworld.com/columbus/article/Feature-INTO-THE-WOODS-at-Short-North-Stage-20230309 Feature: INTO THE WOODS at Short North Stage]</ref>\n\n=== Film and television ===\nDeGarmo joined the cast of ''The Young and the Restless'' in October 2011. She portrayed [[Angelina Veneziano]], the daughter of resident mobster, [[Angelo Veneziano|Angelo]]. Her character was a terrible singer who was obsessed with gaining the affections of [[Kevin Fisher (The Young and the Restless)|Kevin Fisher]]. Her character went through a redemption arc, and by the time her last episode aired in March 2012, Angelina not only could sing, she had matured into a kinder and gentler character.\n\nIn film, DeGarmo played [[Dora Hand]], a dance hall singer in the 2012 [[Western (genre)|western]] film ''Wyatt Earp's Revenge.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://movies.broadwayworld.com/article/Diana_DeGarmo_Val_Kilmer_Set_for_The_First_Ride_of_Wyatt_Earp_Film_20110318 |title=Diana DeGarmo, Val Kilmer Set for 'The First Ride of Wyatt Earp' Film |website=Movies.broadwayworld.com |access-date=November 19, 2012}}</ref>\n\nDeGarmo made a cameo appearance as herself in the Lifetime Network holiday movie ''All About Christmas Eve'' starring [[Haylie Duff]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://via.me/-3eoqs0s |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130221010727/http://via.me/-3eoqs0s |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 21, 2013 |title=Diana DeGarmo (DianaDeGarmo) : Hanging on set with @HaylieK @I |website=Via.me |access-date=November 19, 2012 }}</ref> She also appeared on the second season of TLC's wedding dress show ''Brides of Beverly Hills'', which documented her search for a wedding dress.<ref name=\"celebuzz.com\">{{cite web|url=http://www.celebuzz.com/2012-10-08/american-idol-alums-diana-degarmo-and-ace-young-set-a-wedding-date-and-the-bride-to-be-picks-a-wedding-dress-exclusive-details/ |title=Diana DeGarmo News \u2013 'American Idol' Alums Diana DeGarmo and Ace Young Set a Wedding Date, Bride-To-Be Picks A Wedding Dress (EXCLUSIVE DETAILS) |website=Celebuzz.com |date=October 8, 2012 |access-date=November 19, 2012}}</ref>\n\nDuring 2013, DeGarmo and Ace Young hosted a weekly one-hour entertainment show, ''Planet 360''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/Planet360tv?ref=ts&fref=ts |title=Planet 360 |website=Facebook.com |access-date=August 4, 2014}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=October 2019}} It started on the Hallmark Movie Channel in March, moved to TVGN in May and was canceled in December.\n\nIn 2013, DeGarmo starred in an independent film comedy, ''[[Alto (film)|Alto]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1577040/?ref_=nm_flmg_act_1|title=Alto|website=IMDb.com|access-date=August 4, 2014}}</ref> DeGarmo's character, Frankie, is a struggling musician who falls in love with the daughter of a mafia don, and the two women become involved in a murder while also trying to come out to \"Family.\" As of June 2015 the film has been shown at four festivals: The Miami Gay and Lesbian Film Festival, The VisionFest Film Festival in New York City, the [[Hoboken International Film Festival]] in Middletown, New York and the Frameline LGBTQ film festival in San Francisco. DeGarmo was nominated for the Jack Nance Breakthrough Performance Award at VisionFest, where Alto won the Audience Award.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.visionfest.com/press/releases/ |title=Domani Vision Film Society :: Press :: Releases |access-date=May 16, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170208231933/http://www.visionfest.com/press/releases/ |archive-date=February 8, 2017 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nIn 2016, DeGarmo's third film, ''The Morning Sun'', based on the play ''The Morning the Sun Fell Down'', was released.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wnypapers.com/news/article/featured/2015/10/12/122343/morning-sun-rising-in-village-of-lewiston-watch-video-of-film-announcement|title='Morning Sun' rising in Village of Lewiston; watch video of film announcement|website=Wnypapers.com|access-date=2020-04-08}}</ref>\n\n===Charities===\nDeGarmo is a celebrity ambassador of the Muscular Dystrophy Association, and supports the cause at events including the 2012 MDA \"Show of Strength\" Telethon to raise money for children and adults with neuromuscular disease.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/mda-show-of-strength-features-star-studded-talent-focuses-on-families-165637676.html |title=MDA Show Of Strength\u2122 Features Star-studded Talent, Focuses On Families \u2013 TUCSON, Ariz., Aug. 9, 2012 /PRNewswire-USNewswire/ |agency=PR Newswire |access-date=November 19, 2012}}</ref> She also supports and performs in fundraisers for a number of charitable organizations both nationally and locally, including Broadway Cares/Equity Fights Aids.\n\n===Other activities===\nDeGarmo was the first ''American Idol'' finalist to participate in a USO tour. She has been on four USO tours overseas:\n* From December 2005 through January 2006 she entertained troops in Southwest Asia on a tour hosted by General [[Peter Pace]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uso.org/gallery/details.aspx?id=74 |title=Diana DeGarmo entertains the troops |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613005646/http://uso.org/gallery/details.aspx?id=74 |archive-date=June 13, 2010 }}</ref> Her song \"Thank You\" is inspired by this trip.\n* In April 2012, she and Ace Young toured, accompanied by fellow performers and athletes Anthony Anderson, Weeman, Dennis Haysbert, Randy Johnson, and The Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=116010 |title=News Article: Final Stop on USO Tour Brings Out Ramstein Troops, Families |website=Defense.gov |access-date=November 19, 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114012842/http://www.defense.gov/News/NewsArticle.aspx?ID=116010 |archive-date=November 14, 2012 }}</ref>\n* In February 2013 she toured with Ace Young, Peyton Manning, Austin Collie, Curt Schilling and the Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sigonellamwr.com/|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130411201759/http://www.sigonellamwr.com/?event=uso-spring-troop-visit|url-status=dead|title=USO Spring Troop Visit|archive-date=April 11, 2013|access-date=February 26, 2013}}</ref>\n* In March 2015, DeGarmo, Andrew Luck, Weeman, Miss America, and several other celebrities toured the Middle East and military installations in Korea, Japan, and Hawaii.\n\nIn late 2007/early 2008, DeGarmo participated as a Southern celebrity in television ads for the [[Zaxby's]] restaurant chain. She also made a guest appearance as Cosmo's singing voice in ''[[The Fairly OddParents]]'' episode ''Fairy Idol.''\n\nIn November 2008, DeGarmo appeared on the Howard Stern Show.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://prowrestling.net/artman/publish/InterviewHighlights/article1003330.shtml|title=Kurt Angle appears on Howard Stern with a musical performer who is now involved with TNA, says wrestling is harder than MMA, says he would rather not do business with Vince McMahon again but won't rule it out either|website=Prowrestling.net|access-date=2020-04-08}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nDeGarmo is the niece of [[Eddie DeGarmo]] of [[DeGarmo & Key]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.inthefaith.com/2004/05/25/american-idol-fantasia-barrino-diana-degarmo-ties-to-the-christian-church/ | title = American Idol Contestants Ties to the Christian Church | author = Anthony K. Valley | access-date = June 3, 2016 | date = May 25, 2004 | archive-date = May 6, 2006 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20060506220726/http://www.inthefaith.com/2004/05/25/american-idol-fantasia-barrino-diana-degarmo-ties-to-the-christian-church/ | url-status = dead}}</ref>\n\nDeGarmo married [[Ace Young]] on June 1, 2013, at the Luxe Sunset Boulevard hotel in Los Angeles.<ref name=\"Young Marries DeGarmo\">{{cite web|last=Helling|first=Steve|title=Ace Young Marries Diana DeGarmo|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20705569,00.html|work=People|access-date=June 1, 2013}}</ref> She lives in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] with Young.\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Details\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak chart<br />positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Sales\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! style=\"width:4em;\"| [[Billboard 200|US]]\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Details\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak chart<br />positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Sales\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! style=\"width:4em;\"| [[Billboard 200|US]]\n|-\n! style=\"width:20px;\" rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Title\n! colspan=\"2\"| Chart positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|-\n! style=\"width:60px;\"| <small>[[Billboard Hot 100|US]]</small>\n! style=\"width:60px;\"| <small>[[Canadian Hot 100|CAN]]</small>\n|-\n|rowspan=\"2\"| 2004\n| \"[[Dreams (Diana DeGarmo song)|Dreams]]\"\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| 14\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| 2\n|Non-album single\n|-\n| \"Emotional\"\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n|''Blue Skies''\n|-\n| 2012\n| \"Good Goodbye\"<ref name=\"music video\">{{Cite web|url=https://abc.com/shows/american-idol/diana_degarmo/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425224556/http://www.americanidol.com/diana_degarmo/|url-status=dead|title=Watch American Idol TV Show - ABC.com|website=[[American Broadcasting Company]] |archive-date=April 25, 2012}}</ref>\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n| ''Live to Love''; featured on ''[[The Young and the Restless]]''\n|}\n\n===Other recordings===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Year\n! Title\n! Director\n|-\n| 2012\n| \"Good Goodbye\"\n| [[Spenser Cohen]]\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}\n\n==External links==\n{{Commons|Diana DeGarmo}}\n* {{Official website|http://www.dianadegarmo.com/}}\n*{{IMDb name|0208527}}\n\n{{American Idol 3}}\n{{American Idol}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Degarmo, Diana}}\n[[Category:1987 births]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American actresses]]\n[[Category:American child singers]]\n[[Category:American Idol participants]]\n[[Category:American women singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American musical theatre actresses]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Singers from Birmingham, Alabama]]\n[[Category:19 Recordings artists]]\n[[Category:People from Snellville, Georgia]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Alabama]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Georgia (U.S. state)]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Tracy_Byrd","to":"Tracy Byrd"}],"pages":{"1745354":{"pageid":1745354,"ns":0,"title":"Tracy Byrd","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American musician}}\n{{For|the boxer|Tracy Byrd (boxer)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name                = Tracy Byrd\n| image               = Tracy Byrd at the Republic Country Club, 3-22-19 MG 5817 (33617141408) (cropped).jpg\n| alt = A head shot of country music singer Tracy Byrd.\n| caption             = Byrd in 2019\n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          = Tracy Lynn Byrd\n| birth_date          = {{birth date and age|1966|12|17}}\n| origin              = [[Vidor, Texas|Vidor]], Texas, United States\n| instrument          = Vocals\n| genre               = [[country music|Country]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = 1992\u2013present\n| label               = [[MCA Records|MCA Nashville]], [[RCA Records|RCA Nashville]], [[BNA Records|BNA]], Blind Mule\n| website             = http://tracybyrdmusic.com/\n}}\n'''Tracy Lynn Byrd''' (born December 17, 1966)<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.oxfordreference.com/display/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803095539683?rskey=qYyYYO&result=1 | title=Tracy Byrd }}</ref> is an American [[country music]] artist. Signed to [[Universal Music Group Nashville|MCA Nashville]] Records in 1992, Byrd broke through on the country music scene that year with his 1993 single \"[[Holdin' Heaven]]\", which reached Number One on ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Singles & Tracks]]. Although he did not land a second Number One until 2002's \"[[Ten Rounds with Jose Cuervo]]\", Byrd has charted more than thirty hit singles in his career, including eleven additional Top Ten hits. He has also released ten studio albums and two greatest-hits albums, with four gold certifications and one double-platinum certification from the [[Recording Industry Association of America]]. He was the on-air spokesman for the TNN Outdoors block from 1998 to 2000.\n\n==Biography==\nTracy Lynn Byrd was born December 17, 1966. He is the eldest child of Jerry Lynn and Brenda Vaughn Byrd. Tracy Byrd graduated from [[Vidor High School]] in May 1985. His first college experience was at [[Lamar University]], Beaumont, Texas. He began studying business at [[Texas State University]] (then called Southwest Texas State). While studying he sang with a local band in Beaumont called Rimfire led by Jeffrey Adams and Dave Adams, a band that also featured acts such as [[Mark Chesnutt]].\n\nOne of his friends coaxed him into singing a cover of [[Hank Williams]]' \"[[Your Cheatin' Heart]]\" at a local mall recording studio.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p37699/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Tracy Byrd biography|last=Huey|first=Steve|work=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=May 21, 2009}}</ref> The owner of the studio was so impressed with his version that he entered Byrd into a local talent contest. Byrd signed with [[MCA Records]] in 1992.<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=73|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref>\n\n==Music career==\n\n===1992\u20131999: MCA Records===\n\n====''Tracy Byrd''====\nByrd released his first single, \"That's the Thing About a Memory\", in 1992. Although it and follow-up \"Someone to Give My Love To\" (previously a single in 1971 for [[Johnny Paycheck]]<ref name=\"oldies\">{{cite web|url=http://www.oldies.com/artist-biography/Tracy-Byrd.html|title=Tracy Byrd biography|work=Oldies.com|access-date=May 21, 2009}}</ref>) both missed Top 40, he broke through in 1993 with the Number One hit \"[[Holdin' Heaven]]\".<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> This song was the third release from his self-titled [[Tracy Byrd (album)|debut album]], released by MCA on April 27, 1993. Although the album earned [[RIAA]] gold certification, its final single (\"Why Don't That Telephone Ring\") peaked at No.&nbsp;39. [[Keith Stegall]] and [[Tony Brown (record producer)|Tony Brown]] shared production duties on the album.\n\n====''No Ordinary Man''====\n''[[No Ordinary Man]]'' was the title of Byrd's second album, which was produced by [[Jerry Crutchfield]]. It was also his highest selling, earning a double-platinum certification for U.S. sales of two million copies. All four singles from the album reached Top Five: \"[[Lifestyles of the Not So Rich and Famous]]\", \"[[Watermelon Crawl]]\" (also his first entry on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], at No.&nbsp;81), \"[[The First Step (song)|The First Step]]\" and \"[[The Keeper of the Stars]]\". This last song, a love ballad, became a popular choice for fans to use at their weddings.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> It also won Song of the Year at the Academy of Country Music in 1995.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://countrymusic.about.com/library/blprevacmsong.htm |title=ACMs \u2013 Previous Winners \u2013 Song of the Year |access-date=March 5, 2008 |work=[[About.com]]}}</ref> MCA had not originally planned to issue this song as a single, until Byrd commented that it had been receiving favorable reactions when he sang it in concert.<ref name=\"new\">{{cite journal |author=Brian Mansfield |date=April 1995 |title=City Lights: Byrd's Latest 'Keeper' |journal=New Country |volume=2 |issue=5 |pages=16 |issn=1074-536X }}</ref>\n\n====''Love Lessons''====\nHis third album, 1995's ''[[Love Lessons (album)|Love Lessons]]'', showed a decline in both chart performance and physical sales,<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> despite still earning a gold certification. It was led off by the No.&nbsp;15 \"Walkin' to Jerusalem\", followed by two ballads: the No.&nbsp;9-peaking title track and No.&nbsp;14 \"[[Heaven in My Woman's Eyes]]\", and finally the No.&nbsp;21-peaking \"[[4 to 1 in Atlanta]]\". This album also reunited him with Tony Brown, who would also produce all of his subsequent material for MCA.\n\n====''Big Love''====\n''[[Big Love (Tracy Byrd album)|Big Love]]'', released in 1996, was the title of Byrd's fourth album and its first single. \"[[Big Love (Tracy Byrd song)|Big Love]]\" returned him to the Top Five with a No.&nbsp;3 peak. After it came another Johnny Paycheck cover, this time of his 1971 single \"She's All I Got.\" Re-titled \"[[Don't Take Her She's All I Got]]\", Byrd's cover peaked at No.&nbsp;4. The album's other singles (\"Don't Love Make a Diamond Shine\" and \"Good Ol' Fashioned Love\") reached No.&nbsp;17 and No.&nbsp;47 respectively, with the latter being his first single since 1993 to miss Top 40. ''Big Love'' also became his third gold-selling album.\n\n====''I'm from the Country'' and ''Keepers: Greatest Hits''====\nByrd released his final studio album for MCA, ''[[I'm from the Country]]'', in late 1997. Its [[I'm from the Country (song)|title track]], co-written by Richard Young of [[The Kentucky Headhunters]] and former [[MCA Records]] artist [[Marty Brown (singer)|Marty Brown]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/B/Byrd_Tracy/1998/06/11/743676.html|title=Byrd watching: Tracy Byrd continues his hit-making ways|last=Overall|first=Rick|date=June 1, 1998|work=Canoe \u2013 Jam! Showbiz Music|access-date=June 8, 2009|url-status=usurped|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120714142742/http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/B/Byrd_Tracy/1998/06/11/743676.html|archive-date=July 14, 2012}}</ref> became the first single. This song was added to the album, which was originally to be titled ''Walkin' the Line'', after the rest of the album had already been completed. It also became his ninth Top 10 hit by reaching No.&nbsp;3 in early 1998 and his first No.&nbsp;1 on the ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Country Tracks charts in Canada. Only one other single, the No.&nbsp;9 hit \"I Wanna Feel That Way Again\", was released from the album.\n\nIn 1999, Byrd then released a greatest-hits package entitled ''[[Keepers: Greatest Hits]]'', which is certified gold. This album was led off by the No.&nbsp;31 single \"When Mama Ain't Happy\" before he left the label.\n\n===1999\u20132004: RCA Records===\n\n====''It's About Time''====\nIn 1999, Byrd signed to [[RCA Records]] Nashville. Working with producer Billy Joe Walker, Jr., he released his sixth studio album, ''[[It's About Time (Tracy Byrd album)|It's About Time]]'', that year. This album featured a more [[country pop]] sound than its predecessors,<ref name=\"allmusic\"/><ref name=\"oldies\"/> and was led off by the No.&nbsp;11 \"[[Put Your Hand in Mine]]\". This song was co-written by [[Skip Ewing]] and [[Jimmy Wayne]]. The album's other two singles \u2014 \"[[Love, You Ain't Seen the Last of Me]]\" and \"Take Me With You When You Go\" \u2014 both landed outside the Top 40.\n\n====''Ten Rounds''====\n''[[Ten Rounds (Tracy Byrd album)|Ten Rounds]]'', his second album for RCA, was released in 2001. This album returned him to a more traditionally country sound.<ref name=\"oldies\"/> It was led off by \"A Good Way to Get on My Bad Side\", a duet with Mark Chesnutt.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> This song was a No.&nbsp;21 country hit, and Chesnutt's first Top 40 chart hit since \"This Heartache Never Sleeps\" two years previous. After it came the No.&nbsp;9 \"Just Let Me Be in Love\", and finishing off the album's single releases was its title track, \"[[Ten Rounds with Jos\u00e9 Cuervo]]\". In October 2002, this song became Byrd's second No. 1 country hit,<ref name=\"oldies\"/> and his first since \"Holdin' Heaven\" in 1993. It was also his only Top 40 pop hit, with a No.&nbsp;26 peak on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].\n\n====''The Truth About Men''====\nByrd charted at No.&nbsp;38 in early 2003 with \"Lately (Been Dreamin' 'Bout Babies)\", which was never included on an album.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> This song was followed by \"The Truth About Men\", a song whose second verse featured guest vocals from [[Blake Shelton]], [[Andy Griggs]] and [[Montgomery Gentry]]. This song was the title track to his final RCA album, ''[[The Truth About Men (album)|The Truth About Men]]'', which also produced his final Top Ten hit in the No.&nbsp;7 \"[[Drinkin' Bone]]\", as well as the No.&nbsp;53 \"How'd I Wind Up in Jamaica.\" Also included on this album was the [[Rodney Crowell]] composition \"[[Making Memories of Us]]\", which would later be a Number One country hit in 2005 for [[Keith Urban]].\n\n===2005: BNA Records===\n\n====''Greatest Hits''====\nByrd's second [[Greatest Hits (Tracy Byrd album)|greatest hits]] album was released in 2005 via [[BNA Records]], a sister label to RCA. This album reprised most of his RCA single releases, and included new recordings of \"I'm from the Country\" and \"The Keeper of the Stars.\" Also included on it were the new tracks \"Revenge of a Middle-Aged Woman\", \"Tiny Town\" and \"[[Johnny Cash (Tracy Byrd song)|Johnny Cash]]\". The first two were released as singles, with the former reaching No.&nbsp;34 and the latter failing to chart. \"Johnny Cash\" was later covered by [[Jason Aldean]] on his 2007 album ''[[Relentless (Jason Aldean album)|Relentless]]'', and was a No.&nbsp;6 country hit for him that year.\n\n===2006\u2013present: Blind Mule Records & later work===\n\n====''Different Things''====\nByrd released his next album, ''[[Different Things]]'', in 2006 via his own Blind Mule label. It was led off by the No.&nbsp;55 \"Cheapest Motel\",<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> co-written by Cole Deggs of [[Cole Deggs & the Lonesome]]. After this song came \"Better Places Than This,\" which failed to chart as well.\n\n===='' All American Texan '' ====\nIn June 2016, Byrd returned to the studio to work on his first project in a decade. This album, recorded at Rosewood Studios in Tyler, Texas, was self-produced and promoted. Byrd wrote eight of the album's ten tracks himself. The album was released in October 2016.\n\n===='' Tracy Byrd : Live at Billy Bob's Texas '' ====\nIn November 2019 Byrd released a live album, recorded in June 2019 with his band, The ByrdDawgs. The album was recorded at Billy Bob's Texas, and holds nineteen songs.\n\n===='' Tracy Byrd : Live at Billy Bob's Texas DVD '' ====\n\nThe DVD of Byrd's Billy Bob's Texas concert in June 2019, was released in November 2019. In addition to the music, it contains several interview segments with Byrd.\n\n==Charitable efforts==\nByrd has been the National Spokesperson for [[Special Olympics]] International for the [[Country Music Association]]. He developed a crank bait fishing lure marketed by Norman Lures called ''The Lifestyles of the Not So Rich & Famous''', named after his hit recording of the song written by [[Byron Hill]] and Wayne Tester. For every one of the lures sold Byrd donated ten cents to the Special Olympics.\n\nFor several years Byrd hosted an annual golfing/fishing/music event, \"The Tracy Byrd Homecoming Weekend,\" later called \"The Beaumont Boys Bash\", in Southeast Texas to raise money for local charities, including the [[March of Dimes]], the [[Children's Miracle Network]], and culminating in the donation of money to fund the Tracy Byrd [[Hyperbaric Medicine]] and Wound Care Center at St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Beaumont. Byrd also raised money by soliciting pledges for his attempt to complete the 2002 Houston Marathon. He finished the marathon, and donated all of his pledges to the Children's Miracle Network.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tseentertainment.com/tracy-byrd/|title=All About Tracy|access-date=June 26, 2018}}</ref>\n\nIn 2003 Byrd published ''Eat Like a Byrd: The Tracy Byrd Cookbook''.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.museumofthegulfcoast.org/Content/Personalities/Music_Legends/Tracy_Byrd |title=Museum of the Gulf Coast - Tracy Byrd |access-date=January 5, 2007 |archive-date=December 7, 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061207222555/http://museumofthegulfcoast.org/Content/Personalities/Music_Legends/Tracy_Byrd |url-status=dead }}</ref> He also launched a line of spices, rubs, and marinades to go along with it, called \"Tracy Byrd's Tiny Town Products\"; a portion of these sales were donated to the [[Children's Miracle Network]].\n\nOn December 28, 2012, he performed \"Amazing Grace\" at the memorial service for [[KFDM]] news anchor Bill Leger.<ref>{{cite news |last=Mieux |first=Mary |date=December 28, 2012 |title=KFDM's Bill Leger remembered |url=https://www.panews.com/2012/12/28/kfdms-bill-leger-remembered/ |work=Port Arthur News |location=online |access-date=November 10, 2019 }}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Tracy Byrd discography}}\n\n===Studio albums===\n*''[[Tracy Byrd (album)|Tracy Byrd]]'' (1993)\n*''[[No Ordinary Man]]'' (1994)\n*''[[Love Lessons (album)|Love Lessons]]'' (1995)\n*''[[Big Love (Tracy Byrd album)|Big Love]]'' (1996)\n*''[[I'm from the Country]]'' (1998)\n*''[[It's About Time (Tracy Byrd album)|It's About Time]]'' (1999)\n*''[[Ten Rounds (Tracy Byrd album)|Ten Rounds]]'' (2001)\n*''[[The Truth About Men (album)|The Truth About Men]]'' (2003)\n*''[[Different Things]]'' (2006)\n*''All American Texan'' (2016)\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n=== American Music Awards ===\n\n{{awards Vidor, Texas]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Kevin_Denney","to":"Kevin Denney"}],"pages":{"11721337":{"pageid":11721337,"ns":0,"title":"Kevin Denney","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{BLP sources|date=January 2008}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|image= | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name                = Kevin Denney\n| image_size          =\n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          =\n| birth_date          = {{birth date and age|1978|01|27}}\n| origin              =\n| instrument          = Vocals, acoustic guitar\n| genre               = [[country music|Country]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = 2001\u2013present\n| label               = [[Lyric Street Records|Lyric Street]]\n| associated_acts     = [[Tracy Byrd]]<br />[[Easton Corbin]]<br />[[Craig Morgan (singer)|Craig Morgan]]\n}}\n'''Kevin Denney''' (born January 27, 1978)<ref>{{Cite web |last=Rose |first=Mike |date=January 27, 2020|title=Today's famous birthdays list for January 27, 2020 includes celebrities Alan Cumming, James Cromwell|url=https://www.cleveland.com/life-and-culture/j66j-2020/01/abe688f7241977/todays-famous-birthdays-list-for-january-27-2020-includes-celebrities-james-cromwell-mimi-rogers.html |access-date=January 27, 2023 |website=[[Cleveland.com]]}}</ref> is an American [[country music]] artist. Signed to [[Lyric Street Records]] in 2001, he made his debut on the country music scene with the release of his self-titled album (2002's ''[[Kevin Denney (album)|Kevin Denney]]''), which produced three chart singles, including \"[[That's Just Jessie]]\", a Top 20 hit on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts. He was dropped from Lyric Street's roster in 2003, although he co-wrote a track on [[Tracy Byrd]]'s 2006 ''[[Different Things]]'' album.\n\n==Biography==\nDenney's interest in music began at an early age. His mother and father, both of whom sang in a [[gospel music]] quartet, bought Denney his first guitar when he was three years old.<ref name=\"about\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.liveabout.com/country-4688258|title=Country|website=LiveAbout.com|accessdate=March 25, 2020}}</ref> He also became a frequent listener of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] radio shows, and played in his cousin's [[bluegrass music]] band.<ref name=\"about\"/>\n\nAt age 17, however, he briefly stopped focusing on his musical interests to re-assess his future. On his eighteenth birthday, his girlfriend took him to a [[George Strait]] concert. Seeing Strait in concert helped Denney discover that music was his passion, and he later joined a local band that was looking for a lead singer.<ref name=\"about\"/> Denney later went solo, and was signed to [[Lyric Street Records]] in 2001.<ref name=\"all\">{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/kevin-denney-mn0000767883 |title=Kevin Denny |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=January 6, 2022}}</ref> His eponymous debut album, released in 2002, produced three charting singles on the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts: \"[[That's Just Jessie]]\" at number 16, \"Cadillac Tears\" at number 30 and \"It'll Go Away\" at number 43.<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=122|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref> He also contributed a rendition of \"[[White Christmas (song)|White Christmas]]\" to the label's multi-artist compilation ''No Wrapping Required''.<ref>{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r552889|pure_url=yes}}|title=''No Wrapping Required'' review|last=Birchmeier|first=Jason|website=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref>\n\nIn late 2003, Denney charted a fourth single, \"A Year at a Time,\" which peaked at number 44 on the country charts. The song did not appear on an album, and Denney exited the label.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/>\n\nHe co-wrote a track on [[Tracy Byrd]]'s 2006 album ''[[Different Things]]'', and [[Craig Morgan (singer)|Craig Morgan]]'s 2009 single \"[[Bonfire (Craig Morgan song)|Bonfire]].\" He also co-wrote \"Don't Ask Me About a Woman\", a song recorded by [[Easton Corbin]] on his 2010 [[Easton Corbin (album)|self-titled debut album]].\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"3\"| Peak chart positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[Billboard 200|US]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[Top Heatseekers|US Heat]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Kevin Denney (album)|Kevin Denney]]''\n| \n* Release date: April 23, 2002\n* Label: [[Lyric Street Records]]\n| 14\n| 119\n| 2\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Something in Between''\n| \n* Release date: June 24, 2016\n* Label: KDM Records\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"5\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"2\"| Peak chart<br />positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n! width=\"45\"| [[Billboard Hot 100|US]]\n|-\n| 2001\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[That's Just Jessie]]\"\n| 16\n| 76\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"3\"| ''Kevin Denney''\n|-\n| 2002\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Cadillac Tears]]\"\n| 30\n| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2003\n! scope=\"row\"| \"It'll Go Away\"\n| 43\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"A Year at a Time\"\n| 44\n| \u2014\n| {{n/a}}\n|-\n| 2016\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Ain't Gonna Hurt Nobody but Me\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| ''Something in Between''\n|-\n| colspan=\"5\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Year\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 2002\n! scope=\"row\"| \"That's Just Jessie\"\n| [[Peter Zavadil]]\n|-\n| 2003\n! scope=\"row\"| \"A Year at a Time\"\n| Brent Hedgecock\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{Discogs artist}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Denney, Kevin}}\n[[Category:1976 births]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Kentucky]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Lyric Street Records artists]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Kentucky]]\n[[Category:People from Monticello, Kentucky]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Cowboy_Troy","to":"Cowboy Troy"}],"pages":{"1913554":{"pageid":1913554,"ns":0,"title":"Cowboy Troy","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American rapper and singer (born 1970)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Cowboy Troy\n| image           = Cowboy Troy-blueshirt-whitehat.jpg\n| birth_name      = Troy Lee Coleman III<ref>Full name per [[ASCAP]] database</ref>\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1970|12|18}}\n| origin          = [[Victoria, Texas]], U.S.\n| occupation      = {{hlist|Rapper|singer|songwriter}}\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Country rap|Hick-hop]]<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>|[[country music|country]]}}\n| years_active    = 1999\u2013present\n| label           = {{Hlist|[[Warner Records|Warner Bros.]]|CTMC/Winding Road|Heart Songs Corporation}}\n| website         = [http://www.cowboytroy.com/ CowboyTroy.com]\n}}\n'''Troy Lee Coleman III''' (born December 18, 1970), better known by his stage name '''Cowboy Troy''', is an American rapper and singer. He is best known as a representative of the [[country rap]] genre for the song \"I Play Chicken With The Train\". He has released seven studio albums and one EP, including three releases on [[Warner Records|Warner Bros. Records]], and has charted twice on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country singles charts.\n\n==Early life==\nColeman was born in [[Victoria, Texas]], on December 18, 1970.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> He graduated from [[Skyline High School (Dallas)|Skyline High School]] in the [[Dallas Independent School District]]. Coleman then attended the [[University of Texas at Austin]] where he earned a bachelor's degree.<ref name=rollingstone/> Prior to beginning his career as a singer, he worked as the assistant manager of a [[Dallas]] area [[Foot Locker]].<ref name=rollingstone>[https://web.archive.org/web/20081231074228/http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/cowboytroy/articles/story/7287948/cowboy_troy_bucks_country Cowboy Troy Bucks Country] ''Rolling Stone'' Magazine \"When the song took off last year, Troy had to leave his job at a Dallas Foot Locker store to tour with the duo, which was opening for Tim McGraw.\" May 05, 2005</ref>\n\nHe got the name Cowboy Troy in college, after a friend used the name to distinguish the cowboy-hat-wearing Coleman from his other friends named Troy.<ref name=\"washingtontimes.com\">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2008/oct/17/cowboy-troy/|title=Q. & A. with Cowboy Troy|newspaper=[[The Washington Times]]}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nOn May 17, 2005, Troy released his first major-label solo album, ''Loco Motive'', through the RAYBAW records production label and the [[Warner Music Group]] distribution label.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p700245|pure_url=yes}} |title=Cowboy Troy biography |accessdate=2008-01-03 |last=Jeffries |first=David |website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> The album debuted at No.&nbsp;2 on [[Billboard Magazine|Billboard's]] Top Country Albums chart. The first single, \"I Play Chicken with the Train,\" peaked at No.&nbsp;48 on [[Billboard Magazine|Billboard's]] [[Hot Country Songs]] chart on April 9, 2005 and was the No.&nbsp;1 country download at the [[iTunes Store|iTunes Music Store]] on April 15, 2005.\n\nAs a [[Chevrolet]] promotion, Troy, Gretchen Wilson, and Big & Rich released \"Our America\" as a free, time-limited download on July 1, 2005. They also performed the song live at the Boston Pops concert on July 4, 2005. \"Our America\" combines \"[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]\" with spoken word of parts of the [[United States Constitution|U.S. Constitution]], [[Declaration of Independence (United States)|Declaration of independence]], [[Pledge of Allegiance (United States)|Pledge of Allegiance]] and [[Martin Luther King Jr.]]'s 1963 \"[[I Have a Dream]]\" speech. The song peaked at No.&nbsp;44 on Billboard's Hot Country Songs chart, and appears as a bonus track on both Big & Rich's ''[[Comin' to Your City]]'' and Wilson's ''[[All Jacked Up]]'' albums.\n\nCowboy Troy released the single \"If You Don't Wanna Love Me\", a duet with [[Sarah Buxton (singer)|Sarah Buxton]]. The single failed to chart, as did the follow-up, \"My Last Yee Haw.\" A promotional single, titled \"Hook 'Em Horns\", was released on February 14, 2006 after his alma mater ([[2005 Texas Longhorns football team|the Texas Longhorns]]) [[2006 Rose Bowl|won the national championship]] in [[American football|football]].\n\n===2006-present===\nCowboy Troy co-hosted, with [[Jewel (singer)|Jewel]], the fifth season of ''[[Nashville Star]]'' on the [[USA Network]] and [[Country Music Television Canada|CMT Canada]].<ref>[http://www.zap2it.com/tv/news/zap-jewelnashvillestarhost,0,4310878.story Jewel Takes a Shine to 'Nashville Star', Singer joins Cowboy Troy as co-host] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120927030625/http://www.zap2it.com/tv/news/zap-jewelnashvillestarhost,0,4310878.story |date=2012-09-27 }} Zap2it.com September 27, 2006</ref>\n\nTroy made a special appearance at the March 13, 2006 episode of [[WWE Raw|WWE's ''RAW'']] in [[Beaumont, Texas]]. He came to the announcer's table and helped announce for the match between superstars [[Adam Copeland|Edge]] and [[Dustin Rhodes|Goldust]]. His entrance music was \"My Last Yee Haw.\" The April 30 episode of WWE's ''Raw'', broadcast from [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], showed Troy in the crowd. The announcers mentioned him, and his duties hosting ''Nashville Star''. In 2007, he released ''Black in the Saddle''.\n\nTroy parted ways with Warner Bros. Nashville in 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1606224/country-rosters-remain-stable-despite-sales-downturn/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150110102026/http://www.cmt.com/news/1606224/country-rosters-remain-stable-despite-sales-downturn/|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 10, 2015|title=Country Rosters Remain Stable Despite Sales Downturn|first=Edward|last=Morris|website=CMT News}}</ref> He released ''Demolition Mission: Studio Blue Sessions'' in 2009. Troy returned to Warner Music Nashville to release \"King of Clubs\" in March 2014.\n\nCowboy Troy was cited as a featured guest artist on two tracks from the 2011 [[Vanilla Ice]] release titled ''[[W.T.F. (Wisdom, Tenacity and Focus)|WTF]]'', which is available on [[iTunes]].\n\nIn 2012, Troy appeared on the May 21 and 22 finale of Season 14 of the television show ''[[Dancing with the Stars (American TV series)|Dancing with the Stars]]'', performing \"I Play Chicken With the Train.\"\n\nHis 2017 single \"Pork Chop\" was used as the theme for \"Porktober\", the National Pork Board's October 2017 promotion.<ref>{{cite web |title=Pork Board teams with Cowboy Troy to celebrate pork chops |url=https://www.nationalhogfarmer.com/pork-market-news/national-pork-board-teams-with-hick-hop-innovator-cowboy-troy-to-celebrate-pork-chops |website=www.nationalhogfarmer.com |access-date=25 March 2024 |language=en}}</ref>\n\nTroy starred in the 2022 Western film ''[[Desperate Riders]]''.\n\n==Personal life==\nCowboy Troy performed at the 2008 [[Republican National Convention]] in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|St. Paul, Minnesota]].<ref name=rnc>{{Cite web|url=https://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/08/11/checking-out-the-parties-parties/|title=Checking Out the Parties' Parties|first=Leslie|last=Wayne|website=Thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com|date=August 11, 2008}}</ref> He is a self-described [[Black conservatism in the United States|black conservative]] and a member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] who supported [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[John McCain]] in the [[2008 United States presidential election|2008 U.S. presidential election]].<ref name=\"washingtontimes.com\"/>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n!
