Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jewel_(musician)","to":"Jewel (musician)"}],"pages":{"601081":{"pageid":601081,"ns":0,"title":"Jewel (musician)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"#REDIRECT [[Jewel (singer)]]\n\n[[Category:Unprintworthy redirects]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Big_&_Rich","to":"Big & Rich"}],"pages":{"30874246":{"pageid":30874246,"ns":0,"title":"Big & Rich","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country music duo}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2012}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Big & Rich\n| image           = Big and Rich 1.jpg\n| landscape       = yes\n| caption         = Big Kenny (left) and John Rich (right)\n| origin          = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], United States\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n| years_active    = 1998\u20132008, 2011&ndash;present\n| label           = [[Warner Records|Warner Bros. Nashville]], Big & Rich Records\n| past_member_of = [[MuzikMafia]]\n| spinoff_of = {{hlist|[[Lonestar]]|luvj0i}}\n| website         = {{URL|http://www.bigandrich.com}}\n| current_members = {{hlist|[[Big Kenny]]|[[John Rich]]}}\n}}\n\n'''Big & Rich''' is an American [[country music]] duo composed of [[Big Kenny]] and [[John Rich]], both of whom are songwriters, vocalists, and guitarists. Before the duo's foundation, Rich was bass guitarist in the country band [[Lonestar]], while Kenny was a solo artist for [[Hollywood Records]].\n\nTheir first studio album, ''[[Horse of a Different Color (Big & Rich album)|Horse of a Different Color]]'', was released in 2004. This album produced four straight Top 40 country hits, including the number 11 \"[[Save a Horse (Ride a Cowboy)]]\", plus collaborations with [[Cowboy Troy]], [[Gretchen Wilson]], and [[Martina McBride]]. ''[[Comin' to Your City]]'' was released in November 2005, followed by another Top 20 single the [[Vietnam War]]-inspired \"[[8th of November (song)|8th of November]]\" and two more Top 40 hits. Joining the duo on this album were Cowboy Troy, Wilson, and [[Kris Kristofferson]]. ''[[Between Raising Hell and Amazing Grace]]'', released in 2007, produced their only No.&nbsp;1 single, \"[[Lost in This Moment]]\". Both before and during the duo's hiatus, Rich has worked as a producer and songwriter for several other artists.\n\nAfter this album, both members went on hiatus and released solo albums in 2009\u2014Big Kenny's ''[[The Quiet Times of a Rock and Roll Farm Boy]]'' and Rich's ''[[Son of a Preacher Man (John Rich album)|Son of a Preacher Man]]''. These also produced the duo's first Top 40 solo entries\u2014Big Kenny with \"[[Long After I'm Gone]]\" and Rich with \"[[Shuttin' Detroit Down]]\". In 2010, Big Kenny released his second solo country album, ''Big Kenny's Love Everybody Traveling Musical Medicine Show Mix Tape, Vol. 1'' and in 2011, Rich released the [[extended play]]s ''[[For the Kids (EP)|For the Kids]]'' and ''[[Rich Rocks]]'', the latter of which included the Top 40 country single \"Country Done Come to Town\". Big & Rich reunited in May 2011 to release \"Fake ID\", a cut from the soundtrack to the 2011 film ''[[Footloose (2011 film)|Footloose]]''. A year later, the duo released their fourth album, ''[[Hillbilly Jedi]]'', which produced the Top 20 hit \"[[That's Why I Pray]]\". In July 2013, Rich announced that the duo had begun work on their fifth studio album, ''[[Gravity (Big & Rich album)|Gravity]]'', which was released independently.<ref name=\":0\">{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/big-and-rich-new-studio-album/?trackback=fbshare_top |title=Big & Rich Working on New Studio Album |date=July 12, 2013 |publisher=Theboot.com |access-date=2014-08-10}}</ref><ref name=\"E2.ma\">{{cite web |url=http://e2.ma/message/5e6mg/5qzdaj |archive-url=https://archive.today/20140129003732/http://e2.ma/message/5e6mg/5qzdaj |url-status=dead |archive-date=2014-01-29 |title=email : Webview : Big News from Big & Rich! |publisher=E2.ma |access-date=2014-08-10 }}</ref> Another independent album, ''Did it For the Party'', was announced in 2017 for release in September, led by the single \"California\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/big-rich-did-it-for-the-party-new-album-details/|title=Big & Rich Reveal Details for 'Did It for the Party' Album|website=Taste of Country|date=July 8, 2017 |access-date=March 18, 2018}}</ref>\n\n==History==\nPrior to Big & Rich's foundation, [[John Rich]] was a founding member of the band Texassee, which later became [[Lonestar]].<ref name=\"allmusic lonestar\">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p165799|pure_url=yes}} |title=Lonestar biography |access-date=March 7, 2010 |last=Erlewine |first=Stephen Thomas |author-link=Stephen Thomas Erlewine |publisher=Allmusic}}</ref> Rich played bass guitar in the band and alternated with [[Richie McDonald]] on lead vocals; he also co-wrote their singles \"[[Come Cryin' to Me]]\" and \"[[Say When (song)|Say When]]\".<ref name=\"fourteen\">Rich, Big Kenny, Rucker, p. 14</ref> After Lonestar released their second studio album, Rich departed from the band in 1998, leaving McDonald as the band's sole lead singer.<ref name=\"usa\">{{cite web |url=http://www.usanetwork.com/series/nashvillestar/theshow/characterprofiles/rich/index.html |title=Character profile: John Rich |access-date=August 19, 2010 |work=USA Networks |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110215083929/http://www.usanetwork.com/series/nashvillestar/theshow/characterprofiles/rich/index.html |archive-date=February 15, 2011 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Kenny Alphin (aka [[Big Kenny]]) was signed to [[Hollywood Records]] in 1998,<ref>Rich, Big Kenny, Rucker, p. 11</ref> where he recorded a [[rock music|rock]] album called ''[[Live a Little (Big Kenny album)|Live a Little]]'' a year later.<ref name=\"scene1\">{{cite news|url=http://www.nashvillescene.com/2000-11-16/stories/feeling-the-luv/|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130129115928/http://www.nashvillescene.com/2000-11-16/stories/feeling-the-luv/|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 29, 2013|title=Feeling the Luv After departing Hollywood Records, \"Big Kenny\" Alphin moves on|last=Murray|first=Noel|date=November 16, 2000|work=Nashville Scene|page=1|access-date=February 25, 2010}}</ref>  Although one of its songs was featured in the soundtrack to the film ''[[Gun Shy (2000 film)|Gun Shy]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r461655|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Gun Shy Soundtrack'' review|last=Phares|first=Heather|publisher=Allmusic|access-date=February 25, 2010}}</ref> ''Live a Little'' was not released, and Hollywood Records held the rights to the songs for five years.<ref name=\"scene1\"/> In the meantime, [[The Mavericks]] recorded one of Alphin's songs (\"I Hope You Want Me Too\") on their 1998 album ''[[Trampoline (The Mavericks album)|Trampoline]]'',<ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=Trampoline |others=The Mavericks |year=1998 |type=CD booklet |publisher=[[MCA Nashville]] |id=3804562}}</ref> and [[Danni Leigh]] recorded his \"Beatin' My Head Against the Wall\" on her album ''[[29 Nights]]''.<ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=29 Nights |others=Danni Leigh |year=1998 |type=CD insert |publisher=Decca Records |id=70032}}</ref> Big Kenny then befriended Rich after meeting him at a club,<ref name=\"fourteen\"/> and the two began writing songs together. Their first songwriting collaboration was \"I Pray for You,\" which they wrote in October 1998.<ref>Rich, Big Kenny, Rucker, p. 15</ref>\n\nFollowing his departure from Hollywood Records, Big Kenny recorded in a short-lived band called luvjOi,<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p637739|pure_url=yes}}|title=Big & Rich biography|last=Loftus|first=Johnny|publisher=Allmusic|access-date=2009-05-25}}</ref> whose lead guitarist Adam Shoenfeld and drummer Larry Babb would later become part of Big & Rich's road band.<ref>Rich, Big Kenny, Rucker, p. 12</ref> In 2000, Rich began recording as a solo artist as well. He charted two singles of his own \u2014 \"I Pray for You\" and \"Forever Loving You,\" which respectively reached numbers 53 and number 46 on the U.S. [[Hot Country Songs]] charts<ref>{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=350|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}<!--|access-date=February 25, 2010--></ref> \u2014 but his debut album, ''[[Underneath the Same Moon]],'' was not released at the time.<ref name=\"usa\"/> The two then founded the [[MuzikMafia]] (an abbreviation for Musically Artistic Friends in Alliance),<ref>Rich, Big Kenny, Rucker, p. 30</ref> a roundtable aggregation of singer-songwriters including [[Cowboy Troy]], [[James Otto]], [[Gretchen Wilson]] and [[Shannon Lawson (singer)|Shannon Lawson]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/><ref name=\"bigandrichwhitburn\"/> This group held its first official show at a [[Nashville, Tennessee]], nightclub in 2001.<ref>Rich, Big Kenny, Rucker, p. 33</ref> Big & Rich performed at [[The Bluebird Cafe]] on January 1, 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bluebirdcafe.com/history|title=History|website=The Bluebird Cafe|language=en|access-date=2020-02-15}}</ref>\n\nAmong Big Kenny and John Rich's first outside cuts as songwriters was \"[[Amarillo Sky (song)|Amarillo Sky]]\", which was the title track to [[McBride & the Ride]]'s 2002 album ''[[Amarillo Sky (album)|Amarillo Sky]]''<ref>{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r588182}}</ref> and later a top 5 hit for [[Jason Aldean]] in 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.northplattebulletin.com/index.asp?show=news&action=readStory&storyID=12130&pageID=24 |title=Big & Rich to headline at Comstock |access-date=2008-08-02 |last=Lauby |first=George |date=May 6, 2007 |work=North Platte Bulletin |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081008002951/http://www.northplattebulletin.com/index.asp?show=news&action=readStory&storyID=12130&pageID=24 |archive-date=October 8, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The two also wrote and sang backing vocals on \"She's a Butterfly\", which was recorded by [[Martina McBride]] on her album ''[[Martina (album)|Martina]]''.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/><ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=Martina |others=Martina McBride |year=2003 |type=CD booklet |publisher=RCA Records |id=54207}}</ref> After McBride cut this song, manager Marc Oswald suggested that Rich and Big Kenny begin recording as a duo. Rich was apprehensive at first, as he had been told by BNA staff that he was \"too rock for country\" and was unsure of what major labels would think of Big Kenny's rock influences.<ref name=\"fiftysix\">Rich, Big Kenny, Rucker, pp. 56\u201357</ref> The two began recording songs together at a songwriting seminar. After they recorded a demo of \"[[Holy Water (Big & Rich song)|Holy Water]]\", Rich was convinced that the duo would be successful.<ref>Rich, Big Kenny, Rucker, p. 62</ref> They then met with [[Paul Worley]], a record producer who was then the head of creative affairs at [[Warner Bros. Records]] Nashville, and Worley helped sign Big & Rich to a recording contract in late 2003.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nIn 2007, Reservoir Media Management acquired the publishing rights to Rich's and Kenny's song catalogs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/content_display/industry/news/e3id3e6c7f5a136381a2cbcdabb7575e243 |title=Reservoir Media Management Acquires TVT Publishing Assets |publisher=Billboard.biz |date=April 29, 2010 |access-date=2011-11-13 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120115035803/http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/content_display/industry/news/e3id3e6c7f5a136381a2cbcdabb7575e243 |archive-date=January 15, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>\n\n==Major-label career==\n\n===2004\u20132005: ''Horse of a Different Color''===\nThe two then began writing songs for their debut album. Among these was \"[[Wild West Show (song)|Wild West Show]],\" which they wrote before a trip to [[Deadwood, South Dakota]]. The duo decided to use [[wild West]] imagery to convey \"an argument between a man and a woman.\"<ref>Rich, Big Kenny, Rucker, pp. 65\u201366</ref> In February 2004, it was released as their debut single,<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> going on to peak at number 21 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country singles charts.<ref name=\"bigandrichwhitburn\">Whitburn, p. 49</ref> It was the first release from their debut album ''[[Horse of a Different Color (Big & Rich album)|Horse of a Different Color]]''.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Following the album's release, Big & Rich began touring with [[Tim McGraw]].<ref>Rich, Big Kenny, Rucker, p. 92</ref>\n\nBig & Rich debuted their second single, \"[[Save a Horse (Ride a Cowboy)]]\", at that year's [[Academy of Country Music]] awards.<ref name=\"onethirty\">Rich, Big Kenny, Rucker, p. 130</ref> For this song, Big & Rich employed [[Deaton-Flanigen Productions]], a music video directing duo composed of Robert Deaton and George Flanigen IV.<ref name=\"eightysix\">Rich, Big Kenny, Rucker, p. 86</ref> Deaton-Flanigen and Oswald, along with the duo, decided to make \"a big, big show of a video\", featuring cameo appearances from Gretchen Wilson and Cowboy Troy, as well as a [[marching band]] and a dancing troupe.<ref name=\"eightysix\"/> The song peaked at number 11 on the country singles charts,<ref name=\"bigandrichwhitburn\"/> and the video was the most-requested on the television networks [[CMT (American TV channel)|Country Music Television]] (CMT) and [[GAC Family|Great American Country]] (GAC) for four weeks.<ref>Rich, Big Kenny, Rucker, p. 90</ref> \"Save a Horse\" was also a minor hit in Germany, reaching number 87 on the [[Media Control Charts]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/artist/Big+%26+Rich/single|title=Die ganze Musik im Internet: Charts \u2013 German Singles|publisher=Hung Medien|access-date=May 20, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101231205154/http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/artist/Big+%26+Rich/single|archive-date=December 31, 2010|url-status=dead}}</ref> [[ESPN]] also used the song as the theme music for its ''[[World Series of Poker]]''.<ref>Rich, Big Kenny, Rucker, p. 91</ref> They and Cowboy Troy performed \"Rollin' (The Ballad of Big & Rich)\" at the [[Country Music Association]] awards telecast, where they were also nominated for the Horizon Award. (Now known as the New Artist award, this is awarded to new artists who make significant commercial success from a first or second album.)<ref>Rich, Big Kenny, Rucker, p. 129</ref>\n\n\"[[Holy Water (Big & Rich song)|Holy Water]]\" was the third single release, reaching number 15 on the country singles charts.<ref name=\"bigandrichwhitburn\"/> The duo wrote this song about Big Kenny's sister Charlene, a [[domestic abuse]] victim.<ref>Rich, Big Kenny, Rucker, p. 93</ref> Finishing off the album's single releases was \"[[Big Time (Big & Rich song)|Big Time]]\", which peaked at number 20 in early 2005.<ref name=\"bigandrichwhitburn\"/> Big & Rich also released a special [[Independence Day (United States)|Independence Day]] single titled \"Our America\", with guest vocals from Wilson and Cowboy Troy, which charted for two weeks and peaked at number 44.<ref name=\"bigandrichwhitburn\"/>\n\n''Horse of a Different Color'' was met with generally positive reviews. [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] of [[Allmusic]] called it \"wilder and stranger than most contemporary country albums of 2004,\"<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r688901|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Horse of a Different Color'' review|last=Erlewine|first=Stephen Thomas|publisher=Allmusic|access-date=March 8, 2010}}</ref> and Chris Willman of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' said that \"the disc really flies when Big & Rich just honor the straight-up rowdiness of [[Hank Williams, Jr.|Bocephus]].\"<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://ew.com/article/2004/05/14/horse-different-color/|title=''Horse of a Different Color'' review|last=Willman|first=Chris|date=May 14, 2004|magazine=Entertainment Weekly|access-date=March 8, 2010}}</ref> ''[[Country Weekly]]'' also gave a positive review, praising the variety of musical influences and saying that all of the songs worked \"ridiculously well.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countryweekly.com/reviews/181|title=''Horse of a Different Color'' review|date=May 25, 2004|work=[[Country Weekly]]|access-date=August 19, 2010}}</ref>\n\n===2005\u20132006: ''Comin' to Your City''===\nThe duo's second album, ''[[Comin' to Your City]]'', was released on November 15, 2005.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> The first single, \"[[Comin' to Your City (song)|Comin' to Your City]]\" received a similar reaction as \"Save a Horse (Ride a Cowboy)\" had a year earlier, although rather than poker, [[ESPN]] utilized an altered version of the song as the opening theme for its Saturday program ''[[College GameDay (football)|College GameDay]]''.<ref name=\"onethirty\"/> The song peaked at number 21.<ref name=\"bigandrichwhitburn\"/> In its music video, the duo appeared in a guitar-shaped spaceship.<ref>Rich, Big Kenny, Rucker, pp. 99\u2013101</ref>\n\nTheir next single, \"Never Mind Me\", reached a peak at number 34.  Next came \"[[8th of November (song)|8th of November]]\", while only peaking at number 18, garnered the duo nominations for the [[CMA Awards]], [[Grammy Awards]], and the ACM Awards. The song was inspired by the story of Niles Harris. A subsequent documentary titled \"''November 8: a true American story of honor''\" was released also, debuting on [[Great American Country]] television network over the July 4 weekend. The documentary tells the story of Niles Harris and shows the making of the music video for the single.\n\nAn extended play of live studio performances, ''[[Rolling Stone Original (Big & Rich EP)|Rolling Stone Original]]'', was also released in November 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bigandrich.com/albums/rolling-stone-original|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130929051804/http://www.bigandrich.com/albums/rolling-stone-original|url-status=dead|archive-date=2013-09-29|title=Rolling Stone Original &#124; Big and Rich |date=2013-09-29 |access-date=2020-04-28}}</ref>  During a benefit concert held on October 9, 2006 in Atlanta, Georgia to raise money for the construction of the 173d Airborne Memorial, Big & Rich were awarded the status of Honorary Members of the 503d Regiment of the 173d Airborne Brigade. The concert was the subject of a documentary on [[Great American Country]] in November 2006.\n\nAlso in 2005, Hollywood Records released Big Kenny's debut album and in 2006 BNA Records released Rich's.\n\n===2007\u20132008: ''Between Raising Hell and Amazing Grace''===\nIn early 2007, the duo released \"[[Lost in This Moment]]\", which was the lead-off single to their third album, ''[[Between Raising Hell and Amazing Grace]]''.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>  \"Lost in This Moment\" became Big & Rich's only Number One single, spending two weeks at the top of the country music charts.<ref name=\"bigandrichwhitburn\"/> The song also began receiving airplay on [[adult contemporary]] radio and became their first chart entry for that format, reaching number 12.\n\nThey released their second single, \"Between Raising Hell and Amazing Grace\" to country radio in August 2007, although it failed to make an impact on the charts, peaking at number 37; follow-up \"Loud\" became the duo's first single to miss the Top 40.<ref name=\"bigandrichwhitburn\"/> Another cut from this album, a cover of [[AC/DC]]'s \"[[You Shook Me All Night Long]],\" also charted at number 59 as a non-single two months before the release of the title track.<ref name=\"bigandrichwhitburn\"/>\n\nThe duo also released three live in the studio extended plays during 2007: ''Walmart Soundcheck'', ''Rhapsody Originals''<ref>{{cite web|author=Eric Shea |url=http://www.rhapsody.com/artist/big-and-rich/album/rhapsody-originals |title=Originals (EP, Exclusive) by Big & Rich |publisher=Rhapsody |date=2013-11-14 |access-date=2014-08-10}}</ref> and ''Unplugged at Studio 330''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rhapsody.com/artist/big-and-rich/album/unplugged-at-studio-330/track/lost-in-this-moment-unplugged-at-studio-330 |title=Unplugged At Studio 330 (EP) by Big & Rich |publisher=Rhapsody |date=2013-11-14 |access-date=2014-08-10}}</ref>\n\n===2008\u20132011: Hiatus, solo projects, and reunion===\nIn 2008, Rich announced that Big & Rich would go on hiatus while Big Kenny recovered from an existing neck injury. In the meantime, Rich said that he would release a solo album, \"with Kenny's blessing.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1580269/big-richs-john-rich-releasing-solo-cd.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207162601/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1580269/big-richs-john-rich-releasing-solo-cd.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=February 7, 2009|title=Big & Rich's John Rich Releasing Solo CD|date=January 24, 2008|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]|access-date=August 19, 2010}}</ref> Warner Bros. released Rich's second solo album, ''[[Son of a Preacher Man (John Rich album)|Son of a Preacher Man]]'', in early 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p687833|pure_url=yes}}|title=John Rich biography|last=Monger|first=James Christopher|work=Allmusic|access-date=August 19, 2010}}</ref> The album produced three singles, including the number 12 country hit \"[[Shuttin' Detroit Down]]\". Later in the same year, Big Kenny released ''[[The Quiet Times of a Rock and Roll Farm Boy]]'' via his own Glotown label, and charted at number 34 with the single \"[[Long After I'm Gone]]\".\n\nIn 2010, Big Kenny released his second solo album, ''Big Kenny's Love Everybody Traveling Musical Medicine Show Mix Tape, Vol. 1'' exclusively through BigKenny.TV and BigSouthMusic.com.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bigsouthmusic.merchmo.com/products/detail/Big_Kennys_Love_Everybody_Traveling_Musical_Medic_94 |title=Big South Music Store |access-date=2013-06-20 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130624180319/http://bigsouthmusic.merchmo.com/products/detail/Big_Kennys_Love_Everybody_Traveling_Musical_Medic_94 |archive-date=June 24, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} </ref> Rich released two extended plays in early 2011: ''[[Rich Rocks]]'' and ''[[For the Kids (EP)|For the Kids]]'', both on [[Reprise Records]]. The former produced his second solo top 40 hit in 2010, \"Country Done Come to Town,\" also peaking at number 34.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://allmusic.com/artist/john-rich-p687833/biography|title=John Rich biography|last=Monger|first=James Christopher|work=Allmusic|access-date=July 19, 2011}}</ref> Big & Rich reunited later in 2011 to record the song \"Fake I.D.\" for the soundtrack to the 2011 film ''[[Footloose (2011 film)|Footloose]]''. It includes a guest vocal from Gretchen Wilson, with whom the duo toured that same year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1664120/big-rich-plan-new-album-issue-fake-id.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110522022237/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1664120/big-rich-plan-new-album-issue-fake-id.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=May 22, 2011|title=Big & Rich Plan New Album, Issue \"Fake I.D.\"|date=May 18, 2011|work=CMT|access-date=July 19, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=5503|title=Big & Rich debut new video|publisher=Country Standard Time|date=June 24, 2011|access-date=June 26, 2011| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110629130322/http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=5503| archive-date= June 29, 2011 | url-status= live}}</ref>\n\n===2012\u20132013: ''Hillbilly Jedi''===\nIn 2012, Big & Rich announced that they would release their fourth studio album, ''[[Hillbilly Jedi]]'', led by the single \"[[That's Why I Pray]]\". Danelle Leverett, formerly one-half of [[The JaneDear Girls]], wrote the song with Blair Daly and [[Sarah Buxton]]. Rich said that he felt that the song could be the biggest of the duo's career.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wycd.cbslocal.com/2012/05/22/big-rich-release-thats-why-i-pray-new-cover-art/|title=Big & Rich Release 'That's Why I Pray' + New Music Video|date=May 22, 2012|work=99.5 WYCD \u2013 Detroit's Country|access-date=June 2, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120525141151/http://wycd.cbslocal.com/2012/05/22/big-rich-release-thats-why-i-pray-new-cover-art/|archive-date=May 25, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref> The single debuted at number 24 on the country charts, the highest debut achieved by a duo since the charts were first tabulated by Nielsen BDS in 1990.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/485441/country-countdown-big-rich-make-history-with-thats-why-i-pray|title=Country Countdown: Big & Rich Make History With 'That's Why I Pray'|magazine=Billboard|access-date=June 2, 2012}}</ref>\n\nPreceding the album's release was an [[extended play]] by the name of ''[[That's Why I Pray (EP)|That's Why I Pray]]'', which featured the single as well as three previously released songs.  The EP was only issued on [[compact disc|CD]] and available exclusively at [[Walmart]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.walmart.com/ip/20962791|title=Walmart.com: That's Why I Pray (Walmart Exclusive)|publisher=[[Walmart.com]]|access-date=July 27, 2012}}</ref>\n\nReleased on September 18, 2012, the album produced two more singles, \"Party Like Cowboyz\" and \"Cheat on You,\" both of which failed to make Top 40. In 2012, Big & Rich were nominated for Vocal Duo of the Year at the CMA Awards and in 2013 at the ACM Awards.\n\n===2013\u2013present: Big & Rich Records, ''Gravity'' and \"Did It for the Party\"===\nIn July 2013, Rich announced that the duo was already working on their fifth studio album.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/big-and-rich-new-studio-album/ |title=Big & Rich Working on New Studio Album |date=July 12, 2013 |publisher=Theboot.com |access-date=2014-08-10}}</ref>  Kenny revealed that their new material would be more along the lines of the music on their debut album, and that the executives at Warner Bros. Nashville told them that it was their \"best material in years.\"<ref>{{cite web |last=Conaway |first=Alanna |url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/big-and-rich-have-covertly-been-working-on-fifth-studio-album |title=Big and Rich Have \"Covertly Been Working On\" Fifth Studio Album |publisher=RoughStock |date=2013-08-29 |access-date=2014-08-10 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140109235923/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/big-and-rich-have-covertly-been-working-on-fifth-studio-album |archive-date=January 9, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>  Early in 2014, the duo announced that a new single, titled \"[[Look at You (Big & Rich song)|Look at You]]\", would be sent to radio soon and that the new album would be released later in 2014.  Kenny and Rich also formed their own record label, Big & Rich Records, to handle their future musical endeavors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2014/01/big-rich-forms-new-label-prepare-new-album-and-single/ |title=Big & Rich Forms New Label, Prepare New Album and Single : MusicRow \u2013 Nashville's Music Industry Publication \u2013 News, Songs From Music City |publisher=Musicrow.com |date=2014-01-09 |access-date=2014-08-10}}</ref>\n\nOn January 28, 2014, the lead off single to the album was released and the album title was revealed as ''[[Gravity (Big & Rich album)|Gravity]]''.<ref name=\"E2.ma\"/><ref name=\"apple1\">{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/look-at-you/id797028801?i=797028808 |title=iTunes - Music - Look at You - Single by Big & Rich |publisher=Itunes.apple.com |date=2014-01-28 |access-date=2014-08-10}}</ref>  On July 28, the album's release date was confirmed to be September 23, 2014.  In addition, the track listing and cover art were also revealed the next day.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bigandrich.com/news.html?n_id=147 |title=Big & Rich - New Single Available Now! :: News |publisher=Bigandrich.com |date=2014-07-29 |access-date=2014-08-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006082445/http://www.bigandrich.com/news.html?n_id=147 |archive-date=October 6, 2014 |url-status=dead }}</ref>  The duo said that their decision to start their own label was the result of Warner Bros. Nashville's schedule not allowing for ''Gravity'' to be released until 2015 at the earliest.  Rather than have the project shelved, Big & Rich opted to strike out on their own and release the album sooner.  Of the decision to form their own label, Kenny said that \"it\u2019s the kind of thing we believed in ten years ago as the [[Musik Mafia]]. Just anyway to get the music out there.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nashville.com/music/2014/08/exclusive-interview-big-rich/ |title=EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEW: Big & Rich \u00ab Nashville.com |access-date=2014-09-29 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006115301/http://www.nashville.com/music/2014/08/exclusive-interview-big-rich/ |archive-date=October 6, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The second single from ''Gravity'', \"[[Run Away with You]]\", charted at number 11 on [[Country Airplay]]. \"[[Lovin' Lately]]\", a duet with [[Tim McGraw]], is the third single.\n\nThe duo released a new single, \"California\", in April 2017. The song was previously recorded by McGraw on his album ''[[Damn Country Music]]'', and his version featured them on backing vocals. Their sixth studio album, ''Did It for the Party'', followed in September 2017 to largely rave reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/big-and-rich-california/|title=Big & Rich, 'California' [Listen]|website=Taste of Country|date=April 5, 2017 |access-date=March 18, 2018}}</ref>\n\n==Collaboration and special appearances==\nSince their first collaboration with Martina McBride in 2003, the duo has appeared on several other albums. Wilson and Cowboy Troy then appeared on ''Comin' to Your City'' on the track \"Our America\". Their third album featured [[John Legend]] on \"Eternity\" and [[Wyclef Jean]] on \"Please Man\", as well as [[Lil Jon]] on a remix of \"Loud\" featured on the album's iTunes release. Legend played the piano and sang a verse during the duo's performance of \"Lost in This Moment\" at the 2007 [[Academy of Country Music|ACM Awards]].\n\nIn 2005, the duo contributed vocals to a rerecording of Billy Joe Shaver's 1993 song, \"Live Forever.\"<ref name=\"gacsplit\">{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000QQTKWM/ref=sr_1_album_2_rd?ie=UTF8&child=B000QKZYEG&qid=1338684706&sr=1-2|title=The Real Deal|date=September 20, 2005|work=Amazon.com|access-date=June 2, 2012}}</ref> Big & Rich also co-wrote several songs and provided background vocals on several cuts from Cowboy Troy's two Warner Bros. releases: 2005's ''[[Loco Motive]]'' and 2007's ''[[Black in the Saddle]]''.  In 2006, the [[Hank Williams, Jr.]] song \"That's How They Do It in Dixie\" was released, a single to which Big & Rich, Gretchen Wilson and [[Van Zant (band)|Van Zant]] contributed guest vocals.<ref name=\"bigandrichwhitburn\"/> It debuted one month after the duo's own single \"Never Mind Me.\"\n\nRich co-wrote several of Gretchen Wilson's singles, including her debut release \"[[Redneck Woman]]\".  He also co-wrote singles for [[Jason Aldean]] (\"[[Hicktown]]\", \"[[Amarillo Sky (song)|Amarillo Sky]]\", \"[[Johnny Cash (Tracy Byrd song)|Johnny Cash]]\"), [[Wynonna Judd]] (\"Attitude\"), [[Faith Hill]] (\"[[Mississippi Girl]]\", \"[[Like We Never Loved at All]]\", \"[[Sunshine and Summertime]]\") and [[Keith Anderson]] (\"[[Pickin' Wildflowers]]\"). Big Kenny wrote [[Tim McGraw]]'s \"[[Last Dollar (Fly Away)]]\", which went to number one in 2007, and co-wrote Wilson's \"[[Here for the Party (song)|Here for the Party]]\" with Rich. Rich has also [[record producer|produced]] for Wilson, Cowboy Troy, [[James Otto]], [[Shannon Brown (musician)|Shannon Brown]], [[Jewel (singer)|Jewel]], and [[the JaneDear girls]].\n\nSince 2005, the duo's song \"Comin' to Your City\" has been used as the opening theme to [[ESPN]]'s ''[[College GameDay (football)|College GameDay]]''.  In 2011, the song was reworked and re-recorded by the duo specifically for the event.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.espnfrontrow.com/2011/09/fast-break-big-rich-on-gameday/|title=Fast Break: Big & Rich on 'GameDay'|date=September 17, 2011|work=ESPN Front Row|access-date=June 2, 2012}}</ref>  The duo also contributed to ''[[Instant Karma: The Amnesty International Campaign to Save Darfur]]'' with a cover of [[John Lennon]]'s \"[[Nobody Told Me]]\" in 2007.  That same year, the duo was also featured in a duet with rock band [[Bon Jovi]] on their ''[[Lost Highway (Bon Jovi album)|Lost Highway]]'' album. The song, titled \"We Got It Going On\", was selected as a promotional song for the [[Arena Football League (1987\u20132008)|Arena Football League]]'s 2007 season.  In 2008, Big & Rich recorded a cover of the [[Beastie Boys]]' \"[[(You Gotta) Fight for Your Right (To Party!)]]\" for the compilation album ''The Imus Ranch Record''.  In 2014, the duo performed a cover of \"Same Old Situation\" on a M\u00f6tley Cr\u00fce tribute album.  2015 saw Big & Rich provide background vocals on albums by Tim McGraw and Clint Black.  For the McGraw album, the song \"California\" was written by John Rich.\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Big & Rich discography}}\n===Studio albums===\n* ''[[Horse of a Different Color (Big & Rich album)|Horse of a Different Color]]'' (2004)\n* ''[[Comin' to Your City]]'' (2005)\n* ''[[Between Raising Hell and Amazing Grace]]'' (2007)\n* ''[[Hillbilly Jedi]]'' (2012)\n* ''[[Gravity (Big & Rich album)|Gravity]]'' (2014)\n* ''[[Did It For the Party (Big & Rich album)|Did It for the Party]]'' (2017)\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! \"[[Look at You (Big & Rich song)|Look At You]]\"\n| {{nom}}\n| <ref>{{cite web|title=Nominees & Winners {{!}} 2015 CMT Music Awards|url=http://www.cmt.ca/show/2015-cmt-music-awards/nominees|website=CMT.ca {{!}} Country Music Television Canada|accessdate=10 May 2017|language=en|archive-date=May 5, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170505153440/http://www.cmt.ca/show/2015-cmt-music-awards/nominees|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n|-\n| rowspan=2|2017\n| [[Academy of Country Music Awards|ACM Awards]]\n| Vocal Duo of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|<ref>{{cite magazine|title=ACM Awards 2017 Winners: Complete List|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/7744527/acm-awards-2017-winners-list|magazine=Billboard|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref>\n|-\n| [[CMT Music Awards]] \n| Duo Video of the Year - \"[[Lovin' Lately]]\" <small>(feat. [[Tim McGraw]])</small>\n|{{nom}}\n|<ref>{{cite web|title=CMT Music Awards 2017 Nominees Announced|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/cmt-music-awards-2017-nominees-announced-w481409|website=Us Weekly|date=May 9, 2017 |accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref>\n|}\n\n==Filmography==\n*''[[Blue Collar TV]]'' - Season 1, Episodes 10: \"Music\" and 11: \"Partying\"\n*''[[Las Vegas (TV series)|Las Vegas]]'' \u2013 Season 2, Episode 24: \"Centennial\" (2005)\n*''The 8th of November: A True American Story of Honor'' (2006) (documentary)\n*''[[NASCAR 08]]'' \u2013 Soundtrack (2007) (video game)\n*''[[The Bachelor (U.S. TV series)|The Bachelor]]'' - Season 19, Episode 6: \"Deadwood, South Dakota\"  (2015)\n*''[[Footloose (2011 film)|Footloose]]'' (2011) (film)\n\n==Footnotes==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==References==\n*{{cite book |title=All Access: Big & Rich |author1=John Rich |author2=Big Kenny |author3=Allen Rucker |year=2007 |publisher=Center Street Press |location=Nashville |isbn=978-1-59995-717-3 |url-access=registration |url=https://archive.org/details/bigrichallaccess00bigk }}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.bigandrich.com Official site]\n\n{{Big & Rich}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Big and Rich}}\n[[Category:Country music groups from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:American country music duos]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 1998]]\n[[Category:Musical groups from Nashville, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Warner Records artists]]\n[[Category:1998 establishments in Tennessee]]\n[[Category:American male musical duos]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Hank_Williams_Jr.","to":"Hank Williams Jr."}],"pages":{"168285":{"pageid":168285,"ns":0,"title":"Hank Williams Jr.","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter and musician (born 1949)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2021}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Hank Williams Jr.\n| image             = Hank212.JPG\n| caption           = Williams in 2008\n| image_upright     = \n| birth_name        = Randall Hank Williams\n| alias             = {{hlist|Bocephus|Rockin' Randall|Wham Bam Sam|Luke the Drifter Jr.|Thunderhead Hawkins}}\n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1949|5|26}}\n| birth_place       = [[Shreveport, Louisiana]], U.S.\n| instrument        = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar|banjo|piano|keyboards|harmonica|fiddle|drums}}\n| genre             = {{Hlist|[[Country rock]]|[[southern rock]]|[[outlaw country]]|[[blues rock]]|[[rock and roll]]}}\n| occupation        = {{hlist|Singer-songwriter|musician}}\n| years_active      = 1963\u2013present\n| label             = {{hlist|[[MGM Records|MGM]]|[[Warner Records|Warner Bros.]]|[[Curb Records|Curb]]|Bocephus|NASH Icon}}\n| spouse            = {{marriage|Gwen Yeargin|1971|1977|reason=divorce}} {{marriage|Becky White|1977|1983|reason=divorce}} {{marriage|Mary Jane Thomas|1990|2022|reason=died}} {{marriage|Brandi Williams|2023}}{{efn|group=brandi|Brandi's last name is currently unknown.}}\n| website           = {{URL|hankjr.com}}\n| module            = {{Infobox person|child=yes\n| children = 5, including [[Hank Williams III]] and [[Holly Williams (musician)|Holly Williams]]\n}}\n}}\n\n'''Randall Hank Williams''' (born May 26, 1949), known professionally as '''Hank Williams Jr.''' or '''Bocephus''', is an American singer-songwriter and musician. His musical style has been described as a blend of [[rock music|rock]], [[blues]], and [[country music|country]]. He is the son of country musician [[Hank Williams]] and the father of musicians [[Holly Williams (musician)|Holly Williams]] and [[Hank Williams III]], and the grandfather of [[Coleman Williams]]. He is also the half brother of [[Jett Williams]].\n\nWilliams began his career following in his famed father's footsteps, covering his father's songs and imitating his father's style. Williams' first television appearance was in a December 1963 episode of ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'', in which at age fourteen he sang several songs associated with his father. Later that year, he was a guest star on ''[[Shindig!]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0929947/?ref_=ttfc_fc_cl_t130|title=Hank Williams, Jr.|publisher=[[IMDb]]|access-date=August 8, 2018}}</ref>\n\nAs Williams struggled to define his own voice and place within the [[country music]] genre, his style began slowly to evolve. His career was interrupted by a near-fatal fall while Williams was climbing [[List of mountains in Beaverhead County, Montana|Ajax Peak in Montana]] on August 8, 1975.<ref name=\"People\">{{cite journal|last=Buchalter|first=Gail|date=October 22, 1979|title=Hank Williams Jr. Fell Down a Mountain and Lived Now He's Climbing High on the C&w Charts|journal=[[People (magazine)|People]]|volume=12|issue=17|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20074883,00.html|access-date=August 3, 2013|archive-date=April 25, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160425141320/http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20074883,00.html|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=\"TheFall\">{{cite web|url=http://countrymusichalloffame.org/the-fall/|title=The Fall|publisher=[[Country Music Hall of Fame]]|access-date=August 3, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101104074223/http://countrymusichalloffame.org/the-fall/|archive-date=November 4, 2010|url-status=dead}}</ref> After an extended recovery, he rebuilt his career in the [[country rock]] scene.<ref name=Burns/> As a multi-instrumentalist, Williams' repertoire of musical instrument skills includes guitar, bass guitar, [[upright bass]], [[steel guitar]], [[banjo]], [[dobro]], piano, keyboards, saxophone, [[harmonica]], [[fiddle]], and drums.<ref name=\"autogenerated1\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hankjr.com/about/?id=2|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716224600/http://www.hankjr.com/about/?id=2|url-status=dead|title=Hank Williams Jr. \u2013 Official Website|archive-date=July 16, 2011|access-date=November 5, 2020}}</ref> In 2020, Williams Jr. was inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|Country Music Hall of Fame]].<ref name=\"Paulson\">{{Cite news|url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2020/08/12/hank-williams-jr-marty-stuart-dean-dillon-country-music-hall-fame/3352839001/|title=Hank Williams Jr., Marty Stuart, Dean Dillon to enter the Country Music Hall of Fame|first=Matthew Leimkuehler and Dave|last=Paulson|newspaper=[[The Tennessean]]|access-date=November 5, 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nWilliams was born Randall Hank Williams on May 26, 1949, in [[Shreveport, Louisiana]]. His [[Hank Williams|father]] nicknamed him Bocephus (after [[Grand Ole Opry]] comedian [[Rod Brasfield]]'s ventriloquist dummy).<ref>{{cite magazine|url =https://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-awkward-enduring-influence-of-hank-williams-jr|title =The Awkward, Enduring Influence of Hank Williams, Jr.|magazine =The New Yorker|first =David|last =Cantwell|date =March 24, 2016}}</ref> After his father's death in 1953, he was raised by his mother, [[Audrey Williams]].\n\nWhile he was a child, Williams was influenced by a <!--really? vast--> number of contemporary musicians who visited his family and taught him various musical instruments and styles. {{citation needed|date=June 2020}} Among these figures of influence were [[Merle Haggard]], [[Johnny Cash]], [[Fats Domino]], [[Earl Scruggs]], [[Lightnin' Hopkins]], and [[Jerry Lee Lewis]]. Williams first stepped onto the stage and sang his father's songs when he was eight years old.\n\nHe attended [[John Overton High School]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], where he would bring his guitar to music class and play for pep rallies and performances with the choir.\n\n== Career ==\nIn 1964, Williams made his recording debut with \"[[Long Gone Lonesome Blues]]\", one of his father's many classic songs.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Billboard Book Of Top 40 Country Hits: 1944\u20132006, Second edition |last=Whitburn |first=Joel |year=2004 |publisher=Record Research |page=388 |language=en |isbn=0823082911 }}</ref>\n\nHe provided the singing voice of his father<ref name=\"pc9\">{{Pop Chronicles |9 |4|Hank Williams Jr.}}</ref> in the 1964 film ''[[Your Cheatin' Heart (film)|Your Cheatin' Heart]].''<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0058765/ |title=Your Cheatin' Heart |date=December 1, 1964 |website=IMDb.com}}</ref> He also recorded an album of duets with recordings of his father.<ref name=\"pc9\" />\n\n===A change in appearance and musical direction===\nAlthough Williams' recordings earned him numerous country hits throughout the 1960s and early 1970s with his role as a \"Hank Williams impersonator\", he became disillusioned and severed ties with his mother.\n\nBy the mid-1970s Williams began to pursue a musical direction that would eventually make him a superstar. While recording a series of moderately successful songs, Williams began a pattern of heavy drug and alcohol abuse. Upon moving to [[Alabama]], in an attempt to refocus both his creative energy and his troubled personal life, Williams began playing music with [[Southern rock]] musicians including [[Waylon Jennings]], [[Toy Caldwell]], and [[Charlie Daniels]]. ''[[Hank Williams Jr. and Friends]]'' (1975), often considered his watershed album, was the product of these then-groundbreaking collaborations.\n\nOn August 8, 1975, Williams was nearly killed while mountain climbing in southwestern [[Montana]]. While climbing [[List of mountains in Beaverhead County, Montana|Ajax Peak]] on the [[Continental Divide of the Americas|continental divide]] ([[Idaho]] border) west of [[Jackson, Montana|Jackson]], the snow beneath Williams collapsed and he fell almost {{convert|500|ft}} onto rock, causing multiple severe skull and facial fractures.<ref name=singfll>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8R9OAAAAIBAJ&pg=1923%2C4536621 |work=Spokesman-Review |location=(Spokane, Washington) |agency=Associated Press |title=Singer injured in fall |date=August 11, 1975 |page=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2006-01-11-williams-miner-visit_x.htm?POE=LIFISVA | work=USA Today | title=Hank Williams visits W.Va. mine survivor | date=January 11, 2006}}</ref> Williams spent two years recovering, re-learning how to talk and sing, and undergoing 17 surgeries to repair his skull and reconstruct his face. The accident was chronicled in the semi-autobiographical, made-for-television film ''[[Living Proof: The Hank Williams Jr. Story]]''. To hide his scars and disfigurement from the accident, Williams grew a beard and began wearing sunglasses and a [[cowboy hat]]. The beard, hat, and sunglasses have since become Williams' [[trademark look|signature look]].{{citation needed|date=December 2022}}\n\nIn 1977, Williams recorded and released ''One Night Stands'' and ''The New South'', and worked closely with his old friend Waylon Jennings on the song \"Once and For All\".{{citation needed|date=December 2022}} In 1980, he appeared on the [[PBS]] show ''[[Austin City Limits]]'' during Season 5, along with the Shake Russell-[[Dana Cooper]] Band.{{citation needed|date=December 2022}}\n\n===Country music career===\n{{BLP sources section|date=October 2008}}\n[[File:HankWilliamsJrCollage-1000.jpg|thumb|upright=1.45|Williams performing at the Chumash Casino Resort in Santa Ynez, California, 2006]]\n\nIn 1976, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' wrote that Williams' \"mainstream country material has always been among [[Nashville Tennessee|Nashville]]{{'}}s best\".<ref>{{Cite web| title = Hank Williams Jr.: Hank William Jr. and Friends. By John Morthland : Articles, reviews and interviews from Rock's Backpages.| access-date = June 25, 2018| url = https://www.rocksbackpages.com/Library/Article/hank-williams-jr-ihank-william-jr-and-friendsi|via=[[Rock's Backpages]] |url-access=subscription }}</ref>\n\nHe was prolific throughout the 1980s, sometimes recording and releasing two albums a year. ''[[Family Tradition (album)|Family Tradition]]'', ''[[Whiskey Bent and Hell Bound (album)|Whiskey Bent and Hell Bound]]'', ''[[Habits Old and New]]'', ''[[Rowdy (Hank Williams, Jr. album)|Rowdy]]'', ''[[The Pressure Is On]]'', ''[[High Notes]]'', ''[[Strong Stuff]]'', ''[[Man of Steel (album)|Man of Steel]]'', ''[[Major Moves (album)|Major Moves]]'', ''[[Five-O (album)|Five-O]]'', ''[[Montana Cafe]]'', and many others resulted in a long string of hits.\n\nBetween 1979 and 1992, Williams released 21 albums\u201418 studio albums and three compilations\u2014that were all certified at least [[Music recording certification|gold]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]]. Between 1979 and 1990, he enjoyed a string of 30 Top Ten singles on the Billboard Country charts, including eight No.&nbsp;1 singles, for a total of 44 Top Ten singles, including a total of 10 No.&nbsp;1 singles, during his career.\n\nIn 1982, he had nine albums simultaneously on the Billboard Top Country Albums chart, all of which were original works and not compilations. In 1987\u201388, Williams was named Entertainer of the Year by the [[Country Music Association]]. In 1987, 1988, and 1989, he won the same award from the [[Academy of Country Music]]. The pinnacle album of his acceptance and popularity was ''[[Born to Boogie (album)|Born to Boogie]]''.\n\nDuring the 1980s, Williams Jr. became a country music superstar known for catchy anthems and hard-edged, rock-influenced country. During the late 1970s and into the mid-1980s, Williams' songs constantly flew into the number one or number two spots, with songs such as \"Family Tradition\", \"Whiskey Bent and Hell Bound\", \"Old Habits\", \"Ain't Misbehavin{{'\"}}, \"[[Born to Boogie (song)|Born to Boogie]]\", and \"My Name Is Bocephus\".\n\nThe hit single \"[[Wild Streak]]\" (1987) was co-written by [[Houston]] native [[Terri Sharp]], for which Williams and Sharp both earned gold records. In 1988, he released a Southern pride song, \"[[If the South Woulda Won]]\". The reference is to a notional Southern victory in the [[American Civil War|Civil War]].\n\nHis 1989 hit \"[[There's a Tear in My Beer]]\" was a duet with his father created using electronic merging technology. The song was written by his father, and had been previously recorded with Hank Williams playing the guitar as the sole instrument. The music video for the song combined existing television footage of Hank Williams performing, onto which electronic merging technology impressed the recordings of Williams, which then made it appear as if he were actually playing with his father. The video was both a critical and commercial success. It was named ''Video of the Year'' by both the Country Music Association and the Academy of Country Music. Williams would go on to win a [[Grammy Award]] in 1990 for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Collaboration with Vocals|Best Country Vocal Collaboration]].\n\nHe is well known for his hit \"[[A Country Boy Can Survive]]\" and as the performer of the theme song for ''[[Monday Night Football]]'', based on his 1984 hit \"[[All My Rowdy Friends Are Coming Over Tonight]]\". In 1991, 1992, 1993, and 1994, Williams' opening themes for ''Monday Night Football'' earned him four [[Emmy Award]]s. \n[[File:Hank Williams, Jr. (2006).jpg|thumb|Williams in 2006]]\nIn 2000, he provided the voice of Injun Joe in ''[[Tom Sawyer (2000 film)|Tom Sawyer]]''. In 2001, Williams Jr. co-wrote his classic hit \"A Country Boy Can Survive\" after 9/11, renaming it \"America Can Survive\". In 2004, Williams was featured prominently on ''CMT Outlaws''. In 2006, he starred at the Summerfest concert.\n\nHe has also made a cameo appearance along with [[Larry the Cable Guy]], [[Kid Rock]], and [[Charlie Daniels]] in [[Gretchen Wilson]]'s music video for the song \"[[All Jacked Up (song)|All Jacked Up]]\". He and Kid Rock also appeared in Wilson's \"[[Redneck Woman]]\" video. Hank also had a small part of Kid Rock's video \"Only God Knows Why\", and \"Redneck Paradise\".\n\nIn April 2009, Williams released a new single, \"Red, White & Pink-Slip Blues\", which peaked at number 43 on the country charts. The song was the lead-off single to Williams' album ''[[127 Rose Avenue]]''. The album debuted and peaked at number 7 on the ''Billboard'' Top Country Albums chart. Also in July 2009, ''127 Rose Avenue'' was announced as his last album for Curb Records.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1616664/hank-williams-jr-says-new-album-is-his-last-for-curb-records.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090725202808/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1616664/hank-williams-jr-says-new-album-is-his-last-for-curb-records.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=July 25, 2009|title=Hank Williams Jr. says new album is his last for Curb Records|last=Morris|first=Edward|work=[[Country Music Television]]|date=July 21, 2009|access-date=July 24, 2009}}</ref>\n\n== Musical style ==\nAs a multi-instrumentalist, Williams' repertoire of skills includes guitar, bass guitar, [[upright bass]], [[steel guitar]], [[banjo]], [[Resonator guitar]], piano, keyboards, saxophone, [[harmonica]], [[fiddle]], and drums.<ref name=\"autogenerated1\"/> Williams began his recording career performing covers of his father's songs. Despite catering to the country music market, Williams preferred to listen to [[rhythm and blues]].<ref name=Dukes/> Williams also recorded singles under the name Luke the Drifter Jr.<ref name=Harrington>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1992/12/16/recordings/72741d15-828d-4c87-a3b0-1893e1a975af/ |title=Recordings |last=Harrington |first=Richard |date=December 16, 1992 |newspaper=The Washington Post |access-date=2022-04-22}}</ref> (a reference to his father's alias \"Luke the Drifter\"), [[rock and roll]] singles under the aliases Rockin' Randall<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/hank-williams-jr-mn0000117844/biography |title=Artist Biography |last=Erlewine |first=Stephen Thomas |publisher=AllMusic |access-date=2022-04-22}}</ref> and Bocephus<ref name=Harrington/> (a nickname given to him by his father), and [[blues]] under the name Thunderhead Hawkins.<ref name=Dukes>{{cite web |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/hank-williams-jr-rich-white-honky-blues-album-title-interview/ |title=Hank Williams Jr. Explains 'Rich White Honky Blues' Album Title |last=Dukes |first=Billy |date=June 17, 2022 |publisher=Taste of Country |access-date=2022-09-08}}</ref> Williams' music has been categorized as [[country rock]],<ref name=Burns>{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/kenburns/country-music/hank-williams-jr-biography|title=Hank Williams Jr. Biography |last=Burns|first=Ken |date= |work=PBS |access-date=2023-07-07 |quote=He began the slow rebuilding of his career, this time entirely in the Southern country-rock genre.}}</ref> [[blues rock]],<ref name=Webb>{{cite web |url=https://amp.oklahoman.com/amp/62781299007 |title=Hank Williams Jr. Rocks Norman Crowd |last=Webb |first=Todd |date=December 7, 1984 |publisher=Oklahoman |access-date=2023-07-07 |quote=Williams returned the welcome with an inspired set of country-style rock 'n' roll at its best. [...] a full-speed-ahead set of no-holds-barred rock, blues-rock, and rockabilly rock so intense that Williams himself was forced to partially disrobe near the end of the show. }}</ref> [[southern rock]],<ref name=Malone>{{cite book |editor-last=Malone |editor-first=Bill |date=February 2014 |title=The New Encyclopedia of Southern Culture|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AOynAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA383 |chapter=Williams, Hank Jr. |publisher=University of North Carolina Press |page=383 |isbn=978-1469616667}}</ref> [[outlaw country]],<ref name=Erlewine>{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/hank-williams-jr-mn0000117844/biography |title= Hank Williams, Jr. Biography |last=Erlewine|first=Stephen Thomas |work=AllMusic |access-date=2023-07-07}}</ref> [[rockabilly]]<ref name=Webb/> and [[rock and roll]].<ref name=Webb/>\n\n== Legacy ==\nArtists who have cited Hank Williams Jr. as an influence include Delta Generators,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://amp.telegram.com/amp/63214191007 |title=Country and blues on stage this Friday |last=Banner |first=Sandy Meindersma |date=July 31, 2008 |publisher=Telegram & Gazette |access-date=2022-04-22}}</ref> [[Walker Hayes]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/walker-hayes-hank-williams-jr-song-influence-interview/ |title=WALKER HAYES ON HIS LOVE OF HANK JR., DON WILLIAMS |last=Paul |first=Evan |date=January 27, 2022 |publisher=Taste of Country |access-date= |quote=}}</ref> [[Sam Hunt]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/country-radio-seminar-closes-with-sam-hunt-frankie-ballard-6487466/ |title=Country Radio Seminar Closes With Stellar Performances by Sam Hunt, Cole Swindell & More |last=Dauphin |first=Chuck |date=February 28, 2015 |website= |publisher=Billboard |access-date=2022-04-22}}</ref> Davin James,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/davin-james-mn0000230651/biography |title=Artist Biography |last=Hage |first=Erik |publisher=AllMusic |access-date=2022-04-22 }}</ref> [[Shooter Jennings]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/shooter-jennings-premieres-drunk-talks-hank-williams-jr-influence-8468362/ |title=Shooter Jennings Premieres 'D.R.U.N.K.,' Talks Hank Williams Jr. Influence |last=Dauphin |first=Chuck |date=August 3, 2018 |publisher=Billboard |access-date=2022-04-20}}</ref> [[Wayne Mills (singer)|Wayne Mills]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2013/12/17/country-singer-killed/4049361/ |title=Bar owner charged in singer's death released from jail |last=Gonzalez |first=Tony |date=December 17, 2013 |publisher=USA Today |access-date= |quote=}}</ref> The Sickstring Outlaws<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2019/aug/01/live-five-electric-hoedown-hillbillies-steroids/ |title=Electric hoedown with hillbillies on steroids |last=Sanford |first=Jay Allen |date=August 1, 2019 |publisher=San Diego Reader |access-date=2022-04-22}}</ref> and [[Gretchen Wilson]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://gazettereview.com/gretchen-wilson-doing-now-update/ |title=What Happened To Gretchen Wilson \u2013 What's She Doing Now in 2022 |last=Rogers |first=Bridget |date=March 28, 2022 |publisher=Gazette Review |access-date=2022-04-22}}</ref>\n\nOn April 10, 2006, [[Country Music Television|CMT]] honored Williams with the [[Johnny Cash]] Visionary Award, presenting it to him at the 2006 [[CMT Music Awards]]. On November 11, 2008, Williams was honored as a [[Broadcast Music Incorporated|BMI]] Icon at the 56th annual BMI Country Awards. The artists and songwriters named BMI Icons have had \"a unique and indelible influence on generations of music makers\".<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.bmi.com/news/entry/537255 |title=Hank Williams, Jr. to be Honored as Icon at 56th Annual BMI Country Awards|website=Bmi.com|access-date=October 5, 2010|date=September 17, 2008}}</ref>\n\nIn 2015, Williams was inducted into the Louisiana Music Hall of Fame. On August 12, 2020, Williams was selected to be inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|Country Music Hall of Fame]].<ref name=\"Paulson\"/>\n\n==Personal life==\nHis daughter Katherine Williams-Dunning, the only one of his five children to not pursue a music career, died in a car crash on June 13, 2020, at age 27.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/hank-williams-jr-daughter-katherine-williams-dunning-killed-in-car-accident-tennessee/|title=Daughter of country music legend Hank Williams Jr. dies in car crash, authorities say|website=Cbsnews.com|date=June 14, 2020 |access-date=November 5, 2020}}</ref> His son Shelton performs as [[Hank Williams III]]; his other children include [[Holly Williams (musician)|Holly Williams]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.al.com/life/2021/06/hank-jrs-son-following-in-footsteps-of-legendary-grandpa-hank-williams.html |title=Hank Jr.'s son following in footsteps of legendary grandpa Hank Williams? |last=Colurso |first=Mary |website=al.com |date=June 8, 2021 |access-date=July 23, 2021 }}</ref> who is also a musician, as is his grandson [[Coleman Williams]] (Hank III's son), who performs under the sobriquet \"IV\".<ref name=hank3sonIV>{{cite web |last1=Trigger |title=The Hank Williams Lineage Continues with Hank3's Son \"IV\" |url=https://www.savingcountrymusic.com/the-hank-williams-linage-continues-with-hank3s-son-iv/ |website=Saving Country Music|date=March 7, 2021 }}</ref>  His wife Mary Jane Thomas died on March 22, 2022, aged 58, after complications from a medical procedure.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Avila |first1=Daniela |date=March 23, 2022 |first2=Sarah |last2=Michaud |title=Hank Williams Jr.'s Wife Mary Jane Thomas Has Died: 'A Beautiful Soul' |url=https://people.com/country/hank-williams-jr-wife-mary-jane-dead/ |access-date=2022-03-24 |website=PEOPLE.com |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Hank Williams Jr.'s Wife Mary Jane Thomas Dead at 58 |url=https://www.tmz.com/2022/03/23/hank-williams-jr-wife-dead-dies-mary-jane-thomas/ |access-date=2022-03-24 |website=TMZ|date=March 23, 2022 }}</ref> On September 9, 2023, Williams married his long-time friend since 2003, Brandi. The couple became engaged on Mother's Day of that same year.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Denis |first=Kyle |date=September 12, 2023 |title=Hank Williams Jr. Gets Married in Alabama |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/hank-williams-jr-wedding-married-brandi-1235411287/ |access-date=September 19, 2024 |work=Billboard}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Wilson |first=Angela |date=September 12, 2023 |title=Hank Williams Jr. Marries Fianc\u00e9e Brandi in Alabama Days After Announcing Engagement |url=https://people.com/hank-williams-jr-marries-brandi-in-front-of-a-small-group-of-family-and-friends-in-alabama-7968399 |access-date=September 19, 2024 |work=People}}</ref>\n\n==Politics==\nWilliams has been politically involved with the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. For the [[2000 U.S. Presidential election|2000 U.S. presidential election]], he rerecorded his song \"We Are Young Country\" to \"This is Bush-Cheney Country\". On October 15, 2008, at a rally in [[Virginia Beach, Virginia|Virginia Beach]] for Republican presidential nominee [[John McCain]], he performed \"McCain-Palin Tradition\", a song in support of McCain and his running mate, [[Sarah Palin]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://marcambinder.theatlantic.com/archives/2008/10/the_mccainpalin_tradition.php|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206023625/http://marcambinder.theatlantic.com/archives/2008/10/the_mccainpalin_tradition.php|url-status=dead|title=\"McCain\u2013Palin Tradition\"|archive-date=February 6, 2009|access-date=November 5, 2020}}</ref> He has contributed to federal election campaigns, mostly to Republicans, including [[Michele Bachmann]]'s 2012 presidential campaign. However, he has donated to some Democrats in the past, most notably [[Jim Cooper]] and [[John S. Tanner]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsmeat.com/celebrity_political_donations/Hank_Williams_Jr.php|title=Hank Williams Jr.|publisher=Federal Campaign Contribution Report|access-date=November 27, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921054027/http://www.newsmeat.com/celebrity_political_donations/Hank_Williams_Jr.php|archive-date=September 21, 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nIn November 2008, Williams considered a run for the 2012 Republican nomination as a [[U.S. Senator]] from Tennessee for the seat held by GOP incumbent [[Bob Corker]], although his publicist said regarding Williams \"no announcement has been made\".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://realclearpolitics.blogs.time.com/2008/11/25/hank-williams-jr-for-senate |title=Hank Williams Jr. For Senate? - Real Clear Politics \u2013 TIME.com |publisher=Realclearpolitics.blogs.time.com |date=November 25, 2008 |access-date=November 27, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120128170506/http://realclearpolitics.blogs.time.com/2008/11/25/hank-williams-jr-for-senate/|archive-date=January 28, 2012 }}</ref> Williams ultimately did not run.\n\n===2011 ''Fox and Friends'' controversy===\nIn an October 3, 2011, interview with [[Fox News Channel]]'s ''[[Fox & Friends]]'', Williams discussed a June golf game where President [[Barack Obama]] and Republican House Speaker [[John Boehner]] had teamed against Vice President [[Joe Biden]] and Ohio Governor [[John Kasich]], saying the match was \"one of the biggest political mistakes ever\". When asked why the golf game troubled him, Williams stated, \"Come on. That'd be like Hitler playing golf with [[Benjamin Netanyahu|Netanyahu]]&nbsp;... in the shape this country is in?\" He also said that the President and Vice President were \"the enemy\" and compared them to \"the [[Three Stooges]]\". Later, anchor [[Gretchen Carlson]] said to him, \"You used the name of one of the most hated people in all of the world to describe, ''I think'', the president.\" Williams replied, \"Well, that is true. But I'm telling you like it is.\" As a result of his statements, [[ESPN]] dropped Williams' opening song from its ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' broadcast of the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] versus the [[Indianapolis Colts]] and replaced it with the [[The Star-Spangled Banner|national anthem]].{{citation needed|date=June 2020}}\n\nWilliams later said his analogy was \"extreme \u2013 but it was to make a point\", and \"some of us have strong opinions and are often misunderstood&nbsp;... I was simply trying to explain how stupid it seemed to me \u2013 how ludicrous that pairing was. They're polar opposites, and it made no sense. They don't see eye to eye and never will\". Additionally, Williams said he has \"always respected the office of the president ... Working-class people are hurting \u2013 and it doesn't seem like anybody cares. When both sides are high-fiving it on the ninth hole when everybody else is without a job \u2013 it makes a whole lot of us angry. Something has to change. The policies have to change\". ESPN later said it was \"extremely disappointed\" in Williams' comments, and pulled his opening from that night's broadcast.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2011/football/nfl/10/03/espn.williams.ap/index.html |title=ESPN pulls Hank Williams Jr. intro after singer links Obama with Hitler |publisher=Sportsillustrated.cnn.com |date=October 3, 2011 |access-date=November 27, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111113134647/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2011/football/nfl/10/03/espn.williams.ap/index.html |archive-date=November 13, 2011}}</ref>\n\nThree days later, ESPN announced Williams and his song would not return to ''Monday Night Football'', ending the use of the song that had been part of the broadcast on both ABC and ESPN since 1989.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/7066449/espn-hank-williams-jr-theme-song-return-monday-night-football|title=ESPN, Hank Williams Jr. part ways|date=October 6, 2010|work=ESPN.com}}</ref> Williams expressed defiance and indifference on his website, and said he was the one who had made the decision. \"After reading hundreds of e-mails, I have made MY decision,\" he wrote. \"By pulling my opening Oct 3rd, You (ESPN) stepped on the Toes of The First Amendment Freedom of Speech, so therefore Me, My Song, and All My Rowdy Friends are OUT OF HERE. It's been a great run.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/7066449/espn-hank-williams-jr-theme-song-return-monday-night-football |title=ESPN \u2013 Hank Williams Jr. theme song won't return to Monday Night Football \u2013 ESPN |publisher=ESPN |date=October 6, 2011 |access-date=November 27, 2011}}</ref> Williams' son, [[Hank Williams III]], stayed neutral in the debate, telling [[TMZ.com]] that most musicians, including his father, are \"not worthy\" of a political discussion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tmz.com/2011/10/04/hank-williams-jr-monday-night-football-son-politics-obama-hitler-fox-news-channel-jello-biafra-green-party-politics/ |title=Hank Williams Jr.'s Son \u2013 My Dad Should NOT Talk Politics |publisher=TMZ.com |date=November 22, 2011 |access-date=November 27, 2011}}</ref>\n\nAfter his song was pulled from ''Monday Night Football,'' Williams recorded a song criticizing Obama, ESPN and ''[[Fox & Friends]]'', titled \"[[Keep the Change (Hank Williams Jr. song)|Keep the Change]]\". He released the track on [[iTunes]] and via free download at his website.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/gameon/post/2011/10/hank-williams-jr-retaliates-with-song-that-slams-fox/1|title=Hank Williams Jr. retaliates with song that slams Fox|first=Tom|last=Weir|date=October 10, 2011|work=[[USA Today]]}}</ref> The song garnered over 180,000 downloads in two days.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1672429/hank-williams-jr-thrives-with-downloads-media-coverage-surrounding-controversy.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111014104416/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1672429/hank-williams-jr-thrives-with-downloads-media-coverage-surrounding-controversy.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 14, 2011|title=Hank Williams Jr. Thrives With Downloads, Media Coverage Surrounding Controversy|date=October 12, 2011|publisher=[[CMT News]]}}</ref>\n\nWilliams continued to make his opinions of Obama known and during a performance at the Iowa State Fair in August 2012, [[Barack Obama religion conspiracy theories|he called Obama a Muslim]] telling the crowd, \"We've got a Muslim president who hates farming, hates the military, hates the U.S. and we hate him!\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/OTUS/hank-williams-jr-tells-crowd-obama-muslim-hates/story?id=17042110|title=Country Star Calls Obama 'a Muslim'|date=August 20, 2012|publisher=ABC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Couch |first=Aaron |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/general-news/hank-williams-jr-songs-barack-obama-363946/ |title=Hank Williams Jr. Calls Obama 'Muslim' Who 'Hates The Military'|work=[[Hollywood Reporter]] |date=August 18, 2012 |access-date=July 5, 2023 |archive-date=July 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20230705214720/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/general-news/hank-williams-jr-songs-barack-obama-363946/}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Hank Williams Jr. discography}}\n{{Div col|colwidth=30em}}\n*''[[Your Cheatin' Heart (Hank Williams Jr. album)|Your Cheatin' Heart]]'' (1964)\n*''[[Connie Francis and Hank Williams Jr. Sing Great Country Favorites]]'' (1964)\n*''[[Ballads of the Hills and Plains]]'' (1965)\n*''[[Blues My Name]]'' (1965)\n*''Country Shadows'' (1966)\n*''[[A Time to Sing (album)|A Time to Sing]]'' (1967)\n*''My Own Way'' (1967)\n*''My Songs'' (1967)\n*''Luke The Drifter Jr.'' (1968)\n*''[[Songs My Father Left Me]]'' (1969)\n*''[[Luke the Drifter Jr. Vol. 2]]'' (1969)\n*''[[Live at Cobo Hall]]'' (1969)\n*''Sunday Morning'' (1969)\n*''Removing The Shadow'' (1970)\n*''Luke The Drifter Jr. Vol. 3'' (1970)\n*''Singing My Songs: Johnny Cash'' (1970)\n*''I've Got A Right To Cry'' (1971)\n*''Sweet Dreams'' Last Love Song'' (1974)\n*''Bocephus'' (1975)\n*''[[Hank Williams Jr. and Friends]]'' (1975)\n*''One Night Stands'' (1977)\n*''The New South'' (1977)\n*''[[Family Tradition (album)|Family Tradition]]'' (1979)\n*''[[Whiskey Bent and Hell Bound]]'' (1979)\n*''[[Habits Old and New]]'' (1980)\n*''[[Rowdy (Hank Williams Jr. album)|Rowdy]]'' (1981)\n*''[[The Pressure Is On]]'' Wham Bam Sam]]'' (1996)\n*''[[Three Hanks: Men with Broken Hearts]]'' (1996)\n*''[[Stormy (album)|Stormy]]'' (1999)\n*''[[The Almeria Club Recordings]]'' (2002)\n*''[[I'm One of You]]'' (2003)\n*''[[127 Rose Avenue]]'' (2009)\n*''[[Old School New Rules]]'' (2012)\n* ''[[It's About Time (Hank Williams Jr. album)|It's About Time]]'' (2016)\n* ''[[Rich White Honky Blues]]'' (2022)\n{{div col end}}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{{BLP sources section|date=March 2021}}\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n!
