This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Cody_Jinks","to":"Cody Jinks"}],"pages":{"45719525":{"pageid":45719525,"ns":0,"title":"Cody Jinks","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Cody Jinks\n| image             = \n| image_size        = \n| landscape         = yes\n| alt               = \n| caption           = \n| birth_name        = Meredith Cody Jinks\n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1980|08|18}}\n| occupation        = {{flatlist|\n* Singer\n* songwriter\n}}\n| origin            = [[Haltom City, Texas]], U.S.\n| genre             = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country music|Country]]\n* [[Texas country music|Texas country]]\n* [[Outlaw country]]\n* [[Neotraditional country]]\n* [[Southern Rock]]\n}}\n| years_active      = 1998\u2013present\n| label             = {{flatlist|\n* Cody Jinks\n* [[Late August Records]]\n}}\n| associated_acts   = {{flatlist|\n* Unchecked Aggression\n* The Tone Deaf Hippies\n* Caned by Nod   \n}}\n| website           = {{URL|http://codyjinks.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''Meredith Cody Jinks'''<ref>{{cite web |url=https://kokefm.com/2020/06/12/cody-jinks-shares-powerful-story-of-division-and-unity-on-social-media/ |title=Cody Jinks Shares Powerful Story of Divising and Unity on Social Media |work=KOKE FM |date= January 25, 2012 |first= Haven|last=Medrano}}</ref> (born August 18, 1980) is an American [[Outlaw country|outlaw country music]] singer and songwriter.<ref name=\"fwweekly\">{{cite web |url=https://www.houstonpublicmedia.org/articles/arts-culture/2016/09/08/167380/live-in-studio-cody-jinks/ |title=Live In Studio: Cody Jinks |date=September 8, 2016 |work=Houston Public Media |first=Troy |last=Schulze}}</ref> His breakout 2016 album, ''[[I'm Not the Devil]]'', reached No. 4 on the ''Billboard'' Country Albums chart, while a number of other albums such as ''Lifers'', ''After the Fire'', and ''[[The Wanting (Cody Jinks album)|The Wanting]]'' reached No. 2 on the same chart.\n\n==Early life==\nCody Jinks is a native of [[Haltom City, Texas|Haltom City]], near [[Fort Worth, Texas]], United States,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fwweekly.com/2012/01/25/cody-jinks-hits-30/ |title=Cody Jinks Hits 30 |work=Fort Worth Weekly |date= January 25, 2012 |first= Steve|last=Steward}}</ref> and attended [[Haltom High School]]. He started learning to play a few country music riffs on the guitar from his father when he was 16, but soon formed a heavy metal band.<ref name=\"lubbock\">{{cite news |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151205203301/http://lubbockonline.com/go/music/2015-05-28/cody-jinks-touring-suport-adobe-sessions-album |archive-date=December 5, 2015 |url=http://lubbockonline.com/go/music/2015-05-28/cody-jinks-touring-suport-adobe-sessions-album |title=Cody Jinks touring in {{as written|sup|ort [sic]}} of \"Adobe Sessions\" album |first=Eric |last=May 28, 2015 |work=Lubbock Online }}</ref>\n\n==Music career==\nJinks started out as the lead singer of a [[thrash metal]] band from [[Fort Worth]] named Unchecked Aggression, initially named Silas, that was active from 1998 to 2003. He also played the lead guitar; the other band members were Gary Burkham on bass who left in 2000 and was replaced by Chris Lewis,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sbs666.tripod.com/uncheckedaggressionmainpage.htm |title=Unchecked Aggression|website=sbs666.tripod.com}}</ref> Anthony Walker on drums, and Ben Heffley on guitar.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spirit-of-metal.com/groupe-groupe-Unchecked_Aggression-l-en.html |title=Unchecked Aggression |work=Spirit of Metal }}</ref> They were influenced by [[Metallica]] and [[Pantera]].<ref name=freeman>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/how-cody-jinks-turned-discontent-and-thrash-metal-into-country-success-112864/ |title=How Cody Jinks Turned Discontent and Thrash Metal into Country Success|first=Jon |last= Freeman |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=November 10, 2016 }}</ref> An album, ''The Massacre Begins'' was released in 2002.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.metal-archives.com/bands/Unchecked_Aggression/1743 |title=Unchecked Aggression |work=The Metal Archive}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/lists/10-new-country-artists-you-need-to-know-september-2016-w438056/cody-jinks-w438091 |title=10 New Country Artists You Need to Know: September 2016 |magazine=Rolling Stone }}</ref> Songs they recorded included \"Hell Razor\" and \"Kill Me Again\".<ref name=freeman /> The band however broke up after a trip to Los Angeles, and Jinks took a year off from music. In around 2005, he started playing country music, the music he grew up with.<ref name=\"fwweekly\"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://thedailycountry.com/give-a-listen/category/cody%20jinks |title=Give A Listen: Cody Jinks|date=April 9, 2015 |work=The Daily Country }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wideopencountry.com/the-new-texas-cody-jinks/|title=The New Texas: Cody Jinks |first= Matt |last= Alpert |work=Wide Open Country |date=28 January 2016}}</ref>\n\nJinks is backed by The Tone Deaf Hippies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://roughneckbeardcompany.com/blog/bearded-brothers-honkytonk-proud-beard-cody-jinks/ |title=Bearded Brothers: Honkytonk Proud, the Beard of Cody Jinks |work=Roughneck Beard Company }}</ref> He began to release albums in the country genre in 2008.<ref name=\"fw\">{{cite web |url=https://www.fwweekly.com/2012/01/25/cody-jinks-hits-30/ |title=Cody Jinks Hits 30 |first=Steve |last=Steward |date= January 25, 2012 | work=Fort Worth Weekly}}</ref> An album titled ''30'' was released in 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.outlawmagazine.com/2013/02/05/cody-jinks-tone-deaf-hippies-live-at-thirsty-armadillo-saloon/ |title=Cody Jinks & Tone Deaf Hippies:Thirsty Armadillo |work=Outlaw Magazine |date=February 5, 2013 |access-date=September 10, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160911155821/http://www.outlawmagazine.com/2013/02/05/cody-jinks-tone-deaf-hippies-live-at-thirsty-armadillo-saloon/ |archive-date=September 11, 2016 |url-status=dead }}</ref> He began to develop his own sound in an EP, ''Blacksheep'', which was released in 2013.<ref name=\"black sheep\">{{cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/blacksheep-ep/id663979735 |title=Blacksheep |work=iTunes}}</ref><ref name=freeman />\n\n===2015: ''Adobe Sessions''===\nThe album was recorded at the Sonic Ranch in [[Tornillo, Texas]], and the album title was named after a small adobe room they recorded the album in.<ref name=\"lubbock\"/> It was released in January 2015 and charted in Billboard's regional Heatseekers charts \u2013 No.2 on Heatseekers South Central and No. 8 on Heatseekers Mountain.<ref>{{cite magazine |url= http://www.billboard.com/biz/charts/2015-01-24/heatseekers-south-central |title=Heatseekers - South Central |date = January 24, 2015 |magazine=Billboard }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |url= http://www.billboard.com/biz/charts/2016-05-14/heatseekers-mountain |title=Heatseekers - Mountain |date = May 14, 2016 |magazine=Billboard }}</ref> Jinks toured in support of ''Adobe Sessions'' as an opener for [[Sturgill Simpson]] in 2015.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.omaha.com/go/sturgill-simpson-plays-some-real-country-music/article_5d02950c-2b83-11e5-bda7-c3a1255f8a4a.html | title=Sturgill Simpson plays some real country music | publisher=Omaha World-Herald | date=July 16, 2015 | access-date=April 19, 2017}}</ref>\n\n===2016: ''I'm Not the Devil''===\n''[[I'm Not the Devil]]'' was released on August 12, 2016.<ref name=\"hear\">{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/hear-cody-jinks-profess-im-not-the-devil-in-dark-new-ballad-20160621 |title=Hear Cody Jinks Declare 'I'm Not the Devil' in Dark New Ballad |first=Joseph|last= Hudak|date=June 21, 2016 |magazine=Rolling Stone }}</ref>  The album was recorded at the Sonic Ranch in [[Tornillo, Texas]].<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/see-cody-jinks-live-brooding-im-not-the-devil-w435801 |title=See Cody Jinks' Brooding Live Performance of 'I'm Not the Devil' | first=Joseph|last= Hudak|date=August 23, 2016 |magazine=Rolling Stone}}</ref> It includes a cover of [[Merle Haggard]]'s \"[[The Way I Am (Merle Haggard song)|The Way I Am]]\".<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/7453623/cody-jinks-merle-haggard-cover-listen |title=Cody Jinks' Covers Merle Haggard's 'The Way I Am': Listen|date=July 28, 2016 |first= Elias|last= Leight |magazine=Billboard }}</ref>  The title track was written with his best friend Ward Davis; the album was almost finished and the album title had already been decided, but it was retitled with the name of the song they wrote.<ref name=\"hear\"/> The album debuted at No. 4 on the Top Country Albums chart, selling 11,300 copies in the first week.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://roughstock.com/news/2016/08/40756-country-albums-sales-chart-august-22-2016 |title=Country Albums Sales Chart: August 22, 2016 |first= Matt |last= Bjorke |date= August 21, 2016 |work=Roughstock}}</ref> Jinks supported ''I'm Not the Devil'' with a co-headlining tour with [[Whitey Morgan and the 78's]] in August, September, and October. The album was rated one of the best country albums of 2016 by ''[[Rolling Stone]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country-lists/40-best-country-albums-of-2016-117269/ |title=40 Best Country Albums of 2016 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=December 7, 2016 }}</ref>\n\n===2017===\nJinks released a cover of [[Pink Floyd]]'s hit song \"[[Wish You Were Here (Pink Floyd song)|Wish You Were Here]]\" in January 2017.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/videos/hear-cody-jinks-cover-of-pink-floyds-wish-you-were-here-w462419 | title=Hear Cody Jinks' Swirling Cover of Pink Floyd's 'Wish You Were Here' | publisher=Rolling Stone | date=January 23, 2017 | access-date=April 19, 2017}}</ref> He also re-released a remixed and remastered version of his 2010 album ''Less Wise'', as ''Less Wise Modified 2017'', with three bonus tracks included.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://103kkcn.com/cody-jinks-re-issues-an-album-from-2010/ |date=November 8, 2017|title=Cody Jinks Re-issues an album from 2010Trigger|work=Kickin Country 103.1 |first=Chuck |last=Baker}}</ref>\n\n===2018: ''Lifers''===\nJinks released the album ''Lifers'' on July 27, 2018, via [[Rounder Records]].<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/cody-jinks-details-new-album-lifers-629545/|title=Cody Jinks Details New Album 'Lifers' |first= Chris|last=Parton |date=June 4, 2018 |magazine=Rolling Stone }}</ref> It was preceded by the lead single \"Must Be the Whiskey\", which was released on June 15, 2018.\n\n===2019: ''After the Fire and The Wanting''===\nOn October 11, 2019, Jinks released the album ''After the Fire''. The album was independently produced and released by his own label, Late August Records, marking a departure from Rounder Records, with whom he produced 2018's ''Lifers''.<ref name=hudak>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/cody-jinks-after-the-fire-new-album-870508/ |title=Cody Jinks Announces New Album 'After the Fire'|first= Joseph|last= Hudak |magazine=Rolling Stone|date= August 12, 2019 }}</ref> The album was preceded by two singles, \"Ain't a Train\" and \"Think Like You Think\". Jinks also promoted the song \"William and Wanda\", which was written about his late grandparents. For the week of October 26, 2019, the album was No. 2 on the Billboard Top Country Albums chart.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/country-albums|title=Country Music: Top Country Albums Chart|magazine=Billboard|access-date=December 5, 2019}}</ref>\n\nOne week later, October 18, 2019, Jinks released a second album, ''The Wanting''.<ref name=moore>{{cite web |url=https://theboot.com/cody-jinks-after-the-fire-the-wanting/ |title= Actually, Cody Jinks Is Releasing Two Albums This Fall |date=September 17, 2019 |work=The Boot |first=Bobby |last=Moore}}</ref> Similar to ''After the Fire'', the album was independently produced. It was preceded by two singles, \"Same Kind of Crazy as Me\" and \"Which One I Feed\".\n\nOn October 24, 2019, both albums held the No. 1 and 2 spots for Top Albums on iTunes and Apple Music.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/CodyJinksMusic/|title=Cody Jinks|website=Facebook.com|access-date=December 5, 2019}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\" \n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"3\"| Peak chart positions\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:8em;\"|Sales\n! rowspan=\"2\" |Certifications\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Billboard 200|US]]<br /><ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/cody-jinks/chart-history/billboard-200 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180807034356/https://www.billboard.com/music/cody-jinks/chart-history/billboard-200 |url-status=dead |archive-date=August 7, 2018 |title=Cody Jinks Chart History: Billboard 200 |magazine=Billboard |access-date=August 7, 2018}}</ref>\n! width=\"45\"| [[Independent Albums|US Indie]]<br /><ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/cody-jinks/chart-history/independent-albums |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180807034746/https://www.billboard.com/music/cody-jinks/chart-history/independent-albums |url-status=dead |archive-date=August 7, 2018 |title=Cody Jinks Chart History: Independent Albums |magazine=Billboard |access-date=August 7, 2018}}</ref>\n|-\n!scope=\"row\"| ''Collector's Item''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cdtracks.org/album_cody_jinks_collectors_item-400226.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170216063713/http://www.cdtracks.org/album_cody_jinks_collectors_item-400226.html |archive-date=February 16, 2017 |title=Collectors Item Album by Cody Jinks |work=CDtracks.org }}</ref>\n| \n* Release date: 2006\n* Label: Cody Jinks \n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|\n|\n|-\n!scope=\"row\"| ''Cast No Stones''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cdtracks.org/album_cody_jinks_cast_no_stones-2580204.html |title=Cast No Stones Album by Cody Jinks |work=CDtracks.org }}</ref>\n| \n* Release date: 2008\n* Label: Cody Jinks \n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|\n|\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"|  ''[[I'm Not the Devil]]''\n|  \n* Release date: August 12, 2016\n* Label: Cody Jinks Music\n| 39\n| 4\n| 3\n|\n*US: 67,100<ref>{{cite news |url=http://roughstock.com/news/2017/12/42594-top-10-country-albums-chart-december-18-2017 |title=Top 10 Country Albums Chart: December 18, 2017 |first=Matt |last=Bjorke |date=December 17, 2017 |work=Roughstock}}</ref>\n|\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Mercy''\n|\n* Release date: November 12, 2021\n* Label: Late August\n| 80<br /><ref>{{cite tweet|user=billboardcharts|number=1462805284737409038|title=Debuts on this week's #Billboard200 (1/3)...|date=November 22, 2021|access-date=November 23, 2021}}</ref>\n| 12\n| 12\n|\n|\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Change the Game''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2023/12/cody-jinks-to-change-the-game-with-forthcoming-album/|title=Cody Jinks to ''Change the Game'' With Forthcoming Album|author=Lorie Hollabaugh|date=December 5, 2023|website=Music Row|accessdate=January 16, 2024}}</ref>\n|\n* Release date: March 22, 2024\n* Label: Late August\n| 128<br /><ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/billboard-200/2024-04-06|title=''Billboard'' 200: Week of April 6, 2024|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=April 2, 2024}}</ref>\n| 27<br /><ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/country-albums/2024-04-13|title=Top Country Albums|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=April 13, 2024|access-date=April 9, 2024}}</ref>\n| \u2014\n|\n|\n|-\n| colspan=\"7\" style=\"font-size:85%\" | \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|}\n\n=== Live albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\" \n|-\n! Album\n|-\n| 2018\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Must Be the Whiskey\"\n|\n*US: 27,000<ref>{{cite news|url=http://roughstock.com/news/2018/11/43522-top-30-digital-country-singles-chart-november-13-2018|title=Top 30 Digital Country Singles Chart: November 13, 2018|work=RoughStock|first=Matt |last=Bjorke |date= November 13, 2018|access-date=December 8, 2018}}</ref>\n|\n* RIAA: Platinum<ref name=\"RIAA\"/>\n| rowspan=\"2\" |''Lifers''\n|-\n| 2019\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Somewhere Between I Love You and I'm Leavin'\"\n|\n|-\n| 2020\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Watch the World Die\"\n|\n|\n| ''Watch the World Die''\n|-\n| 2021\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Hurt You\"\n|\n|\n| ''Mercy''\n|-\n| 2022\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Loud and Heavy\"\n|\n|\n| ''Adobe Sessions''\n|-\n| 2024\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Outlaws and Mustangs\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://assets.countryaircheck.com/public/87dc9361-4c9b-4ea1-a2e3243598217264/Issue-892-January-16-2024.pdf|format=PDF|title=Country Aircheck : Issue 892|date=January 16, 2024|website=Assets.countryaricheck.com|access-date=August 18, 2024}}</ref>\n|\n|\n| ''Change the Game''\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Jinks, Cody}}\n[[Category:1980 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Texas]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Texas]]\n[[Category:Outlaw country singers]]\n[[Category:People from Denton, Texas]]\n[[Category:People from Tarrant County, Texas]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]\n[[Category:Rounder Records artists]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Doug_Kershaw","to":"Doug Kershaw"}],"pages":{"1135556":{"pageid":1135556,"ns":0,"title":"Doug Kershaw","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2015}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name         = Doug Kershaw\n| image        = Dougkershaw.jpg\n| caption      = Doug Kershaw playing the fiddle at the 2009 [[Festivals Acadiens et Cr\u00e9oles]].\n| image_size   =\n| birth_name   = Douglas James Kershaw\n| birth_place  = [[Cameron Parish, Louisiana]], U.S.<ref name=\"fiddle\">{{cite web|last=Simmons|first=Michael|title=Doug Kershaw: The \"Real Deal\" in Cajun Fiddle|url=http://www.fiddle.com/Articles.page?Index=23&ArticleID=18818|publisher=Fiddle.com|date=March 1, 2003|access-date=2014-08-11}}</ref><ref name=\"McCall-p263\">{{cite book|last1=McCall|first1=Michael|last2=Paxman|first2=Bob|title=The Encyclopedia of Country Music|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2012|page=263|isbn=978-0195395631}}</ref>\n| birth_date   = {{birth date and age|1936|01|24}}<ref name=\"fiddle\" /><ref name=\"McCall-p263\" />\n| instrument   = [[Vocals]], [[fiddle]], [[cajun accordion]], [[guitar]]\n| origin       = [[Louisiana]]\n| genre        = [[Cajun music]], [[country music|country]], [[folk music|folk]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]]\n| occupation   = Musician, songwriter\n| years_active = 1948\u2013present\n| website      =  {{Website defunct|grabow.biz/Country/DougKershaw.htm}}\n}}\n\n'''Douglas James Kershaw''' (born January 24, 1936<ref name=\"fiddle\" /><ref name=\"McCall-p263\" />) is an American [[Musical styles (violin)#Fiddle|fiddle]] player, singer and songwriter from [[Louisiana]]. Active since 1948, he began his career as part of the duo [[Rusty and Doug]], along with his brother, [[Rusty Kershaw]]. He had an extensive solo career that included fifteen albums and singles that charted on the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. He is also a member of the [[Louisiana Music Hall of Fame]], being inducted in 2009.\n\n== Early life ==\nBorn in an unincorporated community called Tiel Ridge in [[Cameron Parish, Louisiana|Cameron Parish]], Kershaw spoke [[Louisiana French]] and did not learn English until the age of eight. By that time, he had mastered the fiddle, which he played from the age of five, and was on his way to teaching himself to play 28 instruments.<ref name = \"CMT\">{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/kershaw_doug/bio.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110529012212/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/kershaw_doug/bio.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=May 29, 2011 |title=Doug Kershaw Bio |publisher=Cmt.com |access-date=2015-10-17}}</ref> His first gig was at a local bar, the Bucket of Blood, where he was accompanied by his mother on guitar.<ref name=\"LouisianaRocks\">{{cite book|last1=Aswell|first1=Tom|title=Louisiana Rocks!: The True Genesis of Rock and Roll|date=2013|publisher=Pelican Publishing|isbn=9781455607839|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BSHTGsnI8skC&q=%22Doug+Kershaw%22+%2B+%22Bucket+of+Blood%22&pg=PA222|access-date=21 August 2017}}</ref>\n\nKershaw became interested in Cajun music during parties his parents would host on the family's [[houseboat]] in Louisiana, where he first heard Cajun bands playing the music.\n\n==\"Doug and Rusty\"==\nDoug grew up surrounded by [[Cajun music|Cajun]] fiddle and [[accordion]] music. After teaching his brother, Rusty, to play guitar, he formed a band, the Continental Playboys, with Rusty and older brother Nelson \"Peewee\" Kershaw in 1948.<ref name=\"LouisianaRocks\"/> With the departure of Peewee from the group, in the early 1950s, [[Rusty & Doug]] continued to perform as a duo. In 1955, when Kershaw was nineteen, he and Rusty performed on the ''[[Louisiana Hayride]]'' [[KWKH]] radio broadcast in [[Shreveport, Louisiana|Shreveport]], Louisiana.<ref name=\"Stabler-p233\">{{cite book|last=Stambler|first=Irwin|title=Country Music: The Encyclopedia|year=2000|publisher=St. Martin's Griffin|edition=3rd|page=233|isbn=978-0312264871}}</ref> The two also performed at the WWVA Jamboree (later renamed [[Jamboree U.S.A.]]), in [[Wheeling, West Virginia|Wheeling]], West Virginia.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Dregni|first1=Michael|title=Rockabilly: The Twang Heard 'Round the World: The Illustrated History|date=2011|publisher=Voyageur Press|isbn=9780760340622|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=06VWZ69WBAEC&q=%22Doug+Kershaw%22+%2B+%22WWVA+jamboree%22&pg=PA144|access-date=21 August 2017}}</ref>\n\nAlthough the brothers initially sang in French, [[J. D. \"Jay\" Miller]], owner of the [[Feature Records]] label, persuaded them to incorporate songs in English into their repertoire. In 1955, Doug and Rusty recorded their first single, \"So Lovely, Baby.\" Released on the Hickory label, the tune went to number 14 on the country music charts. Later that same year, Doug and Rusty were invited to become members of the ''[[Louisiana Hayride]]'' cast. The Kershaws appeared at the [[Grand Ole Opry]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] and became regular members of the Opry cast the following year.<ref name = \"CMT\" /><ref>{{cite web\n| title = Opry Timeline \u2013 1950s\n| url = http://www.opry.com/about/Timeline_1950.html\n| publisher = Opry.com\n| access-date = July 10, 2012\n| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20190330032424/https://www.opry.com/about/Timeline_1950.html\n| archive-date = March 30, 2019\n| url-status = dead\n}}</ref>\nDespite the demands of his music career, Doug enrolled in [[McNeese State University]], in [[Lake Charles, Louisiana]], where he earned an [[undergraduate degree]] in Mathematics. At the peak of their early career, in 1958, Doug and Rusty both enlisted in the [[United States Army]]. They devoted their attention to the military until their discharge three years later.<ref name=\"LouisianaRocks\"/>\n\n== \"Louisiana Man\" and solo career ==\nAfter fulfilling their military obligation, the two brothers recorded \"[[Louisiana Man]]\", an autobiographical song that Doug had written while in the Army. The song not only sold millions of copies but over the years has come to be considered a standard of modern Cajun music.<ref name=\"Woodstra-p255\">{{cite book|last=Woodstra|first=Chris|title=All Music Guide to Country: The Experts' Guide to the Best Country Recordings|publisher=Backbeat Books|edition=1st|year=1997|page=255|isbn=978-0879304751}}</ref> The song was eventually [[cover version|covered]] by more than 800 artists.\n\nThere were three albums released by the duo on [[Hickory Records]], only one being released before they split up. The first was ''Rusty and Doug Sing Louisiana Man'' (LPM 103) in 1961. ''Kershaw (Genus Cambarus)'' (LPS 163) was released in 1972 and was a double LP. ''Louisiana Man'' (HR 4506) was the final Hickory album, released in 1974. By 1964, the brothers had elected to go their separate ways. It took another three years before Kershaw signed a songwriters' contract with BMI, in 1967.\n\nIn June 1969, Kershaw made his first network television appearance on the debut of the ''[[The Johnny Cash Show (TV series)|Johnny Cash Show]]''.<ref name=\"LouisianaRocks\"/> After watching Kershaw's ''Johnny Cash Show'' performance as an eight-year-old boy, [[Mark O'Connor]] became inspired to learn to play the fiddle.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1993/11/19/mark-oconnors-art-fiddling-with-the-best/ad489226-573c-4281-b521-c7aff4a63e5a/ |title=Mark O'Connor's Art: Fiddling With The Best |author=Himes, Geoffrey |work=washingtonpost.com |access-date=5 May 2022 }}</ref> He capped the year with a week-long engagement at the New York City's [[Fillmore East]] as opening act for [[Eric Clapton]]'s [[Derek and the Dominos]]. While it seemed to many rock and pop fans that Kershaw had appeared out of nowhere, he had already sold more than 18 million copies of the records he had made in the early '60s with his brother, Rusty. \"Louisiana Man\" had been a Top 10 country hit in 1961 and its follow-up, \"Diggy Liggy Lo\", had done almost as well. His performance in front of a national audience led to [[Warner Bros. Records]] signing him to a long-term contract.<ref>{{cite web|title=Richard De La Font Agency, Inc: Doug Kershaw|url=http://delafont.com/music_acts/E/doug-kershaw.htm|publisher=Delafont.com|access-date=2014-08-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110709010841/http://delafont.com/music_acts/E/doug-kershaw.htm|archive-date=July 9, 2011|url-status=dead}}</ref> In July 1969, he performed at the Newport folk festival along with Joni Mitchell, Arlo Guthrie, Ramblin Jack Elliott, Big Mama Thornton, and Mimi Fari\u00f1a, among others. Newcomers that year were Don McLean, James Taylor, and Jerry Jeff Walker. In November 1969, \"Louisiana Man\"  was broadcast back to Earth by the crew of the [[Apollo 12]] Moon mission.<ref>{{cite news|title=Born on the Bayou: Exploring Louisiana in 18 Songs|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/born-on-the-bayou-exploring-louisiana-in-18-songs-20120611|access-date=21 August 2017|publisher=Rolling Stone|date=11 June 2012}}</ref> Beyond the southern venues, Kershaw became widely known in mainstream America as he played at major urban concert halls.\n\nIn 1970, Kershaw contributed a violin part to Arlo Guthrie's [[Single (music)|record single]] \"[[Alice's Restaurant|Alice's Rock and Roll Restaurant]].\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Arlo-Guthrie-Alices-Rock-And-Roll-Restaurant-Ring-Around-A-Rosy-Rag/release/2544222 |title=Arlo Guthrie - Alice's Rock And Roll Restaurant / Ring-Around-A-Rosy Rag (Vinyl) |publisher=[[Discogs]] |access-date=2015-10-17}}</ref>\n\nIn 1971, Kershaw had an acting and musical cameo in the [[Western (genre)|Western film]] ''[[Zachariah (1971 film)|Zachariah]]'', starring [[Don Johnson]] and [[John Rubinstein]].<ref name=NYT>{{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9D05E3DE163BE53BBC4D51DFB766838A669EDE|title=Zachariah (1970) Screen: 'Zachariah,' an Odd Western|author-link=Roger Greenspun|author=Greenspun, Roger|date=January 25, 1971}}</ref>\n\nKershaw's playing was featured in the [[Richard Brooks]] 1971 film ''[[Dollars (film)|Dollars]]''.\n\nIn 1972, Kershaw played electric fiddle in Grand Funk's \"Flight of the Phoenix\" off their LP ''Phoenix''. Capitol SMAS 11099<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Grand-Funk-Phoenix/release/1441635 |title=Grand Funk* - Phoenix (Vinyl, LP, Album) |publisher=[[Discogs]] |access-date=2015-10-17}}</ref>\n\n== Later life ==\nDespite the success of his solo career, Kershaw was plagued by depression and [[sadness|sorrow]]. His father had committed suicide when he was only seven.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Tucker|first1=Tanya|title=100 Ways to Beat the Blues: An Uplifting Book for Anyone Who's Down|date=May 11, 2010|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-1-4391-0602-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6REhl5DWDwwC&q=%22Doug+Kershaw%22+%2B+suicide&pg=PA61|access-date=21 August 2017}}</ref> Marrying his wife, Pam, at the [[Reliant Astrodome|Houston Astrodome]] on June 21, 1975, Kershaw began raising his own family that included five sons \u2013 Douglas, Victor, Zachary, Tyler, and Elijah; and two grandsons and a granddaughter. His son Tyler plays drums in his band, and manages his shows as well.<ref>{{cite news|title=Doug Kershaw and Steve Riley|url=http://fqfi.org/frenchquarter/artists/detail/674/Doug-Kershaw-and-Steve-Riley|access-date=21 August 2017|publisher=French Quarter|archive-date=August 22, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170822020703/http://fqfi.org/frenchquarter/artists/detail/674/Doug-Kershaw-and-Steve-Riley|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nIn 1978, Kershaw appeared briefly as a fiddler in the film ''[[Days of Heaven]]''.<ref>{{cite web |title=Days of Heaven \u2013 Full Cast & Crew |url=https://www.tvguide.com/movies/days-of-heaven/cast/2030112469/ |website=[[TV Guide]] |access-date=14 September 2022}}</ref>\n\nKershaw rebounded with his biggest selling hit, \"Hello Woman\", which reached the country music Top 40. By 1984, Kershaw's battle with [[drug abuse|drug]] and [[alcohol abuse]] came to a close and his previously erratic behavior changed for the better.<ref name=\"CMT\" />\n\nIn 1988, he recorded a duet, \"[[Cajun Baby]]\", with [[Hank Williams, Jr.]],<ref name=\"LouisianaRocks\" /> that became a Top 50 country hit. Kershaw released a French-language album, ''Two Step Fever'', in 1999, and Michael Doucet of Beausoleil is featured on the duet \"Fievre De Deux Etapes\". ''Hot Diggity Doug'' was released in mid-2000 and ''Still Cajun After All These Years'' followed in early 2001.  His brother Rusty died on October 23, 2001.<ref name=\"cmt-rusty\">{{cite web|last=Morris|first=Edward|title=CMT: Rusty Kershaw, of Rusty & Doug, Dead at 63|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1450284/rusty-kershaw-of-rusty-doug-dead-at-63.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121117022900/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1450284/rusty-kershaw-of-rusty-doug-dead-at-63.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=November 17, 2012|publisher=Cmt.com|date=October 23, 2001|access-date=2014-08-11}}</ref>\n\nKershaw formerly owned and operated The Bayou House, a restaurant in Lucerne, Colorado, but parted ways with his partners in 2007 due to his displeasure with management and ambiance.<ref name=\"greeley\">{{cite web|first=Kyle|last=Haas|url=http://www.greeleytribune.com/article/20080528/BUSINESS/642059053|title=Bayou House closes its doors|publisher=Greeley Tribune|date=May 28, 2008|access-date=2010-01-27}}</ref>\n\nIn 2009, Doug was inducted into The [[Louisiana Music Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite news|title=D.L. Mendard to be Inducted Into LA Musical Hall of Fame|url=http://archive.vermiliontoday.com/dl-menard-be-inducted-la-musical-hall-fame|access-date=21 August 2017|publisher=Vermilion Today|date=7 October 2009}}</ref>\n\nDoug's third cousin is country music star [[Sammy Kershaw]].<ref>{{cite book|title=The Encyclopedia of Country Music|date=February 2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-992083-9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tLZz02EzmBYC&q=%22Doug+Kershaw%22+%2B+%22Sammy+Kershaw%22+cousin&pg=PT794|access-date=21 August 2017}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n\n=== Albums ===\n\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n! colspan=\"3\"| Chart Positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Label\n|-\n! style=\"width:50px;\"| <small>[[Top Country Albums|US Country]]</small>\n! style=\"width:50px;\"| <small>[[Kent Music Report|AUS]]</small><ref name=aus>{{cite book|last=Kent|first=David|author-link=David Kent (historian)|title=Australian Chart Book 1970\u20131992|edition=illustrated|publisher=Australian Chart Book|location=St Ives, N.S.W.|year=1993|isbn=0-646-11917-6|page=165}}</ref>\n! style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n|}\n\n== Notes ==\n:1.{{note|a}} This recording of \"Louisiana Sun\" dates from the 1960s, and likely features an uncredited [[Rusty Kershaw]].\n:2.{{note|b}} Promo copies exist with a re-recording of the song as \"Don't Mess With My Popeye's\", done specially for the fast food chain.\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==Relevant reading==\n*Kershaw, Doug This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Allman_Brothers_Band","to":"Allman Brothers Band"}],"pages":{"2196706":{"pageid":2196706,"ns":0,"title":"Allman Brothers Band","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"#redirect [[The Allman Brothers Band]]\n\n[[Category:Unprintworthy redirects]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Moonshine_Bandits","to":"Moonshine Bandits"}],"pages":{"43744250":{"pageid":43744250,"ns":0,"title":"Moonshine Bandits","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country rap duo}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Moonshine Bandits\n| image           =\n| image_size      =\n| landscape       =\n| alt             =\n| caption         =\n| alias           =\n| origin          = [[Los Banos, California]], [[United States]]\n| genre           = [[Country rap]]\n                   [[Rap Rock]]\n| years_active    = 2003\u2013present\n| label           = {{hlist|[[Suburban Noize Records|Suburban Noize]]|[[Average Joes Entertainment|AVJ Records]]|MSB Entertainment}}\n| associated_acts = {{hlist|[[Colt Ford]]|Durwood Black|[[The Lacs]]|[[Bubba Sparxxx]]}}\n| website         = {{url|http://moonshinebandits.com/}}\n| current_members = Dusty \"Tex\" Dahlgren<br /> Brett \"Bird\" Brooks\n| past_members    = \n}}\n\n'''Moonshine Bandits''' is an American [[country rap]] group composed of Dusty \"Tex\" Dahlgren and Brett \"Bird\" Brooks.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|last=Jeffries|first=David|title=Moonshine Bandits {{!}} Biography|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=mn0000928079/biography|pure_url=yes}}|work=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=September 4, 2014}}</ref> The duo formed in [[California]] in 2003 and has released a number of albums, the most recent being ''The Whiskey Never Dries'' released in August 2019.\n\n==Music career==\nThe duo was formed in [[California]] in 2003 and released their debut album, ''Soggy Crackerz''.<ref name=\"allmusic\" /> They met up with Ty Weathers who is the founder of Burn County Music, which has continued to work closely in assisting majority of the Moonshine Bandits Blue Core/Dirt Rock sound. ''Soggy Crackerz'' was followed by ''Prohibition'' in 2006 and ''Divebars and Truckstops'' in 2010.<ref name=\"allmusic\" />\n\nMoonshine Bandits signed with [[Suburban Noize Records]] for the release of their fourth album, ''Whiskey and Women'', in 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=Moonshine Bandits Sign A Record Deal|url=http://skopemag.com/2010/12/08/moonshine-bandits-sign-a-record-deal|accessdate=September 4, 2014|work=[[Skope Magazine]]|date=December 8, 2010}}</ref> The music video for \"My Kind of Country\" premiered on [[CMT Music|CMT Pure Country]] in February 2012 with a special appearance by Mike Allsup (The Bearded Guy playing the guitar) from [[Modesto, California]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Los Banos' Moonshine Bandits premier new video, 'My Kind of Country'|url=http://www.mercedsunstar.com/2012/02/21/2239373/los-banos-moonshine-bandits-premier.html|accessdate=September 4, 2014|work=[[Merced Sun-Star]]|date=February 21, 2012}}</ref> \n\nIn 2014, they partnered with [[Average Joes Entertainment]] for their fifth album ''[[Calicountry]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Conaway|first1=Alanna|title=The Moonshine Bandits to Release New Album Through Average Joes Entertainment|url=http://roughstock.com/news/the-moonshine-bandits-to-release-new-album-through-average-joes-entertainment/|accessdate=September 4, 2014|work=Roughstock|date=September 5, 2013|archive-url=https://archive.today/20140905004321/http://roughstock.com/news/the-moonshine-bandits-to-release-new-album-through-average-joes-entertainment/|archive-date=September 5, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''Calicountry'' sold 3,000 copies in its first week of release, debuting at number 22 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart and number 126 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bjorke|first1=Matt|title=Country Album Chart News: The Week of February 12, 2014: Florida Georgia Line #1, Eric Paslay Debuts Top 5; Whiskey Myers, Moonshine Bandits, Scotty McCreery|url=http://roughstock.com/news/country-album-chart-news-the-week-of-february-12-2014-florida-georgia-line-1-eric-paslay-debuts-top-5-whiskey-myers-moonshine-bandits-scotty-mccreery/|accessdate=September 4, 2014|work=Roughstock|date=February 12, 2014|archive-url=https://archive.today/20140905004322/http://roughstock.com/news/country-album-chart-news-the-week-of-february-12-2014-florida-georgia-line-1-eric-paslay-debuts-top-5-whiskey-myers-moonshine-bandits-scotty-mccreery/|archive-date=September 5, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref>  \n\nTheir sixth album, ''[[Blacked Out]]'', was released in July 2015, and it debuted at No.158 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and No. 13 on the Top Country Albums chart, No. 10 on the Top Rap Albums chart, selling 4,000 copies in its debut week.<ref>{{cite news|title=Country Album Chart Report for July 28, 2015|url=http://roughstock.com/news/2015/07/36603-country-album-chart-report-july-28-2015 |last= Bjorke|first=Matt |publisher=Roughstock |date= July 28, 2015 }} Sales figure given [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1_bRZs8MP6YBv3ww5nYxeGefsT_tgpVFDy4k5J-EAGRw/edit#gid=0 here]</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" scope=\"row\"| \"We All Country\" <small>(with [[Colt Ford]],<br />Sarah Ross and Demun Jones)</small>\n| Daniel Henry\n|-\n| rowspan=\"1\"| 2015\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Outback (Extended Remix)\" <small>(with Durwood Black, [[Redneck Souljers]], [[Bubba Sparxxx]], Demun Jones, [[The Lacs]], [[Jawga Boyz|D. Thrash]], Moccasin Creek and [[Lenny Cooper]])</small>\n|[[Ed Pryor]]\n|-\n| rowspan=\"1\"| 2016\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Dead Man's Hand\"\n| rowspan=\"3\"|Ken Madson\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2017\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Take This Job\" <small>(with [[David Allan Coe]])</small>\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I'm A HellRazor\" \n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2018\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Buried As An Outlaw\"\n|\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Rebel Red Hot\"\n|\n|-\n| 2019\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Do It Again\"\n| rowspan=\"2\"| Josh Fields\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 2020\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Red, White and Boozed\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I'm On Fire\"\n| @Kreatewithkvnvas\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Watchya Got\"\n| rowspan=\"7\"| Josh Fields\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2021\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Live the Madness\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"American Summer\"\n|-\n| 2022\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Like 'Em Wild\"\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 2023\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I'm a Rebel\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I'm a Problem\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Wild\"\n|-\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{official|http://moonshinebandits.com/}}\n\n[[Category:Country music groups from California]]\n[[Category:Average Joes Entertainment artists]]\n[[Category:American country music duos]]\n[[Category:Country rap musicians]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 2003]]\n[[Category:Suburban Noize Records artists]]\n[[Category:People from Los Banos, California]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Neal_McCoy","to":"Neal McCoy"}],"pages":{"2737825":{"pageid":2737825,"ns":0,"title":"Neal McCoy","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country music singer (born 1958)}}\n{{about||the American mathematician|Neal Henry McCoy}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name            = Neal McCoy\n| image           = File:Neal McCoy-090401-N-5471P-004 (cropped).jpg\n| caption         = Neal McCoy performing at Needham Theater at [[Port Hueneme, California]], 2009\n| image_size      = \n| birth_name      = Hubert Neal McGaughey Jr.\n| alt = Singer Neal McCoy at the edge of a stage, holding his arms out.\n| alias           = Neal McCoy<!--Not a typo; he did record as \"Neal McGoy\" with a G early in his career-->\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1958|07|30}}<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1720|pure_url=yes}} |title=Neal McCoy Biography |access-date=2007-12-23 |last=Huey |first=Steve |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>\n| birth_place     = [[Jacksonville, Texas]], U.S.\n| origin          = [[Longview, Texas]], U.S.\n| instrument      = Vocals\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer\n| years_active    = 1988\u2013present\n| label           = {{hlist|[[16th Avenue Records|16th Avenue]]|[[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]|[[Giant Records (Warner)|Giant]]|[[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]]|SEA|903|Tate|Blaster|[[Slate Creek Records|Slate Creek]]}}\n| website         = {{URL|http://www.nealmccoy.com}}\n}}\n'''Hubert Neal McGaughey Jr.''' (born July 30, 1958), known professionally as '''Neal McCoy''' and previously as '''Neal McGoy''', is an American country music singer. He has released 10 studio albums on various labels, and has released 34 singles to country radio. Although he first charted on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart in 1988, he did not reach the top 40 for the first time until 1992's \"Where Forever Begins\", which peaked at number 40. McCoy broke through two years later with the back-to-back number one singles \"[[No Doubt About It (Neal McCoy song)|No Doubt About It]]\" and \"[[Wink (song)|Wink]]\" from his platinum-certified album ''[[No Doubt About It (album)|No Doubt About It]]''. Although he has not topped the country charts since, his commercial success continued into the mid to late 1990s with two more platinum albums and a gold album, as well as six more top 10 hits. A ninth top 10 hit, the number 10 \"[[Billy's Got His Beer Goggles On]]\", came in 2005 from his self-released ''[[That's Life (Neal McCoy album)|That's Life]]''.\n\n==Early life==\nHubert Neal McGaughey Jr. was born on July 30, 1958, in [[Jacksonville, Texas]], to a Filipino-American mother and Irish-American father. Inspired by the variety of music that his parents listened to, which included [[Country music|country]], [[rock music|rock]], [[disco]] and [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]], McGaughey first sang in his church choir before founding an R&B band.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> He later switched his focus to country music, performing in various bars and clubs in Texas. McGaughey, after attending [[junior college]] near his hometown, found work selling shoes at a shopping mall. In the early 1980s, he met his wife, Melinda, at the store.\n\nAfter winning a 1981 talent contest hosted by [[Janie Fricke]], he secured a spot as an opening act for [[Charley Pride]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\n==Musical career==\nCrediting himself as Neal McGoy, a phonetic spelling of his surname,<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> he signed to the independent [[16th Avenue Records]] label in 1988. He released the singles \"That's How Much I Love You\" and \"That's American\", and although the former reached No.&nbsp;85 on the country charts,<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc.|date=August 2008|page=266|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref> he did not release an album for the label. He continued to tour as an opening act for Pride until 1990,<ref name=\"weekly\"/> the same year that the 16th Avenue label closed.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Price|first=Deborah Evans|date=December 7, 1996|title=Gaylord buys Word's music companies|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|pages=6, 90|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uAkEAAAAMBAJ&q=%2216th+Avenue+Records%22+%221990%22&pg=PA90}}</ref>\n\n===1990\u20132000: Atlantic Records===\nHe then signed to [[Atlantic Records]] in 1990, changing his surname to McCoy per the label's request, as fans had already begun to refer to him as McCoy. His debut album, ''[[At This Moment (album)|At This Moment]]'', was released that year. None of the three singles made the country Top 40, although the lead-off single \"If I Built You a Fire\" was a Top 20 country hit in Canada. The other two releases were the [[At This Moment|title track]], a cover of [[Billy Vera]] and the Beaters' #1 Hot 100 hit from late 1986-early 1987,<ref name=\"encyclopedia\">{{cite book|editor1=Paul Kingsbury |editor2=Michael McCall |editor3=John W. Rumble |title=The Encyclopedia of Country Music|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tLZz02EzmBYC&q=%22neal+mccoy%22+%22at+this+moment%22&pg=PT1320|year=2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=0199920834|isbn=9780199920839 }}</ref> and \"[[This Time I've Hurt Her More Than She Loves Me]]\", which was co-written by [[Earl Thomas Conley]] and originally recorded by [[Conway Twitty]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Peppiatt|first=Francesca|title=Country Music's Most Wanted|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=huXRARoi8vcC&q=%22neal+mccoy%22+%22at+this+moment%22&pg=PA7|year=2004|publisher=Brassey's|isbn=1-57488-593-6|page=7}}</ref> McCoy continued touring and developed a \"reputation for exciting, freewheeling live shows.\"<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nA second album for Atlantic, ''[[Where Forever Begins (Neal McCoy album)|Where Forever Begins]]'', followed in 1992. This album produced his first American Top 40 country hit in its No.&nbsp;40-peaking title track,<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> followed by \"There Ain't Nothin' I Don't Like About You\" at No.&nbsp;57, and \"Now I Pray for Rain\" at No.&nbsp;26. The album was also his first entry on [[Top Country Albums]], at No.&nbsp;58.\n\nWorking with producer [[Barry Beckett]] for the first time, McCoy released his breakthrough album, ''[[No Doubt About It (album)|No Doubt About It]]'', in 1994. The album produced his only number 1 country hits in its title track and \"[[Wink (song)|Wink]]\", both of which also made minor entries on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. The album also earned a platinum certification from the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA) and gold certification from the [[Canadian Recording Industry Association]] (CRIA). Its final single was \"[[The City Put the Country Back in Me]]\" at No.&nbsp;5.\n\n===Mid-Late 1990s===\n[[File:US Navy 050921-N-9274T-015 Three-time platinum album country music singer Neal McCoy performs at a USO concert for military personnel supporting Hurricane Katrina relief efforts.jpg|McCoy in 2005.|alt=Singer Neal McCoy singing into a microphone while looking upward.|200px|thumb|left]]\n''[[You Gotta Love That]]'', his fourth album, also received a platinum certification and it produced four singles: \"[[For a Change]]\", \"They're Playin' Our Song\" and the [[You Gotta Love That (song)|title track]] (respectively the first, second, and fourth singles) all peaked at No.&nbsp;3, while \"[[If I Was a Drinkin' Man]]\" reached No.&nbsp;16.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/>\n\nMcCoy's [[Neal McCoy (album)|self-titled]] fifth studio album began a decline in his chart momentum. Although it was certified gold, ''Neal McCoy'' accounted for only one Top Ten hit in a cover of [[The Casinos]]' 1967 [[doo-wop]] single \"[[Then You Can Tell Me Goodbye]]\".<ref name=\"encyclopedia\"/> The next two singles \u2014 \"Going, Going, Gone\" and \"That Woman of Mine\" \u2014 both peaked at No.&nbsp;35. Also in 1996, he sang guest vocals on the multi-artist charity single \"Hope\", the proceeds of which went to the [[Tony Martell|T. J. Martell Foundation]]'s cancer research.<ref>Whitburn, p. 193</ref> After \"That Woman of Mine\", he reached No.&nbsp;5 with \"[[The Shake (Neal McCoy song)|The Shake]]\", the only new song on his first ''[[Greatest Hits (Neal McCoy album)|Greatest Hits]]'' package, which reprised nine of his greatest hits to that point and also earned platinum certification.\n\n''[[Be Good at It]]'', his sixth studio release, followed in 1998. This was his first album since ''Where Forever Begins'' not to include a Top Ten hit. The title track, \"If You Can't Be Good, Be Good at It\", was the highest-peaking single release from it at No.&nbsp;22, followed by \"Party On\", which became his first single since 1992 to miss Top 40 entirely.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> After it came the No.&nbsp;29 \"Love Happens Like That.\" McCoy made a second appearance on a multi-artist charity single that same year, as one of several collaborators on \"One Heart at a Time\", a song written by [[Victoria Shaw (singer)|Victoria Shaw]] to benefit [[cystic fibrosis]] research.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bernarde|first=Scott R.|title=Stars of David: Rock'n'roll's Jewish Stories|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XI4-VnSrEcAC&q=%22one+heart+at+a+time%22+%22olivia+newton+john%22&pg=PA329|year=2003|publisher=UPNE|isbn=1584653035|page=329}}</ref>\n\nIn 1999, McCoy released his final album for Atlantic, ''[[The Life of the Party (album)|The Life of the Party]]''.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> It only accounted for two singles: the [[Phil Vassar]] co-write \"I Was\" at No.&nbsp;37 and \"The Girls of Summer\" at No.&nbsp;42. He, [[Tracy Byrd]], and [[T. Graham Brown]] also sang guest vocals on \"Now That's Awesome\", a song featuring snippets of a [[Bill Engvall]] comedy sketch, found on Engvall's ''[[Now That's Awesome]]'' album. This single peaked at No.&nbsp;59.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> McCoy has performed every July since 1994 at The Hodag Country Festival in Rhinelander,Wisconsin.\n\n===2000\u201304: Warner Bros. Records and SEA Records===\nDue to the closure of Atlantic Records' Nashville division in mid-2000, McCoy's next album, ''[[24-7-365 (Neal McCoy album)|24-7-365]]'', was issued via [[Giant Records (Warner)|Giant Records]]. It included the singles \"Forever Works for Me (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday)\", \"Every Man for Himself\", and \"Beatin' It In\", at No.&nbsp;38, No.&nbsp;37, and No.&nbsp;41 respectively. In late 2000, he released a Christmas medley consisting of \"[[I'll Be Home for Christmas]]\" and \"[[Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas]]\", which reached number 74 based on seasonal airplay.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> After Giant closed as well, he moved again to [[Warner Bros. Records]], where he recorded ''The Luckiest Man in the World''. Although the title track entered the country charts and peaked at number 46,<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> the album itself was not released, and McCoy exited Warner Bros. by the end of the year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/articles/1483906/20031229/mccoy_neal.jhtml?headlines=true |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040116153627/http://www.cmt.com/news/articles/1483906/20031229/mccoy_neal.jhtml?headlines=true |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 16, 2004 |title=It's a Neal McCoy/Wayne Newton New Year |access-date=2009-11-23 |work=CMT.com}}</ref> He signed with an independent label called SEA Records in 2004, and was slated to release a single for it in the middle of the year,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1486806/new-deal-for-mccoy-no-deal-for-pinmonkey.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927134230/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1486806/new-deal-for-mccoy-no-deal-for-pinmonkey.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=September 27, 2013|title=New Deal for McCoy, No Deal for Pinmonkey|publisher=4 May 2004|pages=[[Country Music Television]]|access-date=22 September 2013}}</ref> but he left the label without releasing anything.<ref name=\"goggles\">{{cite magazine|last=Stark|first=Phyllis|title=McCoy finds new 'life' on his own label|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|volume=117|issue=35|page=50|date=27 August 2005|issn=0006-2510|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-BIEAAAAMBAJ&q=%22billy%27s+got+his+beer+goggles+on%22&pg=PA50}}</ref>\n\n===2005\u201307===\nIn 2005, Neal McCoy and his manager Karen Kane founded a label called 903 Music. His first single for his own label was \"[[Billy's Got His Beer Goggles On]]\", which reached the Top 10 on the [[Hot Country Songs]] chart in 2005. The song served as the lead-off to his 2005 album ''[[That's Life (Neal McCoy album)|That's Life]]''. Also included on the album were a cover of Charley Pride's \"[[You're My Jamaica]],\" (Charley Pride also appeared on the tune), and a studio version of \"Hillbilly Rap\", which he had performed in concert since the early 1990s.<ref name=\"goggles\"/> McCoy's next single release, \"The Last of a Dying Breed\", a song preceded by a spoken-word intro from [[United States Army]] general [[Tommy Franks]], peaked at 36.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/>\n\n[[Darryl Worley]] and the [[Drew Davis Band]] were signed to 903 as well. Worley released his 2006 album ''[[Here and Now (Darryl Worley album)|Here and Now]]'' on 903, which produced the top 40 hits \"Nothin' but a Love Thang\" and \"[[I Just Came Back from a War]]\". In May 2007, McCoy announced that the label had filed for bankruptcy and closed its doors.<ref name=\"encyclopedia\"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Brooks |first=Dave |url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/content_display/industry/e3i6aa5bb36869cfa84fd7b70898175ddec |title=Billboard Business &#124; Billboard |website=Billboard.biz |access-date=2020-04-28}}</ref>\n\nIn Summer of 2007, Neal could be seen showing off his comedic chops on local TV commercials in the [[Waco, Texas]] market for Mike Craig Chevrolet Pontiac Buick in [[Marlin, Texas]].  The commercials continued for approximately one year.  In one of them Neal acts like a puppet in the hands of the branch manager of the Mike Craig dealership in [[Hillsboro, Texas]].\n\n===2008\u201313: ''The Very Best of Neal McCoy'', ''XII'', and ''Pride''===\nIn 2008, [[Rhino Records]] issued a compilation album entitled ''The Very Best of Neal McCoy''. This album reprised most of his biggest chart hits to that point, and it included the new recording \"Rednecktified\", which was released as a single but did not chart. Later that same year, he issued another single, \"For the Troops\", which also failed to chart. McCoy released a book titled ''New Mountain to Climb'' in 2011, which coincided with the release of a single of the same name.\n\nIn April 2011, McCoy signed with Blaster Music.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.websterpr.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=532:neal-mccoy-brings-his-multi-platinum-career-to-blaster-records&catid=62:neal-mccoy&Itemid=15 |title=HOME - Kirt Webster |website=Websterpr.com |date=2013-11-22 |access-date=2020-04-28}}</ref> He released his twelfth album, ''[[XII (Neal McCoy album)|XII]]'', for the label on March 6, 2012. [[Blake Shelton]] and [[Miranda Lambert]] co-produced the album with [[Brent Rowan]], and sang backing vocals on its lead-off single \"A-OK\".\n\nA year later, McCoy released ''[[Pride: A Tribute to Charley Pride]]'' via Slate Creek Records, under the production of [[Garth Fundis]]. The album features guest appearances from [[Darius Rucker]], [[Trace Adkins]], and [[Raul Malo]] of [[The Mavericks]]. To promote the album, McCoy and Pride filmed a video for \"[[Kaw-Liga]]\", which was co-written and originally recorded by [[Hank Williams]] before Pride covered it in 1969. \nOn August 25, 2023, McCoy released a new single titled \"Used Car\".<ref name=\"weekly\">{{cite journal|last=Price|first=Deborah Evans|date=30 September 2013|title=Pride: In the Name of Love|journal=[[Country Weekly]]|volume=20|issue=39|pages=40\u201343|issn=1074-3235}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nMcCoy has been married to Melinda since 1980. The two met when McCoy was working at a shoe store in a local mall.<ref name=\"stambler\">{{cite book|last1=Stambler|first1=Irwin|last2=Landon|first2=Grelun|title=Country Music: The Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d18K8QWcEo8C&q=%22neal+mccoy%22+%22melinda%22&pg=PA300|date=July 14, 2000|publisher=MacMillan|isbn=0312264879|pages=300\u2013301}}</ref> The couple have two children, a son and a daughter.<ref name=\"weekly\"/>\n\nMcCoy is also the head of a charity called the East Texas Angel Network, which helps provide money for families of seriously ill children.<ref name=\"texas\">{{cite web|url=http://www.texasmonthly.com/content/entertainer?fullpage=1|title=The Entertainer Neal McCoy wins fans by break-dancing, cracking jokes, and wiggling his behind onstage. He sings too, but that's beside the point.|last=Fields|first=Jamie|date=March 1998|work=[[Texas Monthly]]|access-date=22 September 2013 }}</ref>\n\nMcCoy resides in [[Longview, Texas]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hallmark |first1=Joan |title=Proud of East Texas: Neal McCoy |url=https://www.kltv.com/story/30987995/proud-of-east-texas-neal-mccoy/#:~:text=EAST%20TEXAS%20(KLTV)%20%2D%20Neal,Country%20Music%20Hall%20of%20Fame. |website=KLTV |date=January 17, 2016}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Neal McCoy discography}}\n\n*''[[At This Moment (album)|At This Moment]]'' (1990)\n*''[[Where Forever Begins (Neal McCoy album)|Where Forever Begins]]'' (1992)\n*''[[No Doubt About It (album)|No Doubt About It]]'' (1994)\n*''[[You Gotta Love That!]]'' (1995)\n*''[[Neal McCoy (album)|Neal McCoy]]'' (1996)\n*''[[Be Good at It]]'' (1997)\n*''[[The Life of the Party (album)|The Life of the Party]]'' (1999)\n*''24-7-365'' (2000)\n*''[[That's Life (Neal McCoy album)|That's Life]]'' (2005)\n*''[[XII (Neal McCoy album)|XII]]'' (2012)\n*''[[Pride: A Tribute to Charley Pride]]'' (2013)\n*''You Don't Know Me'' (2016)\n\n===''Billboard'' number-one hits===\n*\"[[No Doubt About It (Neal McCoy song)|No Doubt About It]]\" (2 weeks, 1994)\n*\"[[Wink (song)|Wink]]\" (4 weeks, 1994)\n\n== Awards and nominations ==\n=== Grammy Awards ===\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n|[[39th Grammy Awards|1997]]\n|''Hope: Country Music's Quest for a Cure''\n|[[Grammy Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Ted_Russell_Kamp","to":"Ted Russell Kamp"}],"pages":{"27386414":{"pageid":27386414,"ns":0,"title":"Ted Russell Kamp","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| honorific_prefix =\n| name             = Ted Russell Kamp\n| honorific_suffix =\n| image            =\n| image_upright    =\n| image_size       =\n| landscape        = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank -->\n| alt              =\n| caption          =\n| native_name      =\n| native_name_lang =\n| birth_name       =\n| alias            =\n| birth_date       = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living people supply only the year unless the exact date is already WIDELY published, as per [[WP:DOB]] -->\n| birth_place      =\n| origin           =\n| death_date       = <!-- {{death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date 1st) -->\n| death_place      =\n| genre            = {{Hlist|[[Country rock]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.popmatters.com/142554-ted-russell-kamp-get-back-to-the-land-2496007914.html |title=TED RUSSELL KAMP: GET BACK TO THE LAND |last=Haag |first=Stephen |date=July 18, 2011 |publisher=PopMatters |access-date=2023-01-12 |quote=Don't let Ted Russell Kamp's Zappa-esque cookie duster fool you \u2014 he's no avant-garde prankster. Rather, he's an earnest country-rock/rockin\u2019-country singer-songwriter }}</ref>}}\n| occupation       = Composer<br />Arranger<br />Producer<br />Performer\n| instrument       = Guitar<br />Bass<br />Mandolin<br />Lap Steel Guitar<br />Keyboards\n| years_active     = 1995\u2013present\n| label            = PoMo<br />Kufala<br />[[Dualtone Records|Dualtone]]\n| associated_acts  = [[Shooter Jennings]]\n| website          = {{URL|tedrussellkamp.com}}\n| module           =\n| module2          =\n| module3          = \n}}\n\n'''Ted Russell Kamp''' is an American singer-songwriter. He is the bassist for [[Shooter Jennings]]' backing band. As a solo artist, Kamp has released 11 albums.\n\n==Biography==\nBorn in New York, Kamp grew up in the Northeast U.S. before moving to Seattle where he began his music career. He fronted a trio, Ponticello, which released four albums. During this time, Kamp released his first solo album, ''Dedications'' (1996). Kamp moved to Los Angeles in 2001 and started a new group, Union Pacific. He performed with other bands and worked as a session musician before being hired as the bassist for Shooter Jennings' band, the .357s.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ruhlmann|first=William|title=Artist Biography |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/ted-russell-kamp-mn0000053934/biography|website=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=May 30, 2017}}</ref>\n\nKamp also continued his solo career, with his album Divisadero<ref>{{cite web|title=Album Review: Ted Russell Kamp - Divisadero|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/divisadero-mw0000565354 |website=Allmusic|accessdate=May 30, 2017}}</ref><ref>\n{{cite journal | date=March\u2013April 2007| title=Album Review: Ted Russell Kamp - Divisadero | last = Berick | first = Michael | journal=[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]| volume=1| issue=68 | url=http://nodepression.com/album-review/ted-russell-kamp-divisadero| issn=1088-4971| accessdate=May 30, 2017}}</ref> ranked as #34 on the [[Americana Music Association]]'s 2007 chart.\n\nIn 2011, Kamp released Get Back to the Land,<ref>{{cite web|title=Album Review: Ted Russell Kamp - Get Back to the Land|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/get-back-to-the-land-mw0002092965 |website=Allmusic|accessdate=May 30, 2017}}</ref> which made the top 25 on the Americana Radio Chart and was #1 on the Euro Americana Chart.\n\nIn January 2013, Kamp released Night Owl,<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Music: Ted Russell Kamp - Night Owl|url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/170077-ted-russell-kamp-night-owl/ |magazine=[[PopMatters]]|accessdate=May 30, 2017}}</ref> which made the US Americana Radio Chart (#34) and the Euro Americana Chart (#15).\n\nKamp self-released ''The Low and Lonesome Sound'' in 2015, followed a year later by the acoustic album ''Flying Solo''.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Music: Ted Russell Kamp - The Low and Lonesome Sound|url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/ted-russell-kamp-the-low-and-lonesome-sound/ |magazine=PopMatters|accessdate=May 30, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Bassist Ted Russell Kamp, Flying Solo...|date=8 April 2016 |url=http://bassmusicianmagazine.com/2016/04/flying-solo-featuring-bassist-ted-russell-kamp/ |publisher=[[Bass Musician]]|accessdate=May 30, 2017}}</ref> He joined Ted Wulfers to record the classic song Tulsa Time to help support the Red Cross of Oklahoma. 100% of the proceeds were donated to The Oklahoma Red Cross.\n\nKamp is also an established producer in the music industry.\n\n==Discography==\n===Solo albums===\n* 1996: ''Dedications'' (Poetry Of The Moment [PoMo])\n* 2005: ''Northsouth'' (PoMo)\n* 2005: ''The Ponticello Years'' (Kufala)\n* 2006: ''Nashville Fineline'' (Kufala)\n* 2007: ''Divisadero'' (PoMo)\n* 2008: ''Poor Man's Paradise'' ([[Dualtone Records|Dualtone]] / PoMo)\n* 2010: ''California Country Soul, Vol. 2 : Ballads'' (PoMo)\n* 2011: ''Get Back To The Land'' ([[Dualtone Records|Dualtone]] / PoMo)\n* 2013: ''Night Owl'' (PoMo)\n* 2015: ''The Low and Lonesome Sound'' (self-released via [[CD Baby]])\n* 2016: ''Flying Solo'' [Audio & Video Labs, Inc.)\n* 2019: ''Walkin' Shoes'' (PoMo Records)\n\n===With [[Shooter Jennings]]===\n* 2005: ''[[Put the \"O\" Back in Country]]'' ([[Show Dog-Universal Music|Universal South]])\n* 2006: ''[[Electric Rodeo (Shooter Jennings album)|Electric Rodeo]]'' ([[Show Dog-Universal Music|Universal South]])\n* 2006: ''[[Live at Irving Plaza 4.18.06]]'' ([[Show Dog-Universal Music|Universal South]])\n* 2014: ''Don't Wait Up (For George)'' EP ([[Black Country Rock Media|Black Country Rock]])\n* 2016: ''[[Black Ribbons]]'' ([[Black Country Rock Media|Black Country Rock]])\n* 2016: ''[[Countach (For Giorgio)]]'' ([[Black Country Rock Media|Black Country Rock]])\n\n===As primary artist/song contributor===\n* 2009: various artists - ''A Bob Dylan Tribute: So Happy Just To See You Smile'' (Hanky Panky) - track 15, \"Dignity\"\n* 2010: various artists - ''I Like It Better Here - More Music From Home'' (Hemifr\u00e5n) - track 14, \"You Are My Home\"\n\n===As guest musician===\n* 2007: [[Gina Villalobos]] - ''Miles Away'' (Face West)\n* 2008: [[Waylon Jennings]] and the 357's - ''[[Waylon Forever]]'' ([[Vagrant Records|Vagrant]])\n* 2010: Shy Blakeman - ''Long Distance Man'' (Winding Road)\n* 2014: Calico the Band - ''Rancho California'' (California Country)\n* 2014: Creekwood - '2000 Miles West''\n* 2015: Alice Wallace - ''Memories Music & Pride'' (California Country)\n* 2015: Sam Morrow - ''There is No Map'' (Forty Below / Relativity)\n* 2016: [[Ry Bradley]] - ''You Me and the Music'' (self-released)\n* 2018: Dale Justice - ''Trouble Man'' (Hillbilly Highway)\n* 2021: Chris Armes - ''Ocotillo Rose'' (Yucca Thunder){{ }}\n* 2023: [[Diplo]], [[Sturgill Simpson]], and [[Dove Cameron]] ''Use Me (Brutal Hearts loop)''\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.tedrussellkamp.com/ Official Website]\n* {{AllMusic | id= ted-russell-kamp-mn0000053934 | label= Ted Russell Kamp}}\n* {{discogs artist|696115-Ted-Russell-Kamp|Ted Russell Kamp}}\n* [http://nodepression.com/album-review/ted-russell-kamp-divisadero Ted Russell Kamp - This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Chase_Matthew","to":"Chase Matthew"}],"pages":{"76812984":{"pageid":76812984,"ns":0,"title":"Chase Matthew","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Distinguish|Chase Matthews}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| background        = person\n| name              = \n| image             = \n| image_upright     = \n| image_size        = \n| landscape         = \n| alt               = \n| caption           = \n| birth_name        = Chase Matthew McQuitty\n| alias             = \n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1997|12|20}}<ref>{{cite web |title=Chase Matthew - 24 never felt so good \ud83d\ude4f thank the lord I... |url=https://m.facebook.com/story.php?id=ChaseMatthewMcQuitty&story_fbid=1516239318776182 |publisher=[[Facebook]] |date=December 20, 2021 |access-date=May 19, 2024}}</ref>\n| birth_place       = [[Sevierville, Tennessee]], U.S.<ref>{{cite web |title=Chase Matthew Performs in Kiss 108's Boston Dunkin' Music Lounge |url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?feature=shared&v=PP7hW1dc3fk |website=YouTube | date=23 August 2023 |access-date=May 19, 2024}}</ref>\n| origin            = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| genre             = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation        = Singer-songwriter\n| instrument        = Vocals\n| years_active      = 2019\u2013present\n| label             = Holler Boy, [[Warner Records|Warner Nashville]]\n}}\n'''Chase Matthew McQuitty'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ascap.com/repertory#/ace/search/workID/913719154 |title=CAN'T BUY TIME |website=ASCAP |publisher=American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers |access-date=May 15, 2024}}</ref> (born December 20, 1997) is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. Signed to [[Warner Records]] Nashville, he charted in late 2023 with the single \"[[Love You Again]]\".\n\n==Biography==\nChase Matthew was born in [[Sevierville, Tennessee]], grew up in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] and began recording music in his teenage years while also working as a mechanic.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/chase-matthew-mn0004105421#biography | title=Chase Matthew biography | website=[[AllMusic]] | accessdate=May 3, 2024 | author=Timothy Monger}}</ref> In 2021, [[country rap]] artist [[Upchurch (musician)|Upchurch]] heard some of Matthew's songs online and signed him to his Holler Boy label. Through Holler Boy, Matthew released the single \"County Line\" from the EP of the same name, followed by his debut album ''Born for This'' in 2022.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nIn October 2022, Matthew signed with [[Warner Records]] Nashville.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.billboard.com/pro/chase-matthew-signs-warner-music-nashville/ | title=Chase Matthew Partners With Warner Music Nashville | magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | date=October 13, 2022 | access-date=May 3, 2024}}</ref> The label released the album ''Come Get Your Memory'', consisting of 25 songs, the following June. This was followed by the single \"Love You Again\".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://triblive.com/aande/music/country-singer-chase-matthew-talks-about-dream-come-true-and-his-faith-ahead-of-pittsburgh-show/ | title=Country singer Chase Matthew talks about dreams come true and his faith ahead of Pittsburgh show | website=Trib Live | date=August 16, 2023 | access-date=May 3, 2024}}</ref> On November 10, 2023, he released his second EP ''Hey World Sessions''.\n\nOn February 16, 2024, Matthew released his third EP ''We All Grow Up''.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://musicrow.com/2024/01/chase-matthew-to-remind-us-that-we-all-grow-up |title=Chase Matthew to Remind Us That 'We All Grow Up' |author=Liza Anderson |publisher=Music Row |date=January 19, 2024 |access-date=May 17, 2024}}</ref>\n\nOn June 18, 2024, Matthew released the song \"Saltwater Cinderella\" and announced his fourth EP ''Always Be Mine''. It was released on July 4, 2024. <ref>{{cite web |url=https://ruralradio.com/khyy/abc_news/chase-matthews-ready-with-the-spontaneous-always-be-mine-ep-abcid6193f76e |title=Chase Matthew's Ready with the Spontaneous 'Always Be Mine' EP |author=ABC News Radio |publisher=107.3 the Trail |date=June 18, 2024 |access-date=June 19, 2024}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center\"\n|+List of albums, with selected peak chart positions\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:3em;font-size:90%\"| [[Country Airplay|US Country Airplay]]<br /><ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://bulletins.billboard.com/country/country_update_2024_0906.pdf|title=Billboard Country Update|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=September 6, 2024|access-date=September 7, 2024}}</ref>\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:3em;font-size:90%\"| [[Canada Country|CAN Country]]<br /><ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/canada-country/2024-09-28/|title=Canada Country: Week of September 28, 2024|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=September 24, 2024}}</ref>\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"County Line\"\n| 2021\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|\n* [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]]: Platinum<ref name=\"riaa\">{{cite web | url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&se=chase+matthew#search_section | title=Search results for Chase Matthew | publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]] | access-date=May 3, 2024}}</ref>\n| ''County Line''\n|-\n!
