(U.S. state)]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Bradley_Gaskin","to":"Bradley Gaskin"}],"pages":{"31439270":{"pageid":31439270,"ns":0,"title":"Bradley Gaskin","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country music singer-songwriter}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name         = Bradley Gaskin\n| image        =\n| caption      =\n| image_size   =\n| birth_name   =\n| birth_date   =\n| birth_place  = [[Gadsden, Alabama]], U.S.\n| genre        = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation   = Singer-songwriter\n| instrument   = Vocals\n| years_active = 2011-present\n| label        = [[Sony Music Nashville|Columbia Nashville]]\n[[BNA Records|BNA]]\n[[30A Life Records]]\n}}\n\n'''Bradley Gaskin''' is an American [[country music]] singer-songwriter. He signed with [[Sony Music Nashville|Columbia Nashville]] in 2011 and has released his debut single, \"Mr. Bartender\" after being discovered through a talent contest sponsored by [[John Rich]] of [[Big & Rich]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Amanda Hensel|title=Bradley Gaskin Chats About His Quick Fame, Family and First Single|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/bradley-gaskin-interview-2011/|access-date=2020-06-25|website=Taste of Country|date=3 May 2011 |language=en}}</ref>  At the time, Gaskin had been working for his father hanging sheetrock.  The song entered the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts at number 51 on the chart dated for the week ending April 2, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1660710/sara-evans-keeps-top-album-billy-currington-snags-no-1-song.jhtml#fbid=zqT-IqQ4KNC|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514145146/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1660710/sara-evans-keeps-top-album-billy-currington-snags-no-1-song.jhtml#fbid=zqT-IqQ4KNC|url-status=dead|archive-date=May 14, 2011|title=Sara Evans Keeps Top Album, Billy Currington Snags No. 1 Song|last=Morris|first=Edward|date=26 March 2011|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]|accessdate=8 April 2011}}</ref> He made his [[Grand Ole Opry]] debut on August 20, 2011.\n\n==Discography==\n===Extended plays===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:10em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Bradley Gaskin''\n| \n* Release date: April 10, 2012\n* Label: [[Sony Music Nashville|Columbia Nashville]]\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:14em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"65\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n|- \n| 2011\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Mr. Bartender\"\n| 32\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''Bradley Gaskin''\n|-\n| 2012\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Diamonds Make Babies\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Year\n! style=\"width:14em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2011\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Mr. Bartender\" <small>(acoustic)</small><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/bradley-gaskin/659477/mr-bartender-acoustic.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023220043/http://www.cmt.com/videos/bradley-gaskin/659477/mr-bartender-acoustic.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 23, 2012|title=CMT : Videos : Bradley Gaskin : Mr. Bartender (Acoustic)|publisher=[[Country Music Television]]|accessdate=7 June 2011}}</ref>\n| David Bean\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Mr. Bartender\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/bradley-gaskin/669323/mr-bartender.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726100731/http://www.cmt.com/videos/bradley-gaskin/669323/mr-bartender.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=July 26, 2011|title=CMT : Videos : Bradley Gaskin : Mr. Bartender|publisher=[[Country Music Television]]|accessdate=3 July 2011}}</ref>\n| Ryan Hamblin\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.bradleygaskin.com/ Official website]\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Gaskin, Bradley}}\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Columbia Records artists]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Gadsden, Alabama]]\n[[Category:BNA Records artists]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Alabama]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Alabama]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Eddy_Raven","to":"Eddy Raven"}],"pages":{"1672610":{"pageid":1672610,"ns":0,"title":"Eddy Raven","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country music singer and songwriter (born 1944)}}\n{{good article}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name                = Eddy Raven\n| image               = Eddy Raven.jpg\n| caption             = Raven in 2016\n| image_size          = \n| alt = Country music singer Eddy Raven seated on a stool.\n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          = Edward Garvin Futch<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/eddy-raven-mn0000147306/biography|title=Eddy Raven biography|last=Roland|first=Tom|work=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=2009-05-25}}</ref>\n| birth_date          = {{birth date and age|1944|08|19}}<ref name=\"whitburn\"/>\n| birth_place         = [[Lafayette, Louisiana]], U.S.<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2017|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2017|pages=293\u2013294|isbn=978-0-89820-229-8}}</ref>\n| instrument          = Vocals\n| genre               = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[Cajun music|Cajun]]}}<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n| occupation          = {{hlist|Singer|Songwriter}}\n| years_active        = 1962{{ndash}}2019\n| label               = {{hlist|Cosmos|La Louisianne|[[Monument Records|Monument]]|[[ABC Records|ABC]]/[[Dot Records|Dot]]|Dimension|[[Elektra Records|Elektra]]|[[RCA Records Nashville|RCA Nashville]]|[[Universal Records (1988)|Universal]]|[[Capitol Records|Capitol Nashville]]|[[Intersound Records|Intersound]]|K-Tel|RMG}}\n| website                 = [http://www.eddyraven.com/ EddyRaven.com]\n}}\n\n'''Edward Garvin Futch''' (born August 19, 1944), known professionally as '''Eddy Raven''', is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. Active from 1962 to 2019, Raven has recorded for several record labels, including [[ABC Records|ABC]], Dimension, [[Elektra Records|Elektra]], [[RCA Records|RCA]], [[Universal Records (1988)|Universal]], and [[Capitol Records]]. After multiple albums which yielded few hit songs, his greatest commercial success came between 1984 and 1990, during which time Raven achieved six number-one singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. These were \"[[I Got Mexico]]\", \"[[Shine, Shine, Shine]]\", \"[[I'm Gonna Get You (Billy Swan song)|I'm Gonna Get You]]\", \"[[Joe Knows How to Live]]\", \"[[A Letter to You|In a Letter to You]]\", and \"[[Bayou Boys]]\". Raven has a total of eighteen top-ten hits on that chart. Although his chart success diminished in the 1990s, Raven continued to record throughout the 1990s and into the 21st century. In addition to his own work, he has written singles for [[Don Gibson]], [[Randy Cornor]], [[Jeannie C. Riley]], [[Connie Smith]], and [[The Oak Ridge Boys]] among others. Raven's music is defined by mainstream country, [[country pop]], [[Cajun music]], and [[reggae]], and he wrote a large number of his singles by himself or with [[Frank J. Myers]].\n\n==Biography==\nEdward Garvin Futch was born in [[Lafayette, Louisiana]], on August 19, 1944.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/><ref name=\"Larkin2006\"/> He is the oldest of ten children, and his father worked as a truck driver.<ref name=\"pennies\">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/112678145/ | title=Eddy Raven to perform at 'Pennies' | work=[[The Tennessean]] | date=December 15, 1982 | access-date=April 23, 2019 | author=Sandy Neese | pages=45}}{{subscription required}}</ref> Futch had originally considered a professional career in baseball, but chose not to after breaking his ankle.<ref name=\"gladys\">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/229175341/ | title=Has the country boy caught up with the dream? | work=Daily World | date=January 18, 1981 | access-date=December 28, 2019 | author=Gladys L. deVillier | pages=C1}}{{Subscription required}}</ref> Growing up, he cited [[Cajun music]] as a musical influence, along with the [[country music]] sounds from popular radio broadcasts such as the ''[[Louisiana Hayride]]'', [[New Orleans blues]], and the new sounds of [[rock and roll]]. Futch first played in a band at age thirteen.<ref name=\"Larkin2006\">{{cite encyclopedia |title=Eddy Raven |chapter=Raven Eddy |encyclopedia=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music]] |year=2006 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |editor-last=Larkin |editor-first=Colin |edition=4 |isbn=9780195313734 |url=https://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780195313734.001.0001/acref-9780195313734-e-23066 |access-date=10 December 2019}}</ref> He later went to work for a radio station in [[Georgia (US state)|Georgia]] when his family moved there, and in 1962 he self-released the single \"Once a Fool\".<ref name=\"Larkin2006\"/> The single was credited to \"Eddy Raven\" due to a printing error, but he chose to keep that as his stage name.<ref name=\"sooner\">{{cite journal | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Gavin-Report/90/90/Gavin-1990-02-16.pdf | title=Sooner or later: Eddy Raven's story | author=Cyndi Hoelzle | journal=Gavin Report | pages=49 | date=February 16, 1990}}</ref> When his family moved back to Louisiana, Raven worked at a recording studio called La Louisianne Records and its outlet The Music Mart, where he recorded and released his first album, ''That Cajun Country Sound.''<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\n==Musical career==\n===Beginnings===\nRaven's first record was heard by fellow Cajun country musician [[Jimmy C. Newman]], who helped him sign a publishing contract with [[Acuff-Rose Music]]. Both Newman and Raven's father then encouraged him to move to [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref name=\"use\"/><ref name=\"sooner\"/> There, he wrote singles for various country music artists including [[Don Gibson]], [[Connie Smith]], [[Jeannie C. Riley]], and [[Randy Cornor]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Raven began recording for [[ABC Records]] in 1974 after Acuff-Rose songwriter and producer [[Don Gant]] became head of [[artists and repertoire]] (A&R) for that label.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> His first charted single on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart, his own composition \"The Last of the Sunshine Cowboys\", came in 1974 on ABC. Raven charted seven more singles for the label between then and 1975, the most successful being \"Good News, Bad News\", which achieved a peak of number 27 there.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> ABC also issued one album, ''This Is Eddy Raven'', in early 1976.<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Record-World/70s/76/RW-1976-02-28.pdf | title=ABC releases three | journal=Record World | pages=71 | date=February 28, 1976}}</ref> The album, also produced by Gant,<ref name=\"called\">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/112213012/ | title=Songwriter singing his own hits | work=The Tennessean | date=August 16, 1981 | access-date=April 23, 2019 | pages=63}}{{subscription required}}</ref> was reviewed favorably by ''[[Cash Box]]'' magazine. This review stated that his \"natural musical ability, coupled with the emotional levels of his voice, captures the full flavor of each selection on this appealing album.\"<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Cash-Box/70s/1976/Cash-Box-1976-03-20.pdf | title=Reviews | journal=Cash Box | pages=43 | date=March 20, 1976}}</ref>\n\nRaven left ABC in 1976 when Gant also departed the label.<ref name=\"pennies\"/> He signed with [[Monument Records]] in 1978 and two singles for them: \"You're a Dancer\" was a minor entry on Hot Country Songs,<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> but \"Colinda\" did not chart and Monument closed its country division soon afterward.<ref name=\"robert\">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/112959071/ | title=Cajun Raven flies high with bayou sounds | work=The Tennessean | date=March 5, 1988 | access-date=April 23, 2019 | author=Robert K. Oermann | pages=D1}}{{subscription required}}</ref> After leaving Monument, Raven was encouraged by singer [[Bob Luman]] to travel to [[Texas]] and draw inspiration from that state's music scene.<ref name=\"pennies\"/> This resulted in his 1980 album ''[[Eyes (Eddy Raven album)|Eyes]]'' on Dimension Records, an independent label founded by his then-manager.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/283071544/ | title=Cajun adds his outlook to country | work=[[The Jackson Sun]] | date=January 1, 1982 | access-date=April 23, 2019 | pages=18}}{{subscription required}}</ref> [[Ray Pennington]] produced the album, with assistance from Don Gant's brother Ronnie Gant on three tracks, and Raven wrote or co-wrote every song on it.<ref>{{Cite AV media notes |title=Eyes |others=Eddy Raven |year=1980 |type=LP jacket |publisher=Dimension Records |id=5001}}</ref> The album charted five singles on Hot Country Songs: \"Sweet Mother Texas\", \"Dealin' with the Devil\", \"You've Got Those Eyes\", \"Another Texas Song\", and \"Peace of Mind\". The last of these was the most successful of the five, reaching number 23 in 1981.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> \"Dealin' with the Devil\" was also one of the first country music songs to be promoted via [[music video]];<ref name=\"robert\"/> specifically, Dimension Records shipped videocassettes of Raven performing the song to 54 stations that were surveyed by ''Billboard'' at the time.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/80s/1980/BB-1980-04-19.pdf | title=Vidtape promo success | magazine=Billboard | page=78 |date=April 19, 1980}}</ref> ''[[Record World]]'' published positive reviews of the singles \"Another Texas Song\" and \"Peace of Mind\", calling the former a \"plucky, self-penned tune that displays more of his writer-artist talents\",<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Record-World/80s/80/RW-1980-09-06.pdf | title=Country Single Picks | journal=Record World | page=48 |date=September 6, 1980}}</ref> while calling him \"one of the smoothest country singers around\" in a review of the latter.<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Record-World/80s/81/RW-1981-01-10.pdf | title=Country single picks | journal=Record World |page=50 | date=January 10, 1981}}</ref>\n\nIn 1981, record producer [[Jimmy Bowen]] heard \"Dealin' with the Devil\" and helped Raven sign to [[Elektra Records]]. According to Raven, Bowen was the first record producer he encountered who was willing to let him record \"my music, not what the record company wanted me to cut.\"<ref name=\"pennies\"/> His only Elektra album, ''[[Desperate Dreams]]'', came out late that year. The album accounted for four chart singles on Hot Country Songs between 1981 and 1982: \"[[I Should've Called]]\", \"[[Who Do You Know in California]]\", \"[[A Little Bit Crazy]]\", and \"[[She's Playing Hard to Forget]]\", the last of which became his first top ten hit there. Raven wrote the first three by himself.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> At the time of the album's release, Raven said that many of his songs were inspired by situations that he had encountered while touring. Specifically, he stated that \"Who Do You Know in California\" was inspired by an extramarital affair he had heard of in [[Dallas, Texas]], but changed to being set in [[California]] because the latter fit the song's meter better. A concert review in ''[[The Arizona Republic]]'' noted of Raven's style at the time that his style had potential for pop crossovers, while also stating that the song showed his lyrical skill by not resolving its central theme.<ref name=\"republic\">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/121262933 | title=Eddy Raven is durable in any mode | work=[[The Arizona Republic]] | date=April 27, 1982 | access-date=April 23, 2019 | pages=D5}}{{subscription required}}</ref> ''Record World'' wrote of the album that Raven's \"commercial potential has not yet been reached\", while praising the vocal delivery on the singles.<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Record-World/80s/81/RW-1981-10-10.pdf | title=Country album picks | journal=Record World | pages=55 | date=October 10, 1981}}</ref> Tom Roland of ''[[Allmusic]]'' thought that the album had more creative control from Raven than its predecessors did.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/desperate-dreams-mw0000857038 | title=''Desperate Dreams'' | work=Allmusic | access-date=April 23, 2019 | author=Tom Roland}}</ref> At the end of his contract with Elektra, Raven had a second album recorded but never released,<ref name=\"virgin\">{{cite book | title=The Virgin Encyclopedia of Country Music | publisher=Virgin Books | author=Colin Larkin | year=1998 | pages=349 | isbn=0-7535-0236-4}}</ref> although it did have one charted single in \"San Antonio Nights\".<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Once his contract ended, Raven chose to undergo a brief recording hiatus in order to determine the viability of his career. During this hiatus, he disassociated himself from his existing producers and managers and began writing songs with [[Frank J. Myers]], a songwriter who was also the guitarist and bandleader of his road band. After having success on the songwriting front, which included the title track of [[Tanya Tucker]]'s late-1982 album ''[[Changes (Tanya Tucker album)|Changes]]'', Raven was inspired to resume recording in 1984.<ref name=\"robert\"/>\n\n===1984-88: RCA Records===\n[[File:Frank Myers 190306-D-SW162-1180 (47257966602).jpg|200px|thumb|right|[[Frank J. Myers]] co-wrote several of Raven's singles, and formerly played guitar in his road band.|alt=Musician Frank J. Myers, playing an acoustic guitar and singing into a microphone.]]\nRaven moved to [[RCA Records Nashville]] in 1984 at the end of his self-imposed hiatus. His first single for the label was \"[[I Got Mexico]]\", which also became his first number-one single on Hot Country Songs that year.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Also co-written by Myers,<ref name=\"mixed\"/> it was the first single from his RCA debut ''[[I Could Use Another You]]''.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Raven produced the album with [[Paul Worley]], who was then known mainly as a session guitarist but would become increasingly known as a producer throughout the 1980s and 1990s.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MiQEAAAAMBAJ | title=New looks from old faces | magazine=Billboard | pages=WOCM10 | date=October 13, 1984}}</ref> Also released as singles from the album were the [[I Could Use Another You (song)|title track]] and \"[[She's Gonna Win Your Heart]]\", which both placed within the top ten of Hot Country Songs.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> ''Cash Box'' described the title track as \"an upbeat tune stressing Raven\u2019s clear, distinct vocals.\"<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Cash-Box/80s/1984/CB-1984-06-30.pdf | title=Singles reviews | journal=Cash Box | pages=19 | date=June 30, 1984}}</ref> Writing for ''Stereo Review'' magazine (now known as ''[[Sound & Vision (magazine)|Sound & Vision]]''), [[Alanna Nash]] noted that while it had fewer songs written by Raven and a \"slightly more mainstream\" sound than its predecessors, the album was \"well up to his own high standards\"; she also considered Raven's singing more upbeat and confident than on previous efforts.<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-HiFI-Stereo/80s/HiFi-Stereo-Review-1984-10.pdf | title=Popular music | journal=Stereo Review | date=October 1984 | pages=102\u2013103}}</ref>\n\nHis next RCA album was 1985's ''[[Love and Other Hard Times]]'', which he co-produced with Worley.<ref name=\"bb love\"/> It accounted for three top-ten singles on the country music charts: \"[[Operator, Operator]]\" (previously a single for co-writer [[Larry Willoughby]] in 1983<ref>Whitburn, p. 401</ref>), followed by \"[[I Wanna Hear It from You]]\" and \"[[You Should Have Been Gone by Now]]\".<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Raven co-wrote six of the songs on the album. In the process of recording, he and Worley chose to incorporate a more acoustic influence on some tracks, and thus chose [[Mark O'Connor]] to play fiddle and mandolin.<ref name=\"roots\"/> ''Cash Box'' reviewed the album positively, stating that it was \"another exhibition of his fine vocal range and his valuable songwriting ability.\"<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Cash-Box/80s/1985/CB-1985-06-29.pdf | title=Country album reviews | journal=Cash Box | pages=32 | date=June 29, 1985}}</ref> ''Billboard'' also published a positive review of the album, which said that his \"haunting and sincere voice is matched here by some of the best material he's recorded in recent years.\"<ref name=\"bb love\">{{cite magazine | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/80s/1985/BB-1985-06-29.pdf | title=Reviews | magazine=Billboard | pages=66 | date=June 29, 1985}}</ref> In 1985, Raven was nominated for the Horizon Award (now known as the Best New Artist award) from the [[Country Music Association]].<ref name=\"roots\">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/113518238/ | title=Eddy Raven's cajun roots run deep | work=The Tennessean | date=October 5, 1985 | access-date=April 23, 2019 | pages=D1}}{{subscription required}}</ref>\n\n''[[Right Hand Man (album)|Right Hand Man]]'', released in late 1986 on RCA, accounted for four more singles: \"[[Sometimes a Lady]]\", \"[[Right Hand Man (Eddy Raven song)|Right Hand Man]]\", and \"[[You're Never Too Old for Young Love]]\" all achieved peaks of number three on the country music charts, while the final single \"[[Shine, Shine, Shine]]\" became his second number-one single.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Don Gant returned to production duties except for \"Sometimes a Lady\", which Raven and Worley produced; the album would also be Gant's last production credit, as he died in March 1987.<ref name=\"mixed\"/> In addition to Raven and Myers, other writers on the album included [[Gary Burr]] and Gary Scruggs, brother of bluegrass singer [[Randy Scruggs]].<ref name=\"mixed\">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/112362862/ | title=From country to Cajun, his fans are mixed bag | work=The Tennessean | date=April 25, 1987 | access-date=April 23, 2019 | author=Thomas Goldsmith | pages=D1}}{{subscription required}}</ref> Nash wrote in ''Stereo Review'' that the album seemed to focus more on Raven's singing over his songwriting, noting that the album had more of a [[country pop]] sound than its predecessors.<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-HiFI-Stereo/80s/HiFi-Stereo-Review-1987-04.pdf | title=Popular music | date=April 1987 |journal=Stereo Review | pages=104, 106}}</ref>\n\nRaven's tenure with RCA ended with a compilation album titled ''[[The Best of Eddy Raven]]'' in 1988. In addition to most of his RCA singles, it included three new songs that were all sent out as singles. The first two were \"[[I'm Gonna Get You (Billy Swan song)|I'm Gonna Get You]]\" (written by [[Dennis Linde]]) and \"[[Joe Knows How to Live]]\", which both ascended to the top of the Hot Country Songs charts that year.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Both had originally been cut by other artists in 1987: \"I'm Gonna Get You\" by [[Billy Swan]],<ref>Whitburn, p. 353</ref> and \"Joe Knows How to Live\" by the [[Nitty Gritty Dirt Band]] on their album ''[[Hold On (Nitty Gritty Dirt Band album)|Hold On]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/hold-on-mw0000191120 | title=''Hold On'' | work=AllMusic | access-date=February 11, 2020}}</ref> The final single from ''The Best of Eddy Raven'' was \"[['Til You Cry]]\", which peaked at number four.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> All of these were produced by session keyboardist and record producer [[Barry Beckett]], who had contacted Raven and expressed interest in producing for him. While Beckett had played on some of Raven's previous albums, Raven said that he was unaware of Beckett's roles as a producer at the time, and agreed to the offer after discovering that Beckett had been a producer on several recordings of which he was a fan.<ref name=\"sooner\"/> In advance of the album's release, Raven toured the southern United States with then-labelmates [[Alabama (band)|Alabama]].<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/80s/1988/BB-1988-02-20.pdf | title=Nashville Scene | author=Gerry Wood | magazine=Billboard | pages=38 | date=February 20, 1988}}</ref>\n\n===1988-1991: Universal and Capitol===\nIn 1988, producer Jimmy Bowen founded the independent country music label [[Universal Records (1988)|Universal Records]] and signed Raven. While the editors of ''The Encyclopedia of Country Music'' stated that Raven chose to end his contract with RCA over poor record sales,<ref name=\"encyclopedia\">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=untabCgOVkgC | title=The Encyclopedia of Country Music | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1998 | pages=430| isbn=978-0-19-977055-7 }}</ref> Raven himself said at the time that Bowen had recruited him for the then-new label after determining that his musical style would fit well among the other artists he had signed.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/158491962/ | title=Eddy Raven stands firm against 'pseudo-country' | work=Albuquerque Journal | date=June 20, 1989 | access-date=December 9, 2019 | author=Carroll Cagle | pages=5B}}{{subscription required}}</ref> His initial release for the label was a cover of [[Shakin' Stevens]]' \"[[A Letter to You|In a Letter to You]]\", also written by Dennis Linde.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> The song was the first release from his only Universal album ''[[Temporary Sanity]]'', which came out in 1989. At Bowen's request, Beckett stayed on as Raven's producer.<ref name=\"gumbo\">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/112443423 | title=Eddy Raven and Cajun cousins cook up spicy musical gumbo | work=The Tennessean | date=July 2, 1989 | access-date=April 23, 2019 | author=Thomas Goldsmith | pages=10}}{{subscription required}}</ref> Raven said of the album's sound that he wanted to add influences of [[Latin music (genre)|Latin]] and Caribbean music to his sound, noting in particular the inclusion of [[steel drums]] and comparing \"Zydeco Lady\" to the sound of [[Miami Sound Machine]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/130282200/ | title=Gumbo madness | work=[[The Palm Beach Post]] | date=May 5, 1989 | access-date=April 23, 2019 | author=John Lannert | pages=16}}</ref> \"In a Letter to You\" was the first number-one single for the Universal label, achieving that position on ''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs,<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> along with the country music charts published by ''[[Radio & Records]]'' and ''[[Gavin Report]]''.<ref name=\"gumbo\"/> This was followed by his sixth and final number-one hit, \"[[Bayou Boys]]\", which he wrote with Myers and [[Troy Seals]].<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Universal promoted Raven and all the other acts on its roster through a multi-artist performance hosted by [[Charlie Chase (broadcaster)|Charlie Chase]] at Fan Fair (now [[CMA Music Festival]]) in June 1989.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/113557611/ | title=Milsap, Oaks, Dirt Band among 90 Fan Fair acts | work=The Tennessean | date=May 20, 1989 | access-date=April 23, 2019 | pages=D1}}{{subscription required}}</ref>\n\nIn December 1989, Bowen closed the Universal label to become president of [[Capitol Records]]' Nashville division, to which Raven and several other former Universal artists were transferred.<ref>{{cite journal|date=December 23, 1989|title=TICKERTAPE|journal=[[Cash Box]]|page=2|url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Cash-Box/80s/1989/CB-1989-12-23.pdf}}</ref> Following this transfer, Capitol would issue three more singles from ''Temporary Sanity''. First was \"[[Sooner or Later (The Forester Sisters song)|Sooner or Later]]\", which was co-written by husband-and-wife team [[Bill LaBounty]] and Beckie Foster, and previously cut by [[The Forester Sisters]] on their album ''[[You Again (album)|You Again]]''.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/you-again-mw0000194744 | title=''You Again'' | work=Allmusic | access-date=April 23, 2019}}</ref> Both this song and follow-up \"[[Island (song)|Island]]\" placed within the top ten of Hot Country Songs in 1990, but \"Zydeco Lady\" became his first single since 1979 not to reach top 40 on that chart.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Jason Ankeny of ''Allmusic'' called the album a \"mixed bag\", referring to \"Island\" as a \"moody ballad\" but calling the sound of \"Bayou Boys\" \"hamfisted\".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/temporary-sanity-mw0000653641 | title=''Temporary Sanity'' | work=Allmusic | access-date=April 23, 2019}}</ref> ''Billboard'' published a positive review of \"Sooner or Later\" which described it as a \"pounding, rollicking number\" that \"should propel him back to those same chart heights\".<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/80s/1989/BB-1989-12-16.pdf | title=Reviews | magazine=Billboard | pages=73 |date=December 16, 1989}}</ref>\n\nAnother album for Capitol Nashville, ''[[Right for the Flight]]'', followed in 1991. It accounted for two singles: \"Rock Me in the Rhythm of Your Love\" (co-written by [[Robert Earl Keen]]<ref name=\"whitburn\"/>) and \"Too Much Candy for a Dime\", which were both unsuccessful on the charts.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Also included on the album was \"Cajun Song\", which featured [[Doug Kershaw]] on duet vocals and accordion.<ref>{{Cite AV media notes |title=Right for the Flight |others=Eddy Raven |year=1991 |type=CD booklet |publisher=Capitol Records Nashville |id=594258}}</ref> ''[[The Ottawa Citizen]]'' writer Susan Beyer reviewed the album with favor, noting that it continued to display his Cajun music influences, while considering the latter half of the album \"weightier\" and more upbeat than the first half.<ref name=\"susan\">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/463873018/ | title=Laid Back: Arnold sounds like he's singing from his bed | work=The Ottawa Citizen | date=May 18, 1991 | access-date=November 19, 2019 | author=Susan Beyer | pages=E3}}{{subscription required}}</ref> Following the poor chart performance of the album's singles, Raven was dropped from Capitol's roster in September 1991.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/90s/1991/BB-1991-09-21.pdf | title=Inside track | magazine=Billboard | pages=92 | date=September 21, 1991}}</ref>\n\n===1994-present: Independent===\n[[File:Joelsonnier.jpg|100px|thumb|right|Raven collaborated with [[Jo-El Sonnier]] on the 1996 album ''Cookin' Cajun''.|alt=Cajun musician Jo-El Sonnier singing while playing an accordion.]]\nHis next album, ''Wild Eyed and Crazy'', was released on [[Intersound Records]] in 1994.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> The album included five new tracks, plus re-recordings of eight of his previous singles.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/wild-eyed-and-crazy-mw0000079354 | title=''Wild Eyed and Crazy'' | work=Allmusic | access-date=April 23, 2019}}</ref> The book ''MusicHound Country'' described this album as \"an album of reworked hits that sound pretty much like they did originally, supplemented by new, decidedly lackluster material.\"<ref>{{cite book | url=https://archive.org/details/musichoundcountr0000mans | url-access=registration | title=MusicHound Country: The Essential Album Guide | publisher=Visible Ink | author=Brian Mansfield, Gary Graff | year=1997 | isbn=157859006X}}</ref> This was followed by ''Cookin' Cajun'', a collaboration with fellow Cajun country musician [[Jo-El Sonnier]] which was issued in 1996.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> The album included renditions of Raven's \"I'm Gonna Get You\" and \"Colinda\", along with Sonnier's \"[[Tear Stained Letter]]\" and \"[[No More One More Time]]\". Music critic [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] called it \"a good-natured record that is a lot of fun while it's playing\".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/cookin-cajun-mw0000649039 | title=''Cookin' Cajun'' | work=Allmusic | access-date=May 27, 2019}}</ref>\n\nWhile he continued to record independently, Capitol Records retained the rights to works he had recorded under their tenure. This culminated in the 1997 compilation ''20 Favorites'', consisting of singles, album cuts, and previously-unreleased content.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/20-favorites-mw0000033101 | title=''20 Favorites'' | publisher=Allmusic | access-date=25 May 2019}}</ref> The compilation included two singles: \"Johnny's Got a Pistol\" and \"Somebody's Tearin' the Flag\", the latter of which was previously found on ''Right for the Flight''.<ref name=\"susan\"/><ref name=\"gun\"/> Both of these songs drew minor media attention to Raven, as many radio stations took \"Johnny's Got a Pistol\" out of rotation in the wake of various school shootings, while the television network [[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] refused to air the video for \"Somebody's Tearin' the Flag\" due to concerns that the song did not fit the network's intended programming demographics.<ref name=\"gun\"/> At the time, Raven felt that the songs' failures were due to a preconception that artists of his age were not seen as suitable for mainstream country radio, combined with concerns over political correctness. Despite the lack of radio and television success from the singles, Raven promoted them through performances at an [[American Legion]] convention in [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]] on [[Flag Day (United States)|Flag Day]] (June 14), and as part of Nashville's [[Independence Day (United States)|Independence Day]] (July 4) festivities.<ref name=\"gun\">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/111890908 | title=Flags and guns breed trouble for outspoken Raven | work=The Tennessean | date=July 25, 1998 | access-date=May 25, 2019 | author=Robert K. Oermann | pages=1D, 2D}}{{subscription required}}</ref> Also in 1997, [[The Bellamy Brothers]] featured both Raven and Sonnier on their single \"Catahoula\".<ref>{{cite magazine|date=February 7, 1998|title=Reviews|magazine=Billboard|page=76|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fQ0EAAAAMBAJ&q=%22sons+of+the+desert%22+%22leaving+october%22&pg=PA76}}</ref>\n\nIn 2001, Raven released ''Living in Black & White'' on the independent RMG Records. The album was produced by [[Ron Chancey]], and contributing writers included Frank J, Myers, [[Earl Thomas Conley]], and [[Lonestar]] lead vocalist [[Richie McDonald]]. One of the songs on the album, \"Coldest Fire\", was a song that Raven had begun writing in 1987 at the encouragement of Gant, but found himself unable to finish for a long period following Gant's death that same year.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dhMEAAAAMBAJ | title=Eddy Raven returns 'In Black & White' on RMG Records | magazine=Billboard | pages=37 | date=January 27, 2001}}</ref> One single from the album, \"Cowboys Don't Cry\", charted at number 60 on Hot Country Songs.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Raven has continued to perform throughout the 21st century, including multiple appearances on the [[Grand Ole Opry]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/278368323/ | title=Sweet Loretta graces the Opry stage | work=The Tennessean | page=9F | access-date=May 25, 2019 | date=March 16, 2017}}{{subscription required}}</ref> Raven also co-wrote two songs on [[Toby Keith]]'s 2011 album ''[[Clancy's Tavern]]'',<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/clancys-tavern-mw0002222887 | title=''Clancy's Tavern'' | work=Allmusic | access-date=May 25, 2019}}</ref> and made a cameo appearance at one of Keith's concerts in July 2017.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/322496018 | title=Toby Keith calls the shots | work=The Tennessean | date=July 22, 2017 | access-date=May 25, 2019 | author=Dave Paulson | pages=2A}}{{subscription required}}</ref> In 2018, Raven released a [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] album called ''All Grassed Up'', which features a mix of new songs and re-recordings of existing material, with accompaniment from the bluegrass band Carolina Road.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/all-grassed-up-eddy-raven-with-carolina-road/ | title=All Grassed Up \u2013 Eddy Raven with Carolina Road | work=Bluegrass Today | date=May 7, 2018 | access-date=May 25, 2019 | author=Lee Zimmerman}}</ref>\n\n==Musical styles==\nRaven's musical style is defined largely by his strong influence of [[Cajun music]], along with his lyric-driven songs and distinct vocal delivery. According to Raven, he drew musical influence from his father, who largely listened to country music, but he also drew influence from the prominence of Cajun music in his native Louisiana.<ref name=\"roots\"/> An uncredited 1984 article in ''The Tennessean'' stated that Raven's style at the time was \"characterized by his emotive vocals and musical as well as lyrical hooks.\"<ref name=\"use\">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/111839191 | title=Eddy Raven keeps rolling out hits | work=The Tennessean | date=September 30, 1984 | access-date=April 23, 2019 | pages=55}}{{subscription required}}</ref> Thomas Goldsmith in ''The Encyclopedia of Country Music'' wrote that Raven's style was defined by \"direct, soulful singing, skillful songwriting, and Cajun heritage.\"<ref name=\"encyclopedia\"/> Many of his songs have also displayed influences of [[reggae]] and [[Caribbean music]], such as the reggae-influenced guitar riffs played by session guitarist [[Reggie Young]] on \"I Should've Called\",<ref name=\"roots\"/> and the \"Caribbean sway\" described by Newport News ''Daily Press'' writer Billy Warden in a review of \"Joe Knows How to Live\".<ref name=\"joe\">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/235535483/ | title=Eddy and 'Joe' live it up | work=Daily Press | date=July 22, 1988 | access-date=December 9, 2019 | author=Billy Warden | pages=14}}</ref> Joe Edwards of the ''[[Associated Press]]'' said that Raven \"has a deep, masculine voice that pours out incisive songs in a style he describes as 'Cajun reggae, Cajun Caribbean, electric Cajun.'\"<ref name=\"post\">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/183093547/ | title=Raven's Cajun heritage spices up country music | work=[[Courier-Post]] | date=April 12, 1989 | access-date=April 23, 2019 | author=Joe Edwards | pages=7D}}{{subscription required}}</ref> Similarly, Susan Beyer wrote in a review of ''Right for the Flight'' that \"[h]is voice has a soulful edge, with a nice strip of grit right in the middle\" and said that \"instead of whomping us from the first beats with accordions and Cajun calls, he finds the delicacy in the Cajun legacy.\"<ref name=\"susan\"/>\n\n==Influence on other artists==\nSeveral of Raven's compositions were successful for other artists. Among his early successes as a songwriter were four top-ten hits between 1971 and 1975: \"Country Green\" and \"Touch the Morning\" both by [[Don Gibson]], \"Sometimes I Talk in My Sleep\" by [[Randy Cornor]], and \"[[I Don't Wanna Talk It Over Anymore (song)|I Don't Wanna Talk It Over Anymore]]\" by [[Connie Smith]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.musicvf.com/songs.php?page=artist&artist=Eddy+Raven&tab=songaswriterchartstab | title=Songs written by Eddy Raven | work=MusicVF.com | access-date=23 April 2019}}</ref> Two cuts from ''Eyes'' were later recorded by other artists: [[Merle Haggard]] covered \"Dealin' with the Devil\" on his 1981 live album ''[[Rainbow Stew Live at Anaheim Stadium]]'',<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/mw0000200647 | title=''Rainbow Stew Live at Anaheim Stadium'' | work=Allmusic | access-date=April 23, 2019}}</ref> and [[Waylon Jennings]] covered \"Sweet Mother Texas\" on his 1986 album [[Sweet Mother Texas|of the same name]].<ref name=\"robert\"/> In addition, [[The Oak Ridge Boys]] reached top five on Hot Country Songs in 1982 with Raven's composition \"[[Thank God for Kids]]\". He had written and recorded the song while still on ABC, but the label chose not to release it at the time due to executives considering it unsuitable as a single.<ref name=\"post\"/><ref name=\"pennies\"/> Raven's version of the song later appeared on a 1984 compilation also titled ''Thank God for Kids''; this consisted of singles and other material he had recorded while still on ABC, and was issued by [[MCA Records]] which had acquired ABC in 1979.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/80s/1984/BB-1984-10-13.pdf | title=Greatest Hits Lead Holiday Blitz | author=Edward Morris | magazine=Billboard | pages=53 |date=October 13, 1984}}</ref> Raven later said that the success of The Oak Ridge Boys cut was a factor in his choosing to resume his career after his contract with Elektra ended.<ref name=\"robert\"/>\n\n==Personal life==\nRaven's family lived in the Maurice area, and he graduated from Maurice High School.<ref>Tribute to Eddy Raven, Maurice Today https://mauricetoday.com/tribute-eddie-raven-country-music-singer-songwriter/</ref> Raven has been married twice. His first wife was the former Gayle Breaux,<ref name=\"gladys\"/> whom he married in 1966. The couple had two children: Ryan and Coby,<ref name=\"pennies\"/> the former of whom was the inspiration for the song \"Thank God for Kids\".<ref name=\"post\"/> His second wife is named Sheila, and the two helped launch the RMG label in 2001.<ref>{{cite web | author=Michael Gray | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1443648/eddy-raven-returns-in-black-and-white/ | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190423225851/http://www.cmt.com/news/1443648/eddy-raven-returns-in-black-and-white/ | url-status=dead | archive-date=April 23, 2019 | title=Eddy Raven Returns in 'Black and White' | work=CMT | access-date=April 23, 2019 | date=May 13, 2001}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Eddy Raven discography}}\n\n===Studio albums===\n*''That Cajun Country Sound'' (1973)\n*''This Is Eddy Raven'' (1976)\n*''[[Eyes (Eddy Raven album)|Eyes]]'' (1980)\n*''[[Desperate Dreams]]'' (1981)\n*''[[I Could Use Another You]]'' (1984)\n*''[[Love and Other Hard Times]]'' (1985)\n*''[[Right Hand Man (album)|Right Hand Man]]'' (1986)\n*''[[Temporary Sanity]]'' (1989)\n*''[[Right for the Flight]]'' (1991)\n*''Wild Eyed and Crazy'' (1994)\n*''Cookin' Cajun'' (with [[Jo-El Sonnier]]) (1996)\n*''Living in Black and White'' (2001)\n*''All Grassed Up'' (2018)\n\n===''Billboard'' number-one hits===\n*\"[[I Got Mexico]]\" (1 week, 1984)\n*\"[[Shine, Shine, Shine]]\" (1 week, 1987)\n*\"[[I'm Gonna Get You (Billy Swan song)|I'm Gonna Get You]]\" (1 week, 1988)\n*\"[[Joe Knows How to Live]]\" (1 week, 1988)\n*\"[[A Letter to You|In a Letter to You]]\" (1 week, 1989)\n*\"[[Bayou Boys]]\" (1 week, 1989)\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.eddyraven.com/ EddyRaven.com]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{Eddy Raven}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Raven, Eddy}}\n[[Category:1944 births]]\n[[Category:ABC Records artists]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Cajun musicians]]\n[[Category:Capitol Louisiana]]\n[[Category:University of Louisiana at Lafayette alumni]]\n[[Category:RCA Records Nashville artists]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Louisiana]]\n[[Category:Intersound Records artists]]\n[[Category:Universal Records (1988) artists]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Scott_Joss","to":"Scott Joss"}],"pages":{"35739950":{"pageid":35739950,"ns":0,"title":"Scott Joss","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image           =\n| image_size      =\n| name            = Scott Joss\n| origin          =\n| instrument      = [[Fiddle]], [[mandolin]], guitar\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| birth_date      = 1962, Santa Monica, California, USA\n| years_active    = 1980\u2013present\n| label           =\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = \n}}\n\n'''Scott Joss''' (born 1962) is a songwriter, guitarist, [[Mandolinist|mandolin player]], singer, and [[fiddle]] player primarily in the American [[Country music]] tradition.<ref name=\"JSG\">John 'Scott' Golosio: ''So, what kind of PEOPLE are these musicians?'', http://www.golosio.com/bios.html. Retrieved May 6, 2012.</ref> He has performed with [[Merle Haggard]], [[Dwight Yoakam]], [[Kris Kristofferson]],<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web |last=Lewis |first=Jon |date=February 12, 2020 |title=Longtime Merle Haggard sideman and Redding native Scott Joss to step into the spotlight Sunday |url=https://www.redding.com/story/entertainment/2020/02/12/merle-haggard-sideman-scott-joss-redding-roots-cascade-theatre/4719676002/ |access-date=March 7, 2024 |website=Record Searchlight}}</ref> [[Pete Anderson]], [[Tiny Moore]], [[Roy Nichols]], [[Dusty Wakeman]], [[Chris Gantry]], [[Jana Jae]],<ref name=\"JSG\"/> and as a successful solo artist.<ref name=\"EH\">Erik Hage: ''Review of ''A New Reason to Care'' by Scott Joss'', http://www.allmusic.com/album/a-new-reason-to-care-r490201. Retrieved May 6, 2012.</ref><ref name=\"LDR\">Little Dog Records: ''Scott Joss'', http://www.littledogrecords.com/home/Artists/Scott-Joss.html. Retrieved May 6, 2012.</ref><ref name=\"ANC\">A News Caf\u00e9: ''The Wright Sound: Country\u2019s Scott Joss Plays Pilgrim Church'', http://anewscafe.com/2011/09/06/the-wright-sound-countrys-scott-joss-plays-pilgrim-church/, September 6, 2011.</ref>\n\n==Career==\nBorn in [[Santa Monica, California]] in 1962 and raised in [[Redding, California]], Joss learned to play fiddle from [[Jana Jae]], the one-time wife and fiddle player for [[Buck Owens]] and his [[The Buckaroos|Buckaroos]].  Praised as \"the heir to the [[Bakersfield, California|Bakersfield]] throne\" because of his early association with [[Bakersfield Sound]] musicians,<ref name=\"JPR\">Jana Pendragon: ''Scott Joss \u2013 Biography'', [https://web.archive.org/web/20040730074401/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/joss_scott/bio.jhtml]. Retrieved May 6, 2012.</ref> Joss' playing has been key to hit tunes scored by [[Merle Haggard|Merle Haggard & The Strangers]] and [[Dwight Yoakam]].<ref name=\"LDR\"/> Scott Joss was inducted into the National Fiddler Hall of Fame in 2020.<ref name=\":0\" />\n\n'''<big>Scott Joss</big>'''\n\n==Discography ==\n===Solo===\n* 1996: ''Souvenirs'' (Little Dog) \u2013 Reached #7 on the Americana Music charts <ref>{{Cite web |last=Jaklewicz |first=Greg |date=March 21, 2019 |title=Fiddler Joss helps Kristofferson make it through the night |url=https://www.reporternews.com/story/entertainment/events/2019/03/21/fiddler-joss-helps-kristofferson-make-through-night/3181578002/ |access-date=March 7, 2024 |website=Abilene Reporter News}}</ref>\n* 2000: ''A New Reason to Care'' (Little Dog)\n*2018'': How Far to Jordan''<ref name=\":0\" /> ''(''Miracle Mile Records'') \u2013 Featuring Kris Kristofferson on two songs''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://kriskristoffersonfan.com/scott-joss-how-far-to-jordan/|title=Scott Joss \u2013 How Far to Jordan|date=August 28, 2018|website=Kris Kristofferson by Fans, for Fans|access-date=October 11, 2019}}</ref>\n\n===With Dwight Yoakam===\n* 1988: [[Dwight Yoakam]] \u2013 ''[[Buenas Noches from a Lonely Room]]''  ([[Reprise Records|Reprise]])\n* 1990: Dwight Yoakam \u2013 ''[[If There Was a Way]]'' (Reprise)\n* 1993: Dwight Yoakam \u2013 ''[[This Time (Dwight Yoakam album)|This Time]]'' (Reprise)\n* 1995: Dwight Yoakam \u2013 ''[[Gone (Dwight Yoakam album)|Gone]]'' (Reprise)\n* 1995: Dwight Yoakam \u2013 ''[[Dwight Live]]'' (Reprise)\n* 1997: Dwight Yoakam \u2013 ''[[Under the Covers (Dwight Yoakam album)|Under the Covers]]'' (Reprise)\n* 1997: Dwight Yoakam \u2013 ''[[Come on Christmas]]'' (Reprise)\n* 1998: Dwight Yoakam \u2013 ''[[A Long Way Home (album)|A Long Way Home]]'' (Reprise)\n* 2000: Dwight Yoakam \u2013 ''[[Tomorrow's Sounds Today]]'' (Reprise)\n* 2001: Dwight Yoakam \u2013 ''[[South of Heaven, West of Hell (album)|South of Heaven, West of Hell]]'' (Warner Bros.)\n* 2003: Dwight Yoakam \u2013 ''[[Population Me]]'' (Audium)\n\n===With Merle Haggard===\n* 2003: Merle Haggard \u2013 ''[[Haggard Like Never Before]]'' (Hag Records)\n* 2005: Merle Haggard \u2013 ''[[Chicago Wind]]'' (Capitol)\n* 2007: Merle Haggard \u2013 ''[[The Bluegrass Sessions (Merle Haggard album)|The Bluegrass Sessions]]'' (McCoury Music)\n* 2010: Merle Haggard \u2013 ''[[I Am What I Am (Merle Haggard album)|I Am What I Am]]'' (Vanguard)\n* 2011: Merle Haggard \u2013 ''[[Working in Tennessee]]'' (Vanguard)\n\n== References ==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n* {{Allmusic | id= scott-joss-mn0000837783 | label= Scott Joss}}\n* {{discogs artist|993730-Scott-Joss|Scott Joss}}\n*Scott Joss has a [https://www.facebook.com/groups/899986426862468/ Fan Group on Facebook] \n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Joss, Scott}}\n[[Category:1962 births]]\n[[Category:American country fiddlers]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from California]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:The Strangers (American band) members]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jeff_Carson","to":"Jeff Carson"}],"pages":{"10427789":{"pageid":10427789,"ns":0,"title":"Jeff Carson","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country music artist (1963\u20132022)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2022}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Jeff Carson\n| image            = Jeff carson.jpg\n| caption          = Carson in a promotional picture\n| alt              = Country music singer Jeff Carson, kneeling in front of a rusty door\n| birth_name       = Jeffrey Lee Herndon<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc.|year=2008|pages=81|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref>\n| birth_date       = {{birth date|1963|12|16}}<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p143780/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Jeff Carson biography |accessdate=July 19, 2007 |last=Erlewine |first=Stephen Thomas |authorlink=Stephen Thomas Erlewine |publisher=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref>\n| birth_place      = [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]], U.S.\n| death_date       = {{death date and age|2022|3|26|1963|12|16}}\n| death_place      = [[Franklin, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| origin           = [[Gravette, Arkansas]], U.S.\n| instrument       = Vocals, harmonica, bass guitar\n| genre            = [[country music|Country]]\n| occupation       = Singer\n| years_active     = 1980\u20132012, 2019\u20132022\n| label            = [[Curb Records|Curb]]\n}}\n'''Jeffrey Lee Herndon''' (December 16, 1963 \u2013 March 26, 2022), known professionally as '''Jeff Carson''', was an American [[country music]] artist. Originally a session musician in [[Branson, Missouri]], and later a demo singer, he was signed to [[Curb Records]] in 1995, releasing his self-titled debut album that year, followed by ''Butterfly Kisses'' in 1998 and ''Real Life'' in 2002. He charted 14 singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts, including the Number One hit \"[[Not on Your Love]]\", the Top Ten hits \"[[The Car (song)|The Car]]\" and \"[[Holdin' Onto Something]]\", and the Top 20 \"[[Real Life (I Never Was the Same Again)]]\". He retired from music in 2009 and became a police officer.\n\n==Biography==\nJeffrey Lee Herndon was born in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]], and raised in [[Gravette, Arkansas]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> In his childhood, he played harmonica and guitar and sang in church.<ref name=\"Liebig 2022\">{{cite web | last=Liebig | first=Lorie | title=JUST IN: Jeff Carson, 90s Country Chart-Topper, Dies at 58 | website=Taste of Country | date=March 27, 2022 | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/jeff-carson-dead-dies/ | access-date=March 29, 2022}}</ref> In high school, he and some friends formed a band.<ref name=\"Lambert 2020\">{{cite web | last=Lambert | first=Arden | title=Jeff Carson Showcased The Power of a Father's Love In The Song \"The Car\" | website=Country Thang Daily | date=December 18, 2020 | url=https://www.countrythangdaily.com/the-car-jeff-carson/ | access-date=March 29, 2022}}</ref> They won second place at a local talent show for performing the song \"[[Seven Bridges Road]]\".<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> After graduating, he attended another talent competition held at a park in [[Rogers, Arkansas]].<ref name=\"Lambert 2020\" /> The winner of that competition then asked Carson to play in his band.<ref name=\"Lambert 2020\" /> The band split up after four years.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nCarson later moved on to [[Branson, Missouri]], where he found work playing bass guitar in local bands, in addition to writing songs.<ref name=\"oldies\">{{cite web |url=http://www.oldies.com/artist-view/Jeff-Carson.html |title=Jeff Carson Biography |accessdate=December 28, 2007 |work= Oldies.com}}</ref> While in Branson, he met his then-future wife, who persuaded him to move to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], which he did in 1989.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/><ref name=\"Officer 2022\">{{cite web | title=Country singer-songwriter Jeff Carson, who later became a Tennessee police officer, dies at 58 | website=Law Officer | date=March 27, 2022 | url=https://www.lawofficer.com/country-singer-songwriter-jeff-carson-tennessee-police-officer-dies/ | access-date=March 29, 2022}}</ref> They married in 1989.<ref name=\"memim.com\">{{cite web | title=Jeff Carson | website=memim.com | url=https://memim.com/jeff-carson.html | access-date=March 29, 2022}}</ref> In Nashville, he found work with a band that played at the [[Opryland Hotel]], before convincing the hotel to book him as a solo act.<ref name=\"memim.com\" /><ref name=\"allmusic\"/> He eventually recorded demos for other artists, before he was discovered by record producer Chuck Howard in 1994 and signed to [[Curb Records]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/><ref name=\"oldies\"/><ref name=\"memim.com\" />\n\n==Music career==\n\n===1995\u20131996: ''Jeff Carson''===\nCarson's debut single, \"Yeah Buddy\", was released in early 1995, peaking at number 69 on the U.S. ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] chart. It was followed by \"[[Not on Your Love]]\", which became his only number one later that year.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Both singles were included on his debut album, titled ''[[Jeff Carson (album)|Jeff Carson]]'', which produced two more Top Ten hits in \"[[The Car (song)|The Car]]\" (number 3) and \"[[Holdin' Onto Something]]\" (number 6), the latter of which was previously recorded by [[John Michael Montgomery]]. Between those two singles was a Christmas release called \"Santa Got Lost in Texas\" (number 70), The album's last single was \"That Last Mile\" at number 62.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> In 1996, Carson won the [[Academy of Country Music]]\u2019s Video of the Year for \"The Car\". He also co-wrote the song \"Whoop-De-Do\" on [[Keith Gattis]]' 1996 [[Keith Gattis (album)|self-titled debut]].<ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=Keith Gattis |others=Keith Gattis |year=1996 |type=CD insert |publisher=RCA Records |id=66834}}</ref> ''Jeff Carson'' received a mixed review from ''[[Country Standard Time]]'', whose Larry Stephens said that \"Carson's songs are all good, but nothing sticks or grabs the heart strings.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=1354|title=''Jeff Carson'' review|last=Stephens|first=Larry|work=Country Standard Time|accessdate=November 19, 2012}}</ref>\n\n===1997\u20131999: ''Butterfly Kisses''===\nCarson released his second album in 1997. Entitled ''[[Butterfly Kisses (Jeff Carson album)|Butterfly Kisses]]'', this album produced four singles, none of which reached top 40: \"Do It Again\" at number 55; the album's title track (number 62), which was also a number 1 [[Adult Contemporary (chart)|Adult Contemporary]] hit and minor country hit for [[Bob Carlisle]] as well as a Top 40 pop and country hit for the [[Raybon Brothers]]; \"Here's the Deal\" (number 64); and \"Cheatin' on Her Heart\" (number 52).<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> This album also included an alternative mix of \"Butterfly Kisses\" which combined elements of labelmate [[Kippi Brannon]]'s then-current single \"Daddy's Little Girl\", as well as a duet with [[Merle Haggard]] on a rendition of his hit \"Today I Started Loving You Again\".<ref name=\"oldies\"/>\n\n===1998\u20132002: ''Real Life''===\nHis eleventh single, \"Shine On\", was released in 1998. After it, too, failed to reach Top 40, Carson's third album was repeatedly delayed. \"Scars and All\" did not reach the country charts, but was a number 1 on the PowerSource Christian charts. Following it in 2001 was his first Top 40 country single in five years, \"[[Real Life (I Never Was the Same Again)]]\". It reached number 14 at the end of the year,<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> and was followed by the release of his third studio album, also called ''[[Real Life (Jeff Carson album)|Real Life]]''. In 2002, Carson suffered a broken vertebra in a sledding accident at home. Although he briefly spent some time in a body cast, he was not seriously injured.<ref name=\"home\">{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1452246/20020211/carson_jeff.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930033555/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1452246/20020211/carson_jeff.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 30, 2007 |title=Carson Goes Home |accessdate=July 19, 2007 |publisher=Country Music Television}}</ref> Another single from ''Real Life'', entitled \"Until We Fall Back in Love Again\", peaked at number 47.<ref name=\"Billboard p. 46\">{{cite book | title=Billboard | date=April 6, 2002 | publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc. | issn=0006-2510 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oRAEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA46 | access-date=March 28, 2022 | page=46}}</ref>\n\n===2003\u20132022:  Return to music and police work===\nCarson charted again in 2003 with his cover of the Christian pop hit \"[[I Can Only Imagine (MercyMe song)|I Can Only Imagine]]\", a cut from a multi-artist compilation called ''God Bless the USA 2003''.<ref name=\"Tree 2022\">{{cite web | title=God Bless The USA 2003 \u2013 Best of America Vol 3 | website=Curb | date=March 29, 2022 | url=https://www.curb.com/store/albums/1549/ | access-date=March 29, 2022}}</ref> He also co-wrote the track \"Where Has My Hometown Gone\" on [[Craig Morgan (singer)|Craig Morgan]]'s album ''[[I Love It (album)|I Love It]]'', as well as [[Elbert West]]'s single \"Kimberly Cooper's Eyes\". A duet with [[Lisa Brokop]] entitled \"God Save the World\", released in 2005, also failed to chart. His most recent single, \"When You Said You Loved Me\", was sent to radio in early 2007, as the lead-off single to an upcoming Greatest Hits package. The single failed to chart, however, and his Greatest Hits album was cancelled. In February 2009, he retired from the music business and joined the [[Franklin, Tennessee]], police force as a full-time police officer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1606032/singer-jeff-carson-becomes-police-officer.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228211649/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1606032/singer-jeff-carson-becomes-police-officer.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=February 28, 2009|title=Singer Jeff Carson Becomes Police Officer|date=February 27, 2009|work=CMT|accessdate=March 6, 2009}}</ref>\n\n==Death==\nCarson died from a heart attack at a hospital in Franklin, Tennessee, on March 26, 2022, at the age of 58.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/marcberman1/2022/03/26/country-singer-jeff-carson-dies-at-58/?sh=7eed70fe2250 | title=Country Singer Jeff Carson Dies At 58 | work=Forbes | date=March 26, 2022 | accessdate=March 26, 2022}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n\n====Studio albums====\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Shine On\"<ref name=\"Billboard p. 83\">{{cite book | title=Billboard | date=July 25, 1998 | publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc. | issn=0006-2510 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9gkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA83 | access-date=March 28, 2022 | page=83}}</ref>\n| rowspan=\"2\"| David Abbott\n|-\n| 2001\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Real Life (I Never Was the Same Again)\"\n|-\n| 2020\n! scope=\"row\"| \"God Save The World\"\n|\n|-\n|}\n\n== Awards and nominations ==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n!Year\n!Organization\n!Award\n!Nominee/Work\n!Result\n|-\n|1996\n|[[Academy of Country Music Awards]]\n|Video of the Year\n|\"[[The Car (song)|The Car]]\"\n|{{won}}\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n{{Jeff Carson}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Carson, Jeff}}\n[[Category:1963 births]]\n[[Category:2022 deaths]]\n[[Category:People from Gravette, Arkansas]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Tulsa, Oklahoma]]\n[[Category:American country bass guitarists]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Curb Records artists]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Oklahoma]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Arkansas]]\n[[Category:American country harmonica players]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Oklahoma]]\n[[Category:Guitarists from Oklahoma]]\n[[Category:American male bass guitarists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American bass guitarists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American male musicians]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Deaths from coronary artery disease]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes.
