Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"John_Anderson_(singer)","to":"John Anderson (singer)"}],"pages":{"2428290":{"pageid":2428290,"ns":0,"title":"John Anderson (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country musician (born 1954)}}\n{{other people|John Anderson}}\n{{Distinguish|Jon Anderson}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2023}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name                = John Anderson\n| image               = John_Anderson.jpg\n| caption             = Anderson at the Pike County Fair, 2008\n| birth_name          = John David Anderson<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n| birth_date          = {{birth date and age|1954|12|13}}\n| origin              = [[Apopka, Florida]], U.S.\n| instrument          = Vocals, guitar\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = 1974\u2013present\n| label               = [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]], [[MCA Records|MCA]], [[Capitol Records|Capitol]], [[RCA Records|RCA]], [[BNA Records|BNA]], [[Mercury Records|Mercury]], [[Columbia Records|Columbia]], [[Orpheus Music|Orpheus]], Blu Mountain, Warner Bros./Raybaw, [[Broken Bow Records|Broken Bow]]\n| associated_acts     = [[Waylon Jennings]], [[MuzikMafia]], [[John Rich (musician)|John Rich]], [[Josh Turner]]\n| website             = {{URL|johnanderson.com}}\n}}\n\n'''John David Anderson''' (born December 13, 1954)<ref name=CMT>{{cite web | title=John Anderson bio | url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/anderson_john_1_/bio.jhtml | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040406061724/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/anderson_john_1_/bio.jhtml | url-status=dead | archive-date=April 6, 2004 | publisher=[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] | access-date=May 8, 2009}}</ref> is an American [[country music|country]] singer with a successful career that has lasted more than 40 years. Starting in 1977 with the release of his first single, \"I've Got a Feelin' (Somebody's Been Stealin')\", Anderson has charted more than 40 singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country [[music charts]], including five number ones: \"[[Wild and Blue (song)|Wild and Blue]]\", \"[[Swingin' (John Anderson song)|Swingin']]\", \"[[Black Sheep (John Anderson song)|Black Sheep]]\", \"[[Straight Tequila Night]]\", and \"[[Money in the Bank (John Anderson song)|Money in the Bank]]\". He has also recorded 22 studio albums on several labels. His latest album, ''Years'', was released on April 10, 2020, on the Easy Eye Sound label and was produced by Nashville veteran producer [[David R. Ferguson|David Ferguson]] and [[Dan Auerbach]] of [[The Black Keys]].\n\nAnderson was inducted to the [[Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame]] on October 5, 2014.<ref>[http://www.nashvillesongwritersfoundation.com/2014/nashville-songwriters-hall-of-fame-inducts-john-anderson,-paul-craft,-tom-douglas-and-gretchen-peters-nsai-presents-annual-awards.aspx] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141024070704/http://www.nashvillesongwritersfoundation.com/2014/nashville-songwriters-hall-of-fame-inducts-john-anderson%2C-paul-craft%2C-tom-douglas-and-gretchen-peters-nsai-presents-annual-awards.aspx|date=October 24, 2014}}, nashvillesongwritersfoundation.com, October 6, 2014; accessed January 3, 2015.</ref> He was [[List of Country Music Hall of Fame inductees|elected]] into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|Country Music Hall of Fame]] ten years later in 2024.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://variety.com/2024/music/news/country-music-hall-fame-toby-keith-john-anderson-james-burton-2024-inductees-1235944666/|title=Toby Keith Elected Into Country Music Hall of Fame, in Voting That Wrapped Up Days Before His Death|first1=Chris|last1=Willman|magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=March 18, 2024}}</ref>\n\n==Early career==\nRaised in [[Apopka, Florida]], Anderson's first musical influences were not country artists, but [[rock and roll]] musicians such as [[Jimi Hendrix]] and [[The Rolling Stones]].<ref name=CountryBack>{{cite web | title=John Anderson is Takin' the Country Back... And Who Is Better Qualified | url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1473302/06262003/anderson_john_1_.jhtml | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040505031901/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1473302/06262003/anderson_john_1_.jhtml | url-status=dead | archive-date=May 5, 2004 | publisher=[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] | date=July 29, 1997 | access-date=May 8, 2009}}</ref> He played in a rock band until the age of 15, when he discovered the music of [[George Jones]] and [[Merle Haggard]] and turned to country music.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1503/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=John Anderson biography|last=Huey|first=Steve|work=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=May 18, 2009}}</ref> Anderson moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in 1971, arriving unannounced at his sister's home, and took on odd jobs during the day \u2013 including one as a [[Roof construction|roofer]] at the [[Grand Ole Opry]] House \u2013 while playing in clubs during the evenings.<ref name=Billboard>{{cite web | title=John Anderson bio | url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=john anderson|bio=true}} | publisher=Billboard.com | access-date=May 8, 2009}}</ref>\n\nThe club appearances finally paid off in 1977 when he signed his first recording contract with [[Warner Bros. Records]]. He first hit the [[Hot Country Songs|Billboard Country chart]] in 1977 with the song \"I've Got a Feelin' (Somebody's Been Stealin')\",<ref name=CountryBack/> then broke into the country Top 40 with \"The Girl at the End of the Bar\" the next year. Anderson's decidedly backwoods accent and distinctive vocal timbre helped land him in the forefront of the \"New Traditionalist\" movement with artists like [[Ricky Skaggs]] and [[George Strait]].<ref name=CMT/>\n\nA steady stream of singles through the late 1970s and early 1980s continued to build Anderson's name in the country genre. The song \"[[I'm Just an Old Chunk of Coal (But I'm Gonna Be a Diamond Someday)]]\" from the 1981 album ''[[John Anderson 2]]'' netted Anderson a [[Grammy Award]] nomination for Best Male Country Vocal Performance.<ref>{{cite web | title=John Anderson 2 | url=http://www.johnanderson.com/ja_d_john_anderson_2.html | publisher=johnanderson.com | access-date=May 8, 2009 | url-status=dead | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090401034254/http://www.johnanderson.com/ja_d_john_anderson_2.html | archive-date=April 1, 2009 }}</ref>\n\n==\"Swingin'\" and mainstream success==\n\nThe release of Anderson's fourth album, ''[[Wild & Blue]]'', in 1982 led to his breakthrough to mainstream country when the single \"Swingin'\" hit the airwaves early the next year. Co-written with long-time writing partner, Lionel Delmore, the song broke into the country charts and reached Number One by March, while at the same time crossing over to the Billboard Hot 100, reaching a peak of Number 43.<ref>{{cite news |title=He's as American as swinging on the porch |work=Kingman Daily Miner |page=11 |date=April 8, 1983 |access-date=May 9, 2009 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NlkLAAAAIBAJ&dq=john-anderson%20swingin&pg=5809%2C4208978 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> The single became the biggest selling record in the history of Warner Bros. Records.<ref name=CountryBack/> In the wake of \"Swingin'\", Anderson received five nominations for [[Country Music Association]] awards for the year. He was the winner of the Horizon Award, and the song was named Single of the Year; he also received nominations for Song of the Year, Male Vocalist of the Year, and Album of the Year.<ref name=CMAAwards>{{cite web | title=CMA Awards: John Anderson | url=http://www.cmaawards.com/2008/database/ArtistDetail.aspx?artistId=131 | publisher=cmaawards.com | access-date=May 8, 2009 }}</ref>\n\nAnderson's success with ''Wild & Blue'' carried on through several more albums, but none would match its chart numbers or sales. In 1986, Anderson and Warner Bros. parted ways.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\n==''Seminole Wind'' and later career ==\n\nAfter leaving Warner Bros., Anderson signed with [[MCA Records]] and released two albums under that label, followed by one with [[Capitol Records]] in 1990. Chart success was minimal throughout those years. However, that turned around in 1991 when Anderson joined [[BNA Records]] and, working with legendary country producer [[James Stroud]], released the album ''[[Seminole Wind]]''. Powered by the [[Seminole Wind (song)|title single]], which rose to Number Two, and the Number One single \"[[Straight Tequila Night]]\", the album proved a resurgence for Anderson's career.<ref name=Heartland>{{cite web | title=Heartland | url=http://www.upi.com/Odd_News/2002/12/06/Heartland-UPI-Arts-Entertainment/UPI-87461039161600/ | publisher=UPI.com | date=December 6, 2002 | access-date=May 9, 2009}}</ref> The album has been certified two times [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]], the highest of any of Anderson's albums, and he was nominated for three CMA Awards \u2013 Male Vocalist, Song of the Year and Album of the Year.<ref name=CMAAwards/>\n\nThe success of ''Seminole Wind'' brought a fresh life to Anderson's career, and he released a number of albums that charted well, producing several more singles that pushed to the upper levels of the country charts. The 1993 album ''[[Solid Ground (John Anderson album)|Solid Ground]]'' produced a Number One single, \"[[Money in the Bank (John Anderson song)|Money in the Bank]]\", which turned out to be the most recent chart-topper of Anderson's career. He recorded for BNA through 1996 before leaving the label.<ref name=CMT/> In 1993, Anderson was awarded the [[Academy of Country Music]] Career Achievement award.<ref>{{cite web | title=John Anderson awards | url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/anderson_john_1_/awards.jhtml | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040307074534/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/anderson_john_1_/awards.jhtml | url-status=dead | archive-date=March 7, 2004 | publisher=CMT.com | access-date=May 9, 2009}}</ref>\n\nAnderson has recorded for several labels since his departure from BNA, with moderate chart success.<ref name=Billboard/> An album entitled ''[[Bigger Hands]]'', a return to working with Stroud as producer, was released in June 2009.<ref>{{cite web | title=John Anderson Plans New Album With James Stroud | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1609037/john-anderson-plans-new-album-with-james-stroud.jhtml | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414055201/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1609037/john-anderson-plans-new-album-with-james-stroud.jhtml | url-status=dead | archive-date=April 14, 2009 | work=CMT News | publisher=CMT.com | date=April 10, 2009 | access-date=May 9, 2009}}</ref>\n\nOver his career, Anderson has collaborated with a number of different artists. He worked with [[Waylon Jennings]] on his last ever live album before Jennings's death in 2002, [[Never Say Die: The Final Concert]], where he performed a duet with Jennings on the track Waymore's Blues. He has also worked with [[John Rich (musician)|John Rich]] of [[Big & Rich]] on his 2007 album ''[[Easy Money (album)|Easy Money]]'',<ref name=easymoney>{{cite web | title=Yahoo News | url=http://new.music.yahoo.com/tommy-lee/news/john-anderson-shoots-again-for-charts--19459260 | archive-url=https://archive.today/20130105161014/http://new.music.yahoo.com/tommy-lee/news/john-anderson-shoots-again-for-charts--19459260 | url-status=dead | archive-date=January 5, 2013 | publisher=Yahoo Music | date=April 9, 2007 | access-date=May 9, 2009 }}</ref> and co-wrote Rich's 2009 single \"[[Shuttin' Detroit Down]]\"<ref>{{cite web | title=John Rich: Nation's Financial Crisis Inspired \"Shuttin' Detroit Down\" | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1608315/john-rich-nations-financial-crisis-inspired-shuttin-detroit-down.jhtml | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090405125630/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1608315/john-rich-nations-financial-crisis-inspired-shuttin-detroit-down.jhtml | url-status=dead | archive-date=April 5, 2009 | publisher=CMT.com | date=April 1, 2009 | access-date=May 9, 2009}}</ref> He has been named an honorary member of the [[MuzikMafia]], of which Rich is also a member.<ref>{{cite web | title=MuzikMafia members | url=http://www.muzikmafia.com/artists.php | access-date=May 9, 2009 | archive-date=April 7, 2010 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100407082230/http://www.muzikmafia.com/artists.php | url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nAnderson lives in [[Smithville, Tennessee]], his home for more than 30 years with his wife and two daughters.<ref name=easymoney/>\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|John Anderson discography}}\n\n===''Billboard'' number-one hits===\n*\"[[Wild and Blue]]\" (2 weeks, 1982)\n*\"[[Swingin' (John Anderson song)|Swingin']]\" (1 week, 1983)\n*\"[[Black Sheep (John Anderson song)|Black Sheep]]\" (1 week, 1983)\n*\"[[Straight Tequila Night]]\" (1 week, 1991-1992)\n*\"[[Money in the Bank (John Anderson song)|Money in the Bank]]\" (1 week, 1993)\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n=== Grammy Awards ===\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n|[[24th Grammy Year\n|{{won}}\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{Official website|http://www.johnanderson.com}}\n*{{IMDb name|id=0026946|name=John Anderson}}\n\n{{John Anderson}}\n{{CMA New Artist}}\n{{2020s Country Music Hall of Fame}}\n{{MuzikMafia}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Anderson, John}}\n[[Category:1954 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:People from Apopka, Florida]]\n[[Category:People from Smithville, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:American country guitarists]]\n[[Category:American male guitarists]]\n[[Category:American country Florida]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Tobacco_Rd_Band","to":"Tobacco Rd Band"}],"pages":{"40553788":{"pageid":40553788,"ns":0,"title":"Tobacco Rd Band","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{More citations needed|date=September 2013}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Tobacco Rd Band\n| image           =\n| caption         = From left: Lex Vance, Eric Durrance, Aaron Halford, Joe Markham\n| landscape       = Yes\n| origin          = [[Tallahassee, Florida]], United States\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| years_active    = 2010\u2013present\n| label           = Big Southern Entertainment\n| website         = [http://TobaccoRdBand.com/ TobaccoRdBand.com]\n| current_members = Eric Durrance<br />Ben Castro<br />Dale Shumate<br />Joe Markham\n}}\n\n'''Tobacco Rd Band''' (TRB) is an American musical group that specializes in country-rock. The band, which is based in Tallahassee, Florida, consists of lead singer and songwriter Eric Durrance, lead guitarist Ben Castro, bass player Dale Shumate and drummer Joe Markham.\n\n==History==\nTobacco Rd Band was founded in 2010 by Eric Durrance, who had previously been the lead singer with the acclaimed Christian rock band [[Big Dismal]], which ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' once named one of \"Five Christian Bands on the Rise.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.strummagazine.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=49:eric&catid=34:music |accessdate=2013-09-17 |title=VUGA Enterprises Media Group }}</ref>\n\nAfter Big Dismal broke up, Durrance began performing solo, and was selected to tour with [[Jason Aldean]] and [[Lady Antebellum]] as part of [[Country Music Television]]'s \"CMT on Tour\" in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=Eric Durrance To Open CMT ON TOUR 2008|url=http://www.countryhound.com/Eric-Durrance-To-Open-CMT-ON-TOUR-2008|publisher=Countryhound.com|accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref>  Durrance later formed TRB with his friend, lead guitarist Lex Vance. With its hard-driving sound coupled with Durrance's reputation from his years with Big Dismal, TRB quickly amassed a fan base throughout the South.\n\nIn early 2012, TRB released its debut EP titled \"Where the Girls Are,\" which consisted of six tracks: \"Where the Girls Are,\" \"Jesus & Guns,\" \"All About Me Today,\" \"There's No Such Thing as Goodbye\" and \"Dear Life.\" Shortly thereafter, the band released the single \"That's Country,\" featuring a guest performance by [[Colt Ford]], who also appears in the accompanying music video.<ref>{{cite web|title=615 Spotlight: Tobacco Rd Band Team Up With Colt Ford on 'That's Country'|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/1538509/615-spotlight-tobacco-rd-band-team-up-with-colt-ford-on-thats|publisher=Billboard.com|accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref>\n\nIn the summer of 2013, Durrance became the first artist to sign with Silvercreek Records, a new label in Nashville, which was founded by two Nashville music industry veterans\u2014songwriter Stafond Seago and songwriter, producer and plugger Steve Pope.<ref>{{cite web|title=Silvercreek Records Opens on Music Row|date=13 August 2013 |url=http://www.musicrow.com/2013/08/silvercreek-records-opens-on-music-row/|publisher=Musicrow.com|accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Nashville Business Journal|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/nashville/news/2013/08/13/silvercreek-records-label-launches-on.html|publisher=Bizjournals.com|accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicnewsnashville.com/eric-durrance-and-tobacco-rd-band-sign-with-silvercreek-records|title=Eric Durrance and Tobacco Rd Band Sign with Silvercreek Records|work=Music News Nashville|accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref> However, due to creative differences, Durrance negotiated a severance from Silvercreek and resumed recording under his own independent label, Big Southern Entertainment.\n\nDurrance and Tobacco Rd Band continued writing songs and performing to sell-out crowds, primarily in the South, throughout 2014 and 2015.\n\nIn January 2016, Tobacco Rd Band released their song \"Jesus & Guns\" to country radio stations in response to President [[Barack Obama]]'s executive action on gun control. The pro-[[Second Amendment to the United States Constitution|Second Amendment]] ballad, which advocates the use of guns to protect one's family, had previously appeared on the band's 2012 album \"Where the Girls Are.\"<ref>{{cite web|title=Tobacco Rd Band Releases JESUS & GUNS to Radio|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwmusic/article/Tobacco-Rd-Band-Releases-JESUS-GUNS-to-Radio-20160115|publisher=Broadway World|accessdate=21 January 2016}}</ref>\n\n==Members==\n*Eric Durrance - Lead Vocals / Guitar\n*Ben Castro - Lead Guitar\n*Dale Shumate - Bass Guitar\n*Joe Markham - Drums\n\n==Discography==\n*Where the Girls Are (EP) -  Released: January 6, 2012, Big Southern Entertainment\n\n==Track listing==\n{{tracklist   \n| title1          = Where the Girls Are | length1         = 3:11\n| title2          = Jesus & Guns| length2         = 4:07\n| title3          = Energy Craze | length3         = 2:56\n| title4          = All About Me Today| length4         = 3:40\n| title5          = There's No Such Thing As Goodbye| length5         = 3:46\n| title6          = Dear Life | length6         = 3:09\n}}\n\n*That's Country (single) ft. Colt Ford -  Released: February 6, 2013, Big Southern Entertainment\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* {{Official website|http://TobaccoRdBand.com/}}\n* [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1mkzWB3psMs ''That's Country'' on YouTube]\n* [https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/where-the-girls-are-ep/id493645173 Tobacco Rd Band on iTunes]\n\n[[Category:American country rock groups]]\n[[Category:Musical groups from Florida]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 2010]]\n[[Category:2010 establishments in Florida]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Wade_Hayes","to":"Wade Hayes"}],"pages":{"1745424":{"pageid":1745424,"ns":0,"title":"Wade Hayes","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country music singer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name                = Wade Hayes\n| image =Wade hayes 1 (cropped).jpg\n| caption = Wade Hayes in 2022\n| alt = Singer Wade Hayes, holding a guitar while onstage.\n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          = Tony Wade Hayes\n| birth_date                = {{birth date and age|1969|04|20}}<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p141661/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Wade Hayes biography |access-date=October 12, 2007 |last=Erlewine |first=Stephen Thomas |author-link=Stephen Thomas Erlewine |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>\n| origin              = [[Bethel Acres, Oklahoma]], United States\n| instrument          = Vocals, guitar\n| genre               = [[country music|Country]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = 1994\u20132004<br />2008\u2013present\n| label               = [[Columbia Records|Columbia]], [[Monument Records|Monument]], RPM\n| past_member_of     = [[McHayes]]\n| website                 = [https://www.wadehayes.com/ Website]\n}}\n'''Tony Wade Hayes''' (born April 20, 1969) is an American [[country music]] artist. Signed to [[Columbia Records]] in 1994, he made his debut that year with his gold-certified album ''[[Old Enough to Know Better]]''. Its title track \"[[Old Enough to Know Better (song)|Old Enough to Know Better]]\", which served as his debut single, reached number one on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts. He released two more albums for Columbia Nashville: ''[[On a Good Night]]'' in 1996 and ''[[When the Wrong One Loves You Right (album)|When the Wrong One Loves You Right]]'' in 1998. Later albums were released on [[Monument Records]] and independently. In addition to \"Old Enough to Know Better\", Hayes reached top ten on the ''Billboard'' charts with \"[[I'm Still Dancin' with You]]\", \"[[Don't Stop (Wade Hayes song)|Don't Stop]]\", \"[[What I Meant to Say]]\", \"[[On a Good Night (song)|On a Good Night]]\", and \"[[The Day That She Left Tulsa (In a Chevy)]]\".\n\nIn 2003, he founded the duo [[McHayes]] with Mark McClurg. The duo charted one single on the country charts and recorded one unreleased album for the [[Universal South Records|Universal South]] label, ''Lessons in Lonely''. Hayes' career was briefly placed on hiatus due to a diagnosis of Stage IV [[colon cancer]], which went into remission in 2012. Hayes has continued to tour and record independently since.\n\n==Biography==\nWade Hayes was born and raised in [[Bethel Acres, Oklahoma]]. His father, Don Hayes, also a professional country musician, inspired him to begin playing music as well. Initially, Hayes had learned to play mandolin, but later switched to guitar after his father bought him one.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/><ref name=\"oldies\">{{cite web |url=http://www.oldies.com/artist-biography/Wade-Hayes.html |title=Wade Hayes biography |access-date=October 12, 2007 |work=Oldies.com}}</ref> When he was 11 years old, his family moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], where his father signed with an independent record label. The label soon declared bankruptcy.<ref name=\"oldies\"/> The family returned to Oklahoma, where Wade later found work as a musician in his father's band.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nAlthough he attended three different colleges, Hayes dropped out of college in 1991 in pursuit of a career in country music, after seeing bluegrass musician [[Ricky Skaggs]] perform on the 1991 [[Country Music Association]] awards show.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Wade returned to Nashville, where he began recording demo tapes and writing his own material. Eventually, Hayes partnered with a songwriter named Chick Rains, who recommended him to Don Cook, a record producer who has produced albums for several country music artists, including [[Brooks & Dunn]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\n==Musical career==\n\n===1994\u20131996: ''Old Enough to Know Better''===\nWith Cook's help, Hayes was signed to a record deal with [[Columbia Records]] in late 1994. The same year, Hayes' debut single, \"[[Old Enough to Know Better (song)|Old Enough to Know Better]]\", was released, and by early 1995, it peaked at Number One on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] charts.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> The single was followed by the release of Hayes' debut album, also titled ''[[Old Enough to Know Better]]'', which produced three additional Top Ten singles on the country music charts: \"[[I'm Still Dancin' with You]]\", \"Don't Stop\" and \"What I Meant to Say\", at No.&nbsp;4, No.&nbsp;10 and No.&nbsp;5 respectively. It was also certified gold by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] for shipping 500,000 copies.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Also in 1995, Hayes was nominated for Top New Male Vocalist of the Year by the [[Country Music Association]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\n===1996\u20131997: ''On a Good Night''===\n''[[On a Good Night]]'', Hayes' second album, was released via Columbia in 1996.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Although the album's lead-off single (which was the title track) peaked at No.&nbsp;2 on the country charts, the second and third singles \u2014 \"Where Do I Go to Start All Over\" and \"It's over My Head\" \u2014 both failed to make Top 40. Nonetheless, the album was certified gold as well. Also included on this album was a cover of \"Undo the Right\", a song originally recorded by [[Willie Nelson]].\n\n===1997\u20131999: ''When the Wrong One Loves You Right''===\nIn 1997, Hayes also issued a cover of [[Glen Campbell]]'s song \"[[Wichita Lineman]]\" as the first single for a third album which was to have been titled ''Tore Up from the Floor Up''. This cover failed to reach Top 40, however, and the album was delayed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=HT&p_theme=ht&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAFEBA146F802BE&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=Wade Hayes' \"Wrong\" Is Just Right for Him |access-date=November 21, 2008 |date=November 2, 1997|work=Sarasota Herald-Tribune}}</ref> It was followed with \"The Day That She Left Tulsa (In a Chevy)\", which reached No.&nbsp;5 on the country charts. After this song's release, Hayes's third album \u2013 by then re-titled ''[[When the Wrong One Loves You Right (album)|When the Wrong One Loves You Right]]'' \u2014 was issued, with the Glen Campbell cover omitted. \"The Day That She Left Tulsa\" was followed by \"When the Wrong One Loves You Right\", \"How Do You Sleep at Night\" (his final Top 40 hit at No.&nbsp;13), and finally, \"Tore Up from the Floor Up\". Hayes considered ''When the Wrong One Loves You Right'' as a more mature effort than his first two albums, with more of an emphasis on ballads than his previous two albums.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1473654/20030708/hayes_wade.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070430131449/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1473654/20030708/hayes_wade.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=April 30, 2007 |title=CMT.com : Wade Hayes : Wade Hayes Shifts Gears |access-date=October 12, 2007 |work=CMT.com}}</ref>\n\n===2000\u20132001: ''Highways and Heartaches''===\nBy 2000, Hayes had switched from Columbia Records to [[Monument Records]]. His fourth and final album before his nine-year hiatus, titled ''[[Highways & Heartaches (Wade Hayes album)|Highways & Heartaches]]'', was released in 2000.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Three singles were released from the album before Hayes left Monument.\n\n===2001\u20132004: Duo formation and hiatus===\nIn 2003, Hayes joined fiddler Mark McClurg to form the duo [[McHayes]], which charted one single (\"It Doesn't Mean I Don't Love You\", which reached No.&nbsp;41 on the country charts) and recorded one unreleased album for [[Universal South Records]]. After McHayes disbanded in July 2004, McClurg rejoined Jackson's road band, and Hayes went on hiatus.\n\n===2008\u20132009: Return to music and ''Place to Turn Around''===\nHe rejoined the music business in 2008, taking a role as lead guitarist and singer in former [[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]] lead singer [[Randy Owen]]'s road band.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/concertreview.asp?xid=327 |title=Randy Owen leaves Alabama behind |access-date=December 2, 2008 |last=Remz |first=Jeffrey B. |date=August 3, 2008|work=[[Country Standard Time]]}}</ref> Hayes also returned to touring on his own. Hayes released a fifth album, ''Place to Turn Around'', in July 2009, on an independent label. The album features eleven songs, with ten being penned by Hayes.\n\nIn 2012, Hayes released the single \"Is It Already Time\" through RPM Entertainment.<ref>{{cite news|last=Skates|first=Sarah|title=Original Sony/Columbia Team Reunites for Wade Hayes Single|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2012/09/original-sonycolumbia-team-reunites-for-wade-hayes-single/|access-date=September 11, 2012|newspaper=[[MusicRow]]|date=September 11, 2012}}</ref>\n \n=== 2016\u20132017: Old Country Song ===\n\nOn June 9, 2017, Hayes released ''Old Country Song''. The 11-cut collection of old and new songs was produced by Dave Mcfee and Hayes. It was released on Conabor Records.\n\n==Personal life==\nOn April 4, 1999, Hayes married [[Danni Boatwright]]. The couple divorced in 2003. Boatwright later was a contestant on the [[CBS]] reality television series ''[[Survivor (US TV series)|Survivor]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1474989/20030730/hayes_wade.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080201154434/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1474989/20030730/hayes_wade.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 1, 2008 |title=CMT.com : Wade Hayes : Wade's Wedding |access-date=October 12, 2007 |work=CMT.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.realitytvworld.com/index/articles/person.php?p=516 |title=Danni Boatwright contestant information |access-date=October 12, 2007 |work=Reality TV world}}</ref>\n\nIn December 2011, Hayes was diagnosed with Stage 4 [[colon cancer]], which was successfully operated on that same month.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/sources-wade-hayes-has-stage-iv-colon-cancer/|title=Sources: Wade Hayes Has Stage IV Colon Cancer|last=Bjorke|first=Matt|date=December 9, 2011|work=Roughstock|access-date=December 15, 2011}}</ref> The last tumors were removed in March 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/wade-hayes-chemo-therapy-colon-cancer/|title=Wade Hayes Tumor Free Following Surgery and Chemo Therapy for Colon Cancer|last=Conaway|first=Alanna|date=March 4, 2012|work=Taste of Country|access-date=March 4, 2012}}</ref>\n\nOn September 25, 2018, Hayes became engaged to Lea Bayer, a realtor. The two were introduced by her first cousin, country singer [[John Rich]]. On December 4, 2018, Billboard Magazine published an article announcing their engagement and Hayes\u2019 new song.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/8488658/wade-hayes-who-saved-who-dog-video-interview | title=Wade Hayes Salutes Four-Legged Best Friend in Moving 'Who Saved Who (Jack's Song)': Video Premiere | magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] }}</ref> They were married on January 25, 2019. <ref>[http://www.nashville.com/wadehayestiestheknot www.nashville.com/wadehayestiestheknot]</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jill_King","to":"Jill King"}],"pages":{"15165967":{"pageid":15165967,"ns":0,"title":"Jill King","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Jill King\n| image           =\n| caption         =\n| image_size      =\n| birth_name      = Jill Christine King<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p554208|pure_url=yes}} |title=Jill King biography |accessdate=January 7, 2008 |last=Cohoon |first=Rick |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1973|04|02}}\n| origin          = [[Arab, Alabama]], United States\n| instrument      = Vocals<br />acoustic guitar\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 2003\u2013present\n| label           = Blue Diamond, Foundher\n| website         = {{URL|http://www.jillking.com}}\n}}\n'''Jill Christine King''' (born April 2, 1973, in [[Arab, Alabama]]<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>) is an American [[country music]] artist. A graduate of [[Vanderbilt University]],<ref name=\"allmusic\"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystarsonline.com/FanFairFeatures/JillKing.htm |title=Jill King |accessdate=January 7, 2008 |work=Country Stars Online |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061020153353/http://www.countrystarsonline.com/FanFairFeatures/JillKing.htm |archivedate=October 20, 2006 }}</ref> she spent several years in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], before being discovered at [[Tootsie's Orchid Lounge]], a popular venue for singer-songwriters in Nashville.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/article.asp?xid=541&t=Jill_King_another_singer_from_Tootsies_makes_good |title=Jill King, another singer from Tootsie's, makes good |accessdate=January 7, 2008 |last=Teverbaugh |first=Rick |work=Country Standard Time}}</ref>\n\nIn 2003, she released her debut album, ''Jillbilly'', on the independent Blue Diamond label. The album's first and third singles both entered ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts. Several of her singles have also charted on the independent ''Music Row'' music charts as well.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://magazine.angrycountry.com/article.php?story=20050119160844666 |title=Jill King jumps seven spots on Music Row charts and jumps back into the studio |accessdate=January 7, 2008 |date=January 1, 2005|work=Angry Country |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303175530/http://magazine.angrycountry.com/article.php?story=20050119160844666 |archive-date=March 3, 2016 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Her 2008 single \"[[Somebody New (Billy Ray Cyrus song)|Somebody New]]\" is a cover of a song previously recorded by [[Billy Ray Cyrus]].\n\nKing founded her own label, Foundher Records, in 2010. She released her third album, ''Rain on Fire'', that same year.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:10em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Album details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Jillbilly''\n| \n* Release date: March 18, 2003\n* Label: Blue Diamond\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Somebody New''\n| \n* Release date: June 3, 2008\n* Label: Blue Diamond\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Rain On Fire''\n| \n* Release date: April 6, 2010\n* Label: Foundher\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:20em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"60\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2003\n! scope=\"row\"| \"One Mississippi\"\n| 60\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"5\"| ''Jillbilly''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Hand Me Down Heartache\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2004\n! scope=\"row\"| \"98.6 Degrees and Falling\"\n| 56\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Three Months, Two Weeks, One Day\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2005\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Makes Perfect Sense to Me\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2008\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Somebody New (Billy Ray Cyrus song)|Somebody New]]\"\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| ''Somebody New''\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Director\n|-\n| 2003\n! scope=\"row\"| \"One Mississippi\"\n| Tom Bevins\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.jillking.com/ JillKing.com]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:King, Jill}}\n[[Category:1975 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:People from Arab, Alabama]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Vanderbilt University alumni]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Alabama]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Alabama]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Glen_Templeton","to":"Glen Templeton"}],"pages":{"32458398":{"pageid":32458398,"ns":0,"title":"Glen Templeton","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country singer and songwriter}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Glen Templeton\n| image           = Glen Templeton (cropped).jpg\n| caption         = Templeton performing in 2018\n| origin          = [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama]], United States<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.glentempleton.com/news_details.php?id=6|title=Capstone Artists Signs Glen Templeton|publisher=glentempleton.com|date=November 22, 2010|accessdate=July 18, 2011}}</ref>\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter, musician\n| years_active    = 2010\u2013present\n| label           =\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{url|glen-templeton.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Glen Templeton''' is an American [[country music|country]] singer and songwriter.\n\n==Career==\nTempleton released his debut single \"I Could Be the One\",<ref>{{cite web|title=Glen Templeton \u2013 I Could Be the One|url=http://www.roughstock.com/audio/glen-templeton-i-could-be-the-one|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110320041928/http://www.roughstock.com/audio/glen-templeton-i-could-be-the-one|archive-date=March 20, 2011|accessdate=July 18, 2011|publisher=Roughstock}}</ref> written by Jay Knowles and Thom McHugh, on April 19, 2011. \"I Could Be the One\" was originally recorded by [[Billy Ray Cyrus]] on his 2009 album ''[[Back to Tennessee]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=I Could Be the One \u2013 Single by Glen Templeton|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/i-could-be-the-one-single/id433162129|accessdate=July 18, 2011|publisher=[[iTunes]]}}</ref> In July 2011, Glen was signed to [[Black River Entertainment]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Black River signs artist|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=5564|accessdate=July 20, 2011|publisher=Country Standard Time}}</ref> Templeton also released a self-titled [[extended play]] on June 6, 2011, which included the single as well as three additional songs. \"I Could Be the One\" debuted at number 58 on the U.S. ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart for the week ending July 30, 2011, and ultimately reached a peak of number 53. Two more singles followed: \"Sing That Song Again\" and \"Ball Cap.\" \"Sing That Song Again\" peaked at number 60 on the Hot Country Songs chart, while \"Ball Cap\" (written by Cassidy Lynn Alexander, Forest Whitehead, and [[Dylan Scott]]) was released to SiriusXM Satellite Radio.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/#/column/chartbeat/chart-highlights-adult-contemporary-dance-1005281582.story|title=Chart Highlights: Adult Contemporary, Dance/Club Play Songs & More|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=July 18, 2011}}</ref> In early 2015, Templeton and his label, Black River Entertainment, parted ways.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Extended plays===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:10em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n! Peak positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"65\"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Glen Templeton''\n| \n* Label: Black River Entertainment \n* Release date: June 6, 2011\n* Formats: download\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Let Her Go''\n| \n* Release date: July 29, 2014\n* Label: Black River Entertainment\n* Formats: download\n| 47\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''California''\n| \n* Release date: January 18, 2019\n* Label: Coastal Cowboy Entertainment\n* Formats: download\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"3\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:14em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"65\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"|2011\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Country Boys for Life\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Could Be the One\"\n| 53\n| align=\"left\"| ''Glen Templeton''\n|-\n| 2012\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Sing That Song Again\"\n| 60\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"2\"| ''Let Her Go''\n|-\n| 2013\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Ball Cap\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2016\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Hip to Be Country\"\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| ''California''\n|-\n| 2019\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Run with Me\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2020\n! scope=\"row\"| [https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/glen-templeton-country-wanna-get-premiere/ \"Country as You Wanna Get\"]\n| \u2014\n| \u2014 \n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 2011\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Could Be the One\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/glen-templeton/688051/i-could-be-the-one.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120901125504/http://www.cmt.com/videos/glen-templeton/688051/i-could-be-the-one.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=September 1, 2012|title=CMT : Videos : Glen Templeton : I Could Be the One|publisher=[[Country Music Television]]|accessdate=September 3, 2011}}</ref>\n| Eric Welch\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"|2012\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Country Boys For Life\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/56408888|title=Vimeo : Videos : Glen Templeton : Country Boys For Life|publisher=[[Vimeo]]|accessdate=December 28, 2012}}</ref>\n| Lance Holloway\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[That's My Job]]\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/glen-templeton/791470/thats-my-job.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120901125849/http://www.cmt.com/videos/glen-templeton/791470/thats-my-job.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=September 1, 2012|title=CMT : Videos : Glen Templeton : That's My Job|publisher=[[Country Music Television]]|accessdate=June 18, 2012}}</ref>\n| rowspan=\"2\"| Robert Chavers\n|-\n| 2014\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Let Her Go (Passenger song)|Let Her Go]]\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/glen-templeton/1079970/let-her-go.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140910195753/http://www.cmt.com/videos/glen-templeton/1079970/let-her-go.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=September 10, 2014|title=CMT : Videos : Glen Templeton : Let Her Go|publisher=[[Country Music Television]]|accessdate=September 9, 2014}}</ref>\n|-\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Templeton, Glen}}\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:People from Tuscaloosa, Alabama]]\n[[Category:Black River Entertainment artists]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Alabama]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Alabama]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Shooter_Jennings","to":"Shooter Jennings"}],"pages":{"3040676":{"pageid":3040676,"ns":0,"title":"Shooter Jennings","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American musician and record producer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2023}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Shooter Jennings\n| image            = SHOOTER_JENNINGS_SHOT_02_005.jpg\n| caption          = Jennings at The Rainbow Bar and Grill in 2018\n| birth_name       = Waylon Albright Jennings<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/shooter-jennings-mn0000036312/biography | title=Shooter Jennings biography | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=March 10, 2020 | author=Steve Leggett}}</ref>\n| birth_date       = {{Birth date and age|1979|5|19}}<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n| birth_place      = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| genre            = {{Flatlist|\n* [[Country rock]]\n* [[outlaw country]]<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.sacurrent.com/music/shooter-jennings-bringing-outlaw-country-tunes-to-gruene-hall-this-weekend-16633331?media=AMP+HTML | title=Shooter Jennings Bringing Outlaw Country Tunes to Gruene Hall This Weekend }}</ref>\n* [[southern rock]]<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/shooter-jennings-readies-black-ribbons-for-election-day-re-release-89831/ | title=Shooter Jennings to Re-Release Stephen King Concept Album | magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] | date=July 13, 2016 }}</ref>\n}}\n| occupation       = {{Hlist|Singer|musician|record producer|songwriter}}\n| instrument       = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar|piano}}\n| years_active     = 1996\u2013present\n| label            = {{hlist|[[Show Dog-Universal Music|Universal South]]|[[Black Country Rock Media]]|[[Low Country Sound]]}}\n}}\n\n'''Waylon Albright''' \"'''Shooter'''\" '''Jennings''' (born May 19, 1979) is an American musician and record producer. He is the son of [[Country music|country]] singers [[Waylon Jennings]] and [[Jessi Colter]]. In a career spanning three decades, Jennings has explored a variety of musical genres.\n\nJennings made his debut with the single \"4th of July\" of his 2005 album ''[[Put the \"O\" Back in Country]]'' on [[Universal South Records|Universal South]], which peaked at No. 22 on the Billboard country charts.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Shooter Jennings - Chart history {{!}} Billboard|url = http://www.billboard.com/artist/279176/shooter-jennings/chart?f=320|website = www.billboard.com|access-date = November 21, 2015}}</ref> Jennings has since followed with seven full-length studio albums: ''[[Electric Rodeo (Shooter Jennings album)|Electric Rodeo]]'' (2006), ''[[The Wolf (Shooter Jennings album)|The Wolf]]'' (2007), ''[[Black Ribbons]]'' (2009), ''Family Man'' (2012), ''The Other Life'' (2013) ''[[Countach (For Giorgio)]]'' (2016), and ''Shooter'' (2018), in addition to a live album, a compilation, and numerous [[Extended play|EPs]].\n\n== Early life ==\nJennings was born in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], on May 19, 1979. There are two different accounts regarding how he got his nickname \"Shooter.\" His mother cited her, and husband Waylon Jennings', love of western culture and cowboy art for inspiring the gun-derived moniker. But his father said he came up with the name when, moments after the newborn emerged from his mother's womb, the boy sprayed a nurse before anyone could put on his first diaper. \"I love my mom,\" says Jennings, \"but I like Dad's version better. And I believe it's true. He didn't make [stuff] like that up.\"\n\nHe lived the first few years of his life in a crib on his parents' tour bus surrounded by the likes of [[Johnny Cash]], [[Willie Nelson]] and [[Kris Kristofferson]]. By age 5, he was playing drums. At 8 years old, he began taking piano lessons. He started playing guitar at 14 and on occasion he'd play percussion in his father's band.\n\nIn high school Jennings fronted an industrial rock band called KilRaven for his high school's talent show. In 2011, he released the KilRaven track \"Only You\" on the album \"Missed The Boat\".\n\nIn 1996, Jennings and his father recorded an album together. They called it ''Fenixon'' (a play on the words \"phoenix\" and \"son\") but could not find a label to distribute it.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Waylon and Son, Reunited on Disc|url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB122471459623460261|newspaper = Wall Street Journal|access-date = November 21, 2015|issn = 0099-9660|first = Jim|last = Fusilli}}</ref> Some of the material was remastered and used for the album ''Waylon Forever''. The full ''Fenixon'' recording was finally released by Jennings' label Black Country Rock in 2014. Shooter Jennings is the uncle of William Harness, Professionally known as [[Struggle Jennings]].\n\n== Career ==\n[[File:Shooterjennings(by Scott Dudelson).jpg|thumb|Jennings performing in 2009]]\n\n=== Stargunn ===\nIn 2001, Jennings left [[Nashville, Tennessee]], to seek his fortunes in [[Los Angeles]]. He assembled and performed with Stargunn, a [[rock music|rock]] band. The band featured Jennings on piano and lead vocals, Carter Falco, and Jonathan Boddie (later succeeded by Kevin Sciou) on guitar and background vocals, Curtis Roach on bass, and Lex Lipsitz on drums. Towards the end of 2001, Stargunn released their first album, ''The Only Way Up Is Down'', and toured with [[Saliva (band)|Saliva]], [[Tesla (band)|Tesla]], Mark Ford and others in support of the album. That same year, ''[[Music Connection]]'' magazine listed Stargunn as one of the Hot 100 Unsigned Artists of 2001.\n\nIn 2002, Stargunn was featured on ''I've Always Been Crazy: A Tribute to Waylon Jennings'', and the soundtrack to the [[Vince Vaughn]] film ''[[Made (2001 film)|Made]]''. Shortly after, [[Touchstone Pictures]] licensed the song \"White Lines N Black Ties\" for the film ''[[The Crew (2000 film)|The Crew]]'' starring [[Burt Reynolds]]. Stargunn performed together for three years, built an avid following, and earned praise from the local music press. On March 30, 2003, Jennings dissolved Stargunn and began working on his solo career.\n\nAfter the band's breakup, Jennings was twice presented with the opportunity to front the hard rock supergroup [[Velvet Revolver]], but chose instead to pursue a solo career.<ref>{{Cite web|title = SHOOTER JENNINGS Claims He Was Offered VELVET REVOLVER Job Twice|url = http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/shooter-jennings-claims-he-was-offered-velvet-revolver-job-twice/|website = BLABBERMOUTH.NET|date = March 19, 2009|access-date = November 21, 2015|language = en-US}}</ref>\n\nIn 2015, Jennings' label Black Country Rock released Stargunn's debut album \"The Only Way Up Is Down\" on vinyl as part of Record Store Day.\n\n=== ''Put the \"O\" Back in Country'' ===\nHe returned to Los Angeles in 2004 to begin working on new material. In 2005 Jennings signed his first recording contract, with [[Universal South Records]], releasing his debut album ''[[Put the \"O\" Back in Country]]'' that same year.\n\n\"Put the \"O\" Back in Country\" produced his only entry on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts in its lead-off single \"Fourth of July\", which peaked at No.&nbsp;22. The album version of this song features a cameo appearance by George Jones, who sings the chorus to his signature song \"He Stopped Loving Her Today\" at the end; this guest appearance was removed from the song's radio edit. Despite the edit, Jones was credited on the Billboard charts. The album featured his new band The .357's, which consisted of Leroy Powell on guitar, Bryan Keeling on drums, [[Ted Russell Kamp|Ted Kamp]] on bass with [[Robby Turner]] on steel, and backing vocals by [[Bonnie Bramlett]].\n\nLater that year his song \"Busted In Baylor County\" was then featured in the 2005 film version of ''[[The Dukes of Hazzard (film)|The Dukes of Hazzard]]'', furthermore Jennings portrayed his father in the [[Johnny Cash]] [[Biographical film|biopic]] ''[[Walk the Line]]'' alongside [[Joaquin Phoenix]] and [[Reese Witherspoon]]. His rendition of his father's song \"Long Way From Home\" was featured on the film's soundtrack.\n\n=== ''Electric Rodeo'' and ''The Wolf'' ===\nThough recorded before ''Put the \"O\" Back in Country'', released on April 4, 2006,{{clarify|reason=is this the release date of Put the O Back in Country or the release date of Electric Rodeo?|date=April 2017}} ''[[Electric Rodeo (Shooter Jennings album)|Electric Rodeo]]'' was released as Jennings's second solo album. Sonically, ''Electric Rodeo'' is louder, rawer, more upfront rock and roll than its predecessor.\n\n''Electric Rodeo'' was followed by ''[[The Wolf (Shooter Jennings album)|The Wolf]]'' on October 23, 2007. The album varied from his previous records in that the .357s had opted for a decidedly 1970s feel to the instrumentals. It featured collaborations with [[Doug Kershaw]] and [[The Oak Ridge Boys]], as well as a cover of the [[Dire Straits]] song \"[[Walk of Life]]\".\n\nThat same year Jennings was featured on a duet of \"[[Good Hearted Woman (song)|Good Hearted Woman]]\" on [[Deana Carter]]'s sixth studio album, ''[[The Chain (Deana Carter album)|The Chain]]''.\n\n=== Departure from Universal ===\nIn 2009, Jennings, having issues with his label and wanting out of his four-album contract released his first compilation album, ''[[Bad Magick: The Best of Shooter Jennings and the .357's]]''. The album featured four new tracks; live versions of \"Lonesome Blues\", and \"Daddy's Farm\", as well as covers of his father's \"Lonesome, Onry and Mean\", and the [[Hank Williams, Jr.]] song \"Living Proof\".\n\nAfter the release of ''Bad Magick: The Best of Shooter Jennings and the .357's'', having fulfilled his four-album contract; Jennings parted ways with Universal records.\n\nOn March 23, 2009, Jennings took part in ''[[CMT Crossroads]]'', a television show in which two musicians are paired with one another and perform a small concert together for an intimate crowd. The episode paired Jennings with close friend and fellow musician [[Jamey Johnson]]. The evening's set list consisted entirely of duets, including a cover of \"[[Outlaw country|Outlaw]] Shit\" from the ''[[Waylon Forever]]'' album, two songs from Jennings' discography; \"God Bless Alabama\", \"It Ain't Easy\". As well as four songs from Johnson's album ''[[That Lonesome Song]]''; \"High Cost Of Living\", \"Mowing Down The Roses\", \"Between Jennings and Jones\" and \"In Color\".\n\n=== ''Black Ribbons'' ===\nHaving left Universal, Jennings changed the name of his backing band from The .357's to Hierophant. With the news that he and his band would be joining the likes of [[Paramore]], [[Bad Religion]], [[Fall Out Boy]], [[Jefree Star]], and various other popular rock bands on the 2009 [[Warped Tour]] it became apparent that Jennings next album would differ drastically from his previous efforts.\n\nIn February 2009, it was announced that the album would be titled ''[[Black Ribbons]]''. It was also announced that it would be a dystopian concept rock opera and that writer [[Stephen King]] would play a major role in the album as Will O' The Wisp.\n\nIt was released independently on March 2, 2010, through Black Country Rock Records, and although it was seen as a complete departure from his country sound, the album showed off the diversity as an artist and gained him much critical acclaim, as well as a brand new underground following.\n\nOn May 1, 2010, Jennings announced \"Black Ribbons: The Living Album\" on his Twitter account.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/ShooterJennings |title=Shooter Jennings (ShooterJennings) on Twitter |publisher=Twitter.com |date=June 3, 2014 |access-date=August 4, 2014}}</ref> The \"Living Album\" includes the full studio record and live shows with [[Hierophant]] on a [[USB flash drive]] shaped like a tarot card.\nTowards the end of 2010, Jennings with the help of various other artists launched the \"XXX\" movement to help musicians who struggle to receive mainstream recognition.\n\nIn 2016, Jennings created and released a podcast series title \"Beyond the Black\" dealing with the topics and recording of [[Black Ribbons]]. The series is available on all music streaming formats as well as YouTube and the podcast's own website: [http://www.beyondthe.black www.beyondthe.black]\n\n=== ''Family Man'' ===\nIn 2011, along with childhood friend and master pianist Erik Deutsch, Jennings formed The Triple Crown, a new backing band featuring Erik Deutsch on piano, Tony Leone on drums, Jeff Hill on bass, Jon Graboff on pedal steel, Eleanor Whitmore on fiddle and Chris Masterson on lead guitar.\n\nOn March 13, 2012, having signed a record deal with [[E1 Music]], and with The Triple Crown along for the ride, Jennings returned to his country roots with the release of the album ''Family Man'', his first self-produced outing. The album was originally meant to contain eighteen tracks, but was instead split into two albums: ''Family Man'' and 2013's ''The Other Life''.\n\nOn July 31, 2012, Jennings was featured in [[Bucky Covington]]'s debut single \"The Drinking Side of Country\" from the album ''Good Guys''.\n\nJennings took part in the February 25 Johnny Cash 80th Birthday Bash, in which he sang [[Cocaine Blues]] With [[Willie Nelson]] and [[Amy Nelson]]. The performance was released in a DVD/CD combo.\n\nIn October 2012 Jennings was one of six commentators for the Ovation mini-series ''Song By Song: Johnny Cash''.\n\n=== ''The Other Life'' ===\nWhile recording ''Family Man'', Jennings decided to cut the darker tracks from the album, and instead use them for the album's follow-up, ''The Other Life''.\n\n\"Five of these songs were recorded when we were doing ''Family Man'', and when we were deciding what to do with it we broke it up into two records. ''The Other Life'' is representative of the other side of the coin from ''Family Man'' and the way my life has been going in a lot of ways, At first we were going to call it ''The Outsider'', but once we got into the film we thought, 'Well, it's like a mirror, a dark mirror of what ''Family Man'' was.{{'\"}} - Jennings told TheBoot.com.\n\nJennings premiered the track \"Wild & Lonesome\" (featuring [[Patti Griffin]]) on the 4th season of the FX original series ''[[Sons of Anarchy]]''. Followed by the release of first official single from the album \"The White Trash Song\" (featuring [[Scott H. Biram]]) which premiered on RollingStones.com along with the announcement that the album would be accompanied by a film.\n\nThe album featured seven new songs, as well as two cover songs ([[Harry Nilsson]]'s \"Flying Saucer song\" and [[Steve Young (musician)|Steve Young]]'s \"The White Trash song\") and \"Outlaw You\", which was put out in early 2012 as a digital release.\n\nJennings along with filmmaker Blake Judd released ''The Other Life'' film. Running at 32 minutes long, it utilizes six of the songs from the album as a sort of narration. The film is about a musician leaving his family to tour, but when he does so he finds the road is not the same, and becomes haunted by a mysterious woman. Throughout the film, the musician is forced to face his darker urges and deal with self-discovery, temptation, isolation and rebirth. The film closes with a short adaptation of [[Stephen King]]'s ''[[The Dark Tower (series)|The Dark Tower]]''.\n\nThe Other Life went on to win Best Short Film at the 2013 Horror Hound Festival.\n\nThe album was also heavily featured in the 2nd season of ''[[The Punisher (TV series)|The Punisher]]'', of which Shooter also appears, as himself.\n\n=== Black Country Rock Media ===\n{{main|Black Country Rock Media}}\nIn October 2013, Jennings announced the formation of his new label and multi-format recording company, Black Country Rock. Their initial releases included: a remastered release of the [[Waylon Jennings]] album ''[[Right for the Time]]'', two live albums (one from [[Jessi Colter]] titled ''Live from Cain's Ballroom'', and one from Jennings titled ''The Other Live''), as well as a recording of \"[[You Are My Sunshine]]\" featuring vocals from both [[Jamey Johnson]] and Jennings. All four were released on vinyl, cassette, CD, as well as digitally.\n\n=== ''The Magic'' ===\nOn February 27, 2014, Jennings revealed he would be releasing a spoken word follow-up to Hierophant's 2010 album, ''[[Black Ribbons]]'', titled ''The Magic'', inspired by first story in the controversially interactive horror series thirteen.\n\nIn addition to ''The Magic'' Jennings also announced, that after nearly a decade of waiting, he would be releasing the 1995 collaborative album, ''Fenixon''.\n\nBoth projects were released during 2014's Record Store Day, and subsequently sold out.\n\n=== \"George/Giorgio\" releases ===\nTowards the end of May 2014, Jennings announced his intention to release two EP's later in the year. ''Don't Wait Up (for George)'' is a tribute to his close friend and mentor [[George Jones]], which was released in August 2014. Jennings' seventh studio album, ''[[Countach (For Giorgio)]]'', was originally scheduled to be released in November 2014, but its release was delayed due to the sudden death of [[Jon Hensley (radio personality)|Jon Hensley]], Jennings' longtime manager and friend and Black Country Rock co-founder.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.laweekly.com/music/how-daft-punk-and-the-muppets-inspired-shooter-jennings-giorgio-moroder-tribute-album-6616503 |title=How Daft Punk and the Muppets Inspired Shooter Jennings' Giorgio Moroder Tribute Album |first=Daniel |last=Kohn |work=[[LA Weekly]] |publisher=[[Voice Media Group]] |date=February 23, 2016 |access-date=March 2, 2016}}</ref> A tribute to 1970s electronic-music pioneer and producer, [[Giorgio Moroder]], the album was released on February 26, 2016, and features guest vocals from [[Steve Young (musician)|Steve Young]],<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/6882805/shooter-jennings-giorgio-moroder-tribute-album-countach-david-bowie-interview |title=Shooter Jennings on Giorgio Moroder Tribute Album & How His David Bowie Cover 'Ended Up Meaning So Much More' |first=Chuck |last=Dauphin |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |date=February 19, 2016 |access-date=March 2, 2016}}</ref> [[Brandi Carlile]],<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/shooter-jennings-enlists-marilyn-manson-brandi-carlile-for-countach-20160104 |title=Shooter Jennings Enlists Marilyn Manson, Brandi Carlile for 'Countach' |first=Andrew |last=Leahey |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=January 4, 2016 |access-date=March 2, 2016}}</ref> [[Marilyn Manson]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://consequenceofsound.net/2016/02/marilyn-manson-covers-the-hell-out-of-david-bowies-cat-people-listen/ |title=Marilyn Manson covers the hell out of David Bowie's \"Cat People\" \u2014 listen |first=Ben |last=Kaye |work=[[Consequence of Sound]] |date=February 18, 2016 |access-date=March 2, 2016}}</ref> and [[Richard Garriott|Richard Garriott de Cayeux]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.avclub.com/article/neon-noir-meets-outlaw-country-shooter-jennings-tr-230314 |title=Neon noir meets outlaw country in Shooter Jennings' tribute to Giorgio Moroder |first=Mike |last=Vanderbilt |work=[[The A.V. Club]] |publisher=[[The Onion]] |date=January 5, 2016 |access-date=March 2, 2016}}</ref> The album became his first to enter the Dance Albums chart, peaking at number seven there.<ref name=\"dance\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/shooter-jennHOOings/chart-history/dance-electronic-albums|title=Shooter Jennings - Chart history {{!}} Billboard|website=www.billboard.com|language=en|access-date=March 17, 2017}} {{dead link|date=December 2021|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>\n\n=== ''Shooter'' ===\n\nFollowing Countach, [[Brandi Carlile]] insisted that Jennings be involved in her next project. Together with [[Dave Cobb]], Jennings produced her 2018 album ''[[By the Way, I Forgive You]]'', which landed six Grammy nominations, including the all-genre Album and Song of the Year categories. It won in three categories: Americana album and both best American roots song and best American roots performance (for \"The Joke\").\n\nAfter reuniting with Dave Cobb, with whom Jennings made his first four records, Jennings, inspired by the 1984 country album ''[[Major Moves]]'' decided to shelve the album he had already been working on and instead go in a completely different direction with Cobb and make a fun, straight-ahead drinking, rockin' record. That album, titled ''Shooter'', was released in August 2018. \n \nThe following year Jennings teamed up with Brandi Carlile to produce [[Tanya Tucker]]'s 25th album, ''[[While I'm Livin']]''. The record, Tucker's first in 17 years, earned Grammys for Best Country Album and Best Country Song as well as Americana Award nominations for Album of the Year, Song of the Year and Artist of the Year.\n\n=== ''Over a Cocaine Rainbow'' ===\n\nIn late 2021 Jennings released \"Leave Those Memories Alone\", a tribute to his late friend and manager, Col. John Hensley. the track serves as the first single from the album ''Over a Cocaine Rainbow''. The record was initially slated for a 2017 release, but Jennings felt it was too \"dark and experimental\" to release at the time, given its subject matter and tone. Earlier that same year, Jennings released a remix of his \"From Here to Eternity\" track. The new version is dubbed the \"Goof the Floof Remix\", a reference to something Scientology founder [[L. Ron Hubbard]] once said in an interview.\n\n=== Radio show ===\n\nSince 2005, Jennings has hosted \"Shooter Jennings' Electric Rodeo\" on [[Sirius XM]] Outlaw Country channel.<ref>{{cite web|title=SHOOTER JENNINGS DJS ON SIRIUS RADIO|url=http://www.countryweekly.com/news/shooter-jennings-djs-sirius-radio|website=Country Weekly|access-date=November 13, 2015}}</ref> The show's format primarily consists of country, rock, and outlaw music. It airs on Saturday night at 6\u20138&nbsp;pm EST, with a replay on Sunday at 10\u201312&nbsp;pm.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.siriusxm.com/outlawcountry|title=Outlaw Country - Top Country Music with an Edge on SiriusXM|website=Siriusxm.com|access-date=August 11, 2018}}</ref>\n\n=== Production work ===\nJennings collaborated as producer with [[Duff McKagan]] for his 2019 solo album, [[Tenderness (Duff McKagan album)|''Tenderness'']]. The album was recorded with Jennings band, The Waters and The Suicide Horn Section, amongst others.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.blabbermouth.net/news/does-duff-mckagan-feel-underrated-as-a-bass-player/|title=Does DUFF MCKAGAN Feel Underrated As A Bass Player?|date=May 3, 2019|website=BLABBERMOUTH.NET|access-date=August 30, 2019}}</ref> In March 2019, a tour was announced in support of the album, featuring Jennings band playing both the support slot as well as the headline slot as the backing band for Duff.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ultimateclassicrock.com/duff-mckagan-tenderness-album/|title=Duff McKagan Announces 'Tenderness' Album and Tour Dates|last=Lifton|first=Dave|website=Ultimate Classic Rock|date=March 20, 2019 |language=en|access-date=August 30, 2019}}</ref>\n\nJennings has produced albums and tracks for numerous bands including [[Brandi Carlile]], [[Marilyn Manson]], [[Tanya Tucker]] and [[American Aquarium]], as well as [[Jessi Colter]], [[Jamey Johnson]], [[Jaime Wyatt]], [[The White Buffalo (musician)|The White Buffalo]], [[Hellbound Glory]], [[The Mastersons]], [[Julie Roberts]], [[Yelawolf]], [[Jason Boland & The Stragglers|Jason Boland]], Billy Don Burns, [[Avi Kaplan]], [[Billy Ray Cyrus]], and [[Angry Grandpa]].\n\n== Style and influences ==\nShooter Jennings's influences include [[David Bowie]],<ref name=\"Amorosi\">{{cite web |last=Amorosi |first=A D. |date=August 5, 2016 |title=Shooter Jennings brings his eclectic electric dreams - and his dad's backing band -to Ardmore |url=https://www.inquirer.com/philly/entertainment/20160805_Shooter_Jennings_brings_his_eclectic_electric_dreams_-_and_his_dad_s_backing_band_-to_Ardmore.html?outputType=amp |access-date=April 20, 2022 |publisher=The Inquirer}}</ref><ref name=\"TallahasseeDemocrat\">{{cite web |last=Schardl |first=Kati |date=June 28, 2018 |title=Scoot out for Shooter Jennings' hardcore musical mix |url=https://amp.tallahassee.com/amp/741251002 |access-date=April 20, 2022 |publisher=Tallahassee Democrat}}</ref><ref name=Revolver/> [[Pink Floyd]],<ref name=Speckler>{{cite web |url=https://www.al.com/entertainment-press-register/2010/09/shooter_jennings_brings_parano.html |title= Shooter Jennings brings paranoid 'Black Ribbons' to Mobile|last=Specker |first=Lawrence |date=September 9, 2010 |publisher=Advance Local Media |access-date=April 20, 2022}}</ref> [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.riverfronttimes.com/music/lynyrd-skynyrd-shooter-jennings-2455159 |title=Lynyrd Skynyrd/Shooter Jennings |last=Seabaugh |first=Julie |date=June 21, 2006 |publisher=Riverfront Times |access-date=April 20, 2022}}</ref> [[Hank Williams Jr.]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/shooter-jennings-premieres-drunk-talks-hank-williams-jr-influence-8468362/ |title=Shooter Jennings Premieres 'D.R.U.N.K.,' Talks Hank Williams Jr. Influence |last=Dauphin |first=Chuck |date=August 3, 2018 |publisher=Billboard |access-date=April 20, 2022}}</ref> [[Nine Inch Nails]],<ref name=\"Kohn\">{{cite web |last=Kohn |first=Daniel |date=September 16, 2020 |title=SHOOTER JENNINGS: NEW AGE OUTLAW |url=https://www.spin.com/featured/shooter-jennings-new-age-outlaw-september-2020-cover/ |access-date=April 19, 2022 |publisher=Spin}}</ref> [[Guns N' Roses]],<ref name=Kohn/> [[Rage Against the Machine]]<ref name=Speckler/> and [[Marilyn Manson]].<ref name=Kohn/>\n\n''[[Rolling Stone]]'' described Jennings as a \"[[country rock|country-rock]] outsider\".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/shooter-jennings-producer-marilyn-manson-1029852/amp/ |title=How Shooter Jennings Pivoted to Become a Grammy-Winning Producer |last=Hudak |first=Joseph|date=July 16, 2020 |publisher=Rolling Stone|access-date=January 5, 2023}}</ref> Regarding classification of his music, Jennings said that he did not want to be pigeonholed as being solely a rock musician.<ref name=Dickinson>{{cite web |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-2006-09-29-0609290188-story.html |title= Shooter Jennings isn't wailin' about forging own identity |last=Dickinson |first=Chrissie |date=September 29, 2006 |publisher=Chicago Tribune |access-date=April 20, 2022}}</ref> Marilyn Manson argued against Jennings's work being classified as [[country music]], saying \"southern\" was a more appropriate classification, noting the latter \"also drags in a bit of [[The Rolling Stones|the Stones]], in a way\".<ref name=Revolver>{{cite web |url=https://www.revolvermag.com/music/marilyn-manson-southern-new-album-machine-gun-kelly-twins-evil-tour |title=Marilyn Manson on \"Southern\" New Album, Machine Gun Kelly, Twins of Evil Tour |author=Epstein, Dan |work=[[Revolver (magazine)|Revolver]] |date=July 8, 2019 |access-date=August 7, 2020 |archive-date=August 31, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200831154824/https://www.revolvermag.com/music/marilyn-manson-southern-new-album-machine-gun-kelly-twins-evil-tour |url-status=live}}</ref> ''[[AllMusic]]'' described Jennings as having \"established himself as an artist who played by his own rules\" and said that his music is \"strongly informed by both [[hard rock]] and [[outlaw country]]\", while his album ''[[Black Ribbons]]'' \"explored his interest in [[heavy metal music|metal]] and [[electronic music]]\".<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\n== Personal life ==\nJennings is the son of country music singers [[Waylon Jennings]] and [[Jessi Colter]]. He has six half-siblings in total; five from his father, and one, Jennifer Eddy Harness, from his mother. Jennifer's son, country rap artist [[Struggle Jennings]], spent a substantial amount of his adolescence in the company of Shooter (who was one year older than Struggle) and Waylon Jennings.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Struggle Jennings on 'purpose over popularity,' growth in hip-hop-inspired country music |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2023/12/13/country-music-artists-struggle-jennings-talks-album-el-camino/71660737007/ |access-date=2024-01-11 |website=The Tennessean |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nOn February 13, 2002, Shooter's father died in his sleep of diabetic complications in [[Chandler, Arizona]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Obituaries {{!}} Country singer Waylon Jennings dead at 64 {{!}} Seattle Times Newspaper|url = http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20020213&slug=webjennings13|website = community.seattletimes.nwsource.com|access-date = November 21, 2015}}</ref> He was buried in the Mesa City Cemetery, in [[Mesa, Arizona]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Waylon wall: Country singer's grave finally has marker - Tucson Citizen Morgue, Part 2 (1993-2009)|url = http://tucsoncitizen.com/morgue2/2003/02/19/134679-waylon-wall-country-singer-s-grave-finally-has-marker/|website = tucsoncitizen.com|access-date = November 21, 2015}}</ref> At the life tribute ceremony, on February 15, Shooter sang \"I've Always Been Crazy\" for the attendees, who included Waylon's close friends, family, and fellow musicians.\n\nJennings began dating actress [[Drea de Matteo]] in 2001.<ref name=\"people2007\">{{cite news |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20163275,00.html|title=Drea de Matteo Has a Baby Girl|work=People|first=Tim|last=Nudd |date=November 29, 2007|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080118051339/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20163275,00.html|archive-date= January 18, 2008|access-date= February 23, 2022}}</ref> They have two children together, a daughter born in 2007<ref name=\"people2007\"/> and a son born in 2011.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2011/04/08/drea-de-matteo-shooter-jennings-welcome-son-waylon-albert/|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180407182731/http://celebritybabies.people.com/2011/04/08/drea-de-matteo-shooter-jennings-welcome-son-waylon-albert/ |archive-date= April 7, 2018|title= Drea de Matteo, Shooter Jennings Welcome Son Waylon Albert|work=People|first=Sarah|last=Michaud|date=April 8, 2011|access-date= February 23, 2022}}</ref> Jennings and de Matteo eventually ended their relationship without marrying.<ref name=\"people2013\">{{cite news |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20713974,00.html|title=Shooter Jennings & Misty Brooke Swain Marry in the Desert|work=People|first=Cynthia|last=Sanz|date=July 2, 2013|access-date=November 4, 2013}}</ref>\n\nJennings married long-time friend Misty Brooke Swain on June 4, 2013, in [[Joshua Tree, California]].<ref name=\"people2013\"/> Swain and Jennings had met while he was in his rock band, Stargunn, and Swain was bartending at the Rainbow Bar & Grill. Shooter and Misty live in Hollywood, California.\n\n== Discography ==\n{{main|Shooter Jennings discography}}\n;Studio albums\n*''[[Put the \"O\" Back in Country]]'' (2005)\n*''[[Electric Rodeo (Shooter Jennings album)|Electric Rodeo]]'' (2006)\n*''[[The Wolf (Shooter Jennings album)|The Wolf]]'' (2007)\n*''[[Black Ribbons]]'' (2010)\n*''Family Man'' (2012)\t\n*''The Other Life'' (2013)\n*''Fenixon'' <small>(with [[Waylon Jennings]])</small> (2014)\n*''Don't Wait Up (for George) EP'' (2014)\n*''[[Countach (For Giorgio)]]'' (2016)\n*''Shooter'' (2018)\n*''Sometimes Y'' <small>(with [[Yelawolf]])</small> (2022)\n\n== Production discography ==\n'''Studio albums'''\n*''[[Waylon Forever]]'' - [[Hellbound Glory]] (2022)\n\n== Filmography ==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-  style=\"background:#ccc; text-align:center;\"\n! colspan=\"4\" style=\"background: LightSteelBlue;\" | Film\n|-  style=\"background:#ccc; text-align:center;\"\n!
