Year\n! Title\n! Role\n|-\n| 2008\n| ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation]]''\n| Himself\n|-\n| 2019\n| ''[[The Punisher (TV series)|Marvel's The Punisher]]''\n|| Himself\n|}\n\n== Awards and nominations==\n=== Grammy Awards ===\nThe [[Grammy Award]]s are awarded annually by the [[National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences]]. Jennings has won two awards from five nominations.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/artists/shooter-jennings/243326 |title=Shooter Jennings|website=Grammy.com|access-date=March 23, 2023}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n|rowspan=3|[[61st Annual Grammy Awards|2019]]\n|rowspan=2|''[[By the Way, I Forgive You]]''\n|[[Grammy Award for Best Americana Album|Best Americana Album]]\n|{{won}}\n|-\n|[[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]]\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n|\"[[The Joke (song)|The Joke]]\"\n|[[Grammy Award for Record of the Year|Record of the Year]]\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n|[[62nd Annual Grammy Awards|2020]]\n|''[[While I'm Livin']]''\n|[[Grammy Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]]\n|{{won}}\n|-\n|[[64th Annual Grammy Awards|2022]]\n|\"[[Right on Time (Brandi Carlile song)|Right on Time]]\"\n|[[Grammy Award for Record of the Year|Record of the Year]]\n|{{nom}}\n{{end}}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n{{commons category}}\n* {{official website}}\n* {{allMusic}}\n* {{IMDb name}}\n* [http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/an-interview-with-shooter An Interview with Shooter Jennings]\n\n{{Shooter Jennings}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Jennings, Shooter}}\n[[Category:1979 births]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American country rock singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]\n[[Category:Jennings family]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"JB_and_the_Moonshine_Band","to":"JB and the Moonshine Band"}],"pages":{"36402795":{"pageid":36402795,"ns":0,"title":"JB and the Moonshine Band","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country music group}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = JB and the Moonshine Band\n| image           = JB Moonshine-Press shot with LOGO.jpg\n| image_size      =\n| landscape       =\n| alt             =\n| caption         =\n| origin          = [[Palestine, Texas]], United States\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| years_active    = 2009-present\n| label           = [[Average Joe's Entertainment|Average Joe's]]\n| associated_acts = [[Colt Ford]]\n| website         = {{URL|http://www.jbandthemoonshineband.com/}}\n| current_members = JB Patterson<br />Gabe Guevara<br />Hayden McMullen<br />Chris Flores\n| past_members    = \n}}\n\n'''JB and the Moonshine Band''' is an American [[Texas country music|Texas country]] group from [[East Texas]] composed of JB Patterson, Gabe Guevara, Hayden McMullen and Chris Flores. In 2010, they signed to [[Colt Ford]]'s record label, [[Average Joe's Entertainment]].<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=mn0002148929|pure_url=yes}}|title=JB and the Moonshine Band Biography|last=Leggett|first=Steve|work=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=July 12, 2012}}</ref> Their 2012 album ''Beer for Breakfast'' charted on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart.\n\n==History==\nIn early 2009, front man JB Patterson, lead vocalist, songwriter and rhythm guitarist for the band, gave up his advertising career to pursue his dream of being a songwriter, and listed an open casting call for musicians in his community.  Turnout for the audition was small; only three people showed up, but three was enough.  Gabe Guevara, Hayden McMullen and Chris Flores were immediately dubbed \"the Moonshine Band.\"  After their first show at a local honky-tonk, JB and the boys began touring, and with a jury-rigged PA system and a rented U-Haul van, the band travelled through East Texas, quickly gaining a local following.<ref name=\"jbandthemoonshineband.com\">{{cite web |url=http://jbandthemoonshineband.com/about |title=About |access-date=2012-08-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120625163630/http://www.jbandthemoonshineband.com/about |archive-date=2012-06-25 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nThe group\u2019s big break came while opening for [[Average Joe's Entertainment]] artist [[Colt Ford]] in March 2010.  The band\u2019s country sound and outlaw attitude immediately caught the attention of Colt\u2019s team in Nashville, TN, and in July 2010 JB and the Moonshine Band signed a record deal with Average Joe's Entertainment.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bootfest.org/publicFiles/BootfestPressKit.pdf |title=Archived copy |access-date=2012-08-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426010129/http://www.bootfest.org/publicFiles/BootfestPressKit.pdf |archive-date=2012-04-26 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Label mates include country singer/songwriter Colt Ford, [[American Idol]] finalist [[Josh Gracin]], and award winning country duo [[Montgomery Gentry]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://averagejoesent.com/ourstory |title=Bio |access-date=2012-08-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120414132739/http://averagejoesent.com/ourstory |archive-date=2012-04-14 |url-status=dead }}</ref>  The band\u2019s debut album, \u201cAin\u2019t Goin' Back to Jail\u201d premiered in September 2010, with Gabe Guevara on drums, Hayden McMullen on lead guitar, Chris Flores on bass guitar and JB providing lead vocals, banjo, and acoustic guitar.  JB also serves as the band\u2019s lyricist, writing all of the songs on the record.<ref name=\"jbandthemoonshineband.com\"/>\n\nJB and the Moonshine Band's second album, \"Beer For Breakfast\" was released March 6, 2012 and charted on ''Billboard''.\n\n==Notable accomplishments==\nThe first single from the ''Ain't Goin' Back to Jail'' debut album was \"Perfect Girl\" and was the fasting-raising debut single in 2010 and is the #1 Most Requested Song on XM Nashville 11, with over 2,300 digital sales a week. The single has gained over 1,090,000 YouTube views and has already sold over 50,000 paid single downloads on iTunes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://npgpr.com/client1.php?id=5&page=18 |title=NPG Pr - |access-date=2012-08-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120502052418/http://npgpr.com/client1.php?id=5&page=18 |archive-date=2012-05-02 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Currently, the band's YouTube channel has had over 2,000,000 views.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/user/TheMoonshineBand|title=YouTube|website=Youtube.com|access-date=2020-04-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190513010701/https://www.youtube.com/user/TheMoonshineBand|archive-date=2019-05-13|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nThe music video for \"Perfect Girl\" was also featured on CMT Pure's 12 Pack for months and peaked at #7.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/shows/dyn/cmt_pure_12_pack_countdown/series.jhtml |title=CMT.com : Pure 12-Pack Countdown : Shows Main |access-date=2012-08-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120814235610/http://www.cmt.com/shows/dyn/cmt_pure_12_pack_countdown/series.jhtml |archive-date=2012-08-14 |url-status=dead }}</ref> It was later nominated for CMT's Top 30 Videos of 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/shows/events/cmt_top30_videos_2011/index.jhtml |title=Country Music Television : CMT Celebrates the Top 30 Videos of 2011 |access-date=2012-08-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025020915/http://www.cmt.com/shows/events/cmt_top30_videos_2011/index.jhtml |archive-date=2012-10-25 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nThe second single from their debut album, \"Whiskey Days\" peaked at #7 on Billboard's Texas Regional Radio Report.  The third single, \"Love Don't Let You Decide\" peaked at #15 on the Texas Regional Radio Report.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.texasmusicchart.com/PDFs/Chart.pdf |title=Archived copy |access-date=2012-08-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120508192848/http://texasmusicchart.com/PDFs/Chart.pdf |archive-date=2012-05-08 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.texasregionalradio.com/Top100.asp|title=Texas Regional Radio Report|website=Texasregionalradio.com|access-date=2012-08-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120814032340/http://texasregionalradio.com/Top100.asp|archive-date=2012-08-14|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nIn 2011, JB and the Moonshine Band were nominated for two awards at the Texas Radio Report Awards for \"Best Video\" and \"Best New Group.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jbandthemoonshineband.com/home/82-texas-regional-radio-music-award-nominations |title=Texas Regional Radio Music Award Nominations |access-date=2012-08-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120424011608/http://www.jbandthemoonshineband.com/home/82-texas-regional-radio-music-award-nominations |archive-date=2012-04-24 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nJB Patterson co-wrote the #1 hit single \"Double-Wide Dream\" on the Texas Regional Radio Report for the week of January 15.  The single was cowritten with the frontman from Casey Donahew Band of Texas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.texasmusicchart.com/Pages/Chart.htm|title=Texas Music for the Country|website=Texasmusicchart.com|access-date=2012-08-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070814011905/http://www.texasmusicchart.com/Pages/Chart.htm|archive-date=2007-08-14|url-status=live}}</ref>  The video for the single has recently been played on CMT's show \"High 5\" which features the top five most played songs on CMT.com.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/video/franchise/2089/high_5.jhtml |title=CMT : Videos : Country Music Videos, Movie Trailers, News & Original Video |access-date=2012-08-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120807041531/http://www.cmt.com/video/franchise/2089/high_5.jhtml |archive-date=2012-08-07 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nThe sophomore album, \"Beer For Breakfast\" debuted at No. 4 on iTunes Country Albums day of its release, March 6.  The album debuted at No. 31 on Billboard's Country Chart, No. 31 on Billboard's Independent Albums and at No. 7 on Billboard's Heatseekers Chart.\n\nThe third album ''Mixtape'' was released on June 30, 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://aristopr.com/jb-and-the-moonshine-band-to-release-new-album-mixtape-on-june-30/ |title=JB And The Moonshine Band to Release New Album, Mixtape on June 30 |date=May 13, 2015 |author=Simone Diamond |work=Aristo PR |access-date=July 24, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150725011033/http://aristopr.com/jb-and-the-moonshine-band-to-release-new-album-mixtape-on-june-30/ |archive-date=July 25, 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref> It debuted on the Top Country Albums chart at No. 33, selling 2,600 copies for the week.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://roughstock.com/news/2015/07/36279-country-album-chart-report-july-13-2015/ |title=Country Album Chart Report for July 13, 2015 |last=Bjorke |first=Matt |work=Roughstock  |date=July 13, 2015 |access-date=July 24, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150715022041/http://roughstock.com/news/2015/07/36279-country-album-chart-report-july-13-2015/ |archive-date=July 15, 2015 |url-status=live }} Sales figure given here [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1_cVIDdKRILq9ombqDbHRpCNY9tSEV1A4xiTGRW5C8-g/edit#gid=0] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160428131256/https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1_cVIDdKRILq9ombqDbHRpCNY9tSEV1A4xiTGRW5C8-g/edit#gid=0 |date=2016-04-28 }}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:14em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:20em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"3\"| Peak chart positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! style=\"width:45px;\"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]<br /><ref>{{cite magazine|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=jb and the moonshine band|chart=all}}|title=JB and the Moonshine Band Album & Song Chart History \u2013 Country Albums|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=July 12, 2012}}</ref>\n! Alosio\n|-\n| 2017\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Mess Outta Me\"\n| [[Peter Zavadil]]\n|-\n| 2018\n! scope=\"row\"| \"How Can I Miss You\"\n| [[Trey Fanjoy]]\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.jbandthemoonshineband.com Official Website]\n* [https://www.facebook.com/jbandthemoonshineband Official Facebook Page]\n* [https://www.youtube.com/themoonshineband Official YouTube Channel]\n* [http://www.averagejoesent.com Average Joes Entertainment]\n* [http://www.lexmusicgroup.com LEX Music Group, LLC]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Jb And The Moonshine Band}}\n[[Category:Country music groups from Texas]]\n[[Category:Average Joes Entertainment artists]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 2009]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Dylan_Scott","to":"Dylan Scott"}],"pages":{"43410958":{"pageid":43410958,"ns":0,"title":"Dylan Scott","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2019}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Dylan Scott\n| image           = Dylan Scott 2019 by Glenn Francis.jpg\n| caption         = Scott in 2019\n| birth_name      = Dylan Scott Robinson<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Dylan Scott Scores First Country Airplay No. 1 |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7872873/dylan-scott-my-girl-first-country-airplay-chart |date=July 18, 2017 |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |accessdate=November 14, 2018 |first=Jim|last=Asker}}</ref>\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1990|10|22}}\n| birth_place     = [[Bastrop, Louisiana]], U.S.\n| genre           = [[Country pop]]\n| occupation      = {{Flatlist|\n* Singer\n* songwriter\n}}\n| instrument      = {{Flatlist|\n* Vocals\n* guitar\n* piano\n}}\n| years_active    = 2013\u2013present\n| label           = [[Curb Records|Curb]]\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{URL|http://dylanscottcountry.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''Dylan Scott Robinson''' (born October 22, 1990)<ref name=\"cmt\">{{cite web|title=Dylan Scott Bio|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/dylan-scott/biography/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402155504/http://www.cmt.com/artists/dylan-scott/biography/|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 2, 2015|website=[[Country Music Television]]|accessdate=July 28, 2014}}</ref> is an American country singer and songwriter, better known by his stage name '''Dylan Scott'''. He is signed to [[Curb Records]].<ref name=\"cmt\" />\n\n==Career==\nScott's debut single, \"[[Makin' This Boy Go Crazy]]\", was released in June 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=R&R :: Going For Adds :: Country|url=http://gfa.radioandrecords.com/PublishGFA/GFANextPage.asp?sDate=06/24/2013&Format=4|work=[[Radio & Records]]|accessdate=July 28, 2014|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131015090709/http://gfa.radioandrecords.com/publishGFA/GFANextPage.asp?sDate=06%2F24%2F2013&Format=4|archivedate=October 15, 2013}}</ref> Billy Dukes of ''[[Taste of Country]]'' gave the song three and a half stars out of five, writing that \"the native Louisianan can really rumble when he reaches down to hit the low notes, but his performance won't leave female fans tingling like the greats.\"<ref>{{cite news|last=Dukes|first=Billy|title=Dylan Scott, 'Makin' This Boy Go Crazy' \u2013 Song Review|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/dylan-scott-makin-this-boy-go-crazy/|accessdate=July 28, 2014|newspaper=[[Taste of Country]]|date=June 24, 2013}}</ref> It charted for 10 weeks on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Country Airplay]] chart, peaking at number 54 in April 2014.<ref name=\"airplay\" /> The song's [[music video]] premiered on [[Country Music Television|CMT]] in December 2013.<ref name=\"video\" />\n\nScott's second single, \"Mmm, Mmm, Mmm\", was released in July 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=R&R :: Going For Adds :: Country|url=http://gfa.radioandrecords.com/PublishGFA/GFANextPage.asp?sDate=07/07/2014&Format=4|work=[[Radio & Records]]|accessdate=July 28, 2014|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140811143651/http://gfa.radioandrecords.com/PublishGFA/GFANextPage.asp?sDate=07%2F07%2F2014&Format=4|archivedate=August 11, 2014}}</ref> Markos Papadatos of ''Digital Journal'' gave the song a B+ rating, writing that \"the song has a [[Jake Owen]] meets [[Colt Ford]] vibe to it, especially since he displays his smooth baritone and rap vocals.\"<ref>{{cite news|last=Papadatos|first=Markos|title=Review: Dylan Scott back with new country single 'Mmm, Mmm, Mmm'|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/a-and-e/music/review-dylan-scott-back-with-new-country-single-mmm-mmm-mmm/article/388367|accessdate=July 28, 2014|newspaper=Digital Journal|date=July 2, 2014}}</ref>\n\nBoth songs are included on his [[extended play]], ''Makin' This Boy Go Crazy'' (also as the self-titled  ''Dylan Scott'' EP), which was released on February 11, 2014.<ref>{{cite news|last=Nicholson|first=Jessica|title=Sidewalk Records' Dylan Scott Releases Self-Titled EP|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2014/02/sidewalk-records-dylan-scott-releases-self-titled-ep/|accessdate=July 28, 2014|newspaper=[[MusicRow]]|date=February 12, 2014}}</ref> The EP was produced by [[Jim Ed Norman]].<ref name=\"cmt\" /> It peaked at number 50 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart.<ref name=\"country\" /> Another single, \"Lay It on Me\", came out in late 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/a-and-e/music/review-dylan-scott-charms-on-new-country-single-lay-it-on-me/article/408039|title=Review: Dylan Scott charms on new country single 'Lay It On Me' (Includes first-hand account)|date=October 10, 2014|website=Digitaljournal.com|accessdate=December 2, 2018}}</ref>\n\nDylan Scott had his first number one record in the summer of 2016 with \"My Girl\", a song written for his high school sweetheart-now wife, Blair Robinson.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web|url=https://dylanscottcountry.com/|title=Dylan Scott|website=Dylan Scott|language=en|access-date=2019-10-29}}</ref>  \"My Girl\" is also Scott's first Platinum record,<ref name=\":0\" /> indicating the single has sold  1,000,000 copies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/about-awards/|title=About the Awards|last=|first=|date=n.d.|website=RIAA|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160109215629/http://www.riaa.com:80/gold-platinum/about-awards/ |archive-date=January 9, 2016 |access-date=October 28, 2019}}</ref>\n\nScott released his debut studio album, self-titled ''[[Dylan Scott (album)|Dylan Scott]]'', in August 2016. It debuted at number five on the Top Country Albums chart, selling 9,000 copies for the week.<ref>{{cite magazine|url= http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7486819/dan-shay-country-airplay-justin-moore-albums |title=Dan + Shay 'Up' to No. 1 On Country Airplay; Justin Moore Bows Atop Top Country Albums |date=August 23, 2016 |first= Jim |last=Asker|magazine=Billboard }}</ref>\n\nScott followed up \"My Girl\" with a number 2 record, \"Hooked\", from his ''[[Dylan Scott (album)|Dylan Scott]]'' album, which was later certified Gold.<ref name=\":0\" />\n\nScott released the single \"[[Nothing to Do Town]]\", which was accompanied by a music video and released on December 17, 2018.<ref>{{cite web|title=R&R :: Going For Adds :: Country|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xjrpAFRN39A|work=[[Curb Records]]|accessdate=December 17, 2018}}</ref>\n\nIn 2019, Scott released an EP titled ''An Old Memory'', containing seven covers of [[Keith Whitley]] songs and features a guest appearance from Whitley's widow [[Lorrie Morgan]].<ref name=\"whitley\">{{cite magazine | url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8517939/dylan-scott-keith-whitley-covers-ep-an-old-memory | title=Dylan Scott Salutes His Idol Keith Whitley on Upcoming EP: Exclusive | magazine=Billboard | date=June 28, 2019 | accessdate=May 12, 2020}}</ref>\n\nIn 2023, Scott performed the national anthem and had a pregame concert prior to the [[2023 USFL Championship Game]] in [[Canton, Ohio]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Dylan Scott to Perform Live Before USFL Championship Game|url=https://amp.foxsports.com/stories/usfl/dylan-scott-to-perform-live-before-usfl-championship-game|accessdate=July 1, 2023}}</ref>\n\n== Personal life ==\nScott was born in Louisiana and moved to Nashville at the age of 19.\n\nScott and his wife, Blair Robinson, live in Nashville with their three children, sons Beckett Scott (born December 12, 2017)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1789410/dylan-scott-becomes-a-father/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171213195409/http://www.cmt.com/news/1789410/dylan-scott-becomes-a-father/|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 13, 2017|title=Dylan Scott Becomes a Father|last=Staff 12/13/2017|website=CMT News|access-date=2019-10-29}}</ref> and Barron (born September 26, 2023)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://people.com/dylan-scott-and-wife-blair-welcome-baby-3-7971750|title=Dylan Scott and Wife Blair Robinson Welcome Baby No. 3, a Boy Named Barron: 'Life Is Good!'|website=PEOPLE.com|language=en|access-date=2023-09-30}}</ref> and daughter Finley Gray (born August 28, 2019).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://people.com/parents/dylan-scott-welcomes-daughter-finley-gray-first-photo/|title=Meet Finley Gray! Dylan Scott Welcomes Second Child and Says Wife Blair 'Is a Rockstar'|website=PEOPLE.com|language=en|access-date=2019-10-29}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\" \n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Nothing to Do Town\"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/dylan-scott-nothing-to-do-town-video/|title=Dylan Scott Returns Home in New Video 'Nothing to Do Town'|first=Annie|last=Reuter|website=Taste of Country}}</ref>\n|-\n| 2020\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Nobody\"\n|-\n| 2021\n! scope=\"row\"| \"New Truck\"\n|-\n| 2022\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Can\u2019t Have Mine (Find You a Girl)\"\n|-\n| 2024\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Boys Back Home\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://countrynow.com/dylan-marlowe-and-dylan-scott-light-up-middle-tennessee-in-fun-filled-boys-back-home-music-video/|title=Dylan Marlowe And Dylan Scott Light Up Middle Tennessee In Fun-Filled 'Boys Back Home' Music Video|author=Madeleine O\u2019Connell|date=February 1, 2024|website=Country Now|access-date=August 9, 2024}}</ref><br />{{small|(with Dylan Marlowe)}}\n| Tristan Cusick\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{Commons category-inline}}\n*{{official website|http://dylanscottcountry.com}}\n\n{{Dylan Scott|state=autocollapse}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Scott, Dylan}}\n[[Category:1990 births]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Louisiana]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:People from Bastrop, Louisiana]]\n[[Category:Curb Records artists]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Louisiana]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Bradley_Walker_(singer)","to":"Bradley Walker (singer)"}],"pages":{"52268342":{"pageid":52268342,"ns":0,"title":"Bradley Walker (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country vocalist}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Bradley Walker\n| landscape       =\n| alt             =\n| caption         =\n| birth_name      =\n| birth_date      = 1978\n| birth_place     = [[Athens, Alabama]]\n| occupation      = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter}}\n| origin          =\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]]\n| years_active    = 1998\u2013present\n| label           = [[Gaither Music Group]]\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{URL|bradleywalker.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Bradley Walker''' is an American [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] and [[country music]] singer and songwriter.\n\n==Early life==\nBradley Walker is a native of [[Athens, Alabama]]. He was born with [[muscular dystrophy]], and has been in a wheelchair all his life. He was a student at [[Limestone County School District|East Limestone High School]] where he played percussion in the school band.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://archive.decaturdaily.com/decaturdaily/news/060721/walker.shtml |title=Riding on a 'Highway of Dreams' |first= Holly|last= Hollman |work=The Decatur Daily |date=July 21, 2006 }}</ref>\n\nWalker started singing when he was two or three years old, and began performing in public when he was four.<ref name=\"waff\">{{cite news |url=http://www.waff.com/story/13305350/overcoming-the-odds-country-singer-lives-out-his-dreams |title=Overcoming the Odds: Country singer lives out his dreams |first=Kimberly|last= Essex |work=WAFF48 }}</ref>  When he was ten, he was invited on stage to perform with [[The Oak Ridge Boys]], and when he was eleven, he sang with The Oak Ridge Boys on [[The Nashville Network]]'s [[Nashville Now]] as well as on the [[The Jerry Lewis MDA Labor Day Telethon|Jerry Lewis MDA Telethon]].<ref name=\"profile\">{{cite web |url=http://americanprofile.com/articles/singer-bradley-walker/ |title=Singer Thrives Despite Disease |first= Michael|last= McCall |date=January 20, 2008 |work=American Profile }}</ref>\n\nHe works at the [[Browns Ferry Nuclear Power Plant]] as a Material Inventory Coordinator while pursuing a music career.<ref name=\"waff\"/>\n\n==Music career==\nIn 1998,  Walker formed a band, The Trinity Mountain Boys, and began to perform at bluegrass festivals.<ref name=\"profile\" /> In 2001, he joined the Georgia-based group Lost Horizon.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/297056/bradley-walker/biography |title=Bradley Walker > Biography |magazine=Billboard |access-date=2016-11-13 |archive-date=2016-11-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161129220949/http://www.billboard.com/artist/297056/bradley-walker/biography |url-status=dead }}</ref>  He was signed to [[Rounder Records]], and released his debut album, ''Highway of Dreams'', in 2006. The album was produced by [[Carl Jackson]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=6955339 |title='Highway of Dreams' for Singer Bradley Walker|date=January 23, 2007 |work=NPR}}</ref>  For his performance on the album, he won the Male Vocalist of the Year Award from the [[International Bluegrass Music Association]].<ref name=\"rolling stone\"/>\n\n===2016:  ''Call Me Old-Fashioned''===\nWalker's second album, ''Call Me Old-Fashioned'', was produced by [[Rory Feek]] and recorded at the [[Joey + Rory]] studio out on their farm.  Walker had known Joey and Rory Feek since 2007, and he was asked by Rory Feek to sing the hymn \"[[Leave It There]]\" at the funeral of [[Joey Feek]] in accordance with her wishes.<ref name=\"rolling stone\">{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/features/bradley-walker-on-joey-feeks-influence-behind-new-album-w445844 |title=Bradley Walker on Joey Feek's Influence Behind New Album |magazine= Rolling Stone |first=Deborah |last=Evans Price|date=October 20, 2016 }}</ref> [[Bill Gaither (gospel singer)|Bill Gaither]] of the [[Gaither Music Group]], who was also at the funeral service, heard Walker's performance and signed Walker to his label.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.gospelherald.com/articles/67436/20161021/christian-artist-born-with-muscular-dystrophy-discusses-faith-influence-of-rory-and-joey-feek-album-call-me-old-fashioned.htm |title=Christian Artist Born with Muscular Dystrophy Discusses Faith, Influence of Rory and Joey Feek, Album 'Call Me Old-Fashioned' |first=Leah Marianne |last=Klett|date= October 21, 2016|work=Gospel Herald }}</ref> The album includes a posthumous duet with Joey Feek, \"In The Time That You Gave Me\",  using vocals she recorded before her death.<ref name=\"rolling stone\"/> The album was released on September 23, 2016,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/call-me-old-fashioned-mw0002974140 |title=Call Me Old-Fashioned |first=Mark |last=Deming |work=AllMusic }}</ref> and debuted at No. 9 on the Top Country Albums chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/7550131/bradley-walker-call-me-old-fashioned-album-joey-rory-show|title=Bradley Walker Reflects on His Surprise Top 10 Country Album & Singing at Joey Feek's Funeral |date=October 25, 2016 |first= Chuck |last=Dauphin |magazine=Billboard }}</ref>\n\n===2017\u201319: ''Blessed: Hymns & Songs of Faith'' ===\nOn October 6, 2017, Walker released ''Blessed: Hymns & Songs of Faith''. The album, produced by Ben Isaacs, features collaborations with [[Vince Gill]], [[Alison Krauss]], [[Rhonda Vincent]], [[Jimmy Fortune]], [[The Oak Ridge Boys]], [[The Isaacs]] and [[Ricky Skaggs]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwmusic/article/Blessed-Hymns-and-Songs-of-Faith-by-Bradley-Walker-ft-Alison-Krauss-More-Out-Now-20171006 |title='Blessed: Hymns and Songs of Faith' by Bradley Walker ft, Alison Krauss & More Out Now|date=October 6, 2017 |work = Music World.com }}</ref>  The album received a [[GMA Dove Award]] for the Bluegrass/Country/Roots Album of the Year in 2018.<ref name=\"whnt\" />\n\nHe also performed a song \"Leave It There\" in the Homecoming CD/DVD release ''Give the World A Smile'' in 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.gastongazette.com/entertainment/20170406/bill-and-gloria-gaither-share-2-new-homecoming-albums|title=Bill and Gloria Gaither share 2 new 'Homecoming' albums |work=Gaston Gazette |first=Wade |last=Allen |date= April 6, 2017}}</ref>\n\nWalker appeared at the [[Crossroads Guitar Festival 2019]] alongside Vince Gill.<ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/eric-clapton-2019-crossroads-festival-live-album-1065415/ Eric Clapton\u2019s 2019 Crossroads Fest Set for Live LP/Concert Film Release ] ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', September 23, 2020. Retrieved 11 October 2021</ref>\n\n===2020&ndash;present: Brothers of the Heart===\n\nIn 2020, Walker collaborated with [[Jimmy Fortune]], Ben Isaacs, and Mike Rogers to release an album ''Brotherly Love'' and a concert DVD/TV special filmed at Rory Feek's barn/studio near Columbia, TN.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/jimmy-fortune-isaacs-rogers-walker-elizabeth-premiere/ |title=Jimmy Fortune, Ben Isaacs, Mike Rogers and Bradley Walker Deliver New Take on Statlers' Classic 'Elizabeth' |first= Deborah |last= Evans Price|date= September 18, 2020|work=Sounds Like Nashville }}</ref> The album was released digitally on May 29, 2020, and the DVD and CD released on September 4, 2020.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thechristianbeat.org/index.php/new-music/8383-jimmy-fortune-bradley-walker-mike-rogers-ben-isaacs-release-gaither-music-group-cd-dvd-tv-special |title=Jimmy Fortune, Bradley Walker, Mike Rogers & Ben Isaacs Release Gaither Music Group CD, DVD & TV Special |date= September 3, 2020 |first= Herb |last=Longs|work=The Christian Beat }}</ref> The concert film aired on the [[Circle (TV network)|Circle]] network on October 20, 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thechristianbeat.org/index.php/news/8725-gaither-music-group-s-brotherly-love-premieres-on-circle-network |title=Gaither Music Group's 'Brotherly Love' Premieres On Circle Network |date= October 20, 2020 |first= Herb |last=Longs |work=The Christian Beat}}</ref> The collaboration was successful and they decided to continue with another project, and while they were recording their second album they named their group Brothers of the Heart.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ccmmagazine.com/ccm-cafe/a-conversation-with-brothers-of-the-heart-fortune-walker-rogers-isaacs/ |title=A Conversation with Brothers of the Heart (Fortune, Walker, Rogers, Isaacs) |first= Brandon |last=Woolum |date= February 10, 2023 |work=CCM Magazine}}</ref>\n\nIn February 2023, Brothers of the Heart released the second album, ''Listen To The Music''.  The album reached No. 5 on the Top Christian Albums chart, and No. 32 on Top Album Sales.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://todayschristianent.com/music-news-brothers-of-the-heart-to-perform-on-the-opry-feb-7-listen-to-the-music-hits-1-on-billboard-christian-album-chart/ |title=\nMusic News: Brothers of the Heart to perform on The Opry Feb. 7; 'Listen To The Music' hits #1 on Billboard Christian album chart |work=Today Christian Entertainment }}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Julie_Reeves","to":"Julie Reeves"}],"pages":{"10741666":{"pageid":10741666,"ns":0,"title":"Julie Reeves","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{BLP sources|date=August 2008}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image           =\n| name            = Julie Reeves\n| image_size      =\n| background      = solo_singer\n| birth_name      =\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1974|6|18}}\n| origin          = [[Ashland, Kentucky]], United States\n| instrument      = Vocals\n| genre           = [[country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 1999\u2013present\n| label           = [[Virgin Records Nashville]], Capitol Records\n| associated_acts = [[Cledus T. Judd]]\n}}\n'''Julie Reeves''' (born June 18, 1984) is an American [[country music]]  recording artist and radio personality. She has had three hit singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart with two of those singles charting in the [[Top 40]]. Reeves was formerly married to country music parodist and fellow recording artist [[Cledus T. Judd]] but she is now married to bluegrass singer and musician, Chris Davis.\n\n==Biography==\nJulie Reeves grew up in the city of [[Ashland, Kentucky]] then moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] in 1994 where she gained employment in the country music industry.  Some of her first assignments in Nashville were providing vocals in studio sessions and doing back-up studio work.  She also worked on [[demo recording]]s prior to signing with Capitol Records in 1997. She recorded her debut album with producer Scott Hendricks. After finishing the album, Hendricks left Capitol Records to head the newly formed [[Virgin Records Nashville]]. Julie became the flagship artist of Virgin Records Nashville and released her debut album ''It's About Time'' in 1999 and featured three hit singles which charted on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts including two Top 40 hits. She was featured on \"Shoulda Shut Up\", a song featuring [[Bill Engvall]]'s spoken-word comedy and a sung chorus. Reeves married country music parodist [[Cledus T. Judd]] and gave birth to a daughter, Caitlyn Rose, in 2004.  After giving birth, Reeves took a break from the country music business to raise her daughter.  She later divorced Judd and returned home to the Ashland, Kentucky area.  She is now married to bluegrass musician Chris Davis. The two of them have a son together, Rylan Wesley Davis, born November 5, 2011.\n\nBeginning in April 2013, Reeves became host of the ''Julie Reeves Live'' morning show on [[WDGG|93.7 The Dawg]] (WDGG), which once had the highest share of listeners of all radio stations in the Huntington, WV-Ashland, KY market. She is now the midday announcers for Big Buck Country, a classic country station in the Huntington market.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ratings.radio-online.com/cgi-bin/rol.exe/arb193|title=Nielsen Audio Ratings|website=Ratings.radio-online.com|accessdate=April 26, 2020}}</ref> Coincidentally, Reeves morning radio show aired at the same time as her ex-husband Cledus T. Judd's in the Huntington-Ashland MSA. Judd is co-host of ''The Cletus T. Judd Party on [[WTCR-FM]] 103.3.\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:10em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Album details\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Matt_Mason_(singer)","to":"Matt Mason (singer)"}],"pages":{"35968415":{"pageid":35968415,"ns":0,"title":"Matt Mason (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American musician}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Matt Mason\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| associated_acts = [[Charlie Daniels]]\n| origin          = [[Fairland, Indiana]], U.S.\n| birth_date      = 1985\n| label           = [[Warner Records]]\n}}\n\n'''Matt Mason''' (born {{circa|1985}}) is an American [[country music]] [[singer/songwriter]] from [[Fairland, Indiana]]. He was the winner of ''CMT's Next Superstar'' in 2011. Prior to that, he competed on ''[[Nashville Star]]''.\n\n== Early life and career ==\nMason was born in [[Fairland, Indiana]] and attended [[Triton Central High School]] in [[Shelby County, Indiana]].<ref name=indy>{{cite news|title=Hoosier musician Matt Mason lands label, U.S. tour|url=http://www.indy.com/posts/hoosier-musician-matt-mason-lands-label-u-s-tour|newspaper=Indy Star|date=June 17, 2011}}</ref> He grew up listening to traditional country music, and started playing guitar at age eleven, and from that time onward wanted to sing professionally. At age 16, he opened for [[Charlie Daniels]] in western Massachusetts. Six months after graduating from high school in 2004, he moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] to pursue his career, and found work as a session musician. Within three weeks, he was performing in live shows.<ref name=JournalGazette>{{cite news|author=Penhollow, Steve|date=February 26, 2006|title=Rants & Raves: Indiana supplies fifth of new 'Nashville Star'|newspaper=[[The Journal Gazette]]|page=E1}}</ref>\n\n== Reality Television ==\nIn 2006, at age 20, he appeared on ''[[Nashville Star]]'',<ref name=JournalGazette /> finishing in fourth place.<ref>{{cite news|author=Wooley, John|date=August 4, 2006|title=Star power: 'Nashville Star' champ is hanging on for the ride|newspaper=[[Tulsa World]]|page=S12}}</ref> Afterwards, his productivity was affected by a struggle with alcohol and drug addiction, from which he recovered.<ref name=conaway>{{cite news|last=Conaway|first=Allana|title=Matt Mason Is Ready to Be Country Music's 'Next Superstar'|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/matt-mason-cmt-next-superstar-interview/|newspaper=Taste of Country|date=May 2, 2011|accessdate=October 2, 2014}}</ref> He subsequently performed live as often as four times a week in venues on [[Lower Broadway]].<ref name=conaway /> In 2011, he won ''CMT's Next Superstar''.<ref name=harr>{{cite news|last=Harr|first=Dan|title=Matt Mason From CMT's Next Superstar Performs at Warner Music Nashville|url=http://www.musicnewsnashville.com/matt-mason-from-cmts-next-superstar-performs-at-warner-music-nashville|newspaper=Music News Nashville|date=June 24, 2011}}</ref><ref name=tucker>{{cite news|last=Tucker|first=Ken|title=Matt Mason Wins CMT's Next Superstar|url=http://www.countryweekly.com/news/matt-mason-wins-cmts-next-superstar|newspaper=Country Weekly|date=Jun 12, 2011}}</ref>\n\n== Post-''Superstar'' ==\nFollowing his ''Next Superstar'' win, Mason was signed to [[Warner Records]]. Anticipating a slow process of creating and releasing a major-label album, Mason continued to tour and self-release recordings.<ref name=Thrasher>{{cite news|author=Thrasher, Don|date=June 22, 2012|title=Mason Mason: 'Next superstar' invests in himself|newspaper=[[Dayton Daily News]]|page=AC4}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Thrasher, Don|date=July 26, 2013|title=The Top|newspaper=Dayton Daily News|page=AC3}}</ref> He released the EP ''America's Favorite Pastime'' in 2012.<ref>{{cite news|author=Thrasher, Don|title=Matt Mason: Country singer survives by catering to fans: Musician combines online social media posts with touring|newspaper=Dayton Daily News|date=November 1, 2013|page=AC5}}</ref>\n\nMason lives in [[Nashville]].<ref name=Thrasher />\n\n==Studio albums==\n\n{| This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jamie_Lee_Thurston","to":"Jamie Lee Thurston"}],"pages":{"38595321":{"pageid":38595321,"ns":0,"title":"Jamie Lee Thurston","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country music singer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Jamie Lee Thurston\n| image            =\n| image_size       =\n| landscape        = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank -->\n| alt              =\n| caption          =\n| alias            =\n| birth_place      = [[Montpelier, Vermont]], U.S.<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|date=2008|page=420|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref>\n| origin           = [[Nashville, Tennessee]]\n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation       = Singer-songwriter\n| instrument       = Vocals, guitar\n| years_active     = 2003\u2013present\n| label            = View 2, [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]], Country Thunder, Snakebit\n}}\n'''Jamie Lee Thurston''' is an American [[country music]] singer. He was raised in [[Waterbury, Vermont]] and performed with his father starting at age 15. After moving to Los Angeles, California, he moved again to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] in 1999.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countryweekly.com/vault/jamie-lee-thurston-straight-shooter|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304052945/http://www.countryweekly.com/vault/jamie-lee-thurston-straight-shooter|archivedate=March 4, 2016|title=Jamie Lee Thurston: Straight Shooter|date=March 3, 2003|work=[[Country Weekly]]|accessdate=February 21, 2013}}</ref>\n\nIn 2003, he released the album ''I Just Wanna Do My Thing'' via View 2. The album included the single \"It Can All Be Gone\", which peaked at number 59 on the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. He later signed to [[Warner Bros. Records]] Nashville, then to Country Thunder.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.countryaircheck.com/email_publication/CAT_02_20_07/|title=Country Aircheck|date=February 20, 2007|accessdate=February 21, 2013}}</ref>\n\nThurston wrote [[Rodney Atkins]]' 2009 single \"[[15 Minutes (Rodney Atkins song)|15 Minutes]]\", and cuts by [[Trace Adkins]] and [[Montgomery Gentry]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jamieleethurston.com/bio.php |title=Bio |work=Jamie Lee Thurston |accessdate=February 21, 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115211604/http://www.jamieleethurston.com/bio.php |archivedate=January 15, 2013 }}</ref> In 2013, Thurston appeared on [[Game Show Network]]'s ''[[Family Trade]]'' to compose a jingle for G. Stone Motors in exchange for a new truck.<ref name=\"Family Trade\">{{cite episode|series=Family Trade|network=[[Game Show Network]]|date=April 16, 2013|season=1|number=8}}</ref> The jingle, \"We Trade for Anything\" was also used as the show's opening credits theme music.<ref name=\"Family Trade\"/>\n\nThurston's life is the basis of a screenplay co-written by Tim Rhys, the founder of ''[[MovieMaker]]'' magazine.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:20em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Album details\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| ''I Just Wanna Do My Thing''\n| \n* Release date: 2009\n* Label: CD Baby\n* Format: CD\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| ''Where's an Outlaw When You Need One''\n| \n* Release date: 2010\n* Label: Snakebit\n* Format: CD\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| ''The Stayin Kind''\n| \n* Release date: 2012\n* Label: CD Baby\n* Format: CD\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:12em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak chart<br />positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"65\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n|- \n| 2003\n! scope=\"row\"| \"It Can All Be Gone\"\n| 59\n| ''I Just Wanna Do My Thing''\n|-\n| 2006\n! scope=\"row\"|\"God Bless the Children\" {{small|(with Wayne Warner and the Nashville All-Star Choir)}}<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.waynewarner.com/photos/gbtc/choir.html | title=Nashville All Star Choir | work=Wayne Warner | accessdate=November 28, 2019}}</ref>\n| \u2014\n| ''Turbo Twang'n''\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2007\n! scope=\"row\"| \"People Out There\"\n| \u2014\n| rowspan=2|''I Just Wanna Do My Thing''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Dear God\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Video\n|- \n| 2003\n! scope=\"row\"| \"It Can All Be Gone\"\n|-\n| 2009\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Dance Around The Truth\"\n|-\n| 2017\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Givin' Up Breathin'\"\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.jamieleethurston.com/ Official website]\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Thurston, Jamie Lee}}\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Singers from Vermont]]\n[[Category:People from Montpelier, Vermont]]\n[[Category:Warner Records artists]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jeff_Bates","to":"Jeff Bates"}],"pages":{"2738144":{"pageid":2738144,"ns":0,"title":"Jeff Bates","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{About||the technologist and Slashdot co-founder|Jeff Bates (technologist)|the Australian rules footballer|Jeff Bates (footballer)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n\n{{BLP sources|date=August 2008}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image                = \n| caption              = \n| name                = Jeff Bates\n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          = Jeffery Wayne Bates\n| birth_date          = {{birth date and age|1963|9|19}}<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=45|isbn=0-89820-177-2}}</ref>\n| birth_place         = [[Bunker Hill, Mississippi]], United States\n| origin              = \n| instrument          = Vocals, guitar\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = 2002\u2013present\n| associated_acts     = [[Andy Griggs]]<br />[[Jamey Johnson]]<br />[[Tracy Lawrence]]<br />[[Lonestar]]<br />[[Montgomery Gentry]]\n| label               = [[RCA Records Nashville|RCA Nashville]], [[Black River Entertainment|Black River]] Skydancer Entertainment \n| website             = {{URL|jeffbates.net/}}\n}}\n'''Jeffery Wayne Bates''' (born September 19, 1963) is an American [[country music]] artist. Signed to [[RCA Records Nashville|RCA Nashville]] in late 2002, Bates released his debut album ''Rainbow Man'' in May 2003. In 2005 he released his second album, ''Leave the Light On'', on RCA. He left RCA in 2006. This album was followed by ''Jeff Bates'' in 2008 on the independent [[Black River Entertainment]]. Bates' two RCA albums accounted for seven chart singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts, of which three reached top 40: \"The Love Song\" (his highest, at No.&nbsp;8), \"I Wanna Make You Cry\" at No.&nbsp;23, and \"Long, Slow Kisses\" at No.&nbsp;17.\n\n==Biography==\n{{Expand section|more biographical info|date=November 2007}}\nJeff Bates was born in Bunker Hill, Mississippi, a community in Marion County. He went to East Marion High School in Columbia.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p558738|pure_url=yes}}|title=Jeff Bates biography|last=Jeffries|first=David|work=[[allmusic]]|accessdate=February 17, 2009}}</ref>\n\n==Musical career==\n\n===''Rainbow Man''===\nBefore signing to a record contract, Bates co-wrote [[Tracy Lawrence]]'s 2002 single \"What a Memory\". Bates signed to [[RCA Records]] Nashville in 2003, releasing his debut single, \"[[The Love Song (Jeff Bates song)|The Love Song]]\" in December 2002. Peaking at No.&nbsp;8 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts, it was the first of three singles from his debut album ''[[Rainbow Man]]'',<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> which also produced a No.&nbsp;47 in its title track and a No.&nbsp;23 in \"I Wanna Make You Cry\". Bates co-produced the album with [[David Malloy]], [[Kenny Beard]], and [[Scott Hendricks]].\n\n===''Leave the Light On''===\nHis fourth single, \"[[Long, Slow Kisses]]\", was a re-recording of a cut from his debut album. This re-recording was the third Top 40 hit of his career, peaking at No.&nbsp;17 in 2005. It was also the first of four singles from his second album, ''[[Leave the Light On (Jeff Bates album)|Leave the Light On]]''.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> However, none of the other three singles from this album \u2014 \"Good People\", \"No Shame\" and \"One Second Chance\" \u2014 reached Top 40, (However, \"No Shame\" did reach top 40 at No.&nbsp;40 for Mediabase, which is used by Bob Kingsley's \"Country Top 40\" show), and Bates was dropped from RCA's roster.\n\n===''Jeff Bates''===\nHe signed to [[Black River Entertainment]] in 2008 and released his [[Jeff Bates (album)|self-titled]] third album. The album's first three singles were \"Don't Hate Me for Lovin' You\", \"Riverbank\", and \"One Thing\".\nIn January 2009 he released his first Christmas single \"That's What Christmas Is\" with [[Jimmy Fortune]] of [[The Statler Brothers]] fame singing background vocals.\n\n===''One Day Closer''===\nJeff's second and first EP for Black River, \"One Day Closer\" was released February 15, 2011.\n\n==Personal life==\nAfter signing a contract with Warner-Chappell Publishing, Bates developed a methamphetamine addiction in late 1999. To feed the drug habit, he sold everything he owned and then resorted to stealing, including a guitar from his friend Kenny Beard. On March 14, 2001, he was arrested for drug possession and grand theft. After rehabilitation and jail time, he was given a second chance and signed to RCA. The song \"One Second Chance\" was inspired by this part of his life.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dickinson|first=Chrissie|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/2006/04/09/one-second-chance-cuts-to-bone-of-jeff-bates-story/|title=One Second Chance cuts to the bone of Jeff bates story|work=One Second Chance cuts to the bone of Jeff Bates story|publisher=Chicago Tribune|access-date=February 3, 2012|date=April 9, 2006}}</ref>\n\nIn August 2006, a $3,500 guitar that was a gift to Bates from the [[Takamine Guitars|Takamine]] guitar company and used in his video \"One Second Chance\" was stolen from Bates's garage. When Bates called the [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] police, Det. Rick Mavity was sent to investigate. Mavity was the same officer involved in Bates's arrest in 2001. Mavity located the stolen guitar in a pawn shop and returned it to Bates.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jeff Bates Recovers Stolen Guitar |url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_headlines/article/0,,GAC_26063_4918688,00.html |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130123175010/http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_headlines/article/0,,GAC_26063_4918688,00.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 23, 2013 |accessdate=February 3, 2012 |newspaper=Great American Country |date=August 15, 2006 }}</ref>\n\nIn May 2007, Bates married his girlfriend, Kelly Vaughn,<ref>{{cite web|title=Jeff Bates Pops the Question |url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_headlines/article/0,,GAC_26063_5110632,00.html |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130123161543/http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_headlines/article/0,,GAC_26063_5110632,00.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 23, 2013 |work=Jeff Bates Pops the Question |publisher=Great American Country Headlines |accessdate=February 3, 2012 }}</ref> in an outdoor ceremony. A year later, he signed to [[Black River Music Group]] and released his self-titled third album.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:10em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n! colspan=\"4\"| Peak chart positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"35\"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]<br><ref>{{cite web|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=jeff bates|chart=Country Albums C}}|title=Jeff Bates Album & Song Chart History \u2013 Country Albums|work=Billboard|accessdate=January 12, 2011}}</ref>\n! Year\n! Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 2004\n| \"I Wanna Make You Cry\"\n| Steven L. Weaver\n|-\n| 2005\n| \"Good People\"\n| [[Roman White]]\n|-\n| 2006\n| \"One Second Chance\"\n| [[Deaton-Flanigen Productions|Deaton Flanigen]]\n|-\n| 2008\n| \"Don't Hate Me For Lovin' You\"\n| rowspan=2|Ryan Smith\n|-\n| 2009\n| \"One Thing\"\n|-\n| 2016\n| \"That Thing We Do\"\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p558738|pure_url=yes}} Jeff Bates] at [[Allmusic]]\n* [http://www.jeffbates.net/ Official Jeff Bates website]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Bates, Jeff}}\n[[Category:1963 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:People from Marion County, Mississippi]]\n[[Category:RCA Records Nashville artists]]\n[[Category:Black River Entertainment artists]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Mississippi]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Mississippi]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jeff_Foxworthy","to":"Jeff Foxworthy"}],"pages":{"752960":{"pageid":752960,"ns":0,"title":"Jeff Foxworthy","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American comedian, actor and writer (born 1958)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2023}}\n{{Infobox comedian\n| name           = Jeff Foxworthy\n| image          = Jeff Foxworthy.jpg\n| caption        = Foxworthy in 2010\n| birth_name     = Jeffrey Marshall Foxworthy\n| birth_date     = {{birth date and age|1958|9|6}}\n| birth_place    = [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], U.S.\n| medium         = [[Stand-up comedy|Stand-up]], [[film]], [[radio]], [[television]]\n| active         = 1982\u2013present\n| genre          = {{csv|[[Observational comedy|Observational]]|[[word play]]|[[sitcom]]}}\n| subject        = {{csv|[[Marriage]]|[[Southern culture]]|[[everyday life]]|[[family]]|[[redneck]]s}}\n| spouse         = {{marriage|Pamela Gregg|1985}}\n| children       = 2\n| website        = {{URL|jefffoxworthy.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''Jeffrey Marshall Foxworthy''' (born September 6, 1958) is an American comedian, actor, author, radio and television host, and writer. He is a member of the [[Blue Collar Comedy Tour]], with [[Larry the Cable Guy]], [[Bill Engvall]], and formerly [[Ron White]]. Known for his \"You might be a [[redneck]]\" one-liners, Foxworthy has released six major-label comedy albums. His first two albums were each certified triple [[Platinum album|Platinum]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]]. He has written several books based on his redneck jokes, as well as an autobiography entitled ''No Shirt, No Shoes... No Problem!''<ref name=\"GenePress\">''From Essex England to the Sunny Southern USA: A Harris Family Journey'', Robert E. Harris, Genealogical Press, 1994, page 870.</ref>\n\nFoxworthy has also made several ventures into television, starting in the mid-1990s with his own sitcom called ''[[The Jeff Foxworthy Show]]''. He has also appeared alongside Engvall and Larry the Cable Guy in several Blue Collar television specials, including ''[[Blue Collar TV]]'' for [[The WB]]. In addition, he hosted the game shows ''[[Are You Smarter than a 5th Grader? (American game show)|Are You Smarter than a 5th Grader?]]'' and ''[[The American Bible Challenge]]'', as well as the radio program ''The Foxworthy Countdown''.\n\n==Early life==\nJeffrey Marshall Foxworthy was born in [[Atlanta, Georgia]], on September 6, 1958, the first of three children of Carole Linda (''n\u00e9e'' Camp) and [[IBM]] executive Jimmy Abstance Foxworthy. His parents were both of [[English people|English]] descent,<ref name=\"GenePress\"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/89/Jeff-Foxworthy.html |title=Jeff Foxworthy Biography (1958-) |publisher=Filmreference.com |access-date=October 16, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.surnamedb.com/Surname/Foxworthy|title=Surname Database: Foxworthy Last Name Origin|website=The Internet Surname Database}}</ref> with his roots lying in the county of [[Essex]].<ref name=\"GenePress\"/> His grandfather, James Marvin Camp, was a [[Hapeville, Georgia|Hapeville]] firefighter for over three decades.<ref name=GenePress/> He has two younger siblings, Jay Foxworthy and Jennifer Foxworthy.<ref>{{Cite web|date=February 8, 2013|title=Jeff Foxworthy: a Heart for the Underdog|url=https://www.allprodad.com/jeff-foxworthy-a-heart-for-the-underdog/|access-date=February 12, 2022|website=All Pro Dad|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nFoxworthy graduated from [[Hapeville High School]]. He attended [[Georgia Institute of Technology]] in Atlanta, but left just before graduating.<ref name=\"Redneck Repartee\">{{cite web|url=http://gtalumni.org/Publications/techtopics/fall92/redneck.html |title=Redneck Repartee |publisher=Gtalumni.org |access-date=October 16, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060519041052/http://gtalumni.org/Publications/techtopics/fall92/redneck.html |archive-date=May 19, 2006 }}</ref> He worked for five years in [[mainframe computer]] maintenance at IBM, where his father also worked. At the urging of IBM co-workers, Foxworthy entered and won the Great Southeastern Laugh-off at Atlanta's [[The Punchline|Punchline]] comedy club in 1984.\n\n==Career==\n\n===Comedy albums===\nIn 1993, he released ''[[You Might Be a Redneck If\u2026]]'', which topped the comedy albums chart and started the \"You Might Be a [[Redneck (stereotype)|Redneck]]\" [[fad]]. The album went gold in 1994, platinum by 1995, and 3\u00d7 platinum by 1996, which is more than three million copies.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/|title=Gold & Platinum|website=RIAA|language=en-US|access-date=February 22, 2020}}</ref>\n\nFoxworthy's July 1995 release ''[[Games Rednecks Play]]'' received a 1996 Grammy nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best Comedy Album#1990s|Best Spoken Comedy Album]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/SHOWBIZ/Music/9601/grammy_noms/grammy_list.html |title=List of Grammy nominees - Jan. 4, 1996 |publisher=CNN |date=January 4, 1996 |access-date=October 16, 2010}}</ref>\n\n''[[Totally Committed]]'' was released in May 1998. In conjunction with the album was a one-hour [[HBO]] stand-up special by the same name. The album reached \"gold\" status and received a 1999 Grammy Award nomination.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.utopiaartists.com/bio_jeff_foxworthy.htm |title=Jeff Foxworthy Bio |publisher=Utopia Artists |date=June 12, 2000 |access-date=October 16, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717181445/http://www.utopiaartists.com/bio_jeff_foxworthy.htm |archive-date=July 17, 2011 |url-status=dead }}</ref> The video for the ''Totally Committed'' song featured frequent references to then-[[Atlanta Braves]] [[pitcher]], [[Greg Maddux]] as well as an appearance at the very end by Maddux himself (along with teammate [[John Smoltz]]).\n\nIn 2001, Foxworthy received a nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best Comedy Album#2000s|Best Spoken Comedy Album]] for the 43rd Annual Grammys.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://directory.distributeyourarticles.com/5d91f0f5fb6e/jeff_foxworthy_tickets_foxworthy_received_the_award_for_best_stand_up_comic_at_the_comedy_award|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012051746/http://directory.distributeyourarticles.com/5d91f0f5fb6e/jeff_foxworthy_tickets_foxworthy_received_the_award_for_best_stand_up_comic_at_the_comedy_award|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 12, 2013|title=Directory.distributeyourarticles.com}}</ref>\n\n===Television===\nIn 1995, Foxworthy starred in ''[[The Jeff Foxworthy Show]]'', a sitcom created out of his stand-up comedy persona. It aired on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], but was canceled after one season. [[NBC]] subsequently picked up the show, but it was again canceled after one season. Later, he remarked that the network did not understand how to properly market his humor; thinking his routine was \"too Southern\" for a national network (\"Has anyone heard me talk?\", he commented in one of his stand-up routines), they based the first season of his sitcom in [[Bloomington, Indiana]]. Later, the series aired on [[Nick at Nite]] and [[Country Music Television|CMT]] in 2005 and 2006. He also appeared in [[Alan Jackson]]'s video for \"[[I Don't Even Know Your Name]]\" in 1995.\n\nFoxworthy hosted Country Weekly's \"[[The Nashville Network|TNN]] Music City News Country Awards\" show for 1998, 1999, and 2000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_action=doc&p_docid=110CAD8D8320A8C0&p_docnum=1 |title=Nl.newsbank.com |access-date=August 6, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024163843/http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_action=doc&p_docid=110CAD8D8320A8C0&p_docnum=1 |archive-date=October 24, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nIn 1998, Foxworthy appeared on the mock talk show ''[[Space Ghost Coast to Coast]]'', where he attempts to explain his famous \"You might be a Redneck\" joke to [[Space Ghost]], yet fails entirely. Throughout the episode, Space Ghost, [[Zorak]], and [[Moltar]] are taking the Ghost Planet to the [[United States of America|US]], with plans to make it the 51st state. By the end of the episode Foxworthy is sent to \"The Box\".\n\nHe hosted ''[[Are You Smarter than a 5th Grader? (U.S. game show)|Are You Smarter than A 5th Grader?]]'' on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] in [[prime time]]. He hosted the syndicated version of the series from September 21, 2009, until its cancellation on March 24, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|last=Pursell |first=Chris |url=http://www.tvweek.com/news/2008/09/foxworthy_signs_on_for_syndie.php |title=Foxworthy Signs on for Syndie '5th Grader' | work = In Depth |publisher=TVWeek |access-date=October 16, 2010}}</ref> In 2015 it was announced that Foxworthy would return as host of ''Are You Smarter than a 5th Grader?''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fox.com/article/are-you-smarter-than-a-5th-grader|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209010418/http://www.fox.com/article/are-you-smarter-than-a-5th-grader|url-status=dead|title=Fox.com|archive-date=February 9, 2015}}</ref> In addition, he is a host on ''The Bucks of Tecomate'' which airs on the [[NBC Sports Network]] with Alabama native David Morris.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}}\n\nHe was the subject of a [[Comedy Central Roast]] in 2005.<ref>{{YouTube|_pTQp94T_ts}}</ref>\n\nIn 2011, Foxworthy appeared as a guest \u201cShark\u201d for two episodes of [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s second season of ''[[Shark Tank]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/abc-renews-shark-tank-adds-26467|title= ABC renews 'Shark Tank,' adds Jeff Foxworthy'|date=August 9, 2010|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|access-date=February 7, 2020}}</ref>\n\nSince August 2012, Foxworthy has been the host and a producer of the [[Game Show Network|GSN]] biblical-themed game show ''[[The American Bible Challenge]]'', which has aired two seasons.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/jeff-foxworthy-to-host-the-american-bible-challenge/2012/03/21/gIQAtYcYSS_story.html|title=Jeff Foxworthy to host 'The American Bible Challenge'|date=March 21, 2012|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|access-date=April 5, 2012}}</ref> He is also the host of the food [[reality competition]] series ''[[The American Baking Competition]]'', which aired its first season in summer 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2013/03/05/jeff-foxworthy-to-host-the-american-baking-competition-premiering-wednesday-may-29-on-cbs/172120/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130505011054/http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2013/03/05/jeff-foxworthy-to-host-the-american-baking-competition-premiering-wednesday-may-29-on-cbs/172120/|url-status=dead|archive-date=May 5, 2013|title=Jeff Foxworthy to Host 'The American Baking Competition' premiering Wednesday May 29 on CBS|last=Bibel|first=Sara|publisher=TV by the Numbers|date=March 5, 2013|access-date=March 16, 2013}}</ref>\n\nFoxworthy has appeared as host and featured guest on several programs on the [[Outdoor Channel]] and [[Versus (TV network)|Versus]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.outdoorchannel.com/video.aspx?g=hunting&f=KVKomFAWRC3s&guid=rQyYFY5at6KMBkN42SHIJRqF8vEO9Vzf|title=Outdoor Channel - Watch Videos Hunting|first=Outdoor|last=Channel|website=Outdoorchannel.com|access-date=August 4, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808052927/http://www.outdoorchannel.com/video.aspx?g=hunting&f=KVKomFAWRC3s&guid=rQyYFY5at6KMBkN42SHIJRqF8vEO9Vzf|archive-date=August 8, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fallingblind.com/home/blog/bucks-of-tecomate-versus-channel|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140810230744/http://www.fallingblind.com/home/blog/bucks-of-tecomate-versus-channel|url-status=dead|title=Fallingblind.com|archive-date=August 10, 2014}}</ref>\n\nIn February 2019, Foxworthy was announced as a judge for NBC's comedy competition series ''[[Bring the Funny]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2019/tv/news/nbc-bring-the-funny-1203126089/|title=NBC Orders Comedy Competition Series With Jeff Foxworthy Among Judges|first=Joe|last=Otterson|work=Variety|date=February 1, 2019}}</ref>\n\nIn 2020, a new episode of ''[[Ellen's Game of Games]]'' featured Jeff Foxworthy on a game of Stink Tank.\n\n===Blue Collar Comedy===\n[[File:Jeff Foxworthy at Resch Center.jpg|thumb|Foxworthy in performance at the Resch Center in Green Bay in 2015]]\nIn the early 2000s, Foxworthy had a career resurgence as a result of the [[Blue Collar Comedy Tour]], in which he and three other comedians ([[Larry the Cable Guy]], [[Ron White]], and [[Bill Engvall]]), specializing in common-man comedy, toured the country and performed for record crowds. The tour lasted three full years, constantly being extended after an initial run of 20 shows.\n\nIn 2004, he launched a new television series called ''[[Blue Collar TV]]'' on [[The WB]]. He served as [[executive producer]] and starred alongside Blue Collar Comedy Tour-mates Larry the Cable Guy and Bill Engvall. (Ron White made occasional guest appearances.) On Larry the Cable Guy's website, he posted that the show was canceled on October 17, 2005, by The WB. Reruns of ''Blue Collar TV'' continued until the network merged with [[UPN]] to form [[The CW]]. In 2006, Foxworthy resurrected the ''Blue Collar TV'' format on [[Country Music Television]] (CMT) with ''Foxworthy's Big Night Out''. The show began airing in the fall and was canceled after one season of 12 episodes.\n\n===Books===\nFoxworthy has authored several books, including ''You Might Be a Redneck If...'' (1989), as well as his autobiography, ''No Shirt, No Shoes, No Problem!'' (1996). Artist [[Layron DeJarnette]] provided illustrations for the Redneck Dictionary books. R. David Boyd has been the exclusive illustrator for most of Foxworthy's books and album covers.\n\nHe also has released a [[cookbook]] entitled ''The Redneck Grill'', co-authored with [[Newnan, Georgia]], artist R. David Boyd, and \"''Redneck Extreme Mobile Home Makeover''\" (2005), a book with some of his redneck jokes.\n\n===Written works===\n* ''Jeff Foxworthy's Redneck Dictionary: Words You Thought You Knew the Meaning Of'' (2005)\n* ''Jeff Foxworthy's Redneck Dictionary II: More Words You Thought You Knew the Meaning Of'' (2006)\n* ''Jeff Foxworthy's Redneck Dictionary III: Learning to Talk More Gooder Fastly'' (2007)\n* ''Rednecks in College''\n\nIn February 2008, Foxworthy released his first children's book ''Dirt On My Shirt''. This was followed by ''Silly Street'' in 2009 and ''Hide!!!'' in 2010, both of which were illustrated by Steve Bjorkman.\n\nIn May 2008, Foxworthy released ''How to Really Stink at Golf'', with co-author [[Brian Hartt]] and illustrations by [[Layron DeJarnette]]. In May 2009, he released ''How to Really Stink at Work, A Guide to Making Yourself Fire-Proof While Having the Most Fun Possible''. This book was also co-authored with Hartt and illustrations by [[DeJarnette]].\n\n===Radio work===\nIn April 1999, Foxworthy began ''The Foxworthy Countdown'', a nationally [[radio syndication|syndicated]], weekly [[radio show]], which featured the top 30 country hits of the week, as reported by ''[[Mediabase]]''. In 2001, he received a [[Country Music Association]] nomination for \"Broadcast Personality of the Year\". The program's last broadcast, the 2009 year-end countdown, aired the weekend of December 27, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bmi.com/news/entry/233011 |title=News &#124; Sara Evans Soars to New Heights with 2001 CMA Nominations |publisher=BMI.com |date=August 28, 2001 |access-date=October 16, 2010}}</ref> In 2006, [[Sirius Satellite Radio]] launched the Blue Collar Comedy channel, which featured stand-up comedy centered around the Blue Collar group. In 2015, now under the [[SiriusXM]] banner, the station rebranded as [[Jeff & Larry's Comedy Roundup]], which featured similar programming to the previous channel with an enhanced focus on Foxworthy and Larry the Cable Guy.<ref>{{cite press release|url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/jeff-foxworthy-and-larry-the-cable-guy-to-launch-247-comedy-channel-exclusively-on-siriusxm-300050105.html|title=Jeff Foxworthy and Larry the Cable Guy to launch 24/7 comedy channel exclusively on SiriusXM|date=March 13, 2015|access-date=May 30, 2019}}</ref>\n\n===Foxworthy Outdoors===\nIn August 2011, Foxworthy launched Foxworthy Outdoors, a website carrying an assortment of Foxworthy-brand hunting and outdoors products. On the site, he also hosts a [[web series]] called ''Jeff Foxworthy: Inside & Out'', featuring some of his friends as they document hunting trips, fishing outings, and land conservation on his [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] farm.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxworthyoutdoors.com/videos/category/inside-out|title=Comedian, Outdoorsman, Guy - Jeff Foxworthy|website=Foxworthyoutdoors.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title = Watch the best outdoor shows for free on CarbonTV|url = http://www.carbontv.com/shows/foxworthy-outdoors-inside-and-out/|website = CarbonTV|access-date = February 8, 2016}}</ref>\n\n=== Other ===\nIn 2017 Foxworthy created the [[card game]] ''Relative Insanity'', a game similar to [[Cards Against Humanity]] with a family theme. Family Game Shelf praised the game, saying \"it will have you laughing until your sides hurt\".<ref>{{Cite web |date=October 26, 2021 |title=Relative Insanity Game Review |url=https://familygameshelf.com/2021/10/26/relative-insanity/ |access-date=October 16, 2022 |website=Family Game Shelf |language=en-US}}</ref>[[File:Us mil Foxworthy 0411.jpg|thumb|Foxworthy accepting a new jacket from 3rd Infantry Division Commander Army Maj. Gen. William G. Webster for his support]]\n\n==Personal life==\nFoxworthy met his wife Pamela Gregg at the Punchline in [[Atlanta]], Georgia, and they married on September 18, 1985.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dispatch.com/article/20080303/entertainment/303039930 |title=Family time comes first for comedian - Entertainment - The Columbus Dispatch - Columbus, OH |website=Dispatch.com |date=March 3, 2008 |access-date=April 28, 2020}}</ref> They have two daughters, Jordan and Julianne.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://people.com/parents/jeff-foxworthy/|title=Jeff Foxworthy Leaves Daughters 'Mortified'|website=People.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.atlantaparent.com/jeff_foxworthy_on_being_a_dad/ |title=Jeff Foxworthy on Being a Dad |website=Atlantaparent.com |date=November 29, 2017 |access-date=April 28, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.miamiherald.com/miami-com/miami-com-news/article225866320.html |title=Comedy star Jeff Foxworthy depressed after losing one daughter, writes family book |website=www.miamiherald.com |access-date=January 13, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191010130015/https://www.miamiherald.com/miami-com/miami-com-news/article225866320.html |archive-date=October 10, 2019 |url-status=dead}}</ref> He is a noted hunting enthusiast, beginning when he was a teen hunting on his father's farm property in Central Georgia.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}\n\n===Political positions===\nFoxworthy claims to keep his jokes [[Apoliticism|apolitical]] and has criticized the [[memes]] circulating on social media that appear to show him making jokes at the expense of [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberals]] in his stand-up.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hickman |first=Matt |title=The Good Redneck: Jeff Foxworthy wonders what the hell happened to our country |url=https://www.anchoragepress.com/arts_and_entertainment/the-good-redneck-jeff-foxworthy-wonders-what-the-hell-happened-to-our-country/article_95016c62-c43b-11e9-8ddf-3717a1f4b97f.html |access-date=October 16, 2022 |website=The Anchorage Press |date=August 21, 2019 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=March 2, 2020 |title=Comic Jeff Foxworthy Says All Those Right-Wing Memes That Quote Him Are Fake |url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/jeff-foxworthy-political-memes_n_5e5c8186c5b6beedb4edad58 |access-date=October 16, 2022 |website=HuffPost |language=en}}</ref> Despite this, he donated to the presidential campaign of [[George W. Bush]], as well as the [[Republican National Committee]] in the 2000's.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Dana|first=Rebecca|date=May 21, 2014|title=Why Game Show Hosts Vote Republican|language=en|work=The Daily Beast|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2010/10/31/why-game-show-hosts-vote-republican|access-date=August 15, 2020}}</ref> \nIn 2012, Foxworthy endorsed Republican presidential candidate [[Mitt Romney]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Bingham, Amy|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/OTUS/jeff-foxworthy-throws-redneck-cred-mitt-romney/story?id=15901753|title=Celebrity Endorsements: Jeff Foxworthy Backs Mitt Romney|publisher=ABC News|date=March 12, 2012|access-date=October 19, 2015}}</ref> and later stated that [[Donald Trump]] is \"tapping into the American spirit\".<ref>{{Cite web |last=Caterina |first=Peter |date=September 1, 2015 |title=Jeff Foxworthy On Donald Trump: He Is Tapping Into The American Spirit.|url=https://radio.foxnews.com/2015/09/01/jeff-foxworthy-on-donald-trump-he-is-tapping-into-the-american-spirit/}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Jeff Foxworthy discography}}\n\nFoxworthy has released five comedy albums for [[Warner Bros. Records]], as well as one for [[DreamWorks Records]]. One of his albums included the novelty Christmas song \"[[Redneck 12 Days of Christmas]]\", which reached No. 18 on the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts in late 1995 to early 1996.\n\n==Filmography==\n\n=== Film ===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n!Year\n!Title\n!Role\n!Notes\n|-\n|2003\n|''[[Blue Collar Comedy Tour: The Movie]]''\n|Himself\n|\n|-\n|2005\n|''[[Racing
