Year\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 2001\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Mrs. Steven Rudy\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/mark-mcguinn/387416/mrs-steven-rudy.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090519192624/http://www.cmt.com/videos/mark-mcguinn/387416/mrs-steven-rudy.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=May 19, 2009|title=CMT : Videos : Mark McGuinn : Mrs. Steven Rudy|publisher=[[Country Music Television]]|accessdate=August 5, 2011}}</ref>\n| rowspan=\"2\"| David Abbott\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"That's a Plan\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/mark-mcguinn/387884/thats-a-plan.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024011431/http://www.cmt.com/videos/mark-mcguinn/387884/thats-a-plan.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 24, 2012|title=CMT : Videos : Mark McGuinn : That's A Plan|publisher=[[Country Music Television]]|accessdate=August 5, 2011}}</ref>\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"She Doesn't Dance\"\n| Eric Welch\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[https://www.markmcguinn.com MarkMcGuinn.com]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:McGuinn, Mark}}\n[[Category:1968 births]]\n[[Category:American country pianists]]\n[[Category:American male pianists]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Greensboro, North Carolina]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from North Carolina]]\n[[Category:20th-century American pianists]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from North Carolina]]\n[[Category:21st-century American pianists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American male musicians]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male musicians]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Grimsley High School alumni]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jamey_Johnson","to":"Jamey Johnson"}],"pages":{"2738121":{"pageid":2738121,"ns":0,"title":"Jamey Johnson","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country musician}}\n{{distinguish|Jamie Johnson (disambiguation){{!}}Jamie Johnson}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2022}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name = Jamey Johnson\n| image = Jamey Johnson 2016 (26977803203).jpg\n| caption = Johnson in 2016\n| birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1975|07|14}}<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jhZfSZI4djl_MxnRykC5lZzlBMYQD99E06B01|title=Today in History \u2013 July 14|agency=Associated Press|access-date=July 17, 2009}}{{dead link|date=June 2024|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>\n| birth_place = [[Enterprise, Alabama]], U.S.\n| origin = [[Montgomery, Alabama]], U.S.\n| instrument = Vocals, guitar\n| genre = {{hlist|[[country music|Country]]|[[outlaw country]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://journalstar.com/entertainment/music/on-the-beat-jamey-johnson-to-bring-true-outlaw-country-to-bourbon/article_607e0764-907d-5821-86d9-3ff2f356bae5.html |title=On the Beat: Jamey Johnson to bring true outlaw country to Bourbon |last= |first= |date= October 19, 2018|work= Lincoln Journal-Star|access-date=2023-07-25}}</ref>|}}\n| occupation = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active = 2005\u2013present\n| label = [[BNA Records|BNA]], [[Universal Music Group Nashville|Mercury Nashville]], Big Gassed\n| website = {{URL|jameyjohnson.com}}\n| associated_acts = [[Buddy Cannon]]\n}}\n\n'''Jamey Johnson''' (born July 14, 1975) is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter.\n\nSigned to [[BNA Records]] in 2005, Johnson made his debut with his single \"[[The Dollar (song)|The Dollar]]\", the title track to his 2006 album ''[[The Dollar (album)|The Dollar]]''. He was dropped from BNA in 2006 and signed to [[Mercury Nashville Records]] in March 2008, releasing his second album, the [[gold album|gold]]-certified ''[[That Lonesome Song]]''. This album produced two singles, the top 10 hit \"[[In Color (song)|In Color]]\" and \"High Cost of Living\". Johnson has since released two more albums, ''[[The Guitar Song]]'' in 2010 and ''[[Living for a Song: A Tribute to Hank Cochran]]'' in 2012. In 2014, he released a five-song Christmas EP titled ''The Christmas Song''. In addition to most of his own material, Johnson has co-written singles for [[Willie Nelson]] and [[Merle Haggard]], [[Trace Adkins]], [[George Strait]], [[James Otto]], [[Joe Nichols]], and [[Jessie James Decker]].\n\n== Early life ==\nJohnson was born on July 14, 1975, in [[Enterprise, Alabama]], and raised in [[Montgomery, Alabama]]. From an early age, he was influenced by country acts such as [[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]] and [[Alan Jackson]]; the latter was the first act he saw in concert.<ref name=\"cmt\">{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1525579/jamey-johnson-stirs-fans-with-the-dollar/ |title=Jamey Johnson Stirs Fans With \"The Dollar\" |access-date=March 28, 2008 |last=Morris |first=Edward |date=March 7, 2006 |publisher=[[Country Music Television]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190510153359/http://www.cmt.com/news/1525579/jamey-johnson-stirs-fans-with-the-dollar/ |archive-date=May 10, 2019 |url-status=dead }}</ref> After graduating from [[Jefferson Davis High School (Montgomery, Alabama)|Jefferson Davis High School]], Johnson attended [[Jacksonville State University]], the same university from which Alabama lead singer [[Randy Owen]] graduated.<ref name=\"cmt\" /> During his time at Jacksonville State, he was a member of the [[Marching Southerners]].\n\nJohnson quit college after two years and served in the [[United States Marine Corps Reserve]] for four years.<ref name=\"cmt\" /> While in the Marines, he began playing country music in various bars in the Montgomery area; one of his first gigs was opening for [[David Allan Coe]].<ref name=\"cmt\" /> By 2000, Johnson had moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], to pursue a career in country music. One of his first connections was with Greg Perkins, a fiddler who had played for [[Tanya Tucker]], [[Tammy Wynette]], and other artists. Perkins invited Johnson to sing as a duet partner with [[Gretchen Wilson]] on a demo tape.<ref name=\"cmt\" /> Songs for which Johnson sang demos include \"Songs About Me\" (cut by [[Trace Adkins]]) and \"That's How They Do It in Dixie\" (cut by [[Hank Williams, Jr.]] with [[Big & Rich]], Gretchen Wilson, and [[Van Zant (band)|Van Zant]]).<ref name=\"cmt\" />\n\nJohnson had also made connections with producer and songwriter [[Buddy Cannon]], who helped him land a songwriting contract.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p747306/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Jamey Johnson biography |access-date=March 28, 2008 |last=Monger |first=James Christopher |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> Among Johnson's first cuts as a songwriter was \"[[Honky Tonk Badonkadonk]]\", which Adkins released from his 2005 album ''[[Songs About Me]]''. That song he co-wrote along with hit songwriter Dallas Davidson and fellow country singer-songwriter [[Randy Houser]], who later worked with Johnson again co-writing \"My Cowboy\" for [[country pop]] singer [[Jessie James]] for her [[Jessie James (album)|self-titled debut album]].\n\n== Career ==\n\n=== Career beginnings and ''That Lonesome Song'' (2005\u20132009) ===\nBy 2005, Johnson had been signed to a recording contract with [[BNA Records]]. His first single, entitled \"[[The Dollar (song)|The Dollar]]\", was released that year, followed by his [[Buddy Cannon]]-produced debut album (also entitled ''[[The Dollar (album)|The Dollar]]'') in March 2006. \"The Dollar\" went on to peak at No.&nbsp;14 on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]]. The album's second single, \"Rebelicious\", failed to make the chart and Johnson was dropped from BNA.\n\nAfter the loss of his record deal, Johnson divorced his wife and took on a reclusive lifestyle, residing in a friend's house while working on his songwriting.<ref name=\"yahoo\">{{cite web |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20080712/music_nm/johnson_dc |title=Singer Johnson starts fresh after \"Lonesome\" time |access-date=July 25, 2008 |last=Tucker |first=Ken |date=July 1, 2008|work=Yahoo! News}} {{dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> He wrote several songs for other artists. In 2006, [[George Strait]] reached No.&nbsp;1 on the Country chart with \"[[Give It Away (George Strait song)|Give It Away]]\", a song which Johnson co-wrote with [[Bill Anderson (singer)|Bill Anderson]] and Cannon. This song became Strait's 51st<!--not fifty-fifth; fifty-five counts ALL charts--> No.&nbsp;1 on the ''Billboard'' country charts, setting a new record for most No.&nbsp;1s on that chart.\n\nIn 2007, Trace Adkins charted with two more songs that Johnson co-wrote: \"[[Ladies Love Country Boys]]\" and \"I Got My Game On\", the former being Adkins' first No.&nbsp;1 in 10 years. Also in 2007, [[Joe Nichols]] reached Top 20 with \"[[Another Side of You]]\", another song co-written by Johnson. This song was the first single on Nichols's album ''[[Real Things (Joe Nichols album)|Real Things]]'', which also contained \"She's All Lady\", a song that Johnson originally recorded on ''The Dollar''.\n\nJohnson was part of the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox TV]] television series ''[[Nashville (2007 TV series)|Nashville]]'',<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20054999,00.html |title=TV Preview \u2013 ''Nashville'' |access-date=August 15, 2008 |date=September 1, 2007|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090126211531/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20054999,00.html |archive-date=January 26, 2009 |url-status=dead }}</ref> which was cancelled after two episodes in September 2007.\n\n[[File:JameyJohnson.jpg|thumb|Johnson performing in 2008]]\nJohnson released an album in 2008, ''[[That Lonesome Song]]'', which was only made available online.<ref name=\"yahoo\" /> The album drew the attention of [[Universal Music Group Nashville|Mercury Nashville Records]], who signed him to a record deal in 2008. His first single for the label, \"[[In Color (song)|In Color]]\", was released in March 2008. This song, which Johnson co-wrote with [[Lee Thomas Miller]] and [[James Otto]], entered the Top 40 in June 2008, and ''That Lonesome Song'' was released on CD in August of that year. \"In Color\" peaked at No.&nbsp;9 on the Country chart in January 2009 and was followed a month later by \"High Cost of Living\", which managed to crack the Top 40, but only reaching No.&nbsp;34. By April 2009, ''That Lonesome Song'' was certified Gold by the [[RIAA]].\n\nA fifth single, \"My Way to You\", was issued in July 2009. The song was released to radio on July 13, 2009, and debuted at No.&nbsp;56 on the U.S. ''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs chart. The song peaked at No.&nbsp;52 in September 2009.\n\nJohnson was nominated for the 2009 CMA Awards New Artist of the Year, and has been nominated for the 2010 Academy of Country Music Top New Solo Vocalist.\n\n=== ''The Guitar Song'' (2010\u20132012) ===\nIn 2010, Johnson released a follow-up to his 2008 album, ''[[That Lonesome Song]]''. The album titled ''[[The Guitar Song]]'' was released on September 14, 2010. Upon its release, ''The Guitar Song'' was met with overwhelming praise and universal acclaim from music critics.<ref name=\"Metacritic\">{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/the-guitar-song |title=The Guitar Song reviews at Metacritic.com |work=[[Metacritic]] |access-date=September 16, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100918031551/http://www.metacritic.com/music/the-guitar-song |archive-date=September 18, 2010 |url-status=live }}</ref> The album debuted at number four on the U.S. [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and number one on the U.S. ''Billboard'' [[Top Country Albums]], selling 63,000 copies its first week of release.<ref name=\"Billboard 200\">{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/956178/linkin-park-and-trey-songz-debut-at-nos-1-2-on-billboard-200 |title=Linkin Park and Trey Songz Debut At Nos. 1 & 2 on Billboard 200 |last=Caulfield |first=Keith |publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=September 2, 2010|access-date=September 22, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130623020324/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/956178/linkin-park-and-trey-songz-debut-at-nos-1-2-on-billboard-200 |archive-date=June 23, 2013 |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nJohnson released three singles from the album, including \"Playing the Part\", in summer 2010. The music video for the single was released in October, and was directed by [[Matthew McConaughey]], who also stars in the video as a dancing gorilla.\n\nJohnson was the supporting act on [[Kid Rock]]'s 2011 Born Free Tour, accompanying Rock on a duet or two during most concerts.  He was also a main stage act on Willie Nelson's Country Throwdown from May to July 2011.\n\n=== ''Living for a Song'' and new label (2012\u2013present) ===\nIn addition to producing other acts and writing new material,<ref>{{cite web|last=Skates|first=Sarah|title=Jamey Johnson Plans New Album, Produces Other Artists|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2011/05/jamey-johnson-plans-new-album-produces-other-artists/|work=MusicRow|date=May 24, 2011|access-date=June 17, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511174417/http://www.musicrow.com/2011/05/jamey-johnson-plans-new-album-produces-other-artists/|archive-date=May 11, 2012|url-status=live}}</ref> Johnson released his fourth studio album titled ''[[Living for a Song: A Tribute to Hank Cochran]]'' on October 6, 2012. The album is a tribute to songwriter [[Hank Cochran]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theboot.com/2012/07/31/jamey-johnson-album-hank-cochran-living-for-a-song/ |title=Jamey Johnson Album, 'Hank Cochran: Living for a Song' Due October 16 |website=Theboot.com |date=July 31, 2012 |access-date=April 4, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130522072028/http://www.theboot.com/2012/07/31/jamey-johnson-album-hank-cochran-living-for-a-song/ |archive-date=May 22, 2013 |url-status=live }}</ref> The album garnered Johnson a nomination at the [[55th Grammy Awards]] for Best Country album. The album paired him with acts such as [[Ray Price (musician)|Ray Price]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[Alison Krauss]], [[Emmylou Harris]], [[Elvis Costello]], [[George Strait]], [[Vince Gill]], and [[Merle Haggard]]. Longtime collaborator and producer [[Buddy Cannon]] oversaw the project.<ref>{{cite web|last=Betts|first=Stephen|title=Jamey Johnson Duets Album Pays Tribute to Hank Cochran|url=http://www.theboot.com/2012/03/29/jamey-johnson-duets-album-hank-cochran/|work=The Boot|date=March 29, 2012 |access-date=June 17, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120719144822/http://www.theboot.com/2012/03/29/jamey-johnson-duets-album-hank-cochran/|archive-date=July 19, 2012|url-status=live}}</ref> The album was released on vinyl September 25, 2012, and other formats on October 16, 2012.<ref name=\"Jamey Johnson salutes Hank Cochran\">{{cite news|title=Jamey Johnson salutes iconic country songwriter Hank Cochran with star-studded duets album|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/music/jamey-johnson-salutes-iconic-country-songwriter-hank-cochran-with-star-studded-duets-album/2012/07/31/gJQAZruMMX_story.html|newspaper=The Washington Post|agency=Associated Press|access-date=July 31, 2012}} {{dead link|date=April 2014|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}{{cbignore}}</ref>\n\nFollowing a dispute with his label, Johnson founded his own label, Big Gassed Records. His first release on the label was a Christmas-themed EP, ''[[The Christmas Song (EP)|The Christmas Song]]'', including several covers and one new original song, which was released in November 2014. It was announced that more new music would follow in 2015.<ref name=RSIndie>{{cite magazine|title=Jamey Johnson Reveals Surprise Christmas EP and Reveals New Indie Direction|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/jamey-johnson-previews-surprise-christmas-ep-and-reveals-his-new-indie-direction-20141124?page=2|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=November 27, 2014|date=November 24, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141203201916/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/jamey-johnson-previews-surprise-christmas-ep-and-reveals-his-new-indie-direction-20141124?page=2|archive-date=December 3, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref> In January 2015, Johnson released a new song, \"Alabama Pines\" as a free download.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bjorke|first1=Matt|title=Get a Jamey Johnson Single for Free|url=http://roughstock.com/news/2015/01/31756-get-a-jamey-johnson-single-free/|website=Roughstock|access-date=January 5, 2015|date=January 3, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150105215423/http://roughstock.com/news/2015/01/31756-get-a-jamey-johnson-single-free/|archive-date=January 5, 2015|url-status=live}}</ref> This was followed by the release of another single, \"You Can\", in February.<ref name=FebSingle>{{cite web|last1=Dunkerley|first1=Beville|title=Jamey Johnson Goes 'Big Band Meets Vaudeville' on New Song 'You Can'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/jamey-johnson-goes-big-band-meets-vaudeville-on-new-song-you-can-20150210|website=Rollingstone.com|access-date=February 15, 2015|date=February 10, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150212222443/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/jamey-johnson-goes-big-band-meets-vaudeville-on-new-song-you-can-20150210|archive-date=February 12, 2015|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nIn a 2017 interview, Johnson stated that he had been having more difficulty with songwriting after an incident about seven years prior when he received a concussion due to slipping on ice and hitting his head.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/jamey-johnson-concussion-songwriting/|title=Jamey Johnson Cites Years-Old Concussion for Lack of Songs|work=Taste of Country\n|first=Sterling|last=Whitaker|date=June 14, 2017|access-date=July 27, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kentuckycountrymusic.com/2017/06/jamey-johnson-reflects-on-his.html|title=Jamey Johnson reflects on his relationship with God, family, and fans|website=Kentucky Country Music|first=Jessica|last=Bray|date=June 11, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170616232854/http://www.kentuckycountrymusic.com/2017/06/jamey-johnson-reflects-on-his.html|access-date=July 27, 2020|archive-date=June 16, 2017}}</ref> In 2019, Johnson played alongside [[Don Was]], [[Warren Haynes]], [[Lukas Nelson]], and [[Cyril Neville]] on ''The Last Waltz Tour'', a live celebration of [[The Band]]'s 1976 farewell show at the [[Winterland Ballroom]], also known as ''[[The Last Waltz]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://blackbirdpresents.com/concert/the-last-waltz-tour-2019/ |title=The Last Waltz 40 Tour 2019 |website=Blackbirdpresents.com |access-date=April 4, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200110190724/https://blackbirdpresents.com/concert/the-last-waltz-tour-2019/ |archive-date=January 10, 2020 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://liveforlivemusic.com/news/last-waltz-tour-2019-capitol-theatre-11-5-19/|title=Warren Haynes, John Medeski, More Open 'The Last Waltz Tour 2019' At The Capitol Theatre [Videos]|date=November 6, 2019|website=L4LM|access-date=April 7, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191212051453/https://liveforlivemusic.com/news/last-waltz-tour-2019-capitol-theatre-11-5-19/|archive-date=December 12, 2019|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nOn March 19, 2022, [[Bill Anderson (singer)|Bill Anderson]] invited him to become a member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]], which he accepted; Johnson had performed regularly on the show for the previous seventeen years.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2022/03/20/jamey-johnson-invited-become-newest-grand-ole-opry-member/7111654001/|title=Jamey Johnson invited to become newest Grand Ole Opry member|work=The Tennessean|date=March 20, 2022|first=Matthew|last=Leimkuehler|access-date=March 20, 2022}}</ref> He was inducted on May 14, 2022.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.opry.com/artists/jamey-johnson/|title=Jamey Johnson|publisher=Grand Ole Opry|access-date=June 25, 2022}}</ref>\n\nOn December 15, 2023, Johnson gave the [[commencement speech]] to the 2023 Fall graduating class of Jacksonville State University and received an honorary doctorate from the school. Alabama Governor [[Kay Ivey]] proclaimed December 15 Jamey Johnson Day.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jameyjohnson.com/news/jamey-johnson-receives-honorary-doctorate-from-jacksonville-state-university-during-jamey-johnson-day-in-alabama|title=Jamey Johnson Receives Honorary Doctorate from Jacksonville State University During Jamey Johnson Day in Alabama|work=Jamey Johnson's official website|date=December 18, 2023|access-date=December 19, 2023}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Highway Feet\" <small>(with Larry Fleet) </small>\n| ''Stack of Records''\n|-\n| rowspan=\"6\"| 2022\n| \"Stubborn Pride'\" <small>(with [[Zac Brown Band]])</small>\n| ''[[The Comeback (Zac Brown Band album)|The Comeback]]''\n|-\n| \"If I Needed You\" <small>(with Rachel Bradshaw)</small>\n| ''Rachel Bradshaw''\n|-\n| \"Just Dropped In (To See What Condition My Condition Is In)\"\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''Kenny Rogers: All In For The Gambler ''\n|-\n| \"Sweet Music Man\"\n|-\n| \"Music City's Killing Me\" <small>(with [[Julie Roberts]])</small>\n| ''TBA''\n|-\n| \"[[I'm Just an Old Chunk of Coal (But I'm Gonna Be a Diamond Someday)]]\"\n| ''Something Borrowed, Something New: A Tribute to [[John Anderson (musician)|John Anderson]]''\n|}\n\n== Awards and nominations ==\nJohnson received three [[Grammy Award]] nominations at the [[51st Grammy Awards]]: Best Country Album for ''That Lonesome Song'', and Best Country Song and Best Male Country Vocal Performance for \"In Color\".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.grammy.com/grammy_awards/51st_show/list.aspx |title=THE 51ST ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS NOMINATIONS LIST |date=December 4, 2008 |work=[[Grammy Award]] |access-date=December 4, 2008 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081205000239/http://www.grammy.com/GRAMMY_Awards/51st_Show/list.aspx |archive-date=December 5, 2008 }}</ref> \"In Color\" won the [[Academy of Country Music]]'s 2009 award for Song of the Year and the same award during the 2009 [[Country Music Association Awards]]. Going into 2010, Johnson received two more [[Grammy Award]] nominations for the [[52nd Grammy Awards]]: Best Country Song and Best Male Country Vocal Performance, both for his 2009 single \"High Cost of Living\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grammy.com/grammy_awards/52nd_show/list.aspx |title=THE 52ND ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS NOMINATIONS LIST |date=December 2, 2009 |work=[[Grammy Award]] |access-date=December 3, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091203194315/http://www.grammy.com/grammy_awards/52nd_show/list.aspx |archive-date=December 3, 2009 }}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2007\n| [[Academy of Country Music]]\n| Song of the Year \u2013 ''Give It Away''\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| [[Country Music Association]]\n| Song of the Year \"In Color\"\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Best Male Country Vocal Performance \u2013 \"In Color\"\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| [[Academy of Country Music]]\n| Song of the Year \u2013 \"In Color\"\n| Lambert]])</small>\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n|rowspan=3|2011\n|rowspan=3|[[53rd Grammy Awards]]\n| Best Male Country Vocal Performance \u2013 \"Macon\"\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Best Country Collaboration with Vocals \u2013 \"Bad Angel\" <small>(with Dierks Bentley and Miranda Lambert)</small>\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Best Country Album \u2013 ''The Guitar Song''\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| 2013\n| [[55th Grammy Awards]]\n| Best Country Album \u2013 ''Living for a Song: A Tribute to Hank Cochran''\n| {{nom}}\n|}\n\n== References ==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n* {{official website}}\n* {{Discogs artist|Jamey Johnson}}\n* {{IMDb name|id=2780010}}\n\n{{Jamey Johnson}}\n{{Grand Ole Opry members}}\n{{CMA for Song of the Year}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Johnson, Jamey}}\n[[Category:1975 the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Trent_Willmon","to":"Trent Willmon"}],"pages":{"5041187":{"pageid":5041187,"ns":0,"title":"Trent Willmon","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Trent Willmon\n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = \n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1973|03|06}}\n| origin           = [[Afton, Texas]], United States\n| instrument       = Vocals, acoustic guitar\n| genre            = [[country music|Country]]\n| occupation       = Singer-songwriter, record producer\n| years_active     = 1998\u2013present\n| label            = [[Sony Music Nashville|Columbia Nashville]], [[Compadre Records|Compadre]]\n| website          = [http://trentwillmon.com/ www.trentwillmon.com]\n}}\n'''Trent Willmon''' (born March 6, 1973) is an American [[country music]] artist, [[songwriter]], and [[Record producer|producer]]. Active since 1998 as a songwriter in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], Willmon was signed to [[Columbia Records]] in 2004. He released two albums for the label (2004's ''[[Trent Willmon (album)|Trent Willmon]]'' and 2006's ''[[A Little More Livin']]'') and charted six singles on the U.S. ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts before exiting Columbia in 2006. A third album, ''[[Broken In]]'', was released on the independent Compadre label in February 2008.\n\n==Musical career==\nWillmon was born in [[Amarillo, Texas]]<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p668804|pure_url=yes}} |title=Trent Willmon biography |accessdate=January 1, 2008 |last=Ruhlmann |first=William |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> and was raised on a ranch near [[Afton, Texas]]. After 2 years at South Plains College as an Animal Science major, he left to pursue music, playing with several Texas- based bands, including playing bass for bluegrass legend Karl Shiflett. In 1999 he signed a staff writing deal with SeaGayle Music. One of his first cuts as a songwriter was \"It Doesn't Mean I Don't Love You\", which he co-wrote with [[Bobby Pinson]] and Jeremy Spillman. It was recorded by the duo [[McHayes]] (which comprised 1990s country singer [[Wade Hayes]] and fiddler Mark McClurg), and reached 41 on the country charts in 2003.\n\nWillmon signed with [[Columbia Records]] in 2004. His [[Trent Willmon (album)|self-titled debut album]] was released that year, and it produced four singles. The first of these was \"Beer Man\", which peaked at 30 on the country charts. Following it were \"Dixie Rose Deluxe's Honky-Tonk, Feed Store, Gun Shop, Used Car, Beer, Bait, BBQ, Barber Shop, Laundromat\" at 36, \"Home Sweet Holiday Inn\" at 49, and finally \"The Good Life\" at 38.<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=469|isbn=0-89820-177-2}}</ref> A second album, ''[[A Little More Livin']]'', followed in 2006. Although its lead-off single \"On Again Tonight\" became his highest chart entry at 27, the follow-up \"So Am I\" peaked at 59, and Willmon exited Columbia's roster.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/>\n\nWillmon signed with [[Compadre Records]] in 2007. His third album, ''[[Broken In]]'', was released on February 26, 2008.<ref name=\"weekly\"/> The album produced three singles in \"There Is a God\", the title track, and \"Cold Beer and a Fishing Pole\", though none of these entered the charts. In early 2008, he also made his acting debut in the film ''Palo Pinto Gold'', a cowboy film also starring [[Roy Clark]] and [[Mel Tillis]].<ref name=\"weekly\">{{cite journal |last=Neal |first=Chris |author2=Larry Holden  |date=January 14, 2008 |title=The Scoop: Trent Goes to the Movies |journal=[[Country Weekly]] |volume=15 |issue=1 |pages=14 }}</ref><!--Country Weekly post-dates its issues--> Willmon also co-wrote [[Montgomery Gentry]]'s 2009 single \"[[Back When I Knew It All (song)|Back When I Knew It All]]\" and [[Steel Magnolia]]'s 2010 single \"[[Keep On Lovin' You]]\".\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|+List of studio albums, with selected details and peak chart positions\n! ''Little Ol' Cafe''\n| \n* Release date: October 6, 2010\n* Label: Feed Store Records\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"10\" style=\"font-size:85%\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|+List of singles, with selected peak chart positions\n!scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\"|Year\n!scope=\"col\" Honky-Tonk, Feed Store, Gun Shop,<br />Used Car, Beer, Bait, BBQ, Barber Shop, Laundromat]]\"\n| align=\"center\"| 36\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2005\n| \"Home Sweet Holiday Inn\"\n| align=\"center\"| 49\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| \"Population 81\"\n| align=\"center\"| 38\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2006\n| \"[[On Again Tonight]]\"\n| Beer and a Fishin' Pole\"\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable\" border=\"1\"\n|+List of music videos\n! scope=\"col\"| Year\n! Gilley's\"\n| Texas Roadhouse Live\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Willmon, Trent}}\n[[Category:1973 births]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Columbia Records artists]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Amarillo, Texas]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Texas]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Texas]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Sammy_Kershaw","to":"Sammy Kershaw"}],"pages":{"1745440":{"pageid":1745440,"ns":0,"title":"Sammy Kershaw","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{use mdy dates|date=March 2024}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Sammy Kershaw\n| image            = Sammy Kershaw 2018.jpg\n| caption          = Kershaw in 2018\n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = Samuel Paul Cashat<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/544263565/ | title=Sandwich Fair full of fun | work=The Times-Press | date=September 9, 1999 |access-date=February 25, 2024 | pages=9}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/445904672/ | title=February birthdays | work=The Kaplan Journal |date=February 1, 1962 |access-date=February 25, 2024 | pages=2}}</ref>\n| birth_date       = {{Birth date and age|1958|02|24}}<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p5966|pure_url=yes}} |title=Sammy Kershaw biography |access-date=2008-10-03 |last=Huey |first=Steve |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>\n| birth_place      = [[Kaplan, Louisiana]], U.S.\n| origin           = \n| instrument       = [[Singing|Vocals]]<br />[[Guitar]]\n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]]\n| years_active     = 1986\u2013present\n| label            = Master-Trak, [[Mercury Records|Mercury]], [[Audium Entertainment|Audium/Koch]], [[Category 5 Records|Category 5]], Boomerville, Big Hit, Cleopatra\n| spouse = {{Marriage|[[Lorrie Morgan]]|2001|2007|end=div}}\n| website          = {{URL|http://www.sammykershaw.com/}}\n}}\n'''Samuel Paul Cashat''' (born February 24, 1958), known professionally as '''Sammy Kershaw''', is an American [[country music]] artist. He has released 16 studio albums, with three RIAA platinum certifications and two gold certifications among them. More than 25 singles have entered the Top 40 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, including his only number one hit \"[[She Don't Know She's Beautiful]]\" and 10 more Top 10 hits: \"[[Cadillac Style]]\", \"[[Anywhere but Here (song)|Anywhere but Here]]\", \"[[Haunted Heart (Sammy Kershaw song)|Haunted Heart]]\", \"[[Queen of My Double-Wide Trailer]]\", \"[[I Can't Reach Her Anymore]]\", \"[[National Working Woman's Holiday]]\", \"[[Third Rate Romance]]\", \"[[Meant to Be (Sammy Kershaw song)|Meant to Be]]\", \"[[Vidalia (song)|Vidalia]]\", and \"[[Love of My Life (Sammy Kershaw song)|Love of My Life]]\".\n\nKershaw tried to enter politics, running as a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] candidate for [[lieutenant governor of Louisiana]] in 2007 and 2010. In 2007 he finished third in the jungle primary, but Democrat [[Mitch Landrieu]] won strongly in the general election. In 2010 he carried more parishes than any other candidate, but placed third. He endorsed Republican [[Jay Dardenne]], Secretary of State, for the position, who won the general election.\n\n==Early life and career==\nSamuel Paul Cashat was born in the [[Acadiana]] town of [[Kaplan, Louisiana|Kaplan]], located in South Louisiana. He is the third cousin of singers [[Rusty and Doug|Rusty]] and [[Doug Kershaw]].<ref name=\"allmusic\" /> When he was 11, his grandfather gave him his first [[guitar]]. But his father died that year, so Sammy started to work a variety of day jobs while playing [[Roadhouse (facility)|roadhouse]]s at night to support his family. He began performing in Acadiana with Louisiana legend J.B. Pere. At the age of 12, Kershaw was playing in a variety of honky-tonks and beer joints, and when he was 14 he met [[George Jones]], his lifelong idol.<ref name=\"villages-news.com\">{{cite web|url=http://www.villages-news.com/sammy-kershaw-tells-tales-battling-booze-bankruptcy-lorrie-morgan |title=Sammy Kershaw tells tales of battling booze, bankruptcy and Lorrie Morgan |website=Villages-News.com|date=28 June 2016 |access-date=2016-08-25}}</ref> Subsequently, he opened shows for [[Ray Price (musician)|Ray Price]], [[Merle Haggard]], and [[George Jones]] while still barely into his teens. When the pressures of growing up fast took their toll in the form of a serious [[drug abuse|drug]] and [[alcohol (drug)|alcohol]] problem, he quit his bad habits in 1988. He took a break from the music world to work as a remodeling supervisor at [[Wal-Mart]].\n\n==Musical career==\nOne of Kershaw's demonstration tapes made its way to [[Mercury Records]], which released his debut album ''[[Don't Go Near the Water (album)|Don't Go Near the Water]]'' in 1991. This album was certified [[platinum album|platinum]] by the [[RIAA]], and it produced four hit singles. The lead-off, \"[[Cadillac Style]]\", went to No.&nbsp;3 in late 1991 and early 1992, followed by the [[Don't Go Near the Water (Sammy Kershaw song)|title track]] at No.&nbsp;12, \"[[Yard Sale (song)|Yard Sale]]\" at No.&nbsp;17, and \"[[Anywhere but Here (song)|Anywhere but Here]]\" at No.&nbsp;10. Kershaw was initially reluctant to release \"Cadillac Style\" because he felt that it was not suitable for his style; however, his co-producer, [[Buddy Cannon]], convinced him to give the song a chance. Kershaw's often [[honky-tonk]] material and singing voice led to critical comparisons to [[George Jones]], and he covered one of Jones's early singles, \"What Am I Worth\", on his debut as well.\n\nIn 1993, Kershaw received an initial nomination for the [[Academy of Country Music Award for New Male Artist of the Year|Academy of Country Music Award for New Male Vocalist of the Year]]. He was nominated alongside [[Billy Ray Cyrus]], [[Tracy Lawrence]], [[Chris LeDoux]] and [[Collin Raye]]; Cyrus, Lawrence and Raye would make the final three.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.worldradiohistory.com/Archive-All-Music/Cash-Box/90s/1993/CB-1993-02-13.pdf|title=ACM Announces Nominations|magazine=[[Cashbox (magazine)|Cashbox]]|pages=21|date=February 13, 1993}}</ref>\n\nKershaw's second album, ''[[Haunted Heart (Sammy Kershaw album)|Haunted Heart]]'', followed in 1993. Its lead-off single, \"[[She Don't Know She's Beautiful]]\", became his only Number One hit, in April of that year. Following it were the [[Haunted Heart (Sammy Kershaw song)|title track]], the [[Dennis Linde]]\u2013penned \"[[Queen of My Double-Wide Trailer]]\", and \"[[I Can't Reach Her Anymore]]\", all of which hit the Top 10 as well. Although Kershaw had been told by others that radio audiences might not identify with the subject matter on \"Queen of My Double-Wide Trailer\", Kershaw wanted to release the song because he had an experience similar to its story line. Like his debut, ''Haunted Heart'' was a platinum album.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> In mid-1994, Kershaw also covered the [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]] song \"[[I Know a Little]]\" on the tribute album ''[[Skynyrd Frynds]]'', which included country music covers of Skynyrd songs. Also in 1994, Kershaw contributed the song \"[[Fire and Rain (song)|Fire and Rain]]\" to the [[AIDS]] benefit album ''[[Red Hot + Country]]'', produced by the [[Red Hot Organization]].\n\n''[[Feelin' Good Train]]'' was Kershaw's third album, released later in 1994. This album also produced four hits, including two consecutive No.&nbsp;2's in \"[[National Working Woman's Holiday]]\" and \"[[Third Rate Romance]]\" (the latter a cover of the [[Amazing Rhythm Aces]] hit from 1975),<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> with the No.&nbsp;27 \"[[Southbound (Mac McAnally song)|Southbound]]\" and No.&nbsp;18 \"[[If You're Gonna Walk, I'm Gonna Crawl]]\" following in 1995. The album included a duet with George Jones on \"Never Bit a Bullet Like This\", which had previously been released on Jones's 1993 album ''[[High-Tech Redneck]]''. ''Feelin' Good Train'' was certified gold. It was followed by a Christmas album, ''[[Christmas Time's A-Comin' (album)|Christmas Time's A-Comin']]'', and Kershaw's first greatest-hits package, ''Greatest Hits, Volume 1'', both in 1995. The latter produced a No.&nbsp;47 single in \"Your Tattoo\" (written by [[Kostas Lazarides|Kostas]] and [[Jack Tempchin]]), the first single of Kershaw's career not to reach the Top 40.\n\n===Mid-late 1990s===\nKershaw's fourth studio album, the gold-certified ''[[Politics, Religion and Her]]'', was issued in 1996. It produced Top 10 hits in \"[[Meant to Be (Sammy Kershaw song)|Meant to Be]]\" and \"[[Vidalia (song)|Vidalia]]\", the latter of which Kershaw also considered a risky song, saying, \"If radio will play this one more than twice\u2014so people can get the story and learn what a [[Vidalia onion]] is\u2014it'll be a smash.\" These songs were followed by \"[[Fit to Be Tied Down (Sammy Kershaw song)|Fit to Be Tied Down]]\" and the [[Politics, Religion and Her (song)|title track]], both of which hit the Top 30. Also included on ''Politics, Religion and Her'' were covers of [[Chuck Berry]]'s \"[[Memphis, Tennessee (song)|Memphis, Tennessee]]\" and [[Sammy Johns]]' \"[[Chevy Van (song)|Chevy Van]]\". The same year, Kershaw briefly took ownership of a [[NASCAR]] Busch series team (now Xfinity Series).\n\n''[[Labor of Love (Sammy Kershaw album)|Labor of Love]]'' was issued later in 1997 as his fifth album. Unlike his previous albums, this one was predominantly composed of ballads.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> It produced a No.&nbsp;2 (and final US Top 10 hit) in \"[[Love of My Life (Sammy Kershaw song)|Love of My Life]]\", and although none of the other three singles (\"[[Matches (Sammy Kershaw song)|Matches]]\", \"[[Honky Tonk America]]\" and \"[[One Day Left to Live]]\") reached higher than No.&nbsp;22, the album was nonetheless certified platinum. His next album, ''[[Maybe Not Tonight]]'', brought a Top 20 duet with [[Lorrie Morgan]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nKershaw stated that he enjoyed working with Morgan on the song, telling ''[[Country Weekly]]'' magazine, \"I knew our vocals would match up\u2026 Plus, we have fun together. We're friends and we have been friends for a long time.\" \"[[Maybe Not Tonight (song)|Maybe Not Tonight]]\" was commercially less successful than its predecessors, however, and it became the first album of Kershaw's career not to achieve an RIAA certification. Following \"Maybe Not Tonight\" were the singles \"[[When You Love Someone (Sammy Kershaw song)|When You Love Someone]]\" and \"[[Me and Maxine]]\", both of which peaked in the thirties. \"[[Louisiana Hot Sauce]]\", the final release from ''[[Maybe Not Tonight]]'', was also the first single of his career not to enter the charts.\n\nIn 2000, Kershaw released an album of [[cover song]]s, ''[[Covers the Hits]]''. This album comprised 10 cover songs that Kershaw had recorded in his career. Some of the songs on it, such as the single \"Third Rate Romance\", were previously found on Kershaw's studio albums, while others came from various tribute albums (such as ''Skynyrd Frynds'') to which he had contributed. ''Covers the Hits'' also included a rendition of [[Dr. Hook]]'s \"Little Bit More\", a previously unreleased cover which Kershaw had recorded during the sessions for ''Labor of Love''.\n\n===2000s===\nBy 2001, Kershaw and Morgan had married. The two recorded a vocal duet album in 2001 entitled ''[[I Finally Found Someone (Lorrie Morgan and Sammy Kershaw album)|I Finally Found Someone]]'' (the [[I Finally Found Someone|title track]] being a cover of the [[Barbra Streisand]]/[[Bryan Adams]] duet). This album was less successful commercially, with its only Top 40 hit being the No. 39 \"He Drinks Tequila\". Shortly afterward, a second 'greatest hits' package was released, and Kershaw left Mercury's roster.\n\nIn 2003, Kershaw signed to [[Audium Entertainment]] to release the album ''[[I Want My Money Back]]''.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> This album produced a No. 33-peaking in its [[I Want My Money Back (song)|title track]], but the second single \"I've Never Been Anywhere\" fell short of the Top 40. The third and final single, \"Beer, Bait & Ammo\" (which failed to chart), was previously recorded and written by [[Kevin Fowler]] on his 2000 debut album [[Beer, Bait & Ammo|of the same name]], and would later be recorded by [[Mark Chesnutt]] on his 2004 album ''[[Savin' the Honky Tonk]]''.\n\nAfter Audium closed its Nashville division, Kershaw signed to [[Category 5 Records]], then a newly established independent label, in 2006. His first release for the label and first chart single in three years, \"Tennessee Girl\", fell three spaces short of the Top 40 that year. It was the first release from his 2006 album ''[[Honky Tonk Boots]]''. The album's only other single, a cover of [[Mel McDaniel]]'s Number One hit \"[[Baby's Got Her Blue Jeans On]]\", failed to chart, and financial difficulties caused the label to close in 2007.\n\nIn 2008, Sammy Kershaw was inducted into The [[Louisiana Music Hall of Fame]] in honor of his career achievements and was also inducted into the Louisiana Songwriters Association Hall Of Fame in 2010.\n\nKershaw's first single in two years, \"[[Real People (song)|Real People]]\", was released in late 2008 in the Boomerville/Big Hit label. However, the single failed to chart. His tenth studio album, ''[[Better Than I Used to Be]]'', was released on August 31, 2010.\n\n===Political activity===\nKershaw had become increasingly interested in politics. On June 13, 2007, he announced his candidacy for [[lieutenant governor]] of Louisiana in the October 20 [[jungle primary]]. The position was held by the incumbent [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], [[Mitch Landrieu]]. Kershaw also faced a second Republican candidate, [[Louisiana State Legislature|State Representative]] Gary Beard of [[Baton Rouge]], an [[engineer]] first elected to the State House in a 2001 [[special election]]. Kershaw finished second with 30 percent of the vote, but Landrieu won re-election with a majority on the first ballot.\n\nWatching his state embroiled in the [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill|Gulf Oil Spill]] in April 2010, Kershaw, a Lafayette resident, became the official spokesperson for Protect Our Coastline, a non-profit dedicated to providing relief to the fishermen and shrimpers affected most by the spill.\n\nOn August 28, 2010, Kershaw announced his second bid for lieutenant governor in the October 2 [[special election]] to replace Mitch Landrieu, who left office in May after being elected [[mayor]] of [[New Orleans]]. Kershaw's intraparty rivals included  state Republican chair Roger F. Villere Jr. of [[Metairie, Louisiana|Metairie]], [[St. Tammany Parish]] president Kevin Davis of [[Slidell, Louisiana|Slidell]], and Secretary of State [[Jay Dardenne]] of Baton Rouge. Kershaw polled 19 percent and carried 31 of the 64 parishes (more than any other candidate).<ref>{{cite news\n|url = http://www.bayoubuzz.com/buzz/latest-buzz/item/520-louisiana-lt-governors-race-dardenne-vs-fayard-is-gender-party-region-showdown\n|newspaper = BayouBuzz News\n|first = Christopher \n|last = Tidmore \n|title = Louisiana Lt. Governor's Race: Dardenne Vs. Fayard Is Gender, Party, Region Showdown  \n|date = 2010-10-11\n|access-date = 2010-10-17\n}} Tidmore argues that Kershaw attracted most of the [[Tea Party movement|Tea Party]] voters.</ref> But he finished third in overall votes behind Dardenne and [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] Caroline Fayard. Kershaw endorsed fellow Republican Dardenne in the [[runoff election]],<ref>{{cite news\n |first      = Ed\n |last       = Anderson\n |url        = http://www.nola.com/news/t-p/capital/index.ssf?/base/news-8/128651950998280.xml&coll=1\n |archive-url = https://archive.today/20130104074600/http://www.nola.com/news/t-p/capital/index.ssf?/base/news-8/128651950998280.xml&coll=1\n |url-status   = dead\n |archive-date = 2013-01-04\n |title      = Dardenne, Fayard garner ex-rivals' endorsements: Two left in race for lieutenant governor\n |newspaper  = Times-Picayune\n |issue      = Saint Tammany Edition\n |date       = 2010-10-08\n |page       = A3\n |access-date = 2010-10-08\n}}</ref> joining him at campaign events, and giving Dardenne a \"bear hug\" at his victory celebration.<ref>{{cite news\n |title      = Dardenne tops Fayard in lieutenant governor race: He rolls up big victory after intense campaign\n |first      = Ed\n |url        = http://www.nola.com/news/t-p/capital/index.ssf?/base/news-8/128876582934530.xml&coll=1\n |archive-url = https://archive.today/20130130092142/http://www.nola.com/news/t-p/capital/index.ssf?/base/news-8/128876582934530.xml&coll=1\n |url-status   = dead\n |archive-date = 2013-01-30\n |newspaper  = Times-Picayune\n |page       = A14\n |issue      = Metro Edition\n |date       = 2010-11-03\n |access-date = 2010-11-03\n |last       = Anderson\n}}</ref>\n{{Clear}}\n\nIn the 2011 race for lieutenant governor, Kershaw endorsed Dardenne's opponent, fellow Republican [[Billy Nungesser]].  Dardenne ultimately defeated Nungesser 53%-47%.<ref>[http://www.theadvertiser.com/article/20111023/NEWS01/110230338/In-brutalest-races-Dardenne-survives] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.today/20111025230724/http://www.theadvertiser.com/article/20111023/NEWS01/110230338/In-brutalest-races-Dardenne-survives|date=October 25, 2011}}</ref>\n\n===2010s and Beyond===\nKershaw continues touring throughout the year with his band, as well as performances with his often sold-out acoustic \"Roots and Boots\" tour, which has featured himself onstage with other artists including [[Aaron Tippin]], [[Joe Diffie]], [[Pam Tillis]], [[Darryl Worley]] and [[Collin Raye]]. \n[[File:Sammy Kershaw onstage, July 3, 2016 Norway, Michigan.jpg|thumb|Sammy Kershaw live in concert, with band members Steve Farmer (piano) and Robert Wright (bass guitar), Norway, Michigan - July 3, 2016]]\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Sammy Kershaw discography}}\n;Studio albums\n* ''[[Don't Go Near the Water (album)|Don't Go Near the Water]]'' (1991)\n* ''Business Is Pleasure'' (1992)\n* ''[[Haunted Heart (Sammy Kershaw album)|Haunted Heart]]'' (1993)\n* ''[[Feelin' Good Train]]'' (1994)\n* ''[[Christmas Time's A-Comin' (album)|Christmas Time's A-Comin']]'' (1994)\n* ''[[Politics, Religion and Her]]'' (1996)\n* ''[[Labor of Love (Sammy Kershaw album)|Labor of Love]]'' (1997)\n* Got Me'' (2016)\n* ''Swamp Poppin''' (2017)\n* ''Cross Road Blues'' (2024)\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n=== TNN/Music City News Country Awards ===\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n|[[27th TNN/Music City Boyd"}],"pages":{"44675141":{"pageid":44675141,"ns":0,"title":"Craig Wayne Boyd","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country singer and songwriter|bot=PearBOT 5}}\n{{BLP sources|date=December 2014}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Craig Wayne Boyd\n| image           = Craigwayneboyd.jpg\n| caption         = Craig Wayne Boyd in 2014\n| birth_name      = Craig Wayne Boyd<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.buddytv.com/info/craig-wayne-boyd-info.aspx |title=Craig Wayne Boyd Biography |publisher=Buddytv.com |access-date=2015-08-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924041607/http://www.buddytv.com/info/craig-wayne-boyd-info.aspx |archive-date=2015-09-24 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = {{Birth date and age|1978|12|31}}<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/style-blog/wp/2014/12/17/the-voice-finale-why-craig-wayne-boyd-was-never-an-underdog/|title=\u2018The Voice\u2019 finale: Why Craig Wayne Boyd was never an underdog|last=Yahr|first=Emily|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=December 17, 2014|access-date=December 17, 2014}}</ref><ref name=\"birthdate\">{{cite web|last=Carter|first=Brooke|url=https://gazettereview.com/2017/03/happened-craig-wayne-boyd-news-updates/|title=What Happened to Craig Wayne Boyd \u2013 Now in 2018|work=Gazette Review|date=March 23, 2017|access-date=April 29, 2019}}</ref>\n| birth_place     = [[Mesquite, Texas|Mesquite]], Texas, United States\n| origin          =\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar\n| genre           = {{Flat list|\n* [[Country music|Country]]\n* [[country rock]]}}\n| occupation      = Singer\n| years_active    = 2004\u2013present\n| label           = {{Flat list |\n* [[Dot Records|Dot]]\n* [[Universal Republic Records|Universal Republic]]\n}}\n| associated_acts = [[Blake Shelton]]\n| website         = http://www.craigwayneboyd.com/\n}}\n'''Craig Wayne Boyd''' (born December 31, 1978)<ref name=\"birthdate\"/> is an American [[Country music|country]] singer and songwriter. A native of [[Dallas]], Texas, Boyd is based in and resides in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], Tennessee. He is best known for winning [[The Voice (American TV series) season 7|Season 7]] of [[NBC]]'s reality TV singing competition ''[[The Voice (American TV series)|The Voice]]'' as a part of [[Blake Shelton]]'s team.\n\n==Early life==\nBoyd was born on December 31, 1978, and raised in the Dallas suburb of [[Mesquite, Texas|Mesquite]].<ref name=\"birthdate\"/> He grew up influenced by gospel and country music. He played many instruments in his youth. He was also his church's choir director.\n\n==Career==\n===Early years===\nBoyd moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] at the age of 25 in 2004 to pursue a career in [[country music]]. Boyd was signed to a publishing deal with EMI. He spent many years songwriting. Boyd began touring, opening for acts such as [[Jamey Johnson]], [[Randy Houser]], and [[Brantley Gilbert]].\n\n===''The Voice'' (2014)===\nOn Sept. 30, 2014, Boyd debuted on [[The Voice (American TV series) season 7|7th season]] of ''[[The Voice (American TV series)|The Voice]]''. During his Blind Audition, Boyd sang \"[[The Whiskey Ain't Workin']]\" by [[Travis Tritt]] and [[Marty Stuart]].  Two coaches ([[Blake Shelton]] and [[Pharrell Williams]]) turned around. Boyd chose [[Blake Shelton]] as his coach.  During the Battle Rounds, Boyd was paired with James David Carter to sing \"[[Wave on Wave (song)|Wave on Wave]]\" by [[Pat Green]].  Coach Shelton chose Carter over Boyd, but Boyd was stolen by Coach [[Gwen Stefani]].  In the Knockout Rounds, Boyd was paired with [[Anita Antoinette]].  Boyd sang \"[[Can't You See (The Marshall Tucker Band song)|Can't You See]]\" by [[The Marshall Tucker Band]].  Boyd lost the round, but was stolen back by Coach Shelton and advanced to the Live Playoffs.  During the Live Playoffs, Boyd sang \"[[Some Kind of Wonderful (Soul Brothers Six song)|Some Kind of Wonderful]]\" and was saved by the Public's votes to advance to the Top 12.\nFor the week of the Top 12, Boyd performed \"[[You Look So Good in Love]]\" by [[George Strait]]. Boyd was saved by the public's votes.\nFor the week of the Top 10, Boyd performed \"[[I Walk the Line]]\" by [[Johnny Cash]]. Boyd was saved by the public vote with his performance in the Top 10 of the iTunes Chart.\nFor the week of the Top Eight, Boyd performed \"[[Take It Easy]]\" by the [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]]. Boyd was saved by the public vote and advanced to the Top Five.\nFor the week of the Semi-finals, Coach Shelton picked \"[[Workin' Man Blues]]\" by [[Merle Haggard]] for Boyd to sing and Boyd also sang \"[[The Old Rugged Cross]]\" which was in the iTunes Top 10. Boyd advanced to the finals.\nFor the week of the Finals, Boyd performed three songs. He performed \"[[In Pictures (song)|In Pictures]]\" by [[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]] as his solo song. He performed \"[[Boots On]]\" by [[Randy Houser]] as a duet with his coach [[Blake Shelton]]. He also performed an original song called \"[[My Baby's Got a Smile on Her Face]]\". The song was written for Shelton, but he decided to give it to Boyd. The song is Boyd's debut single.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/craig-wayne-boyd-my-babys-got-a-smile-on-her-face/ |title=Craig Wayne Boyd, \u2018My Baby\u2019s Got a Smile on Her Face\u2019 |publisher=Tasteofcountry.com |access-date=2015-08-08}}</ref>\n\nBoyd was declared the winner on December 16, 2014, giving [[Blake Shelton]]'s team its fourth win out of the seven Seasons. He beat out [[Matt McAndrew]], [[Chris Jamison]], and Damien, all three of whom were from Team [[Adam Levine]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Ashley Lee |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/voice-season-7-winner-craig-758718 |title='The Voice' Season 7 Winner Craig Wayne Boyd Named: Recap |publisher=Hollywood Reporter |date=2014-12-16 |access-date=2015-08-08}}</ref>\n\nShortly after winning the show and signing with [[Universal Republic Records|Universal Republic]] and [[Dot Records]], Boyd played at the Grand Ole Opry and went on a 65 city tour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/the-voice-craig-wayne-boyd-grand-ole-opry-debut/ |title='The Voice' Winner Craig Wayne Boyd Set for Opry Debut |publisher=Tasteofcountry.com |access-date=2015-08-08}}</ref><ref name=\"postShowTour\">{{cite web | url=http://www.axs.com/craig-wayne-boyd-winner-of-the-voice-live-at-the-snoqualmie-casino-bal-40732 | title=Craig Wayne Boyd, winner of 'The Voice' live at the Snoqualmie Casino Ballroom | first=Sue | last=Gabel | date=February 14, 2015 | access-date=December 15, 2015 | website=axs.com }}</ref> In early May 2015, following 6 weeks of rumors, it was reported that Boyd parted ways with Dot. Boyd released one single under Dot records \"My Baby\u2019s Got A Smile On Her Face\", which debuted at No. 1 on the Billboard Hot Country Songs. His second single \"I'm Still Here\" was released to iTunes under his own imprint \u2013 Long Haul Records. The song peaked at No. 35 on the Billboard Digital charts.<ref name=\"DotDropped\">{{cite web | url=http://www.mjsbigblog.com/voice-7-winner-craig-wayne-boyd-no-longer-signed-to-dot-recordsbig-machine-label-group.htm | title=UPDATED: \u2018Voice\u2019 7 Winner Craig Wayne Boyd No Longer Signed To Dot Records/Big Machine Label Group | date=May 5, 2015 | first=Deb | last=B | access-date=December 15, 2015 | website=mjsbigblog.com}}</ref>\n\n:{{Color box|gold|border=darkgray}} \u2013 Studio version of performance reached the top 10 on iTunes\n{| class=\"wikitable\" style=\"text-align:center; font-size:90%; line-height:16px;\"\n|-\n! Haggard"}],"pages":{"169941":{"pageid":169941,"ns":0,"title":"Merle Haggard","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter (1937\u20132016)}}\n{{pp-move}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2016}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Merle Haggard\n| image            = Merle Haggard in 1971.jpg\n| caption          = Haggard performing live in 1971\n| birth_name       = Merle Ronald Haggard\n| birth_date       = {{birth date|1937|04|06|mf=yes}}\n| birth_place      = [[Oildale, California]], U.S.\n| death_date       = {{death date and age|2016|04|06|1937|04|06|mf=yes}}\n| death_place      = [[Palo Cedro, California]], U.S.\n| instrument       = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar|[[fiddle]]}}\n| genre            = {{flatlist|\n*[[Country music|Country]]\n*[[outlaw country]]\n*[[Bakersfield sound]]}}\n| occupation       = Singer, songwriter, musician\n| years_active     = 1961\u20132016 \n| label            = {{flatlist|\n*[[Capitol Records|Capitol]]\n*[[MCA Records|MCA]]\n*[[Epic Records|Epic]]\n*[[Curb Records|Curb]]\n*[[Anti- (record label)|ANTI-]]\n*[[Vanguard Records|Vanguard]]}}\n| past_member_of   = [[The Strangers (American band)|The Strangers]]\n| module             = {{Infobox person|embed=yes\n| spouse           = {{plainlist|\n* {{marriage|Leona Hobbs|1956|1964|reason=divorced}}\n* {{marriage|[[Bonnie Owens]]|1965|1978|reason=divorced}}\n* {{marriage|[[Leona Williams]]|1978|1983|reason=divorced}}\n* {{marriage|Debbie Parret|1985|1991|reason=divorced}}\n* {{marriage|Theresa Ann Lane|1993}}\n}}\n| children         = 6, including [[Marty Haggard|Marty]] and [[Noel Haggard]]\n| website          = {{URL|merlehaggard.com}}\n}}\n}}\n\n'''Merle Ronald Haggard''' (April 6, 1937 \u2013 April 6, 2016) was an American [[country music]] singer, songwriter, guitarist, and [[fiddle]]r.\n\nHaggard was born in [[Oildale, California]], toward the end of the [[Great Depression]]. His childhood was troubled after the death of his father, and he was incarcerated several times in his youth. After being released from [[San Quentin State Prison]] in 1960, he managed to turn his life around and launched a successful country music career. He gained popularity with his songs about the working class; these occasionally contained themes contrary to the anti\u2013[[Vietnam War]] sentiment of some popular music of the time. Between the 1960s and the 1980s he had 38 number-one hits on the US country charts, several of which also made the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' all-genre singles chart]]. Haggard continued to release successful albums into the 2000s.\n\nHe received many honors and awards for his music, including a [[Kennedy Center Honors|Kennedy Center Honor]] (2010); a [[Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award]] (2006); a [[BMI Awards|BMI Icon Award]] (2006);<ref name=bmiawards /> and induction into the [[Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame]] (1977);<ref name=nashvillehof>{{cite web|url=http://nashvillesongwritersfoundation.com.s164288.gridserver.com/Site/inductee?entry_id=2344|title=Merle Haggard|website=[[Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame]]|access-date=April 9, 2016|quote=Induction year: 1977|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150727055941/http://nashvillesongwritersfoundation.com.s164288.gridserver.com/Site/inductee?entry_id=2344|archive-date=July 27, 2015}}</ref> [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|Country Music Hall of Fame]] (1994)<ref name=countrymusichof>{{cite web|url=http://countrymusichalloffame.org/full-list-of-inductees/view/merle-haggard |title=Full List of Inductees |publisher=Country Music Hall of Fame |date=2010 |access-date=April 16, 2013 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130331231437/http://countrymusichalloffame.org/full-list-of-inductees/view/merle-haggard |archive-date=March 31, 2013}}</ref> and [[Oklahoma Music Hall of Fame]] (1997).<ref name=okmusichof>{{cite web|url=http://www.omhof.com/Inductees/tabid/56/ItemID/54/Default.aspx|title=Inductees|website=Oklahoma Music Hall of Fame|access-date=April 16, 2013|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130419195117/http://www.omhof.com/Inductees/tabid/56/ItemID/54/Default.aspx|archive-date=April 19, 2013}}</ref> He died on April 6, 2016\u2014his 79th birthday\u2014at his ranch in [[Shasta County, California]], having recently suffered from [[Classification of pneumonia#Double pneumonia (bilateral pneumonia)|double pneumonia]].<ref name=nytobit>{{cite news|last=Friskics-Warren|first=Bill|title=Merle Haggard, Country Music's Outlaw Hero, Dies at 79|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/07/arts/music/merle-haggard-country-musics-outlaw-hero-dies-at-79.html?_r=0|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=April 6, 2016|access-date=April 7, 2016}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\n{{external media | width = 210px | float = right | audio1 = [https://freshairarchive.org/segments/country-music-legend-merle-haggard-1 Country Music Legend Merle Haggard], interviewed by [[Terry Gross]] on ''[[Fresh Air]]'', 42:14, August 14, 1995.<ref name=\"Fresh Air\">{{cite interview |last=Haggard |first=Merle |interviewer=Terry Gross |title=Country Music Legend Merle Haggard |url=https://freshairarchive.org/segments/country-music-legend-merle-haggard-1 |work=[[Fresh Air]] |publisher=[[WHYY-FM|WHYY]] ([[NPR]]) |date=August 14, 1995 |access-date=September 15, 2019}}</ref>}}\n\nHaggard's parents were Flossie Mae (n\u00e9e Harp; 1902\u20131984) and James Francis Haggard (1899\u20131946).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://merlehaggard.com/bio|title=Haggard bio|publisher=Merlehaggard.com|access-date=June 2, 2015|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626141355/http://merlehaggard.com/bio|archive-date=June 26, 2015}}</ref> The family moved to California from their home in [[Checotah, Oklahoma]], during the Great Depression, after their barn burned in 1934.{{sfn|Cusic|2002|p=XVII}}\n\nThey settled with their two elder children, James 'Lowell' (1922\u20131996) and Lillian, in an apartment in [[Bakersfield, California|Bakersfield]], while James started working for the [[Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway|Santa Fe Railroad]]. A woman who owned a [[boxcar]] placed in [[Oildale, California|Oildale]], a nearby town, asked Haggard's father about the possibility of converting it into a house. He remodeled the boxcar, and soon after moved in, also purchasing the lot, where Merle Ronald Haggard was born on April 6, 1937.{{sfn|Witzel|Young-Witzel|2007|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=Oq80iaT38k4C&dq=lewell%20guitar%20merle&pg=PA130 130]}}{{sfn|Cusic|2002|p=XVIII}} The property was eventually expanded by building a bathroom, a second bedroom, a kitchen, and a breakfast nook in the adjacent lot.{{sfn|Witzel|Young-Witzel|2007|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=Oq80iaT38k4C&dq=lewell%20guitar%20merle&pg=PA130 130]}}\n\nIn 1946 Haggard's father died of a brain hemorrhage.{{sfn|Cusic|2002|p=XVIII}} Nine-year-old Haggard was deeply affected by the loss, and it remained a pivotal event to him for the rest of his life. To support the family, Haggard's mother took a job as a [[bookkeeping|bookkeeper]].{{sfn|Cusic|2002|p=XX}} Older brother Lowell gave his guitar to Merle when Merle was 12. Haggard learned to play it on his own,{{sfn|Witzel|Young-Witzel|2007|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=Oq80iaT38k4C&dq=lewell%20guitar%20merle&pg=PA130 130]}} with the records he had at home, influenced by [[Bob Wills]], [[Lefty Frizzell]], and [[Hank Williams]].<ref name=\"CMT\" /> While his mother was out working during the day Haggard started getting into trouble. She sent him to a juvenile detention center for a weekend to try to correct him, but his behavior did not improve. If anything, he became worse.{{sfn|Cusic|2002|p=XIX}}\n\nBy the age of 13, Haggard was stealing and writing bad checks.{{clarify|date=December 2021}} In 1950 he was caught shoplifting and sent to a juvenile detention center.<ref>{{cite AV media notes|title=Haggard's 40 #1 Hits|others=Merle Haggard|year=2004|type=CD|publisher=Capitol Records}}</ref> The following year he ran away to Texas with his friend Bob Teague.<ref name=\"CMT\">{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/merle-haggard/biography|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121223065051/http://www.cmt.com/artists/merle-haggard/biography|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 23, 2012|title=About Merle Haggard|work=Country Music Television|publisher=MTV Networks|access-date=April 5, 2013}}</ref> The two [[Freighthopping|rode freight trains]] and [[hitchhike]]d throughout the state.{{sfn|Aronowitz|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=CVUEAAAAMBAJ&dq=merle%20haggard%20bakersfield%20singing&pg=PA12 12]|1968}}{{sfn|Gleason|1988|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=DYcbla8ulxkC&dq=merle%20haggard%20potato%20truck&pg=PA34 34]}} When they returned later that year the two boys were accused of robbery and sent to jail. This time, they had not actually committed the crime, and were released when the real robbers were found. The experience did not change Haggard much. He was again sent to a juvenile detention center later that year, from which he and his friend escaped and headed to [[Modesto, California]]. There he worked a series of laborer jobs, including potato truck driver, short order cook, hay pitcher and [[oil well shooting|oil well shooter]].{{sfn|Aronowitz|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=CVUEAAAAMBAJ&dq=merle%20haggard%20bakersfield%20singing&pg=PA12 12]|1968}} His debut performance was with Teague in a Modesto bar named \"Fun Center\", for which he was paid US$5 and given free beer.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://m.facebook.com/merlehaggard?v=info&expand=1|title=Merle Haggard|publisher=M.facebook.com|date=April 6, 1937|access-date=June 2, 2015}}</ref>\n\nIn 1951 he returned to Bakersfield, where he was again arrested for [[truancy]] and [[petty larceny]] and sent to a juvenile detention center. After another escape, he was sent to the [[Preston School of Industry]], a high-security installation. He was released 15 months later but was sent back after beating a local boy during a burglary attempt. After Haggard's release, he and Teague saw Lefty Frizzell in concert. The two sat backstage, where Haggard began to sing along. Hearing the young man from the stage, Frizzell refused to go on unless Haggard was allowed to sing first. Haggard did, and was well received by the audience. After this experience Haggard decided to pursue a career in music. At night he would sing and play in local bars, while working as a farmhand or in the oil fields during the day.\n\nMarried and plagued by financial issues,<ref name=\"CMT\" /> in 1957 he tried to rob a Bakersfield [[Roadhouse (premises)|roadhouse]], was caught and arrested.{{sfn|Kingsbury|2004|p=223}} Convicted, he was sent to the Bakersfield Jail.{{sfn|Cusic|2002|p=XX}} After an escape attempt he was transferred to [[San Quentin Prison]] on February 21, 1958.{{sfn|Cusic|2002|p=XXI}} There he was prisoner number A45200.<ref>PBS America: Country Music: The Sons and Daughters of America (1964-1968)</ref> While in prison, Haggard learned that his wife was expecting another man's child, which stressed him psychologically. He was fired from a series of prison jobs, and planned to escape along with another inmate nicknamed \"Rabbit\" (James Kendrick<ref>[https://crimescribe.com/2018/11/03/on-this-day-in-1961-james-rabbit-kendrick-friend-of-merle-haggard/On This Day in 1961; James \u2018Rabbit\u2019 Kendrick, friend of Merle Haggard.] Crime Scribe.</ref>) but was dissuaded by fellow inmates.{{sfn|Hochman|p=462|1999}}\n\nWhile at San Quentin, Haggard started a gambling and brewing racket with his cellmate. After he was caught drunk, he was sent for a week to solitary confinement where he encountered [[Caryl Chessman]], an author and death-row inmate.{{sfn|Erlewine|Bogdanov|Woodstra|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=LdxCPLZAExsC&dq=gambling%20and%20brewing%20merle&pg=PA307 307]|2003}} Meanwhile, \"Rabbit\" had successfully escaped, only to shoot a police officer and be returned to San Quentin for execution.{{sfn|Hochman|p=462|1999}} Chessman's predicament, along with the execution of \"Rabbit\", inspired Haggard to change his life.{{sfn|Erlewine|Bogdanov|Woodstra|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=LdxCPLZAExsC&dq=gambling%20and%20brewing%20merle&pg=PA307 307]|2003}} He soon earned a high school equivalency diploma and kept a steady job in the prison's textile plant.{{sfn|Erlewine|Bogdanov|Woodstra|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=LdxCPLZAExsC&dq=gambling%20and%20brewing%20merle&pg=PA307 307]|2003}} He also played for the prison's country music band.<ref name=\"bio\">{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/merle-haggard-9542118|title=Merle Haggard biography|work=Biography Channel|publisher=A&E Networks|access-date=April 5, 2013}}</ref> He also attended a [[Johnny Cash]] concert at the prison in 1958. Cash sang his song \"[[Folsom Prison Blues]]\" (1956) and \"had a profound influence on the young inmate, who upon release set out on forging a career as a singer-songwriter\".<ref name=RS15/> Haggard was released from San Quentin on parole in 1960.<ref>{{cite web |title=A Look at San Quentin |url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0412/16/lkl.01.html |publisher=CNN |date=December 16, 2004 |access-date=April 6, 2016}}</ref>\n\nIn 1972, after Haggard had become an established country music star, then-California governor [[Ronald Reagan]] granted Haggard a full and unconditional [[pardon]] for his past crimes.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/pictures/merle-haggard-the-life-and-times-of-a-badass-legend-20091021/merle-haggard-1972-pardon-from-reagan-5730553 |title=Merle Haggard: The Life and Times of a Badass Legend|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=October 21, 2009|access-date=April 7, 2016}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\n===Early career===\n[[File:Merle Haggard Tally Records - Cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|Haggard in a 1961 publicity photo for Tally Records]]\nUpon his release from San Quentin in 1960, Haggard started digging ditches for his brother's electrical contracting company. Soon, he was performing again and later began recording with Tally Records. The [[Bakersfield sound]] was developing in the area as a reaction against the overproduced [[Nashville sound]].{{sfn|Cusic|2002|pp=XXIII\u2013XXVI}} Haggard's first record for Tally was \"Singing My Heart Out\" backed by \"Skid Row\"; it was not a success, and only 200 copies were pressed. In 1962, Haggard wound up performing at a [[Wynn Stewart]] show in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] and heard Wynn's \"Sing a Sad Song\". He asked for permission to record it, and the resulting single was a national hit in 1964. The following year, he had his first national top-10 record with \"[[(My Friends Are Gonna Be) Strangers]],\" written by [[Liz Anderson]], mother of country singer [[Lynn Anderson]], and his career was off and running.{{sfn|Cusic|2002|pp=XXVII\u2013XXVIII}} Haggard recalls having been talked into visiting Anderson\u2014a woman he did not know\u2014at her house to hear her sing some songs she had written. \"If there was anything I didn't wanna do, it was sit around some danged woman's house and listen to her cute little songs. But I went anyway. She was a pleasant enough lady, pretty, with a nice smile, but I was all set to be bored to death, even more so when she got out a whole bunch of songs and went over to an old pump organ.... There they were. My God, one hit right after another. There must have been four or five number one songs there....\"{{sfn|Haggard|Russell|1981}}\n\nIn 1967, Haggard recorded \"[[I'm a Lonesome Fugitive]]\" with [[The Strangers (American band)|the Strangers]], also written by Liz Anderson, with her husband Casey Anderson, which became his first number-one single.<ref name=RS15>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/12-most-badass-merle-haggard-prison-songs-20150406/im-a-lonesome-fugitive-20150406|title=12 Most Badass Merle Haggard Prison Songs|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=April 6, 2015|access-date=April 6, 2016}}</ref> When the Andersons presented the song to Haggard, they were unaware of his prison stretch.{{sfn|Cantwell|2013|p=103}} [[Bonnie Owens]], Haggard's backup singer and then-wife, is quoted by music journalist Daniel Cooper in the liner notes to the 1994 retrospective ''Down Every Road'': \"I guess I didn't realize how much the experience at San Quentin did to him, 'cause he never talked about it all that much ... I could tell he was in a dark mood ... and I said, 'Is everything okay?' And he said, 'I'm really scared.' And I said, 'Why?' And he said, 'Cause I'm afraid someday I'm gonna be out there ... and there's gonna be ... some prisoner ... in there the same time I was in, stand up\u2014and they're gonna be about the third row down\u2014and say, 'What do you think you're doing, 45200?'\" Cooper notes that the news had little effect on Haggard's career: \"It's unclear when or where Merle first acknowledged to the public that his prison songs were rooted in personal history, for to his credit, he doesn't seem to have made some big splash announcement. In a May 1967 profile in ''Music City News'', his prison record is never mentioned, but in July 1968, in the very same publication, it's spoken of as if it were common knowledge.\"<ref name=\"autogenerated1962\">{{Cite AV media notes |title=Down Every Road 1962\u20131994 |title-link=Down Every Road 1962\u20131994 |others=Merle Haggard |year=1996 |first=Cooper |last=Daniel |type=Liner notes |publisher=[[Capitol Records]] }}</ref>\n\nThe 1967 album ''Branded Man'' with [[The Strangers (American band)|the Strangers]] kicked off an artistically and commercially successful run for Haggard. In 2013, Haggard biographer David Cantwell stated, \"The immediate successors to ''I'm a Lonesome Fugitive''\u2014''Branded Man'' in 1967 and, in '68, ''[[Sing Me Back Home]]'' and ''[[The Legend of Bonnie and Clyde]]''\u2014were among the finest albums of their respective years.\"{{sfn|Cantwell|2013|p=125}} Haggard's new recordings showcased his band the Strangers, specifically [[Roy Nichols]]'s [[Telecaster]], [[Ralph Mooney]]'s [[steel guitar]], and the harmony vocals provided by [[Bonnie Owens]].\n\nAt the time of Haggard's first top-10 hit \"[[(My Friends Are Gonna Be) Strangers]]\" in 1965, Owens, who had been married to [[Buck Owens]], was known as a solo performer, a fixture on the [[Bakersfield, California|Bakersfield]] club scene and someone who had appeared on television. She won the new [[Academy of Country Music]]'s first ever award for Female Vocalist after her 1965 debut album, ''Don't Take Advantage of Me'', hit the top five on the country albums chart. However, Bonnie Owens had no further hit singles, and although she recorded six solo albums on Capitol between 1965 and 1970, she became mainly known for her background harmonies on Haggard hits such as \"[[Sing Me Back Home (song)|Sing Me Back Home]]\" and \"Branded Man\".<ref>{{Cite AV media notes|title=Queen of the Coast |year=2007 |url=http://www.dekedickerson.com/docs/DekeDickerson-BonnieOwens.doc |first=Deke |last=Dickerson |type=Liner notes |others=[[Bonnie Owens]] |publisher=Bear Family Records |location=Germany |url-status=bot: unknown |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160207091721/http://www.dekedickerson.com/docs/DekeDickerson-BonnieOwens.doc |archive-date=February 7, 2016 }}</ref>\n\nProducer Ken Nelson took a hands-off approach to produce Haggard. In the episode of ''[[American Masters]]'' dedicated to him, Haggard remembers: \"The producer I had at that time, Ken Nelson, was an exception to the rule. He called me 'Mr. Haggard' and I was a little twenty-four, twenty-five-year-old punk from Oildale... He gave me complete responsibility. I think if he'd jumped in and said, 'Oh, you can't do that,' it would've destroyed me.\"<ref name=AmericanMasters>{{Cite episode |title=Merle Haggard: Learning to Live With Myself|url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/americanmasters/merle-haggard-learning-to-live-with-myself/1545|access-date=April 7, 2016|series=American Masters|series-link=American Masters|first=Merle|last=Haggard|network=[[PBS]]|date=July 21, 2010}}</ref> In the documentary series ''Lost Highway'', Nelson recalls, \"When I first started recording Merle, I became so enamored with his singing that I would forget what else was going on, and I suddenly realized, 'Wait a minute, there's musicians here you've got to worry about!' But his songs\u2014he was a great writer.\"<ref>{{Cite episode|title=Beyond Nashville|series=Lost Highway: The History of American Country|first=Ken|last=Nelson|network=[[BBC]]|date=March 8, 2003|season=1|number=3}}</ref>\n\nTowards the end of the decade, Haggard composed several number-one hits, including \"[[Mama Tried (song)|Mama Tried]],\" \"The Legend of Bonnie and Clyde,\" \"Hungry Eyes,\" and \"Sing Me Back Home\".{{sfn|Cantwell|2013|p=125}} Daniel Cooper calls \"Sing Me Back Home\" \"a ballad that works on so many different levels of the soul it defies one's every attempt to analyze it\".<ref name=\"autogenerated1962\" /> In a 1977 interview in ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' with [[Bob Eubanks]], Haggard reflected, \"Even though the crime was brutal and the guy was an incorrigible criminal, it's a feeling you never forget when you see someone you know make that last walk. They bring him through the yard, and there's a guard in front and a guard behind\u2014that's how you know a death prisoner. They brought Rabbit out ... taking him to see the Father, ... prior to his execution. That was a strong picture that was left in my mind.\"  In 1969, Haggard's first tribute LP ''[[Same Train, A Different Time|Same Train, Different Time: A Tribute to Jimmie Rodgers]]'', was also released to acclaim.\n\nIn the 1969 ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' review for Haggard and the Strangers 1968 album ''Mama Tried'', [[Andy Wickham]] wrote, \"His songs romanticize the hardships and tragedies of America's transient proletarian and his success is resultant of his inherent ability to relate to his audience a commonplace experience with precisely the right emotional pitch.... Merle Haggard looks the part and sounds the part because he is the part.
